
<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/rdx/2018/">Acura RDX</a> carries over into the 2018 model year unchanged. The crossover will receive a redesign for 2019, built on a new platform and with a new turbocharged engine.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The RDX is currently <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/">Acura</a>’s smallest crossover slotting before the three-row MDX. Price-wise, the RDX starts above the ILX and TLX sedan. The smaller CDX crossover <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/report-acura-cdx-may-come-u-s/">might make its way to the U.S. in the next few years</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 RDX comes equipped with a 3.5-liter V-6 that produces 279 hp and 252 lb-ft of torque and is backed by a six-speed automatic. Front-wheel drive is standard with available all-wheel drive. The front-wheel drive model delivers an EPA-rated 19/27 mpg city/highway and 20/28 mpg with all-wheel drive. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the RDX AWD hit 60 mph in a quick 6.2 seconds.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/rdx/2018/">2018 Acura RDX</a> comes standard with a power liftgate, power moonroof, Jewel Eye LED headlights, leatherette-trimmed seats and interior trim, 10-way power driver’s seat, heated front seats, leather-wrapped shift knob and steering wheel, a 5.0-inch information display, and an audio interface with iPhone integration. Available features include sport seats with perforated leather, heated and ventilated front seats, a second display screen below the 8.0-inch navigation screen, ELS Studio premium audio system, Siri Eyes Free (but no Apple CarPlay or Android Auto), AcuraLink infotainment interface, and 3D view navigation.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 RDX was given the highest five-star rating for the crossover’s overall rating and is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick+ (the highest possible rating) for scoring the highest rating of Good in all five test evaluations (small overlap front, moderate overlap front, side, roof strength, and head restraints and seats) and the highest rating of Superior in the front crash prevention evaluation. The RDX was able to reduce the speed of a 12 mph collision by 11 mph and a 25 mph collision by 16 mph thanks to the available Collision Mitigation Braking system in AcuraWatch Plus package. The package also consists of adaptive cruise control, lane keep assist, and a color multi-information display in the instrument panel. Other driver assist safety features include a forward collision warning system, lane departure warning, blind spot alert, and rear-cross traffic alert.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/rdx/2016/2016-acura-rdx-awd-first-test-review/">First Test</a> review of the refreshed 2016 Acura RDX, we praised the crossover for its acceleration, large cargo capacity, fuel economy, and low base price with so many standard features. However, we weren’t crazy about the conservative exterior and interior styling. “The 2016 RDX won’t speak to everyone, but it offers enough interior space, power, and features to please most buyers,” we said.</p>

<p>After spending a year with our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/rdx/2013/2013-acura-rdx-awd-verdict/">long-term 2013 Acura RDX</a> (the current-gen crossover), we definitely enjoyed the crossover, but said, “Compared with the previous-generation RDX, basically everything in this 2013 version — styling, fuel economy, ride — is head and shoulders better. But there is still something missing — that deeper connection, that feeling of looking forward to driving it — in essence, a soul. The RDX does everything well, but there is nothing that wows you, nothing that excites you, nothing that makes you eager to go for a drive.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The RDX sports a respectable 8.1-inches of ground clearance and has up to 76.9 cubic feet of cargo room.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/nsx/2018/">2018 Acura NSX</a> is unchanged.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/nsx/2018/">Acura NSX</a> is a hybrid supercar and is the flagship vehicle of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/">Acura</a> brand. Unlike its rear-drive predecessor, the second-generation NSX is all-wheel drive.</p>

<p>Available only as a single trim, the 2018 NSX comes standard with a rear-view camera, magnetic dampers, keyless entry and start, full LED headlights, automatic climate control, perforated leather and Alcantara-trimmed sport seats, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, Bluetooth, an eight-speaker audio system, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, two USB ports, staggered 19-inch front and 2o-inch rear alloy wheels, and high-performance Brembo brakes.</p>

<p>Optional extras include track-oriented performance tires, an 8.0-inch multi-information display, a nine-speaker ELS premium audio system, front and rear parking sensors, and carbon fiber exterior bits such as the front spoiler, rear diffuser and side sills.</p>

<p>The 2018 Acura NSX is powered by a hybrid system that combines a 3.5-liter twin-turbo V-6, three electric motors, a lithium-ion battery, and a nine-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission for a combined output of 573 hp and 476 lb-ft of torque. EPA fuel economy ratings are 21/22 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p>The 2018 Acura NSX hasn’t been crash tested by the NHTSA and IIHS. There are no drive assistance features available on the 2018 NSX.</p>

<p>Behind the engine is a trunk that can hold 4.4 cubic feet of cargo.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/nsx/2017/2017-acura-nsx-first-drive-review/">2017 First Drive</a>, we said that with the help of the electric motors, the NSX accelerates smoothly and feels like a naturally aspirated vehicle. Despite its bold exterior styling, you can easily see out of the cabin but its infotainment system lacks a volume knob. Each drive mode is distinct from each other and in Track mode, the NSX comes alive. Steering, however, is numb and uncommunicative regardless of the mode you’re in.</p>

<p>The NSX won a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/nsx/2017/2017-acura-nsx-vs-nissan-gt-r/">2016 comparison test</a> against the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/gt-r/2018/">Nissan GT-R</a> because it had a more superior ride and handling balance, and its nine-speed dual-clutch transmission is more responsive.</p>

<p>The Acura NSX is manufactured in Marysville, Ohio at <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a>’s Performance Manufacturing Center.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/">Acura</a> redesigned the MDX’s dual-screen interface with more menus and command structures, featuring a new 7.0-inch capacitive touchscreen with a 30-percent faster response time. The infotainment system now comes standard with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Basque Red and San Marino Red are two new exterior colors.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The MDX is Acura’s flagship crossover and the automaker’s only three-row vehicle. The MDX also has the third highest starting price out of the entire lineup, below the flagship RLX sedan and the NSX supercar. Those who find the three-row MDX too big might also consider the two-row RDX.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/mdx/2018/">2018 Acura MDX</a> is powered by a 3.5-liter V-6 that produces 290 hp and 267 lb-ft of torque and comes paired to a nine-speed automatic transmission. The engine, with front-wheel drive, delivers an EPA-rated 20/27 mpg city/highway with the auto engine start/stop feature and 19/27 mpg without it. With all-wheel drive (AWD), the MDX delivers 19/26 mpg with auto start/stop and 18/26 mpg without it. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/mdx/2018/">Acura MDX</a> AWD hit 60 mph in 6.2 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a 121 feet, both respectable numbers for a three-row crossover.</p>

<p>The <strong>MDX Sport Hybrid</strong> comes standard with AWD and comes equipped with a hybrid powertrain consisting of a 3.0-liter V-6 mated to an electric motor for a total system output of 321 hp and 289 lb-ft of torque. The hybrid powertrain is backed by a seven-speed dual-clutch transmission and delivers an impressive 26/27 mpg.</p>

<p>The 2018 Acura MDX comes standard with Jewel Eye LED headlights, LED taillights, power moonroof, heated side-view mirrors with reverse gear tilt-down function, a leather trimmed interior, 10-way power driver’s seat, eight-way powered front passenger seat, heated front seats, sliding second-row seats with one-touch third-row access, tri-zone automatic climate control, leather-wrapped steering wheel with power tilt and telescoping, ambient interior lighting, Hidden Cargo Storage with Smart Lid, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and a 7.0-inch upper screen and 8.0-inch lower display screen.</p>

<p>Upgrade to the range-topping MDX with the Advance and Entertainment packages and your MDX will add perforated leather with contrast stitching and piping, heated and ventilated front seats, second-row heated captain’s chairs, second-row center console with sliding tray, a larger 9.0-inch center display screen, rear door sunshades, a 12-speaker surround sound audio system, heated steering wheel, two third-row USB ports, LED fog lights, Acura Navigation System with 3D View and HD traffic, and a 16.2-inch ultra-wide screen with split screen capability.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Acura MDX received the highest rating of five stars for the crossover’s overall safety rating from the NHSTA and is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick+ for receiving the highest rating of Good in all five crash tests and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention evaluation. The Superior rating was issued because the MDX properly warned the driver of a possible collision and avoided a 12 mph and 25 mph frontal collision thanks to the Collision Mitigation Braking System found the AcuraWatch suite of driver assist safety features standard on all MDX models. AcuraWatch also includes adaptive cruise control, lane keep assist, and a road departure mitigation system. Additional driver assist safety features include a blind spot information system, a surround view camera system, front and rear parking sensors, and rear cross-traffic alert.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/mdx/2017/2017-acura-mdx-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the refreshed 2017 Acura MDX, we had mixed feeling about the new grille but liked the strong acceleration and braking power. We were impressed by the fuel economy and the handling of the AWD model (SH-AWD), “It has a surprisingly nice chassis on winding roads and one of the better FWD-architecture platforms in terms of steering, balance, and grip,” we said. “Good power and response from the engine. It has a nicely measured demeanor when driven hard.”</p>

<p>The biggest complaint is the nine-speed automatic that is very jerky at low speeds and when driven hard and is slow to respond. “It has a very quiet cabin and little or no wind noise at 75 mph,” we said. “On [the highway], the MDX is much more comfortable than the Q7 was. I sense no gut jiggle.”</p>

<p>“By placing the hybrid powertrain in the center of the underbody, Acura lowered the center of gravity by 26mm, giving the MDX Sport Hybrid less body roll. This was noticeable during our drive in the windy roads outside of Seattle, where the three-row SUV handled the curves with confidence,” we said in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/mdx/2017/2017-acura-mdx-hybrid-first-drive-review-small-piece-nsx/">First Drive review</a> of the 2017 Acura MDX Sport Hybrid. The dual-clutch transmission shifts well, we liked the seven USB ports, and the easy to access third row (although it’s small for adults). We also liked the standard suite of driver assist features, AcuraWatch, and very comfortable and quiet ride. “With the addition of the new 2017 Acura MDX Sport Hybrid, the luxury brand is stepping up its game and trying to attract a younger generation looking for a capable and confident vehicle. The MDX hybrid’s quick torque delivery, good handling, and decent packaging set it apart without compromising any space.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The MDX Sport Hybrid’s electrified powertrain utilizes a port-injected (versus direct injection) 3.0-liter V-6 (<a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a>’s only 3.0-liter V-6) that produces 257 hp and 218 lb-ft of torque. However, thanks to the three electric motors, the powertrain makes more horsepower and torque than the non-hybrid MDX.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/tlx/2018/">Acura TLX</a> sedan gets updated styling and new standard and available features for the 2018 model year. New standard features include AcuraWatch active safety tech, as well as Apple CarPlay and Android Auto connectivity. Six-cylinder models are available with a new A-Spec trim featuring revised steering and suspension tuning, and 19-inch alloy wheels, lip spoiler, body kit, bigger dual-exhaust tips, and badging as well as a new steering wheel and sport seats.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/tlx/2018/2018-acura-tlx-first-look-review/">refreshed 2018 Acura TLX performance luxury sedan</a> sits between the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/ilx/2018/">Acura ILX</a> compact sport sedan and larger <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/rlx/2018/">Acura RLX</a> luxury flagship sedan in the premium Japanese automaker’s lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Power for the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/tlx/2018/">2018 Acura TLX</a> comes from either a 2.4-liter K24 I-4 making 206 hp and 182 lb-ft of torque mated to an eight-speed dual-clutch transmission or an optional 3.5-liter J35 V-6 making 290 hp and 267 lb-ft backed by a nine-speed automatic transmission. Both transmissions feature paddle shifters. Front-drive is standard with both engines and features Precision All-Wheel Steer (P-AWS), and the automaker’s Super Handling All-Wheel-Drive (SH-AWD) is available with the V-6 engine.</p>

<p>Four-cylinder models ride on restyled 17-inch wheels, six- cylinder models ride on 18-inch wheels, and V-6 A-Spec models feature 19-inch alloy wheels. All 2018 Acura TLX models feature LED headlights, and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto.</p>

<p>The V6 TLX with a Technology package gains new features including chrome side sill trim, new seats with contrast piping and stitching, and a driver’s seat with power thigh extension. The Advance package gains trapezoidal LED foglights, a multi-camera parking system, wireless charging pad, LED ambient lighting, heated steering wheel and heated rear seats, a rear spoiler, and power-folding side mirrors.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>All 2018 Acura TLX sedans feature standard AcuraWatch suite of active safety tech, which includes collision mitigation braking system, lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control with low-speed follow, and road departure mitigation.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors: </strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/ilx/2018/">2018 Acura ILX</a> gets a new Special Edition trim that comes with additional standard features including 18-inch alloy wheels, side sills, and a rear spoiler taken from the A-Spec package.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/ilx/2018/">Acura ILX</a> is a front-drive premium compact sedan that slots under the larger TLX.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/">Acura</a> ILX is powered by a 2.4-liter I-4 rated at 201 hp and 180 lb-ft of torque, and it comes paired exclusively to an eight-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 25/35 mpg city/highway. There’s 12.3 cubic feet of trunk space and it can be expanded via the folding rear seats.</p>

<p>Standard features include 17-inch alloy wheels, a rearview camera, dual-zone climate control, keyless entry/start, heated front seats, LED headlights, leatherette upholstery, a multi-information display, a 5.0-inch screen, and Bluetooth connectivity. Options include 18-inch alloy wheels, navigation, a larger 8.0-inch screen, leather upholstery, a moonroof, fog lights, and an ELS premium audio system. The A-Spec package adds a rear spoiler, side sills, red instrument lighting, aluminum pedals, suede inserts on the seats, fog lights, and unique 18-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 ILX a five-star overall safety score (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 ILX but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except the headlights test, where it received a Marginal rating (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the ILX received a Superior rating after it reduced the impact speed of a 12-mph collision by 11 mph and the impact speed of a 25-mpg crash by 15 mph (Superior is the highest score for front crash prevention).</p>

<p>Available as a its own package, AcuraWatch bundles together forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, and road departure mitigation. Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert are available as part of the Premium and Technology packages.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/ilx/2016/2016-acura-ilx-first-drive/">2016 First Drive</a>, we said that the 201-hp 2.4-liter I-4 offers plenty of power and the dual-clutch automatic fires off quick shifts to keep the car in its power band. The car’s steering is surprisingly well-calibrated and linear, making it easy to operate when driving through winding roads. Cabin noise levels are low thanks to the addition of noise cancelling tech in the car. However, the interior has minimal headroom as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/ilx/2016/2016-acura-ilx-a-spec-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>. The infotainment system, on other hand, has way too many buttons and can be finicky to use. Although it has folding rear seats, it only folds as a single piece, making it less practical than some of its rivals.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2.4-liter I-4 in the ILX first appeared in the larger TLX sedan.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The RLX has been refreshed for 2018 with <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/">Acura</a>’s new diamond pentagon grille, as well as a redesigned hood, wheels, LED taillights, dual exhaust finishers, and a gloss black rear diffuser. Inside, the RLX receives upgraded materials, redesigned seats featuring contrast piping and stitching, and a new Espresso interior color option. A new 10-speed automatic transmission backs the standard 3.5-liter V-6 (non-hybrid) and Brilliant Red Metallic and Majestic Black Pearl are new paint offerings.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The RLX is Acura’s flagship sedan, positioned above the ILX and TLX sedans. With the exception of the NSX hybrid supercar, the RLX is the automaker’s most expensive model, topping the three-row MDX crossover.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/rlx/2018/">2018 Acura RLX</a>’s standard 3.5-liter V-6 produces 310 hp and 272 lb-ft of torque and comes paired to the automaker’s new 10-speed automatic that routes power to an all-wheel-drive system. The 2017 model (with the outgoing six-speed automatic) delivered an EPA-rated 20/30 mpg city/highway; we expect the new 10-speed to deliver slightly better fuel economy. The range-topping <strong>Sport Hybrid model</strong> with Acura’s Super-Handling All-Wheel Drive utilizes a hybrid system similar to the NSX’s that includes the above 3.5-liter V-6 paired to an electric motor (47 hp) and backed by a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. Two additional rear electric motors (each 36 hp) power the rear wheels for a total system output of 377 hp and 341 lb-ft of torque. The 2017 model uses the same hybrid powertrain and returned 29/30 mpg; expect a similar figure for 2018.</p>

<p>Standard equipment on the base model will likely stay the same and include LED headlights, 19-inch alloy wheels, a Milano leather-trimmed interior, 12-way power front seats, a 7.0-inch multi-use display, an 8.0-inch multi-information display with navigation, and a 14-speaker ELS audio system. Standard equipment on the Sport Hybrid will include a surround view camera system, parking sensors, a Krell audio system, LED fog lights, remote engine start, ventilated and heated front seats, and heated rear seats and steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 RLX comes standard with a host of AcuraWatch driver assist safety features. New to AcuraWatch is Traffic Jam Assistant, a feature that works in conjunction with adaptive cruise control with Low-Speed Follow and works by keeping the sedan in its lane and will keep a set distance to the vehicle in front. AcuraWatch also includes the Collision Mitigation Braking system with automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning, forward collision warning, lane keep assist, and Road Departure Mitigation. The 2018 model has yet to be crash tested, but the 2017 model received the highest five-star rating from the NHTSA and was considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick by the IIHS.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/rlx/2014/2014-acura-rlx-first-test/">First Test review</a> of a 2014 model (before the 2018 restyle), we said: “Though the 2014 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/rlx/2018/">Acura RLX</a> offers an impressive set of features, buyers of $50,000-$60,000 cars often seek something more emotionally satisfying than a spacious interior and innocuous styling. That’s where the RLX Sport Hybrid SH-AWD — if it’s well-received — might help.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/rlx-hybrid/2014/2014-acura-rlx-sport-hybrid-sh-awd-first-drive/">First Drive review</a> of the 2014 RLX Sport Hybrid SH-AWD, we enjoyed the way the sedan drove: “This RLX dances like a much smaller sporty car. Driven in Sport mode, the DCT is willing to downshift and hold gear without driver prompting. The rack-assist electric power steering is accurate but we’d welcome more feedback. An Electric Servo Brake system yields a very stiff brake pedal that simultaneously helps mask the handover from initial regenerative to more powerful hydraulic braking.”</p>

<p>Overall, we liked the premium hybrid and said: “Super-conservative styling aside, a car with Sport Hybrid SH-AWD, an estimated 30 combined mpg with 377 hp, a nicely trimmed cabin with gaggles of technology, and brand firsts such as the DCT, electronic gear selector, head-up display, and variable accelerator-pedal effort is a natural fit.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The non-hybrid RLX handles better thanks to the standard Precision All-Wheel Steer (rear-wheel steering) system.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The Stelvio is an all-new model from <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/">Alfa Romeo</a> that shares the same platform and powertrains as the Giulia sedan.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The Stelvio is Alfa Romeo’s sole crossover with a starting price higher than the Giulia sedan but lower than the 4C sports car.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/stelvio/2018/">2018 Alfa Romeo Stelvio</a> and Stelvio Ti come standard with all-wheel drive and are powered by a 2.0-liter turbocharged engine that produces 280 hp and 306 lb-ft of torque and delivers an EPA-rated 22/28 mpg city/highway. The high-performance <strong>Quadrifoglio</strong> model utilizes a 505-hp, 443 lb-ft of torque 2.9-liter twin-turbo V-6 that routes power to an all-wheel-drive system. Both powertrains are backed by an eight-speed automatic. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the Stelvio Ti Sport hit 60 mph in a quick 5.4 seconds and the quarter-mile in 14.0 seconds at 97.3 mph.</p>

<p>The 2018 Stelvio comes standard with many features including HID projector headlights with LED daytime running lights, LED taillights, power folding and heated side view mirrors, an integrated rear spoiler, LED interior ambient lighting, dual-zone automatic climate control, a 7.0-inch color driver’s display, a 6.5-inch center display with a rotary controller, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, four USB ports, 10-way powered leather front seats, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, a power liftgate, automatic up/down on all windows, Alfa DNA Drive Mode Selector, Brembo four-piston front brakes with one-piston rear brakes, and 18-inch wheels.</p>

<p>Available features include black roof rails, genuine Light Walnut Wood trim, leather-wrapped upper door panels and instrument panel with accent stitching, an 8.8-inch widescreen center display with 3-D navigation and rotary controller, a 14-speaker Harman Kardon premium audio system, aluminum sport pedals, luxury leather seats with Cannelloni design, heated front seats and steering wheel, 110V auxiliary power outlet, hands free liftgate, trailer tow hitch, a mechanical limited-slip differential, an active suspension system, an 20-inch sport aluminum wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>Some of the driver assist safety features can be found in the Driver Assistance Static package (also available with front parking sensors), which includes blind-spot monitoring, Rear Cross Path detection, and auto-dimming exterior mirrors. The Driver Assistance Dynamic Plus package consists of Adaptive Cruise Control Plus with full-stop, Forward Collision Warning Plus (includes automatic emergency braking), Lane Departure Warning, and automatic high beams. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/stelvio/2018/">Alfa Romeo Stelvio</a> has yet to be crash tested, however, the 2018 Giulia (the sedan on which the crossover is based) is considered an IIHS 2017 Top Safety Pick+, the highest honor issued by the institution.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>“Although there are people haulers and people haulers that haul ass, none do the latter with such glamour as the Stelvio. Damn, this thing looks good. And I hate SUVs,” we said in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/stelvio/2018/2018-alfa-romeo-stelvio-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2018 Stelvio. We also loved the driving experience, “…I found the Stelvio to be a new contender for the best-handling SUV on the planet. Sure, <em>Motor Trend</em> recently <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/f-pace/2017/jaguar-f-pace-s-mercedes-amg-glc43-porsche-macan-gts-comparison/">tested top-end versions</a> of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/macan/2018/">Porsche Macan</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a> GLC, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/">Jaguar</a> F-Pace, which will scoot quicker, but if we’re looking at just base models, the Alfa could very well take the crown for most-fun-to-flog crossover.”</p>

<p>The crossover’s 5.4-second 0-60 time and 28 mpg highway are also impressive. However, we aren’t fans of the low-revving 2.0-liter turbo engine, red-lining at only 5,500 rpm. In a controlled panic stop, the Stelvio “dove to a quick stop without fuss” instead of triggering “an instant and uncomfortable <em>ka-dunk ka-dunk ka-dunk</em> from the ABS fighting for traction,” as in most vehicles (the Stelvio has standard Brembo brakes).</p>

<p>One drawback on the Stelvio is the lack of any kind of terrain driving modes for the all-wheel drive system in case the driver ventures off-road. We had a few complaints, “The engine drones a bit when cruising in the 2,500- to 2,800-rpm range. The navigation system cuts out all audio—rather than quieting it slightly—when it gives directions. The steering wheel requires manual tilt and telescoping adjustment rather than powered controls, which seems petty except that most luxury players offer it. The stop-start system is slow to react, and when it does, it’s with an unpleasant jolt (but it can be defeated, fortunately).” We concluded by saying, “But these are minor quibbles for a vehicle that is dynamically outstanding and does a good enough job of ergonomics and features while packaging it all in a beautiful wrapper.”</p>

<p>In our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/stelvio/2018/2018-alfa-romeo-stelvio-first-test-italian-bandwidth/">First Test review</a> of the 2018 Stelvio, we immediately called it the “sports cars of SUVs,” but it is a lot more than that. The Stelvio is the fastest four-cylinder SUV in its class and quicker than many V-6 (naturally aspirated or turbocharged) crossovers. Considering the starting price, it’s a speed-bargain. The Stelvio aces canyon roads as well thanks to its superb steering and transmission, “The Stelvio scythes through a canyon better than some legitimate sport sedans. It flows around curves like massage oil over bare flesh. The steering responds immediately and precisely as the body leans in like a star running back changing direction. Both the steering and the car feel light and delicate, dancing down the road with the slightest effort. The transmission is always in the right gear, and the engine is surprisingly linear in response. After every corner, you marvel at how fast the Stelvio was able to take it and resolved to take the next one even faster.”</p>

<p>The crossover is even comfortable for daily driving, “Left in ‘N’ mode, the Stelvio is more than happy to loaf gently through town. You have to try to make it spill your coffee. It’s as easy to drive in traffic or on a long highway commute as any luxury SUV.” During testing we experienced three electrical issues, worrying for a brand known for electrical problems. Also, the engine stop/start function is slow to restart the engine, the brakes have no feedback due to the brake-by-wire system, and the infotainment system got mixed reviews. “In that way, the Stelvio is everything we’ve come to expect from an Italian car. It’s shamelessly good-looking and drives with a passion normally reserved for expensive sports cars, but it’s got quirks you’re going to have to be willing to put up with.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>That Stelvio comes standard with a carbon fiber driveshaft, double wishbone front suspension, patented Alfa Link design with vertical rod link rear suspension, and Brembo four-piston front calipers clamping 13.0-inch rotors and single-piston rear calipers with 12.5-inch rotors.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>New options on the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/">Alfa Romeo</a> include a front fascia with carbon fiber vents and black leather seats with yellow accent stitching. We expect Alfa to refresh the 4C for the</p>

<p>Along with the Giulia sedan and Stelvio crossover, the mid-engine 4C sports car is part of Alfa Romeo’s three-car North American lineup.</p>

<p><strong>2018 4C Coupe</strong>: The 4C Coupe comes standard with 17-inch alloy wheels in the front with 18-inch wheels in the rear, Brembo four-piston front calipers with drilled rotors, a dual exhaust system with chrome tips, a sport-tuned suspension, an electronic rear differential, LED taillights, LED daytime running lights, bright aluminum pedals, a drive mode selector, an Alpine audio system with Bluetooth and USB and auxiliary ports, a 7.0-inch instrument panel driver’s display, four-way manual adjustable cloth sport seats, a flat-bottomed leather-wrapped steering wheel with paddle shifters, aluminum instrument panel bezel trim, a rear console lockable leather storage compartment, and an instrument cluster with a lateral-g acceleration meter, a turbo-boost pressure gauge, and an oil pressure gauge.</p>

<p><strong>2018 4C Spider</strong>: The Spider adds a black cloth convertible top, a carbon fiber windshield surround, a black halo (a large roll hoop behind the cabin) leather-wrapped dashboard and door panels, and black leather seats with red accent stitching.</p>

<p>The Coupe Track package (also available as the Spider Track package for the Spider) adds racing suspension with upgraded anti-roll bars, performance-tuned shock absorbers, a performance flat-bottom steering wheel with a microfiber insert, a carbon fiber rear spoiler, carbon fiber side view mirrors (Italian flag is optional), choice of leather seat color (black, red, Tobacco, or black with microfiber), and a choice of upgraded wheels. Individual optional features include an Akrapovic dual mode center-mounted exhaust system, a carbon fiber roof, satin side view mirrors, an upgraded Alpine audio system, and HID headlights.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/4c/2018/">2018 Alfa Romeo 4C</a> packs a 1.7-liter turbo-four engine that produces 237 hp and 258 lb-ft of torque and is backed a six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission that sends power to the rear wheels. The 4C delivers an EPA-rated 28/34 mpg city/highway, not bad for a sports car. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2015 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/4c/2018/">Alfa Romeo 4C</a> Coupe (same powertrain) hit 60 mph in a quick 4.2 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a very short 97 feet.</p>

<p>The Alfa 4C comes standard with hill-start assist, an individual tire-pressure monitoring system, driver’s knee airbag, side airbags, and optional rear parking sensors.</p>

<p>The 2018 4C offers 42.7 inches of legroom for both passengers and only 3.7 cubic feet of cargo space under the hatch, behind the engine.</p>

<p>Like many mid-engine sports cars, the 4C offers little in terms of technology but comes standard with a 7.0-inch instrument panel driver’s display and an Alpine audio system (an upgraded Alpine audio system is available) with Bluetooth and USB and auxiliary ports. Performance tech includes the Alfa Electronic Differential control system and the Alfa DNA Pro drive mode selector with Dynamic, Natural, All-weather, and Race modes.</p>

<p>During our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/4c/2015/2015-alfa-romeo-4c-launch-edition-track-package-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 2015 Alfa Romeo 4C Launch Edition with the Track package, we loved the coupe on the track and its impressive performance numbers but felt the cheap interior components, bad audio system, rough ride, and heavy manual steering are hard to live with, especially for a car that’s not cheap.</p>

<p>“While those are issues unacceptable in a $55,000 car, they’re just about inexcusable in a $69,545 car like our tester,” we wrote, “especially given how good the 4C’s competition, including the new Corvette Stingray and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/">Porsche</a> Cayman, is. That’s a lot of dough to throw at a car that would be borderline masochistic to drive every day. While an impressive performer, a treat on the track, and at home on glass-smooth surfaces, the Alfa 4C is ultimately tough to live with on a daily basis. Though the <em>Alfisti</em> will no doubt flock to it, I’m not convinced the buyers Alfa needs to give it a viable market in the U.S. will.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/4c/2015/2015-alfa-romeo-4c-spider-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2015 Alfa Romeo 4C Spider, we concluded our drive by saying, “Understand, the 4C is a sports car that will make you work a little, will have you feeling as though you’re woven into the very carbon-fiber fabric of the monocoque, and in the process, will mold a permanent grin on your face with its Olympian showcase of athletic ability. Want an Alfa Romeo with comfort and convenience? [Get the Giulia, Alfa’s]. But if what matters is a smile on your sunburned lips, this little Italian has your name on it.”</p>

<p>Watch the 2016 Alfa Romeo 4C compete in a Head2Head episode <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2016-alfa-romeo-4c-goes-head-2-head-unlikely-foe-wvideo/">here</a>.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Entering its second model year, the Giulia gains more standard features including chrome door speaker surrounds, 18-inch double Y-spoke aluminum wheels on the Ti model, and Forward Collision Warning Plus and a Harman Kardon premium audio system on the Quadrifoglio. New options now available on the base Giulia and Giulia Sport models include 18-inch Bright Turbine aluminum wheels, an 8.8-inch display with a free year of SiriusXM satellite radio, a Harman Kardon premium audio system, and a two-tone Black/Ice leather interior with Dark Gray accent stitching (also available with sport leather and on the Ti models).</p>

<p>The Ti Sport model is now available with 19-inch Bright five-hole aluminum wheels and 19-inch polished Y-spoke aluminum wheels and the Ti Lusso model now gets an optional light Walnut wood trim. All models now get Apple CarPlay and Android Auto available and the optional Cargo Convenience package. Additional new packages include the Driver Assistance Static with Front Park Sensors package for the base Giulia and Sport models and the Ti Sport Performance package for the Ti Sport model.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The Giulia is the Italian automaker’s only sedan in the U.S market and Alfa’s entry-level vehicle, slotting before the more expensive Stelvio crossover and 4C sports car.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The standard engine in the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/giulia/2018/">2018 Alfa Romeo Giulia</a> is a potent 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 that churns out 280 hp and 306 lb-ft of torque and comes with an EPA-rating of 24/33 mpg city/highway with the Q2 rear-wheel drive model and 23/31 mpg with the Q4 all-wheel drive model. The powerful 505-hp, 443-lb-ft of torque 2.9-liter twin-turbo V-6 is only available in the range-topping rear-wheel drive <strong>Quadrifoglio</strong> model and delivers 17/24 mpg. An eight-speed automatic backs both engines. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the Quadrifoglio hit 60 mph in an impressive 3.9 seconds and the standard 2.0-liter turbo engine with rear-wheel drive did it in a very quick 5.1 seconds.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/giulia/2018/">Alfa Romeo Giulia</a> comes standard with HID headlights with LED daytime running lights and static bending, LED taillights, power-folding and heated side-view mirrors, LED interior ambient lighting, automatic dual-zone climate control, a 7.0-inch driver’s display, a 6.5-inch center display with rotary controller, 3 USB ports, 10-way powered leather front seats, leather-wrapped steering wheel, automatic up/down for all windows, Alfa DNA drive mode selector, four-piston Brembo brakes painted in silver, and 10-spoke 17-inch wheels. Available features for the Giulia include genuine aluminum interior trim, an 8.8-inch widescreen display with 3-D navigation, a 14-speaker Harman Kardon premium audio system, aluminum sport pedals, 12-way powered heated luxury leather front seats with Cannelloni design, a heated steering wheel, steering column-mounted aluminum paddle shifter, Brembo six-piston front and four-piston rear performance brakes, red/yellow/black painted calipers, a mechanical limited-slip differential, an active suspension system, and an assortment of 19-inch wheels.</p>

<p>The Quadrifoglio model receives unique features like an active aero front splitter system, front carbon fiber spoiler, Quadrifoglio badging, quad exhaust tips with rear diffuser, a carbon fiber hood and roof, carbon fiber rear spoiler, carbon fiber interior trim, a 200-mph speedometer, leather and Alcantara ultra high-performance Sparco carbon fiber racing seats, leather and Alcantara-wrapped steering wheel with accent stitching and carbon fiber inserts, Alfa DNA Pro drive mode selector (with race mode), ultra high-performance Brembo carbon ceramic braking system, a torque vector differential, a two-mode performance exhaust system, Quadrifoglio-tuned active suspension, Pirelli PZero Corsa “AR” high-performance tires, and a selection of staggered 19×8.5 inch front, 19×10-inch rear wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/">Alfa Romeo</a> Giulia is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick+ from the IIHS, the institution’s highest honor. The Giulia earned that designation by receiving the highest rating of Good in all five crash test evaluations and received the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention test. That rating was achieved by properly warning the driver of a possible collision, for avoiding a 12 mph impact, and for reducing a 25 mph impact by 24 mph thanks to the Forward Collision Warning Plus driver assist safety feature. That tech is found in the Driver Assistance Dynamic Plus package, which also includes Adaptive Cruise Control Plus with full stop, Lane Departure Warning, and automatic high-beams. The Driver Assistance Static package includes blind-spot monitoring, Rear Cross Path detection, and auto-dimming exterior mirrors.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/giulia/2017/alfa-romeo-giulia-bmw-330i-audi-a4-mercedes-benz-c300-cadillac-ats-jaguar-xe-lexus-is-200t-volvo-s60-comparison/">Big Test</a> comparison of eight premium sedans, the Giulia came out on top. We were impressed with its incredible handling and comfortable ride, fast acceleration, good Real MPG fuel economy numbers, and value. We had issues with the interior, although styling, there were too many cheap aspects and poor ergonomics. In conclusion, we said, “Efficient, economical, quick, safe, and without question the most fun to drive, the Giulia is a car we’re willing to gamble on despite its reliability legacy and lack of cost-of -ownership data.” “Its incredible performance and driving experience make it the easy choice for us. We’re willing to look past the reliability question marks to experience the passion this Italian delight delivers. Without question, if it were our money, this would be the car we’d pick.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/giulia/2017/2017-alfa-romeo-giulia-quadrifoglio-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 Alfa Romeo Giulia 2.0, we liked the sedan’s very quick acceleration, transmission, and throttle blips when the driver downshifts with the large aluminum shift paddles. We also loved the way the car drove, “Head out on a twisty road, and dial up Dynamic mode from the DNA selector, and from the first twirl of the smaller-than-usual steering wheel, you’ll enjoy the quick turn-in and feedback through the steering wheel rim. This reinforces the impression made by the eager engine’s snarl and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ferrari/">Ferrari</a> lookalike steering wheel–mounted start button that this is a car that encourages aggressive driving.”</p>

<p>Unfortunately, the stability control system cannot be turned off, hurting the Giulia’s at-the-limit handling numbers. Regardless, we said, “Plying real-world roads with all systems engaged, few drivers reported any stability meddling, and nearly everyone who thrashed the Giulia agreed that its neutral balance and poise make it the best-driving sedan in the class.” Ride quality was also spot-on, “Several also praised its ride quality as approaching that of class leaders such as the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/c-class/">Mercedes-Benz C-Class</a>.” We felt the infotainment system was fine but needs some work. The interior was stylish but not first-class, “Interior styling meets Italian expectations and complements the gorgeous exterior, but some knocked the red leather for seeming a bit too pleathery. Others criticized the graining and gloss of some plastic bits.”</p>

<p>“So if not a slam dunk on space, comfort, and ergo-quirkiness, at least it’s darned competitive.” We concluded with questioning its unknown reliability, “It’s that third item that nobody can assess yet. This car behaved perfectly for two weeks but for an errant car alarm incident. Alfa Romeo as a company ranked near the bottom of J.D. Power’s 2016 Dependability Study for the U.K., reporting 235 problems per car—just behind <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/">BMW</a> (196), Jag (173), and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a> (169). But this is an all-new car. A fresh start? Nobody knows.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Giulia’s 2.0-liter turbo engine is direct injection, uses the automaker’s MultiAir 2 valve technology, is SOHC (unlike the usual DOHC), uses a direct-mount twin-scroll turbocharger with an electronic wastegate, and has an indicated red line of only 5,500 rpm with a max engine speed of 6,200 rpm.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/aston-martin/vanquish/2018/">Aston Martin Vanquish</a> has been reduced to a single model, the Vanquish S, which features a revised suspension setup, an updated transmission, a new carbon fiber front splitter and rear diffuser, and extra power thanks to larger inlet manifolds and a quad exhaust system.</p>

<p><strong>Trim Levels (Interior and Exterior Options)</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/aston-martin/">Aston Martin</a> Vanquish is a rear-drive luxury grand tourer that’s available as a coupe or a convertible. The car slots above the new DB11 and is available in a two-seat or a 2+2 configuration. Convertible variants come exclusively in a 2+2 configuration.</p>

<p>Standard features on the Vanquish S include 20-inch alloy wheels, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, power operated front seats, front and rear parking sensors, heated front seats, a rearview camera, a 6.5-inch screen, navigation, Bluetooth, a 13-speaker Bang &amp; Olufsen premium audio system, and a USB port.</p>

<p><strong>Performance and Fuel Economy</strong></p>

<p>All 2018 Vanquish models come with a 5.9-liter V-12 with 580 hp and 465 lb-ft of torque paired to an eight-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy is rated at 13/21 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Active driver assistance features aren’t available on the 2018 Vanquish.</p>

<p><strong>Utility</strong></p>

<p>Trunk space on the 2018 Vanquish is 13 cubic feet.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/aston-martin/vanquish/2018/2018-aston-martin-vanquish-s-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive</a>, we were impressed with the Vanquish S’ performance. The car’s high-revving V-12 engine revs smoothly and sounds epic doing it while the new eight-speed automatic transmission’s shifts are quick yet smooth and crisp. Handling, on the other hand, is excellent thanks to its retuned suspension and minimal body roll. Despite its agility, the Vanquish S rides comfortably and never gets harsh even in Sport mode. As with older generation Aston Martin vehicles, however, the Vanquish S has an outdated multimedia system and a small screen by today’s standards.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Alongside the Rapide S, the Aston Martin Vanquish was one of the first vehicles in Aston’s lineup to receive the eight-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/aston-martin/db11/2018/">Aston Martin DB11</a> gets a 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 that now serves as the base engine. All models now come standard with a hands-free power-operated trunk lid.</p>

<p><strong>Trim Levels (Interior and Exterior Options)</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/aston-martin/">Aston Martin</a> DB11 is a high-end luxury grand tourer that’s available in coupe or convertible body styles.</p>

<p>All models comes standard with an Alcantara headliner, monotone leather upholstery, heated front seats, a 360-degree camera system, keyless entry and start, a 400-watt audio system, an 8.0-inch screen, a USB port, 20-inch alloy wheels, and Bluetooth.</p>

<p>Options include ventilated front seats, perforated leather upholstery, a glass key, a Bang &amp; Olufsen premium audio system, an automatic parking system, 20-inch alloy wheels in Shadow Chrome, Silver, or Gloss Black finish, and Brogue interior detailing.</p>

<p><strong>Performance and Fuel Economy</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 DB11 comes standard with a 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 with 503 hp and 513 lb-ft of torque. A 5.2-liter twin-turbo V-12 with 600 hp and 516 lb-ft is optional. Both engines come exclusively with an eight-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the 2018 DB11 haven’t been released yet. We don’t expect the V-12 model to change much from the previous model year, which is 15/21 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/aston-martin/db11/2017/2017-aston-martin-db11-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we enjoyed the V-12-powered DB11  with its excellent steering, great handling and punchy engine. However, its no track car and is best experienced as a grand tourer that’s fun to drive and features an interior that’s beautifully appointed.</p>

<p>The less powerful DB11 V-8 is just as impressive and offers even better steering response, lighter weight, and superior weight distribution, making it more engaging to drive. On the road it’s more composed than the DB11 V-12 and it’s more tossable on winding roads, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/aston-martin/db11/2018/2018-aston-martin-db11-v8-first-drive/">2018 First Drive</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The V-8-powered DB11 is the first Aston Martin vehicle to feature an engine sourced from <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>-AMG.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s7/2018/">2018 Audi S7</a> gets new 20-inch alloy wheels as standard and a new 21-inch option.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s7/2018/">Audi S7</a> is one of two performance-minded variants of the A7, slotting below the larger S8. It comes standard with <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a>’s Quattro all-wheel drive system.</p>

<p><strong>S7 Premium Plus:</strong> The base Premium Plus trim is well-equipped with standard features including full LED headlights, four-zone climate control, a sunroof, leather upholster, heated front seats, navigation, front and rear parking sensors, a rearview camera, Apple CarPlay and Android auto integration, a 14-speaker Bose audio system, a 7.0-inch instrument cluster display, Audi’s MMI interface with an 8.0-inch screen, and a hands-free tailgate.</p>

<p><strong>S7 Prestige:</strong> Move up to the Prestige trim and you get a corner view camera, a head-up display, soft-close doors, and interior ambient lighting. Optional features include multi-contour seats with ventilation and massage functions, heated rear seats, a heated steering wheel, and the S Sport package, which adds dynamic steering, a sport rear differential, black exhaust finishers, and red brake calipers.</p>

<p>The 2018 Audi S7 is powered by a 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 with 450 and 406 lb-ft of torque paired to a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy estimates are 16/24 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p>The 2018 S7 hasn’t been crash tested by the NHTSA and IIHS. Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert come standard on the base Premium Plus trim. The Driver Assistance package adds adaptive cruise control, automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, lane keeping assist, and high beam assist. Night vision and pedestrian and large animal detection is only available on the Prestige grade.</p>

<p>The 2018 S7 has 24.5 cubic feet of cargo space that can be expanded to 49.1 cubic feet with the standard split-folding rear seats down.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s7/2016/2016-audi-s7-first-drive-review/">2016 First Drive</a>, we said that the S7 offers effortless acceleration and the engine stays quiet even at high speeds. Although the steering is responsive, it can be unpredictable at initial turn-in. Despite its size, the S7 handles well and stays neutral through turns. Interior quality is excellent and the cabin looks good with the Arras red option paired with red-accented carbon fiber interior trim.</p>

<p>Unlike the A7, the S7 deletes the rear center middle seat, limiting seating capacity to four.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/tt/2018/">2018 Audi TT</a> gets a new S Line competition package that adds brushed aluminum interior accents, red brake calipers, a sport-tuned suspension, leather/Alcantara sport seats, and a flat-bottom steering wheel. A Bang &amp; Olufsen premium audio system is now part of the optional technology package. Nappa leather seats are now available as part of an optional interior package for the TTS. Perhaps the most important addition to the TT lineup is the range-topping TT RS, which has 400 hp and is the most potent variant.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/tt/2018/">Audi TT</a> RS is a compact luxury sports car that’s available in a 2+2 coupe or two-seat convertible variant. All-wheel drive is standard. In addition to the base TT, the TTS and TT RS performance coupes are available.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two engines are available in the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a> TT including a 2.0-liter turbo-four rated at 220 hp and 258 lb-ft of torque in the base TT or 292 hp and 280 lb-ft in the TTS. The TT RS gets a 2.5-liter turbo-five with 400 hp and 354 lb-ft. The TT and TTS use a six-speed dual-clutch automatic and the TT RS gets a new seven-speed unit. EPA fuel economy ratings are 23/30 mpg city/highway for the TT regardless of body style, 23/27 mpg for the TTS, and 19/29 mpg for the TT RS. The coupe body style has a 12-cubic-foot cargo area in the hatch and can be expanded with the split-folding rear seats; however, the TT convertible only has 7.5 cubic feet of trunk space.</p>

<p>Standard features on the 2018 TT include full LED headlights, Bluetooth connectivity, the Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster, a rearview camera, keyless entry/start, Audi Drive Select, 50/50 split-folding rear seats (coupe only), heated front seats, 18-inch alloy wheels, and parking sensors. Options include Nappa leather upholstery, navigation, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, and a Bang &amp; Olufsen premium audio system. The TT RS adds more performance goodies front carbon ceramic brakes, a sports exhaust system, and a fixed sport suspension plus a 174-mph top speed.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Audi TT. No active safety features are available in any variant of the Audi TT, but blind spot warning is available as part of a package.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/tt/2016/2016-audi-tt-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we said the new TT’s eye-catching exterior design and minimalist interior makes it even more distinctive. The car features nimble handling thanks to its excellent chassis but it still has the same numb steering feel typical of Audis. The more powerful TTS, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/tts/2016/2016-audi-tts-coupe-second-drive-review/">2016 Second Drive</a>, is even quicker. However, the gearbox could use a seventh gear to help it cruise at a lower rpm and minimize the sluggish response off the line.</p>

<p>The TT RS offers a nice balance between comfort and performance thanks to its combination of a good ride and excellent handling courtesy of the standard magnetic shocks. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/tt/2018/2018-audi-tt-rs-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive</a>, we noted that the TT RS comes alive in the corners where you can throw it around and take advantage the all-wheel-drive system’s prodigious grip and its rear-wheel bias to allow it to rotate.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The TT RS is currently one of two Audi models using a five-cylinder engine, the other being the RS 3 sports sedan.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Like its A6-sedan sibling, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a7/2018/">2018 Audi A7</a> gets a slightly more powerful V-6 engine. Premium Plus trims now come with LED ambient lighting as standard while the Prestige model gets a corner view camera. The Competition package option adds red brake calipers, sport-tuned suspension, a sport differential, aluminum interior trim, a flat-bottom steering wheel with paddle shifters, and S Sport seats. High-performance S7 and RS 7 get a new 20- and 21-inch alloy wheel options, respectively.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a7/2018/">Audi A7</a> is a midsize hatchback that slots above the new A5 Sportback and comes standard with all-wheel drive. Two high-performance variants, the S7 and RS 7 are also available for those looking for more power.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 A7 comes with a standard 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 good for 340 hp and 325 lb-ft of torque; the engine is paired exclusively to an eight-speed automatic transmission. The <strong>S7</strong> is powered by a 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 with 450 hp and 406 lb-ft and a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic. The <strong>RS 7</strong> uses a more powerful version of the 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 rated at 560 hp and 516 lb-ft in base trim or 605 hp and 516 lb-ft in the Performance model. Both variants of the RS 7 come exclusively with an eight-speed automatic. EPA fuel economy ratings stand at 20/29 mpg city/highway for the A7, 17/27 mpg for the S7, and 15/25 mpg for the RS 7. Cargo space behind the rear seats is 24.5 cubic feet</p>

<p>Standard features on the base Premium Plus include leather upholstery, heated front seats, the MMI interface with navigation and a 7.0-inch screen, a Bose premium audio system, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, a rearview camera, keyless entry/start, LED headlights, 60/40 split-folding rear seats, leather upholstery, and four-zone climate control. Options include heated rear seats, ventilated and massaging front seats, multi-contour front seats, and night vision assist. The S7 comes with additional go-fast goodies such as dynamic steering, a sport exhaust system, and a sport rear differential. Most of the go-fast options in the A7 and S7 come standard in the RS 7 except for a titanium exhaust system that’s only available in the RS 7 Performance trim.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a> A7. Available active safety features include automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, adaptive cruise control with a stop-and-go function, and active lane keeping assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>The base 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 offers plenty of power, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a6/2016/2016-audi-a6-a7-30t-first-test/">2016 First Test</a> and acceleration comes with little drama thanks to the smooth engine and quick-shifting eight-speed automatic. Interior quality remains top notch and the MMI system is now easier to use compared to the infotainment systems found in its rivals. Ride quality, however, is jarring over less-than-perfect roads when the A7 is equipped with larger alloy wheel options.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s7/2016/2016-audi-s7-first-drive-review/">2016 S7 First Drive</a>, we said that it offers impressive acceleration and feels neutral through the turns with the available sport differential. Opt for the more powerful RS 7 and you’ll get blistering acceleration in a large hatchback that flies under the radar, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/rs-7/2017/2016-audi-rs-7-performance-s8-plus-review/">2016 First Drive.</a></p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Audi A7 was previewed by the Sportback concept that debuted at the 2009 Detroit auto show.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s3/2018/">2018 Audi S3</a> gets a new S Sport package option. Two USB ports and heated front seats are now standard across the A3 and S3 lineup.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s3/2018/">Audi S3</a> is one of two performance variants of the A3, slotting below the more powerful RS 3. As with most performance-oriented Audis, all-wheel drive comes standard.</p>

<p><strong>S3 Premium Plus: </strong>The base Premium Plus trim comes standard with full LED headlights, leather upholstery, 18-inch alloy wheels, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, a 7.0-inch screen, Bluetooth, keyless entry and start, a rearview camera, two USB ports, heated front seats, and a panoramic sunroof.</p>

<p><strong>S3 Prestige: </strong>The S3 Prestige adds a 14-speaker Bang &amp; Olufsen audio system, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a>’s Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster, and navigation.</p>

<p>Options include 19-inch alloy wheels, S sport seats, and the S Sport package, which adds magnetic dampers and red brake calipers.</p>

<p>The 2018 Audi S3 is powered by a 2.0-liter turbo-four rated at 292 hp and 280 lb-ft of torque paired to a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 22/28 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p>The 2018 Audi S3 received a five-star overall rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 A3, the car on which the S3 is based, received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except for the passenger side front overlap test where it hasn’t been tested and the headlights test where it received an Average rating (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the A3 received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph and a 25-mph collision (Superior is the highest rating on the front crash prevention test).  Standard active driver assistance features include blind-spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, forward collision warning and automatic emergency braking. Adaptive cruise control and lane keeping assist is standard only on the range-topping Prestige trim.</p>

<p>The 2018 S3 has a 10.0-cubic-foot trunk that can be expanded via the standard split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s3/2016/2015-audi-a3-2016-audi-s3-review-verdict/">2015 review</a> of our long-term S3, we concluded that the car offers smooth acceleration thanks to its powerful turbo engine and smooth transmission. We also noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s3/2015/2015-audi-s3-first-test/">2015 First Test</a> that the S3’s interior is simple but modern looking. Material quality is excellent and everything inside the cabin feels and looks expensive. Handling was agile but the S3’s steering feels artificial and with the optional 19-inch alloy wheels, the ride does get firm.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a6/2018/">2018 Audi A6</a> gets new standard equipment on the base Premium trim level including keyless entry/start and the MMI interface with navigation. Premium Plus models gets LED headlights as standard while the range-topping Prestige grade now comes with a 360-degree camera system. Cars with the optional V-6 now have more power and can be had with the Competition package, which adds black side mirror covers, red brake calipers, 20-inch alloy wheels, sport-tuned suspension, Quattro sport differential, aluminum interior trim, S Sport seats, and a three-spoke flat-bottom steering wheel with paddle shifters.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting above the compact A4, the 2018 <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a6/2018/">Audi A6</a> is the brand’s midsize luxury sedan and is available in front- or all-wheel-drive configurations. In addition to the standard A6, there’s also a performance variant called the S6 that comes standard with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Three engines are available in the 2018 <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a> A6 and they’re paired exclusively to automatic transmissions.</p>

<p><strong>Model: A6, A6 Quattro</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 2.0-liter turbo-four – seven-speed dual-clutch automatic (A6) or eight-speed automatic (A6 Quattro)<br>
Power: 252 hp/273 lb-ft of torque<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 25/34 mpg city/highway (A6), 22/31 mpg (A6 Quattro)</br></br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: A6 3.0T Quattro</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 – eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 340 hp/325 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 20/29 mpg</br></br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: S6</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 – seven-speed dual-clutch automatic<br>
Power: 450 hp/406 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 18/27 mpg</br></br></br></p>

<p>Standard features include keyless entry/start, Audi’s MMI interface with navigation and a 7.0-inch screen, a rearview camera, 60/40 split-folding rear seats, tri-zone climate control, 18-inch alloy wheels, Audi Drive Select and HID headlights. Options include alloy wheels up to 20 inches in diameter, heated rear seats, full LED headlights, a head-up display, ventilated and massaging front seats, and a power operated trunk. Trunk space on all A6 and S6 variants is 14.1 cubic feet. The S6 is available with more go-fast goodies such as a sport differential, a sport exhaust, and dynamic steering.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Audi A6 a five-star overall safety score (out of a possible five stars). It only received the Top Safety Pick award from the IIHS after it received a Good rating on all crash tests and a Marginal on the headlight test. In the front collision prevention test, the A6 received an Advanced rating after it reduced the impact of a 12-mph crash by 10 mph and a 25-mph crash by 1 mph.</p>

<p>Forward collision warning, adaptive cruise control with stop and go function, automatic emergency braking, automatic rear emergency braking, blind spot warning, active lane keep assist, and high beam assist are available on higher trim levels.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a6/2016/2016-audi-a6-20t-quattro-first-drive-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we said that the 252-hp 2.0-liter turbo-four offers strong power but suffers from minor turbo lag. The A6 2.0T tends to understeer when pushed hard and the steering lacks feedback. Road noise, on the other hand, is minimal.</p>

<p>Even before it gained a bit more power, the V-6-powered A6 had prodigious power, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a6/2016/2016-audi-a6-a7-30t-first-test/">2016 First Test</a> and it delivers its might with little drama. However, ride quality does take a hit when the car is equipped with the larger 20-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p>The more powerful S6 is essentially an Autobahn missile with gobs of power on tap from the twin-turbo V-8 that’s paired to a quick-shifting seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/cts-v/2016/comparison-audi-s6-4-0t-quattro-vs-cadillac-cts-v-sport-vs-lexus-gs-f/">comparison test against the Lexus GS F and Cadillac CTS VSport</a>, the S6 placed third due to its disconnected driving experience. Like every Audi, the S6’s interior is built with high-quality materials and feels luxurious.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a>’s best-selling vehicle has been <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/q5/2018/2018-audi-q5-first-look/">thoroughly redesigned for the 2018 model year</a> including a move to an updated version of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/">VW</a> Group’s MLB chassis, which reduced wright by nearly 200 pounds, despite larger dimensions. The Q5 and SQ5 also get revised engines for more power and increased fuel economy.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The midsize two-row <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/q5/2018/">Audi Q5</a> and SQ5 crossover slots above the compact Q3 and full-size Q7 crossovers as well as the A3 Sportback e-tron and A4 Allroad models.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/q5/2018/">2018 Audi Q5</a> is powered by a revised turbocharged 2.0-liter TSFI I-4 rated 252 hp and 273 lb-ft of torque – that’s 32 hp and 15 lb-ft more than before. Power for the SQ5 comes from a new turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6 making 354 hp and 369 lb-ft. That’s 23 lb-ft more power than the previous supercharged 3.0-liter V-6 engine. Both engines are mated to the automaker’s seven-speed dual-clutch transmission and Quattro all-wheel-drive system.</p>

<p>With its 2018 update, the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/refreshing-revolting-2018-audi-q5/">Q5 finally gets the modern exterior styling</a> seen on the Q3 and Q7 crossover including the bold single-frame grille flanked by standard HID headlights and LED daytime running lights. LED headlights are optional. Around back, the Q5 sports LED taillights with dynamic rear turn signals.</p>

<p>Inside, the midsize crossover features premium materials as well as three-zone climate control and an updated MMI infotainment system with rotary and touchpad controls. Audi’s new signature digital virtual cockpit is also now available.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Audi Q5 and SQ5 are available with lots of advanced safety and driver assistance tech including adaptive cruise control with traffic-jam assist and the pre-sense city system.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think </strong></p>

<p>We were impressed with the luxury crossover in our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/q5/2018/2018-audi-q5-review/">2018 Audi Q5 Review</a>, saying, “the new turbo-four Q5 launches strongly off the line with little turbo lag. It continues to pull strongly through the powerband even with a relatively packed cabin of four adults and their gear….</p>

<p>“Audi has managed to hit a sweet spot with the standard suspension. Bumps and road imperfections were never jarring even with our tester’s large 20-inch wheels (18-inch wheels are standard). The body leans a tad through fast corners, but the chassis remained planted and never seemed to understeer. … Steering is what we’d expect from a high-riding crossover. There’s little feedback, but on-center feel is good, and the chassis responds well to steering inputs…</p>

<p>“Taller, stronger, and packed with fancy tech, the new <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/q5/2018/2018-audi-q5-euro-spec-first-drive-review/">2018 Audi Q5</a> should continue to stand out in this über-popular segment. Audi is better-equipped to keep up with demand, too, thanks to its new plant in Mexico, which is responsible for global production of the Q5 (except for China, which gets its own production facility for vehicles sold in that country).”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/sq5/2018/">2018 Audi SQ5</a> is rumored to have a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/hear-drift-mode-craze-spreading-2018-audi-sq5/">drift mode</a>.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a> Allroad gets blind-spot monitoring and rear auto emergency braking as standard on the Premium Plus grade. Prestige models get active lane assist, adaptive cruise control, high beam assist and traffic sign recognition as standard. Ventilated front sport seats are now part of the Warm Weather package in the Premium Plus grade.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Audi Allroad is a slightly raised wagon that’s essentially a more rugged version of the A4 Avant found in the rest of the world. All-wheel drive comes standard on all variants of the 2018 Allroad.</p>

<p><strong>Overview      </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Audi Allroad is powered by a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 252 hp and 273 lb-ft of torque. A seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission is the only gearbox available on the 2018 Allroad. EPA fuel economy ratings are 22/30 mpg city/highway. With the standard 40/20/40 split-folding rear seats in place, the 2018 Allroad has 24.2 cubic feet of cargo space and it can be expanded to  58.5 cubic feet.</p>

<p>Standard features include 18-inch alloy wheels, a rearview camera, HID headlights, tri-zone automatic climate control, interior ambient lighting, heated front seats, leather upholstery, a 5.0-inch multi-information display, Audi’s MMI interface with a 7.0-inch screen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, Bluetooth connectivity, and a panoramic sunroof. Options include memory function for the driver’s seat and side mirrors, a Bang &amp; Olufsen premium audio system, keyless entry/start, front and rear parking sensors, a 360-degree camera system, front sport seats, navigation, a larger 8.3-inch screen, Audi’s Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster, ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, and heated steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Allroad received a five-star rating on the NHTSA’s side crash test (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 Allroad received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except the passenger side front overlap test where it hasn’t been tested and the headlights test, where it got a Marginal rating (Good is the highest possible score). The Allroad received a Superior rating on the front crash prevention test after it avoided a 12-mph crash and reduced the severity of a 25-mph impact by 22 mph (Superior is the highest rating in the front crash prevention test). As a result, the 2018 Allroad received the IIHS’ 2017 Top Safety Pick rating.</p>

<p>Forward collision warning and automatic emergency braking are standard on all 2018 Allroads. Higher trims can be had with turn assist, collision avoidance assist, adaptive cruise control, traffic jam assist, traffic sign recognition, active lane keeping assist, and high beam assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/allroad/2017/2017-audi-a4-allroad-first-drive-review/">2017 First Drive</a>, we said that despite the slightly higher ground clearance, the Allroad drives like a wagon with excellent ride and handling. Each of the five drive modes on the Audi Drive Select system are also distinct with Dynamic tightening up the whole car, particularly the steering, and Off-Road mode improving the way the Allroad performance on dirt roads.</p>

<p>Despite the additional weight it carries, the Audi Allroad offers plenty of power on tap, giving it strong acceleration. The seven-speed dual-clutch automatic shifts quickly and smoothly, keeping the engine in its powerband. Even with a slightly raised suspension, we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/allroad/2017/2017-audi-a4-allroad-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a> that the Allroad handles well with well-controlled body motions through turns and minimal understeer when pushed hard. The interior, on the other hand, is luxurious and well-appointed with high quality materials everywhere. Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, however, could be improved if the car had a touchscreen since it currently forces you to use the MMI knob.</p>

<p>If you’re interested in an Audi but aren’t attached to the wagon body style, also consider the less expensive five-seat <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/q5/2018/">Audi Q5</a> crossover.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Audi Allroad shares its 2.0-liter turbo-four with the A4, A5, A6, Q5, and Q7.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>A new Executive package for the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a8/2018/">2018 Audi A8</a> adds 20-inch alloy wheels, a full suite of driver assistance tech, ventilated and massaging front seats, heated rear seats, a panoramic sunroof, and a four-spoke steering wheel with paddle shifters. Higher trims add rear seat lumbar, ventilation, and massage as part of the Executive package. The Black Optics package can now be had with 20- or 21-inch alloy wheels. The A8 gets redesigned <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2019-audi-a8-first-look-review/">for the 2019 model year</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a8/2018/">Audi A8</a> is the brand’s flagship sedan, slotting above the midsize A6 sedan and A7 four-door hatchback.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a> A8 offers V-6 and V-8 engines including a 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 with 333 hp and 325 lb-ft of torque in the A8 L 3.0T and a 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 with 450 hp and 444 lb-ft in the A8 L 4.0T. Go for the S8 Plus and the 4.0T engine gets upgraded to 605 hp and 517 lb-ft. Both engines are paired exclusively with an eight-speed automatic transmission. EPA ratings stand at 19/29 mpg city/highway for the A8 L 3.0T, 18/29 mpg for the A8 L 4.0T, and 15/24 mpg for the S8 Plus. Trunk space is 14.2 cubic feet for all variants.</p>

Options include alloy wheels up to 21 inches in diameter, a head-up display, a panoramic sunroof, ventilated and massaging front seats, night vision assistant, heated/ventilated/massaging rear seats, a 360-degree camera system, a Bang &amp; Olufsen audio system and power adjustable rear seats. The S8 Plus can be had with carbon ceramic brakes, an increased top speed of 190 mph, and a sports exhaust system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The IIHS and NHTSA haven’t crash tested the 2018 Audi A8.
