Optional active safety tech includes active lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control with a stop-and-go function, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, and high beam assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a8/2013/2013-audi-a8-l-first-test/">2013 First Test</a>, we said that the A8 feels lighter than it is when equipped with the base 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 and is more tossable than its size would suggest while still providing a comfortable ride even on less-than-perfect surfaces. With the optional 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8, the A8 is even quicker, offering acceleration rivaling some sports cars.</p>

<p>Should you need more speed, the S8 Plus allows you to fly under the radar. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/rs-7/2017/2016-audi-rs-7-performance-s8-plus-review/">2017 First Drive</a>, we said that the S8 Plus offers insane amounts of power and can easily get to Autobahn speeds with ease. Despite its prodigious power, the S8 Plus retains comfortable and stealthy thanks to its restrained exterior design.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s8/2018/">Audi S8</a> Plus shares its twin-turbo V-8 with the RS 7 Performance model.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>For the 2018 model year, changes for the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a4/2018/">Audi A4</a> include new alloy wheel options and the Black Optics package, which adds red brake calipers as well as gloss black side sills, rear spoiler, and side mirror covers. The base Premium trim gets heated front seats as standard while the Premium Plus grade gets additional active safety features such as active lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control with stop and go function, traffic sign recognition, and high beam assist.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting above the smaller A3, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a4/2018/">2018 Audi A4</a> is a compact luxury sedan that’s available in front- or all-wheel-drive configurations. In addition to the sedan body style, the A4 is also available as a raised wagon called the Allroad. At the top of the range is the high-performance S4.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 A4 offers three engine options, from the front-drive A4 Ultra to the all-wheel-drive A4 Quattro and Allroad, and the sporty all-wheel-drive S4.</p>

<p><strong>Model: A4 Ultra</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 2.0-liter turbo-four – seven-speed dual-clutch automatic<br>
Power: 190 hp/236 lb-ft of torque<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 27/37 mpg city/highway</br></br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: A4 Quattro, A4 Allroad</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 2.0-liter turbo-four – seven-speed dual-clutch automatic or six-speed manual<br>
Power: 252 hp/273 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 24/34 mpg( A4 Quattro automatic); 24/33 mpg (A4 Quattro, manual), 22/30 mpg (A4 allroad)</br></br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: S4</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 3.0-liter turbo V-6 – eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 354 hp/369 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 21/30 mpg</br></br></br></p>

<p>Standard features include HID headlights, tri-zone climate control, , Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, heated front seats, 40/20/40 split-folding rear seats, a rearview camera, a 7.0-inch screen, leather upholstery, and Bluetooth connectivity. Options include <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a>’s MMI interface with navigation, an 8.3-inch screen, the Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster, a Bang &amp; Olufsen premium audio system, keyless entry/start, full LED headlights, ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, a power tailgate for the A4 allroad, sport seats, a head-up display, and alloy wheels up to 19 inches in diameter. The A4 and S4 sedans offer 13 cubic feet of cargo space.</p>

<p>For more cargo carrying capability, the A4 Allroad has 24.2 cubic feet behind the second row and 58.5 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 A4 a five-star overall score (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS evaluations, the car received the Top Safety Pick+ award after it scored Good on all crash tests, Average on the headlight test, and Superior on the front crash prevention test when it avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the impact of a 25-mph one by 22 mph (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>All trim levels of the 2018 Audi A4 comes standard with automatic emergency braking and forward collision warning. Higher grade models come with lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control with stop and go function, blind spot warning, rear automatic emergency braking, rear cross-traffic alert, and high beam assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>A 2017 Audi A4 placed second in <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/giulia/2017/alfa-romeo-giulia-bmw-330i-audi-a4-mercedes-benz-c300-cadillac-ats-jaguar-xe-lexus-is-200t-volvo-s60-comparison/">a recent comparison test of compact luxury sport sedans</a> thanks to its slick tech features and solid driving dynamics. However, the Audi fell behind the winning <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/giulia/2018/">Alfa Romeo Giulia</a> due to its lack of character and sterile personality on the road. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a4/2017/2017-audi-a4-20t-quattro-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we also noted that while the A4 handles well, but it doesn’t have the same level of driver engagement as some of the more sporting competitors in its class. The A4 Allroad, on the other hand, offers the same confident driving dynamics as the A4 sedan even with the slight increase in ride height. Inside, the A4 offers a conservative but luxurious cabin that’s packed with cutting-edge tech and high quality materials, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/allroad/2017/2017-audi-a4-allroad-first-test-review/">2017 A4 Allroad First Test</a>.</p>

<p>The <strong><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s4/2018/">Audi S4</a></strong> kicks things up a notch with its powerful 354-hp 3.0-liter turbo V-6, a more aggressive suspension, and a torque vectoring differential that helps give it excellent road holding and even better handling. We noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s4/2018/2018-audi-s4-s5-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive</a> that the S4 always remains neutral, and that the car adds “a new level of interior and exterior sophistication to what were already competent—if a little bland—cars in their previous iterations.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Audi A4 Ultra, along with the front-drive A3 sedan, were the first Audi vehicles to utilize the high-fuel economy version of Audi’s 2.0-liter turbo-four.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/q3/2018/">2018 Audi Q3</a> gets standard S Line exterior design cues and heated front seats. Premium Plus models get full LED headlights and blind-spot monitoring as standard. A new Convenience package is now available on the base Premium trim. A three-spoke flat bottom steering wheel, Black Optics exterior body kit, black roof rails, and 19-inch alloy wheels now come with the optional Sport package.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/q3/2018/">Audi Q3</a> is a small premium crossover that slots below the larger Q5. Front-wheel drive is standard and all-wheel drive is available.</p>

<p><strong>Overview          </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a> Q3 is powered exclusively by a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 200 hp and 207 lb-ft of torque, and the engine is paired to a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 20/28 mpg city/highway for front- and all-wheel-drive models. When properly equipped, the Audi Q3 can tow up to 2,200 pounds. With the 60/40 split-folding rear seats in place, there’s 16.7 cubic feet of cargo space. Fold those seats down and there’s 50.3 cubic feet of space.</p>

<p>Standard features include heated power adjustable front seats, 18-inch alloy wheels, HID headlights, dual-zone climate control, leather upholstery, a rearview camera, Bluetooth connectivity, and a panoramic sunroof. The Premium Plus package adds full LED headlights, keyless entry/start, and a power liftgate. Options include navigation, a Bose premium audio system, a multi-information display in between the gauges, the Audi Drive Select system, front sport seats, and a multi-function flat-bottom steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The IIHS hasn’t crash-tested the 2018 Q3 but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except for the new passenger side front small overlap impact because it hasn’t been evaluated in that test yet (Good is the highest possible score). In the headlights test, the Q3 received a Poor rating.</p>

<p>Blind-spot monitoring is standard on all 2018 Q3s. There are no active safety and driver assistance features available on any variant of the 2018 Audi Q3.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Audi Q3 is the last front-drive-based Audi vehicle that isn’t based on the new MQB platform.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The new <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a5/2018/">2018 Audi A5</a> represents the brand’s second-generation of its sexy coupe and convertible. For the first time, the U.S. market will also receive the A5 and S5 Sportback, a four-door hatchback body style that was once only available in Europe.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a5/2018/">Audi A5</a> is a compact luxury car that’s available as a coupe, convertible, or four-door hatchback. All A5 variants come standard with all-wheel drive. Two performance variants are available including the <strong>S5</strong> and <strong>RS 5</strong>.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a> A5 offers three engines, and if you want a six-speed manual transmission, consider the A5 Coupe.</p>

<p><strong>Model: A5</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 2.0-liter turbo-four – six-speed manual (coupe only) or seven-speed dual-clutch automatic<br>
Power: 252 hp/273 lb-ft of torque<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 24/34 mpg city/highway, 24/33 mpg (manual coupe)</br></br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: S5</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 3.0-liter turbo V-6 – eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 354 hp/369 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 21/30 mpg, 20/29 mpg (S5 convertible)</br></br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model RS 5</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 2.9-liter twin-turbo V-6 – eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 450 hp/443 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: Not Yet Rated</br></br></br></p>

<p>Standard features on the base Premium trim include HID headlights, tri-zone climate control, Audi’s MMI interface with a 7.0-inch screen, a rearview camera, keyless entry/start, Bluetooth connectivity, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, 40/20/40 split-folding rear seats, Audi Drive Select, a panoramic roof, and 18-inch alloy wheels. Optional features include full LED headlights, navigation with a larger 8.3-inch screen, a Bang &amp; Olufsen premium audio system, Audi’s Virtual Cockpit system, adaptive damping, a head-up display, and alloy wheels up to 19 inches in diameter. The S5 can be hand with dynamic steering, a sport rear differential, adaptive damping suspension, and red brake calipers.</p>

<p>Cargo space in the A5 coupe is 11.6 cubic feet, and the A5 convertible has 9.3 cubic feet. The A5 Sportback has the most cargo space at 21.8 cubic feet behind the rear seats and 35 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Audi A5. Automatic emergency braking and forward collision warning are standard on all 2018 A5s. Optional active safety features include adaptive cruise control with stop-and-go function, lane keeping assist, high beam assist, rear automatic emergency braking, and blind spot warning.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a5/2018/2018-audi-a5-s5-sportback-first-drive-logic-dose-passion/">2018 First Drive</a>, we said the the A5 Sportback has the same confident handling and overall driving dynamics as the A4 sedan. The interior, in typical Audi fashion, is high quality with excellent materials that feel expensive. The more powerful S5, on the other hand, offers plenty of power and excellent handling. However, the steering, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s4/2018/2018-audi-s4-s5-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive</a>, doesn’t communicate with you. The adaptive damping suspension also helps keep the car composed.</p>

<p>In comparison to the car it replaces, the new RS 5 features a meatier power band that has more mid-range torque, meaning it’s not as rev-happy. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s5/2018/2018-audi-rs5-coupe-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive</a>, we said that the RS 5 continues to offer prodigious grip levels and is a more restrained car than before — still quick, but now better able to travel “long distances at high speed without raising a sweat.” The dynamic suspension helps keep body motions in check especially at high speeds, where it keeps the car stable.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Audi A5’s base 2.0-liter turbo-four is shared with multiple Audi models including the A4, A6, Q5, and A7.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/q7/2018/">2018 Audi Q7</a> gets keyless entry/start on all models, a standard Bose premium audio system on the Premium Plus models, and power-closing doors on the range-topping Prestige grade.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting above the compact Q5, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/q7/2018/">Audi Q7</a> is a three-row crossover with seating for seven passengers and standard all-wheel drive.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two engines are available on the 2018 Q7 including a 2.0-liter turbo-four rated at 252 hp and 273 lb-ft of torque and a 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 with 333 hp and 325 lb-ft. Both engines are paired exclusively to an eight-speed automatic transmission and are EPA-rated at 19/25 mpg city/highway. Cargo space is 14.8 cubic feet behind the third row, 37.5 cubic feet behind the second row, and 71.6 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>Standard features include HID headlights, tri-zone climate control, split-folding second and third rows, a 7.0-inch multi-information display, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a>’s MMI system with a 7.0-inch screen, leather upholstery, keyless entry/start, Bluetooth connectivity, heated front seats, a panoramic sunroof, Audi Drive Select, a rearview camera, and 18-inch alloy wheels. Higher trim levels are available with LED headlights, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay compatibility, the Virtual Cockpit system, navigation, a 360-degree camera system, ventilated and massaging front seats, a heated steering wheel, alloy wheels up to 21 inches in size, air suspension, four-wheel steering, a Bang &amp; Olufsen premium audio system, a larger 8.3-inch screen for the MMI system, parking sensors, and a head-up display.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Audi Q7 hasn’t been crash tested by the NHTSA but in IIHS evaluations it received the Top Safety Pick rating after it received a Good score on all crash tests (Good is the highest possible score). The crossover earned a Superior rating on the front crash prevention test after it avoided a 12-mpg collision and reduced the impact of a 25-mph impact by 23 mph (Superior is the highest possible score). On the new headlight test, the 2018 Q7 received a Marginal score, which prevented it from receiving the higher Top Safety Pick+ rating. Automatic emergency braking comes standard on all 2018 Q7s. Optional active safety tech include active lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control with a stop-and-go function, blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, and high beam assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/q7/2017/2017-audi-q7-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we said that the Q7 is supremely comfortable and, like all Audis, the interior is built with high-quality materials and the slick Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster. Although first- and second-row space is plenty for adults, the third row is best left for children, as there’s minimal head- and legroom back there. Tire noise was minimal and despite its size, the Q7 handles well with the standard or air suspension, but the latter does cause the car to get bouncy. Acceleration with the 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 is strong and makes it one of the quicker cars in its class with a <em>Motor-Trend-</em>tested 0 to 60 mph time of 5.7 seconds.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The second-generation Audi Q7 is the first seven-seat crossover from Audi to feature a standard turbocharged four-cylinder engine.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/rs-7/2018/">2018 Audi RS 7</a> gets standard sport exhaust and new five-spoke 21-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/rs-7/2018/">Audi RS 7</a> is the second high performance variant of the A7, offering more power and a tighter suspension calibration. A performance-oriented all-wheel drive system comes standard.</p>

<p><strong>RS 7: </strong>The base RS 7 comes standard with full LED headlights, a power tailgate, four-zone climate control, leather upholstery, heated front seats, a 7.0-inch instrument cluster display, a 14-speaker Bose audio system, navigation, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a>’s MMI interface with an 8.0-inch screen, two USB ports, front and rear parking sensors, keyless entry and start, a head-up display, a rearview camera, and a corner view camera system.</p>

<p><strong>RS 7 Performance: </strong>The RS 7 Performance adds more go-fast goodies like Audi’s Dynamic Ride Control suspension and carbon ceramic brakes.</p>

<p>Options include ventilated and massaging front seats, heated rear seats, a heated steering wheel, a titanium exhaust system, and a Bang &amp; Olufsen surround sound system.</p>

<p>The 2018 Audi RS 7 is powered by a 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 rated at 560 hp and 516 lb-ft of torque in the standard version or 605 hp and 553 lb-ft in the RS 7 Performance. An eight-speed automatic is the only gearbox available. EPA fuel economy ratings are 14/24 mpg city/highway for both variants of the RS 7.</p>

<p>Standard active driver assistance features include blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, forward collision warning, and automatic emergency braking. The Driver Assistance package adds adaptive cruise control, high beam assist, lane keeping assist and an enhanced automatic emergency braking system that works at higher speeds.</p>

<p>The 2018 RS 7 has 24.5 cubic feet of cargo space with the split-folding rear seats up and 49.1 cubic feet with them down.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/rs-7/2017/2016-audi-rs-7-performance-s8-plus-review/">2016 First Drive</a>, we said the RS 7 Performance offers prodigious acceleration thanks to its powerful engine and it comes with plenty of burbles and a sweet exhaust note. The standard RS 7 is no slouch as it accelerates explosively thanks to its twin-turbo V-8. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/luxury-super-sports-sedan-comparison/">2014 comparison test</a> that also included the previous-generation <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/panamera/2018/">Porsche Panamera</a> Turbo and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>-AMG CLS63 S, the RS 7 placed second because of its straight-line performance but its soft suspension held it back. Additionally, it understeers too much when pushed hard, especially on a track.</p>

<p>The RS 7 Performance is one of a number of Audi vehicles that’s available with carbon fiber interior trim that has colored accents embroidered within it.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/r8/2018/">2018 Audi R8</a> is now available with laser LED headlights and comes standard with Android Auto and Apple CarPlay. A new Black Optics package option adds 20-inch alloy wheels, Mythos Black side blades, Titanium Black exterior trim, and gloss black exhaust tips. Anthracite interior trim now comes standard on the R8 V10 while the R8 V10 Plus gets Carbon Sigma high gloss inlays.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/r8/2018/">Audi R8</a> is the flagship supercar of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a> brand. The car features a mid-engine layout, comes standard with all-wheel drive and comes in either coupe or convertible body styles.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>A 5.2-liter V-10 paired to a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic gearbox is the only powertrain combination available. In the R8 V10 and R8 Spyder, it makes 540 hp and 398 lb-ft of torque or 610 hp and 413 lb-ft on the R8 V10 Plus. EPA fuel economy ratings stand at 14/22 mpg city/highway for all variants. Cargo space in the R8’s front trunk is 8.0 cubic feet.</p>

<p>Standard features include full LED headlights, Nappa leather upholstery, heated 18-way power adjustable seats, the Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster, Audi’s MMI interface with navigation (in the instrument cluster), Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, keyless entry/start, 19-inch alloy wheels, Audi Drive Select, a rearview camera, parking sensors, and a Bang &amp; Olufsen premium audio system (optional on the R8 V10 Plus). Optional features include a dynamic steering system, a full leather interior, 20-inch alloy wheels, and contrast stitching for the seats. Audi will also allow you to customize your R8 with exclusive exterior colors for an extra charge.</p>

<p><strong>Safety<br/></strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Audi R8. Active safety tech isn’t available in any variant of the Audi R8.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/r8/2017/2017-audi-r8-v10-plus-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we said that despite the minimalist design, the R8’s cabin is well-built and packed with tech such as the Virtual Cockpit system. On the road, the R8 offers explosive acceleration especially the 610-hp R8 V10 Plus despite having a high-revving engine. Its handling is also excellent and its steering is crisp and sharp, making it great to drive on winding mountain roads. At the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mclaren/570/2016/2016-motor-trend-best-drivers-car/">2016 Best Driver’s Car </a>competition, however, the Audi R8 V10 Plus only placed seventh due to it being overly precise and clinical on the track. Additionally, the car had a tendency to understeer when pushed hard to its limit.</p>

<p>We recently <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/r8/2017/2017-audi-r8-v10-spyder-first-test-review/">tested a 2017 R8 Spyder</a> and found that even with the less powerful version of the 5.2-liter V-10, it has strong acceleration, just not as violent as the R8 V10 Plus when launching. In most driving situations, the seven-speed dual-clutch automatic shifts smoothly; however, in Sport mode it’s rougher and less refined. As with most supercars, the R8 Spyder offers excellent handling but the steering doesn’t have as much feel as one would expect. The interior, as with most Audi vehicles, is well built and features a minimalist design. In this case, the R8 Spyder lacks the traditional screen on the dash for the infotainment system, leaving only the Virtual Cockpit as the place where all information is displayed.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Audi R8 is closely related to the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lamborghini/huracan/2018/">Lamborghini Huracan</a> since both use the same V-10 engine and dual-clutch transmission.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s5/2018/">2018 Audi S5</a> is powered by a new turbocharged engine and is now available in a hatchback called the S5 Sportback.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s5/2018/">Audi S5</a> is the performance variant of the A5, slotting below the larger S7 hatchback. The car comes standard with all-wheel drive and is available in coupe, convertible, or four-door hatchback body styles.</p>

<p><strong>S5 Premium Plus: </strong>The base Premium Plus trim comes standard with 18-inch alloy wheels, full LED headlights, heated front seats, Bluetooth, keyless entry and start, front and rear parking sensors, a rearview camera, a 7.0-inch screen for the MMI interface, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a 7.0-inch instrument cluster display and two USB ports.</p>

<p><strong>S5 Prestige: </strong>Moving up to the Prestige trim adds features like <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a>’s Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster, a 19-speaker Bang &amp; Olufsen audio system, navigation, a 360-degree camera system, a larger 8.3-inch screen for the MMI interface, and a head-up display.</p>

<p>Optional features include ventilated front seats, a heated steering wheel, 19-inch alloy wheels, dynamic steering, and the S Sport package, which adds red brake calipers, adaptive dampers, and a sport rear differential.</p>

<p>The 2018 S5 is powered by a 3.0-liter turbocharged V-6 with 354 hp and 369 lb-ft of torque paired to an eight-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 21/30 mpg city/highway for the S5 Coupe and Sportback, and 20/29 mpg for the S5 Cabriolet.</p>

<p>Not all body styles of the 2018 Audi S5 have been crash tested but the Sportback received a five-star rollover score from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). When the IIHS tested the A5 Coupe and Sportback, both variants received a Good rating on all crashworthiness tests except the passenger side front overlap test where it hasn’t been tested and the headlights test where it received a Marginal score (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the S5 Coupe and Sportback received a Superior rating after both avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the severity of a 25-mph one by 22 mph (Superior is the highest score for front crash prevention). Both models earned a 2017 IIHS Top Safety Pick rating.</p>

<p>Blind-spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, forward collision warning and automatic emergency braking come standard on all S5 models. The Driver Assistance package, which is only available on the Prestige trim, adds adaptive cruise control, active lane keeping assist, high beam assist and traffic sign recognition.</p>

<p>The 2018 S5 Coupe has 11.6 cubic feet of cargo space and can be expanded with the standard split-folding rear seats while the S5 Cabriolet has 9.3 cubic feet. The S5 Sportback has the most cargo capacity at 21.8 cubic feet behind the second row and 35 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a5/2018/2018-audi-a5-s5-sportback-first-drive-logic-dose-passion/">2018 First Drive</a>, offers strong acceleration and offers plenty of grip even in the wet thanks to its standard all-wheel drive system. The eight-speed automatic is quick to shift but the steering is disconnected even in its most aggressive setting. Build quality is excellent with solid materials throughout the interior and it’s complemented with slick tech features like Audi’s Virtual Cockpit.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>All 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a> A3s get two USB ports and heated front seats. Blind spot warning now comes standard on the Premium Plus trim while the Bang &amp; Olufsen premium audio system is now bundled with navigation and the Virtual Cockpit system. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s3/2018/">Audi S3</a> gets a new S Sport package option that bundles together the magnetic ride system with red brake calipers. Plug-in hybrid models are now available with 18-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a3/2018/">2018 Audi A3</a> is a premium compact car offered in front- or all-wheel-drive configurations. In the lineup, the A3 is the entry-level sedan, slotting below the A4 sedan. A hatchback body style is also available in addition to the sedan but it’s only available as a plug-in hybrid.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>There are five powertrain choices available on the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a3/2018/">Audi A3</a> and they’re all available only with automatic transmissions.</p>

<p><strong>Model: A3 2.0T FWD; A3 2.0T FWD Cabriolet</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 2.0-liter turbo-four – seven-speed dual-clutch automatic<br>
Power: 186 hp/221 lb-ft of torque<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 26/35 mpg city/highway; 25/33 mpg (cabriolet)</br></br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: A3 2.0T Quattro; A3 2.0T Quattro Cabriolet</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 2.0-liter turbo-four – six-speed dual-clutch automatic<br>
Power: 220 hp/258 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 24/31 mpg; 22/30 mpg (Cabriolet)</br></br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: S3</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 2.0-liter turbo-four – six-speed dual-clutch automatic<br>
Power: 292 hp/280 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 22/28 mpg</br></br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model RS 3</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 2.5-liter turbo-five – seven-speed dual-clutch automatic<br>
Power: 400 hp/354 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 19/28 mpg</br></br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: A3 E-Tron</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 1.4-liter turbo-four + electric motor – six-speed dual-clutch automatic<br>
Power: 204 hp/258 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 33 mpg combined; 16 miles EV mode range; 380 miles EPA-estimated total range</br></br></br></p>

<p>Standard features on the base A3 include HID headlights, dual-zone climate control, a panoramic sunroof, leather upholstery, 12-way power seats, Bluetooth connectivity, a rearview camera, and 17-inch alloy wheels. Options include a Bang &amp; Olufsen premium audio system, keyless entry/start, the Audi Drive Select system, LED headlights, Audi’s MMI system, navigation with a 7.0-inch retractable screen, the Virtual Cockpit system, a sport suspension, and alloy wheels up to 19 inches in diameter.</p>

<p>The S3 gets additional goodies like magnetic ride, S Sport seats with a fixed back, and red brake calipers.</p>

<p>The RS 3 can be had with a 174-mph top speed, a fixed sport suspension, carbon ceramic front brakes, RS sport exhausts, and staggered tires.</p>

<p>In terms of cargo space, sedans have a 12.3-cubic foot trunk while the A3 E-Tron hatch has 13.6 cubic feet behind the second row. Both the sedan and hatchback come with split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Audi A3 received a five-star overall safety score from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS evaluations, the 2018 A3 received a Good score on all crash tests, a Superior rating for front crash prevention after it avoided a 12- and 25-mph collision, and Average on the headlight test, giving it a Top Safety Pick+ rating (Good is the highest possible score). Standard on all Audi A3 models are forward collision warning and automatic emergency braking. Higher trim levels can be optioned with lane keeping assist, blind spot warning, adaptive cruise control, high beam assist, and rear cross-traffic alert.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>We haven’t tested the Audi A3 with the new base engine but the 2.0T Quattro we evaluated in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a3/2015/2015-audi-a3-20t-quattro-first-test/">2015 First Test</a> offered strong power with minimal turbo lag and well balanced ride and handling. However, it suffered from excessive tire noise and cramped rear seats. As for the S3, we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s3/2017/2017-audi-s3-first-drive-review/">2017 First Drive</a> that it has generous amount of power, supportive seats, and comes with slick on-board technologies especially the Virtual Cockpit system. However, like lesser A3s, the S3 gets upset quickly by imperfect road surfaces.</p>

<p>The range-topping RS 3, on the other hand, offers excellent handling thanks to its retuned suspension, lighter weight, improved steering, and lower center of gravity. In a 2018 RS 3 <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s3/2017/2017-audi-rs-3-first-drive-review/">First Drive</a> we also noted at that the car feels like it’s rear-wheel drive with the front wheels only gaining traction to save you from a sticky situation.</p>

<p>The A3 E-Tron hatchback offers a better ride and stable handling despite the added weight of the plug-in hybrid powertrain. However, we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a3/2016/2016-audi-a3-sportback-e-tron-first-drive-review/">2016 First Drive</a> that the brakes have a “mildly gooey regen feel,” though we’ve driven plug-ins with worse braking feel.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The high-performance RS 3 sedan shares its turbocharged five-cylinder engine with the TT RS coupe and convertible.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The redesigned <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s4/2018/">2018 Audi S4</a> gets a new 3.0-liter turbo V-6 engine.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s4/2018/">Audi S4</a> is the performance variant of the A4 sedan, and it comes standard with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p><strong>S4 Premium Plus: </strong>The base Premium Plus trim comes standard with 18-inch alloy wheels, full LED headlights, heated front seats, leather/Alcantara upholstery, a 7.0-inch instrument cluster display, a 19-speaker Bang &amp; Olufsen audio system, Bluetooth, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, keyless entry and start, front and rear parking sensors, a rearview camera, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a>’s MMI interface with a 7.0-inch screen, and two USB ports.</p>

<p><strong>S4 Prestige:</strong> Moving up to the S4 Prestige gets you navigation, Audi’s Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster, a larger 8.3-inch screen for the MMI interface, and a head-up display.</p>

<p>Options include ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, a heated steering wheel, 19-inch alloy wheels, a dynamic steering system, and the S Sport package, which adds adaptive dampers, a sport rear differential and red brake calipers.</p>

<p>The 2018 Audi S4 is powered by a turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6 rated at 354 hp and 369 lb-ft of torque paired to an eight-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 21/30 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p>The 2018 S4 received a five-star rollover score from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 S4 received a Good rating on all crashworthiness tests except for the passenger side front small overlap test where it hasn’t been tested yet and the headlights test where it received a Marginal score (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the 2018 S4 received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the severity of a 25-mph impact by 22 mph (Superior is the highest score in the front crash prevention test). The 2018 S4 earned the IIHS’ 2018 Top Safety Pick rating.</p>

<p>Standard active driver assistance features on the 2018 S4 include blind-spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, forward collision warning, and automatic emergency braking.</p>

<p>The 2018 S4 has a 13-cubic-foot trunk that can be expanded via the standard split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s4/2018/2018-audi-s4-first-test-review/">2018 First Test</a>, we noted that despite being the sportier model, the S4’s ride is still comfortable enough for everyday driving. The car accelerates quickly and handles well with good body control. The start/stop system is unrefined because it turns the engine off right before the car has come to a complete halt. As with most Audis, the S4’s interior looks sharp and the multimedia system has crisp graphics, especially on the head-up display. The S4’s exterior is a bit conservative, making it a sleeper.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s6/2018/">2018 Audi S6</a> is unchanged.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s6/2018/">Audi S6</a> is the performance variant of the A6 midsize luxury sedan slotting above the smaller S4 and below the larger S8. All-wheel drive comes standard on all S6 models.</p>

<p><strong>S6 Premium Plus</strong>: Base Premium Plus models come standard with full LED headlights, four-zone climate control, a sunroof, leather upholstery, heated front seats, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a>’s MMI interface with an 8.0-inch screen, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, a 7.0-inch instrument cluster display, a 14-speaker Bose audio system, navigation, Bluetooth, a rearview camera, keyless entry and start, as well as front and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>S6 Prestige:</strong> Moving up to the Prestige trim adds LED interior lighting, a 360-degree camera system, a power-operated trunk, a head-up display, and a power rear sunshade.</p>

<p>Options include ventilated and massaging front seats, heated rear seats, a heated steering wheel, a Bang &amp; Olufsen audio system, and the S Sport package, which adds dynamic steering, a sport rear differential, red brake calipers, and a sport exhaust system.</p>

<p>The 2018 Audi S6 is powered by a 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 with 450 hp and 406 lb-ft of torque. A seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission is standard and the EPA rates its fuel economy at 16/24 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 S6 a five-star overall safety rating (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS hasn’t crash tested the S6 but it has evaluated the A6, the car on which the S6 is based. The A6 received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except the passenger side front small overlap test where it hasn’t been evaluated and the headlights test where it got a Marginal rating (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>In the IIHS’ forward collision prevention test, the 2018 A6 received an Advanced rating after in reduced the severity of 12- and 25-mph impacts by 10 mph and 1 mph, respectively (Superior is the highest score on the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p>Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert come standard on all S6 trims. The Driver Assistance package adds lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, and high beam assist. Night vision, pedestrian detection, and large animal detection are optional only on the Prestige model.</p>

<p>The 2018 S6 has a 14.1-cubic-foot trunk that can be expanded via the 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/cts-v/2016/comparison-audi-s6-4-0t-quattro-vs-cadillac-cts-v-sport-vs-lexus-gs-f/">2016 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/gs/2018/">Lexus GS</a> F and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/cts/2018/">Cadillac CTS</a> V-Sport, the Audi S6 placed third because it was too focused on straight-line performance. The car’s acceleration was excellent and the interior is typical Audi, quiet and well-appointed with high-quality materials. However, the S6 is heavy, its steering is sluggish, and it feels disconnected when driven enthusiastically.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/sq5/2018/">2018 Audi SQ5</a> has been redesigned with an updated exterior design, a new turbocharged V-6 engine, an optional air suspension, and the latest version of <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a>’s MMI interface.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/sq5/2018/">Audi SQ5</a> is the performance model of the Q5 model and comes standard with the automaker’s Quattro all-wheel-drive system.</p>

<p>Base Premium Plus models comes with 20-inch alloy wheels, full LED headlights, a power tailgate, three-zone climate control, heated front seats, a 7.0-inch instrument cluster display, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, a rearview camera, front and rear parking sensor, keyless entry and start, a 7.0-inch screen for the MMI interface, Bluetooth, and leather/Alcantara upholstery.</p>

<p>Moving up to the range-topping Prestige trim gets you a 19-speaker Bang &amp; Olufsen audio system, an 8.3-inch screen for the MMI interface, navigation, Audi’s Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster, and a head-up display.</p>

<p>Options include full leather upholstery, 21-inch alloy wheels, dynamic steering, heated rear seats, a heated steering wheel, a Sport rear differential, and an adaptive air suspension.</p>

<p>The 2018 SQ5 is powered by a 3.0-liter turbo V-6 with 354 hp and 369 lb-ft of torque paired to an eight-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy is 19/24 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p>The 2018 SQ5 hasn’t been crash tested, but the Q5, the car on which the SQ5 is based, received a five-star overall rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS tests, the 2018 Q5 received a Good rating on all crashworthiness tests except the headlights test where it only got a Marginal rating (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the 2018 Q5 received a Superior rating after it nearly avoided a 12-mph collision and completely avoided a 25-mph impact (Superior is the highest rating for the front crash prevention test). Because it didn’t receive an Average of higher rating in the headlights test, the 2018 Q5 only received the 2018 Top Safety rating from the IIHS.</p>

<p>Standard active driver assistance features include blind-spot monitoring, forward collision warning, rear cross-traffic alert, and forward and rear automatic emergency braking. On the range-topping Prestige trim, the Driver Assistance package adds adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assist, traffic sign recognition, and high beam assist.</p>

<p>The 2018 SQ5 has 26.8 cubic feet of cargo space behind the split-folding rear seats and 60.4 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/sq5/2018/2018-audi-sq5-first-drive-young-love/">2018 First Drive</a>, we said that the new 3.0-liter turbo V-6 offers strong acceleration and quick response, easily getting you to highway speeds. Despite its height, the SQ5 is surprisingly nimble through the corners and feels light on its feet. The steering, however, isn’t very precise and the start/stop system’s operation is rough. At highway speeds, the cabin stays quiet and material quality is excellent.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/rs-3/2018/">2018 Audi RS 3</a> is a new variant of the A3 that becomes the highest-performing model of the lineup.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/rs-3/2018/">Audi RS 3</a> is the most potent variant of the A3, slotting above the S3. All-wheel drive is standard.</p>

<p>Available as a single trim, the 2018 RS 3 comes standard with full LED headlights, dual-zone climate control, Nappa leather upholstery, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, keyless entry and start, front and rear parking sensors, a 7.0-inch screen, Bluetooth, and a panoramic sunroof.</p>

<p>Options include navigation, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a>’s Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster, a Bang &amp; Olufsen audio system, and the Dynamic package, which adds a sport exhaust, staggered high performance tires, and red brake calipers. You can upgrade the Dynamic package to the Dynamic Plus package to add a carbon fiber engine cover, carbon ceramic front brakes, a fixed sport suspension, and raise the top speed limiter to 174 mph.</p>

<p>The 2018 RS 3 is powered by a 2.5-liter turbo I-5 with 400 hp and 354 lb-ft of torque paired to a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 19/28 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 RS 3 a four-star rollover score (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 A3, the car on which the RS 3 is based, received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except the passenger side front small overlap crash where it hasn’t been tested and the headlights test where it received an Average rating (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>In the IIHS’ front crash prevention evaluation, the 2018 A3 received a Superior rating after it avoided collisions in 12- and 25-mph tests (Superior is the highest possible score for the front crash prevention test).  Forward collision warning, and automatic emergency braking come standard on the 2018 RS 3. The Driver Assistance package adds adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assist, and high beam assist.</p>

<p>The 2018 RS 3 has a 10.0-cubic-foot trunk that can be expanded via the standard split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/rs-3/2017/2017-audi-rs-3-first-test-review/">2018 First Test</a>, we were impressed with the RS 3’s commanding exhaust note that’s amplified by the optional sport exhaust. The 400-hp turbo five-cylinder engine offers strong acceleration, and the car’s steering was surprisingly precise, especially compared to the less powerful S3. Agility didn’t come at cost of ride comfort because although it was stiff, it proved reasonably compliant even on its most aggressive setting. Road noise does become excessive at higher speeds. Inside, the rear seats are tight like the other A3 variants but the multimedia system looks modern, especially when equipped with Audi’s Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster.</p>

<p>Along with the mechanically-related TT RS, the RS 3 is one of two vehicles in the U.S. sold with a gasoline five-cylinder engine.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/">Bentley</a> redesigned the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/continental/2019/2019-bentley-continental-gt-first-look/">Continental GT</a> Coupe for 2019 leaving the 2018 model as a convertible only and introduced the new Timeless Series and <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/set-sail-in-the-yacht-inspired-bentley-continental-gt-galene-edition/">Galene</a> limited-edition models.</p>

<p>The 2018 Continental GT is available as a convertible (the 2019 model is a coupe) and is part of Bentley’s lineup that also consists of the range-topping Mulsanne, the Flying Spur sedan, and the Bentayga SUV.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/continental-gt/2018/">2018 Bentley Continental GT</a> V8</strong>: The base GT V8 model comes standard with a twin-turbo V-8, 20-inch alloy wheels, air suspension with a continuous damping system, HID headlights with LED daytime running lights, LED taillights, dual stainless steel exhaust finishers, premium hide leather upholstery, Dark Fiddleback veneer, a leather and chrome-trimmed gear shifter, seating for four, Bentley embossed door sill plates, an 8.0-inch touchscreen with SiriusXM satellite radio, an eight-speaker audio system, and a four-layer insulated fabric top.</p>

<p><strong>2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/continental-gt/2018/">Bentley Continental GT</a> V8 S</strong>: The GT V8 S receives a more powerful version of the twin-turbo V-8 and increases the amount of available exterior colors to 17 (up from seven), increases the number of available interior roof colors to eight (up from four), increases the amount of available convertible tops to five (up from three), adds a choice of six two-tone interior color choices (up from one monotone color), and increases the amount of available interior leather colors to 17 (up from four). The V8 S adds LED taillights with special trim details inside the lamp, piano black veneer, a knurled sports gear shifter with leather, and a Beluga gloss front splitter, side sills, rear extension, and a diffuser.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Bentley Continental GT</strong>: The twin-turbo W-12 powered Continental GT adds a Burr Walnut veneer and optional features and packages that are not available on the GT V8 S such as the Mulliner Driving package, choice of six single-finish veneers, carbon fiber trim, a choice of two steering wheels, drilled alloy pedals, a neck warmer, a Wi-Fi hotspot, and seats by Mulliner.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Bentley Continental GT Speed</strong>: The GT Speed comes powered by a more powerful twin-turbo W-12 engine and adds sport-tuned air suspension with a continuous damping control system, 21-inch Speed dark alloy wheels, dark exterior accents, dark LED taillights, unique stainless steel exhaust finishers, unique GT Speed interior colors, Speed emblem stitching, piano black veneer, diamond quilted seats, a premium leather-wrapped Sports steering wheel, drilled alloy pedals, and the Mulliner Driving Specification package that includes an indented leather headliner and a choice of 21-inch wheels.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Bentley Continental Supersports</strong>: The range-topping Supersports is powered by 700-hp version of the W-12 engine and adds carbon ceramic brakes with red or black calipers, a torque vectoring system, 21-inch twenty spoke forged alloy wheels, black tint exterior trim, black logos and badges, black gloss exhaust finishers, carbon fiber front and rear bumper accents, hood vents, and side skirts, the Supersports two-tone interior with choice of 11 interior leathers and 18 accent colors, Supersports embroidered headrests, an Eliade cloth headliner, piano black veneer with high gloss checkered carbon fiber pattern (or a choice of three alternatives), an Alcantara and premium leather-trimmed Supersports steering wheel, a knurled gear shifter with Alcantara, and Supersports embossed door sill plates.</p>

<p>The Supersports can be optioned with a Supersports titanium exhaust system, carbon fiber exterior mirrors, a high-gloss carbon fiber engine cover, dark aluminum fascia panels, a Naim audio system, and personalized headrest embroidery and door sills.</p>

<p>The entry-level GT V8 is powered by a 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 that produces 500 hp and 487 lb-ft of torque, but the V8 S’ engine produces more at 520 hp and 502 lb-ft and delivers an EPA-rated 15/25 mpg city/highway and 14/24 mpg for the convertible (2017). The GT is equipped with a 582-hp, 531-lb-ft 6.0-liter twin-turbo W-12 engine and is rated at 12/20 mpg. The 6.0-liter twin-turbo W-12 engine in the GT Speed produces 633 hp and 620 lb-ft but the Supersports is tuned to produce a whopping 700 hp and 750 lb-ft. All engines are backed by an eight-speed automatic and are only available with all-wheel drive. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 Bentley Continental Supersports hit 60 mph in 3.5 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 115 feet.</p>

<p>All Continental GT models feature an 8.0-inch multimedia touchscreen with a navigation system, SiriusXM satellite radio, a 30 GB hard drive, Bluetooth, and an available Wi-Fi hotspot. The standard 420-watt, eight-speaker audio system uses Balanced Mode Radiator speaker technology. The upgraded 1,100-watt Naim audio system features 11 Balanced Mode Radiator speakers.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/continental-gt/2017/2017-bentley-continental-supersports-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2017 Bentley Continental Supersports, we noted that even though the car is the fastest Bentley road car in history, “it remains, above all, a luxury car.” “The Supersports rides 0.4 inch lower than regular Conti GTs. Spring and damper rates are stiffer—up 45 percent at the front, and 35 percent at the rear—and the rear stabilizer bar is 50 percent stiffer. Bushes throughout the suspension have been stiffened between 30 and 70 percent,” we said. “That W-12 engine is utterly magnificent, delivering imperious thrust that simply demolishes distances between corners. Artfully tuned exhaust rumble apart, the big Bentley is otherwise so smooth and refined you tend to arrive at corners carrying much more speed than you expect,” we continued. However, “it’s no track rat, the Bentley Continental Supersports— it’s simply too big, too heavy.” “It’s the last of the line, this Supersports. An all-new Continental GT, built using the very different front/mid-engine vehicle architecture shared with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/panamera/2018/">Porsche Panamera</a>, will make its debut later this year. But it’s the best of the lot,” we concluded.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/continental-gt/2016/2016-bentley-continental-gt-speed-convertible-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2016 Bentley Continental GT Speed, we said that “piloting the Continental GT Speed Convertible through the canyons is definitely entertaining, if not comical. We expected a clumsy mess, but instead got cool and composed.”</p>

<p>“While the canyons were fun,” we continued, “the Bentley excels on the open highway. The air suspension does an outstanding job of erasing road blemishes and there are zero hints of wind noise. We wouldn’t be surprised if that soft top were bulletproof. To get an idea of how quiet it is at highway speeds, ride in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/s-class/">Mercedes S-Class</a> while wearing earplugs. It’s that silent.” Unfortunately, “the tech, however, is woefully stuck in the early 2000s. The voice command system obeys just as well as a pug puppy and connecting Bluetooth devices requires a clumsy process done with the steering wheel controls and not the main touchscreen. USB ports? Zero,” we said. We concluded by saying, “Despite our test car’s technological shortcomings and eye-searing shade of paint, it’s very much a timeless cruiser and a rolling expression of economic privilege with an as-tested price of $289,795. That said, there are other options with just as much exclusivity, but a tad more tech.”</p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/">Bentley</a> added plenty of updates for the Bentayga’s second model year including a seven-passenger seating option, new 21- and 22-inch wheel options, fluted seating, a Liquid Amber veneer option, an optional Breitling clock, a Blackline package, additional interior color options, and gloss black exhaust finishers.</p>

<p>The Bentayga is Bentley’s only SUV and part of the automaker’s lineup that includes the Continental GT coupe and convertible, the Flying Spur sedan, and the range-topping Mulsanne sedan.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/bentayga/2018/">2018 Bentley Bentayga</a>: </strong>The Bentayga is powered by a twin-turbo W-12 engine and comes standard with black-painted brake calipers, an air suspension system with four adjustable heights, 21-inch wheels, full LED adaptive headlights with high beam assist, LED taillights, large oval exhaust finishers, a panoramic sunroof, a leather headliner, Burr Walnut veneer, a premium leather-trimmed steering wheel, a leather and chrome-trimmed gear shifter, Bentley embossed door sills, and an 8.0-inch infotainment touchscreen with a navigation system and a 60 GB hard drive, SiriusXM satellite radio, a 10-speaker audio system, and the Mulliner Driving Specification package that includes diamond-quilted seats, drilled alloy pedals, Bentley emblems embroidered on the seats, and a full selection of leather, carpet, and color combinations.</p>

<p>The Bentayga can be customized or ordered in unique visual packages that include Molten Bronze, Big Skies, Quicksilver, Roulette, Stonecutter, and Alpine Air.</p>

<p><strong>2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/bentayga/2018/">Bentley Bentayga</a> Mulliner</strong>: The very well-equipped Bentayga Mulliner adds the Color Specification (two-tone interior color options), the All-Terrain Specification (adds four off-road driving modes and underfloor protection), the City Specification (a self-parking system, traffic sign recognition, pedestrian detection, a surround-view camera system, rear-cross traffic alert, and an automatic emergency braking system), the Touring Specification (adaptive cruise control, a head-up display, lane keep assist, a semi-autonomous driving system, and a night vision system), and the Sunshine Specification (electric sun blinds on the rear side windows and double sun visors). The Mulliner trim also adds 22-inch Mulliner wheels, Ombre Burr Walnut fade veneer, LED welcome lights, a console drink cooler, and the Naim audio system.</p>

<p>Unique visual packages include Monsoon, Dusk, Flare, Bamboo, Sterling, Cambric, and Sirius. Additional options include ambient lighting, a rear entertainment system, front and rear-seat ventilation with massaging function, a two-tone premium leather-trimmed steering wheel, and veneered rear foldable tables.</p>

<p>The Bentayga is powered by a 600 hp and 664 lb-ft of torque 6.0-liter twin-turbo W-12 engine back by an eight-speed automatic that routes power to a standard all-wheel drive system. The powertrain delivers an EPA-rated 12/19 mpg city/highway. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, a European-spec 2017 Bentley Bentayga hit 60 mph in a quick 3.5 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 119 feet. Look for an eight-cylinder model for the 2019 model year.</p>

<p>The Bentayga’s driver assist safety features are found in two packages: The City package consists of a self-parking system, traffic sign recognition, pedestrian detection, a surround-view camera system, and a low-speed automatic emergency braking system. The Touring package includes adaptive cruise control, lane keep assist, a semi-autonomous driving system, and a night vision system.</p>

<p>In the Bentayga’s five-seat configuration, the SUV can hold 17.1 cubic feet of cargo behind the rear seats, 15.2 cubic feet behind its four-seat configuration, and 7.6 when equipped with the seven-seat option. When the rear seats of the five-seat configuration are folded down, the Bentayga can hold 62.6 cubic feet of cargo.</p>

<p>The Bentayga’s standard tech includes an 8.0-inch infotainment touchscreen with a navigation system, a 60 GB hard drive, SiriusXM satellite radio, and a 10-speaker audio system. The upgraded audio system is a 700-watt, 12-speaker system. The top 1950-watt Naim system utilizes 21 speakers, including a 300-watt subwoofer and two super tweeters. The rear entertainment system features two 10.2-inch displays with two wireless headphones with USB and micro SD ports. Two packages of driver assist safety features are available.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/bentayga/2017/2017-bentley-bentayga-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 Bentley Bentayga, we were very impressed with the SUV’s very quick acceleration, the quickest we have ever tested at the time. The quiet interior is covered in premium leather and has a good driving position, outward visibility, and first-rate ergonomics. The transmission is “smooth as silk, but it lacks the quick-fire, perfectly imperceptible shifts that, for example, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/">BMW</a>’s engineers make [a similar transmission] accomplish.” The W-12 engine is very smooth and delivers an exhaust note that “strikes the perfect balance of sporty and elegant.” We also liked the Dynamic Ride feature that keeps the Bentayga flat through the corners.</p>

<p>Unfortunately, the Bentayga looks and sometimes feels a little too much like the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/">Audi</a> Q7 that it’s based on. Because it’s not based on another Bentley vehicle, the interior is missing “the massive width that defines Bentley’s coupes and sedans,” we said. “Although the rear buckets in our four-seat version, which are similar in design to the fronts, are comfortable, they present no luxurious sense of First Class.” The large wheels and low profile tires send sharp impacts into the cabin and steering is absent of any feel. The W-12 engine is strong but “under full throttle, the Bentayga rears back on its haunches and sprays the cars in front with photons from its superbright LED headlights. Under braking, the front end dives significantly,” we said.</p>

<p>“This might be the fastest, quickest internal-combustion SUV ever, but just like the ability to seat seven people, the 187-mph top speed is a marketing tool that most will never take advantage of. The reality is that the Bentayga isn’t going to sell on its cornering behavior; it’ll sell on its price and its looks,” we concluded.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/bentayga/2017/2017-bentley-bentayga-second-drive-review/">Second Drive review</a> of the 2017 Bentley Bentayga, we enjoyed the SUV’s ride so much that “on the pristinely paved, undulating, and winding byways snaking through the rocky hills above Málaga, Spain, this 5,400-pound brute felt virtually indistinguishable from a Continental GT W12 from a dynamic standpoint.” The braking was “smooth, strong, fade-free whoa the whole way down out of the hills at the kinds of speeds one might expect with mobs of pitchfork-wielding commoners in pursuit, driving Grand Cherokee SRTs,” we said.</p>

<p>“Another observation: The auto-start/stop and cylinder deactivation features are among the least noticeable in the biz,” we added. Off-road, you probably won’t go “far enough into the wilderness to escape determined <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/">Land Rover</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/">Jeep</a> pursuers, but with the wheel articulation afforded by those active anti-roll bars, plus 9.6 inches of max ground clearance and the ability to wade through 19.7-inch-deep water, this truck will go farther than its owners ever would of their own accord.”</p>

<p>We concluded by saying, “Most of the gripes I was able to muster sound like plebian whining: Why must we pay an extra $7,870 for a package with active cruise control, lane keeping assist, a head-up display, and night vision? Why doesn’t that lane keeping assist system work as well as a <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a>’s? Why, with 17 standard paint colors, do all the cool colors cost between $5,715 and $12,530?”</p>

<p>There are no significant changes to the Mulsanne for the 2018 model year.</p>

<p>The Mulsanne sedan is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/">Bentley</a>’s flagship model.</p>

<p><strong>2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/mulsanne/2018/">Bentley Mulsanne</a></strong>: A twin-turbo V-8 powers the large sedan, which comes standard with Bentley-branded brake calipers, air suspension with continuous damping control and four selectable modes, a choice of 25 exterior paint colors, 20-inch alloy wheels, full LED headlights, LED taillights, oval stainless steel exhaust finishers, polished stainless steel exterior trim, a choice of 24 premium leather interior colors (can be monotone or two-tone), a leather headliner, a choice of five veneers, a leather-trimmed four-spoke steering wheel, a leather and chrome-trimmed shift lever, polished stainless steel Mulsanne embossed doors sill plates, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, SiriusXM satellite radio, and a 14-speaker, six-channel audio system.</p>

<p>You can customize your Mulsanne or order one of six visual packages called Nimbus; Dusk; Blue Skies, Bright Days; Fire and Passion; Power of Contrast, and Subtle Sensuality.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Bentley Mulsanne Speed</strong>: The Speed packs a more powerful version of the twin-turbo V-8 engine and adds a sports mode with a lowered ride height to the air suspension system, 21-inch painted Speed alloy wheels, full LED dark headlights, a choice of many interior color combinations including the unique Speed interior, Bentley embossed headrests, an indented leather headliner, a leather-trimmed knurled gear lever, diamond quilted seat design, and drilled alloy sport pedals. The Speed can be optioned with the Speed Premier package which includes 21-inch dark or polished Speed wheels, a Flying B radiator ornament, a valet key, a veneered iPod drawer and minor gauge panel, and two city umbrellas.</p>

<p>The Mulsanne Speed can be ordered in one of its visual packages, which are called Bullion, Red Mercury, Mercurial, Magma, Oceanic, and Cool Crystal.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Bentley Mulsanne Extended Wheelbase</strong>: The Mulsanne Extended Wheelbase adds 9.8 inches of legroom for the rear passengers and comes standard with the same features as the regular Mulsanne but adds unique optional features like rear airline style seats, a full rear center console with folding picnic tables, and a large rear sunroof with an Alcantara sunblind.</p>

<p>The Mulsanne Extended Wheelbase’s available visual packages include Synchronicity, Gun Metal, Voyage, Quiet Intensity, Mariana, and Velveteen.</p>

<p>Optional features for the Mulsanne include a choice of 21-inch wheels, a choice of extended range paints (including two-tone options), veneered door panels, ventilated front and rear seats with massaging function, lambswool front and rear floor mats, a Naim audio system, a rear seat entertainment system, a refrigerated bottle cooler, black rear curtains, a front corner view camera, and adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p>The Mulsanne and Mulsanne Extended Wheelbase are powered by a 6.8-liter twin-turbo V-8 that produces 505 hp and 752 lb-ft of torque. The Mulsanne Speed uses the same engine but tuned to produce 530 hp and 811 lb-ft. An eight-speed automatic routes power to the rear wheels and the sedan comes with an EPA rating of 11/18 mpg city/highway. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2015 Bentley Mulsanne Speed hit 60 mph in 5.0 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in an impressive 110 feet.</p>

<p>The Bentley Mulsanne and Mulsanne Extended Wheelbase can hold 15.7 cubic feet of cargo in the trunk.</p>

<p>All Mulsanne models feature an 8.0-inch multimedia touchscreen with a navigation system, SiriusXM satellite radio, a 20 GB hard drive, Bluetooth, and a 14-speaker, two subwoofers, six-channel audio system. The upgraded 2,200-watt Naim audio system utilizes 20 speakers and is custom-made for the Mulsanne. The rear seat entertainment system consists of two 10.4-inch monitors that electronically deploy from the seat backs at the touch of a button. Adaptive cruise control and a front corner view camera system are optional.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/mulsanne/2017/2017-bentley-mulsanne-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the refreshed 2017 Bentley Mulsanne, we concluded our review by saying “the 2017 Bentley Mulsanne ups its game in all the right areas to keep it competitive with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/rolls-royce/">Rolls-Royce</a> Phantom at the top end of the ultra-luxury segment and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>-Maybach at the entry-level end. To most of us, a sedan whose base model starts at $340,670 seems an extravagance that’s impossible to justify. But to those who can afford it, the fact the Mulsanne is painstakingly assembled by skilled craftspeople—it takes 150 hours to assemble an interior that, among other things, contains 480 individual pieces of leather and 40 bits of carefully matched and highly polished wood veneer—makes it more than just another car.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/mulsanne/2016/bentley-mulsanne-speed-vs-mercedes-maybach-s600/">comparison</a> between the 2016 Bentley Mulsanne Speed and the 2016 Mercedes-Maybach S600, we said, “That’s where the Mulsanne Speed bests the Maybach S600, and why the price is essentially double. There are men in Crewe with bulging forearms holding chisels that perform the woodworking. The leather is crafted using a pre-1955 tanning process,” we said. “The Maybach, on the other hand, comes off the S-Class assembly line in Sindelfingen, using many of the same parts as the $95,000 model (can you even imagine?),” we continued.</p>

<p>The new Flying Spur V8 S Black Edition features 21-inch gloss black wheels, beluga exterior trim, dark tint headlights and taillights, red brake calipers, a sports steering wheel, and contrast stitching. Additionally, there is also a new design series by Mulliner.</p>

<p>The Flying Spur is the sedan version of the two-door Continental GT and is part of <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/">Bentley</a>’s lineup which also includes the Mulsanne and Bentayga.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/flying-spur/2018/">2018 Bentley Flying Spur</a> V8</strong>: The Flying Spur V8 is powered by a twin-turbo V-8 and comes standard with 19-inch painted alloy wheels, black brake calipers, touring-tuned air suspension with continuous damping control and height adjustment, choice of seven exterior colors, HID headlights with LED daytime running lights, full LED taillights with special trim details inside the lamp, figure-eight stainless steel exhaust finishers, a choice of four premium leather interior colors, an Eliade cloth headliner, Dark Fiddleback Eucalyptus veneer, premium leather-trimmed three-spoke steering wheel, a leather and chrome-trimmed gear shifter, seating for five, Bentley embossed door sill plates, an 8.0-inch infotainment screen, SiriusXM satellite radio, and an eight-speaker audio system featuring Balanced Mode Radiator speakers.</p>

<p>The Flying Spur can be customized or ordered in six packages with unique color combinations: Eclipse, Lifeblood, Inner Fire, Hidden Depths, The Classicist, and The Tuscan.</p>

<p><strong>2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/flying-spur/2018/">Bentley Flying Spur</a> V8 S</strong>: The Flying Spur V8 S is powered by a more powerful twin-turbo V-8 and adds 20-inch painted wheels, a sport-tuned air-suspension system with continuous damping control, a choice of 17 exterior colors, Red “B” badging, a choice of 17 premium leather colors including the unique V8 S color combination, a leather headliner, piano black veneer, a premium leather-trimmed sports steering wheel, a leather-trimmed knurled gear shifter, and V8 S embossed door sills.</p>

<p>Unique visual packages include Deep Flame, Black Light, Silver Sphere, Cool Crystal, Halcyon, and Sunrise.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Bentley Flying Spur</strong>: The Flying Spur is powered by a twin-turbo W-12 and come standard with touring-tuned air suspension with continuous damping control, a choice of 17 exterior paint colors, 20-inch painted and diamond-turned wheels, a W-12 badge on the rear pillar, HID headlights with LED daytime running lights, full LED taillights with special trim details inside the lamp, dual oval stainless steel exhaust finishers, choice of 17 interior premium leather colors, a leather headliner, Burr Walnut veneer, a premium leather and chrome trimmed gear shifter, and the Comfort Specification package that includes front and rear seat ventilation with massaging and rear seat front passenger seat controls.</p>

<p>Unique visual packages include Almost Midnight, Alter Ego, Cool Stone, Blue Fusion, Fire on Ice, and Monte Carlo.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Bentley Flying Spur W12 S</strong>: Building off the features of the Flying Spur, the W-12 S adds a more powerful twin-turbo W-12, black or red painted calipers, sport-tuned air suspension, 21-inch black alloy wheels, dark HID headlights with LED accents, dark LED taillights, embroidered Bentley or W12 S emblems to the headrests, piano black veneer, a black tint aluminum fascia, a sports plus premium leather-trimmed steering wheel, a premium-leather trimmed knurled gear shifter, diamond-quilted seating, and drilled alloy pedals.</p>

<p>Ember, Tourmaline, Chroma, Lustre, Cirrus, and Blaze are the visual packages offered on the Flying Spur W12 S model.</p>

<p>Available features include adaptive cruise control, a valet key, rear foldable tables, a refrigerated bottle cooler, a choice of extended range of exterior colors, choice of 21-inch wheels, a power sunroof, an Alcantara headliner, semi-aniline leather seats and door panel inserts, a Naim audio system, and a Wi-Fi hotspot.</p>

<p>The Flying Spur V8 is powered by a twin-turbo V-8 that develops 521-hp, 487 lb-ft of torque and 521 hp and 502 lb-ft in the V8 S. The V-8 delivers an EPA-rated 13/22 mpg city/highway. The 6.0-liter twin-turbo W-12 develops 616 hp and 590 lb-ft in the Flying Spur and 626 hp and 605 lb-ft in the W12 S. The W-12 engines rated at 12/20 mpg. Both engines are backed by an eight-speed automatic that routes power to a standard all-wheel drive system. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2014 Bentley Flying Spur (with the same powertrain as the 2018 model) hit 60 mph in 4.3 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in an impressive 106 feet.</p>

<p>The Bentley Flying Spur can hold 16.7 cubic feet of cargo in the trunk.</p>

<p>The Flying Spur features an 8.0-inch multimedia screen with a navigation system, SiriusXM satellite radio, and Bluetooth. The upgraded Naim audio system utilizes 11 Balanced Mode speakers. Other optional tech features include adaptive cruise control, a wireless privacy phone, a 4G Wi-Fi hotspot, and a SIM card reader with Google Maps.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/flying-spur/2015/2015-bentley-flying-spur-v8-first-drive/">First Drive review</a> of the 2015 Bentley Flying Spur V8, we said that although the W12 model might be slightly quicker, the eight-cylinder variant “remains plenty swift, its throttle response noticeably more alert, and its thirst for premium petrol reduced by about 13 percent.” We liked the V-8 engine so much, in fact, that even if we hadn’t known how much money the eight-cylinder model saves, we’d still prefer that power plant.</p>

<p>“The rest of the car is pretty much the familiar W12 with an eight-speed automatic and all-wheel drive, plus all the same hyper-cosseted opulence inside. Lovely, lovely car,” we continued. We concluded by saying, “Bentley has used different badge colors before — black, red, green, and even yellow – to signal various engines and special editions. But in the case of the new Flying Spur V8, its red shouldn’t be seen as a signal to stop, but a green light to go get this version instead.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/flying-spur/2014/2014-bentley-flying-spur-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 12-cylinder 2014 Bentley Flying Spur, we were very impressed with the smooth and quick acceleration of the very heavy sedan: “The big Bentley rockets to 60 mph in just 4.3 seconds, and does so with little effort or drama.” We also felt the eight-speed automatic transmission was smooth and shifted quickly. Although the Flying Spur softly glides through roads most of the time, “there were a few occasions when the sedan couldn’t completely mask potholes and bumps. We’ll chalk that up to the large, two-piece, 21-inch rims and low-profile Pirelli P Zero tires.”</p>

<p>Out on the track, the steering was responsive and the brakes were strong, stopping in only 106 feet from 60 mph. The interior was one of the impressive ones we’d ever seen with high-quality materials and solid construction, but the infotainment system “still feels much more antiquated compared to the competition.”</p>

<p>“If your idea of special is punishing Mustangs while relishing old-school craftsmanship and comfort, then the Flying Spur is your car,” we concluded.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>For the 2018 7 Series, minor updates include the Active Driving Assistant as a standalone option on the 740 models, and the Driver Assistance Plus II package is no longer offered (its features are now in the Driving Assistance Plus package).</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The 7 Series is the flagship model for <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/">BMW</a>, the largest and most expensive offered by the German automaker and is positioned above the 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 Series models.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The base <strong>740i</strong> (RWD) and 740i xDrive (AWD) models are powered by a 320-hp, 330-lb-ft of torque, 3.0-liter turbocharged I-6, and have an EPA-rating of 21/29 mpg city/highway and 20/29 mpg in RWD and AWD forms. The <strong>750i</strong> and 750i xDrive models pack a 4.4-liter twin-turbo V-8 that produces 445 hp and 480 lb-ft and is rated at 16/25 mpg and 17/25 mpg for the xDrive. The <strong>740e </strong>xDrive iPerformance<strong> plug-in</strong> model utilizes a 255-hp, 295 lb-ft 2.0-liter turbo-four paired to an electric motor that has a combined power output 322 hp and 369 lb-ft and delivers 27 mpg combined. Thanks to the large battery pack, the 740e can drive up to 14 miles on all-electric power. The uber-luxurious <strong>Alpina B7</strong> xDrive uses the same 4.4-liter twin-turbo V-8 but tuned to produce 600 hp and 590 lb-ft and delivers 16/25 mpg. The range-topping <strong>M760i</strong> xDrive is powered by a 6.5-liter twin-turbo V-12 that churns out an impressive 601 hp and 590 lb-ft and is rated at 13/20 mpg. All engine are backed by an eight-speed automatic.</p>

<p>Like many flagships, the 7 Series comes standard with many premium options including 18-inch V-spoke light alloy wheels, adaptive LED headlights, Dakota leather upholstery, a 14-way power front seats, high-gloss Fineline wood trim, a 16-speaker Harman Kardon surround sound audio system, Display Key with a LCD touchscreen, leather-wrapped sport steering wheel, a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, a 10.2-inch display screen with 3D navigation, Gesture Control, 4-zone climate control, panoramic moonroof, and the iDrive 6.0 system with touchpad controller. Standard equipment in the range-topping M760i consists of 20-inch double spoke light alloy wheels, Adaptive full LED headlights, M rear spoiler, 20-way power multi-contour front seats, Nappa leather upholstery, illuminated door sills with V12 logo, M leather steering wheel, full-color head-up display, parking assistant, and heated front and rear seats. If you expect to be driven around, opt for the rear executive lounge seating package and your 7 Series will receive adjustable rear comfort seats, adjustable rear foot rest, rear seat entertainment screens with a 7.0-inch Touch Command Tablet, a foldable table for the right rear passenger, and rear massaging seats.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>
