<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/corvette/2018/">Chevrolet Corvette</a> is the quintessential rear-wheel drive American sports car and is available as a coupe with a removable roof or a convertible. In addition to the standard model, other models from this generation of Corvette have included Grand Sport and the higher-performance Z06.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>With the exception of the rumored mid-engine Corvette, the most anticipated variant of the iconic sports car is the Corvette ZR1, which will likely be the most powerful model to date, with more grunt than the Z06, which is currently rated at 650 hp. If the next Corvette ZR1 debuts for the 2018 model year, expect it to feature a full aero package to help it handle better and stick to the road. The car should also come with wider tires, and an even more aggressive suspension setup, Magnetic Ride Control, and an actie rear spoiler for additional downforce.</p>

<p>We’ll update this space as soon as we have official info on the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/corvette/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Corvette</a> — until then, check out <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/spied-mid-engine-chevrolet-corvette-caught-winter-testing-zr1/"><strong>spy shots</strong></a> of the mid-engine Corvette alongside a ZR1 prototype <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/spied-mid-engine-chevrolet-corvette-caught-winter-testing-zr1/"><strong>HERE</strong></a>.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The new LT Driver Confidence package includes rear parking sensors, rear cross-traffic alert, and blind-spot monitoring. Vinyl now wraps the steering wheel and shift knob on the LT model and two new colors are available: Green Mist Metallic and Cajun Red Tintcoat.</p>

<p>In <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevy</a>’s electrified lineup, the all-electric Bolt EV has a higher starting price (not including tax incentives).</p>

<p><strong>2018 Volt LT</strong>: The base Volt LT trim comes well-equipped with an 8.0-inch LCD instrument panel driver’s display, an 8.0-inch center touchscreen display with <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a> MyLink and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, satellite radio, 2 USB ports, OnStar Guidance, and OnStar 4G LTE with Wi-Fi hotspot. Also standard are six-way manual adjustable front seats, four drive modes (Normal, Sport, Mountain, and Hold), remote engine start, LED headlights and taillights, LED interior lighting, and 17-inch aluminum wheels.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Volt Premier</strong>: The top Premier trim adds leather-appointed seats, heated front and rear seats, leather-wrapped and heated steering wheel, a self-parking system, front and rear parking sensors, wireless phone charging, a Bose premium sound system, and 17-inch ultra-bright machined aluminum wheels with painted pockets.</p>

<p>For additional safety, the Premier trim is available with two driver assist packages—learn more about them below.</p>

<p>The Volt’s electric drive system consists of a 101-hp, 103 lb-ft of torque 1.5-liter I-4 engine paired to an electric motor for a total system output of 149 hp and a potent 294 lb-ft of torque. A CVT routes power to the front wheels. The Volt can drive up to an EPA-rated 53 miles on all-electric power (106 mpg-e) and delivers 43/42 mpg city/highway when in hybrid mode. Charging a depleted battery takes approximately 13 hours using a 120-volt (Level 1) charger and 4.5 hours using a 240-volt (Level 2 charger). In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 Volt Premier hit 60 mph in a quick-for-a-hybrid 7.5 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 116 feet.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/volt/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Volt</a> is an IIHS 2018 Top Safety Pick for receiving the highest rating of Good in all five conducted crash tests and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention evaluation by avoiding 12- and 25 mph frontal collisions thanks to the optional forward automatic braking system that comes with the available adaptive cruise control system and is part of the Volt’s features-list if you have both Driver Confidence packages. When the Volt is only equipped with the low speed forward automatic braking system found in the Driver Confidence package II, the car avoided the 12 mph collision in IIHS testing and reduced speed in a 25 mph collision test by 5 mph. The LT Driver Confidence package adds three driver assist features: rear parking sensors, rear cross-traffic alert, and blind-spot monitoring with lane change alert. The previously mentioned Driver Confidence package II also includes forward collision alert, lane keep assist, a following distance indicator, and automatic high beams.</p>

<p>The Volt only offers 10.6 cubic feet of cargo space thanks to the large battery pack. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/prius/2018/">Toyota Prius</a> Prime, which has an EV range of only 25 miles before the gas engine kicks in, almost doubles that with 19.8 cubic feet of cargo space. The Volt has 42.1 inches of front seat legroom and 34.7 inches of rear legroom, the Prius Prime offers 43.2 inches of legroom for the front passengers and 33.4 inches for the rear.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/volt/2018/">Chevrolet Volt</a> comes well-equipped with Chevrolet’s MyLink infotainment system displayed on an 8.0-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, Bluetooth phone and streaming audio, satellite radio, and two USB ports. The Volt also comes standard with an 8.0-inch LCD driver’s instrument panel screen, four driving modes (Normal, Sport, Mountain, and Hold), remote engine start, OnStar Guidance, OnStar 4G LTE with a Wi-Fi hotspot, and OnStar Basic. Available technology includes a self-parking system, Chevrolet MyLink with Navigation and SiriusXM Nav Traffic, and an eight-speaker Bose premium audio system.</p>

<p>When we compared the Chevrolet Volt to the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/prius-prime/2018/">Toyota Prius Prime</a> in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/bolt-ev/2017/hyundai-ioniq-hybrid-vs-toyota-prius-chevrolet-volt-vs-prius-prime-bolt-ev-vs-ioniq-ev-vs-honda-clarity-vs-mirai/">large alternative fuel vehicle comparison</a>, we commended the Volt’s long 53-mile all-electric driving range, planted handling, and comfortable ride. However, the interior packaging is bad, leaving very little headroom for the rear passengers. In the end, the Prius Prime won the comparison: “So despite the Prius Prime’s peculiarities (the recorded piano accompaniment to ingress and egress sounds like the sappy soundtrack to a daytime soap opera), its usability, packaging, acceptable EV range, and much better hybrid-mode mileage give it the edge.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/volt/2016/2016-chevrolet-volt-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2016 Chevrolet Volt, we liked the Volt’s longer electric range, lighter weight, good brake feel for a hybrid, and modern design. We were surprised by the very agile handling when testing is around the figure-eight course, “The car moves as a coherent whole, balanced, responsive, reminding me of how suited a properly integrated electric drivetrain is for serious driving.” We concluded by saying, “This isn’t just another Volt, a second one, a slightly better one, a $1200 cheaper one. Or one to kinda ignore because we’ve been there, done that, and the i3 and Mirai seem more, <em>au current</em>. This Volt is a whole new deal, as revolutionary as anything else out there. Try it again.”</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/malibu/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Malibu</a> gets a special Redline Edition model based on the LT trim that gets black bowtie logos, black nameplates with red highlights, 19-inch black alloy wheels with red accents, black side mirror covers, and a black grille. A new exterior color, Sandy Ridge Metallic, has been added for the 2018 model year.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/malibu/2018/">Chevrolet Malibu</a> is a front-drive midsize sedan that slots above the compact Cruze and below the full-size Impala. In addition to the gas-powered variant, the 2018 Malibu is also available as a hybrid. Gas-powered models are available in four trims while the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/malibu-hybrid/2018/">Malibu Hybrid</a> in a single grade.</p>

<p><strong>Malibu L: </strong>The base Malibu L gets 16-inch steel wheels, a six-speaker audio system, Bluetooth, keyless entry/start, a 3.5-inch instrument cluster info display, and daytime running lights.</p>

<p><strong>Malibu LS: </strong>Moving up to the LS grade gets you 16-inch alloy wheels, a rearview camera, a USB port, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a>’s MyLink infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, as well as Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration.</p>

<p><strong>Malibu LT: </strong>Jumping up to the LT model adds 17-inch alloy wheels, ambient lighting, an eight-way power-operated driver’s seat, and LED daytime running lights.</p>

<p><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/malibu-hybrid/2018/"><strong>Malibu Hybrid</strong></a><strong>: </strong>Positioned as the second highest model, the Malibu Hybrid comes with the same equipment as the LT trim plus its own unique instrument cluster and dual-zone climate control.</p>

<p><strong>Malibu Premier: </strong>Currently the most powerful model and the range-topper, the Malibu Premier adds LED taillights, a powerful 2.0-liter turbo-four, 18-inch alloy wheels, remote start, a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, a nine-speaker Bose premium audio system, two additional USB ports, a wireless charging pad, ventilated front seats, six-way power adjustable front passenger seat, leather upholstery, a heated steering wheel, navigation, and 4.2-inch instrument cluster info display.</p>

<p>Available features include a panoramic sunroof, 19-inch alloy wheels, front and rear parking sensors, an electric parking brake and automatic parking assist.</p>

<p>The 2018 Malibu comes standard with a 1.5-liter turbo-four with 163 hp and 184 lb-ft of torque and it’s paired to a six-speed automatic transmission. A 2.0-liter turbo-four rated at 250 hp and 260 lb-ft is available only on the Premier trim and is paired to a nine-speed automatic transmission. The Malibu Hybrid features a 1.8-liter I-4 paired to an electric motor, a lithium-ion battery, and a CVT with a combined output of 182 hp.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings are 27/36 mpg city/highway for the 1.5-liter turbo-four, 22/32 mpg for the 2.0-liter turbo-four, and 49/43 mpg for the hybrid.</p>

<p>The 2018 Malibu received a five-star overall rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 Malibu received a Good rating on all crashworthiness tests except for the passenger side front small overlap impact and headlights test where it got a Marginal and Poor score respectively (Good is the highest possible score). In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the 2018 Malibu received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the severity of a 25-mph impact by 24 mph (Superior is the highest score for front crash prevention test). As a result, the 2018 Malibu received the IIHS’ 2017 Top Safety Pick rating.</p>

<p>Available on the LT and Premier trims is the Driver Confidence package, which adds automatic high beams, following distance indicator, forward collision warning, lane change alert, blind spot warning, lane keeping assist, pedestrian detection, and low-speed automatic emergency braking. The Driver Confidence II package, which is available only on the Premier trim, adds adaptive cruise control and an automatic emergency braking system that works at higher speeds.</p>

<p>The 2018 Malibu has a 15.8-cubic-foot trunk that can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats. Hybrid variants have less trunk space at 11.6 cubic feet.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/malibu/2016/2016-chevrolet-malibu-15t-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we said that the low-rolling resistance tires hurt its braking performance. Its limit handling takes a hit because of the eco-focused rubber but it rides comfortably and steering feel is reasonably good for a midsize sedan focused on comfort. The 1.5-liter turbo-four isn’t very powerful but it has plenty of usable power for daily driving. Interior quality on lower trims, however, is disappointing with plenty of hard plastics and cloth that feels cheap. Chevrolet’s MyLink infotainment system is easy to use and the rear seats are spacious.</p>

<p>The more powerful Malibu 2.0T offers plenty of power on tap even with passengers in the car. Its handling is also much improved thanks to its wider tires, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/malibu/2017/2017-chevrolet-malibu-20t-premier-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>. There’s also a generous amount of tech available on the Malibu such as wireless phone charging, multiple USB ports and Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, which should make it easy to stay connected.</p>

<p>We were impressed with the Malibu Hybrid in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/malibu-hybrid/2016/2016-chevrolet-malibu-hybrid-second-drive-review/">2016 Second Drive review</a> thanks to its linear-feeling brakes and a hybrid system that operated smoothly, and didn’t call attention to itself when the gas engine and electric motor were interacting. There’s enough power on tap but you have to bury your foot into the accelerator so that the car knows you want full power. Like its more powerful 2.0-liter turbo-four-equipped sibling, the Malibu Hybrid handles reasonably well for a midsize sedan with precise steering, good body control, and minimal understeer, all while maintaining a comfortable ride. Tire noise, however, can get excessive and some of the plastics in the cabin feel cheap.</p>

<p>The current-generation Chevrolet Malibu was the first to utilize GM’s new 1.5-liter turbo-four, a more powerful version of which is now found on the Equinox and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/terrain/2018/">GMC Terrain</a>.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/traverse/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Traverse</a> is all-new and rides on a new platform for midsize and large crossovers. It sports exterior styling that’s less rounded than its predecessor.</p>

<p>The 2018 Traverse is a full-size three-row crossover that slots below that larger Tahoe and above the smaller Equinox, and can seat up to eight passengers. Front-wheel drive comes standard and all-wheel drive is optional on all trims except the range-topping High Country trim, where AWD is standard.</p>

<p><strong>Traverse L: </strong>Well-equipped from the start, the base L trim comes standard with a rearview camera, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a>’s MyLink infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, 18-inch alloy wheels, HID headlights, six USB ports, a 3.5-inch multi-information display, keyless entry/start, tri-zone climate control, and the Teen Driver feature that monitors your teenager’s driving habits.</p>

<p><strong>Traverse LS: </strong>The LS adds tinted glass on top of the L’s long list of standard features.</p>

<p><strong>Traverse LT Cloth: </strong>The LT Cloth trim adds fog lights, roof rails, second-row captain’s chairs, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and Bright Silver 18-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Traverse LT Leather: </strong>Moving up to the more upscale LT Leather trim gets you rear parking sensors, a 360-degree view camera system, navigation, a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, heated front seats, leather upholstery, remote start, a programmable power liftgate, a Bose premium audio system, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, and 20-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Traverse RS: </strong>As the sportier trim of the Traverse, the RS adds dark 20-inch alloy wheels, black badges, black roof rails, and black window surrounds in addition to all the standard features found on the LT Leather grade. The Traverse RS also gets a powerful turbo-four instead of the V-6 on other trims.</p>

<p><strong>Traverse Premier: </strong>One of two luxury-oriented trims, the Traverse Premier adds 20-inch metallic alloy wheels, a wireless device charger, LED headlights, a hands-free power liftgate, memory settings for the driver’s seat, a heated steering wheel, perforated leather upholstery, ventilated front seats, and heated second-row captain’s chairs.</p>

<p><strong>Traverse High Country: </strong>The range-topping High Country grade adds polished 20-inch alloy wheels, a panoramic sunroof, a power-folding third row, a heavy-duty cooling system, trailer hitch, and a two-tone black and brown leather upholstery.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/traverse/2018/">Chevrolet Traverse</a> is powered by either a 3.6-liter V-6 rated at 310 hp and 266 lb-ft of torque or a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 255 hp and 295 lb-ft. However, the four-cylinder is available exclusively on the RS trim and isn’t available with all-wheel drive. Both engines are paired to a nine-speed automatic transmission that General Motors co-developed with <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a>. EPA fuel economy ratings are 18/27 mpg city/highway for V-6-powered front-drive models and 17/25 mpg with all-wheel drive. The turbo-four is the most efficient at 20/26 mpg.</p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Chevrolet Traverse. On the LT Cloth trim, blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert are available as part of the Convenience and Driver Confidence package or standard on the LT Leather and higher grades. Low speed automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, IntelliBeam headlights, following distance indicator, lane keeping assist, and lane departure warning are available on the Premier trim via the Driver Confidence II package, and they come as standard on the High Country model. Adaptive cruise control and an automatic emergency braking system that works at higher speeds is available exclusively on the High Country trim where they come as standard features.</p>

<p>When properly equipped, the 2018 Traverse can tow up to 5,000 pounds of payload. Cargo space is generous at 23 cubic feet behind the third row, 58.1 cubic feet behind the second row, and 98.2 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/traverse/2018/2018-chevrolet-traverse-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive</a>, we noted that the 3.6-liter V-6 moves the Traverse with ease and that the nine-speed automatic does its job without much drama. Despite its size, the 2018 Traverse possesses surprising good handling with minimal body roll. Interior space is generous, especially for cargo, thanks to the addition of underfloor storage. Passenger space in the third row, however, is cramped and forces occupants to sit with their knees up higher.</p>

<p>We noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/traverse/2018/2018-chevrolet-traverse-awd-first-test-review/">2018 First Test</a> that despite its newfound handling prowess, the Traverse continues to offer a smooth ride thanks to its upgraded suspension with new shock absorbers. Although it has plenty of cargo space, the Traverse is still no match for a minivan, which offers more usable space.</p>

<p>The 2018 Chevrolet Traverse shares its platform with a number of General Motors vehicles including the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/acadia/2018/">GMC Acadia</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/buick/enclave/2018/">Buick Enclave</a>.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/spark/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Spark</a> gets a new exterior color called Sorbet.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/spark/2018/">Chevrolet Spark</a> is a subcompact front-drive city car available in four trim levels including a crossover-like variant with additional ground clearance called the Spark Activ.</p>

<p><strong>Spark LS:</strong> The base LS trim comes standard with a USB port, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a>’s MyLink infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, 4G LTE connectivity, 15-inch steel wheels, a four-speaker audio system, and a rearview camera.</p>

<p><strong>Spark 1LT:</strong> Moving up to the 1LT adds cruise control, power windows and locks, keyless entry, steering wheel controls for the infotainment system, a six-speaker audio system, fog lights, 15-inch alloy wheels, and power mirrors.</p>

<p><strong>Spark Activ:</strong> The crossover-like Spark Activ adds a slightly raised suspension, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, roof rails, a unique grille and rear fascia, 15-inch alloy wheels, leatherette upholstery, and heated front seats.</p>

<p><strong>Spark 2LT:</strong> The range-topping 2LT grade adds keyless start, chrome exterior and interior door handles, rear parking sensors, and an instrument cluster info display.</p>

<p>The 2018 Chevrolet Spark is powered by a 1.4-liter I-4 with 98 hp and 94 lb-ft of torque that can be paired to either a five-speed manual transmission or a CVT. EPA fuel economy ratings for the 2018 Spark are 29/39 mpg city/highway with the manual and 30/38 mpg with the CVT. The Spark Activ is slightly less efficient at 29/38 mpg with the manual and 30/37 mpg with the CVT.</p>

<p>The NHTSA hasn’t crash tested the 2018 Chevrolet Spark. In IIHS testing, the 2018 Spark received a Good score on the moderate front overlap and side impact test (good is the highest possible score).Optional on the 2LT trim, the Driver Confidence package adds forward collision warning and lane departure warning.</p>

<p>Cargo space is limited to 11.1 cubic feet with the standard split-folding rear seats in place and 27.2 cubic feet with them folded.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/spark/2016/2016-chevrolet-spark-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we liked the Spark’s quirky interior and bright exterior color options, giving it more character. The car handles surprisingly well with good grip for a city car and the ride is comfortable despite its size. However, large imperfections easily unsettle it and there’s plenty of road and engine noise on the highway. The lack of power becomes most apparent at highway speeds with four passengers, where the Spark struggles to get up to speed. Chevrolet’s MyLink infotainment system offers Android Auto and Apple CarPlay smartphone connectivity options, making onboard navigation redundant as long as you have reception on your cell phone.</p>

<p>The 2018 Chevrolet Spark is one of three vehicles manufactured my General Motors in Korea. The other two are the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/trax/2018/">Chevrolet Trax</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/buick/encore/2018/">Buick Encore</a>.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/bolt-ev/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Bolt EV</a> gets sliding sun visors for the driver and front passenger and an automatic heated steering wheel that’s standard on the Premier trim and part of the optional Comfort and Convenience package in the base LT model.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/bolt-ev/2018/">Chevrolet Bolt EV</a> is a front-drive compact all-electric hatchback available in two trim levels.</p>

<p><strong>Bolt EV LT:</strong> The base LT trim comes standard with 17-inch alloy wheels, HID headlights, a rearview camera, single-zone automatic climate control, keyless entry/start, an 8.0-inch reconfigurable display, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a>’s MyLink infotainment system with a 10.2-inch touchscreen, 4G LTE connectivity, two USB ports, a six-speaker audio system, Bluetooth, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, and cloth upholstery.</p>

<p><strong>Bolt EV Premier:</strong> Moving up to the Premier trim adds roof rails, leather upholstery, a 360-degree view camera system, a heated steering wheel, ambient lighting, heated front and rear seats, blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p>Notable options include a seven-speaker Bose audio system, a wireless charger, and two additional USB charging ports for rear passengers.</p>

<p>The 2018 Chevrolet Bolt EV is powered by an electric motor with 200 hp and 266 lb-ft of torque backed by a single-speed transmission and a 60-kWh lithium-ion battery. On a single charge, the 2018 Bolt EV can travel up to 238 miles according to the EPA.</p>

<p>On a standard level 1 charger (a household outlet) the 2018 Bolt EV can regain 4 miles of range per hour. A level 2 charger will allow the car to fully charge from empty in a little over 9 hours while a level 3 DC fast charger allows it to gain up to 90 miles of range in 30 minutes.</p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash-tested the 2018 Bolt EV. In IIHS testing, the 2017 Bolt EV received a Good score on all crash tests except for the headlights test where it got a Poor rating and the passenger’s side small front overlap test where it hasn’t been tested (Good is the highest possible score). The 2017 model also received a Superior rating on the front crash prevention test after it avoided a 12- and a 25-mph collisions (Superior is the highest rating on the front crash prevention test). As a result, the 2017 Bolt EV received the Top Safety Pick rating from the IIHS.</p>

<p>Lane change assist, blind-spot monitoring, and rear cross-traffic alert are available on the base LT trim as part of the Driver Confidence package and are standard on the Premier trim. The Driver Confidence II package, which is only available on the Premier trim, adds lane keeping assist, forward collision warning, low-speed automatic emergency braking, pedestrian detection, automatic high beams, lane departure warning, and a following distance indicator.</p>

<p>The 2018 Bolt EV has 16.9 cubic feet of cargo space behind the 60/40 split-folding rear seats. That space can be expanded to 56.6 cubic feet when you fold down the rear seats, and there’s a two-level false floor for additional flexibility.</p>

<p>In a recent <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-3/2017/the-automobile-2-0-chevrolet-bolt-ev-premier-vs-nissan-leaf-sl-vs-tesla-model-3-long-range/">comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-3/2018/">Tesla Model 3</a> and the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> Leaf, the Chevrolet Bolt EV ranked second. We were impressed with its nimble handling and how easy it was to drive the Bolt EV with just one pedal. We were also impressed with the Bolt EV’s range and how it felt like a completely normal car. The car’s brakes feel linear and seamlessly blend regenerative and mechanical brakes.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/bolt-ev/2017/2017-chevrolet-bolt-ev-range-test-review/">2017 Range Test</a>, we liked the punchy electric motor and were impressed by how much range it can regain while regenerating when driving downhill. The Chevrolet Bolt EV was the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/chevrolet-bolt-ev-2017-car-of-the-year/">2017 <strong><em>Motor Trend</em></strong> Car of the Year</a>.</p>

<p>The 2018 Chevrolet Bolt EV’s battery pack is mounted under the passenger compartment, giving it a low center of gravity, which in turn helps improve its handling.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/impala/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Impala</a> gets keyless entry/start on all trims, standard LED daytime running lights and remote start on the LT trim, a Sunroof and Spoiler package, and a heated steering wheel on the LT grade. Three new exterior colors—Nightfall Gray Metallic, Graphite Metallic, and Cajun Red Metallic—have been added.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/impala/2018/">Chevrolet Impala</a> is a front-drive full-size sedan that slots above the midsize Malibu and is available in three trim levels.</p>

<p><strong>Impala LS:</strong> The base LS comes with keyless entry/start, 18-inch alloy wheels, cloth/leatherette upholstery, three USB ports, a multi-information display, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a>’s MyLink infotainment system with an 8.0-inch touchscreen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, Bluetooth, a rearview camera, and eight-way power adjustable driver’s seat.</p>

<p><strong>Impala LT:</strong> Moving up to the LT grade gets you remote start, four-way power adjustable passenger’s seat, dual-zone climate control, LED daytime running lights, and a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob.</p>

<p><strong>Impala Premier:</strong> On the range-topping Premier trim, additional standard features include rear parking sensors, heated front seats, eight-way power adjustable front passenger’s seat, HID headlights, 19-inch alloy wheels, navigation, an 11-speaker Bose audio system, wireless device charging, and chrome side mirror covers.</p>

<p>Notable features include a memory function for the driver’s seat, 20-inch alloy wheels, a heated steering wheel, ventilated front seats, auto-dimming rearview mirror, and a power tilt and telescoping steering wheel.</p>

<p>The 2018 Chevrolet Impala comes standard with a 2.5-liter I-4 rated at 197 hp and 191 lb-ft of torque. Optional on the LS and LT trims and standard on the range-topping Premier model is a 3.6-liter V-6 rated at 305 hp and 264 lb-ft. Both engines are mated exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings are 22/30 mpg city/highway for the 2.5-liter I-4 and 19/28 mpg with the V-6. An E85 ethanol capable variant of the V-6 is rated slightly lower at 18/28 mpg on gas and 14/20 mpg on E85.</p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Impala a five-star overall safety rating (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 Impala received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except the small front overlap crash test where it received Acceptable rating for the driver’s side and hasn’t been test for the passenger side (Good is the highest possible score). The car also received a Poor rating on the headlights test. In the front crash prevention test, the 2018 Impala received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the speed of a 25-mph impact by 10 mph (Superior is the highest possible rating for the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p>On the LT trim, the available Driver Confidence package adds rear parking assist, lane change assist, blind-spot monitoring, and rear cross-traffic alert. The Driver Confidence package comes standard on the Premier trim. Available only on the Premier trim, the Premier Confidence package adds forward collision warning, lane departure warning, automatic emergency braking, and adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p>The 2018 Impala has an 18.8-cubic-foot trunk and can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/impala/2016/2016-chevrolet-impala-ltz-v6-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we said that even with the V-6, you need to bury your foot into the gas pedal to get it going, as the powertrain feels like it was tuned for maximum fuel economy. Despite the large alloy wheels, the Impala’s ride remains comfortable and its interior is spacious enough to hold five adults comfortably. Surprisingly for a large car, it handles securely and doesn’t understeer too much when pushed hard. The cabin stays well-insulated on the road and the comfortable front seats further hint at the Impala’s main mission, which is to coddle occupants.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/suburban/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Suburban</a> gets standard LED daytime running lights on all models and two new exterior colors called Havana Metallic and Satin Steel Metallic. Like the smaller Tahoe, the 2018 Suburban gets a special RST Edition package but it is limited to the LT and Premier trims only. The RST Edition gets 22-inch gloss black wheels, black bowtie logos, a black sport grille, body-colored door handles and headlight accents, black side mirror covers and roof rails, an air suspension with leveler, and black name badges. Brembo brakes and a Borla exhaust have been added as new dealer-installed accessories.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/suburban/2018/">Chevrolet Suburban</a> is a large SUV that slots above the Tahoe and has seating for up to nine passengers. The truck-based SUV comes in three trim levels and is available in rear- or four-wheel-drive configurations.</p>

<p><strong>Suburban LS:</strong> The base LS trim comes standard with a rearview camera, split-folding second and third rows, tri-zone climate control, rear parking sensors, remote start, LED daytime running lights, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a>’s MyLink infotainment system with an 8.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, a six-speaker audio system, cloth upholstery, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, keyless entry, cloth upholstery and 18-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Suburban LT:</strong> Moving up to the LT trim adds a nine-speaker Bose audio system, a programmable power liftgate, leather upholstery on the first- and second-row seats, and heated front seats.</p>

<p><strong>Suburban Premier:</strong> As the most luxurious trim, the Premier trim adds 12-way power adjustable front seats, ventilated front seats, HID headlights, front parking sensors, 20-inch alloy wheels, Magnetic Ride Control, a hands-free programmable power liftgate, navigation, a 10-speaker Bose audio system, a wireless charging pad, keyless start, power-folding second- and third-row seats, a sunroof, and heated second-row seats.</p>

<p>Power folding second- and third-row seats are available, as is a hands-free programmable tailgate.</p>

<p>The 2018 Chevrolet Suburban is powered by a 5.3-liter V-8 rated at 355 hp and 383 lb-ft of torque and comes paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 16/23 mpg city/highway for rear-drive variants and 15/22 mpg for models with four-wheel drive.</p>

<p>The 2018 Chevrolet Suburban received a four-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS hasn’t crash tested the 2018 Suburban but the 2017 model received a Basic rating for the front crash prevention test for its available forward collision warning system (Superior is the highest score for the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p>The LS’ Enhanced Driver Alert package includes low-speed automatic emergency braking, lane keeping assist, lane departure warning, automatic high beams, and a safety alert seat. Blind-spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, and lane change alert are available as part of the Luxury package in the LT trim and standard on the Premier grade. Adaptive cruise control is available on the Premier trim and is bundled together with an automatic emergency braking system that works at higher speeds.</p>

<p>Behind the third row, the 2018 Suburban has 39.3 cubic feet of cargo capacity that can be expanded to 76.7 cubic feet behind the second row, and 121.7 cubic feet when the second- and third-row seats are folded. When properly equipped, the 2018 Suburban can haul up to 8,300 pounds in rear-drive guise or up to 8,000 pounds in four-wheel drive models.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/suburban/2015/2015-chevrolet-suburban-gmc-yukon-xl-first-test/">2015 First Test</a>, we said that the Suburban feels truck-like on the road and it drives as big as it looks. The six-speed automatic needs to downshift multiple times to get the necessary passing power. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/suburban/2015/2015-chevrolet-suburban-2015-gmc-yukon-first-drive/">2015 First Drive</a>, we liked the Suburban’s cylinder deactivation system, which turns four cylinders on and off seamlessly. Ride comfort is excellent despite the Suburban’s truck-based roots. The multimedia system is also easy to use and is available with 4G LTE, allowing the Suburban to turn into a mobile hot spot.</p>

<p>The standard 5.3-liter V-8 in the 2018 Suburban is also used in the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-1500/2018/">Chevrolet Silverado 1500</a> and Tahoe, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/yukon/2018/">GMC Yukon</a>, Yukon XL and Sierra 1500.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong> A rearview camera and a 7.0-inch touchscreen are now standard on the <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-2500hd/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Silverado 2500HD</a>. The Z71 and High Country models get a new grille design, and the tire pressure monitor on all models now has a tire fill alert system. Three new exterior colors, Cajun Red Tintcoat, Havana Metallic, and Iridescent Pearl, are now available.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong> Slotting below the Silverado 3500HD, the 2018 <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-2500hd/2018/">Chevrolet Silverado 2500HD</a> is the smaller of the two heavy-duty trucks sold by <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a>. Rear-wheel drive is standard, and four-wheel drive is optional. In addition to two bed lengths, the Silverado 2500HD is available in three cab styles.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong> Two engines are available in the 2018 Silverado 2500HD, a 6.0-liter V-8 rated at 360 hp and 280 lb-ft of torque or an optional 6.6-liter turbodiesel V-8 with 445 hp and 910 lb-ft. Both engines are paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. Opting for the diesel engine, however, adds over $10,000 to the truck’s base price, making it an expensive proposition. The Silverado 2500HD can tow up to 3,534 pounds of payload or haul up to 18,100 pounds when properly equipped. Standard features include Chevrolet’s MyLink infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, a rearview camera, a 3.5-inch multi-information display, Bluetooth connectivity, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, 17-inch steel wheels, an automatic locking differential and a 60/40 split-folding rear seats on dual- and crew cab models. Higher trims can be had with cloth or leather upholstery, heated and ventilated front seats, a heated steering wheel, alloy wheels up to 20 inches in diameter, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, a wireless device charging pad, a Bose premium audio system, dual-zone climate control, and remote start.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong> The NHTSA gave the 2018 Silverado 2500HD a four-star overall rating (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS hasn’t tested the 2018 Silverado 2500HD. On higher trims, the Driver Alert package is available. and it adds lane departure warning, forward collision warning, the Safety Alert Seat, and parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong> In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-2500hd/2015/2015-chevrolet-silverado-hd-gmc-sierra-hd-first-drive/">2015 First Drive</a>, we noted that the Silverado 2500HD rides surprisingly well and that the interior features a user-friendly infotainment system. Even before it received additionally power, the optional diesel engine offers plenty of grunt on tap and remains quiet. We also noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-2500hd/2015/2015-chevrolet-silverado-2500hd-ltz-first-test/">2015 First Test</a> that the interior is well-built and well-insulated, with minimal noise entering the cabin. The truck’s ride has also improved substantially and has minimal bucking and porpoising compared to older heavy-duty pickups.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong> The 2018 Chevrolet Silverado 2500HD’s diesel engine is shared with the larger Silverado 3500HD and the <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/sierra-2500hd/2018/">GMC Sierra 2500HD</a> and 3500HD.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/camaro/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Camaro</a> receives a new variant of the powerful Camaro <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/the-2017-chevrolet-camaro-zl1-is-capable-of-200-mph/">ZL1</a> called the Camaro <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2018-chevrolet-camaro-zl1-1le-supercharged-z28-successor/">ZL1 1LE</a>, a track-focused variant with a full aero kit to keep the car planted. The Camaro ZL1 1LE also features special wheels and tires to keep it light, and an adjustable suspension.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/camaro/2018/">Chevrolet Camaro</a> is a rear-drive sports car that slots below the Corvette and is available in a number of variants including the track-oriented 1LE model. In addition to the coupe, a convertible variant is available.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2017 Camaro lineup includes four engines that can be paired to a manual or automatic transmission. As soon as we learn more about the 2018 Camaro aside from the new ZL1 1LE model, we’ll update this space (we don’t expect the lineup to change much, if at all).</p>

<p><strong>Model: Camaro LT 2.0T</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 2.0-liter turbo-four – six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 275 hp/295 lb-ft</br></br></p>

Engine and Transmission: 3.6-liter V-6 – six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic<br>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/camaro/2017/2017-chevrolet-camaro-zl1-first-test-brute-squad-goals/">2017 First Test</a>, we said the Camaro ZL1 offers impeccable performance, with strong acceleration and the same excellent handling that the current generation Camaro is known for. Additionally, the car is at home at the track, even without the 1LE package, making it an excellent all-around high-performance sports car.</p>

<p>The less powerful Camaro V6 1LE paced fourth in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/fiat/124-spider/2017/chevrolet-camaro-1le-bmw-m2-ford-focus-rs-fiat-124-spider-abarth-porsche-718-boxster-s-toyota-86/">2017 comparison test</a> due to its long brake pedal travel and shifter that’s not as crisp as the one found on the SS 1LE. It also lacks Mgnetic Ride Control and the electronically operated limited-slip differential, which means it doesn’t have the same level of capability as its V-8-powered bretheren. However, the car is exceptionally neutral and it’s hard to make it understeer, giving it great balance and confident handling.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/mustang/2016/comparison-2016-chevrolet-camaro-rs-vs-2016-ford-mustang-ecoboost/">2016 four-cylinder pony car comparison test</a> with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/mustang/2018/">Ford Mustang</a> EcoBoost, the Camaro with the 2.0-liter turbo-four lost due to it wearing all-season tires, which was what dragged the car down, particularly its handling and braking. The car’s engine, on the other hand, is energetic and isn’t as laggy as the 2.3-liter turbo-four we’ve experienced in the pre-2018 Mustang EcoBoost.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Chevrolet Camaro rides on GM’s Alpha platform shared with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/ats/2018/">Cadillac ATS</a> and CTS.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors<br/></strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Redesigned for the 2018 model year, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/equinox/2018/">Chevrolet Equinox</a> features a new exterior design reminiscent of the Malibu, Cruze, and Volt. The car also receives a new engine lineup that includes a diesel option and an available suite of active safety technologies.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting below the larger three-row Traverse but above <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/trax/2017/2017-chevrolet-trax-first-look-review/">the smaller Trax</a>, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/equinox/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Equinox</a> can seat up to five and can be had with front- or all-wheel-drive configurations. Compared to the crossover it replaces, the new Equinox is about 400 pounds lighter.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two new turbocharged four-cylinder gas engines are available including a 1.5-liter unit estimated to have 170 hp and 203 lb-ft of torque, and a 2.0-liter with around 252 hp and 260 lb-ft. A 1.6-liter turbodiesel I-4 will also be available and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a> expects it to have 136 hp and 236 lb-ft. The smaller 1.5-liter turbo-four and the 1.6-liter turbodiesel I-4 come paired with a six-speed automatic transmission and the 2.0-liter turbo-four is coupled to a new nine-speed automatic. EPA fuel economy estimates haven’t been released yet, but the diesel-powered Equinox will be the most efficient at approximately 40 mpg on the highway. Gas-powered variants with front-wheel drive are expected to achieve up to 31 mpg on the highway with the 1.5-liter and up to 28 mpg with the 2.0-liter.</p>

<p>Cargo space in the 2018 Equinox, according to Chevrolet’s estimates, is slightly less than in the car it replaces at 29.9 cubic feet with the split-folding second row in place and 63.5 cubic feet with them down (versus 31.5 and 63.7 cubic feet), not bad for a vehicle that’s 4.7 inches shorter than the vehicle it replaces. New features include an updated version of Chevrolet’s MyLink multimedia interface with a seven-inch touchscreen as standard or an optional eight-inch touchscreen with navigation. Android Auto and Apple CarPlay are standard on both systems.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Equinox is now available with a full suite of active safety tech that includes the Safety Alert Seat, a multi-camera parking system, forward collision warning with following distance indicator, a low-speed automatic emergency braking system, lane keeping assist, lane departure warning, and rear cross-traffic alert. A rear seat reminder can remind you to check the second row if you’ve left anything. The NHTSA and IIHS have yet to safety test the 2018 Equinox.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>We haven’t driven the 2018 Equinox yet but wonder if the top-seller might be an improvement over the current generation, which we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/equinox/2016/2016-chevrolet-equinox-ltz-awd-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a> as having a harsh, naturally aspirated base engine that struggled going up freeway onramps.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Chevrolet Equinox’s gas engines are shared with the current-generation <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/malibu/2016/2016-chevrolet-malibu-15t-first-test-review/">Malibu midsize sedan</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-1500/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Silverado 1500</a> gets a rearview camera and tire fill alert on all models. WT models now get a standard MyLink infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen. LTZ models are now available with the eAssist mild hybrid system and the Custom trim is now available on crew cab models.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-1500/2018/">Chevrolet Silverado 1500</a> is a full-size truck slotting above the midsize Colorado and below the larger heavy Silverado 2500. Three cab styles are available and two bed lengths are offered. Rear-wheel drive is standard while four-wheel drive is optional. A number of special-edition packages help make the 2018 Silverado 1500 more distinctive including the Black Out Edition, Special Ops Edition, and Redline Edition.</p>

<p><strong>Silverado 1500 WT:</strong> The base WT comes well equipped with 17-inch alloy wheels, HID headlights, a full-size spare tire, a 3.5-inch instrument cluster info display, vinyl upholstery, a rearview camera, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a>’s MyLink infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth, a USB port, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, and a six-speaker audio system.</p>

<p><strong>Silverado 1500 LS: </strong>Moving up to the LS grade adds keyless entry, 4G LTE connectivity, chrome front and rear bumpers, and a grille with chrome surrounds.</p>

<p><strong>Silverado 1500 Custom:</strong> The Custom model adds 20-inch alloy wheels, body-colored headlight bezels and grille surrounds, a locking tailgate, and front recovery hooks.</p>

<p><strong>Silverado 1500 LT:</strong> LT variants get more features like bright alloy wheels, the EZ Lift &amp; Lower tailgate, a 4.2-inch instrument cluster info display, a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, cloth upholstery, and 40/20/40 split-folding bench seat.</p>

<p><strong>Silverado 1500 LTZ:</strong> One of two more upscale trims, the LTZ comes with bright 18-inch alloy wheels, full LED headlights, dual-zone climate control, heated front seats, 10-way power adjustable front seats, remote start, a 110V outlet, and chrome door handles, side mirror covers, door moldings, and beltline moldings.</p>

<p><strong>Silverado 1500 High Country:</strong> The luxury-oriented High Country grade gets you a heated steering wheel, ventilated front seats, 12-way power adjustable front seats, a spray-on bedliner, 20-inch alloy wheels, a Bose audio system, navigation, a wireless phone charger, and a two-tone Saddle and Black interior.</p>

<p>One notable option is the Z71 package, which is available on the LT and LTZ trims. The Z71 package adds an off-road-tuned suspension with Rancho monotube shocks, hill descent control, a high capacity air cleaner, a heavy duty automatic locking differential, underbody skid plates covering the transfer case, and an appearance package that adds unique door plates, gauge clusters, a different grille, and a unique lower front bumper.</p>

<p>The 2018 Silverado 1500 is available with three engine options including a 4.3-liter V-6 with 285 hp and 305 lb-ft of torque, a 5.3-liter V-8 with 355 hp and 383 lb-ft, and a 6.2-liter V-8 with 420 hp and 460 lb-ft. A six-speed automatic transmission is standard on the V-6 and the 5.3-liter V-8, while an eight-speed automatic is optional on the latter. Silverado 1500s with the 6.2-liter V-8 come exclusively with the eight-speed automatic.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the base V-6 engine are 18/24 mpg city/highway in rear-drive form and 16/21 mpg with four-wheel drive. Move up to the 5.3-liter V-8 and those numbers drop to 16/23 mpg for rear-drive trucks and 16/22 with four-wheel drive. Models with the 5.3-liter V-8 and the optional eight-speed automatic aren’t as efficient at 16/21 mpg for rear-drive trucks and 15/20 mpg with four-wheel drive. An eAssist mild hybrid system is available with the 5.3-liter V-8, bumping fuel economy ratings up to 18/24 mpg for rear-drive models but four-wheel-drive-equipped variants are rated at 16/21 mpg. The 6.2-liter V-8 is the least efficient at 15/20 mpg for rear-drive models and 15/19 mpg on four-wheel-drive-equipped trucks.</p>

<p>The 2018 Silverado received a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 Silverado 1500 received a Good score on all but headlights test where it received a Poor rating and front small overlap test where extended cab models received an Average rating and the crew cab model received a Marginal rating (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the 2018 Silverado 1500 received a Basic rating since its active safety features haven’t been tested yet (Superior is the highest rating on the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p>Higher trim levels are available with lane keeping assist, forward collision warning, and low-speed automatic emergency braking.</p>

<p>When properly equipped, the 2018 Silverado 1500 can tow up to 12,500 pounds; however, that’s limited to rear-drive double cab and crew cab models. The truck can also carry up to 2,250 pounds of payload provided you choose the rear-drive double cab model.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-1500/2017/2017-chevrolet-silverado-1500-z71-4wd-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we said that on-road ride comfort is a weak point because the Silverado 1500 easily gets unsettled over the smallest road imperfections. Off-road, however, the truck shines and can easily get through obstacles thanks to the additional ground clearance of the Z71 package’s off-road-tuned suspension. The interior is well-insulated and doesn’t get too noisy on the highway, but the available 5.3-liter V-8 isn’t especially quickest.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong> The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-3500hd/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Silverado 3500HD</a> gets a standard rearview camera and 7.0-inch touchscreen. High Country and Z71 models get new grille designs, and the tire pressure monitoring system now comes with tire fill alert. Three exterior colors, Cajun Red Tintcoat, Havana Metallic, and Iridiscent Pearl Tricoat, are now available.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong> The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-3500hd/2018/">Chevrolet Silverado 3500HD</a> is the largest truck <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a> makes, slotting above the smaller Silverado 2500HD. Rear-wheel drive is standard and four-wheel drive is optional.  There are three cab styles, two bed lengths and either single or dual rear-wheel configurations available in the 2018 Silverado 3500HD.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong> Two engines are available in the 2018 Silverado 3500HD, a 6.0-liter V-8 with 360 hp and 380 lb-ft of torque and an optional 6.6-liter turbodiesel V-8 with 445 hp and 910 lb-ft. Opting for the diesel engine, however, adds nearly $10,000 to the Silverado 3500HD’s base price. Both engines are paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. The truck can haul up to 7,153 pounds of payload, and when properly equipped, the 2018 Silverado 3500HD can tow up to 23,300 pounds. Standard features on the base WT trim include a rearview camera, Chevrolet’s MyLink infotainment system, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, 60/40 split-folding rear seats on the double- and crew-cab models, an automatic locking differential, 4G LTE connectivity, a 3.5-inch multi-information display, Bluetooth connectivity, 18-inch steel wheels, and vinyl upholstery. Higher trims can be had cloth or leather upholstery, navigation, a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, heated and ventilated front seats, a larger 4.2-inch multi-information display, a heated steering wheel, a Bose premium audio system, and a wireless device charger.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong> The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Chevrolet Silverado 3500HD. On higher trim levels, buyers can opt for the Driver Alert package, which adds forward collision warning, lane departure warning, the Safety Alert Seat, and parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong> We’ve yet to test the 2018 Silverado 3500HD, but in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-2500hd/2015/2015-chevrolet-silverado-hd-gmc-sierra-hd-first-drive/">2015 First Drive</a> we said that the truck’s interior features a similar look to that of the smaller Silverado 1500, excellent build quality, and a user-friendly infotainment system. Ride comfort, on the other hand, is firm, but it’s much improved over the past-generation heavy-duty trucks. Even before it received a power upgrade, the optional diesel engine, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-2500hd/2015/2015-chevrolet-silverado-2500hd-ltz-first-test/">2015 First Test</a> of the smaller Silverado 2500HD, offered plenty of power for accelerating and hauling payloads and trailers.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong> The Chevrolet Sierra 3500HD shares its underpinnings and powertrain options with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/sierra-3500hd/2018/">GMC Sierra 3500HD</a>, which is slightly more premium, especially in Denali trim.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/cruze/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Cruze</a> gets a new exterior color, Satin Steel Gray Metallic. Additionally, hatchback models are now available with the diesel engine.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/cruze/2018/">Chevrolet Cruze</a> is a front-drive compact sedan and hatchback slotting below the midsize Malibu and above the subcompact Sonic. Four trim levels are available.</p>

<p><strong>Cruze L: </strong>The base L trim gets 15-inch steel wheels, Bluetooth, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a>’s MyLink infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, a four-speaker audio system, a USB port, cloth upholstery, and a rearview camera.</p>

<p><strong>Cruze LS: </strong>Moving up to the LS trim adds a compass, a center console armrest and floor mats.</p>

<p><strong>Cruze LT: </strong>The LT trim adds 16-inch alloy wheels, a six-speaker audio system, cruise control, LED daytime running lights, and 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p><strong>Cruze Diesel: </strong>Diesel-powered models come standard with heated front seats, an eight-way power-operated driver’s seat, keyless entry/start, and remote start on automatic models. The manual-equipped Cruze Diesel hatchback also comes standard with the RS package, which adds a body kit, fog lights, a roof spoiler, 18-inch alloy wheels, and a Watt’s Link rear suspension for improved ride quality.</p>

<p><strong>Cruze Premier: </strong> Range-topping Premier trim comes with 17-inch alloy wheels, ambient lighting, a heated steering wheel, leather upholstery, a Watt’s Link rear suspension, and a USB charging port for rear passengers.</p>

<p>Options include a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, a sunroof, a nine-speaker Bose audio system, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, heated rear seats, automatic climate control, and wireless phone charging. Most of the available options are available on automatic-equipped models while some are limited to the range-topping Premier trim. Diesel models miss out on features such as navigation, wireless phone charging, and heated rear seats.</p>

<p>The 2018 Cruze comes standard with a 1.4-liter turbo-four with 153 hp and 177 lb-ft of torque, which can be paired to a six-speed manual or a six-speed automatic transmission. A 1.6-liter turbodiesel I-4 with 137 hp and 240 lb-ft is also available and can be paired to either a six-speed manual or a new nine-speed automatic that General Motors co-developed with <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a>.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the 2018 Cruze sedan are 27/40 mpg city/highway for the manual and 29/40 mpg with the automatic. Premier models are less efficient at 29/39 mpg. The hatchback is rated at 27/38 mpg with the manual and 29/38 mpg with the automatic. As in the sedan, the Premier trim on the hatch takes a hit in fuel economy and is rated at 28/37 mpg.</p>

<p>Diesel-powered models are the most efficient, with the EPA rating the Cruze sedan at 31/47 mpg with the manual and 30/52 mpg with the automatic. Hatchback variants powered by the diesel engine are a smidge less efficient at 29/48 mpg with the manual or 30/45 mpg with the automatic.</p>

<p>The Chevrolet Cruze received a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS evaluations, the 2018 Cruze has only been tested in side and moderate front overlap impact tests where it received a Good rating (Good is the highest possible score). It also received a Basic rating on the IIHS’ front crash prevention test for having an available forward collision warning system (Superior is the highest score for the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p>Lane change assist, blind-spot monitoring, and rear cross-traffic alert are available as part of the Driver Confidence package on the LT, Premier, and automatic-equipped Diesel models. The Driver Confidence II package, which is only available on the Premier trim, includes following distance indicator, forward collision warning, automatic high beams, lane departure warning, and lane keeping assist. Adaptive cruise control, automatic emergency braking, and pedestrian detection are not available on any trim of the 2018 Cruze. Diesel-powered models equipped with an automatic transmission are available only with the Driver Confidence package.</p>

<p>The 2018 Cruze sedan has a 13.9-cubic-foot trunk and can be expanded via the available split-folding rear seats from the LT trim and higher. For extra practicality, the hatchback has 22.7 cubic feet with the rear seats in place and 47.2 cubic feet with them folded.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2016/2016-2017-big-test-compact-sedans/">2016 Big Test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2018/">Honda Civic</a>, Mazda3, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/sentra/2018/">Nissan Sentra</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/corolla/2018/">Toyota Corolla</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/elantra/2018/">Hyundai Elantra</a>, and the previous-generation <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/jetta/2018/">Volkswagen Jetta</a>, the Chevrolet Cruze placed second thanks to its comfortable ride, buttoned down chassis, and tightly controlled body motions. However, its low-speed ride was busy compared to its rivals. Its interior was finished in a cool two-tone color scheme but had quality issues such as a rocking driver’s seat. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/cruze/2016/2016-chevrolet-cruze-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we were impressed with the Cruze’s infotainment system, which was easy to use and easily integrates smartphones. Road noise, on the other hand, does get excessive with the larger alloy wheel options.</p>

<p>With the standard six-speed manual transmission, the Cruze’s fun to drive factor doesn’t really get amped up. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/cruze/2017/2017-chevrolet-cruze-lt-hatchback-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we noted that the manual feels vague with long throws, poor clutch engagement. With the standard 16-inch alloy wheels wrapped in tires with plenty of sidewall, the ride is plenty comfortable and easily soaks up road imperfections. Handling is still reasonably secure but it won’t provide you with the same level of confidence as more sporting compact hatchbacks.</p>

<p>Diesel-powered models offer a comfortable ride and secure handling, but we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/cruze/2018/2018-chevrolet-cruze-td-hatchback-first-test/">2018 First Test</a>, the car can get unsettled over large road imperfections with the optional 18-inch alloy wheels. The turbodiesel I-4’s generous low-end torque also means it doesn’t feel underpowered and can easily pass slower traffic on the highway; however, it does suffer from turbo lag. Although the nine-speed automatic is no longer stingy with downshifts, it gets confused in traffic and is often changing gears. Interior quality is mixed, with a number of large panel gaps and hard plastics surround soft-touch areas where your arms fall.</p>

<p>The 1.6-liter turbodiesel I-4 is also used in the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/equinox/2018/">Chevrolet Equinox</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/terrain/2018/">GMC Terrain</a>.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/pacifica/2018/">2018 Chrysler Pacifica</a> gets rear parking sensors and blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert as standard. A new entry-level L trim has also been added to the gas-only Pacifica, and the plug-in hybrid gets a Touring Plus variant. All models get an updated version of FCA’s UConnect infotainment system with Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration. New cosmetic options include new alloy wheel designs, bright side moldings, and a chrome roof rack.</p>

<p>Touring Plus variants get remote start standard and Touring L models get standard perforated leather upholstery. The Touring L trim can now be had with a Premium group with the 13-speaker Alpine audio system and a larger 8.4-inch touchscreen. Touring L Plus variants add a panoramic sunroof option, and the Harman Kardon premium audio system is now a standalone option in the gas-only Limited model. A new S Appearance package is now available and it comes with gloss black grille surrounds, black 20-inch alloy wheels, black <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/">Chrysler</a> badges, and black seats with Light Diesel Gray accents.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/pacifica/2018/">Chrysler Pacifica</a> is a minivan that can seat up to eight passengers when equipped with the second-row bench seat. In addition to the standard gas-only Pacifica, there’s also the Pacifica plug-in hybrid, which offers better fuel economy. However, the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/pacifica-plug-in/2018/">Pacifica Hybrid</a> is only available with a seven-seat configuration.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Chrysler Pacifica is powered by a 3.6-liter V-6 rated at 287 hp and 262 lb-ft of torque, and the engine is paired exclusively to a nine-speed automatic transmission. The Pacifica plug-in hybrid pairs the same 3.6-liter V-6 to an electric motor, a CVT, and a lithium-ion battery for a combined output of 260 hp.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the gas-only Pacifica are 19/28 mpg city/highway on models with the engine stop/start system and 18/28 mpg on those without it. Plug-in hybrid variants are capable of traveling up to 33 miles on a single charge. With a full tank and a full charge, the Pacifica Hybrid is rated at 32 mpg combined and has a driving range of 570 miles.</p>

<p>Both variants of the 2018 Pacifica offer excellent cargo capacity at 32.3 cubic feet behind the third row, 87.5 cubic feet behind the second row and 140.5 cubic feet behind the front seats. However, only the gas-powered Pacifica is rated for towing and when properly equipped it can tow up to 3,600 pounds.</p>

<p>Standard features include 17-inch alloy wheels, cloth upholstery, FCA’s UConnect infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, a rearview camera, keyless entry, and rear parking sensors. Options include a 360-degree multi-camera system, remote start, keyless start, automatic parking assist, alloy wheels up to 20 inches in diameter, premium audio systems from Alpine or Harman Kardon, a larger 8.4-inch touchscreen, navigation, a rear seat entertainment system, heated and ventilated front seats, heated second-row seats, leather upholstery, a heated steering wheel, HID headlights, an onboard vacuum, and tri-zone climate control.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Pacifica a five-star overall safety score (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 model but the 2017 Pacifica received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests and Average on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Pacifica received a Superior rating after it avoided collisions in 12- and 25-mph tests (Superior is the highest rating in the front crash prevention test). As a result, the Chrysler Pacifica received the 2017 Top Safety Pick+ rating from the IIHS.</p>

<p>A suite of active safety features available on higher trims of the Pacifica includes lane departure warning, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, automatic high beams, and adaptive cruise control. Blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert is standard on all 2018 Pacifica variants.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/pacifica/2017/2017-chrysler-pacifica-limited-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a> of the range-topping Limited trim, we were impressed with its excellent build quality, which is a big step up compared to its predecessor, the Town &amp; Country. The nine-speed automatic is a transmission we’ve experienced issues with in other Fiat-Chrysler vehicles, but in the Pacifica, it works well with the 3.6-liter V-6, offering strong acceleration for a minivan. However, in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/pacifica/2017/2017-chrysler-pacifica-touring-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a> of the mid-level Touring trim, we found the transmission was hunting for gears on a few occasions. The easy-to-operate Stow ‘n Go second-row seats provide an additional layer of flexibility.</p>

<p>Despite having less power and more weight than the regular model, the Chrysler Pacifica plug-in hybrid offers strong acceleration. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/pacifica-plug-in/2017/2017-chrysler-pacifica-hybrid-first-test-charging-ahead/">2017 First Test</a>, we noted that the brakes were squishy and the brake pedal had a long travel. In terms of handling, the Pacifica plug-in hybrid is surprisingly well composed for a minivan and the cabin stays quiet on the highway. Opting for the plug-in hybrid means not having Stow ‘n Go second-row seats or an eighth seat (since the second-row bench isn’t available on the Pacifica Hybrid).</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The second- and third-row seats on the Chrysler Pacifica can be stowed into a bin under the floor to create a flat cargo floor.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018<br/></strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/pacifica/2018/">2018 Chrysler Pacifica</a> Plug-In (also known as the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/pacifica/2018/">Chrysler Pacifica</a> Hybrid) gets an updated UConnect infotainment system with a larger 7.0-inch touchscreen as standard and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration. All trims now come standard with rear parking sensors and blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert. Two new exterior colors — Copper Pearl Coat and Ocean Blue Metallic — have also been added. Touring L variants get remote start and perforated leather upholstery as standard.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/">Chrysler</a> Pacifica Hybrid is the plug-in hybrid variant of the Pacifica minivan and it comes with seating for up to seven passengers. Unlike the gas-only Pacifica, the plug-in hybrid variant doesn’t come with the Stow N’ Go second-row seats.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Chrysler Pacifica Plug-In is powered by a 3.6-liter V-6 coupled to a lithium-ion battery, an electric motor and a CVT for a combined output of 260 hp. Despite its large interior, the Pacifica Plug-In is still good for an EPA-rated 32 mpg combined. With a full battery charge, the minivan can travel up to 33 miles before the gas engine turns on. On a full tank and a full charge, the Pacifica Plug-In can travel up to around 570 miles.</p>

<p>Since its batteries are mounted under the second-row, the 2018 Chrysler Pacifica Plug-In has the same cargo capacity at 32.3 cubic feet behind the third row, 87.5 cubic feet behind the second row and 140.5 cubic feet behind the front seats. However, the Pacifica Plug-In isn’t rated for towing like the gas-only Pacifica.</p>

<p>Standard features include 17-inch alloy wheels, three-zone climate control, cloth upholstery, FCA’s UConnect infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, a rearview camera, and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p>Options include a 360-degree camera system, 18-inch alloy wheels, a rear-seat entertainment system, remote start, keyless entry/start, heated and ventilated front seats, a heated steering wheel, leather upholstery, a larger 8.4-inch touchscreen, navigation, a tri-pane panoramic sunroof, a Harman Kardon premium audio system, front parking sensors, and automatic parking assist.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Pacifica Plug-In but the non-hybrid Pacifica received a five-star overall rating (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the gas-powered Pacifica received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests and Acceptable on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Pacifica received a Superior rating after it avoided a collision in 12- and 25-mph tests (Superior is the highest rating in the front crash prevention test). As a result, the Pacifica was given the 2017 Top Safety Pick+ award by the IIHS.</p>

<p>Available as an option on the Limited trim is a full active safety suite that includes forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, adaptive cruise control automatic high beams, lane keeping assist and lane departure warning. Blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert is standard on all Pacifica Plug-In models.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/pacifica-plug-in/2017/2017-chrysler-pacifica-hybrid-first-test-charging-ahead/">2017 First Test</a>, we said that even though the Pacifica plug-in hybrid is heavier and not as powerful as the standard Pacifica, the engine-upgrade model offers strong acceleration for a minivan. Its handling is surprisingly good thanks to its low center of gravity, which makes it feel planted on the road. The brake pedal, however, feels squishy and has a long travel. Ride comfort is excellent with its suspension soaking up bumps well. Even though it’s a mainstream minivan, the Pacifica Plug-In in higher trims has an interior that feels premium thanks to extensive use of high-quality materials. However, even though its interior is spacious the Pacifica Plug-In isn’t as flexible as the gas-only Pacifica since it doesn’t have the Stow N’ Go second-row seats and it can only seat up to seven passengers (instead of the eight-passenger seating offered on the non-hybrid).</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Chrysler Pacifica Plug-In’s battery is placed under the floor where the second-row Stow N’ Go bins are normally located.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/300/2018/">2018 Chrysler 300</a> gets a new base Touring trim with 17-inch alloy wheels and cloth upholstery, and two new exterior colors, Green Metallic Clear Coat, and Ocean Blue Metallic Clear Coat. All 300C models mode come standard with the 5.7-liter V-8 and the Limited model is now available with 20-inch alloy wheels. The Harman Kardon premium audio system, navigation, power sunshade, and the dual-pane sunroof are now available as standalone options in the 300 Limited and 300C. Touring models can now get the Sport Appearance and Chrome Appearance packages while the 300S now has the Beats audio system and the Alloy package as available options.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/300/2018/">Chrysler 300</a> is a full-size sedan that’s available in rear- or all-wheel-drive configurations. The 300 is the only sedan in <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/">Chrysler</a>’s lineup, now that the 200 midsize sedan has been discontinued.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Chrysler 300 is available with two engine choices a 3.6-liter V-6 rated at 292 hp and 260 lb-ft of torque (300 hp and 264 lb-ft in the 300S) or a 5.7-liter V-8 with 363 hp and 394 lb-ft. Both engines come paired exclusively to an eight-speed automatic transmission; however, all-wheel drive is only available with the V-6. EPA fuel economy ratings are 19/30 mpg city/highway for rear-drive models with the V-6 and 18/27 mpg with all-whee drive. The more powerful 5.7-liter V-8 is the least efficient at 16/25 mpg.<b> </b>Trunk space is generous at 16.3 cubic feet of cargo space and can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base trim include 17-inch alloy wheels, cloth upholstery, dual-zone climate control, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, a power-operated drive’s seat, a six-speaker audio system, Bluetooth connectivity, FCA’s UConnect infotainment system with an 8.4-inch touchscreen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, a rearview camera, and keyless entry/start. Options included alloy wheels up to 20 inches in diameter, HID headlights, leather upholstery, heated and ventilated front seats, a heated steering wheel, heated rear seats, a Harman Kardon premium audio system, and remote start. The 300S is further distinguished by a sportier suspension tune compared to other trim levels.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Chrysler 300 received a four-star overall safety score from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 300 but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except for the front small overlap test and the headlights test where it received a Marginal and Poor rating respectively (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Chrysler 300 received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the severity of a 25-mph impact by 14 mph (Superior is the highest rating in the front crash prevention test)</p>

<p>Active safety features such as automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, lane departure warning, automatic high beams, lane keeping assist, and adaptive cruise control are available only on higher trims as part of an optional package. Blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert is available  as part of another package.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/300/2018/2018-chrysler-300-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive</a>, we said that the fit and finish of the luxury-oriented 300C is excellent — nearly as luxurious as a midsize sedan with a luxury badge. The sportier 300S, on the other hand, has a slightly stiffer suspension but doesn’t sacrifice the car’s comfortable ride; however, it’s difficult to tell the difference in handling. With the optional V-8, the 300 offers strong acceleration and the eight-speed automatic shifts quickly and smartly.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>
