<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/">Dodge</a> adds the SXT Plus and GT Plus trims to the Charger lineup, and GT trims now come standard with 300 hp, the Performance Pages feature on the infotainment screen, and 19-inch alloy wheels. A 7.0-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto is now standard on the base SXT trim and red Brembo brake calipers are now available on the R/T Scat Pack and Daytona 392 models. The SRT 392 model now offers optional Brass Monkey wheels and low-gloss, black lightweight alloy wheels. The SRT Hellcat receives a new grille and fender badges, an optional Matt Vapor wheel finish, optional black, orange, and gunmetal Brembo brake calipers, an available Demonic Red Laguna leather interior, and available dual Gunmetal Grey racing stripes. New exterior colors include F8 Green and IndiGO Blue and B5 Blue and Plum Crazy return to the lineup. A rearview camera with rear parking sensors is now standard on all models.</p>

<p>The Charger is Dodge’s only sedan, slotting above the two-door Challenger in starting price.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/charger/2018/">2018 Dodge Charger</a> SXT</strong>: The base SXT trim comes standard with a 3.6-liter V-6, 17-inch alloy wheels, a remote start system, a push-start ignition, automatic headlights with LED daytime running lights, illuminated front cup holders, six-way power adjustable driver’s seat, cloth seating, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, a 7.0-inch instrument cluster display, a six-speaker audio system, two USB ports, and a 7.0-inch central touchscreen with Bluetooth, Apple CarPlay, and Android Auto.</p>

<p><strong>2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/charger/2018/">Dodge Charger</a> SXT Plus</strong>: Building off the SXT trim, the SXT Plus adds the upgraded 8.4-inch touchscreen with Sirius XM satellite radio (Apple CarPlay and Android Auto still included), 18-inch alloy wheels, LED fog lights, heated front seats, a six-speaker Alpine audio system, an eight-way power driver’s seat, and dual-zone climate control.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Dodge Charger SXT Plus (Leather)</strong>: This additional SXT Plus sub-trim adds 20-inch Satin Carbon wheels, heated and ventilated sport seats, heated rear seats, HID headlights, a heated steering wheel, eight-way power passenger’s seat, and adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Dodge Charger GT</strong>: The GT trim adds all-wheel drive, a slightly more powerful 300-hp 3.6-liter V-6 engine (versus the standard 292 hp), 19-inch Granite Crystal alloy wheels, a rear spoiler, and a performance steering wheel with paddle shifters.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Dodge Charger GT Plus</strong>: The GT Plus adds heated and ventilated Nappa leather-trimmed sport seats, HID headlights with LED accents, a heated performance steering wheel, adaptive cruise control, and an eight-way power passenger’s seat.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Dodge Charger R/T</strong>: The R/T adds a more powerful 5.7-liter V-8 and includes 20-inch Satin Carbon wheels, Sport Mode 2 (a more aggressive Sport mode), an active exhaust system (a more aggressive sound), sport-tuned suspension, a body-color rear spoiler, eight-way power driver’s seat, front heated cloth sport seats, a six-speaker Alpine audio system, and the 8.4-inch touchscreen infotainment system.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Dodge Charger Daytona</strong>: The Daytona trim builds off the R/T trim and adds 20-inch forged and painted alloy wheels, Daytona perforated suede and leather seats, heated and ventilated eight-way power front seats, heated rear seats, a three-mode electronic stability control system, a performance Mopar cold-air intake system, performance-tuned suspension, a black grille (lower trims have gloss black grills), HID headlights with LED accents, projector LED fog lights, a matte black rear spoiler, carbonite interior accents, power tilt and telescoping steering wheel, and a heated performance steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Dodge Charger Daytona 392</strong>: The Daytona 392 adds a larger and more powerful 6.4-liter V-8, 20-inch forged lightweight wheels, six-piston front Brembo performance brakes, a limited-slip rear differential, high-performance suspension,  illuminated rear cupholders, unique interior and exterior visual tweaks, and LED interior ambient lighting.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Dodge Charger R/T Scat Pack</strong>: The Scat Pack trim also uses the 6.4-liter V-8 and comes equipped with 20-inch machined satin black wheels, front four-piston Brembo brakes, a limited-slip rear differential, a more aggressive Sport mode, high-performance suspension, matte black rear spoiler, an active exhaust system, heated cloth performance seats, and eight-way power front seats.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Dodge Charger SRT 392</strong>: The SRT 392 uses the 6.4-liter V-8 and comes standard with 20-inch SRT low-gloss wheels, red six-piston front Brembo brakes, a limited-slip rear differential, high-performance suspension with adaptive damping, HID headlights with LED daytime running lights, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, a body-color rear spoiler, eight-way power front seats, Laguna luxury performance SRT seats, a heated premium leather-wrapped SRT steering wheel, a six-speaker Alpine audio system, the 8.4-inch touchscreen with navigation, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Dodge Charger SRT Hellcat</strong>: The outrageous Hellcat utilizes a 6.2-liter supercharged V-8 and comes standard with 20-inch low-gloss black lightweight alloy wheels, SRT drive modes, launch control, a valet mode, two key fobs for two horsepower outputs (500 hp and 707 hp), an air induction hood with dual heat extractors, six-piston red Brembo front brakes, a three-mode performance Bilstein adaptive damping system, a sportier suspension tuning, a 200-mph speedometer and red-faced instrument cluster gauges, Laguna-leather-trimmed lightweight performance seats, premium leather-wrapped flat-bottom SRT steering wheel, and the 8.4-inch touchscreen infotainment system with navigation, Apple CarPlay, and Android Auto.</p>

<p>The Charger’s standard engine is a 3.6-liter V-6 that produces 292 hp (300 hp with the Super Track Pak) and 260 lb-ft of torque (264 with the Super Track Pak) and delivers an EPA-rated 19/30 mpg with rear-wheel drive and 18/27 mpg with the GT’s all-wheel drive system (the V-6 is the only engine offered with all-wheel drive). The 5.7-liter V-8 makes 370 hp and 395 lb-ft and is rated at 16/25 mpg and the 485 hp, 475 lb-ft 6.4-liter V-8 delivers 15/25 mpg. The Hellcat’s powerful 707-hp, 650 lb-ft 6.2-liter supercharged V-8 is rated at 13/22 mpg. All engines are mated to an eight-speed automatic and all V-8s come in rear-drive form only. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the V-6 powered Charger hit 60 mph in 6.4 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in an impressive 110 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 Dodge Charger received in the highest five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA in both rear- and all-wheel-drive forms. In IIHS testing, the 2018 Charger received the second-lowest score of Marginal for the small overlap front crash test and the highest score of Good in the other crash tests. The Charger received the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention evaluation by avoiding a collision in a 12-mph test and reducing the speed of a 25-mph collision by 12 mph thanks to the optional automatic emergency braking system found in the Premium and Technology packages. The Technology package adds other driver assist safety features including adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning with lane keep assist, a rain-sensitive windshield, and automatic high beams. Blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert is available in three packages and is standard on the SRT 392 and Hellcat. A rearview camera with rear parking sensors is standard on all trims.</p>

<p>The Dodge Charger can hold 16.5 cubic feet of cargo in its trunk and offers 41.8 inches of legroom for the front seats and 40.1 inches for the rear seats.</p>

<p>The standard 7.0-inch touchscreen infotainment system is only equipped on the base SXT model and includes SiriusXM satellite radio, Bluetooth, Apple CarPlay, and Android Auto. Two USB ports and a six-speaker audio system are also standard. The rest of the trims receive the 8.4-inch touchscreen infotainment system but the SRT 392 and Hellcat also include navigation. The six-speaker system can be upgraded to a 10-speaker Beats Audio system or a 19-speaker Harman Kardon audio system. A 7.0-inch instrument cluster display is standard on all trims.</p>

<p>After one year with our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/charger/2016/2016-dodge-charger-srt-hellcat-review-long-term-verdict/">long-term 2016 Dodge Charger</a> SRT Hellcat, we felt that this 707-hp sedan was a normal car in many ways: “It’s roomy, it’s surprisingly comfortable, the Uconnect infotainment system works pretty much OK, and the back seats are good for three adults, fantastic for two. But if any of the above figures into your decision to go out and purchase a Charger Hellcat—a $73,725 purchase that I highly recommend—you’re doing it wrong.”</p>

<p>However, the Hellcat is not a normal car in many other ways: “You get yourself a 707-hp Charger so that when you’re virtually parked in traffic you can relieve tension by spinning the back wheels a bit. Not a big smoky burnout, but just enough to make everyone around you nervous. It helps both relieve the tension and break up the monotony. You buy yourself a Charger Hellcat because it’s as close to a concealed carry permit as there is in the automotive world. Just like a .357 Magnum under your coat, you always know the immense power is there, mere inches away.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/charger/2016/2016-dodge-charger-sxt-blacktop-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the six-cylinder <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/challenger/2016/">2016 Dodge Challenger</a> SXT Blacktop, we felt the heavy sedan needed a little more power and sound from the engine, but “despite the lack of solid power, the Charger SXT Blacktop shined in other areas. The brakes were strong and confident whether stopping abruptly or gradually. Handling was top-notch with excellent grip in sharp, quick corners and stiff steering. The ride itself was smooth, and road imperfections were barely felt.”</p>

<p>We were not fans of the hard plastic used throughout the interior, but the infotainment system was easy to use. We concluded by saying, “The 2016 Dodge Charger SXT Blacktop is ideal for customers looking for a little more edge in their daily driver. This large sedan is a great alternative to traditional sedans, offering plenty of cargo room, passenger room, and technology. Although the performance may not be where we would like, it likely won’t be a hindrance to those buying the SXT.”</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/durango/2018/">2018 Dodge Durango</a> gets a high-performance SRT model, an updated infotainment system with Android Auto and Apple CarPlay compatibility, a new steering wheel with paddle shifters, and two new exterior colors: B5 Blue and In Violet Metallic. All models get a 7.0-inch touchscreen and rearview camera as standard equipment.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/durango/2018/">Dodge Durango</a> is a midsize three-row SUV that slots above the smaller Journey and is available in rear- or four-wheel drive configurations. Unlike its rivals, the Durango is available with a V-8 engine option and a performance-oriented variant.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/">Dodge</a> Durango is available with three engines including a 3.6-liter V-6 with 293 hp (295 hp in models with dual exhausts) and 260 lb-ft of torque, a 5.7-liter V-8 rated at 360 hp and 390 lb-ft, and a 6.4-liter V-8 with 475 hp and 470 lb-ft. All engines come exclusively with an eight-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings are 19/26 mpg city/highway for V-6-powered rear-drive models and 18/25 mpg with four-wheel drive. Move up to the 5.7-liter V-8 and fuel economy drops to 14/22 mpg for both rear- and four wheel drive models. The Durango SRT with its 6.4-liter V-8 is the least efficient at 13/19 mpg.</p>

<p>Cargo space is 17.2 cubic feet behind the third row, 47.7 cubic feet behind the second row, and 84.5 cubic feet behind the front seats. When properly equipped, the V-6 models can haul up to 6,200 pounds while the 5.7-liter V-8 can tow up to 7,400 pounds in rear-drive guise or 7,200 pounds with four-wheel drive. The Durango SRT can haul the most at 8,700 pounds when properly equipped.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base model include 18-inch alloy wheels, a 7.0-inch reconfigurable multi-information display, cloth upholstery, two USB ports, FCA’s Uconnect infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, a rearview camera, Bluetooth connectivity, keyless entry/start, and three-zone climate control.</p>

<p>Options include a larger 8.4-inch touchscreen, navigation, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, power-operated heated and ventilated front seats, a heated steering wheel, HID headlights, leather upholstery, second-row captain’s chairs, heated second-row seats, a Beats premium audio system, and a rear-seat entertainment system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Durango received a four-star rating in the NHTSA’s front crash test and in the rollover test, three stars with all-wheel drive and four stars with rear-wheel drive (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 Durango but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except the small overlap test and the headlights test where it received a Marginal rating (Good is the highest rating).</p>

<p>Optional on all but the base SXT trim is a suite of active safety features that includes forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking and lane departure warning. Blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert is available as part of an available package.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/durango/2014/the-big-test-2014-three-row-crossovers/">2014 comparison test</a> that included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/santa-fe/2018/">Hyundai Santa Fe</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/pathfinder/2018/">Nissan Pathfinder</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/highlander/2018/">Toyota Highlander</a>, and the previous generations of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/pilot/2018/">Honda Pilot</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-9/2018/">Mazda CX-9</a>, the spacious Durango won even though it can get quite pricey. On the road, the Durango doesn’t feel underpowered even with its base 3.6-liter V-6 and with its massive 24.5-gallon fuel tank, it has excellent cruising range. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/durango/2014/2014-dodge-durango-limited-awd-first-test/">2014 First Test</a>, we also noted that the Durango’s independent suspension gives it a comfortable ride and surefooted handling for an SUV its size. The car’s UConnect infotainment system is user-friendly and getting into the third row is a breeze thanks to easy to use sliding second row seats.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Durango SRT’s 6.4-liter V-8 is also found in the Challenger and Charger SRT 392 and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/grand-cherokee/2018/">Jeep Grand Cherokee</a> SRT.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The news on the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/challenger/2018/">2018 Dodge Challenger</a> is the outrageous 808-hp dragstrip brute, the Challenger SRT Demon, certified by the National Hot Rod Association as the quickest quarter-mile production in the world. The Demon is capable of producing 840 hp and 770 lb-ft of torque on high-octane race fuel.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>With the discontinuation of the Viper, the Challenger becomes the only coupe offered by <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/">Dodge</a> and one of two non-SUV cars, with a starting price set below the Charger sedan. The Challenger is now the automaker’s sportiest car with a wide range of models, limited editions, and appearance packages.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/challenger/2018/">Dodge Challenger</a> will likely come with a choice of the previous four engine options along with the addition of the new Demon supercharged engine. The V-6 and Demon engines can only be paired to an eight-speed automatic transmission and the rest of the engine options have an available six-speed manual. Power is routed to rear wheels with the exception of the new-for-2017 all-wheel-drive GT model. Once we have official info on the rest of the non-Demon 2018 Challenger lineup, we’ll update this space.</p>

<p>Here’s how the 2018 Challenger lineup will likely look:</p>

<p><strong>Model: Challenger SXT, Challenger SXT Plus, Challenger GT</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 3.6-liter V-6 – eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 305 hp/268 lb-ft of torque</br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: Challenger R/T, Challenger R/T Plus, Challenger T/A, Challenger T/A Plus, Challenger R/T Shaker, Challenger R/T Plus Shaker</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 5.7-liter V-8 – six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 372 hp/400 lb-ft (automatic); 375 hp/410 lb-ft (manual)</br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: Challenger R/T Scat Pack, Challenger T/A 392, Challenger SRT 392, Challenger 392 Hemi Scat Pack Shaker</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 6.4-liter V-8 – six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 485 hp/475 lb-ft</br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: Challenger SRT Hellcat</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: supercharged 6.2-liter V-8 – six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic<br>
Power : 707 hp/650 lb-ft</br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: Challenger SRT Demon</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: supercharged 6.2-liter V-8 – eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 808 hp/717 lb-ft (91-octane gas), 840 hp/770 lb-ft (100-plus high-octane race fuel)</br></br></p>

<p>Equipped with only a driver’s seat, the new SRT Demon is built for the dragstrip. Even so, the front passenger and rear seats can be purchased for $1 each. The Demon’s wheels are 18 by 11 inches with Demon-branded 315-40R18 Nitto street-legal drag radials (on all four corners) with NTO 5R compound. Owners can order a personalized Demon crate with the buyer’s name, VIN, and serial number. The crate can fit in the trunk and contains narrow front runner aluminum drag wheels for track use, tools, jacks, and performance parts like the powertrain control module that allows the engine to operate on high-octane race fuel. It’s the first factory production car with Drag mode suspension tuning, a Drag mode assist that helps prevent wheel hop, and the largest functional hood scoop on a production car at 42.5 square inches. On a prepared drag strip surface, Dodge claims the 2018 Challenger SRT Demon can hit 60 mph in 2.1 seconds, a 100 mph 5.1, and reaches the quarter mile in 9.65 seconds at 140 mph (making it illegal to race on a track without a roll cage, not offered by Dodge).</p>

<p>As the Challenger SRT Demon takes its place at the top of the Dodge performance lineup, the Challenger lineup should continue to offer plenty of other packages and options when you’re considering a car with <em>under</em> 800 hp. On the 2017 model, the Blacktop package consists of 20-inch Gloss Black aluminum wheels, black grille with a Blacktop badge, dual Blacktop stripes along the top of the coupe from hood to trunk, a performance steering wheel, and Gloss Black interior accents. The R/T Classic package features 20-inch Hyper Black aluminum wheels, Nappa leather-trimmed sport seats with suede inserts, HID headlights, and Challenger script badge with dual black or red side stripes. Expect to see interior features like the latest edition of Dodge’s Uconnect infotainment system in addition to available features like the Harman Kardon premium audio system, remote start, and heated/ventilated front seats.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>Opt for the Technology Group that will likely return and your Challenger will come equipped with Automatic High Beam Headlamp Control, Rain Sensitive Windshield Wiper system, Adaptive Speed Control (not available with manual transmission), and Forward Collision Warning. Blind Spot Monitoring and the rearview camera are additional safety features.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/challenger/2015/2015-dodge-challenger-srt-hellcat-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 2015 Dodge Challenger SRT Hellcat, we loved the whine from the engine bay and said, “The supercharger whine can double as an air raid siren.” The Hellcat is a burnout machine: “Honestly, if big smoky burnouts are your top car-buying priority, stop researching. The Hellcat creates stinky, juvenile white clouds better than any other new car.”</p>

<p>Handling is on the poor side, but that is not what the Hellcat is built for. When you boil everything down, the Hellcat is a straight-line monster: “Get some fatter, stickier rear meats for the Challenger Hellcat and it really does have the intestinal fortitude to embarrass cars costing double and triple the price.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/challenger/2017/2017-dodge-challenger-gt-awd-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the six-cylinder-powered all-wheel-drive 2017 Challenger GT, we said that “the Challenger GT had no issues accelerating or braking in the snow, but we noticed it felt particularly slow in passing maneuvers on a wet two-lane highway. It made us wish we had the all-wheel-drive option with the more powerful Hemi V-8 engines.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Challenger SRT Demon has an Eco mode that limits the horsepower output to 500, starts the coupe in second gear, and will short-shift the remaining gears for maximum fuel economy.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/journey/2018/">2018 Dodge Journey</a> lineup has been reduced to four trims and gets three-row seating as standard on all models. Crossroad models get black 19-inch alloy wheels as standard and the Blacktop package’s availability has been expanded to the SE trim, in addition to the SXT and GT.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/journey/2018/">Dodge Journey</a> is as compact three-row crossover with seating for up to seven passengers and slots below the larger Durango. Front-wheel drive is standard and all-wheel drive is optional on models equipped with the available V-6 engine.</p>

<p>Journey SE: The base SE trim comes with 17-inch steel wheels, cloth upholstery, a 4.3-inch touchscreen for the infotainment system, a USB port, a six-speaker audio system, and keyless entry/start.</p>

<p>Journey SXT: Building on the SE trim, the Journey SXT adds fog lights, body-colored side mirror covers, and 17-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p>Journey Crossroad: Additional standard features on the Journey Crossroad include leather upholstery with mesh cloth inserts, FCA’s UConnect infotainment system with an 8.4-inch touchscreen, dual-zone climate control and Bluetooth connectivity.</p>

<p>Journey GT: The range-topping GT trim adds 19-inch alloy wheels, leather upholstery, heated front seats, a six-speaker premium audio system, and an alarm.</p>

<p>Notable options include navigation, a rearview camera, rear parking sensors, remote start, a second-row entertainment system, and the Blacktop package, which adds cosmetic tweaks such as a gloss black grille, headlight bezels, roof rails, and on certain trims, gloss black 19-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p>The base engine in the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/">Dodge</a> Journey is a 2.4-liter I-4 rated at 173 hp and 166 lb-ft of torque paired to a four-speed automatic transmission. A 3.6-liter V-6 with 283 hp and 260 lb-ft coupled to a six-speed automatic is optional. EPA fuel economy ratings are 19/25 mpg city/highway for four-cylinder models, 17/25 mpg for front-drive models with the V-6 and 16/24 mpg with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Dodge Journey a four-star rating for the front crash and rollover tests (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test a 2018 Journey but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except for the headlights and driver’s side front small overlap test, where it received a Poor score (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>Cargo space is acceptable at 10.7 cubic feet behind the third row, 37 cubic feet behind the second row, and 67.6 cubic feet behind the front seats. When properly equipped, the 2018 Journey can tow 1,000 pounds with the base four-cylinder or up to 2,500 pounds with the optional V-6.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/journey/2017/2017-dodge-journey-gt-awd-blacktop-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we said that even with the optional 3.6-liter V-6, the Journey is slower than expect due to its 4,405-pound curb weight. Ride comfort isn’t very good—when you go over potholes, the car gets easily unsettled. The rear suspension is also prone to shuddering even at moderate speeds on smooth roads. There’s also excessive powertrain jerkiness due to the six-speed automatic not shifting very smoothly. Second-row seating in the Journey is tight and the third row is best left folded since it is extremely cramped. The version of FCA’s UConnect interface in the Journey is also dated and not as responsive as units found in newer FCA vehicles but thankfully it’s sharp and user-friendly. The Journey also features plenty of small storage cubbies including a space under the front passenger seat. Unlike other three-row crossovers, the Journey costs under $25,000 making it one of the least expensive vehicles that offers seating for up to seven.</p>

<p>The optional 3.6-liter V-6 is shared with a number of FCA vehicles including the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/cherokee/2018/">Jeep Cherokee</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/pacifica/2018/">Chrysler Pacifica</a>.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Fiat reconfigures the Lusso and Abarth model’s packaging for more flexibility, adds a new Red Top Edition to the Lusso model, and offers Puro Bianco Perla (Tri-Coat White Pearl), Grigio Chiero (Silver Metallic), and Blu Scuro (Dark Blue Metallic) exterior colors.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The 124 Spider is Fiat’s only non-hatchback and rear-wheel drive model. With the exception of the 500e EV, the Fiat 124 Spider has the highest starting price of any Fiat.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Fiat 124 Spider is powered by a 1.4-liter turbocharged I-4 that produces 160 hp (164 for the Abarth model) and 184 lb-ft of torque, and delivers an EPA-rated 25/36 mpg city/highway with the six-speed automatic or 26/35 mpg with the six-speed manual transmission. Power is routed to the rear wheels of this two-seater. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 124 Spider hit 60 mph in 6.5 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 108 feet. The 124 Spider is based on the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/miata/2018/">Mazda Miata</a>.</p>

<p>The base 124 Spider Classica model comes standard with independent front and rear suspension, electronic locking differential, 16-inch alloy wheels, dual stainless steel exhaust tips, two USB ports, a black soft top, and leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob. The Lusso model adds 17-inch premium wheels, fog lights with automatic headlights, dual chrome exhaust tips, a 7.0-inch touchscreen display and command dial, automatic temperature control, heated leather-trimmed front seats, and a rearview camera. The range-topping Abarth model adds a sport mode selector, a mechanical limited slip differential, Bilstein front and rear performance suspension with strut tower bar, 17-inch gunmetal wheels, a unique body-color sport fascia, a sport-tuned quad-tipped chrome exhaust, heated leatherette and microfiber performance seats with red accent stitching, a perforated leather-wrapped steering wheel, aluminum accent sport pedals, and mirror caps, roll bar cover, and windshield surround in a Gunmetal finish. For more features, order the Luxury Collection with Sirius that consists of a nine-speaker Bose audio system, sport leather seats, auto-dimming and heated exterior mirrors, automatic headlight leveling system, Fiat Connect with navigation, headlight washers, LED headlights, and SiriusXM satellite radio.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Fiat 124 Spider offers some driver assist safety features including blind-spot monitoring, Rear-Cross Path Detection, and Rear Park Assist (rear parking sensors), in addition to adaptive front headlights (they turn as you steer).</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/fiat/124-spider/2017/chevrolet-camaro-1le-bmw-m2-ford-focus-rs-fiat-124-spider-abarth-porsche-718-boxster-s-toyota-86/">six-way sports car comparison</a>, the 2017 Fiat Spider Abarth topped the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/m2/2018/">BMW M2</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/camaro/2018/">Chevrolet Camaro</a> (V-6), <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/focus/2018/">Ford Focus</a> RS, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/718-boxster/2018/">Porsche 718 Boxster</a> S, and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/86/2018/">Toyota 86</a> because it was the most fun car to drive in the group. We said, “In this group, the Fiat 124 Abarth had the least powerful engine, but it was also the king of back-road perma-grin. The top-down motoring is enjoyable, but the Fiat is also willing to give it all. To wit: In its driver’s seat, I followed the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/">BMW</a> M2, being pushed to its absolute limit by back-road demon Scott Evans (the guy who hated the Fiat.)”</p>

<p>“Not once in 30 miles of tight, twisty road could he, in the 365-hp M2, pull away from me in the 164-hp Fiat. This isn’t because Evans isn’t a fast driver (he is), because the BMW isn’t quicker (it is), or because it doesn’t handle better (it does.) The Fiat kept up with a much more capable car because it earns its driver’s trust. That meant I could turn off its overly intrusive stability control and throw it into every corner without fear.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/fiat/124-spider/2017/2017-fiat-124-spider-abarth-first-test-review/">First Test</a> of all three Fiat 124 Spiders, we concluded, “Among the three Fiats, it’s no surprise to learn that the Lusso is by far the most comfortable; its cushier seat even makes it seem like it rides smoother than the Classica despite its 17-inch wheels. It also seems more posh and comfy than any available trim level of MX-5. Clearly, if you’re looking for a boulevardier roadster, this is your choice. The Classica on 16s feels like it subdivides the other two—not quite as sharp as the Abarth or as pillowy as the Lusso. As such, for many it may be the Goldilocks choice and the one that seems to most closely match the Miata’s demeanor. Choose this one if you really just prefer the Fiat’s styling. Folks planning to track their roadster will be best served by the harder-edged Abarth, especially if they’re willing to aggressively shop the Abarth/Mopar go-fast catalogue. Any turbo engine can be tweaked to produce more power, so those who’ve longed for a Mazdaspeed Miata can make their wishes come true in the Fiat aftermarket.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 124 Spider uses the same 1.4-liter turbocharged I-4 found in the 500 Abarth but produces a little more power thanks to the 22 psi boost rating versus the 500 Abarth’s 18 psi rating.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Fiat updates the 500L’s exterior with a new front and rear fascia, new exterior side moldings, new wheel designs, and new daytime running light lens and rear side reflector designs. Inside, the 500L gets a new instrument cluster display, a redesigned center console with relocated cup holders, a new gear shifter, parking brake handle, an additional USB port, LED interior lighting, and a new steering wheel. New standard equipment includes a rearview camera and the Uconnect 4 system with a 7.0-inch center display screen and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto capability. Blue Denim, Arancio Pastello (Pastel Orange), and Bronzo Metallizzato (Metallic Bronze) are new exterior colors.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The 500L is Fiat’s largest and most expensive hatchback (besides the pricier 500e), positioned above the 500 and 500X models.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Fiat 500L comes equipped with one powertrain option, a 160-hp, 184-lb-ft of torque 1.4-liter turbocharged I-4 engine backed by a six-speed automatic transmission that routes power to the front wheels and delivers an EPA-rated 22/30 mpg city/highway. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 500L Trekking hit 60 mph in 8.6 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a respectable 121 feet.</p>

<p>The base 500L Pop comes standard with 16-inch aluminum wheels, a bright exhaust tip, heated and powered side view mirrors, front and rear one-touch automatic windows, leather-wrapped steering wheel and gear shift knob, and the previously mentioned Uconnect 4 system with a 7.0-inch center display and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto capability. The top Lounge model adds dual-zone automatic temperature control, 17-inch painted aluminum wheels, chrome exterior mirrors, leather-trimmed seats, heated front seats, Uconnect 4 with navigation, and a Beats premium audio system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>In IIHS testing, the 2017 Fiat 500L received the lowest rating of Poor for the small overlap front crash evaluation but received the highest rating of Good in the remaining four crash tests (moderate overlap front, side, roof strength, and head restraints and seats). The front crash prevention evaluation was not conducted because the Fiat 500L does not have emergency automatic braking or any driver assist safety feature. The 500L comes standard with the previously mentioned rearview camera and is available with rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>“Out on the open road, this little engine struggles a bit to hustle the biggest 500 up to speed. For around-town driving, it is just fine, but I am concerned about how it would perform on mountain vacations with the whole family onboard and a cargo compartment filled with weekend gear,” we said in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/fiat/500l/2017/2017-fiat-500l-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2017 Fiat 500L. “The combined result is that the 2017 Fiat 500L doesn’t feel like a very sporty car deep down, which may explain why there’s no Abarth variant offered and why Fiat has never done one of those “<a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2017-fiat-124-spider-stars-new-blue-pill-commercial/">little blue pill</a>” Viagra-gag commercial featuring the 500L. No, if you’re into cheeky, boutiquey small four-doors and you need a bit more sport, the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mini/clubman/2016/2016-mini-clubman-first-drive-review/">Mini Clubman</a> might be a better choice,” we concluded.</p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2014-motor-trend-car-of-the-year-contenders-and-finalists/">2014 Car of the Year testing</a> we said, “The 500L weebled and wobbled but didn’t fall down as editors pushed it through the ride and handling course. ‘Drives like it looks — top-heavy, wallowing at times, but also surprisingly stable at higher speeds.’” The judges didn’t care for the interior, “The emergency brake hides under the driver’s armrest, and the gearshift knob on the manual model is the size of a baseball. The second row folds forward and up to create a useless storage space. The upright driving position and the lack of bolstering make it easy for the driver to slide around the seat.” However, the judges agreed that the 500L is driver-friendly, ergonomically sound, and is relatively quiet with a nice ride. “Attempting to sell the 500L here on its practical merits is a waste of energy, just as it would be trying to sell <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/">Ram</a> pickups to Europeans.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>When the 500L was first launched, the hatchback utilized a six-speed manual transmission and a six-speed dual-clutch automatic, now it is just offered with a traditional six-speed automatic.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The 500 Pop and Lounge trims receive a new and more powerful standard turbocharged engine, an upgraded braking system, sport-tuned suspension, a rearview camera, and a spoiler.</p>

<p>The two-door 500 is offered as a hatchback and convertible, and is Fiat’s most affordable model. Above the 500 in Fiat’s lineup is the 124 Spider, the 500L, and the 500X.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Fiat 500 Pop</strong>: The base Pop comes standard with 16-inch semi-gloss alloy wheels, heated and power side view mirrors, a 5.0-inch touchscreen with a six-speaker Alpine audio system and Bluetooth, a 7.0-inch instrument cluster display, fog lights, adjustable front cloth seats, spoiler (hatchback model) a leather-wrapped steering wheel, a rearview camera (cabrio model also gets rear sensors), and a black cabrio top (cabrio model only).</p>

<p><strong>2018 Fiat 500 Lounge</strong>: The Lounge model adds 16-inch Tech Silver wheels, leather-trimmed seats, heated front seats, chrome mirror caps, automatic climate control, SiriusXM satellite radio, a fixed glass roof (for hatchback model), and an auto-dimming rearview mirror.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Fiat 500 Abarth</strong>: The higher-performance and top Abarth model comes equipped with a more powerful 1.4-liter turbo-four, 16-inch Hyper Black alloy wheels, a higher-performance braking system with red brake calipers, dual chrome exhaust tips, performance-tuned suspension for the hatchback model and high-performance tuned suspension for the cabrio, a black performance top (for the cabrio model), a spoiler, a three-mode electronic stability control system, performance high-back cloth seats with seat-belt pass-through, a turbo boost gauge, a leather-wrapped shift knob, and a perforated leather-wrapped, a leather-wrapped instrument panel, flat-bottom Abarth steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Fiat 500e</strong>: The 500e is powered by an all-electric powertrain and comes standard with 15-inch wheels, a 7.0-inch instrument cluster display, a 5.0-inch infotainment screen with a navigation system and SiriusXM satellite radio, rear parking sensors, an audible pedestrian warning system, automatic climate control, heated front seats, and heated side view mirrors.</p>

<p>The highly customizable Fiat 500 is available in 15 exterior colors, and the dashboard is the same color as the exterior paint. If you want a more exciting cabrio top color than black, the non-Abarth models also offer Bordeaux and beige, soft tops and the Abarth has an optional gray top. The Abarth’s and Pop’s mirror caps and roof can be finished in black, red, white, or gray (Abarth only). The Abarth’s wheels can be upgraded to 17-inch Hyper Black forged wheels or 17-inch Bronze forged wheels.</p>

<p>The Pop and Lounge’s new standard engine is 1.4-liter turbo-four that produces 135 hp and 150 lb-ft of torque and is backed by a five-speed manual or a six-speed automatic transmission. The Abarth’s 1.4-liter turbo-four makes 160 hp and 170 lb-ft with the five-speed manual and 157 hp and 183 lb-ft with the six-speed automatic. All 500 models are front-wheel drive. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2012 500 Abarth with the five-speed manual (same power output as the 2018 model) hit 60 mph in 6.8 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 117 feet.</p>

<p>The 2017 Fiat 500 received a four-star overall rating out of five stars from the NHTSA. In IIHS testing, the 2017 Fiat 500 received the lowest rating of Poor in the small overlap front driver side crash test and the highest rating of Good in all other crash tests. Front crash prevention was not tested because the 500 does not offer an automatic emergency braking or a collision warning system. A rearview camera and a tire pressure monitoring system are standard on all trims. Rear parking sensors are standard on the Pop cabrio model and up.</p>

<p>The Fiat 500 hatchback offers up to 9.5 cubic feet of cargo room behind the rear seats but the cabrio offers less, at 5.4 cubic feet. If you fold down the seats of the hatchback, the 500 can hold up to 30.1 cubic feet. Front seat passengers receive up to 40.7 inches of legroom and rear seat passengers have 31.7 inches.</p>

<p>The 500’s standard multimedia system features a 5.0-inch touchscreen with a six-speaker Alpine audio system and Bluetooth. A navigation system, SiriusXM satellite radio, and a Beats Audio system are optional.</p>

<p>After one year with our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/fiat/500/2012/2012-fiat-500-sport-verdict/">long-term 2012 Fiat 500</a>, we didn’t like the lack of power and wish the 500 was more stable under hard braking but the fuel economy was great. The small size is great for tight maneuvering into small spaces and the “cuteness is undeniable, inside and out, and it earned many a thumbs-up from strangers,” we said. “I love the simple, retro/modern dash design, a nice expression of the Fiat’s Italian genes, and the shiny dash panel matches the exterior paint and doesn’t show fingerprints or smudges.”</p>

<p>We didn’t care for the high seating position and small sun visors but the Fiat was reliable the entire year we had it. The Fiat 500 is just not very practical for most, “The Fiat’s size makes it an ideal city car, but not so great for road trips involving more than one adult passenger, and forget about lugging a lot of luggage,” we said. “So anytime I needed to drive them somewhere more than two hours away, I signed into another car.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/fiat/500/2012/mini-cooper-vs-scion-tc-vs-honda-crz-vs-volkswagen-beetle-vs-hyundai-veloster-vs-fiat-500-comparison/">six-way comparison</a> of small cars, the liked the cute looks and charm of the 2012 Fiat 500 but the small hatchback placed fifth. “With its little-bitty trunk and vestigial rear seats, the Fiat isn’t practical by any stretch,” we said. “The Fiat’s other failing was in the drive. A short wheelbase combined with a narrow footprint and a sport-tuned suspension conspire to give the car a bouncy ride that keeps your head tossing constantly on the freeway. Unfortunately, that didn’t translate into fun in the hills, either. While the 500 is incredibly nimble, it tends to bounce around over bumps and is quick to understeer when pressed,” we added. “Exacerbating everything was the driving position, which felt like driving from a bar stool.”</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>All Fiat 500X model receive the Uconnect 4 system which includes a 7.0-inch center display with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto capability.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The 500L slots above the smaller 500 model but below the larger and more expensive 500L. The 124 Spider sports car (Fiat’s only non-hatchback) and 500e EV also have higher starting prices.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The base 500X Pop model comes powered by a 1.6-liter turbocharged 1.4-liter engine produces that 160 hp and 184 lb-ft of torque and is backed by a six-speed manual transmission that powers that front wheels (2017 EPA-rating of 25/33 mpg city/highway). Available on the Pop (but standard with AWD), but standard on the Trekking and Lounge models is a 180-hp, 175 lb-ft of torque 2.4-liter I-4 engine paired to a nine-speed automatic that delivers 22/30 mpg with front-wheel drive and 21/29 mpg with AWD (2017 figures).  In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2016 Fiat 500X Pop Trekking AWD hit 60 mph in an expected 8.5 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a short 116 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 Fiat 500X comes standard with the previously mentioned Uconnect 4 system with smartphone compatibility and a 7.0-inc display, heated side-view mirrors, a 3.5-inch driver’s display screen, a USB port, electric parking brake, 16-inch steel wheels with covers, chrome exhaust tip, and a body-color rear spoiler. If you opt for the top Lounge model, add Uconnect with navigation, heated front seats and steering wheel, an eight-way power driver seat, dual-zone climate control, a traction control system with three modes (Auto, Sport, and Traction+), interior ambient lighting, auto-dimming rearview mirror, an eight-speaker premium audio system, and 17-inch aluminum wheels. For additional features, order the Lounge Premium package that consists of 18-inch wheels, Beats premium audio system, and a dual-pane power moonroof.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2017 Fiat 500X is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick by the IIHS for receiving the highest rating of Good in all five crash test evaluations and the second highest rating of Advanced for the front crash prevention evaluation because the crossover managed to properly warn the driver of a possible collision, avoided a 12 mph collision, and reduced the speed of a 25 mph collision by 5 mph thanks to the Full Speed Forward Collision Warning with Active Braking driver assist safety feature found in the optional Advanced Safety package. The lowest rating of Poor for the headlights kept it out of the Top Safety Pick+ designation. The Advanced Safety package also contains automatic high beams, Blind Spot Monitoring with Rear Cross-Path Detection, Lane Departure Warning Plus, ParkSense Rear Park Assist system, and rain sensitive windshield wipers.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/fiat/500x/2016/2016-fiat-500x-first-drive/">First Drive review</a> of the 2016 Fiat 500X, we did not care for the slow acceleration and ride comfort, “Press on the gas pedal and you can count the few long seconds it takes to get up to a reasonable speed. Expect quite a bit of growl during the drive, as well as a bouncy ride with little protection from potholes and other road imperfections. It’s also easy to tell when the nine-speed is at work…” We like the available AWD with different traction modes and the tight steering. We also enjoyed some of the interior quirkiness, “Colorful, shiny plastics cover the dashboard, complemented by circular controls and either a 3.0-inch, 4.0-inch, or 6.5-inch Uconnect screen depending on the model. Oversize door handles, a flat-bottom steering wheel, and clever storage cubbies complete the cabin. The two-tone seats are stylish and comfortable enough for long drives.” We concluded by saying that “although it doesn’t feel spacious, the 500X offers a different formula for practicality.”</p>

<p>“The 500X targets other models with funky exterior designs, such as the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> Juke and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/trax/2018/">Chevrolet Trax</a>, but adds more personality and a more cohesive exterior and interior design; everything about the small crossover was done with intention,” we said in our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/fiat/500x/2016/2016-fiat-500x-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2016 Fiat 500X AWD Trekking. We felt the acceleration was just decent with the 2.4-liter and the nine-speed transmission shifted roughly at highway speeds with slow to respond paddle shifters. The manual transmission Pop model was easy to drive with a light clutch pedal. “The 500X has a competitive edge in many aspects and clings to the persona of Fiat, but it also has its drawbacks. Regardless, for those shopping in the small CUV segment, the Fiat 500X is definitely worth at least a test drive,” we concluded.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 1.6-liter turbocharged I-4 gets good fuel economy at 25/33 mpg city/highway but with recommended premium 91 octane fuel.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/taurus/2018/">Ford Taurus</a> did not receive any significant updates for the new model year, all model features carry over. The 2.0-liter EcoBoost engine has been dropped from the lineup.</p>

<p>The Taurus is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a>’s flagship sedan, positioned above the subcompact Fiesta, the compact Focus, and the midsize Fusion in size and price.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Taurus SE</strong>: The base Taurus comes equipped with 18-inch Sparkle Silver aluminum wheels, a sport mode, rear seat vents, Ice Blue instrumentation lighting, SYNC infotainment system with a 4.2-inch center display screen, six-way power driver’s seat, dual-chrome exhaust tips, keyless entry keypad, illuminated entry, and an SOS Post-Crash Alert system.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Taurus SEL</strong>: The better-equipped SEL adds dual-zone automatic climate control, an auto-dimming rearview mirror, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, integrated remote start system, unique cloth seating upholstery, and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Taurus Limited</strong>: The Limited trim comes well-equipped with 19-inch Luster Nickel Painted aluminum wheels, interior ambient lighting, branded front floor mats, power-adjustable pedals, power rear window sunshade, wood and leather-trimmed steering wheel with power tilt and telescope, a heated steering wheel, a Sony audio system, an 8.0-inch touchscreen with SYNC 3 and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, 10-way power heated and cooled front seats, heated rear seats, perforated leather-trimmed seats, automatic high beams, blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert, lane keep assist, and auto-dimming side view mirrors.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Taurus SHO</strong>: The range-topping and higher-performance Taurus comes standard with the 3.5-liter Ecoboost engine, all-wheel drive, sport-tuned suspension, paddle shifters, 20-inch Ebony Black-painted machined aluminum wheels, aluminum pedals, SHO interior trim, perforated leather-trimmed seats with SHO graphics, dual exhaust system with chrome exhaust tips, HID headlights, SHO side view mirrors, and SHO grille with fender and rear badging.</p>

<p>The optional SHO Performance package includes performance brake pads, sport-calibrated electric power steering, stiffer springs and stabilizer bars, Track Mode/True Off electronic stability modes, performance summer tires, larger front and rear brake rotors, and an Alcantara-wrapped steering wheel.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/taurus/2018/">2018 Ford Taurus</a> is powered by a standard 288-hp, 254-lb-ft of torque 3.5-liter V-6 that delivers an EPA-rated 17/24 mpg city/highway with all-wheel drive and 18/27 when equipped with front-wheel drive. The top SHO comes standard with AWD and utilizes a 365-hp, 350-lb-ft of torque 3.5-liter twin-turbo V-6 that comes rated at 16/24 mpg. All powertrains are backed by a six-speed automatic transmission. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2013 Ford Taurus Limited AWD (with the same 3.5-liter V-6 that’s standard today) hit 60 mph in a decent 7.2 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a respectable 120 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 Ford Taurus earned a five-star overall rating from the NHTSA (five stars is the highest possible rating). In IIHS testing, the Taurus received the second-highest rating of Acceptable for the small overlap front crash test and received the highest rating of Good in the remaining four crash test evaluations. The lowest score of Basic was given for the front crash prevention evaluation because the Taurus properly warned the driver of a possible collision but did not brake for the driver (the sedan does not offer an automatic emergency braking feature). The Collision Warning with Brake Support feature is found in the Driver Assist package that also includes adaptive cruise control, Lane Keep Assist, Lane Departure Warning, and Active Park Assist (self-parking feature). Other safety features include automatic high beams, blind-spot monitoring with Cross-traffic Alert (standard on Limited SHO), rear parking sensors, and an SOS post-crash alert system.</p>

<p>The Ford Taurus’ trunk offers lots of room, measuring in at 20.1 cubic feet of cargo room, more than the redesigned <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/accord/2018/">2018 Honda Accord</a>’s 16.7 cubic feet. The Taurus offers 44.2 inches of front legroom and 38.1 inches of rear legroom, about even with the Accord’s 42.3 and 40.4 inches, respectively.</p>

<p>The 2018 Ford Taurus standard SYNC infotainment is displayed on a 4.2-inch center display and comes with a single CD player and MP3 capability, a 4.2-inch driver’s instrument panel display screen, and an SOS Post-Crash Alert system. The optional SYNC 3 system with an 8.0-inch touchscreen includes Apple CarPlay, Android Auto, AppLink, 911 Assist, and two <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/smart/">smart</a>-charging USB ports. The optional voice-activated navigation system features SiriusXM and Travel Link. For enhanced audio, opt for the available 12-speaker Sony audio system that features Clear Phase and Live Acoustic technologies.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/taurus/2013/2013-ford-taurus-sel-v-6-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 2013 Ford Taurus SEL, we liked the improved interior materials, less cluttered center stack, and were surprised by the heavy sedan’s cornering ability, “The 255mm Michelins cling and coexist nicely with the abundant body roll.”</p>

<p>We were also pleased with the acceleration of the sedan with the 288-hp, 3.5-liter V-6. We concluded by saying, “First, we’d request the Limited model’s 10-way power seats. The SEL has a power switch to adjust the seat base position and height, but altering the seat back recline angle and lumbar support means fiddling with stiff plastic controls. The entire process seems disjointed. Second, on the driving controls area, we’d request the gas pedal be less touchy. Third, lower the step-in heights for the front and back rows.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/taurus/2013/the-big-test-2013-2014-full-size-sedans/">five-way full-size sedan comparison in 2013</a>, the Ford Taurus came in last place. Although we liked the price point on the sedan, “the Taurus needs more than a refresh to compete in this segment. If you’re on a budget, shop for something in the midsize category.”</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/transit/2018/">2018 Ford Transit</a> Connect is unchanged.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/transit/2018/">Ford Transit</a> Connect is a compact commercial van that’s available as a cargo vehicle or a passenger van with seating for up to seven passengers. The Transit Connect slots below the larger Transit.</p>

<p><strong>Transit Connect XL:</strong> The base Transit Connect XL comes with vinyl upholstery, 16-inch steel wheels with covers, 180-degree swing out rear cargo doors, sliding side doors, cruise control, keyless entry, and a radio. Passenger van models add a rearview camera, a 4.2-inch screen, a USB port, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a>’s Sync infotainment system.</p>

<p><strong>Transit Connect XLT:</strong> Moving up to the XLT trim adds cornering fog lights, a fold flat front passenger seat, a 4.2-inch screen, automatic headlights, and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>Transit Connect Titanium:</strong> Available only on the passenger variant, the Transit Connect Titanium comes with 16-inch alloy wheels, Ford’s Sync 3 infotainment system with a 6.5-inch touchscreen, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, leather upholstery, heated front seats, dual-zone climate control, and navigation.</p>

<p>Notable options include a panoramic glass roof, aircraft-style overhead storage bins, 17-inch alloy wheels, remote start, and front parking sensors.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/transit-connect/2018/">2018 Ford Transit Connect</a> is available only with a 2.5-liter I-4 rated at 169 hp and 171 lb-ft of torque paired exclusively with a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 20/27 mpg city/highway for the cargo van and 19/27 mpg for the passenger variant.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/transit-connect/2018/">Ford Transit Connect</a> received a five-star overall rating for the passenger van model called the Wagon and a four-star front crash and five-star side impact rating for the cargo variant (out of a possible five stars). Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert are available only on the XLT trims for both the cargo van and passenger model.</p>

<p>Cargo vans have a maximum capacity of 124.3 cubic feet in short-wheelbase form and 149 cubic feet in long-wheelbase guise. Short wheelbase passenger vans have 46.9 cubic feet of cargo space behind the split-folding rear seats and 77.1 cubic feet behind the front seats. Opt for the long-wheelbase passenger van and you’ll have 15.7 cubic feet behind the third row, 58.9 cubic feet behind the second row, and 104.2 cubic feet behind the front seats. When properly equipped, the Transit Connect can haul up to 2,000 pounds of payload.</p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/transit-connect/2014/2014-ford-transit-connect-titanium-wagon-lwb-first-test/">2014 First Test</a>, we said that the Transit Connect handles well despite being tall and feels light on its feet similar to a <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/focus/2018/">Ford Focus</a>. The van’s steering is well-weighted, making it fun to toss into a corner. The 2.5-liter I-4, however, doesn’t have much torque available at higher revs and tends to run out of steam pretty quickly. Interior space is generous with comfortable seating for all rows. The build quality in the Titanium is good, though no one will think of the cabin ; as luxurious.</p>

<p>The Ford Transit Connect is closely related to the Focus and C-Max.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/expedition/2018/">2018 Ford Expedition</a> has been redesigned and now uses the same aluminum-intensive architecture as the current generation <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-150/2018/">Ford F-150</a>. As a result, the new Expedition is around 300 pounds lighter than its predecessor. Additionally, it also features more multimedia and safety technologies than the model it replaces.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/expedition/2018/">Ford Expedition</a> is a full-size SUV that slots above the three-row, car-based Explorer. Rear-wheel drive is standard and four-wheel drive is optional. In addition to the standard Expedition, a long wheelbase variant called the Expedition Max replaces the EL model.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>An updated EcoBoost 3.5-liter twin-turbo V-6 with more power and torque will power the 2018 Expedition and the six-speed automatic has been replaced by a new 10-speed unit that first saw duty in the F-150 Raptor. Expect the 2018 Expedition to be able to tow more payload and have a larger cargo capacity than the SUV it replaces.</p>

<p>Available features include leather upholstery, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a>’s Sync 3 infotainment system, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, a wifi hot spot, a rear seat entertainment system, a 12-speaker B&amp;O Play sound system, a panoramic sunroof, and a new advanced cargo manager that features a shelf that lets owners customize the space behind the third row.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Expedition. Active safety features and driver aids such as automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, and lane keeping assist are available.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>We haven’t driven the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/expedition/2018/2018-ford-expedition-first-look-review/">2018 Expedition</a> yet but we expect it to be quicker and more capable than the model it replaces. Since it’s lighter, the new Expedition might also be more efficient and handle better. Platinum models will be more luxurious with chrome accents, 22-inch polished alloy wheels, and quilted leather upholstery.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Ford Expedition is the third vehicle to use an aluminum-intensive architecture, following the Ford F-150 and Super Duty trucks.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/11-significant-changes-refreshed-2018-ford-mustang/">2018 Ford Mustang gets its first major makeover</a> since the all-new car was introduced for 2015. Up front, the 2018 Mustang gets a more aggressive front clip including standard LED headlights and available LED foglights, and a lower hood with new vents. Around back, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> has also revised the LED taillights and rear fascia, and added quad exhaust tips for the GT. The 2018 Mustang also gains new paint colors, four spoilers, new stripe options, more wheel choices, and more.</p>

<p>Inside, the 2018 Mustang gains a new customizable 12.o-inch digital instrument cluster with Track Apps, a heated leather steering wheel, and revived interior trim.</p>

<p>Ford also made drivetrain revisions. The V-6 engine is no longer available, while both the 2.3-liter EcoBoost I-4 and 5.0-liter Coyote V-8 have been revised for more power and better fuel mileage. The six-speed manual has been updated for both engines, and V-8 models gain a twin-disc clutch and dual-mass flywheel for better torque capability. The previously available six-speed automatic has been replaced by an <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/leaked-document-2018-ford-mustang-to-add-10-speed-automatic/">all-new 10-speed automatic</a>.</p>

<p>Other performance upgrades include revised monotube shocks, V-8 exhaust manifold and optional active exhaust system. Additionally, the revised Performance Packs will be available on all trims and engines. The Performance Pack now includes MagneRide dampers, a new Michelin performance tire, Brembo brakes, and more.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/mustang/2018/">Ford Mustang</a> coupe <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/mustang/2018/2018-ford-mustang-convertible-first-look/">and convertible</a> is the automaker’s legendary front-engine rear-drive sports car that slots below the much more expensive mid-engine rear-drive <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/gt/2018/">Ford GT</a> supercar and above the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/focus/2018/">Ford Focus</a> RS hatchback.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>For 2018, the Ford Mustang is available with turbocharged 2.3-liter EcoBoost I-4 in the base model or a port- and direct injected 5.0-liter Coyote V-8 in the Mustang GT. Performance Packs are available with either engine and both standard and Premium trim levels. Cloth seats are standard, and leather is optional. The Ford Mustang is offered in a wide variety of exterior paint colors and available stripes, interior colors and trim choices as well as wheels and spoilers.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Although the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/mustang/2018/">2018 Ford Mustang</a> hasn’t been crashed tested yet, we expect the coupe and convertible to retain similar NHTSA safety ratings as the 2017 model. The 2017 Ford Mustang has a five-star overall NHTSA safety rating (out of a possible five stars). Both Mustang body styles earned a Good rating from the IIHS in the moderate overlap front, side, and head restraints &amp; seats tests, while the coupe earned a Good in the roof strength and an Acceptable rating in the small overlap front tests. The 2017 Ford Mustang also earned a Basic rating for its optional Forward Collision Warning.</p>

<p>New active safety tech for the 2018 model year included distance alert, lane departure warning, pedestrian detection, and Pre-Collision Assist system that adds automatic emergency barking to the forward collision warning system.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think </strong></p>

<p>Although we are excited to test the updated drivetrains, in our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/mustang/2018/2018-ford-mustang-first-look-first-refresh-since-ponycar-went-global/">2018 Ford Mustang First Look</a>, we’re already looking ahead to the higher-performance variants: “Come on, Ford. Time to spill on the GT500.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>In addition to port- and (new) direct-injection, the 5.0-liter Coyote V-8 features the same wire arc spray-bore cylinder lining process used on the GT350/R coupe’s 5.2-liter Voodoo V-8 in place of the heavy iron cylinder liners.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>The 1.0-liter turbocharged I-3 engine has been dropped and a rearview camera is now standard on all models. All other features carry over. If the Fiesta returns to the U.S. market for another generation, we can expect the subcompact to be similar to the redesigned <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fiesta/2018/2018-ford-fiesta-european-spec-review/">European model that we reviewed</a>.</p>

<p>The subcompact <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fiesta/2018/">Ford Fiesta</a> sedan and hatchback are the automaker’s smallest vehicles and sit below the compact Focus sedan and hatch, and the midsize Fusion and full-size Taurus sedans.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Fiesta S</strong>: The base S trim comes equipped with a six-speaker radio with an auxiliary input jack, a rearview camera, hill-start assist, halogen headlights, six-way manual driver’s seat, Sync infotainment system, a tilt/telescoping steering wheel, and a tire pressure monitoring system.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Fiesta SE</strong>: The SE trim adds interior ambient lighting, cruise control, power windows with driver one-touch up and down, 15-inch aluminum wheels, keyless entry, upgraded front cloth seats, and a shift knob with a chrome insert (on automatic-transmission models).</p>

<p><strong>2018 Fiesta Titanium</strong>: Building off the SE’s features, the Titanium adds 16-inch aluminum  wheels, power and heated side view mirrors, fog lights, Sync 3 with SiriusXM satellite radio and two USB ports, a 6.5-inch touchscreen center display, a Sony audio system with HD Radio, leather-trimmed and heated front seats, automatic climate control, auto-dimming rearview mirror, push-button start, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Fiesta ST</strong>: The performance-oriented ST adds a turbocharged 1.6-liter I-4 engine, a six-speed manual transmission, sport suspension, 17-inch Rado Gray aluminum wheels, performance summer tires and brakes, twin chrome-tipped exhaust, ST fog lights, a mesh grille insert, unique body-color rocker panels, unique high-mounted rear spoiler, aluminum pedals, and ST badging.</p>

<p>The Fiesta ST can be optioned with red brake calipers and the ST Recaro package that includes Recaro partial leather-trimmed seats (six-way manual adjustable), heated front seats, and heated side view mirrors.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fiesta/2018/">2018 Ford Fiesta</a> is powered by a 1.6-liter I-4 that produces 120 hp and 112 lb-ft of torque in all models except the ST. The 1.6-liter delivers an EPA-rated 27/35 mpg city/highway with the standard five-speed manual transmission and 27/37 mpg with the optional six-speed dual clutch automatic. The high-performance Fiesta ST model is powered by a 1.6-liter turbo-four that pumps out a healthy 197 hp and 202 lb-ft of torque, is backed by a six-speed manual, and delivers 26/33 mpg. The Fiesta is available in sedan and hatchback body styles and front-wheel drive is the only option. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2014 Fiesta ST hit 60 mph in a quick 6.4 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in an impressive 104 feet.</p>

<p>In IIHS testing, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> Fiesta sedan and hatchback received the second-lowest score of Marginal for the small overlap front crash test but received the highest score of Good in four other crash tests. The front crash prevention test was not conducted because the Fiesta does not offer a collision warning or emergency automatic braking system. The 2018 Fiesta received a four-star overall safety rating out of five stars from the NHTSA. Standard safety features include a rearview camera, Ford’s Personal Safety System for front passengers with dual-stage airbags, and a tire pressure monitoring system.</p>

<p>Cargo space in the Fiesta sedan’s trunk is 12.8 cubic feet and 14.9 cubic feet for the hatchback behind the rear seats (10.1 cubic feet for the ST). That is less than the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/rio/2018/">2018 Kia Rio</a> that offers 13.7 cubic feet in the sedan and 17.4 cubic feet behind the rear seats of the hatchback. Legroom in the sedan and Rio hatchback are the same, 43.6 inches for the front and 31.2 inches for the rear passengers.</p>

<p>The 2018 Fiesta’s list of standard tech features is short, and includes a six-speaker radio with an audio input jack, a rearview camera, and the Sync infotainment system. Optional and standard on the Titanium trim is the Sync 3 system with SiriusXM satellite radio, a 6.5-inch touchscreen center display, two USB ports, and a Sony audio system with HD radio. A push-button start ignition and interior ambient lighting are also available.</p>

<p>In a 2014 Ford Fiesta SFE Ecoboost I-3 <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fiesta/2014/2014-ford-fiesta-sfe-ecoboost-first-test/">First Test review</a>, we were very impressed with the fuel economy and the torquey power band that the turbocharged three-cylinder engine provides (this engine was discontinued for the 2018 model year). However, interior vibration – especially at idle and lower rpm – might bother some people. To our surprise, the little three-cylinder is actually quicker than the 1.6-liter I-4 that’s standard on all non-ST 2018 Fiestas, and emits a unique but muffled growl.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fiesta/2014/2014-ford-fiesta-st-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 2014 Ford Fiesta ST, we were impressed with the lack of torque steer and understeer from the powerful front-wheel drive car. We did notice some turbo lag but once the boost hits, the subcompact rockets away. Acceleration is quick and the short stopping distance of 104 feet from 60 mph is impressive. The front seats have plenty of room but the rear seats lack space and cargo room is limited, like many subcompacts. The Fiesta ST offers very fun handling dynamics and is quite the driver’s car: “The clutch is light but communicative, rev matching is easy, and the pedals are positioned favorably for heel-and-toe shifts. Though not completely connected to the road, steering is nicely responsive and communicative. In all,” we continued, “there’s nothing here a driver won’t enjoy.” “Having spent time in both the Focus ST and the Fiesta ST, it’s a safe bet to say that those most interested in driving are going to prefer the Fiesta by a considerable margin. It’s simply much more fun to drive.”</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fusion/2018/">Ford Fusion</a> does not receive any significant changes for the new model year.</p>

<p>Positioned below <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a>’s largest sedan, the Taurus, the Fusion is larger and more expensive than the Fiesta and Focus sedans. The Fusion Hybrid and Energi plug-in are part of Ford’s electrified lineup that also consists of the C-Max hybrid and Focus Electric.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Fusion S</strong>: The Fusion’s base S trim comes equipped with a 2.5-liter I-4 engine, 16-inch alloy wheels, six-way manual driver’s seat, a four-speaker audio system, Sync infotainment system, a 2.3-inch instrument panel driver’s display, rotary gear shift dial, automatic headlights, push start ignition, a chrome grille, LED taillights, and hill start assist.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Fusion SE</strong>: In the SE trim, the 1.5- and 2.0-liter turbocharged engines are now optional, and more features are standard including 17-inch alloy wheels, 10-way power driver’s seat, six-way power passenger’s seat, a six-speaker audio system, a 4.2-inch instrument cluster driver’s display, SiriusXM satellite radio, power and heated side view mirrors, and LED daytime running lights.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Fusion Titanium</strong>: The Titanium trim comes standard with the 2.0-liter turbocharged engine, paddle shifters, 18-inch machined-face alloy wheels, leather upholstery, heated front Sport seats, 10-way power front seats, dual-zone climate control, a 12-speaker Sony audio system with HD radio, Sync 3 with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, dual 4.2-inch instrument panel driver’s display, leather-wrapped steering wheel, interior ambient lighting, rear A/C vents, remote engine start, LED fog lights, LED headlights, dual bright exhaust tips, and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Fusion Sport</strong>: The Sport model adds additional power with the 2.7-liter turbocharged V-6 engine and sportiness with all-wheel drive, continuously controlled damping, 19-inch wheels, heated sport seats with Dark Earth Gray Miko and leather surfaces, premium floor mats with Sport logo, aluminum sport pedals, unique high-gloss black mesh grille, quad-tip dual exhaust system, and LED headlights.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Fusion Platinum</strong>: The range-topping Fusion Platinum builds off the Titanium trim and comes well-equipped. The Fusion Platinum adds paddle shifters, 19-inch polished aluminum wheels, premium leather upholstery, premium leather-wrapped and stitched instrument panel and console rails, cooled front seats, Sync Connect, a navigation system, rain-sensing wipers, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, lane keep assist, a 110-volt power outlet, power tilt and telescoping steering wheel, a self-parking system, adaptive cruise control, pre-collision assist with pedestrian detection, power moonroof, a heated steering wheel, premium grille, and automatic high beams.</p>

<p>The Fusion Hybrid comes in S, SE, Titanium, and Platinum trims and the Energi plug-in comes in SE, Titanium, and Platinum trims (neither has a Sport trim).</p>

<p>The Fusion’s base 2.5-liter engine produces 175 hp and 175 lb-ft of torque and is only available with front-wheel drive (EPA-rated 21/32 mpg city/highway). The 1.5-liter turbocharged I-4 pumps out 181 hp and 185 lb-ft and like the 2.5-liter engine, it can only be paired to a FWD system but delivers a better 23/34 mpg. The more powerful 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 makes 245 hp and 275 lb-ft and is offered in FWD (21/31 mpg) and all-wheel drive (20/29 mpg). The Sport’s 2.7-liter turbocharged engine produces 325 hp and a healthy 380 lb-ft of torque and delivers 17/26 mpg with its standard AWD system. The Hybrid’s powertrain is rated at 43/41 mpg and the Energi plug-in can travel up to 21 miles on all-electric energy.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fusion/2018/">2018 Ford Fusion</a> received the highest five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA. In IIHS testing, the 2018 Ford Fusion is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick because it received the highest rating of Good in all six crash tests and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention evaluation for avoiding 12- and 25-mph frontal collisions thanks to the available (standard on Platinum trim) adaptive cruise control with stop-and-go and forward collision warning including active braking with pedestrian detection. The Fusion missed the “+” designation because it received the lowest rating of Poor for the headlights evaluation.</p>

<p>The Driver Assist package includes automatic high beams, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, a heated steering wheel, lane keep assist with lane keep alert, rain-sensing wipers, a 110-volt power outlet, and auto-dimming side view mirrors. A self-parking system is optional on all trims and standard on the top Platinum trim.</p>

<p>The Fusion can hold up to 16.0 cubic feet of cargo in its trunk, the Hybrid and Energi models hold less–12.0 cubic feet due to the battery pack. Front and rear legroom is 44.3 and 38.3 inches, respectively.</p>

<p>The Fusion’s standard tech includes the Sync infotainment system displayed on a 4.2-inch center display, a 2.3-inch driver’s display, and a rotary gear shifter. The driver’s instrument panel display can be upgraded to a 4.2-inch screen or a pair of 4.2-inch display screens. Sync 3 comes with a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, Sirius XM satellite radio, as well as Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. The standard four-speaker system can be upgraded to a six-speaker system or to the 12-speaker Sony unit with HD radio.</p>

<p>The Ford Pass app allows owners to find parking, compare fuel prices, receive important vehicle information, lock/unlock and start your vehicle, and schedule service from your smartphone. Sync Connect can also remotely start your vehicle and lock/unlock the doors, schedule remote start times, locate your Fusion in a parking lot, and check the car’s status. The optional continuously controlled damping with pothole mitigation smooths out the ride by detecting potholes and adjusts the suspension before the tire hits it.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fusion/2017/2017-ford-fusion-ecoboost-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 Ford Fusion with the turbocharged 1.5-liter engine, we liked how intuitive the Fusion’s Sync 3 infotainment system with Android Auto and Apple CarPlay is and how well it worked. We didn’t care for the sedan’s acceleration and short power band but the transmission shifts well and the engine provides good fuel economy, beating the EPA rating during Real MPG testing. The Fusion’s chassis is tuned well and offers a good mix of ride comfort and handling prowess. The cabin is comfortable, spacious, and quiet but has some cheap trim pieces. We concluded: “Priced at $25,000, our test car is attainable and surprisingly well-connected for the money. Multimedia tech is the main highlight in the refreshed Fusion. Its interface is user-friendly and easily integrated with mobile devices. The car isn’t perfect, however, because the cabin materials, chassis damping, and engine response could be improved.”</p>
