<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fusion/2017/2017-ford-fusion-sport-ecoboost-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 Ford Fusion Sport, we praised the engine for its strong power and very quick acceleration, hitting 60 mph in just 5.3 seconds. The standard AWD system delivers the power very well, even when launched hard. However, we wish the transmission was snappier with downshifts but it upshifts well. Handling is good and steering feel is fine, but braking was not stand-out; the car stopped from 60 mph in 122 feet. The cabin is comfortable and quiet, though maybe too quiet as we wanted to hear more of that powerful engine. “But still with two turbos, all-wheel drive, and impressive straight-line speed, the unassuming Fusion Sport is a surprisingly fun outlier in a segment that thrives on playing it safe,” we said.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p> </p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> dropped the C-Max Energi plug-in model from the lineup, leaving the unchanged C-Max Hybrid for its last model year.</p>

<p>The C-Max is Ford’s only hatchback hybrid and the automaker’s only other hybrid vehicle along with the Fusion Hybrid.</p>

<p><strong>2018 C-Max SE</strong>: The base trim comes equipped with 17-inch aluminum wheels, Sync infotainment system with USB and auxiliary ports, LED daytime running lights, active grille shutters, dual-zone automatic climate control, leather-wrapped steering wheel, 110-volt outlet, and 10-way power adjustable driver seat.</p>

<p><strong>2018 C-Max Titanium</strong>: The top Titanium trim adds 17-inch aluminum wheels with painted pockets, power and heated exterior mirrors, fog lights, a chrome grille, rear parking sensors, rain-sensing wipers, leather-trimmed seats, heated front seats, push-start ignition, remote engine start, Sync 3 with unique hybrid content and an 8.0-inch touchscreen, a nine-speaker Sony audio system with HD radio, 10-way power adjustable passenger’s seat, and an auto-dimming rearview mirror.</p>

<p>Some notable features include a panoramic fixed glass roof and a motion-activated power liftgate.</p>

<p>The 2018 Ford C-Max’s electrified powertrain consists of a 2.0-liter I-4 engine paired to an electric motor for a total system output of 188 hp, delivering an EPA-rated 42/38 mpg city/highway and has a driving range of 540 miles (based on the EPA’s default split of 55 percent city and 45 percent highway). A CVT routes power to the front wheels. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2013 C-Max Hybrid hit 60 mph in 8.1 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 128 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 Ford C-Max received four stars out of five for the hatchback’s overall safety rating. In IIHS testing, the C-Max received the second-highest rating of Acceptable for the driver-side small overlap front crash test and the highest rating of Good for four other crash tests. The front crash prevention test was not conducted because the C-Max does not offer an automatic emergency braking system. A blind-spot monitoring system with rear-cross traffic alert is found in the Titanium Driver Assist package that also includes front parking sensors and a self-parking system. A rearview camera and an SOS post-crash alert system are standard.</p>

<p>The 2018 C-Max offers 24.5 cubic feet of cargo space behind the rear seats and 52.6 cubic feet with the rear seats folded down. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/niro/2018/">Kia Niro</a> hybrid has 19.4 cubic feet behind the rear seats and 54.5 with the rear seats folded down. Front seat passengers in the C-Max have 43.1 inches of legroom while rear seat passengers make due with 36.5 inches.</p>

<p>The C-Max comes standard with the Sync infotainment system with USB and auxiliary ports and a 110-volt power outlet for devices. Sync 3 is the upgraded infotainment system that is displayed on an 8.0-inch touchscreen; SiriusXM satellite radio and a navigation system are optional. A six-speaker audio system is standard and a nine-speaker Sony sound system with HD radio is available. A self-parking system and remote engine start are optional.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/c-max/2013/2013-ford-c-max-hybrid-sel-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 2013 Ford C-Max, we liked the cabin and its “comfortable and airy environment with plenty of cushy materials, bright lightings, and supportive seating. The extra-large windows add to the interior’s open feel and allow for superb all-around visibility. Storage compartments and power outlets galore make the interior as useful as it is stylish.”</p>

<p>We also liked the hatchback’s fuel efficiency and said “If you drive it with the A/C blasting, radio blaring, and the occasional jackrabbit start from a stoplight, you’ll easily see 35-plus mpg, thanks to its highly efficient 2.0-liter Atkinson four-cylinder that’s good for 141 hp and 129 lb-ft of torque, 118-hp electric motor, and library-quiet HF35 eCVT transmission.” We thought it was fun to drive for a hybrid—so much so, that the author recommended “two different people to purchase a C-Max Hybrid instead of a Prius.”</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/flex/2018/">Ford Flex</a> did not receive any significant changes for the new model year and all model features carry over.</p>

<p>In <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a>’s crossover lineup, the three-row Flex is positioned above the all-new and subcompact EcoSport, Escape, and Edge. Among Ford’s SUVs and crossovers, only the three-row Explorer and Expedition have higher starting prices.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Flex SE</strong>: The base SE trim comes standard with 4.2-inch instrument cluster and center LCD screens, rear parking sensors, bright dual exhaust tips, power and heated side view mirrors, rear climate controls, auto-dimming rearview mirror, manual tilt and telescoping steering wheel, a USB port, SYNC infotainment system, six-way power driver’s seat, 17-inch painted aluminum wheels and a rearview camera.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Flex SEL</strong>: If you upgrade to the SEL, your Flex will also get fog lights, stainless steel bright beltline side and rear molding, chrome door handles, dual-zone automatic climate control, San Macassar Wood interior trim, heated front seats, a remote start system, blind spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert, Intelligent access with push-start ignition, two USB charging ports, an 8.0-inch center touchscreen display, SYNC 3, 10-way power driver’s seat, six-way power front passenger seat, and 18-inch painted aluminum wheels.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Flex Limited</strong>: In addition to the SEL features, the range-topping model comes with a power liftgate, HID headlights, LED taillights, Satin-aluminum finish grille and liftgate applique, power-folding and heated side view mirrors with security approach lights, interior ambient lighting, perforated leather-wrapped steering wheel with wood inlay, Charcoal Black leather-trimmed seats with perforated inserts, Yoho Maple Cross interior instrument panel and door trim, a navigation system with Sirius XM Traffic and Travel Link, a 12-speaker Sony audio system, and 19-inch painted aluminum wheels.</p>

<p>A self-parking system, Multipanel Vista Roof, heated and cooled front seats, and one-touch power-folding third-row seats are some notable features.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/flex/2018/">2018 Ford Flex</a> is powered by a standard 3.5-liter V-6 that produces 287 hp and 254 lb-ft of torque and delivers an EPA-rated 16/23 mpg city/highway with front-wheel drive and 16/22 mpg with all-wheel drive. The available 3.5-liter twin-turbo V-6 produces a healthy 365 hp and 350 lb-ft of torque and is only paired to an all-wheel-drive system, delivering 15/21 mpg. Both engines are backed by a six-speed automatic. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2013 Ford Flex Limited with the twin-turbo V-6 (the same EcoBoost powertrain is still offered today) hit 60 mph in a quick 5.9 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a respectable 122 feet.</p>

<p>In NHTSA testing, the Ford Flex was only evaluated for the rollover crash test and the crossover received four stars out of five stars. With the exception of an Acceptable rating in the small overlap front crash test, the Flex scored the highest rating of Good in the remaining four crash evaluations in IIHS testing. The lowest score of Basic was issued for front crash prevention for properly warning the driver of a collision but the Flex does not offer emergency automatic braking and cannot avoid a frontal accident. Standard safety features for the 2018 Ford Flex include AdvanceTrac with Roll Stability Control, a rearview camera, and an SOS Post-Crash alert system that flashes the hazard lights and honks the horn in an event of an accident. Available driver assist safety feature include adaptive cruise control with forward collision warning with brake support, blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert, inflatable rear safety belts, and a self-parking system.</p>

<p>Behind the second-row, the Flex offers 43.2 cubic feet of cargo space. Put the second row down, and the cargo space grows to a massive 83.2 cubic feet. That actually tops the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/explorer/2018/">Ford Explorer</a>’s maximum cargo capacity of 81.7 cubic feet. Behind the third row is 20.0 cubic feet of cargo space. The Flex offers 42.6 inches of front legroom, 44.3 inches of second-row legroom, and 33.3 inches of third-row legroom.</p>

<p>The 2018 Flex’s standard infotainment system is SYNC with a 4.2-inch LCD center display screen and a 4.2-inch driver’s display screen with AppLink and 911 Assist and SOS Post-Crash Alert system. An audio USB port and an auxiliary audio jack are also standard. Upgrading to the larger 8.0-inch touchscreen will get you SYNC 3 and two quick-charging USB ports. The Limited model comes standard with a 12-speaker Sony audio system, navigation, and a 110-volt power outlet for electronics. The Active Park Assist self-parking system is available.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/flex/2013/2013-ford-flex-first-drive/">First Drive review</a> of the 2013 Ford Flex, we said that “the added power and broader torque curve are readily noticeable on the base V-6, which steps off with greater authority, though we wish the shifts happened quicker and with less torque sag. The new brakes feel great — nice firm pedal, minimal travel, easily modulated for smooth stops. And try as I could, I found no fault with the electric power steering. Its weighting felt natural; the quicker ratio is welcome; and with most of the rubber isolation out of the system, the driver can sense road-surface texture through the rim, but not changes in road-surface grip. Interior noise levels are remarkably low, allowing front-seat conversation to be easily heard from the third row. EcoBoost models dial all of the above impressions up several notches, with truly naughty acceleration rates and slightly crisper steering feel.”</p>

<p>A new SEL trim joins the lineup offering leather and Sync 3. The 2018 Escape SEL is positioned above the S and SE trims but below the Titanium trim. The 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 is now only available in the top Titanium trim.</p>

<p>The compact 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/escape/2018/">Ford Escape</a> crossover is positioned above the new subcompact EcoSport but below the midsize Edge, three-row Flex, three-row Explorer, and three-row Expedition SUVs.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Escape S</strong>: The base S trim comes equipped with the 2.5-liter I-4 engine, 17-inch steel wheels, six-way manual front seats, Sync infotainment system with a 4.2-inch screen, Ice Blue instrument panel lighting, automatic headlights, LED taillights, and a rearview camera.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Escape SE</strong>: The SE trim adds the 1.5-liter turbocharged I-4 engine, 17-inch alloy wheels, 10-way power driver’s seat, dual-zone climate control, sync with SiriusXM satellite radio, one-touch up/down on all windows, fog lights, dual chrome exhaust tips, and black roof rails.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Escape SEL</strong>: The new SEL trim builds off the SE trims, adding leather-trimmed front seats, a power liftgate, heated side view mirrors, heated front seats, signature LED lighting, Sync 3 with a Wi-Fi hotspot and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, an 8.0-inch center touchscreen, a leather-wrapped steering wheel and gear-shift knob, and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Escape Titanium</strong>: The top trims comes equipped with the 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 engine, adds 18-inch wheels, a 10-way power passenger’s seat, driver’s seat memory, a 10-speaker Sony audio system, a heated steering wheel, an auto-dimming rearview mirror, a 110-volt power outlet, interior ambient lighting, quick entry with a push-start ignition, remote engine start, a self-parking system, silver roof racks, and a foot-activated liftgate.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/escape/2018/">2018 Ford Escape</a> is available with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> Smart and Safe package of driver assist safety features, all-wheel drive, a panoramic moonroof, and 19-inch alloy wheels, and a navigation system.</p>

<p>The Escape’s base engine is a 2.5-liter I-4 with 168 hp and 170 lb-ft of torque. Only available on the Escape S, the Ford delivers an EPA-rated 21/29 mpg city/highway with front-wheel drive (all-wheel drive is not available on the base engine). The optional engine is a 1.5-liter turbocharged I-4 that produces 170 hp and 177 lb-ft and is rated at 23/30 mpg with FWD and 22/28 mpg with AWD. The top 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 engine makes 245 hp and 275 lb-ft and delivers 21/28 with FWD and 20/27 with AWD. All engines are mated to a six-speed automatic. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 Ford Escape with the 1.5-liter turbo-four and FWD hit 60 mph in 9.2 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 126 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 Ford Escape received the highest five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA. In IIHS testing, the Escape received the second-highest rating of Acceptable for the driver-side small overlap front crash test and the highest rating of Good in the other four conducted crash tests. The lowest rating of Basic was issued for the front crash prevention test for properly warning the driver of a possible collision thanks to the optional forward collision warning feature, but the Escape does not offer emergency automatic braking. The available Ford Safe and Smart package consists of rain-sensing windshield wipers, adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning with brake support, automatic high beams, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, lane keep assist, and a windshield wiper de-icer.</p>

<p>The Escape offers a healthy amount of cargo room with 34.0 cubic feet behind the rear seats and 68.0 with the rear seats folded down. The new <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/equinox/2018/">Chevrolet Equinox</a> offers 29.9 cubic feet and 63.5, respectively. Front passengers receive 43.1 inches of legroom and the rear seats offer 37.3 inches.</p>

<p>Standard tech for the Escape includes the Sync infotainment system displayed on a 4.2-inch center screen with voice recognition and a rearview camera. The upgraded Sync 3 system comes displayed on an 8.0-inch center screen and comes with a Wi-Fi hotspot, SiriusXM satellite radio, and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto smartphone compatibility. A six-speaker audio system is standard and a 10-speaker Sony system is optional. Other tech features include remote engine start, a self-parking system, a foot-activated power liftgate, and a 110-volt power outlet. The FordPass app allows the owner to do several things such as finding parking, looking up vehicle information and scheduling service, locating fuel stations and comparing prices, locking/unlocking and starting your Escape remotely.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/escape/2017/2017-ford-escape-ecoboost-awd-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 Ford Escape 2.0 EcoBoost, we felt that out loaded Titanium tester with AWD was pricey at $39,010, comparable to a mid-level Explorer. However, during SUV of the Year testing, judges praised the crossover’s handling dynamics and neutral chassis, saying it drove “very much like a hot hatch; you can tell that Ford of Europe had their hand in there somewhere.” Acceleration was quick and Real MPG testing numbers surpassed the EPA’s. We enjoyed the roomy interior and technology but felt the styling was showing its age. “All the goodness to be found in the 2017 Ford Escape could be had for several thousand dollars less than this loaded Titanium example; consider the midgrade SE trim with the outstanding 2.0-liter EcoBoost engine. This version might’ve even won that mega comparison test … [and] will suit both the driving enthusiast and the economy enthusiast,” we concluded.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-5/2016/small-crossover-comparison-big-test/">Big Test comparison</a> of nine compact crossovers, the Ford Escape SE with the 1.5-liter EcoBoost engine came in sixth place. The aged interior, tight backseat and slow acceleration took a toll on its ranking. “In sixth place is the Ford Escape SE. The Ford has a lot going for it from a ride-and-handling perspective, but there’s more to being a good family hauler than good dynamics. Its sluggish instrumented testing performance and tight cabin are really what sunk the Ford,” we said.</p>

<p>A SEL Sport Appearance package is new, as are seats that feature Mayan Gray fabric with Umber-colored cloth seats with Miko suede cloth inserts. SEL, Titanium, and Sport models add an available Safe and Smart package.</p>

<p>In size, the midsize two-row <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/edge/2018/">2018 Ford Edge</a> slots above the new subcompact EcoSport and compact Escape crossovers, but below the three-row Flex, Explorer, and Expedition.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Edge SE</strong>: The Edge’s base model comes standard with 18-inch wheels, automatic headlights, dual stainless steel exhaust tips, LED taillights, rear spoiler, Sync infotainment system, a 4.2-inch center screen, push-start ignition, a USB port, and a leather-wrapped shift knob.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Edge SEL</strong>: The SEL trim adds dual-zone climate control, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, auto-dimming rearview mirror, a 10-way power driver’s seat, 6-way power passenger’s seat, unique cloth seats, SiriusXM satellite radio, EasyFold rear seats, rear parking sensors, heated side view mirrors with approach lights, and LED signature lighting.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Edge Titanium</strong>: Move up to the Titanium trim and the Edge adds interior ambient lighting, an 8.0-inch center LCD touchscreen, two 4.2-inch LCD instrument cluster driver’s displays, Sync 3 infotainment system, leather-trimmed sport bucket seats, a 12-speaker Sony audio system, heated front seats, two USB ports, illuminated door sills, 10-way front passenger’s seat, a hands-free foot-activated liftgate, and LED taillights with light bar.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Edge Sport</strong>: The range-topping Sport trim comes with the 2.7-liter Ecoboost engine, sport-tuned suspension, all-wheel drive, adaptive steering, 20-inch polished wheels, leather-trimmed seats with Miko suede cloth inserts, power tilt and telescoping steering wheel, unique body-color front, and rear lower fascia, and a piano black grille with Magnetic surround.</p>

<p>The 401A equipment package adds luxury and safety with a navigation system, ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, a self-parking system, a front 180-degree camera, HID headlights, remote engine start, rain-sensing wipers, a 110-volt power outlet, adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, and lane keep assist.</p>

<p>The base engine in the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> Edge is a 2.0-liter turbo-four rated 245 hp and 275 lb-ft of torque, with an EPA-rated 20/29 mpg city/highway with front-wheel drive (21/29 mpg with auto start/stop) and 20/27 mpg with all-wheel drive. The optional 3.5-liter V-6 pumps out 280 hp and 250 lb-ft and is rated at 17/26 mpg with FWD and 17/23 mpg with AWD. <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/edge/2016/2016-ford-edge-sport-awd-first-test-review/">The Ford Edge Sport</a> is powered by a 2.7-liter twin-turbo V-6 rated 315 hp and 350 lb-ft and comes standard with AWD, delivering 17/24 mpg. All engines are mated to a six-speed automatic transmission. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2016 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/edge/2018/">Ford Edge</a> Sport hit 60 mph in 5.7 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 120 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 Ford Edge received the highest overall safety rating of five stars from the NHTSA. In IIHS testing, the 2018 Ford Edge received the second-highest rating of Acceptable for the driver-side small overlap front crash test but received the highest rating of Good in four other crash tests. The lowest rating of Basic was issued for the front crash prevention evaluation because the Edge properly warned the driver of a possible collision but doesn’t offer emergency automatic braking. Available driver assist safety features include adaptive cruise control and forward collision with brake support, blind-spot monitoring with cross-traffic alert, active park assist with side parking sensors, lane keep assist, and a front 180-degree camera. A rearview camera system and an SOS post-crash alert system are standard.</p>

<p>The Edge offers 39.2 cubic feet of cargo room behind the rear seats and 73.4 cubic feet with the rear seats folded down. Front and rear seat legroom are 42.6 and 40.6 inches, respectively. The Edge tops the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/santa-fe/2018/">Hyundai Santa Fe</a> Sport’s cargo space of 35.4 cubic feet with the seats up and 71.5 with the seats down. <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/murano/2015/2015-ford-edge-nissan-murano-hyundai-santa-fe-sport-comparison/">In a comparison</a> with the Edge, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/murano/2018/">Nissan Murano</a>, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/">Hyundai</a> Santa Fe, we noted that even though the Edge has more rear-seat legroom on paper, in person, the Murano had noticeably more room.</p>

<p>The standard Sync infotainment system is displayed on a 4.2-inch center display screen and comes with one USB port, but the available Sync 3 system comes with an 8.0-inch touchscreen and two USB ports. Two 4.2-inch instrument panel driver display screens, SiriusXM satellite radio, and a Sony audio system are available. Other optional tech includes a hands-free motion-activated liftgate, a self-parking system, a dual-screen rear entertainment system, and adaptive cruise control with other driver assist features.</p>

<p>In a of the 2015 Ford Edge Sport AWD, we liked the quick acceleration and loads of features but all that came with a high price tag. “Should you be in the market and score a test drive with the Sport,” we wrote, “let us know if you thought the suede inserts in the front and rear leather seating caused discomfort, as they did with some editors. There’s no question this is the most impressive Edge yet.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/edge/2016/2016-ford-edge-sport-awd-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2016 Ford Edge Sport AWD with adaptive steering, we said: “What is it like to drive this quick, firm-riding SUV that doesn’t prioritize on-road ride comfort or fuel savings (16.5/23.9/19.2 city/highway/combined Real MPG)? Pretty much the same as last time. Aside from the presence of the attractive and faster-reacting Sync 3 and the newly gained ease of parking thanks to adaptive steering, it was a challenge to spot the differences.”</p>

<p>The <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-350/2018/">2018 Ford F-350</a> gets an upgraded diesel engine option with more torque.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-350/2018/">Ford F-350</a> is a heavy duty truck that slots above the F-250. Available in five grades, the F-350 offers three cab styles, single or dual-wheel layouts, and two bed lengths.</p>

<p><strong>F-350 XL:</strong> The base XL trim comes standard with bench seats (including rear seats on the SuperCab and crew cab), vinyl seats, air conditioning, a four-speaker audio system, a rearview camera, and 17-inch steel wheels.</p>

<p><strong>F-350 XLT: </strong>Move up to the XLT trim and you’ll get 18-inch wheels, cloth upholstery, cruise control, a 4.2-inch instrument cluster display, and steering wheel audio controls.</p>

<p><strong>F-350 Lariat: </strong>The Lariat model is the first of three variants that lean toward luxury and come standard with leather upholstery, 10-way power front seats, dual-zone climate control, a 10-speaker Sony audio system, Sync 3 with an 8.0-inch touchscreen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, rear parking sensors, and a leather-wrapped steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>F-350 King Ranch: </strong>King Ranch models feature unique treatments including bright 18-inch alloy wheels, Mesa brown leather upholstery, heated and ventilated front seats, navigation, and a heated steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>F-350 Platinum: </strong>Range-topping Platinum models come with 20-inch alloy wheels, heated rear seats, full LED headlights, and multicontour front seats with a massage function.</p>

<p>Options include remote start, power-deployable side steps, LED bed lighting, a 360-degree camera system, a panoramic sunroof, and a power-sliding rear window. The FX4 off-road package is also available and includes unique suspension tuning and transfer case, and skid plates for the fuel tank.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> F-350 comes standard with a 6.2-liter V-8 good for 385 hp and 430 lb-ft of torque. A 6.7-liter turbodiesel V-8 rated at 450 hp and 935 lb-ft is also available. Both engines are paired to a heavy-duty six-speed automatic transmission. The EPA doesn’t rate heavy duty trucks for fuel economy.</p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Ford F-350. Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert are optional on the XL, XLT, and Lariat trims and standard on higher grades. Lariat, King Ranch and Platinum models are also available with adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, and automatic emergency braking.</p>

<p>When properly equipped, the 2018 F-350 can haul up to 7,630 pounds of payload depending on the cab style and bed length. The F-350 has the ability to pull up to 21,000 pounds of payload with a conventional trailer or up to 32,000 pounds with a fifth wheel or goose neck.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-250/2017/2017-ford-f-series-super-duty-first-drive-tow-masters/">2017 First Drive</a>, we appreciated the F-350’s towing capability and the improved cabin materials. Ride quality, however, is still stiff when empty but becomes smooth when loaded. Both engines offers plenty of power but the diesel is punchier. We were impressed by how easy it was to use the driving aids that facilitate towing and hauling.</p>

<p>With its generous towing capacity, torque-rich diesel engine, and slick tech features that help with towing, the Ford Super Duty family was crowned <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/ford-super-duty-2017-motor-trend-truck-of-the-year/"><em>Motor Trend’s </em>2017 Truck of the Year</a>.</p>

<p>The current-generation Ford F-350, like the smaller F-150, has an aluminum body to help reduce the truck’s overall weight.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Everything. The 2018 <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/ford-ecosport-small-crossover-confirmed-for-north-america/">Ford EcoSport is a new model for the U.S. market</a>. Although the Fiesta-based crossover has been on sale in various global markets for years, 2018 is the first model year for the subcompact crossover in the U.S.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>Based on the subcompact <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fiesta/2018/">Ford Fiesta</a>, the new <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/ecosport/2018/">Ford EcoSport</a> slots below the Escape, Edge, three-row Explorer, three-row full-size Flex, and three-row Expedition in the automaker’s SUV/crossover lineup. The subcompact Ford EcoSport competes in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/xv-crosstrek/2015/the-big-test-2015-2016-subcompact-crossovers/">growing segment</a> that also includes the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/renegade/2018/">Jeep Renegade</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/trax/2018/">Chevrolet Trax</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/hr-v/2018/">Honda HR-V</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-3/2018/">Mazda CX-3</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/kicks/2018/">Nissan Kicks</a>, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/crosstrek/2018/">Subaru Crosstrek</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The base engine in the Ford EcoSport is a variation of the 1.0-liter EcoBoost turbo-three also found in the Fiesta and Focus cars. In the 2018 EcoSport, the engine makes 123 hp and 125 lb-ft of torque and is only offered with front-wheel drive. A 2.0-liter I-4 is optional on all-wheel-drive models, making 166 hp and 149 lb-ft. Both engines are mated to a six-speed automatic transmission. Front-drive is standard, though all-wheel-drive is standard with the 2.0-liter engine.</p>

<p>Four trim levels will be offered including S, SE, SES, and top-spec Titanium. The sporty SES trim features intelligent all-wheel-drive, a sport-tuned suspension, sport seats, copper interior accents, and more.</p>

<p>Other standard and available features include ambient lighting, a floating infotainment screen with an available 8.0-inch screen, Apple CarPlay, Android Auto, fast-charging USB ports, 12-volt ports, and leather seats (heated in front).</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Available active safety features include a blind-spot monitoring system with cross-traffic alert.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>We <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/six-first-impressions-2018-ford-ecosport/">got our first look at the new subcompact crossover</a> during its North American reveal. Although the rear seats fold flat, they don’t fold level with the rear cargo floor. A height-adjustable shelf solves that issue. The EcoSport also features lots of storage bins and cubbies.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The EcoSport is available with a 10-speaker, 675-watt B&amp;O Play audio system by Harman.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>New features for 2018 include a high-mounted rearview camera for medium- and high-roof models. Available features include forged alloy dual-rear wheel package for both body styles. Other new options include a heavy-duty cargo flooring option, heavy-duty rear scuff plate kits and rear-door scuff plate kit (cargo van), power-folding short-arm heated mirrors with turn signals, and push-down parking brake on certain models.</p>

<p>D-pillar assist handles are available on medium- and high-roof models. A new optional AM/FM stereo includes Bluetooth, auxiliary jack and microphone. Stone Gray is a new exterior paint color, while charcoal leather seating is also available.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Designed in Europe, the full-size <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/transit/2018/">2018 Ford Transit</a> arrived in the U.S. market in 2015 as a replacement for the aging Econoline (E-Series) van. Available as a passenger wagon or cargo van, the Transit is complemented by the smaller front-drive Transit Connect passenger wagon and cargo van.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/transit/2018/">Ford Transit</a> is available with a choice of three engines. The base engine is a 3.7-liter V-6 making 275 hp and 260 lb-ft of torque. Optional engines include a twin-turbo 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6 rated 310 hp and 400 lb-ft and a 3.2-liter Powerstroke turbodiesel I-5 making 185 hp and 350 lb-ft. All engines are mated to a six-speed automatic overdrive transmission with SelectShift capability.</p>

<p>Body styles and trims include Cargo Van, Passenger Wagon XL, and Passenger Wagon XLT. Roof heights include low- (83-inch), medium- (100-inch), and high-roof (109-110-inch). Two wheelbases (130-inch and 148-inch) are available in three lengths including regular (130-inch wheelbase, 126-inch load floor), long (148-inch wheelbase), 143.7-inch load floor), and extended length (148-inch wheelbase, 172.2-inch load floor).</p>

<p>The Transit is also available with single- or dual-rear wheels that are tucked inside the bodywork. Dual sliding side doors are available on medium- and high-roof models. Wagon models are available in eight-, 10-, 12-, or 15-passenger versions. Chassis cab and cutaway versions are also available.</p>

<p>Options include SYNC 3 with a 6.5-inch touchscreen display and navigation, while fleet customers can specify a GPS-based <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> Telematics powered by Telogis that can keep track of maintenance schedules and track the vehicle’s location.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Standard safety features include AdvanceTrac with roll stability control, front airbags, and Tire Pressure Monitoring System.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think </strong></p>

<p>“The flavors are many, as are the toppings,” we said in our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/transit/2015/2015-ford-transit-first-drive/">2015 Ford Transit First Drive</a>. “But no matter which variety is earmarked for daily duty, buyers can count on a comfortable, efficient, highly capable, nicely priced foundation. In other words, the fiery rumble between commercial vans in America just got hotter. Hey, ProMaster, NV, Sprinter, Express — you’d better watch out.”</p>

<p>At the end of our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/transit/2015/2015-ford-transit-150-350hd-first-test/">2015 Ford Transit 150, 350HD First Test</a>, we concluded: “Ford has entered a quick growing segment in the cargo/passenger van/wagon market and has done it the right way. It offers a massive variety of configurations to fit any need its customers might have, from a comfort-friendly passenger vehicle to heavy-duty work vehicle and everything in between. What Ford has done with the 2015 Transit will not go unnoticed by its competition, and for very good reason.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Ford Transit’s unit-body construction is stronger and more capable than the old body-on-frame Econoline van.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2018-ford-explorer-gets-mildest-refreshes-new-york/">2018 Ford Explorer gets mild freshening</a> before its next major redesign. Updates include a new grille and foglights, and quad exhaust tips on models with the 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6. Other exterior changes include four new paint options and five wheel choices. The interior gains a 4G LTE modem and Wi-Fi hotspot. A new Safe and Smart package combines several popular active safety and driver assist tech together.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>In price, the three-row midsize <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/explorer/2018/">2018 Ford Explorer</a> slots above the compact Escape, midsize two-row Edge, and three-row Flex, but below the full-size Expedition SUV.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>Three engine options are offered for the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/explorer/2018/">Ford Explorer</a> including a 3.5-liter V-6 base engine making 290 hp and 255 lb-ft of torque. Optional engines include turbocharged 2.3-liter EcoBoost I-4 with 280 hp and 310 lb-ft or a twin-turbo 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6 making 365 hp and 350 lb-ft. A six-speed automatic backs all engine options. Front-drive is standard with the 3.5-liter and 2.3-liter, and the automaker’s all-wheel-drive system is available with the base 3.5-liter and 2.3-liter EcoBoost and standard with 3.5-liter EcoBoost.</p>

<p>The 2018 Explorer is available in five trim levels including the base model, XLT, Limited, Sport, and top-spec Platinum. Standard and available options include cloth or leather seating surfaces, rear auxiliary climate control, 12-speaker Sony premium audio system, SiriusXM satellite radio, navigation, a twin-panel moonroof, heated and cooled seats, heated steering wheel, and more.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>With only a mild refresh to the 2018 Explorer, we expect the 2017 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> Explorer’s five-star <a href="https://www.nhtsa.gov/">NHTSA rating</a> (out of a possible five stars) to carry over, as well as <a href="http://www.iihs.org/iihs/ratings/vehicle/v/ford/explorer-4-door-suv">the IIHS’ Good ratings</a> in the moderate overlap front, side, and roof strength tests and its Marginal rating in the small overlap front test. The 2017 Explorer also earned a Basic rating for its front crash warning. Available active safety and driver assistance tech on the 2017 model includes in the new Safe and Sound package includes collision warning and emergency braking, lane keeping, blind-spot warning, cross-traffic warning, adaptive cruise control, auto high beams, and rain-sensing wipers.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>“Ultimately, that might be the single biggest problem with the new Explorer Platinum and the Explorer as a whole: For every one thing it does well, someone else does it better. Want something roomier? There’s the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/pilot/2018/">Honda Pilot</a>. Want something more fun to drive? Look at the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-9/2018/">Mazda CX-9</a>. Want something more luxurious? Check out the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/acadia/2018/">GMC Acadia</a>,” we concluded in out <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/explorer/2016/2016-ford-explorer-platinum-first-test/">2016 Ford Explorer Platinum EcoBoost First Test</a>. “The Ford Explorer line is thoroughly competitive on paper, but its dominance has ultimately led the competition to simply try harder. With others overtaking the Explorer in comfort, packaging, luxury, and dynamics, it’s now finally time for Ford to show ‘we try harder’ when the next-generation Explorer hits the streets in 2019.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2.3-liter EcoBoost is available with all-wheel drive, while the previous 2.0-liter EcoBoost I-4 was front-drive only.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fusion/2018/">Ford Fusion</a> Hybrid and Energi plug-in did not receive any significant changes for the new model year.</p>

<p>The Fusion Hybrid and the C-Max hybrid are the only non-plug-in hybrids in <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a>’s lineup. The Fusion Energi plug-in is Ford’s only plug-in hybrid now that the C-Max Energi has been discontinued.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fusion/2018/">2018 Ford Fusion</a> Hybrid S</strong>: The base S trim comes standard with 17-inch alloy wheels, six-way manually adjustable driver’s seat (four-way for passenger), dual-zone climate control, Sync infotainment system, a nine-speaker audio system, two 4.2-inch instrument panel displays, a rotary gear shifter, automatic headlights, rear A/C vents, push-start ignition, power and heated side view mirror, and a rearview camera.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fusion-hybrid/2018/">2018 Ford Fusion Hybrid</a> SE</strong>: Moving up to the SE trim adds a 10-way power driver’s seat (six-way for passenger), SiriusXM satellite radio, and LED daytime running lights. The SE trim also makes features that are not on the S trim available such as heated seats, 18-inch wheels, and an available 11-speaker  audio system.</p>

<p><strong>2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fusion-hybrid/2018/">Ford Fusion Hybrid</a> Titanium</strong>: The Titanium trim comes equipped with 18-inch alloy wheels, 10-way power front seats with memory settings, leather seating, heated front seats, a 12-speaker Sony audio system with HD radio, Sync 3, a 110-volt outlet, interior ambient lighting, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, aluminum sport pedals, quick entry with remote engine start, LED fog lights, LED headlights, and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Ford Fusion Hybrid Platinum</strong>: Building off the Titanium, the top trim adds premium seating surfaces, premium-leather wrapped instrument panel and armrests, cooled front seats, Sync Connect, a navigation system with SiriusXM Traffic and Travel Link, rain-sensing wipers, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, lane keep assist, a self-parking system, adaptive cruise control, automatic emergency braking with pedestrian detection, a power moonroof, a heated steering wheel, a unique sport grille, automatic high beams, and a power tilt/telescoping steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fusion-energi/2018/">Ford Fusion Energi</a> SE</strong>: The base Energi SE model comes standard with 17-inch wheels, 10-way power driver’s seat (six-way passenger) with memory settings, leather-trimmed seating, an 11-speaker audio system, Sync 3, dual 4.2-inch instrument panel driver’s display, SiriusXM satellite radio, 110-volt power outlet, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, auto-dimming rearview mirror, quick entry with remote start ignition, LED daytime running lights, LED headlights, and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Ford Fusion Energi Titanium</strong>: The Titanium adds 10-way power front seats, heated front seats, a 12-speaker Sony audio system with HD radio, interior ambient lighting, aluminum sport pedals, a power moonroof, LED fog lights, and a rear spoiler.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Ford Fusion Energi Platinum</strong>: The top Platinum trim comes equipped with premium leather seating, premium leather-wrapped instrument panel and armrests, cooled front seats, a navigation system with SiriusXM Traffic and Travel Link, rain-sensing wipers, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, lane keep assist, power tilt/telescoping steering wheel, a self-parking system, adaptive cruise control, automatic emergency braking with pedestrian detection, a heated steering wheel, a unique sport grille, and automatic high beams.</p>

<p>The Ford Fusion Hybrid and Energi plug-in are powered by a 2.0-liter I-4 engine paired to an electric motor for a combined output of 188 hp. The Hybrid comes with an EPA rating of 43/41 mpg city/highway and the Energi is also rated at 43/41 mpg when in hybrid mode, with 97 mpg-e on all-electric power. Before the gas engine turns on, the Fusion Energi is rated for up to 21 miles of all-electric power. A CVT routes power to the front wheels. In <em>Motor Trend </em>testing, the 2017 Ford Fusion Hybrid hit 60 mph in 8.7 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 123 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 Ford Fusion Hybrid received the highest five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA. The 2018 Ford Fusion is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick for receiving the highest rating of Good in all crash tests and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention test by avoiding 12- and 25-mph collisions thanks to the automatic emergency braking feature that’s part of a package that also consists of adaptive cruise control with stop/go, pre-collision warning, and brake support. Other driver assist features are found in the Driver Assist package, which includes automatic high beams, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, lane keep assist, lane departure alert, rain-sensing windshield wipers, and auto-dimming side view mirrors with security approach lights. A self-parking system, rear parking sensors, and inflatable rear safety belts are also offered.</p>

<p>The Ford Fusion offers up to 44.3 inches of legroom for the front seats and 38.3 inches for the rear seats in all models. Without a battery pack taking up space, the non-hybrid Fusion offers 16.0 cubic feet of space in the trunk. The Fusion Hybrid has 12.0 cubic-feet of space, which shrinks to 8.2 cubic-feet on the Fusion Energi plug-in hybrid.</p>

<p>The Fusion’s standard infotainment system is displayed on a 4.2-inch center screen that can be upgraded to an 8.0-inch center touchscreen with SiriusXM satellite radio. The Platinum trims have a navigation system with SiriusXM Traffic and Travel Link. Dual 4.2-inch instrument panel displays are standard on all trims. The standard nine-speaker audio system can be upgraded to a 12-speaker Sony system with HD radio. The Fusion also offers two packages of driver assist safety features, a self-parking system, a 110-volt power outlet, and the Sync Connect app that offers many functions like locating your car and turning it on.</p>

<p>In a review comparing the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fusion-energi/2017/2017-ford-fusion-hybrid-energi-review/">2017 Ford Fusion Hybrid and Energi</a> models, we noted that the cargo space and acceleration is worse than many competitors. However, we like the available suite of driver assist safety features and the solid crash safety scores. We concluded by saying, “The Fusion hybrids aren’t the most efficient or cargo-friendly in their classes, but they drive well and boast attractive looks in a sedan body style. At the right price, they might just make sense.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fusion/2017/2017-ford-fusion-ecoboost-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 non-hybrid Ford Fusion SE (1.5-liter turbo-four engine), we said, “Although the 2017 Fusion doesn’t forget that it’s a family sedan, it brings plenty of substance in the form of user-friendly technology and agile handling. … Multimedia tech is the main highlight in the refreshed Fusion. Its interface is user-friendly and easily integrated with mobile devices.”</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/focus/2018/">2018 Ford Focus</a> is unchanged for the new model year.</p>

<p>The compact <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/focus/2018/">Ford Focus</a> sedan and hatchback slot above the subcompact Fiesta sedan and hatch and below the midsize Fusion and full-size Taurus sedans in the automaker’s passenger car lineup.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Focus S</strong>: Available as a sedan only, the base S trim comes equipped with power-operated side view mirrors, automatic headlights, keyless entry, hill start assist, power front windows, a 4.2-inch instrument cluster driver’s display, a 4.2-inch center display screen, a USB port, six-way manual adjustable driver’s seat, and 15-inch steel wheels.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Focus SE</strong>: Moving up to the SEL trim adds 16-inch aluminum wheels, power front and rear windows, cruise control, SiriusXM satellite radio, and illuminated entry.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Focus SEL</strong>: The SEL trim adds LED daytime running lights, black bezel headlights, fog lights, rear parking sensors, dual-zone climate control, interior ambient lighting, power moonroof, Sync 3 infotainment system with HD Radio, an 8.0-inch center touchscreen, a 10-speaker Sony audio system, two USB ports, and 17-inch machined aluminum wheels.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Focus Titanium</strong>: Building off the SEL’s features, the Titanium adds chrome headlight and fog light bezels, heated side view mirrors, one-touch up/down on all windows, remote engine start, quick entry with a push-start ignition, a heated steering wheel, leather-trimmed and heated front seats, eight-way power front seats, and 17-inch polished aluminum wheels.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Focus Electric: </strong>Offered in a single trim, the Focus Electric comes standard with HID headlights, LED taillights, LED charging indicator, rear parking sensors, remote engine start, dual 4.2-inch instrument panel driver’s display, Sync 3 with navigation, HD Radio, SiriusXM satellite radio, a nine-speaker Sony audio system, six-way manual driver’s seat with eco-conscious cloth, and 17-inch aluminum wheels.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Focus ST</strong>: The Focus ST adds sporty and performance features like a unique ST grille, unique rock panels, performance-inspired rear spoiler, a leather-wrapped flat-bottom steering wheel, unique ST leather-wrapped and alloy gear shift knob, mini analog cluster gauges, aluminum pedals, sport-tuned suspension, ST center exhaust tip, chin spoiler, 18-inch Rado Grey alloy wheels with summer tires, and the 2.0-liter turbo-four engine backed by a six-speed manual.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Focus RS</strong>: The range-topping and high-performance RS model enhances performance and looks with a unique RS grille, HID headlights, functional rear spoiler, unique RS leather-wrapped Sport steering wheel with blue stitching, interior carbon-fiber accents, unique RS leather-wrapped and alloy shifter, unique instrument panel finish, mini analog cluster gauges, heated steering wheel, SYNC 3, 10-speaker Sony audio system, six-way power adjustable and heated front seats, Recaro seats with Miko Dinamica microfiber inserts and RS logo,, driver-selectable sport suspension, a high-performance braking system with blue painted calipers, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> Performance all-wheel drive with torque vectoring, a Quaife mechanical limited slip differential, selectable drive modes, 19-inch painted forged-alloy wheels with RS center cap, and a 2.3-liter turbocharged I-4 engine paired to a six-speed manual.</p>

<p>For more creature comforts along with the Focus ST’s performance-focused credentials, consider ST3 package that adds Recaro Charcoal black full-leather heated front seats, a navigation system, eight-way power driver’s seat, interior ambient lights, heated steering wheel, and carbon-fiber interior accents. If you plan to track your Focus RS or just want maximum grip, opt for the available Michelin Pilot Cup Sport 2 summer tires.</p>

<p>Four engines are offered on the 2018 Ford Focus depending on trim level. The base engine is a 2.0-liter I-4 that develops 160 hp and 146 lb-ft of torque and delivers an EPA-rated 25/34 mpg city/highway when backed by the five-speed manual and 26/38 mpg when backed by the six-speed dual-clutch automatic (24/34 mpg with the SelectShift six-speed dual-clutch). The 1.0-liter turbo-three produces 123 hp and 125 lb-ft and comes mated to a six-speed manual (30/40 mpg) or a six-speed automatic (27/38 mpg) and is standard on the SE trim.</p>

<p>The sporty Focus ST hatch is powered by a 252-hp, 270 lb-ft 2.0-liter turbo-four mated to a six-speed manual (22/30 mpg), and the high-performance Focus RS hatch is powered by a 350-hp, 350 lb-ft 2.3-liter turbocharged I-4 mated to a six-speed manual and an all-wheel-drive system (19/26 mpg). In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2015 Ford Focus RS hit 60 mph in a quick 4.8 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 110 feet. The Focus ST hit 60 in 6.3 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 108 feet. The Ford Focus Titanium with the 2.0-liter engine most Focuses will have, hit 60 in 8.4 seconds and stopped from 60 in a very short 105 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 Ford Focus received the highest overall safety rating of five stars from the NHTSA for sedan and hatchback body styles. In IIHS testing, The 2018 Ford Focus received the second-highest rating of Acceptable in the driver-side small overlap front crash test and received the highest rating of Good in four other crash test evaluations. The front crash prevention test was not conducted because the Focus does not offer emergency automatic braking. Standard safety features include a rearview camera, dual-stage front airbags, and a tire pressure monitoring system. Available safety features include active park assist (self-parking system), rear parking sensors, lane keep assist, and blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert.</p>

<p>The Focus sedan offers 13.2 cubic feet of cargo space in the trunk and the hatch has 23.3 cubic feet behind the rear seats and up to 43.9 cubic feet behind the front seats. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/cruze/2018/">Chevrolet Cruze</a> sedan offers more with up to 14.8 cubic feet of cargo room in the trunk and the hatch has 22.7 cubic feet behind the rear seats and 47.2 with the seats folded down. Legroom up front for the Focus measures at 43.1 inches and the rear seats have 33.2 inches of legroom.</p>

<p>Standard technology for the Focus includes the Sync infotainment system displayed on a 4.2-inch center screen, a USB port, keyless entry, a 4.2-inch instrument cluster driver’s display, and a four-speaker radio system. The upgraded infotainment system is Sync 3 displayed on an 8.0-inch center touchscreen with HD Radio, SiriusXM satellite radio, two USB ports, and a 10-speaker Sony audio system. Navigation, interior ambient lighting, and dual 4.2-inch instrument cluster driver displays (Electric model) are optional.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/focus/2016/2016-ford-focus-rs-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2016 Ford Focus RS, we said the acceleration, lateral grip, stopping power, and figure-eight course time were all very impressive, on par with more expensive sports cars. One of our biggest complaints happen when the hatch is in track mode: “At that point the dampers turn into pogo sticks, and the hatchback starts bouncing up and down like an excited Boston terrier. It isn’t like a rough ride that you’d ignore in a sports car, but an unbelievable and constant vertical shake, as if riding a sine wave. It happens both mid-corner and on the straights, no matter how smooth the pavement.”</p>

<p>Take away the pogo stick effect and, “the Focus RS will reframe your perception of previous all-wheel-drive sport compacts, such as the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/wrx/">Subaru WRX</a> STI and <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mitsubishi/lancer/">Mitsubishi Lancer</a> Evolution. It’s much, much faster and more fun to drive.” However, when loaded, the Focus RS gets expensive, “the Focus RS gets close in price to the vastly superior-handling and faster <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/camaro/">Chevrolet Camaro</a> SS 1LE. The hatchback and four doors make the car more livable for a single-car family, but there are better-performing and better-riding cars available for $42,245.”</p>

<p>When we reviewed both 2016 Ford Focus SE sedan and hatchback with the 1.0-liter turbocharged I-3 EcoBoost engine <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/focus/2016/2016-ford-focus-se-ecoboost-i3-first-test-review/">during a First Test</a>, we were not impressed with the performance, but that was expected because these engines were developed for maximum fuel efficiency and not quick acceleration. We felt the manual-transmission model was more responsive around town and the engine was quiet and torquey (once the engine gets past the turbo lag). The Focus handles surprisingly well but the steering is vague on center with plenty of play. We concluded by saying: “The 2016 Ford Focus SE Sedan 1.0-Liter EcoBoost is a compelling choice for those looking to maximize fuel economy in their compact sedan or hatchback. We would choose the manual transmission to save on upfront costs and at the pump. The manual-equipped car is significantly quicker and seals the deal.”</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The mid-engine 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/gt/2018/">Ford GT</a> supercar returns as the automaker’s flagship sports coupe. Other sporty Fords include the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/mustang/2018/">Ford Mustang</a> coupe and convertible, Taurus SHO sedan, Fusion Sport sedan, Focus ST and RS hatchbacks, Fiesta ST hatchback, and F-150 Raptor pickup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>First shown at the 2015 Detroit auto show, we don’t expect any major changes to the limited production supercar, but we’ll update this space as soon as we have more info. The automaker has shown some special-edition versions since it first debuted, including the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/ford-gt-competition-series-sheds-weight-honors-rolex-24-win/">Competition Series</a>. The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/gt/2016/ford-gt-in-detroit-is-very-real-with-600-plus-hp/">Ford GT</a> is powered by a mid-mounted twin-turbo 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6 mated to a seven-speed dual-clutch transmission. The domestic mid-engine supercar is rated 647 hp and 550 lb-ft of torque and has a top speed of 216 mph. The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2017-ford-gt-epa-rated-1118-mpg-cityhighway/">Ford GT is EPA-rated</a> 11/18/14 mpg city/highway/combined.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> GT is based around a carbon-fiber tub with aluminum front and rear sub-frames covered by carbon fiber body panels. <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/everything-we-know-about-the-new-ford-gt/">Other performance bits</a> include a inboard-mounted torsion beam and pushrod suspension with adjustable ride height mated to Multimatic’s Dynamic Suspension Spool Valve (DSSV) shock absorbers, active aerodynamics, and carbon-ceramic brakes. <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2017-ford-gt-carbon-fiber-wheels-detailed/">Carbon fiber wheels</a> are optional. Inside, the Ford GT features a reconfigurable <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2017-ford-gt-has-a-fancy-digital-gauge-cluster/">digital gauge cluster</a> with five driving modes (Normal, Wet, Sport, Race, and V-Max).</p>

<p>While Ford originally planned to make 500 cars over two model years (250 cars each year), the automaker announced it will <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/ford-gt-production-expanded-to-four-years/">expand its production to four years</a> for a total of 1,000 examples of the Ford GT. We’ve yet to drive the new <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/gt/2017/2017-ford-gt-first-ride/">American supercar, but you can read our First Ride story here</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-250/2018/">2018 Ford F-250</a> gets an updated diesel engine with more torque.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-250/2018/">Ford F-250</a> is a heavy duty truck that slots above the smaller F-150 and below the larger F-350. The truck is available in five trim levels, three cab styles, and two bed lengths. Rear-wheel drive is standard and four-wheel drive is optional</p>

<p>The 2018 F-250 comes standard with a 6.2-liter V-8 with 385 hp and 430 lb-ft of torque. A 6.7-liter turbodiesel V-8 with 450 hp and 935 lb-ft is also offered. Both engines come exclusively with a six-speed automatic transmission. Heavy duty trucks are not rated for fuel economy by the EPA.</p>

<p><strong>F-250 XL: </strong>The base XL trim comes standard with 17-inch steel wheels, vinyl seats, manual air conditioning, a four-speaker audio system, a rear-view camera, a 2.3-inch screen, and bench front and rear seating configuration.</p>

<p><strong>F-250 XLT: </strong>Moving up to the XLT grade adds 18-inch painted aluminum wheels, cloth upholstery, the basic version of <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a>’s Sync infotainment system, keyless entry, and cruise control.</p>

<p><strong>F-250 Lariat: </strong>Lariat models come standard with leather upholstery, dual-zone climate control, 10-way power adjustable driver’s seat, a 10-speaker Sony audio system, Ford’s Sync 3 infotainment system with an 8.0-inch touchscreen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, rear parking sensors, and remote start.</p>

<p><strong>F-250 King Ranch: </strong>One of two luxury-oriented trims, the King Ranch adds unique Mesa Brown leather upholstery, heated and ventilated front seats, navigation, a heated steering wheel, and driver’s seat memory.</p>

<p><strong>F-250 Platinum: </strong>The range-topping Platinum grade comes with a panoramic sunroof, 20-inch wheels, front passenger side memory, heated rear seats, multicontour front seats with massage function, Platinum-specific leather upholstery in black or Dark Masala, adaptive steering, and full LED headlights.</p>

<p>Optional extras include a 360-degree camera system, front parking sensors, power deployable running boards, LED bed lighting, and the FX4 Off-road package, which includes unique suspension tuning and transfer case, and skid plates for the fuel tank.</p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 F-250 a five-star rating for the side impact test (out of a possible five stars). On the NHTSA’s rollover test, rear-drive models received four-stars and four-wheel drive models got three stars.</p>

<p>Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert is available on all models. Lane keeping assist, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, and adaptive cruise control are available only on higher-grade models.</p>

<p>Depending on the cab style, drivetrain configuration, and bed length, the 2018 F-250 can haul up to 15,000 pounds with a conventional trailer or 18,500 pounds with a fifth wheel or goose neck. Maximum payload capacity for the 2018 F-250 is 4,000 pounds.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-250/2017/2017-ford-f-series-super-duty-first-drive-tow-masters/">2017 First Drive</a>, we were impressed with the material quality inside the F-250’s cabin and the optional diesel engine, which offers plenty of power on tap to move the massive truck. Ride quality is comfortable when the truck is carrying payload but it’s stiff when it’s empty. We were also impressed with the F-250’s driver assistance features, which helps make towing easier by giving the driver plenty of guidance when backing into a trailer. It’s also got a blind-spot warning system than includes the trailer when driving.</p>

<p>The 2017 F-250 was <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/ford-super-duty-2017-motor-trend-truck-of-the-year/"><em>Motor Trend’s </em>2017 Truck of the Year</a> as part of the Super Duty family.</p>

<p>Although its body is now mainly constructed out of aluminum, the rest of the F-250’s platform continues to use steel.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The best-selling <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-150/2018/2018-ford-f-150-first-look-review/"></a><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-150/2018/">Ford F-150</a> gets a major update for its 40<sup>th</sup> birthday. The big news is a new 3.0-liter Power Stroke turbodiesel V-6 as well as revised gasoline engines. Power ratings for the turbodiesel haven’t been revealed. The 10-speed automatic now has a wider availability. Other changes include a new front end and rear end including exterior lighting, grille, and tailgate. Inside, more interior colors are available, and SYNC 3 offers more infotainment and connectivity features.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The full-size <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> F-Series is the number one selling vehicle in the U.S. The light-duty F-150 pickup lots below the F-Series Super Duty pickups in the automaker’s lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>Not only is the Ford F-Series the number one selling truck for four decades, it’s also the best-selling vehicle in the U.S. for 35 years. For 2018, the refreshed F-150 gets a new 3.0-liter Power Stroke turbodiesel V-6 that has yet to be rated for power or fuel economy. The new engine, which will likely feature twin turbos, is backed by a 10-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p>Ford also updated most of the F-150’s gasoline engines. The previous model’s base 3.5-liter V-6 has shrunk to 3.3 liter, but gains a new twin-injection system (port and direct). Power ratings are unchanged at 282 hp and 253 lb-ft of torque. The 3.3-liter is backed by a six-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p>The new second-generation 2.7-liter EcoBoost V-6 also gains the twin-injection system, while the 5.0-liter Coyote V-8 gains new plasma-transferred wire arc spray-bore cylinder lining for reduced weight over the previous engine’s iron cylinder liners. Ford says the 2.7-liter EcoBoost and 5.0-liter V-8 make more power than before. The second-generation twin-injection 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6, with 375 hp and 470 lb-ft, introduced in 2017 carries over. A 10-speed automatic backs the 2.7-liter EcoBoost, 5.0-liter, and 3.5-liter EcoBoost engines. All 2018 F-150 drivetrains feature standard automatic start/stop.</p>

<p>We expect the new for <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-150/2017/2017-ford-f-150-raptor-first-test-velocity-raptor/">2017 Ford F-150 Raptor</a> and its 450-hp, 510 lb-ft 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6 and 10-speed auto combo to carry over unchanged.</p>

<p>The current-generation <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-150/2015/2015-ford-f-150-first-look/">Ford F-150 arrived in 2015</a> amidst lots of controversy due to its (mostly) aluminum cab and box. Ford claims the aluminum construction reduced weight by up to 700 pounds depending on configuration and options.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The pre-refresh <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-150/2017/">2017 Ford F-150</a> pickup has a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars) and is considered a 2016 Top Safety Pick by the IIHS. That F-150, last year’s model, received a front crash prevention designation of basic for its optional Adaptive Cruise Control and Collision Warning with Brake Support. The 2018 F-150 features precollision assist with pedestrian detection, which first warns the driver and second brakes the vehicle to lessen impact, while the adaptive cruise control now features stop-and-go traffic-jam cruising.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think </strong></p>

<p>“From their hauling and towing abilities to trailer-attaching in-truck electronic guidance to the quality of materials lining the cab’s innards to the sticker prices slapped on the driver-side window, pickups have never been more impressive,” we said in our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-150/2017/2017-ford-f-150-platinum-4x4-ecoboost-first-test/">2017 Ford F-150 Platinum 4×4 EcoBoost First Test</a>. “Which means the eager, post-peak secondhand pickup shoppers have a lot of F-150 to look forward to.”</p>

<p>We look forward to driving the refreshed 2018 Ford F-150 soon.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 G80 receives a new Sport trim with a new 3.3-liter turbocharged V-6. Also, the G80 enters the new model year with an updated 8-speed automatic transmission, refreshed headlights, a tweaked lower front grille, updated front and rear fascias, a new standard 18-inch wheel design, new instrument cluster, shift knob, analog clock, and premium speaker design. Additionally, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/genesis/">Genesis</a> adds newly available genuine matte wood finishes, an additional USB charging port, added Pedestrian Detection and Driver Attention Alert as standard safety features, and improved interior noise levels with added NVH (noise, vibration, and harshness) cancellation enhancements.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The G80 is currently the entry-level model of the newly created Genesis premium brand, slotting before the larger and more expensive flagship G90 model. Before it became its own premium brand, the Genesis sedan was <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/">Hyundai</a>’s flagship model. Expect a smaller and less expensive Genesis sedan possibly called the G70 in a couple years.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/genesis/g80/2018/">2018 Genesis G80</a> sedan comes standard with a 3.8-liter V-6 that produces 311 hp and 293 lb-ft of torque. The top-of-the-line engine is a 420-hp, 383-lb-ft of torque 5.0-liter V-8, and the new G80 Sport model is powered by a 3.3-liter twin-turbo V-6 that churns out 365 hp and 376 lb-ft of torque. The G80 sports an eight-speed automatic transmission that routes power to an all-wheel drive system or to the rear wheels.</p>

<p>The Genesis Sport model comes standard with a 9.2-inch touchscreen navigation system, multi-view camera, full LED headlights with Dynamic Bending Light, wireless device charging, and a Lexicon Premium Sounds System with 17 speakers, QuantumLogic Surround Sound and Clari-Fi music restoration technology. Continuous Damping Control suspension, dark chrome trim with copper-colored accents, leather sport seats with copper contrast stitching, carbon fiber interior trim with aluminum sport pedals, and 19-inch dark alloy wheels are some available options. The Sport model comes in Casablanca White, Caspian Black, and Himalayan Gray and in two exclusive colors: Polar Ice and Sevilla Red. <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/can-now-command-genesis-g80-g90-via-amazons-alexa/">Genesis owners can now use Amazon Alexa</a> to send remote commands such as remote start with climate control and the remote door lock/unlock using Connected Services or an Alexa-enabled device.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/genesis/g80/2018/">Genesis G80</a> comes standard with a host of advanced safety features including Automatic Emergency Braking with Pedestrian Detection, Driver Attention Alert, Blind Spot Detection, Rear Cross-traffic Alert, Lane Keep Assist, and Lane Departure Warning. Adaptive cruise control with Stop/Start driving, High Beam Assist, a rearview camera, a haptic steering wheel, and Pre-Active Seatbelts are additional standard features. LED headlights with Dynamic Bending Light and a multi-view camera are some available safety features.</p>

<p>All Genesis models come available with Genesis Connected Services that consists of Destination Search powered by Google, Car Finder, Enhanced Roadside Assistance, and Stolen Vehicle Recovery. Additional services include SOS Emergency and Automatic Collision Notification.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 G80 offers 3 years/36,000 mile complimentary normally scheduled maintenance, valet service, Genesis Connected Services, SiriusXM Travel Link (traffic data), and Map Care (annual navigation map updates).</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong><strong>:</strong></p>

<p>The 3.3T Premium model now comes standard with steering-responsive full LED headlights and the 5.0 Ultimate model now comes standard with a rear seat entertainment system that includes dual 10.3-inch monitors. All models receive a CD/DVD player located in the glove box.</p>

<p>The G90 is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/genesis/">Genesis</a>’ flagship sedan, positioned above the smaller and less expensive G70 and G80 premium sedans.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/genesis/g90/2018/">2018 Genesis G90</a> 3.3T Premium</strong>: The G90 comes standard with a long list of premium features including 19-inch alloy wheels, steering-responsive full LED headlights, Nappa leather seating, 22-way power adjustable driver’s seat (16-way power for passenger), a 12.3-inch center HD display with a navigation system and SiriusXM satellite radio, a 7.0-inch instrument panel driver’s display, a 17-speaker Lexicon surround sound audio system, front and rear USB ports, heated and ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, tri-zone automatic climate control, a multi-view camera system, high-beam assist, a full-color head-up display, a wireless charging pad, microfiber suede headliner, leather-wrapped dashboard, genuine wood interior trim, rear power sunshades, interior ambient lighting, Genesis Connected Services, and a suite of driver assist safety features.</p>

<p><strong>2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/genesis/g90/2018/">Genesis G90</a> 5.0 Ultimate</strong>: The 5.0 Ultimate adds a more powerful 5.0-liter V-8 and rear seat upgrades including a 14-way power right rear seat (12-way power for the left rear seat), ventilated rear seats, rear seat illuminated vanity mirrors, and a rear seat entertainment system with dual 10.3-inch displays.</p>

<p>The 2018 Genesis G90’s standard engine is a 3.3-liter twin-turbo V-6 that produces 365 hp and 376 lb-ft of torque and delivers an EPA-rated 17/24 mpg city/highway with rear-wheel drive and exactly the same with all-wheel drive equipped. The upgraded 5.0-liter V-8 pumps out 420 hp and 383 lb-ft of torque and is rated at 16/24 mpg with rear-wheel drive and 15/23 mpg with all-wheel drive. Both engines are backed by an eight-speed automatic. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 G90 5.0 (RWD) hit 60 mph in a quick 5.0 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a respectable 121 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 Genesis G90 is considered a 2018 Top Safety Pick+ by the IIHS for receiving the highest rating of Good in all crash tests and in the headlights evaluation, and the highest rating of Superior in the front crash prevention test by avoiding 12- and 25-mph frontal collisions thanks to the standard automatic emergency braking with pedestrian detection system. The G90 comes standard with many additional driver assist safety features including adaptive cruise control with stop/go, a pre-collision warning system, lane keep assist, blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert and lane change assist, driver attention alert, a multi-view camera system, front and rear parking sensors, and pre-active seatbelts that automatically tighten when needed.</p>

<p>The G90’s trunk holds up to 15.7 cubic feet of cargo and front seat passengers have 46.3 inches of legroom while rear passengers get 37.8 inches.</p>

<p>The 2018 G90 comes standard with a 12.3-inch center HD display with a navigation system and a rotary controller, SiriusXM satellite radio, HD radio, Bluetooth, a 7.0-inch instrument panel driver’s display, a head-up display, a wireless charging pad, two USB ports, and a 17-speaker Lexicon surround sound audio system. The 5.0 Ultimate adds the rear seat entertainment system with dual 10.3-inch HD monitors. A surround-view camera system and a suite of driver assist safety features are also standard. The Genesis Connected Services app features roadside assistance, automatic collision notification, vehicle diagnostics, and maintenance reminders. The app can also remote start/stop your engine, lock/unlock the doors, and honk the horn and flash the lights.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/genesis/g90/2017/2017-genesis-g90-33t-awd-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 Genesis G90 3.3T AWD, we were impressed with the superior ride comfort, great value, and very quiet interior. The large sedan feels floaty but can still handle a corner well. The fuel economy did not impress us and we didn’t have much to say about the sedate exterior and interior styling.</p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/genesis-g90-2017-car-of-the-year-finalist/">2017 Motor Trend Car of the Year testing</a>, the G90 was a finalist due to its very impressive ride comfort, great value, strong base twin-turbo V-6, good high-speed stability, and high-quality interior. However, the premium sedan was not our Car of the Year, and “it was more than the ho-hum styling. If Genesis wanted to make an entrance, it should have made a technological statement, as well. Every feature about the car screams table stakes. There is nothing exceptional here.’”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/genesis/g90/2018/bmw-740e-vs-lexus-ls-500-vs-genesis-g90-33t-vs-lincoln-continental-30/">four-way comparison</a> of big and luxurious sedans, The 2018 Genesis G90 3.3T (with AWD) was the victor, topping the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/continental/2017/">2017 Lincoln Continental</a> 3.0, 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/">BMW</a> 740e xDrive iPerformance, and the redesigned <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/ls/2018/">2018 Lexus LS</a> 500. The G90 has remarkable value thanks to its low starting price and a long list of standard features. At the track, we were impressed with the Genesis’ strong acceleration, braking, and good handling dynamics. On the road the G90 is “…as smooth as a Marvin Gaye ballad. Its engine and transmission are particularly noteworthy for how effortless they make the process of driving. Dip into the throttle, and the G90 accelerates with pure elegance, with no noise from the V-6 under the hood and no physical sensation of gearshifts, save for the tach needle’s swing.”</p>

<p>Inside, the G90 is a “…peaceful sensory deprivation chamber. You know, like Lexuses used to be. The leather seats are ‘buttery smooth’ and enormously comfortable both up front and in the cavernous rear passenger area. With much to prove, Genesis appears to have thought out every function of the G90’s interior—with high-quality materials on every surface and easy-to-find controls for everything from the 360-degree camera and radar cruise control to the infotainment system.” However, some judges noted that the interior was “sterile” compared to some of its rivals.</p>

<p>We concluded by saying, “It’s easy to dismiss upstart luxury automakers such as Genesis as luxury car imitators. But the G90 is no knock-off Rolex—it’s a proper luxury flagship in its own right. Although we admittedly wish the G90 made more of a visual statement, the cabin is comfortable, luxurious, and filled with the latest creature comforts and semi-autonomous technologies. The drive is smooth yet engaging. And its value story is undeniable.”</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong> The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/sierra-2500hd/2018/">2018 GMC Sierra 2500HD</a> gets a rearview camera and a 7.0-inch touchscreen as standard. Three new exterior colors, Deep Mahogany Metallic, Red Quartz Tintcoat, and White Frost Tricoat, are now available. A tire-fill alert has been added to the tire pressure monitoring system, and the Denali trim gets a new grille.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong> The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/sierra-2500hd/2018/">GMC Sierra 2500HD</a> is one of two heavy-duty trucks sold by <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/">GMC</a>, slotting below the larger Sierra 3500HD and above the smaller Sierra 1500. Rear-wheel drive is standard and four-wheel drive is optional. Two box styles and three cab styles are available.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong> Two engines are available in the 2018 GMC Sierra 2500HD, a 6.0-liter V-8 producing 360 hp and 380 lb-ft of torque and a 6.6-liter turbodiesel V-8 rated at 445 hp and 910 lb-ft. Both engines are paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. When properly equipped, the Sierra 2500HD can tow up to 18,100 pounds and can haul up 3,534 pounds of payload.
