Standard features on a base Sierra 2500HD include 17-inch alloy wheels, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, a rearview camera, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, Bluetooth connectivity, 60/40 split-folding rear seats on the double- and crew-cab models, and a six-speaker audio system. Higher trim levels can be had with navigation, a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, a Bose premium audio system, leather upholstery, 18-inch chrome wheels, heated and ventilated front seats, keyless entry/start, remote start, and a wireless charging pad.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong> The NHTSA gave the 2018 GMC Sierra 2500HD a four-star overall rating (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 Sierra 2500HD. Higher trim levels can be had with safety features such as the lane departure warning and forward collision warning, both of which are bundled together with parking sensors and the Safety Alert Seat in the Driver Alert package.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong> In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2015-gmc-sierra-denali-hd-first-test/">2015 First Test,</a> we noted that, like all heavy duty trucks, the Sierra 2500HD has a jittery ride; however, it smooths out when there’s payload in the bed. Having payload in the bed also didn’t hurt the truck’s acceleration, allowing it to haul with ease. The transmission, however, is programmed to go to the highest gear as possible, which can make the Sierra 2500HD feel sluggish. Interior quality on the Denali trim is higher than in others, giving it a more upscale feel.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong> The more new diesel engine, which was introduced last year, offers 165 lb-ft of torque more than the older unit it replaces.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The all-new <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/terrain/2018/">2018 GMC Terrain</a> rides on a new platform and features a new range of turbocharged engines and a full suite of active safety features.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting below the three-row Acadia, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/terrain/2018/">GMC Terrain</a> is the brand’s front- and all-wheel-drive entry-level crossover. Unlike the new Acadia, the Terrain is no longer available with a six-cylinder engine option</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Terrain is offered with three new turbocharged four-cylinder engines including a base 1.5-liter unit with 170 hp and 203 lb-ft of torque, a larger 2.0-liter with 252 hp and 260 lb-ft, and a 1.6-liter diesel rated at 137 hp and 240 lb-ft. A new nine-speed automatic developed in house by General Motors is standard on the 1.5-liter and 2.0-liter, while the diesel makes do with a six-speed unit. Cargo capacity stands at 29.6 cubic feet behind the second row and 63.3 cubic feet behind the front seats. The 2018 Terrain is rated to tow up to 3,500 pounds when properly equipped and powered by the 252-hp 2.0-liter gas turbo-four.</p>

<p>Available features include <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/">GMC</a>’s IntelliLink multimedia interface with a 7.0- or 8.0-inch touchscreen and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, 4G LTE connectivity, navigation, a Bose premium audio system, a 360-degree view camera system, a heated steering wheel, the Rear Seat Reminder system that reminds you to check the back seats before leaving the car, LED headlights, alloy wheels up to 19 inches in diameter, and Bluetooth connectivity. As with every GMC model, there’s a range-topping Denali trim level that’s more upscale and is distinguished by its chrome exterior accents and a unique grille.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The Terrain makes available a full suite of active safety features that includes forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, lane keeping assist, lane departure warning, lane change alert, blind spot warning, and rear cross-traffic alert.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>We’ve yet to drive the 2018 Terrain, but the lighter crossover’s turbocharged engines will likely provide more accessible power compared to the last-gen model’s naturally aspirated four- and six-cylinder mills. The 2018 Terrain’s infotainment system should also be a major improvement as it now features smartphone integration even on the base unit with the smaller 7.0-inch touchscreen.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 GMC Terrain is closely related to the recently redesigned <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/equinox/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Equinox</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/acadia/2018/">2018 GMC Acadia</a> now gets a heated steering wheel on the Denali trim and a new exterior color, Blue Steel Metallic. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/">GMC</a> has also made the six- and seven-seat configurations available on the All-Terrain trim, in addition to the standard five-seat layout.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting above the smaller Terrain and below the larger, full-size Yukon, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/acadia/2018/">GMC Acadia</a> is a midsize crossover that’s available in front- or all-wheel-drive configurations. In addition to the standard five-seat layout, the Acadia also has a six- and seven-seat configuration.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two engines are available on the 2018 GMC Acadia including a 2.5-liter I-4 with 193 hp and 188 lb-ft of torque or an optional 3.6-liter V-6 with 310 hp and 271 lb-ft. Both are paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 21/26 mpg city/highway for front-drive or 21/25 mpg with all-wheel drive for four-cylinder models. Jumping to the V-6 doesn’t come at a huge cost to fuel economy since front-drive models are rated at 18/25 mpg while all-wheel-drive cars are rated at 17/25 mpg. With the base four-cylinder, the 2018 Acadia can tow up to 1,000 pounds but with the optional V-6, it increases to 4,000 pounds. Cargo capacity is 12.8 cubic feet with the third row in place, 41.7 cubic feet behind the second row, and 79 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>The base SL trim comes standard with 17-inch alloy wheels, keyless entry/start, tri-zone climate control, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a rearview camera, the rear seat reminder system, 4G LTE connectivity, a six-speaker audio system, Bluetooth connectivity, and split-folding second- and third-row seats. Options on higher trim levels include a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, a programmable power liftgate, heated and ventilated front seats, second-row captain’s chairs, HID headlights, alloy wheels up to 20 inches in diameter, remote start, and a Bose premium audio system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the front-drive 2018 Acadia a four-star safety rating and the all-wheel drive variant a five-star rating (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 Acadia received a Good score on all crash test but only got a Marginal rating for the new headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Acadia avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the impact in a 25-mph test by 24 mph, enabling it to get a Superior rating (Superior is the highest score in the front crash prevention test). As a result, the IIHS gave the 2018 Acadia the Top Safety Pick rating.</p>

<p>Optional on higher trims is the Driver Alert II package, which adds pedestrian detection, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, Intellibeam headlights, front and rear parking sensors, following distance indicator, the safety alert seat, lane keeping assist, rear cross-traffic alert, blind spot warning, and lane change assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>Despite the shorter wheelbase compared to the outgoing model, the Acadia features a comfortable ride and confident handling for a crossover, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/acadia/2017/2017-gmc-acadia-terrain-first-test-smaller-faster/">2017 First Test</a>. With the optional 310-hp 3.6-liter V-6, the GMC Acadia offers strong acceleration. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-9/2016/2017-gmc-acadia-2016-mazda-cx-9-2017-toyota-highlander-comparison/">2016 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-9/2018/">Mazda CX-9</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/highlander/2018/">Toyota Highlander</a>, the Acadia placed third due to an interior with some cheap-feeling interior materials, sluggish throttle response, and a transmission that’s slow to response.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The GMC Acadia uses a shortened version of the same platform in the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/traverse/2018/">2018 Chevrolet Traverse</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/buick/enclave/2018/">Buick Enclave</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong> The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/sierra-3500hd/2018/">2018 GMC Sierra 3500HD</a> gets a rearview camera and a 7.0-inch touchscreen as standard on all trim levels. Three new colors, Deep Mahogany Metallic, Red Quartz Tintcoat, and White Frost Tricoat, have been added to the Sierra 3500HD’s exterior color palette. The tire pressure monitor system now also includes a tire pressure alert system.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong> The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/sierra-3500hd/2018/">GMC Sierra 3500HD</a> is the largest truck sold by <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/">GMC</a>, slotting above the smaller Sierra 2500HD. It is available in rear- or four-wheel-drive configurations and in either single or dual rear-wheel setups. Two bed lengths and three cab styles are available.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong> Two engines are offered on the 2018 GMC Sierra 3500HD, a 6.0-liter V-8 rated at 360 hp and 380 lb-ft of torque and a 6.6-liter turbodiesel V-8 with 445 hp and 910 lb-ft. Both engines are paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. Maximum payload on the 2018 Sierra 3500HD is 7,153 pounds, and when properly equipped, it can tow up to 23,300 pounds. Standard features include a GMC’s IntelliLink infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, a rearview camera, an automatic locking differential, 18-inch steel wheels, Bluetooth connectivity, and 60/40 split-folding rear bench seats on double- and crew-cab models. Higher trim levels can be had with heated and ventilated front seats, a Bose premium audio system, navigation, a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, leather upholstery, a remote locking tailgate, keyless entry/start, remote start, dual-zone climate control, wireless phone charging, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, 4G LTE connectivity, and a rear-seat entertainment system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong> The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 GMC Sierra 3500HD. On higher trim levels, you can also opt for forward collision warning and lane departure warning, both of which are bundled together with parking sensors and the Driver Alert Seat as part of the Driver Alert package.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong> We’ve yet to test a 2018 Sierra 3500HD, but in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2015-gmc-sierra-denali-hd-first-test/">2015 First Test</a> of a Sierra 2500HD we said that like other trucks of the same size, the ride is jittery when the bed is empty; however, add some payload, and it smooths out without affecting its ability to accelerate. In the Denali trim, the truck’s interior is well-appointed and packed with plenty of tech features including 4G LTE connectivity. The transmission is tuned for fuel economy and always wants to upshift to the highest gear, making the truck feel sluggish at times.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong> The GMC Sierra 3500HD distinguishes itself from its sister truck, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-3500hd/2018/">Chevrolet Silverado 3500HD</a>, with a more luxurious Denali trim that features more standard equipment plus design cues such as a unique large chrome grille.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/yukon/2018/">2018 GMC Yukon</a> gets a 10-speed automatic transmission on Denali models. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/">GMC</a> also gave the 2018 Yukon and Yukon XL minor exterior design tweaks to freshen up the SUV’s looks.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting above the midsize Acadia, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/yukon/2018/">GMC Yukon</a> is a full-size SUV that can seat up to eight passengers and is available with rear-wheel drive is standard and all-wheel drive is optional. In addition to the standard model, <strong>a long-wheelbase variant called the Yukon XL is also offered</strong>.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two engines are available in the 2018 Yukon including a 5.3-liter V-8 with 355 hp and 383 lb-ft of torque in the SLE and SLT trims, and a 6.2-liter V-8 with 420 hp and 460 lb-ft in the Denali grade. The 5.3-liter comes paired with a six-speed automatic transmission while the 6.2-liter is coupled to a 10-speed automatic. Towing capacity  for the standard Yukon stands at 8,500 pounds for rear-drive models and 8,200 pounds on four-wheel-drive variants. The long-wheelbase Yukon XL can tow 8,300 pounds in rear-drive guise and 8,000 pounds with four-wheel drive.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the standard-wheelbase Yukon are 16/23 mpg city/highway for the rear-drive Yukon and 16/22 mpg with four-wheel drive. The more powerful Yukon Denali is rated at 14/23 mpg with rear-wheel drive or 14/22 mpg with four-wheel drive. The Yukon XL gets the same 16/23 mpg for rear-drive models as the standard Yukon, but opting for four-wheel drive drops those numbers  to 15/22 mpg. In the Yukon XL Denali, rear-drive models retain the same 14/23 mpg from the Yukon Denali but four-wheel drive variants are less efficient at 14/21 mpg.</p>

<p>Cargo space in the standard wheelbase Yukon is 15.3 cubic feet behind the third row, 51.7 cubic feet behind the second row and 94.7 cubic feet behind the front seats. The long-wheelbase Yukon XL features more cargo capacity at 39.3 cubic feet behind the third row, 76.7 cubic feet behind the second row, and 121.1 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base Yukon SLE trim includes 18-inch alloy wheels, a rearview camera, parking sensors, a Bose premium audio system, GMC’s IntelliLink infotainment system with an 8.0-inch touchscreen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, Bluetooth connectivity, tri-zone climate control, and the rear-seat reminder system. Options include power-operated split-folding second- and third-row seats, leather upholstery, heated and ventilated front seats, heated second-row seats, keyless entry/start, navigation, active noise cancellation, Magnetic Ride Control, 4G LTE connectivity, and a programmable power liftgate.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Yukon a four-star overall score (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS hasn’t crash tested the 2018 Yukon but the 2017 model was given the Basic rating in front crash prevention for the availability of forward collision warning (Superior is the highest possible rating). Other available active safety features include automatic emergency braking, lane keeping assist, lane departure warning, blind spot warning, adaptive cruise control, and rear cross-traffic alert.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/suburban/2015/2015-chevrolet-suburban-2015-gmc-yukon-first-drive/">2015 First Drive</a>, we noted that despite its size, the GMC Yukon, even in XL guise, is easy to drive thanks to its smooth steering, making it easy to maneuver such a large. Material quality in the Yukon, especially the Denali trim, is excellent and the infotainment system is easy to use. However, we noted on a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/suburban/2015/2015-chevrolet-suburban-gmc-yukon-xl-first-test/">2015 First Test</a> that the Yukon’s ride with the available 22-inch alloy wheels is rough even with Magnetic Ride Control, making it feel more truck-like. Additionally, prices of the Yukon and its sister vehicles, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/tahoe/2018/">Chevrolet Tahoe</a> and Suburban can easily skyrocket, putting them in the same bracket as luxury crossovers and SUVs.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 GMC Yukon Denali uses the same 6.2-liter V-8 with The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a> Tahoe RST and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/escalade/2018/">Cadillac Escalade</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/sierra-1500/2018/">2018 GMC Sierra 1500</a> now comes standard with a rearview camera, a six-speaker audio system, and a 7.0-inch touchscreen. Two new exterior colors, Deep Mahogany Metallic and Red Quartz Tintcoat, have been added. A tire fill alert has been added to the tire pressure monitoring system.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting above the midsize Canyon and the heavy duty Sierra 2500HD, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/sierra-1500/2018/">GMC Sierra 1500</a> is a full-size pickup that’s available in rear- or four-wheel drive configurations. There are three cab styles to choose from and two bed lengths.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>There are four powertrain options on the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/">GMC</a> Sierra 1500 including a mild hybrid. A 4.3-liter V-6 with 285 hp and 305 lb-ft of torque paired to a six-speed automatic transmission is the base engine. Upgrade engines include a 5.3-liter V-8 with 355 hp and 383 lb-ft and a 6.2-liter V-8 rated at 420 hp and 460 lb-ft. The 5.3-liter can be paired to either a six- or eight-speed automatic, and the 6.2-liter comes exclusively with the eight-speed. A mild hybrid that combines the 5.3-liter V-8 with a small electric motor is also available and comes paired only with the eight-speed automatic; however, its power output is the same as the nonhybrid 5.3-liter V-8. The 2018 Sierra 1500 can carry up to 2,250 pounds of payload and, when properly equipped, can top up to 12,500 pounds.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings are 18/24 mpg city/highway for a rear-drive V-6-powered Sierra 1500 and 17/22 mpg with four-wheel drive. The 5.3-liter V-8 with the eight-speed automatic is rated at 16/23 mpg with rear-wheel drive or 15/20 mpg with four-wheel drive. Opting for the six-speed automatic gets you the same 16/23 mpg for rear-drive models and an improvement to 16/22 mpg for four-wheel-drive models. The 6.2-liter V-8 is the least efficient at 15/21 mpg for rear-drive models and 15/20 with four-wheel drive. Opting for the eAssist model gets you similar gas mileage in rear-drive Sierra 1500s at 18/24 mpg; however, four-wheel drive variants are still less efficient than the V-6 at 16/21 mpg.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base 2018 Sierra 1500 include a six-speaker audio system, a rearview camera, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, Bluetooth connectivity, 17-inch alloy wheels, and 60/40 split-folding bench seats on the double cab and crew cab variants. Higher trim levels come with features such as a large 8.0-inch touchscreen, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, a Bose premium audio system, heated and ventilated front seats, LED headlights, 4G LTE connectivity, Magnetic Ride Control, and alloy wheels up to 20 inches in diameter.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 GMC Sierra 1500 received a five-star safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the truck received an Average score on the headlights test and a Good score on all crash tests except the small overlap front test where the crew cab variant only received a Marginal score while the double cab model got an Average rating (Good is the highest possible score). The IIHS also gave the 2018 Sierra 1500 a Basic rating for front crash prevention for its available forward collision warning system (Superior is the highest rating). Standard on the Denali trim and optional on the SLT trim, the Enhanced Driver Alert package bundles together the Driver Alert Seat, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, lane keeping assist, and Intellibeam headlights.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/sierra-1500/2016/2016-gmc-sierra-denali-1500-4wd-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we said that with the available 420-hp 6.2-liter V-8, the Sierra 1500 is one of the quickest pickups we’ve tested, offering strong acceleration even when hauling a trailer. However, despite the Denali trim’s well-built interior, there’s still some missing features that can be found in less expensive vehicles, making its value proposition questionable. Ride comfort, on the other hand, is respectable with the available Magnetic Ride Control suspension, but it’s easily upset by road imperfections.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The optional 6.2-liter V-8 is shared with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/silverado-1500/2018/">Chevrolet Silverado 1500</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/tahoe/2018/">Chevrolet Tahoe</a> RST, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/escalade/2018/">Cadillac Escalade</a>, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/yukon/2018/">GMC Yukon</a> Denali.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/canyon/2018/">2018 GMC Canyon</a> gets a leather upholstery option on the All-Terrain trim.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/canyon/2018/">GMC Canyon</a> is a midsize truck that’s available in two bed lengths and two cab styles. It slots below the larger, full-size Silverado 1500 and is available in rear- or four-wheel drive configurations.</p>

<p><strong>Canyon SL</strong>: Standard features included on the base trim include a rearview camera, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, Bluetooth connectivity, a USB port, a six-speaker audio system, vinyl upholstery, and a 3.5-inch multi-information display.</p>

<p><strong>Canyon:</strong> The Canyon builds on the base SL trim with 16-inch alloy wheels, a power-operated driver’s seat and projector headlights with LED accents.</p>

<p><strong>Canyon SLE</strong>: Moving to the SLE trim gets you a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, four USB ports, 17-inch alloy wheels, steering wheel controls, an automatic locking differential in four-wheel drive models, 4G LTE connectivity, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, and the EZ Lift and Lower locking tailgate.</p>

<p><strong>Canyon SLT</strong>: The SLT trim adds 18-inch alloy wheels, remote start, a power-operated passenger seat, automatic climate control, a sliding rear window, heated front seats, and chrome side mirrors and door handles.</p>

<p><strong>Canyon All-Terrain</strong>: The off-road-oriented Canyon All-Terrain adds an off-road-tuned suspension, 17-inch dark alloy wheels, faux carbon fiber interior accents, red contrast stitching on the seats, hill descent control, and a transfer case shield.</p>

<p><strong>Canyon Denali</strong>: As the range-topping trim, the luxury-oriented Canyon Denali adds 20-inch alloy wheels, navigation, a Bose premium audio system, side steps, a heated steering wheel, a wireless charging pad, and ventilated front seats.</p>

<p>Key options such as navigation and the Bose premium audio system are available as options on lower grades of the Canyon.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/">GMC</a> Canyon comes standard with a 2.5-liter I-4 rated at 200 hp and 191 lb-ft of torque. A 3.6-liter V-6 with 308 hp and 275 lb-ft, and a 2.8-liter turbodiesel I-4 with 181 hp and 369 lb-ft is optional. A six-speed manual is standard on the base 2.5-liter I-4 and a six-speed automatic is optional. Diesel-powered Canyons come exclusively with the six-speed automatic while the 3.6-liter V-6 comes with an eight-speed automatic.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the base engine are 20/26 mpg city/highway for rear-drive models and 19/24 mpg with four-wheel drive. Trucks with the V-6 are rated at 18/25 mpg with rear-wheel drive or 17/24 mpg with four-wheel drive. The most efficient models is the diesel-powered Canyon, which is rated at 22/30 mpg for rear-drive trucks and 20/28 mpg with four-wheel drive.</p>

<p>The 2018 Canyon received a four-star rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars).  In IIHS testing, the crew cab version received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except for the passenger side front small overlap impact where it hasn’t been tested yet (Good is the highest possible score). Extended-cab models didn’t do as well scoring Good on all crashworthiness tests except for driver’s side front small overlap and side impact tests where it got an Acceptable rating. Both cab variants of the 2018 Canyon received a Poor score on the headlights test. The truck also received a Basic rating since it’s available with forward collision warning (Superior is the highest rating for the front crash prevention test). Lane departure warning is available only on certain trim levels.</p>

<p>With the base four-cylinder engine, the 2018 Canyon can tow up to 3,500 pounds when properly equipped. Trucks powered by the V-6 engine are more capable with a tow up to 7,000 pounds of payload. The most capable Canyon is the diesel-powered model, which can tow up to 7,700 pounds in rear-drive configuration or 7,600 pounds with four-wheel drive.</p>

<p>Extended-cab models can haul 1,599 pounds of payload in rear-drive configuration or 1,559 pounds with four-wheel drive. Crew cab models with the short bed are rated at 1,605 pounds of payload in rear-drive guise and 1,528 pounds with four-wheel drive. The Canyon crew cab with the long bed has the least maximum payload at 1,555 pounds in rear-drive guise or 1,459 pounds with four-wheel drive.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/canyon/2017/2017-gmc-canyon-denali-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we said that the new eight-speed automatic paired to the 308-hp 3.6-liter V-6 offers strong acceleration despite only having a slight bump in output. Denali models offer plenty of creature comforts but lack certain features like a moonroof, push button start, and fully powered front seats. Ride comfort is excellent and for a truck, the Canyon handles reasonably well. However, the eight-speed automatic is reluctant to give downshifts unless you floor it.</p>

<p>Cool Fact<br>
The GMC Canyon’s 3.6-liter V-6 is shared with a number of General Motors products including the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/colorado/2018/">Chevrolet Colorado</a> and Camaro.</br></p>

<p> </p>

<p>Although <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a> has only shown a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2018-honda-odyssey-teased-ahead-detroit-debut/">teaser sketch of the next-generation 2018 Honda Odyssey</a>, we expect the popular model to continue its influence over the minivan segment. Honda suggests the next Odyssey will feature “sophisticated styling” with the teaser sketch suggesting a new take on the current floating roof design on many modern vehicles.</p>

<p>Additionally, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/odyssey/2018/">2018 Honda Odyssey</a> will introduce new powertrain technologies and other innovative features. We expect the cool box (a refrigerated glove compartment) and <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/odyssey/2014/2014-honda-odyssey-touring-elite-first-test/">HondaVac to carry over</a>. The next-gen Odyssey debuts at the 2017 Detroit auto show in January.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018 </strong></p>

<p>In addition to the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/clarity/2018/">Honda Clarity</a> Fuel Cell hydrogen car already roaming California highways, the Japanese automaker revealed the all-new <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/honda-clarity-ev-plug-hybrid-debut-new-york/">2018 Honda Clarity Electric and 2018 Honda Clarity Plug-in Hybrid models</a> at the 2017 New York auto show. Buyers will now have three powertrains choices with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a> Clarity sedan.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/clarity/2018/">2018 Honda Clarity</a> Fuel Cell hydrogen car, 2018 Honda Clarity Electric, and 2018 Honda Clarity Plug-in Hybrid sedans will slot alongside the Fit EV, CR-Z hybrid, and Accord Hybrid in the automaker’s alternative vehicle lineup as well as the gasoline-powered Civic and Accord in its sedan lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Motivation for the Clarity Plug-in Hybrid comes from an electric motor with 181 hp and 232 lb-ft of torque, with power from a 17 kWh battery pack. A 1.5-liter Atkinson cycle I-4 gasoline engine is used primarily to generate electricity to recharge the battery pack, but in some conditions can be used for vehicle motivation. The battery pack can be recharged in 2.5 hours with a 240-volt Level 2 charger. The plug-in model has an expected range of 42 miles on electricity alone and about 330 miles overall with the generator in hybrid mode as well as a 105 mpg-e rating.</p>

<p>The Clarity Plug-in Hybrid features three driving modes including Normal, Econ, and Sport, while the HV mode, which maintains the battery’s state of charge, can be used with any of the three driving modes. Two trims are available including standard and Touring.</p>

<p>The Honda Clarity Electric is powered by a 161-hp, 221 lb-ft electric motor paired with a 25.5 kWh battery pack, which can be charged in a little over three hours via a 240-volt charger or to an 80 percent charge via an SAE Combined Charging System DC fast charger. Honda expects the Clarity Electric to have a 120/102/111 mpg-e city/highway/combined and a total range of just 80 miles. Initially, the Clarity Electric will be available for lease in California and Oregon.</p>

<p>The fuel cell in the regular Honda Clarity Fuel Cell  is said to be 33 percent smaller and 60 percent more power dense than the previous Honda FCX Clarity four-door. The hydrogen fuel cell and integrated powertrain are about the size of a V-6 engine and fits completely under the hood of the car. The Clarity Fuel Cell has an EPA-rated 68 mpg-e combined and a 366-mile range. Currently, the Clarity Fuel Cell is only offered for lease in California.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>All three 2018 Honda Clarity models feature the full suite of Honda Sensing safety and driver assist technologies including Collision Mitigation Braking System (CMBS) with Forward Collision Warning (FCW), Road Departure Mitigation (RDM) with Lane Departure Warning (LDW), Lane Keeping Assist System (LKAS) and Adaptive Cruise Control (ACC). Other safety features include a multi-angle rearview camera as well as array of front and side airbags.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Honda claims the Clarity Electric is more spacious and luxurious than any other non-<a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/">Tesla</a> EV.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors: </strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The refreshed <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/fit/2018/">2018 Honda Fit</a> gets slightly tweaked front fascia and a new Sport trim that gets a unique body kit, 16-inch alloy wheels with a gloss black finish, bright orange pinstriping, a chrome exhaust tip, and black cloth upholstery with orange contrast stitching. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a> also added a new multimedia system with a volume knob as well as Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/fit/2018/">Honda Fit</a> is a front-drive subcompact hatchback that slots under the compact Civic and serves as the automaker’s entry-level vehicle.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Honda Fit is powered by a 1.5-liter I-4 with 130 hp and 114 lb-ft of torque when equipped with the standard six-speed manual transmission or 128 hp and 113 lb-ft with the optional CVT. EX-L models come exclusively with the CVT. EPA fuel economy ratings are 29/36 mpg city/highway with the manual, 31/36 mpg with the CVT in Sport, EX, and EX-L trims, and 33/40 mpg with the CVT in the base LX grade. Cargo space with the split-folding rear seats in place is 16.6 cubic feet and 52.7 cubic feet with them folded.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base LX trim include cloth upholstery, a four-speaker audio system, a 5.0-inch screen, Bluetooth connectivity, a USB port, 15-inch steel wheels, keyless entry, and a rearview camera. The Sport trim adds 16-inch black alloy wheels, fog lights, a chrome exhaust tip, a body kit, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, a six-speaker audio system, the HondaLink infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, and a second USB port. The EX trim adds keyless start, 16-inch machine-finished alloy wheels, and a moonroof. On the range-topping EX-L grade, additional features include leather upholstery, heated front seats, heated side mirrors, and an optional navigation system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Honda Fit a five-star overall safety rating (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 Fit received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests for which it was tested except a Poor rating on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the 2018 Fit received a Superior rating after it avoided collisions in 12- and 25-mph tests (Superior is the highest possible score for the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p>Standard on the EX and EX-L trims and optional on the LX and Sport grades is Honda Sensing, an active safety suite that includes adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, lane keeping assist, road departure mitigation, and lane departure warning.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/fit/2018/2018-honda-fit-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive</a>, we said that the addition of a volume knob has made the Fit’s infotainment more user-friendly. The Fit remains great to drive and the suspension deals with road imperfections well despite being on the sportier side. However, even though the 1.5-liter I-4 is one of the more powerful engines in its class, it could still use more torque. The manual transmission is easy to use in traffic and can be had with advanced safety tech.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>In order to give the Fit its expansive interior, Honda mounted the fuel tank under the front seats to free up space in the rear.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The three-row <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/pilot/2018/">Honda Pilot</a> did not receive any new changes for the 2018 model year, but expect to see a refresh for the 2019 model year.</p>

<p>The Pilot is the largest and most expansive crossover in <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a>’s lineup, positioned above the compact CR-V and subcompact HR-V.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/pilot/2018/">2018 Honda Pilot</a> LX</strong>: The base LX trim comes standard with 18-inch wheels, eight-passenger seating, a 5.0-inch center screen, Bluetooth, two USB port, a 4.2-inch instrument panel driver’s display, a 200-watt seven-speaker audio system, push-start ignition, hill-start assist, cruise control, rearview camera, and manually adjustable front seats.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Honda Pilot EX</strong>: Moving up to the EX trim adds remote engine start, LED daytime running lights, Honda LaneWatch, an 8.0-inch center display with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto connectivity, SiriusXM satellite radio, 10-way power driver’s seat (manual for passenger), heated and power side-view mirrors, a quick entry system, fog lights, tri-zone climate control, rear facing conversation mirror, and three USB ports.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Honda Pilot EX-L</strong>: The well-equipped EX-L trim comes with a power moonroof, a power tailgate, four-way power passenger’s seat, leather-trimmed seats, heated front seats, an auto-dimming rearview mirror, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and one-touch folding second-row seats.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Honda Pilot Touring</strong>: Building off the Pilot EX-L, the Touring trim adds a nine-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters (upgraded from the six-speed automatic), a navigation system, a rear seat entertainment system with a 9.0-inch top-mounted screen, a 540-watt 10-speaker audio system, a fifth USB port in the second-row, front and rear parking sensors, roof rails, automatic reverse-tilting side-view mirrors, blue ambient lighting, courtesy door lights, and Honda Sensing, which includes automatic emergency braking, lane centering assist, adaptive cruise control, and lane departure assist.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Honda Pilot Elite</strong>: The Pilot’s top Elite trim comes standard with all-wheel drive, LED headlights, automatic high beams, a panoramic moonroof, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, rain-sensing windshield wipers, LED map lights, front and second-row illuminated cup holders, heated and ventilated front seats with perforated leather, heated second-row captain’s chairs with perforated leather, front and rear parking sensors with indicators, and HD radio.</p>

<p>The Pilot’s 3.5-liter V-6 produces 280 hp and 262 lb-ft of torque and delivers an EPA-rated 18/26 mpg city/highway with the six-speed automatic and all-wheel drive, or 19/27 mpg with front-wheel drive. With the nine-speed automatic, the Pilot is rated at 20/27 mpg with front-wheel drive and 19/26 mpg with all-wheel drive. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, a 2016 Honda Pilot AWD with the nine-speed automatic hit 60 mph in a quick 6.2 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 119 feet.</p>

<p>The Honda Pilot received the highest five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA. The Pilot is considered an IIHS 2018 Top Safety Pick for receiving the highest rating of Good in five crash tests, the second-highest rating of Acceptable for the headlights evaluation, and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention test for avoiding a 12-mph collision and reducing the speed of a 25-mph collision by 12 mph thanks to the automatic emergency braking system found in the Honda Sensing package. Honda Sensing—available on the EX and standard on the Touring trim—also consists of adaptive cruise control, lane centering assist, and lane departure assist. Blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert and automatic high beams are standard on the Elite trim. Honda LaneWatch (standard on EX, EX-L, and Touring, but not available on LX or Elite) activates a camera viewing the lane to the right of the Pilot when the right blinker is activated. Front and rear parking sensors become standard on the Touring trim.</p>

<p>The 2018 Honda Pilot can carry up to 16.5 cubic feet of cargo behind the third-row, 46.8 with the third-row folded down, and 83.9 cubic feet with the second and third rows folded down. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/explorer/2018/">Ford Explorer</a> has more behind the third row with 21.0 cubic feet, but less behind the second row with 43.9 cubic feet and 81.7 behind the front seats. First, second, and third-row legroom in the Pilot is 40.9 inches, 38.4 inches, and 31.9 inches, respectively.</p>

<p>The Pilot LX’s standard 5.0-inch center screen is upgraded to the 8.0-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto and SiriusXM satellite radio in the EX trim. The Touring trim adds a navigation system, a rear seat entertainment system, a fifth USB port, and a 115-volt outlet to power your devices. The standard 200-watt audio system is upgraded to a 225-watt on in the EX trim and a 10-speaker, 540-watt system in the Touring trim. A 4.2-inch instrument panel driver’s display is standard on all trims.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/pilot/2016/2016-honda-pilot-elite-awd-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2016 Honda Pilot Elite, we were very impressed with the crossover’s quick acceleration and comfortable ride. The optional one-touch second-row seats make getting into the decently sized third row easy. The all-wheel-drive system provides good off-road traction but the nine-speed automatic transmission was “a bit clunky at times” on the road and we questioned why the Pilot still had a manual pedal parking brake instead of an electric one. We liked the available Honda Sensing package of driver assist safety features, the 8.0-inch center touchscreen on almost every trim, and the digital speedometer located at the top of the instrument cluster. We concluded our review by saying, “Although the 2016 Pilot is more attractive than the boxy previous generation crossovers, it reminded more than one driver of a minivan from inside—not a good connection for a minivan alternative. If you don’t mind the low-speed behavior of the nine-speed auto on Touring and Elite models, however, the Honda merits a top spot on your shopping list.”</p>

<p>After 15 months in our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/pilot/2016/2016-honda-pilot-elite-review-verdict/">long-term 2016 Honda Pilot</a>, we appreciated the three-row crossover’s interior that took a beating after 38,528 miles but wished it had a volume knob (Honda is starting to bring back the volume knob to its lineup). Besides a transmission replacement that was covered under warranty, the Pilot suffered no additional mechanical defects and had average maintenance costs. One thing that really impressed us was the Pilot’s traction in a bad mountain winter storm. The Honda traversed snow and ice-covered roads with confidence while on factory tires without chains.</p>

<p>Our biggest issue with the Pilot remained the nine-speed automatic found on the top two trims: “It’s great for cruising on the highway, but the nine-speed lacks smoothness for stop-and-go in-town driving. It can be especially maddening in driving conditions when the throttle needs constant modulation, with jerkiness and hesitation between upshifts and downshifts.”</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>For the 2018 model year, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/ridgeline/2018/">Honda Ridgeline</a> now only has nine trim levels, down from 12 in 2017. Also, the Sport trim is now available with two new exterior colors: White Diamond Pearl and Lunar Silver Metallic.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/ridgeline/2018/">2018 Honda Ridgeline</a> is a midsize pickup truck that’s available in front- or all-wheel drive configurations. Unlike other midsize trucks, the Ridgeline features a unibody, and not body-on-frame construction.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a> Ridgeline is powered by a 3.5-liter V-6 rated at 280 hp and 262 lb-ft of torque. With the Ridgeline’s six-speed automatic transmission EPA fuel economy ratings are 19/26 mpg city/highway for front-drive models and 18/25 mpg with all-wheel drive. When properly equipped, the front-drive Ridgeline can tow up to 3,500 pounds and the all-wheel drive model can tow up to 5,000 pounds.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base RT trim include the in-bed trunk, the Dual-Action tailgate, keyless start, cloth upholstery, 60/40 split-folding rear seats, a 5.0-inch screen, Bluetooth connectivity, a USB port, 18-inch alloy wheels, a rearview camera, and a 4.2-inch multi-information display in the instrument cluster. Higher trims can be had with keyless entry, LED headlights, a 540-watt audio system, leather upholstery, heated front seats, power-adjustable front seats, the HondaLink infotainment system with an 8.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, three additional USB ports, an in-bed audio system, and interior ambient lighting.</p>

<p>A Black Edition sits at the top of the 2018 Ridgeline lineup, including all the features of the RTL-E trim, but adding black exterior and interior accents (including black leather and black wheels), as well as red ambient lighting.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Ridgeline a five-star overall rating (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 Ridgeline but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests and the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Ridgeline received a Superior rating after it avoided collisions in the 12- and 25-mph tests (Superior is the highest possible rating in the front crash prevention test). As a result, the Honda Ridgeline received the Top Safety Pick+ award from the IIHS.</p>

<p>Standard on the RTL-E and Black Edition models is Honda Sensing, a suite of active safety features that includes adaptive cruise control, automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, lane keeping assist, lane departure warning, automatic high beams, road departure mitigation, and blind-spot warning.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/ridgeline/2017/honda-ridgeline-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we said that even though the Ridgeline rides on a car-based platform, its handling benefits is minimal compared to body-on-frame competitors such as the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/colorado/2018/">Chevrolet Colorado</a>. The truck’s towing capabilities are also less than rivals but it easily hauls its rated capacity. Ride comfort is where the Ridgeline excels. Thanks to its car-based chassis, the Ridgeline doesn’t wander around on the highway and rarely gets jittery. The truck is also less prone to lean into corners. However, the V-6 engine needs more revs to get moving and there’s no manual shift mode function.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The in-bed trunk in the Honda Ridgeline can be turned into a cooler thanks to a drain plug built into its bottom.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2018/">2018 Honda Civic</a> is unchanged. The performance-minded Civic Si and Civic Type R were late additions to the 2017 model year lineup and carry over with the rest of the lineup unchanged.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2018/">Honda Civic</a> is a front-drive compact car that slots below the larger Accord and above the subcompact Fit. Three body styles are offered, coupe, hatchback, and sedan. In addition to the standard models, two performance-oriented variants are available the Civic Si, which is available as a sedan or coupe, and the Civic Type R, which is offered only as a hatchback.</p>

<p><strong>Civic LX:</strong> The base LX trim comes with automatic headlights, cruise control, a 160-watt audio system with four speakers, a 5.0-inch screen, Bluetooth, a USB port, 16-inch steel wheels with covers, cloth upholstery, and a rearview camera. Hatchback variants get the 1.5-liter turbo-four as standard.</p>

<p><strong>Civic Sport:</strong> Available only on the hatchback, the Civic Sport gets a unique exhaust system, 18-inch alloy wheels, fog lights, and underbody spoilers to give it a more aggressive look in addition to the same standard features as the LX trim.</p>

<p><strong>Civic EX:</strong> Moving up to the EX trim adds <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a>’s Lane Watch system, 16-inch alloy wheels, keyless entry/start, a second USB port, a 180-watt audio system with eight speakers, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, remote start, a moonroof, and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration.</p>

<p><strong>Civic EX-T:</strong> The EX-T trim adds 17-inch alloy wheels, the 1.5-liter turbo-four, fog lights, a rear spoiler, dual-zone climate control, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and heated front seats.</p>

<p><strong>Civic Si:</strong> Available as a single trim, the Civic Si comes with the same features as the EX-T trim plus sport seats with fixed headrests, a Sport mode, 18-inch alloy wheels, a sportier suspension setup, a more powerful 1.5-liter turbo-four, a limited-slip differential, and adjustable dampers.</p>

<p><strong>Civic EX-L:</strong> Jumping to the EX-L gets you leather upholstery, eight-way power adjustable front seats, and an auto-dimming rearview mirror.</p>

<p><strong>Civic Touring:</strong> Range-topping Touring Models get you full LED headlights, heated outboard rear seats on the sedan, navigation, a four-way power adjustable front passenger seat, a 450-watt premium audio system with 10 speakers, and the Honda Sensing suite of active safety tech that’s an option on other trims.</p>

<p><strong>Civic Sport Touring:</strong> Another trim available only on the hatchback, the Sport Touring is the range-topper of the Civic hatchback and comes with the same cosmetic changes as the Sport trim but with the creature comforts of the sedan and coupe’s Touring trim. It also gets a 540-watt premium audio system with 12 speakers instead of the 450-watt unit found in the sedan and coupe.</p>

<p><strong>Civic Type R</strong>: The highest-performing Civic model comes with 20-inch alloy wheels, adjustable dampers, a performance-tuned suspension, high performance front bucket seats, a limited-slip differential and a fully functional aero kit complete with a large rear wing. Unlike the Civic Si, which is based on the EX-T trim, the Civic Type R is based on the Touring trim but doesn’t include the Honda Sensing suite.</p>

<p>The 2018 Honda Civic is available with three engine choices. A 2.0-liter I-4 with 158 hp and 138 lb-ft of torque paired to a six-speed manual or CVT is standard on the coupe and sedan. A 1.5-liter turbo-four with 174 hp and 167 lb-ft (manual) or 162 lb-ft (CVT) is optional on the coupe and sedan, and standard on the hatchback.</p>

<p>The Sport trim on the hatchback features the same 1.5-liter turbo-four but it’s rated at 180 hp and 177 lb-ft with the six-speed manual. With the optional CVT, the engine retains its 162 lb-ft. In the Civic Si, the same 1.5-liter turbo-four is rated at 205 hp and 192 lb-ft. The most powerful model is the Civic Type R, which uses a 2.0-liter turbo-four good for 306 hp and 295 lb-ft. A six-speed manual is the only transmission available on the Civic Si and Civic Type R.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the sedan with the 2.0-liter I-4 are 28/40 mpg city/highway with the manual and 31/40 mpg with the CVT. Opt for the optional 1.5-liter turbo-four and you’ll get even better fuel economy at 31/42 mpg with the manual or 32/42 mpg with the CVT. The coupe is less efficient, with the 2.0-liter at 28/39 mpg with the manual or 30/39 mpg with the CVT. With the 1.5-liter turbo-four the coupe is rated at 30/41 mpg with the manual or 31/40 mpg with the CVT.</p>

<p>The Civic hatchback is rated at 29/38 mpg with the manual or 31/40 mpg with the CVT. Sport and Sport Touring models are less efficient with the CVT at 30/36 mpg. For a performance-oriented model, the Civic Si is surprisingly fuel efficient at 28/38 mpg. The Civic Type R, on the other hand, is the least efficient model at 22/28 mpg.</p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Civic a five-star overall safety rating (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS evaluations, the 2018 Civic received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except for the new headlights test where it got a Poor rating (Good is the highest possible score). Coupe and hatchback models haven’t been tested for the new passenger side front small overlap impact as of this writing. In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the 2018 Civic avoided a 12-mph and a 25-mph collision, allowing it to receive a Superior rating (Superior is the highest score in the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p>Honda Sensing is standard on the Touring and Sport Touring trims and available on all but the Sport, Si and Type R models. That package bundles together adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assist, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, and road departure mitigation. Instead of blind-spot monitoring, the Civic features Honda’s Lane Watch system, which utilizes a camera on the right side mirror to show your right side blind spot on the main touchscreen.</p>

<p>The Civic sedan has 15.1 cubic feet of trunk space on all but Touring and Si trims, which has less at 14.7 cubic feet. Coupe models have less trunk space at 12.1 cubic feet for the LX trim or 11.9 cubic feet on the EX-T, EX-L, Touring, and Si grades. For more cargo space, the Civic hatchback has 25.7 cubic feet behind the split-folding second row and 46.2 cubic feet behind the front seats. Sport and Sport Touring models have less cargo space with the rear seats in place at 22.6 cubic feet.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2016/2016-2017-big-test-compact-sedans/">2016 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/elantra/2018/">Hyundai Elantra</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/cruze/2018/">Chevrolet Cruze</a>, Mazda3, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/corolla/2018/">Toyota Corolla</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/jetta/2018/">Volkswagen Jetta</a>, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/sentra/2018/">Nissan Sentra</a>, the Honda Civic won because of its combination efficiency, safety, and performance. The interior packaging is also impressive, with its reconfigurable center console storage area and generous passenger space. However, the infotainment system lacks a volume knob and can be finicky to use.</p>

<p>The Civic hatchback takes things up a notch and offers better handling than the coupe and sedan, making it plenty of fun to drive. It offers even more interior space than the Civic coupe and sedan, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2017/2017-honda-civic-hatchback-sport-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>. We found the Civic hatchback’s cargo cover to be a highlight because you can stow it on the side without having to take it out of the car.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2017/2017-honda-civic-si-sedan-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a> of the first turbocharged Civic Si, we were surprised that the car wasn’t quicker than its naturally aspirated predecessors, but its braking performance was better. The new Civic Si retains the model’s expected excellent handling, especially with the optional summer performance tires, without sacrificing much in terms of ride quality. However, because it shares powertrain bits from the regular Civic, the Civic Si no longer feels special like its predecessors were with their high-revving engines.</p>

<p>The highlight of the 10<sup>th</sup>-generation Civic lineup is the 306-hp Civic Type R, which offers a slick shifter and exceptional performance that belies the fact that it’s front-wheel drive. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2017/2017-honda-civic-type-r-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we were impressed with the way the Civic Type R balances its excellent handling with comfort and daily drivability, despite what its aggressive looks might convey.</p>

<p>The Civic hatchback, including the Type R model, is built in Honda’s Swindon plant in the UK.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/cr-v/2018/">Honda CR-V</a> did not receive any significant changes for the 2018 model year.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The CR-V is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a>’s compact crossover, slotting above the subcompact HR-V and below the three-row Pilot in size and price. The CR-V has a higher starting price than the Accord sedan and Civic hatchback.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The base LX model for the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/cr-v/2018/">2018 Honda CR-V</a> is powered by a 2.4-liter I-4 engine that produces 184 hp and 180 lb-ft of torque and is rated at an EPA-estimated 26/32 mpg city/highway with front-wheel drive and 25/31 mpg with all-wheel drive. The CR-V EX, EX-L, and Touring trims come standard with a 190-hp, 179-lb-ft of torque 1.5-liter turbocharged I-4 engine that delivers 28/34 mpg with front-wheel drive and 27/33 with all-wheel drive. Both engines are backed by a CVT. In <span style="font-style: normal !msorm"><em>Motor Trend</em></span> testing, the 2017 Honda CR-V AWD Touring hit 60 mph in a respectable 7.5 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in an impressive 115 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 CR-V comes standard with 17-inch wheels, automatic climate control, a 5.0-inch LCD center display screen with Bluetooth phone and streaming audio, one USB charging port, a multi-information drivers display, and a six-way manual adjustable driver’s seat. The EX model adds a power moonroof, fog lights, push-button start, heated front seats, and a 7.0-inch center display with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. The EX-L includes a 12-way power driver’s seat, four-way power passenger’s seat, leather upholstery and an automatic dimming rearview mirror. The top Touring model comes standard with 18-inch alloy wheels, a hands-free power liftgate with programmable height, LED headlights with auto on/off, dual-zone automatic climate control, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, and a 330-watt premium audio system. If you’re seeking bolder styling, opt for the available body side moldings and 19-inch diamond-cut alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Honda CR-V received the highest overall safety rating from the NHTSA of five stars, and the crossover is considered an IIHS 2017 Top Safety Pick+. The highest award of Top Safety Pick+ was issued because the CR-V scored the highest rating of Good in all five crash test evaluations, the highest rating of Superior for front crash prevention, and scored the second highest rating of Acceptable for the headlights evaluation. The Superior rating for front crash prevention was issued because the CR-V properly warned the driver of a possible collision and avoided frontal collisions in 12- and 25-mph tests thanks to the optional Collision Mitigation Braking System found in the Honda Sensing package that is standard on the EX trim and above. The Honda Sensing package also includes Forward Collision Warning, Lane Departure Warning, Road Departure Mitigation System, Lane Keeping Assist System, and adaptive cruise control with Low-Speed Follow. Other safety features include the standard multi-angle rearview camera system, automatic high beams, rain-sensing windshield wipers, rear parking sensors, and blind-spot monitoring with Cross Traffic Monitor.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/cr-v/2017/2017-honda-cr-v-touring-awd-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 Honda CR-V, we liked the crossover’s quick acceleration for the segment, the responsive and smooth automatic transmission, and plentiful rear seat room. The CR-V provides more cargo room than most in its class and has easy-folding second-row seats. We like the modern design of the CR-V but wished the center screen was a little larger and was canted toward the driver. We also wished the CR-V had better outward visibility; this made us appreciate the Honda Sensing package of driver assist safety features even more. “It’s not that the CR-V does everything well, but just like its predecessor, it’s good or <em>soooo</em> good at so many important things that it’s difficult not to appreciate the Honda. Does the CR-V have a chance at claiming the SUV of the Year title? It surely has a chance and, in the meantime, the crossover is ready to do showroom battle as it likely becomes Honda’s best-selling vehicle.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/cr-v/2017/2017-honda-cr-v-vs-2017-mazda-cx-5-comparison-review/">two-way comparison</a> against the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-5/2018/">Mazda CX-5</a>, we loved just about everything the CR-V offered except the excessive wind and tire noise, a slightly frustrating user interface, and a less premium interior versus the CX-5. We concluded the comparison by saying: “Yes, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/">Mazda</a> CX-5 is prettier, more luxurious, and a little more fun to drive, but the Honda CR-V is just damn good. If you want to be coldly rational, the CR-V has more space, gets better fuel economy, has more-advanced technology, and is cheaper to own. It’s also very good to drive. In the past, we lead-footed sports car lovers might have excused the Mazda’s deficiencies in exchange for its lusty driving experience. But this time, we have no hesitation in recommending the CR-V to enthusiasts as well as our automotively apathetic friends and family. It’s a narrow margin of victory, but whether your other car is a Camaro or a Corolla, if you want a compact crossover, you’ll be slightly better served by the new Honda CR-V.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The large three-row <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/pilot/2018/">Honda Pilot</a> offers up to 83.9 cubic feet of cargo space, which is not too much more than the CR-V’s impressive 75.8 cubic feet of cargo space.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The subcompact <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/hr-v/2018/">Honda HR-V</a> is the automaker’s entry-level crossover and slots below the compact CR-V and full-size three-row Pilot SUV. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a> also sells the three-row Odyssey minivan and four-door Ridgeline pickup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>Because the HR-V arrived for the 2015 model year, the small crossover might be refreshed for the 2018 or 2019 model year, with available active safety tech on higher trims and a mild facelift. We’ll update this space as soon as we have official info.</p>

<p>Power for the current, 2017 HR-V comes from a 1.8-liter I-4 rated at 121 hp and 127 lb-ft of torque. The engine is backed by either a six-speed manual in front-drive form or a CVT in front- or all-wheel-drive. Three trims are available including LX, EX, and EX-L-Navi. The top-spec model includes leather seating, navigation, and paddle shifters standard.</p>

<p>Standard active safety tech includes multi-angle rearview camera, Vehicle Stability Assist (VSA) with traction control, Tire Pressure Monitoring System (TPMS), and daytime running lights. Honda LaneWatch, a rear-facing camera mounted on the passenger side-view mirror, is included on EX and EX-L-Navi.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/accord/2018/">2018 Honda Accord</a> is all-new and rides on a new platform with new turbocharged engines and features an updated infotainment system that has volume and tuning knobs. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a> has discontinued the Accord’s coupe body style, leaving only the sedan.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/accord/2018/">Honda Accord</a> is a front-drive midsize sedan slotting above the compact Civic. In addition to the 1.5T and 2.0T gas-powered models, there’s also a hybrid variant.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Honda Accord is available with two turbocharged four-cylinder engines including a 1.5-liter with 192 hp and 192 lb-ft of torque. The non-hybrid upgrade engine is a 2.0-liter unit with 252 hp and 273 lb-ft. A six-speed manual is available on the Sport trims for both engines. Automatic transmission options include a CVT for the 1.5-liter unit or a 10-speed unit for the more powerful 2.0-liter. The Accord Hybrid returns with an updated version of Honda’s two-motor hybrid system that couples a 2.0-liter I-4 to two electric motors and a lithium-ion battery for a total output of 212 hp. Unlike some of its competitors, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/accord-hybrid/2018/">Honda Accord Hybrid</a> doesn’t utilize a conventional transmission.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings are 30/38 mpg city/highway for the CVT-equipped 1.5-liter in all trims except Sport and Touring, which get 29/35 mpg Go for the manual transmission on the 1.5T and the ratings are 26/35 mpg. Fuel economy ratings with the both variants of the 2.0-liter and the hybrid haven’t been released yet. Trunk space on all variants is 16.7 cubic feet even in the Accord Hybrid, which now has its batteries placed under the rear seats.</p>

<p>The base Accord LX trim comes with, a rearview camera, LED low-beam headlights, cloth upholstery, 17-inch alloy wheels, Bluetooth connectivity, a 7.0-inch screen, and a USB port. Moving up to the Accord EX trim adds a moonroof, remote start, 60/40 split-folding rear seats, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, heated front seats, an eight-speaker audio system, and keyless entry/start. Accord Sport models get 19-inch alloy-wheels, paddle shifters on CVT-equipped 1.5-liter turbo-four variants, unique exhausts, aluminum pedals, a rear spoiler, LED fog lights, and a leather-wrapped steering wheel.</p>

<p>Moving up to the Accord EX-L trim adds a power operated passenger seat, a 10-speaker audio system, memory function for the driver’s seat, a leather-wrapped shift knob, leather upholstery, and an optional navigation system. The range-topping Accord Touring grade adds 19-inch alloy wheels, a head-up display, adaptive dampers, full LED headlights, ventilated and heated front seats, wireless charging, heated rear seats, and parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Honda Accord. Standard on all models is the Honda Sensing active safety suite that includes forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, road departure mitigation, traffic sign recognition, and adaptive cruise control. A driver attention monitor, blind-spot warning, and rear cross-traffic alert are also available on certain trim levels.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/accord/2018/2018-honda-accord-15t-vs-2018-toyota-camry-25-comparison-review/">2018 comparison test</a> against the new <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/camry/2018/">Toyota Camry</a>, the 1.5-liter-equipped Accord handily won because of its sophisticated interior design, spacious interior, intuitive multimedia system, and superior powertrain. Although it needs slightly more throttle input than the Camry’s 2.5-liter I-4, the Accord’s turbocharged 1.5-liter accelerates in a more linear fashion and the CVT operates seamlessly without much droning. The Accord’s chassis is more responsive, giving it better cornering capabilities and minimal body roll. However, there’s excessive tire noise in the Accord and on less-than-perfect roads, it jostles around more.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/accord/2018/2018-honda-accord-15t-vs-2018-toyota-camry-25-comparison-review/">2018 First Test</a>, we noted that when the midsize sedan is equipped with the optional 2.0-liter turbo-four, the Accord offers strong acceleration, making it slightly quicker than its V-6-powered predecessor. The optional manual transmission, however, lacks the precision found in more sporting Hondas like the Civic Si and Type R. We were impressed with the Touring model, which comes with adaptive dampers and features excellent handling and responsiveness. Road noise, on the other hand, continues to be an issue in the Accord. The interior is a class above with high-quality materials everywhere.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Honda Accord’s optional 2.0-liter turbo-four is closely related to the 306-hp unit found in the high-performance Civic Type R.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>Android Auto and Apple CarPlay are now available on the 7.0-inch center display and heated seats and a heated steering wheel are offered on more trims. When equipped, Blue Link Connected Care, Remote Services and Guidance is now free for three years.</p>

<p>The Tucson is positioned above the new subcompact Kona crossover and below the larger and more expensive two-row Santa Fe Sport and three-row Santa Fe crossover.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Tucson SE</strong>: The Base SE trim comes standard with a 2.0-liter I-4 engine, 17-inch alloy wheels, a rearview camera, six-way manually adjustable driver’s seat, a 5.0-inch center touchscreen, a 3.5-inch LCD driver’s instrument panel display, and a tilt and telescoping steering wheel with audio, cruise, and phone controls.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Tucson SEL</strong>: The SEL trim adds quite a bit more equipment including a 7.0-inch center touchscreen with Android Auto and Apple CarPlay, SiriusXM satellite radio, heated front seats, a drive mode selector, roof rails, LED daytime running lights, and eight-way power driver’s seat.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Tucson Value</strong>: The Value trim replaces the 2.0-liter with a 1.6-liter turbo-four engine, and adds 19-inch wheels, a hands-free power liftgate, a panoramic sunroof, LED map lights, rear parking sensors, proximity key with push-button ignition, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, lane change assist, premium front and rear fascias, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, and dual automatic climate control.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Tucson SEL Plus</strong>: Building off the SEL’s features, the SEL Plus adds a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen with navigation, leather upholstery, an eight-way power passenger’s seat, an Infinity premium audio system, rear-seat air vents, Blue Link Connected Car system (including Guidance for navigation), auto-dimming rearview mirror, and a premium instrument panel, door panels, and window switches. The SEL Plus utilizes the 2.0-liter I-4 engine.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Tucson Limited</strong>: The top Limited trim packs the 1.6-liter turbo-four and adds LED headlights and tail lights, a heated steering wheel, and a chrome grille and exterior door handles.</p>

<p>The Ultimate package offered on the Limited trim adds luxury and safety with steering-responsive HID headlights, automatic emergency braking with pedestrian detection, lane departure warning, rear parking sensors, a panoramic moonroof, a 4.2-inch driver’s instrument panel display, ventilated front seats, and heated rear seats.</p>

<p>The 2018 Tucson’s base engine is a 164-hp, 151-lb-ft of torque 2.0-liter I-4 that delivers an EPA-rated 23/30 mpg city/highway with front-wheel drive and 21/26 mpg with all-wheel drive. The upgraded 1.6-liter turbocharged I-4 engine produces 175 hp and 195-lb-ft of and is rated at 25/30 mpg with FWD and 24/28 mpg with AWD. The 2.0-liter is backed by a six-speed automatic transmission and the 1.6-liter turbo-four gets paired to a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the Tucson Limited with AWD hit 60 mph in a respectable 7.9 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 120 feet.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/tucson/2018/">2018 Hyundai Tucson</a> received the highest five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA. The Tucson is also considered a 2018 Top Safety Pick from the IIHS because the crossover received the highest rating of Good in all six crash tests and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention test for avoiding both a 12- and 25-mph frontal collision thanks to the optional automatic emergency braking system found in the Ultimate package for the Limited model. Blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert and keep assist are standard on the SEL Plus, Value, and Limited trims and the aforementioned Ultimate package also consists of lane departure warning.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/tucson/2018/">Hyundai Tucson</a> can hold up to 31.0 cubic feet with the rear seats up and 61.9 with the rear seats folded down. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/escape/2018/">Ford Escape</a> tops the Tucson with 34.0 and 68.0 cubic feet, respectively. Legroom for the front passengers measures at 41.5 inches and 38.2 inches for the rear passengers.</p>

<p>The base Tucson is equipped with a 5.0-inch center touchscreen and a 3.5-inch LCD driver’s instrument panel display. The SEL trim adds more tech with a drive mode selector, a larger 7.0-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, SiriusXM satellite radio, and HD radio. In the SEL Plus, the screen size is increased to 8.0 inches and an Infinity premium audio system is added. The Blue Link Connected Car package offers services like automatic collision notification, SOS emergency assistance, and a vehicle monthly health report. The Remote package uses an app that can remote start your car (and adjust climate control), lock/unlock doors, honk the horn, find your vehicle in a parking lot, and several other services.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-5/2016/small-crossover-comparison-big-test/">Big Test comparison</a> among nine compact crossovers, the Tucson Limited AWD fared well and earned third place. Keeping it from first place was the powertrain’s slow throttle response, the high price tag, a small backseat, and a somewhat harsh ride. We said, “Our first podium finisher is the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/">Hyundai</a> Tucson. We all liked its upscale cabin, its around-town road manners, and its solid safety scores, but all that doesn’t quite justify the high Tucson’s high price.” “With a little refinement in that powertrain, we’d have had a much harder time picking our top two.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/tucson/2016/2016-hyundai-tucson-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the base SE trim and the top Limited trim, we liked the acceleration of the Limited model but not the slow acceleration of the base model with the 2.0-liter engine. Both engines have the same slow throttle response issue. The crossover offers a stiff ride but handles corners well. Inside, the Limited “is nicely appointed with a laundry list of standard features. Its 8-inch BlueLink information and entertainment screen is intuitive and responsive with crisp graphics. The materials are good quality, and the vehicle feels worthy of its price tag.”</p>

<p>On the other hand, “the SE, on the other hand, feels like the cheapest SUV option at the rental counter. All of the fancier safety features are options, just like the conveniences. The monotone coloring, cheap-feeling materials, and dearth of features were disappointments. The rough plastic steering wheel drew considerable rebuke.” Regardless, both vehicles are quiet inside, comfortable, and have good visibility. We concluded by saying, “The new Tucson offers a nice upgrade with more space and some of the best styling in the class from the outgoing model. Should you be willing to pay for it, you can add more features than most competitors while maintaining class-competitive fuel economy and performance. In terms of how it drives, we find the new Tucson to be average, but if that matters less to you than features and style, you’ll find plenty to like.”</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>The Accent enters its fifth generation with the redesigned 2018 model that rides on a new platform and features new styling inside and out, new technology, and new driver assist safety features. The hatchback body style has been dropped.</p>

<p>The Accent is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/">Hyundai</a>’s smallest sedan, slotting below the larger and more expensive Elantra, Sonata, and Azera sedans.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Accent SE</strong>: The Accent’s base SE trim is equipped with a 5.0-inch color touchscreen, Bluetooth, a USB port, a rearview camera, power side view mirrors, remote keyless entry, six-way adjustable driver’s seat, and 15-inch steel wheels.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Accent SEL</strong>: The SEL trim adds a 7.0-inch center touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, SiriusXM satellite radio, automatic headlights, heated side view mirrors, tilt/telescoping steering wheel, two USB ports, Bluetooth voice recognition, and 15-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Accent Limited</strong>: The range-topping Limited trim adds lots of features including 17-inch alloy wheels, emergency automatic braking, push-start ignition, heated front seats, power sunroof, LED daytime running lights, fog lights, a chrome grille, automatic climate control, a 3.5-inch instrument panel driver’s display, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, Blue Link Connected services, and an automatic hands-free trunk that opens by simply standing behind the car with the key fob.</p>

<p>The front- drive <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/accent/2018/">2018 Hyundai Accent</a> is powered by a 1.6-liter I-4 that produces 130 hp and 119 lb-ft of torque and comes paired to a six-speed manual transmission (EPA rated 28/37 mpg) or a six-speed automatic transmission (28/38 mpg).</p>

<p>The Accent offers automatic emergency braking that comes standard on the Limited trim. Hill-start assist is optional and a rearview camera with guidelines is standard.</p>

<p>The 2018 Accent carries up to 13.7 cubic feet of cargo room in the trunk and offers 42.1 inches of legroom for front passengers and 33.5 inches for rear passengers.</p>

<p>The Accent comes standard with a 5.0-inch touchscreen with Bluetooth calling and a USB port. The available 7.0-inch touchscreen with Bluetooth voice recognition and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto is standard on the SEL trim. Blue Link Connected services allows owners to remotely control their car (start, lock/unlock, honk the horn) from their smartphone and is standard on the Limited trim for three years.</p>

<p>In our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/accent/2018/2018-hyundai-accent-first-drive-review/">First Drive</a> review of the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/accent/2018/">Hyundai Accent</a>, we felt the power was adequate and the transmission shifted well. Handling was well-controlled and ride comfort was good but unsettled over rough pavement. The front seats are comfortable and interior quality is good but there are a lot of hard plastics and road and tire noise can get loud.
