We concluded by saying, “With a generous list of standard features on each trim, the 2018 Hyundai Accent proves that buying a subcompact car doesn’t mean you’ll be driving something extremely basic. Sure, there’s still some road and tire noise, but it’s better than the old car and quieter than rivals such as the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/fit/">Honda Fit</a>, <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/versa/">Nissan Versa</a>, and <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fiesta/">Ford Fiesta</a>. The car’s exterior is stylish, and its driving dynamics have improved. With all of the improvements made to the new car as well as its long warranty, the 2018 Accent might just win over buyers who would otherwise only consider a used vehicle.”</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>A new Value package joins the Santa Fe Sport lineup and the premium wood-finish trim is now standard on leather-equipped models. Blue Link-equipped models now have all services standard for three years.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/santa-fe/2018/">Hyundai Santa Fe</a> Sport is positioned above the subcompact Kona and compact Tucson, but below the larger and more expensive three-row Santa Fe.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Santa Fe Sport</strong>: The base Santa Fe Sport comes standard with a 2.4-liter I-4 engine, 17-inch alloy wheels, a 5.0-inch center touchscreen, projector headlights with LED accents, automatic headlights, power and heated side view mirrors, and a rear spoiler.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Santa Fe Sport 2.0T</strong>: The 2.0T model adds a more powerful 2.0-liter turbo-four engine, 18-inch alloy wheels, a unique lower front fascia, chrome-tipped dual exhaust, LED daytime running lights, fog lights, hands-free liftgate, blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert, a 7.0-inch center display with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, SiriusXM satellite radio, dual zone climate control, Blue Link telematics, power and heated front seats, leather upholstery, an LCD instrument panel driver’s display, and wood-finish trim.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Santa Fe Sport 2.0T Ultimate</strong>: The range-topping Ultimate trim builds off the regular 2.0T trim and adds HID headlights, 19-inch alloy wheels, a panoramic sunroof, rear parking sensors, an Infinity premium audio system, a heated steering wheel, heated rear seats, ventilated front seats, an 8.0-inch touchscreen with a navigation system, a multi-view camera system, Blue Link Guidance, Connected Care, and Remote package for three years.</p>

<p>The new Value package can be ordered on the base trim and consists of heated and powered side view mirrors, express up/down front windows, push-start ignition, a 7.0-inch screen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, dual-zone automatic climate control, Blue Link connected car system, power driver’s seat, heated front seats, LED daytime running lights, fog lights, and roof rails.</p>

<p>The Santa Fe Sport’s base 2.4-liter I-4 produces 185 hp and 178 lb-ft of torque and delivers an EPA-rated 21/27 mpg with the standard front-wheel-drive system and 20/26 mpg with the available all-wheel drive system. The optional 2.0-liter turbo-four engine pumps out 240 hp and 260 lb-ft of torque and is rated at 20/28 mpg with FWD and 19/26 mpg with AWD. With the 2.0-liter turbo-four equipped in the range-topping Ultimate trim, fuel economy slightly drops to 20/27 mpg with FWD and 19/24 mpg with AWD. All models are backed by a six-speed automatic transmission. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 Santa Fe Sport (2.4-liter with FWD) hit 60 mph in 8.3 seconds and the 2.0T Ultimate AWD did it in 8.4 seconds.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/santa-fe/2018/">2018 Hyundai Santa Fe</a> Sport received the highest five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA. The 2018 Santa Fe Sport is considered a 2018 Top Safety Pick+ because the crossover received the highest score of Good in five crash tests and the second-highest rating of Acceptable for the new passenger-side small overlap front crash test. The highest designation was also received because the Santa Fe Sport received the highest rating of Good for the headlights test and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention test by avoiding a 12- and 25-mph frontal collision thanks to the automatic emergency braking system found in the optional Tech package. The Tech package of driver assist safety features is only offered on the Ultimate trim (the base trim offers a different Tech package) and consists of adaptive cruise control with stop/go, lane departure warning, electronic parking brake, high-beam assist, and steering-responsive headlights. Blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert is standard on the 2.0T trim. A rearview camera is standard on all trims and the surround view camera system is optional.</p>

<p>The Santa Fe Sport offers 35.4 cubic feet of cargo space behind the rear seats and 71.5 cubic feet with the seats down. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/edge/2018/">Ford Edge</a> offers a bit more with 39.2 and 73.4 cubic feet, respectively. Front seat passengers have 41.3 inches of legroom and rear seat passengers make due with 39.4 inches.</p>

<p>The Santa Fe Sport’s standard six-speaker audio system also includes a 5.0-inch center touchscreen, Bluetooth, a USB port and an audio jack. The upgraded system comes with a 7.0-inch center touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Andriod Auto, HD Radio, SiriusXM satellite radio, and Blue Link connected car system. The top system features an 8.0-inch touchscreen with navigation and an Infinity premium audio system. The Blue Link system offers the Connected Care package (SOS emergency assistance, automatic collision notice, maintenance reminder and more), the Remote package (remote start, remote lock/unlock doors, car finder, stolen vehicle recovery and more), and the Guidance package supplements the navigation system.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/santa-fe-sport/2018/2018-hyundai-santa-fe-sport-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/santa-fe-sport/2018/">2018 Hyundai Santa Fe Sport</a> base FWD model and AWD Ultimate model, we preferred the 2.0-liter turbo-four engine over the naturally aspirated 2.4-liter (even though the 2.4-liter in the base model was slightly quicker), “Of the two variants, the all-wheel drive with the 2.0-liter turbo was by far the better to drive. The rear wheel traction helped to keep the car steadier on the entry into corners and pushed it out on the exits, keeping the safety nannies from intervening.”</p>

<p>The AWD system did a good job off-road but the FWD model, of course, struggled off-road. The interior received a lot of praise, “For a base model, the Santa Fe is surprisingly nice to look at. I like the color and the interplay of different materials and textures in the interior. The materials are obviously less expensive, and the light brown parts look pretty cheap, but at the price point, it’s not bad.”</p>

<p>We concluded by saying, “All in all, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/santa-fe-sport/2018/">Hyundai Santa Fe Sport</a> is a great car for its value. Whether it’s a $26,000 model or a more-equipped trim, the Santa Fe Sport does its job fine. We’d still like to see a better suspension and a more powerful drivetrain that brings more emotion to the driver.”</p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/hyundai-santa-fe-sport-2018-suv-of-the-year-contender/">2018 <em>Motor Trend </em>SUV of the Year testing</a>, the Santa Fe Sport did not become a finalist but we liked the interior of the base model and preferred the 2.0-liter turbo-four equipped model for its better driving dynamics. Although, the Santa Fe Sport got dinged for its ride that felt “both floaty and flinty” and for excessive NVH. “It’s a thoughtfully designed, well-executed SUV that lacks excitement. It’s anonymous and anodyne but strong on value.” Although it serves its purpose well, it’s not good enough to be SUV of the Year,” we concluded.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/">Hyundai</a> gives the 2018 Santa Fe more comfort and convenience with the new Value package. Leather-equipped models now have premium wood finish trim and Blue Link now includes all services standard for three years.</p>

<p>The Santa Fe is the largest crossover from Hyundai, slotting above the subcompact Kona, compact Tucson, and two-row Santa Fe Sport.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Santa Fe SE</strong>: The Santa Fe’s base trim comes equipped with seven-passenger seating, 19-inch wheels, dual-zone automatic climate control, eight-way power driver’s seat, LED daytime running lights, powered and heated side view mirrors, roof rails, rear seat vents, a 7.0-inch center touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, HD radio, SiriusXM satellite radio, and Blue Link Connected Care and Remote packages.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Santa Fe Ultimate</strong>: The Ultimate comes well-equipped and adds 19-inch wheels, leather seating, a panoramic sunroof, a multi-view camera system, LED fog lights, rear parking sensors, hands-free liftgate, blind spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, lane change assist, heated steering wheel, heated front and rear seats, ventilated front seats, a 115-volt power outlet, four-way power passenger seat,  an LCD instrument panel driver’s display, manual rear side sunshades, a larger 8.0-inch center touchscreen with navigation and Blue Link Guidance, and an Infinity premium audio system.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Santa Fe Limited Ultimate</strong>: Building off the Santa Fe Ultimate’s features, the Limited Ultimate adds 19-inch wheels, steering-responsive HID headlights, LED taillights, and six-passenger seating with second-row captain’s chairs.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/santa-fe/2018/">2018 Hyundai Santa Fe</a> is powered by a 3.3-liter V-6 that produces 290 hp and 252 lb-ft of torque and is backed by a six-speed automatic transmission that routes power to a front-drive system (EPA-rated 18/25 mpg city/highway) or an all-wheel drive system (18/24 mpg). The heavier Ultimate model is rated at a slightly less 17/23 mpg with FWD and 17/22 mpg with AWD. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 Santa Fe Limited Ultimate hit 60 mph in a respectable 7.3 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 125 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/santa-fe/2018/">Hyundai Santa Fe</a> received the highest five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA. The Santa Fe is considered a 2018 Top Safety Pick+ because the crossover received the highest rating of Good in five crash tests and the second-highest rating of Acceptable for the new passenger-side small overlap front crash test. The highest designation was also issued because the Santa Fe received the highest rating of Good for the headlights evaluation and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention test for avoiding both a 12- and 25-mph collision thanks to the emergency automatic braking with pedestrian detection feature found in the Tech package that is optional on the Ultimate and Limited Ultimate trims. The Tech package also consists of adaptive cruise control with stop/go, lane departure warning, an electronic parking brake, HID lights with steering-responsive headlights, and high beam assist. Blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, lane change assist, and a multi-view camera system are standard on the Ultimate trim. A rearview camera is standard on all trims.</p>

<p>Behind the third row, you can fit up to 13.5 cubic feet of cargo room in the Santa Fe, 40.9 cubic feet with the third row folded down, and 80.0 cubic feet with both rows folded down. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/pilot/2018/">Honda Pilot</a> offers more with up to 16.5, 46.8, and 83.9 cubic feet, respectively. Front seat passengers get 41.3 inches of legroom, second-row occupants have 40.4 inches, and the third row offers a tighter 30.9 inches.</p>

<p>The 2018 Santa Fe comes standard with lots of tech including a 7.0-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, HD radio, SiriusXM satellite radio, and Blue Link Connected Care and Remote packages. The Ultimate trim adds a larger 8.0-inch screen with navigation and Blue Link Guidance, a multi-view camera system, a hands-free liftgate, a 115-volt power outlet, and an Infinity premium audio system. The Limited Ultimate adds steering-responsive HID headlights. The Santa Fe also offers a host of driver assist safety features. The Blue Link Connected Car package offers services like automatic collision notification, SOS emergency assistance, and roadside assistance. The Remote package uses an app that can remote start your car, lock/unlock doors, honk the horn, find your vehicle in a parking lot, and several other services.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/santa-fe/2017/2017-hyundai-santa-fe-limited-ultimate-fwd-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 Hyundai Santa Fe Limited Ultimate, we appreciated the decent acceleration, handling, and braking when tested at the track. However, we didn’t care for the slow throttle response, slow steering, and unpleasant ride over road imperfections. Rear seat room is good and the rear seats have their own A/C control and vents. The interior offers lots of luxury but is showing its age. As for fun driving dynamics, “buyers might want to look at the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/durango/2018/">Dodge Durango</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/explorer/2018/">Ford Explorer</a> EcoBoost, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-9/2018/">Mazda CX-9</a>.” We concluded by saying, “For features and value, the Santa Fe is a pretty good bet. Some competitors offer a rear seat entertainment system but the Santa Fe hits all the most important notes and more.”</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/kona/2018/">2018 Hyundai Kona</a> is an all-new subcompact crossover, slotting below larger Tucson.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/kona/2018/">Hyundai Kona</a> is a subcompact crossover that slots below the Tucson as the automaker’s new entry-level crossover. Front-wheel drive come standard and all-wheel drive is optional on all trims.</p>

<p><strong>Kona SE: </strong>The base Kona SE comes with 16-inch alloy wheels, a rearview camera, full LED headlights, Bluetooth, a six-speaker audio system, cloth uphosltery, keyless entry, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, as well as Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration.</p>

<p><strong>Kona SEL: </strong>Moving up to the SEL grade adds heated side mirrors, 17-inch alloy wheels, blind-spot monitoring, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, heated front seats, keyless start, and a leather shift knob.</p>

<p><strong>Kona Limited: </strong>The Limited trim adds the 1.6-liter turbo-four, a power-operated driver’s seat, a sunroof, 18-inch alloy wheels and LED taillights.</p>

<p><strong>Kona Ultimate: </strong>Opt for the range-topping Ultimate trim and you get rain-sensing wipers, a head-up display, a wireless charging pad, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, an Infinity premium audio system, and navigation.</p>

<p>Key options and features include a lime green exterior that’s paired with a black interior with lime green accents, a dual-level cargo area, and a multilink rear suspension for all-wheel-drive variants.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/">Hyundai</a> Kona is available with two engines, 2.0-liter I-4 with 147 hp and 132 lb-ft of torque and paired to a six-speed automatic transmission. A 1.6-liter turbo-four rated at 175 hp and 195 lb-ft is optional and comes exclusively with a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission.</p>

<p>The Kona is EPA-rated at 27/33 mpg city/highway with the base engine and front-wheel drive, or 25/30 mpg with all-wheel drive. Upgrade to the turbo-four and fuel economy is 28/32 mpg with front-wheel drive or 26/29 mpg with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p>Active safety tech such as forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, pedestrian detection, lane keeping assist, driver attention assist, automatic high beams, blind-spot monitoring, and rear cross-traffic alert are available on the SEL and Limited trims.</p>

<p>Behind the split-folding rear seats, there’s 19.2 cubic feet of cargo space that can be expanded to 45.8 cubic feet. The 2018 Hyundai Kona is not rated for towing.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/kona/2018/2018-hyundai-kona-quick-drive-review/">2018 Quick Drive</a> we said that the Kona’s steering was on the heavy side while the suspension did a good job dealing with uneven surfaces. The optional 1.6-liter turbo-four offers plenty of power thanks to its wide powerband.</p>

<p>The optional 175-hp 1.6-liter turbo-four in the 2018 Kona is shared with the larger Tucson.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">A new variant, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/ioniq/2018/">Hyundai Ioniq</a> Pug-In, joins the electrified lineup for the new model year. The Ioniq Electric and Hybrid are carryover models. Paddle shifters are now standard on the plug-in model and available on the hybrid Lane Departure Warning adds the Lane Keep Assist function.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/">Hyundai</a> Ioniq is a hatchback that offers a traditional hybrid, plug-in electric hybrid, and battery electric variants.</strong> The hybrid model is the most affordable of the three, with a starting price similar to the midsize Sonata sedan and compact Tucson crossover.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/ioniq/2018/">2018 Hyundai Ioniq</a> Hybrid is powered by a 1.6-liter I-4 paired to a 32kW electric motor for a total system output of 139 hp and delivers an impressive EPA-rated 57/59 mpg city/highway for the base Blue model and 55/54 mpg for the rest of the lineup (2017 figures). The Ioniq Plug-In uses the same 1.6-liter engine but paired to a larger 45kW electric motor with an estimated total output of 156 hp. The EPA has yet to rate the plug-in model. The hybrid and plug-in models send power to the front wheels through a six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">A 118-hp, 215-lb-ft of torque 88kW electric motor powers the Ioniq Electric and comes with an EPA-rated driving range of 124 miles. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the Ioniq Hybrid hit 60 mph in 9.4 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 124 feet, expected numbers from a hybrid vehicle.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">The range-topping Hyundai Ioniq Limited comes with 17-inch alloy wheels, power moonroof, heated front leather seats, HID headlights with LED accents, LED interior illumination, LED taillights, a 7.0-inch center touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a 7.0-inch driver’s display screen, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, and Blue Link Telematics, Connected Care, and Remote Charge Access. The Ioniq Electric Limited comes standard with heated leather front seats, a powered driver’s seat, LED headlights, 16-inch eco-spoke wheels, 7.0-inch center touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a 7.0-inch driver’s display screen, power-folding side mirrors with puddle lamps, rear seat air vents, leather-wrapped steering wheel, and Blue Link Telematics, Connected, Remote Package, and Remote Charge Access.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>All of the driver assist safety features for the Ioniq lineup are included in the Ultimate package for the Limited trim and include automatic emergency braking, adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, headlights with Dynamic Bending Light (HIDs on the Electric model), and rear parking sensors. If you don’t get the Limited trim, the Tech package for the SEL trim includes automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning, and adaptive cruise control. The SEL trim on the Hybrid model comes standard with blind-spot warning and rear-cross traffic alert as does the Limited trim on the Electric model.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>After a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/ioniq/2017/2017-hyundai-ioniq-hybrid-and-ev-first-test-review/">First Test</a> review of the 2017 Hyundai Ioniq Hybrid and Electric, we liked the amazing fuel economy of the Ioniq Hybrid (the best in the market), but we weren’t sure about the short 124-mile driving range of the Electric model. We also felt that the interior and exterior designs were very conservative. We concluded by noting that “Hyundai is obviously playing it safe with the Ioniq’s styling—a good or bad thing, depending on how your eyes react to the Prius. … Dimensionally it’s Prius-like, too. It’s 2.7 inches shorter and 2.4 inches wider and has a bit more passenger and cargo space. And most obviously, it’s clearly hell-bent on beating the Prius’s mileage numbers—to such a degree that the racket from the Ioniq’s low rolling resistance tires was a noticeable issue. But unlike the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a> Insight, which was blind-focused on a strategy of being not quite a Prius at not quite the cost, Hyundai is asking us to see the Ioniq as a very good car that just happens to be a deal, delivers ridiculous mileage, and is fun to drive. If you compare it to a Prius, well, that’s good, too.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/bolt-ev/2017/hyundai-ioniq-hybrid-vs-toyota-prius-chevrolet-volt-vs-prius-prime-bolt-ev-vs-ioniq-ev-vs-honda-clarity-vs-mirai/">2017 Hyundai Ioniq Hybrid and 2016 Toyota Prius comparison</a>, the Prius was the victor: “Since the fourth-generation Prius transitioned to <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a>’s dynamic new TNGA platform, it doesn’t really drive ‘like a Prius’ anymore. But Toyota doubled down on a design personality that—even if you hate it—will never bore you. Hyundai’s rookie effort has had a good first round against the champ, but it hasn’t landed enough blows yet for a dethroning. Our pick? Still the Prius.”</p>

<p>When we compared the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/bolt-ev/2017/hyundai-ioniq-hybrid-vs-toyota-prius-chevrolet-volt-vs-prius-prime-bolt-ev-vs-ioniq-ev-vs-honda-clarity-vs-mirai/">2017 Chevrolet Bolt EV and the 2017 Hyundai Ioniq Electric</a>, the Bolt EV won: “The Bolt EV’s advantages go beyond range, though. Unlike the Volt, our 2017 Car of the Year is brilliantly packaged. With the battery mostly beneath the floor, there’s space in spades for people and cargo, and the slightly elevated seat heights are great for outward vision in our SUV-infested world. The low center of gravity gives it planted handling. (Unlike its hybrid version, the Ioniq’s aft-battery and simpler twist-beam rear suspension impart an occasional tail wiggle.)”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Hyundai claims that the Ioniq Plug-In can run on all-electric power for up to 27 miles and has a total driving range of more than 650 miles.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The new Elantra GT hatchback joins the lineup for 2018 and a new SEL trim replaces the former SE with Popular Equipment trim. The Limited trim adds gloss black interior accents and an auto-dimming rearview mirror with Blue Link and HomeLink. The Sport trim receives a power sunroof and blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert and all trims receive a new exterior color, Machine Gray.</p>

<p>The Elantra sedan slots in the middle of <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/">Hyundai</a>’s sedan lineup, above the smaller Accent and below the larger Sonata (the Azera has been discontinued for 2018). The Elantra GT is Hyundai’s only non-hybrid hatchback offering besides the Veloster, which skipped the 2018 model year—read about the redesigned <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/veloster/2019/2019-hyundai-veloster-first-look-review/">2019 Veloster here</a>.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Elantra SE</strong>: The base SE trim comes standard with a 2.0-liter I-4, 15-inch steel wheels, power side view mirrors, six-way manual adjustable front seats, tilt and telescoping steering wheel, a four-speaker audio system with Bluetooth, a USB port, Blue Link features free for three years, and a 3.5-inch instrument panel driver’s display.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Elantra SEL</strong>: The SEL trims adds 16-inch alloy wheels, a 7.0-inch display screen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, Sirius XM satellite radio, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert and lane change assist, dual-zone automatic climate control, a hands-free <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/smart/">smart</a> trunk that pops open if you stand behind the car for a few seconds with the key fob in your pocket, a rearview camera, heated side view mirrors, automatic headlights, and a quick entry system with push-start ignition.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Elantra Value Edition</strong>: The Value Edition adds more features including a power sunroof, LED daytime running lights, an auto-dimming rearview mirror, heated front seats, door handle approach lights, and a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Elantra Eco</strong>: The Eco model offers the same features as the Value Edition model but rides on 15-inch alloy wheels and is powered by a more fuel-efficient 1.4-liter turbo-four that’s mated to a seven-speed dual-clutch transmission.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Elantra Sport</strong>: The Sport model adds more power with a 1.6-liter turbo-four engine and adds sport-inspired features such as 18-inch alloy wheels, an independent rear suspension, larger front brakes, sport-tuned suspension, HID headlights, LED taillights, sport front seats with leather seating surfaces, a flat-bottom leather-wrapped sport steering wheel, and a sport front grille, front fascia, rear fascia, and side sill extensions.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Elantra Limited</strong>: The Elantra Limited is powered by the 2.0-liter I-4 and adds more luxury including unique 17-inch alloy wheels, leather seating, six-way power driver’s seat (passenger stays manual), steering-responsive HID headlights, Blue Link Connected Car and Remote services, chrome beltline molding, unique chrome grille, two USB ports, and gloss black interior accents.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Elantra GT</strong>: The GT hatchback is powered by the 2.0-liter I-4 and features 17-inch alloy wheels, an 8.0-inch center display with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a rear spoiler, heated side view mirrors, cloth seating, a 3.5-inch instrument panel driver’s display, automatic headlights, an auto-dimming rearview mirror, and a cargo area cover.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Elantra GT Sport</strong>: The range-topping GT Sport adds sportiness and luxury with a more powerful 1.6-liter turbo-four, 18-inch alloy wheels, an independent suspension, larger front brakes, full-LED headlights LED taillights, a quick entry system with push-start ignition, a 4.2-inch instrument panel driver’s display, leather seating, heated front seats, alloy pedals, and rear A/C vents.</p>

<p>The base 2.0-liter I-4 engine produces 147 hp and 132 lb-ft of torque and delivers an EPA-rated 26/36 mpg city/highway with the six-speed manual and 28/37 mpg with the six-speed automatic in the sedan (29/38 mpg in the base SE trim). In the Elantra GT, that engine delivers 23/31 mpg with the manual and 24/32 mpg with the automatic. The Elantra Eco produces 128 hp and 156 lb-ft from its 1.4-liter turbo-four that comes mated to a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic and delivers a lineup-best 32/40 mpg. The 1.6-liter turbo-four in the Sport model is rated at 22/30 mpg with the six-speed manual and 26/33 mpg with the seven-speed dual-clutch automatic in the sedan. When equipped in the Elantra GT Sport, that engine delivers 22/29 mpg with the manual and 26/32 mpg with the automatic. All models are front-wheel drive.</p>

<p>In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 Elantra Limited hit 60 mph in 8.9 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 117 feet. The Elantra GT Sport (manual) had a 0-60 time of 7.2 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 118 feet.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/elantra/2018/">2018 Hyundai Elantra</a> sedan and GT hatchback both received a four-star overall safety rating out of five stars from the NHTSA. The 2018 Elantra sedan and GT hatchback are considered 2018 Top Safety Picks from the IIHS for receiving the highest rating of Good in all conducted crash tests and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention test for avoiding a 12-mph collision and reducing the speed of a 25-mph collision by 22 mph thanks to the automatic emergency braking system with pedestrian detection found in the Ultimate package. That package is available on the Limited trim for the sedan and in the Tech package for the GT Sport hatchback.</p>

<p>Additional safety features in the sedan’s Ultimate package include forward collision warning, adaptive cruise control, lane keep assist, and automatic high beams. Additional safety features in the hatchback’s Tech package include adaptive cruise control with stop/start capability, forward collision warning, lane keep assist, high beam assist and a driver attention alert system. Blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert and lane change assist become standard on the SEL sedan trim and on the GT Sport trim. The base SE trim is the only one without a rearview camera. The Connected Care package in the Blue Link system includes automatic collision notification, SOS emergency assistance, and roadside assistance.</p>

<p>The 2018 Elantra sedan can hold 14.4 cubic feet of cargo in its trunk while the GT hatchback can hold up to 24.9 cubic feet with the rear seats up and 55.1 with the rear seats down. Front seat passengers have 42.2 inches of legroom in both body styles but the sedan’s rear seats offer 35.7 inches, more than the GT’s 34.8 inches.</p>

<p>The base SE trim for the sedan comes with a four-speaker radio system with Bluetooth. Upgrade to the SEL trim and you’ll get a six-speaker audio system with a 7.0-inch center display, Apple CarPlay, Android Auto, and SiriusXM satellite radio. The top system—available on the Ultimate package for the Limited sedan—adds a larger 8.0-inch screen, a navigation system with SiriusXM Data services, and an eight-speaker Infinity audio system with Clari-fi music restoration technology, and two USB ports. That package also includes the upgraded 4.2-inch instrument panel driver’s display (up from 3.5 inches). The Elantra GT hatchback comes well-equipped with an 8.0-inch center display with Apple CarPlay, Android Auto, and SiriusXM satellite radio. A navigation system with a seven-speaker Infinity premium audio system with Clari-fi music restoration is available on both GT trims. The available Blue Link packages include the Connected Care package (automatic collision notification, diagnostic report, roadside assistance, and other services), the Remote package (the remote app can honk the horn, turn on/off lights, find your car, remote start with climate control, and more), and the Guidance package that supplements the navigation system.</p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/hyundai-elantra-gt-2018-car-of-the-year-contender/">2018 Motor Trend Car of the Year testing</a>, the 2018 Elantra GT Sport hatchback did not make the finalist cut due to the lack of a limited-slip differential, some cheap interior components, and a tight rear seat. However, we liked the GT Sport’s fun-to-drive factor, solid handling dynamics, and the fact that Sport actually means something—more power, bigger brakes, and an independent rear suspension. Some judges preferred it over the new Civic Si and one judge called it “a genuine Golf GTI-lite.” We concluded by saying that “the Elantra GT Sport is the perfect car for someone who wants something more fun than your run-of-the-mill compact but without the compromises of a straight-up hot hatch.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/elantra/2017/2017-hyundai-elantra-sport-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/elantra/2018/">Hyundai Elantra</a> Sport sedan, we enjoyed the improved acceleration over the regular Elantra but not as much as the improved handling dynamics thanks to the rear independent suspension: “Testing director Kim Reynolds … found that you can drift it slightly by lifting your foot off the throttle. Reynolds concluded that the Elantra Sport’s balance is its best attribute and said that no one attribute stands out ahead of the others.”</p>

<p>On the road, the Elantra Sport handles very well when pushed through the corners with “plenty of grip and minimal body roll, allowing you to confidently string corners and maintain your momentum.” The brakes have a good feel, the ride is comfortable, and steering is a big improvement but feels artificially heavy sometimes. The engine power trails off at high rpm but it provides plenty of low-end torque and the shifter is “…smooth and precise with reasonably short throws, and [has] a clutch that’s light and easy to predict.”</p>

<p>[The Elantra Sport] is a well-balanced car with a nice blend of power, agility, and comfort so you can easily drive it during the week and take it to an autocross over the weekend,” we concluded. “Sure, a limited-slip differential and stronger brakes would be nice, but even without them the Elantra Sport is able to put its power down effectively and scrub off speed quickly when needed.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2016/2016-2017-big-test-compact-sedans/">2016/2017 Big Test review</a> of seven compact sedans, the Elantra Limited did well, placing third. Although we didn’t like the sedan’s ride, steering feel, handling dynamics, and coarse powertrain, the Elantra made up for it with its impressive infotainment system, good value, and premium presentation. We concluded by saying: “Third place goes to the premium presentation from Hyundai. Despite still having the industry’s best warranty, the Elantra’s value proposition has waned. ‘The visuals promise,’ we said, ‘but the mechanicals don’t quite deliver on that promise.’”</p>

<p>The refreshed <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata-hybrid/2018/2018-hyundai-sonata-hybrid-plug-in-hybrid-first-look-review/">2018 </a><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/">Hyundai</a> <strong>Sonata Hybrid</strong> and its <strong>Plug-In Hybrid</strong> variant get a revised exterior featuring the same new front fascia found in the gas-only car and a recalibrated steering system. Suspension updates include a stiffer front anti-roll bar, a more rigid trailing arm design, and retuned bushings. Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert are now standard on all models. All variants get 16- or 17-inch alloy wheels with new designs. There are also a host of new optional features including full LED headlights and an updated navigation system.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata/2018/">2018 Hyundai Sonata</a> Hybrid and Plug-in Hybrid is a family of midsize hybrid sedans that slot above the smaller, more efficient Ioniq hatchback. It’s available in two trims.</p>

<p><strong>Sonata Hybrid SE: </strong>The base SE trim comes with features like Bluetooth, a rearview camera, 16-inch alloy wheels, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay, and keyless entry and start.</p>

<p><strong>Sonata Hybrid Limited: </strong>Moving up to the Limited grade adds features such as heated and ventilated front seats, 17-inch alloy wheels, leather upholstery, LED headlights, and power-adjustable front seats.</p>

<p><strong>Sonata Plug-In Hybrid: </strong>The base Sonata Plug-In Hybrid comes standard with 17-inch alloy wheels, keyless entry/start, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay, dual-zone climate control, heated front seats, Bluetooth, a rearview camera, and the hands-free <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/smart/">smart</a> trunk.</p>

<p><strong>Sonata Plug-In Hybrid Limited: </strong>The range-topping Sonata Plug-In Hybrid Limited adds an Infinity premium audio system, ventilated front seats, rear parking sensors, and leather upholstery.</p>

<p>Optional features on the 2018 Sonata Hybrid include LED headlights, wireless phone charging, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, and a heated steering wheel.</p>

<p>The 2018 Sonata Hybrid and Plug-In Hybrid are powered by a hybrid system that couples a 154-hp 2.0-liter I-4 with 140 lb-ft of torque to an electric motor, lithium-ion battery and a six-speed automatic transmission. In the standard hybrid, the electric motor generates 51 hp and 151 lb-ft while the the Plug-In Hybrid features a more powerful 67-hp unit. Total output for the 2018 Sonata Hybrid and Plug-In Hybrid is 193 hp and 202 hp respectively. Charging times for the Plug-In Hybrid from empty are 8.7 hours on a level 1 charger (household outlet) or 2.7 hours on a level 2 public charger.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy estimates for the 2018 Sonata Hybrid are 40/46 mpg city/highway for the SE trim and 39/44 mpg for the Limited. The Sonata Plug-In Hybrid can travel up to an estimated 27 miles in EV mode.</p>

<p>The 2018 Sonata Hybrid received a five-star overall rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). Plug-in hybrid variants haven’t been rated yet. Both the 2018 Sonata Hybrid and Plug-In Hybrid haven’t been tested by the IIHS but the gas-only variant received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests and the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>In the IIHS front crash prevention test, the gas-only 2018 Sonata received a Superior rating after it avoided collisions in 12- and 25-mph tests (Superior is the highest rating for the front crash prevention test). As a result of its excellent crash test and collision avoidance scores, the gas-only 2018 Sonata received the IIHS’ 2018 Top Safety Pick+ rating.</p>

<p>Available active driver assistance features include forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, lane keeping assist, auto high beams and adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p>The 2018 Sonata Hybrid only has 13.3 cubic feet of trunk space (compared to the gas-only Sonata’s 16.3 cubic feet) but it can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.  Plug-In Hybrid variants have even less cargo capacity at 9.9 cubic feet and it loses the split-folding rear seats because of the larger battery.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata-hybrid/2016/2016-hyundai-sonata-hybrid-first-test/">2016 First Test</a> of the Sonata <strong>Hybrid</strong>, we said that it offers good power and has smooth ride thanks to a suspension that soaks up bump well. However, on rough surfaces, excessive road noise penetrates the interior. As for the interior’s build quality, it has plenty of soft-touch materials throughout the cabin. Passenger space is generous for four thanks to the roomy rear seats.</p>

<p>The <strong>plug-in hybrid</strong> offers quicker acceleration thanks to the more powerful electric motor. We also noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata-plug-in/2016/2016-hyundai-sonata-plug-hybrid-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a> that ride comfort is a strong point, making the Sonata Plug-in a great road trip car (as long as you don’t have too much luggage). As with most Hyundai vehicles, the Sonata plug-in’s multimedia system is user-friendly. Handling is secure, but since the Sonata plug-in is more of a cruiser, it’s not very engaging to drive.</p>

<p>The Sonata receives an extensive refresh for the new model year including a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/hyundai-sonata-gets-eight-speed-auto-cascading-grille/">new eight-speed automatic, “cascading” grille</a>, narrower headlights and taillights, a new hood, front fenders, a larger trunk lid, new wheel designs, available LED headlights, and a new rear fascia. Inside, the center stack and steering wheel have been redesigned, and the 2.0T model differentiates itself from the rest of the lineup with a mesh grille, black bezel headlights, a black lower front bumper, black DRL surrounds, dark chrome exterior trim, and chrome on the rear diffuser. Blind-spot monitoring and rear-cross traffic alert are now standard on all trims.</p>

<p>The Sonata is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/">Hyundai</a>’s midsize sedan that’s positioned above the smaller Accent and Elantra, but below the larger Azera. Aside from a choice of gas engines, the Sonata will continue to be offered as a</p>

<p><strong>2018 Sonata SE</strong>: The Sonata’s base SE trim comes well-equipped with 16-inch alloy wheels, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert and lane change assist, a 7.0-inch center touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, Bluetooth, a 3.5-inch instrument panel driver’s display, automatic headlights, a drive mode selector, remote keyless entry, six-way manually adjustable driver’s seat, as well as USB and auxiliary ports.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Sonata Eco</strong>: The Eco trim comes with the same equipment as the SE trim (minus the drive mode selector) but adds the more efficient 1.6-liter turbo-four and seven-speed dual-clutch transmission powertrain instead of the 2.4-liter I-4 engine.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Sonata SEL</strong>: Building off the SE’s features, the SEL adds 17-inch alloy wheels, a 10-way power driver’s seat, quick-entry with a push-start ignition, heated front seats, LED daytime running lights, heated side view mirrors, a hands-free automatic trunk, a 4.2-inch instrument panel driver’s display,  leather-wrapped steering wheel, leatherette door panel inserts, SiriusXM satellite radio, a rear USB port, and the Blue Link telematics system with Connected Care and Remote packages.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Sonata Sport</strong>: The Sport trim adds a Sport grille, front fascia, rear diffuser, shift knob, seats, rocker panels, and instrument cluster. The Sport also adds a leather-wrapped D-shaped steering wheel, glossy trim, black headliner, aluminum pedals, the 3D tech appearance interior trim, dark chrome doors handles, LED interior lights, power sunroof, and a dual exhaust.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Sonata Limited</strong>: The Limited adds more luxury with leather upholstery, heated and ventilated front seats, steering-responsive LED headlights, power sunroof, LED taillights, six-way power passenger’s seat, wood grain appearance interior trim, dual automatic climate control, rear A/C vents, auto-dimming rearview mirror, and metal door sills.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Sonata Sport 2.0T</strong>: Building off the Sonata Sport’s features, the Sport 2.0T adds the more powerful 2.0-liter turbo-four engine and new eight-speed automatic, 18-inch alloy wheels with Michelin tires, a sport-tuned suspension, and larger front brakes.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Sonata Limited 2.0T</strong>: Building off the Limited’s trim, the Limited 2.0T adds the 2.0-liter turbo-four powertrain, automatic emergency braking, lane keep assist, adaptive cruise control with start/stop, an 8.0-inch center touchscreen with navigation (with Blue Link Guidance), an Infinity premium audio system, automatic high beams, rear parking sensors, electronic parking brake with automatic vehicle hold, leather upholstery, a heated steering wheel, SiriusXM Travel Link, and wireless device charging.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata/2018/">2018 Hyundai Sonata</a> is powered by a 185-hp, 178-lb-ft of torque 2.4-liter I-4 that delivers an EPA-rated 25/36 mpg city/highway on the base SE model and 25/35 mpg on the other trims. The 178-hp, 195-lb-ft 1.6-liter turbo-four found in the Sonata Eco model delivers the best fuel economy in the lineup at 28/37 mpg. The 245-hp, 260-lb-ft 2.0-liter turbo-four that powers the 2.0T model is rated at 23/32 mpg. A six-speed automatic routes power to the front wheels on the 2.4-liter engine, but a new eight-speed automatic backs the 2.0-liter turbo-four engine option this year. A more efficient seven-speed dual-clutch automatic is used on the Eco’s 1.6-liter turbo-four. The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata-hybrid/">Sonata hybrid and plug-in hybrid</a> models sport a 154-hp 2.0-liter I-4 engine paired to a 51-hp and 67-hp electric motor, respectively. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2018 Sonata 2.0T Limited hit 60 mph in 7.1 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a short 113 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata/2018/">Hyundai Sonata</a> received the highest five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA. The 2018 Sonata is also considered a 2018 Top Safety Pick+ from the IIHS because the sedan received the highest rating of Good in all six crash tests, Good for the headlights evaluation, and the highest rating of Superior for front crash prevention test by avoiding 12- and 25-mph frontal collisions thanks to the automatic emergency braking feature in the Tech and Ultimate packages  that also adds adaptive cruise control with start/stop, lane keep assist, and an electronic parking brake. The Ultimate package adds automatic high beams, rear parking sensors, and other comfort and entertainment features. The 2018 Sonata comes standard with blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert and lane change assist. Steering-responsive headlights are standard on the Limited trims.</p>

<p>The Sonata can carry up to 16.3 cubic feet of cargo in the trunk and offers 45.5 inches of front seat legroom and 35.6 inches of rear seat legroom. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/altima/2018/">Nissan Altima</a> offers slightly less cargo room at 15.4 cubic feet but the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/accord/2018/">Honda Accord</a> edges them both out, with 16.7 cubic feet.</p>

<p>The standard 7.0-inch touchscreen with Bluetooth as well as Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration can be upgraded to an 8.0-inch touchscreen with a navigation system in the Limited trims. The 3.5-inch non-color instrument panel driver’s display found in the base SE trim becomes a 4.2-inch color display in the other trims. The standard six-speaker audio system is upgradable to the eight-speaker Infinity audio system but only in the Limited trims. One USB port is standard but a second one for the rear seats is optional, as is the wireless device charger. The Blue Link system offers the Connected Care package (SOS emergency assistance, automatic collision notice, maintenance reminder and more), the Remote package (remote start, remote lock/unlock, car finder, stolen vehicle recovery and more), and the Guidance package that supplements the Sonata’s navigation system.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata/2018/2018-hyundai-sonata-20t-limited-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2018 Hyundai Sonata Limited 2.0T, we liked the improved acceleration over the outgoing model but the Sonata is still slower than comparable rivals. Braking feel was praised during testing and the car felt nimble around the figure-eight handling course. The Sonata handles very well, the steering is much improved and feels more precise, and the eight-speed automatic is smooth. During Real MPG testing, the Sonata returned results higher than the EPA, 28.9 mpg combined driving, an impressive figure.</p>

<p>“In our eyes, the Sonata is not the top competitor in its segment. But once again, the Sonata stands apart because it offers great value for the money, a particularly impressive feat once you get to the top trim level. With improved acceleration and driving dynamics, as trite as it sounds, the Sonata is a good pick in a segment filled with many good options,” we concluded.</p>

<p>During our , we felt the 2.4-liter engine had plenty of power for around-town driving and the six-speed automatic was smooth. We found the Sonata’s ride to be comfortable and appreciated the interior’s high-quality materials, spaciousness, and good outward visibility.</p>

<p>“Although the 2018 Sonata is only a refreshed model, ” we wrote, “it builds on the seventh-generation car by adding a more distinctive exterior and an interior that feels more upscale, especially on higher trim levels. Now offering better driving dynamics, the 2018 Sonata is ready to compete with the redesigned <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/camry/2018/">2018 Toyota Camry</a> and the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/accord/2018/">2018 Honda Accord</a>. As a whole, the 2018 Sonata is a better midsize sedan that offers user-friendly tech, space, and comfort wrapped in an attractive, high-value package, especially considering that the base car’s sticker price only increased by $100.</p>

<p><strong> </strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>With the exception of revised model naming (all non-hybrid models now include the word Luxe), new package naming, and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/">Infiniti</a> InTouch single display now standard, the Q70 and Q70L are unchanged.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The Q70 and Q70L are Infiniti’s flagships sedans positioned above the Q50 sedan and Q60 coupe. The Q70L has the second highest starting price in the automaker’s entire lineup, after the full-size QX80 SUV.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/q70/2018/">2018 Infiniti Q70</a> 3.7 and Q70L 3.7 are powered by a 3.7-liter V-6 that produces 330 hp and 270 lb-ft of torque and comes with an EPA-rating of 18/25 mpg city/highway with rear-wheel drive and 18/24 mpg with AWD. The available 5.6-liter V-8 found in the Q70 5.6 churns out 420 hp and 417 lb-ft (416 hp, 414 lb-ft for the Q70L) and is rated at 16/24 mpg with rear-wheel drive and 16/23 mpg with AWD. The Q70 Hybrid utilizes a 302-hp, 258 lb-ft 3.5-liter V-6 paired to 67-hp, 214-lb-ft electric motor for a total combined output of 360 hp. The Hybrid is only available in rear-wheel drive and delivers 28/33 mpg. All engines are backed by a seven-speed automatic.</p>

<p>The Q70 comes standard with 18-inch wheels, LED fog lights and taillights, power sliding moonroof, leatherette upholstery, 10-way power adjustable heated front seats, a sequential welcome lighting illuminated entry system, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, genuine Japanese Ash wood interior accents, active noise cancellation, a 7.0-inch center display screen, Enhanced Intelligent Key memory settings, and an Infiniti analog clock.</p>

<p>For additional luxury, opt for the Premium package that includes Infiniti Navigation, an multi-camera parking system with Moving Object Detection, front and rear parking sensors, a Bose 10-speaker premium audio system, leather upholstery, heated and ventilated front seats, and a heated steering wheel. The Premium Select Edition package consists of Dark Chrome exterior trim, darkened lower rear bumper, rear spoiler, 20-inch wheels, suede-like headliner, aluminum interior trim, semi-aniline leather seating, contrast piping floor mats, illuminated door sills, and sport brakes.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA has yet to conduct its full array of crash evaluations, but 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/q70/2018/">Infiniti Q70</a> did received four out of five stars for the frontal and rollover crash tests. The 2017 Infiniti Q70 is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick from the IIHS because the sedan received the highest rating of Good in all five crash tests and the highest rating of superior for front crash prevention. The Superior rating was issued because the sedan properly warned the driver of a possible collision, avoided a 12 mph collision, and reduced a 25 mph collision by 22 mph thanks to the Forward Emergency Braking system found in the Technology package. The Technology package also includes the remaining driver assist features – blind spot warning, blind spot intervention, Intelligent Cruise Control (adaptive), forward collision warning, lane departure warning, lane departure prevention, and back-up collision intervention.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/le-cabriolet/2015/2015-infiniti-q70s-56-first-drive/">First Drive review</a> of the standard- and long-wheelbase versions of the 2015 Infiniti Q70S 5.6, we liked the improved ride in the long-wheelbase version and the huge backseat the sedan provides. When driving the car, the recalibrated transmission and steering were much improved. Sportiness was good but not as much as other rivals. We liked the new styling but the technology inside was a little outdated. “To me, the GS and the CTS are still the sports sedans to beat. Let’s not forget that not only is the new CTS-V on the horizon, so is the GS F. However, the biggest Infiniti sedan does drive much better than the car it replaces.”</p>

<p>In our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2015-infiniti-q70l-3-7-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the Q70L, we said, “No matter how much you spend on a Q70, the center-stack screen is 7 inches, plenty big if your daily driver predates the march toward gigantic <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-s/2018/">Tesla Model S</a>-size screens but not so big if you just test drove a <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/">Lexus</a> GS with its 12.3-inch screen. I’m also looking forward to seeing an instrument cluster screen with better graphics and more info or an available head-up display. Better fuel economy would be a plus, too.”</p>

<p>At the end of our review we said, “When passenger space is more important than fuel economy, the Q70L should rise toward the top of your search. Avoid those flashy 20-inch wheels, and you’re left with a somewhat exclusive sub-$60,000 luxury sedan with a back seat [few others in the segment can match].”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The long-wheelbase version offers an additional 5.6 inches of rear seat space.</p>

<p><strong>Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>After a 2017 redesign, updates for 2018 include new 20-inch wheels for the Red Sport 400, new 19-inch wheels for the 3.0t Sport model, and a new exterior color: Solar Mica. A new trim level structure now consists of the Pure, Luxe, Sport, and Red Sport designations.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The Q60 is the coupe version of the Q50 sedan. In price, the Q60 is positioned above the Q50 but below the flagship Q70.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Q60’s base 2.0t models are powered by a 208-hp, 258-lb-ft of torque 2.0-liter turbo I-4 and delivers an EPA-rated 21/28 mpg city/highway with rear-wheel drive and 22/30 mpg for all-wheel drive (AWD). The available 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 produces 300 hp and 295 lb-ft and comes with a rating of 19/28 with rear-wheel drive and 19/27 with AWD. The range-topping Red Sport 400 utilizes the same twin-turbo V-6 but tuned to churn out a potent 400 hp and 350 lb-ft and is rated at 20/27 mpg with rear-wheel drive and 19/26 with AWD. A seven-speed automatic transmission backs all engines.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base 2.0t Pure include LED headlights and daytime running lights, LED fog lights and turn signals, LED rear combination lights, 19-inch wheels, a chrome front grille, leatherette upholstery, eight-way power front seats, leather wrapped steering wheel, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/">Infiniti</a> InTouch dual display system with an upper 8.0-inch and a 7.0-inch lower LCD touchscreens with controller, aluminum interior trim, dual-zone automatic temperature control, satellite radio, and Infiniti’s customizable InTuition infotainment system. Opt for the 3.0t models for the best packages like the Sensory package 3.0t consists of auto dimming outside mirrors, power tilt and telescoping steering wheel, Infiniti InTouch with Navigation and Infiniti InTouch Services, driver’s seat power lumbar, driver’s seat power torso bolsters, heated steering wheel and remote start. Silver Optic Fiber interior trim and an illuminated grille emblem are additional options.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/q60/2018/">Infiniti Q60</a> has yet to be crash tested, but the Q50 sedan on which it’s based received the highest rating of Good in four of the IIHS’ crash test evaluations and the highest rating of Superior for front crash prevention (thanks to the Forward Emergency Braking system also available on the Q60). The Q60 should fare well if ever crash tested. The available driver assist safety features are found in either the ProAssist package or the ProActive package and include blind-spot warning, blind spot intervention, adaptive cruise control, backup collision intervention with rear cross-traffic alert, forward collision warning, forward emergency braking, lane departure warning, and Lane Departure Prevention with Active Lane Control.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/q60/2017/2017-infiniti-q60-red-sport-coupe-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/q60/2017/">2017 Infiniti Q60</a> Red Sport 400 with AWD, acceleration was strong in Sport mode with minimal lag and the transmission was quick to downshift. The suspension was smooth in Sport mode with good handling but the Standard mode felt too floaty at speed. The steering was light but quickly got artificially heavy and boosted too much when turning. The Standard mode for steering was preferred for its natural and linear feel. The rear-wheel drive model felt lighter and more responsive versus the AWD model but felt slower in the corners.</p>

<p>As for Infiniti’s Direct Adaptive Steering (DAS), we said: “We would probably save the $1,000 for the DAS and stick with the conventional steering system. The DAS is required, however, for the Technology package.” Inside, we liked the center stack layout and double infotainment screens.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The twin turbochargers make a maximum 9.5 psi for the 300-hp V-6 engine and 14.7 psi for the 400-hp version.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Introduced last year, there are no significant changes to the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/qx30/2018/">Infiniti QX30</a> for the 2018 model year.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The QX30 is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/">Infiniti</a>’s entry-level crossover and the most affordable vehicle in the automaker’s lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/qx30/2018/">2018 Infiniti QX30</a> is powered by a 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 that produces 208 hp and 258 lb-ft of torque and is available in front-wheel drive (EPA-rated 24/33 mpg city/highway) and in all-wheel drive (21/30 mpg). Like its German twin, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/gla-class/2018/">Mercedes-Benz GLA-Class</a>, a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission routes power to the wheels. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the QX30 AWD hit 60 mph in a quick 6.2 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a very respectable 113 feet.</p>

<p>Standard features for the QX30 include LED daytime running lights, power-folding and heated outside mirrors with puddle lamps, Fibretec upholstery, eight-way manual front seats with power lumbar support, leatherette stitched dashboard and console, paddle shifters, 7.0-inch touchscreen with Infiniti InTouch, illuminated entry system, two USB ports, and dual exhaust outlets with chrome finishers. Available only on the top Premium AWD model, the Café Teak Theme package consists of Brown Nappa leather-appointed seats, brown leatherette console and door trim, black contrast stitching, real wood center stack and door trim, enhanced LED interior ambient lighting, black suede-like headliner and A-pillars, and Satin Silver mirror caps. Other available features include LED headlights and fog lights, panoramic moonroof, eight-way power heated front seats, surround view camera system, a 10-speaker Bose premium audio system, and navigation.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The QX30 comes standard with a rearview camera, electronic stability control, and front, side, and knee airbags. Driver assist safety features are found in the Technology package that consists of blind-spot warning, lane departure alert, forward emergency braking, adaptive cruise control, high beam assist, Intelligent Park Assist (self-parking system), and the Around View camera system with front and rear parking sensors. The IIHS nor the NHSTA have yet to evaluate the QX30 or the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> GLA-Class, its sister vehicle.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/qx30/2017/2017-infiniti-qx30-first-drive-review/">First Drive</a> of the 2017 Infiniti QX30, we were impressed with the luxurious interior and the comfortable seats, but the rear seats and cargo space are both on the small side. The transmission also impressed us: “Infiniti’s tweaks to the engine and sole-option seven-speed dual-clutch transmission seem to be mostly refinements, smoothing out power delivery and shifting for a slightly more relaxed demeanor than the playful GLA.”</p>

<p>The driving dynamics and ride comfort were also on par, “The same can be said for the QX30’s driving behavior. It’s more mature and straight-laced than its German half-brother. The ride is smooth and unperturbed by most bumps and holes, but the suspension still returns moderately sporty handling when pressed.” At the end of our review we said, “In a crowd trying to blend sport, luxury, and cost-savings as effectively as possible, the QX30 feels like <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/smart/">smart</a>, confident choice for someone less concerned with badges. At a starting price of just $30,900 ….it’s likely to be friendlier to the wallet than the competition, as well.”</p>

<p>When we reviewed the 2017 QX30 during <em><a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/infiniti-qx30-2017-suv-of-the-year-contender/">Motor Trend’s SUV of the Year testing</a></em>, we loved the compact crossover for its sharp looks and very fun handling and felt it was more of a raised hatchback than an SUV or crossover. The biggest complaints were the small back seats and cargo area. “Pretty little hot hatch with an interior nicer than the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/x1/2018/">BMW X1</a>’s, …In fact, both the exterior and the interior look better than the GLA the QX30 is based on—although back-seat space in the Infiniti definitely gets a failing grade.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The QX30 Sport model differentiates itself with a lower ride height, unique front, and rear lower fascias, gloss black grille, cross-drilled front brake rotors, dark chrome exhaust finishers and 19-inch Gun Metallic wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/">Infiniti</a> refreshed the QX80 with a redesigned front fascia, grille, headlights, liftgate, taillights, and rear bumper finisher. Inside, you will find new stitching, piping, and quilting on the seats, and new wood grain trim as well. The center console has also been updated to fit mugs with handles and adds USB ports.</p>

<p>The QX80 is the automaker’s only body-on-frame SUV and is positioned above the smaller QX30 and QX60 crossovers. The QX50 skips the 2018 model year and the QX70 has been discontinued.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/qx80/2018/">2018 Infiniti QX80</a></strong>: The QX80 is offered in one well-equipped trim that includes 20-inch alloy wheels, automatic LED headlights, LED fog lights, power sunroof, power-folding and heated side view mirrors with auto-dimming and reverse tilt-down, quick-entry with a push-start ignition, remote engine start, tri-zone climate control, leather seating, 10-way power front driver’s seat (eight-way for passenger), heated front seats, heated steering wheel, Stratford Burl trim, second-row captain’s chairs, a 13-speaker Bose audio system, an 8.0-inch center touchscreen with navigation and SiriusXM satellite radio, a power-adjustable steering wheel, a surround view camera system, plus nine cup holders and four bottle holders.</p>

<p><strong>2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/qx80/2018/">Infiniti QX80</a> 4WD</strong>: Infiniti adds its All-Mode four-wheel-drive system in addition to all the above standard features.</p>

<p>The Theater package adds entertainment to the rear seats with dual 8.0-inch display screens, two wireless headphones and headphone jacks, a wireless remote control, auxiliary HDMI and USB audio/visual ports, an additional 120-volt outlet, heated second-row seats, and remote tip-up second-row seats.</p>

<p>The 2018 Infiniti QX80 is powered by a 400-hp, 413-lb-ft of torque 5.6-liter V-8 backed by a seven-speed automatic transmission that delivers an EPA-rated 14/20 mpg with two-wheel drive and 13/19 mpg with four-wheel drive. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2015 Infiniti QX80 hit 60 mph in a quick 6.3 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a respectable 123 feet.</p>

<p>Driver assist safety features are found in Driver Assistance package that consists of emergency automatic braking with pedestrian detection, forward collision warning, reverse automatic braking, blind-spot monitor, blind-spot intervention, lane departure warning with lane keep assist, distance control assist, and full-speed adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p>The QX80 can fit up to 16.6 cubic feet of cargo behind the third row, 49.6 behind the second row, and 95.1 cubic feet with both rows folded down. The redesigned <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/navigator/2018/">2018 Lincoln Navigator</a> (regular wheel-base) offers more with 19.3, 57.5, and 103.3 cubic feet of cargo space, respectively. The QX80’s front seat passengers have 39.6 inches of legroom, second-row passengers have 41.0 inches, and third-row passengers receive much less at 28.8 inches.</p>

<p>Standard tech in the QX80 consists of an 8.0-inch center touchscreen with a navigation system and a central controller, SiriusXM satellite radio, SiriusXM Travel and Traffic Link, and Bluetooth streaming audio and calling. The standard 13-speaker Bose audio system can be upgraded to a 15-speaker Bose Cabin Surround audio system found in the Deluxe Technology package that also consists of the Hydraulic Body Motion Control system, the Smart Rear View Mirror (a traditional rearview mirror that can change to a camera rear view), climate-controlled seats, an adaptive front lighting system with auto-leveling headlights, advanced climate control, and some additional luxurious features. The Infiniti Wi-Fi package can connect up to five devices and is available in 1 GB and 5 GB monthly plans. The previously mentioned Driver Assistance package and Theater package adds lots of tech.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/qx80/2018/2018-infiniti-qx80-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2018 Infiniti QX80, we liked all the interior and exterior updates the QX80 received this model year, but the platform and powertrain remained unchanged. The ride is still comfortable and the QX80 still handles like a large SUV—the new Hydraulic Body Motion Control system didn’t seem to make a difference from previous models. The suite of driver assist safety feature is unchanged—we hoped ProPilot Assist would be available. The new Smart Rearview Mirror is a nice touch. Unfortunately, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto and a digital instrument cluster are not available.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/escalade/2015/the-big-test-large-luxury-suvs/">2015 Big Test</a> of large luxury SUVs, the pre-refresh Infiniti QX80 came in last place out of six competitors. We liked the ride comfort, braking distance, powerful V-8, and some impressive cabin materials, but we concluded, “When you factor in worst in test fuel economy, a cramped third row, and those awkward looks, you have a big SUV that only one of us loved.”</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The QX60’s only significant change for the 2018 model year is the discontinuation of the low-volume hybrid model, leaving the QX60 3.5 and QX60 3.5 AWD.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The QX60 is positioned above the entry-level QX30 and below the larger and more expensive QX80. The QX70 has been discontinued. Below the QX60 is the QX50 model, which will not see a 2018 model but will return for the 2019 model year, and the entry-level QX30.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/qx60/2018/">2018 Infiniti QX60</a> is powered by a 295-hp, 270 lb-ft of torque 3.5-liter V-6 paired to a CVT that routes power to the front wheels (EPA-rated 19/26 mpg city/highway) or to an all-wheel drive (AWD) system (20/27 mpg). The QX60 (which is based on the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/pathfinder/2018/">Nissan Pathfinder</a>) offers 15.8 cubic feet of cargo space with the third row up, 40.8 cubic feet with the third row down, and healthy 76.5 cubic feet with the second row down.</p>

<p>Standard features for the 2018 QX60 include 18-inch wheels, heated outside mirrors, chrome grille, power moonroof, leather upholstery (1<sup>st</sup> and 2<sup>nd</sup> row), power tilt and telescoping steering wheel, leather wrapped steering wheel, eight-way power adjustable driver’s seat, heated front seats, an 8.0-inch center display, tri-zone climate control, and rear A/C vents (not third row). For additional features, opt for the Premium package that includes a Bose Premium audio system, dual front memory seats (includes outside mirrors and steering wheel), Enhanced Intelligent Key (occupant memory settings), heated steering wheel, reverse-tilt-down side view mirrors, and a stainless steel rear bumper protector. The above Premium package is required if you want the Premium Plus package that adds navigation, a multi-camera parking camera system with Moving Object Detection, rain-sensing windshield wipers, illuminated door sills, as well as front and rear parking sensors. Additional optional features include 20-inch wheels and a second and third row moonroof with power sunshade.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2017 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/qx60/2018/">Infiniti QX60</a> is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick because the crossover received the highest rating of Good in all five crash evaluations and the highest rating of Superior for front crash prevention from the IIHS for being able to avoid a 12 mph and 25 mph frontal collision thanks to the available Forward Emergency Braking with Pedestrian Detection found in the Deluxe Technology package that includes Lane Departure Warning, Lane Departure Prevention, adaptive cruise control, Backup Collision Intervention, front and rear parking sensors, Blind Spot Intervention, forward collision warning, and blind spot warning. The QX60 missed out on a Top Safety Pick+ rating because the IIHS rated its headlights as Poor. The 2018 model has yet to be IIHS-rated.</p>

<p>The NHTSA issued its highest rating of five stars for the crossover’s overall rating in front- and all-wheel drive forms.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2016-infiniti-qx60-nine-things-to-know/">Nine Things to Know</a> review of the refreshed 2016 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/">Infiniti</a> QX60, we felt the crossover drove sportier than the pre-refreshed model but still very comfortable. The NVH (noise, vibration, and harshness) was reduced, keeping the interior quiet over rough surfaces. We liked the four USB ports but having only one in the front and two for the third-row confused us. Inside, we liked the new premium shifter, contrast stitching, and good-looking wood-grain trim. The second-row was nice with optional heated seats, rear entertainment system, and seats that slide forward and tilt up for easy third-row access.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The available Bose Cabin Surround audio system includes 15 speakers and digital 5.1 decoding, great for watching movies with the optional rear entertainment system.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>A new range-topping <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2018-jaguar-xjr575-debuts-new-performance-flagship-sedan/">XJR575 performance model</a> joins the lineup, built by Special Vehicle Operations (SVO). Technology upgrades include the latest <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/">Jaguar</a> InControl TouchPro infotainment system with 4G WiFi, a new 10-inch touchscreen display, and a new suite of driver assist safety features.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The XJ is Jaguar’s flagship sedan, positioned above the XE and XF sport sedans. The XJ has the highest starting price in the automaker’s lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 XJ comes standard with a 340-hp, 332-lb-ft of torque 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 that delivers an EPA-rated 18/27 mpg city/highway with rear-wheel drive and 17/26 mpg with all-wheel drive (AWD; EPA figures here are from the 2017 model year). The long-wheelbase version, the XJL, is also rated at 18/27 mpg in rear-wheel drive form and 17/25 with AWD. The available 5.0-liter supercharged V-8 produces 470 hp and 424 lb-ft of torque and is rated at 15/23 mpg in both traditional and long-wheelbase versions and is only available with rear-wheel drive. The XJR575 uses the same 5.0-liter supercharged V-8 that is tuned to produce a potent 575 hp and 517 lb-ft of torque and is only available in rear-wheel drive (the EPA has yet to rate the engine’s fuel economy). All powertrains use an eight-speed automatic transmission. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2016 Jaguar XJL AWD V-6 hit 60 mph in a quick 5.4 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in an impressive 112 feet.</p>

<p>The base XJ R-Sport model comes standard with 19-inch wheels, an R-Sport exterior trim with black mesh grille, full LED headlights with automatic high beams, LED taillights, panoramic roof, ventilated heated and cool front and rear seats, Touch Pro with connected navigation, a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, a 20-speaker Meridian surround sound system, interior ambient lighting, rear air suspension, a drive mode selector, 16-way powered perforated Softgrain leather front seats, and a Softgrain leather-wrapped heated steering wheel. Opt for the Comfort package and your XJ will come with 18-way heated and cooled front seats with massaging function, front seat passenger memory, four-zone climate control, and an electric rear sunshade. The impressive Premium Rear Seat package comes with two individual massaging seats, a folding center armrest with seat controls, rear business tables, and the Rear Seat Entertainment system which includes dual 10.2-inch LCD screens, a rear media interface, touch-screen remote control, and two wireless headphones. The XJR575 features exterior badging, twin hood louvers, red brake calipers, 20-inch five split-spoke Gloss Black wheels, bespoke door sills, diamond-quilted seating, and an electronic Active Differential.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The standard driver assist safety features for the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/xj/2018/">2018 Jaguar XJ</a> include a blind-spot monitoring system, rear-cross traffic alert, traffic sign recognition with adaptive speed limiter, Driver Condition Monitor (drowsy driver alert), and Lane Departure Warning with Lane Keep Assist. Available driver assist safety features include a multi-camera visibility system, Park Assist (self-parking and exiting system), and adaptive cruise control with Queue Assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/xj-series/2016/2016-jaguar-xjl-3-0-awd-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2016 Jaguar XJL 3.0 AWD, we felt the Jaguar was powerful and responsive with a quick 0-60 mph time. However, the auto start/stop function shook the body briefly upon restarting and the steering feel is a little vague. We liked the Jaguar’s first-class interior, price tag, and warranty. “There are certainly much worse vehicles to be stuck in while inching along in the rain,” we said. “The XJL is a soothing vehicle to drive. The motor purrs along, and the sound isolation is excellent. The only interruptions are potholes or rough, irregular pavement; the stiff aluminum chassis transmits a surprising amount of shock into the cabin. In this regard, the big Jag doesn’t feel up to the same level as the S-Class or new 7 Series.”</p>

<p>“As impressive as the XJL is, I have a few quibbles for this nearly six-figure car,” we said during a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/xj-series/2014/2013-jaguar-xjl-supercharged-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 2013 Jaguar XJL 5.0. “For example, the manual rear door shades and the power rear window shade didn’t work for two days from the front or rear cabin switches. Being able to use the heated seat backs and ventilated seat bottoms at the same time with the messaging function (as on the outgoing <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> S-Class) would be a welcome feature, as would massaging and reclining rear seats.” In conclusion, we said: “Despite the few complaints, the Jaguar wowed most of those who experienced it. With a base price of $93,475 and an as-tested price of $98,075, the 2013 Jaguar XJL 5.0 pampers with luxury and comfort along with power and handling for true driving enthusiasts; something not found in all of its similarly priced German competitors.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Jaguar claims that the XJR575 can hit 60 mph in 4.2 seconds and has a top speed of 186 mph.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/">Jaguar</a> F-Pace receives a third engine option: a 2.0-liter gas turbo-four from Jaguar <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/">Land Rover</a>’s Ingenium engine family. Owners can use a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/jaguar-launches-car-payment-system-fueling-stations/">new Shell app</a> to pay for gas using the car’ infotainment system. Forward traffic detection and forward vehicle guidance have also been added to the available suite of active safety systems.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The Jaguar F-Pace is the British automaker’s first crossover, and it comes standard with all-wheel drive and a choice of gas or diesel powertrains.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>
