<p>Three engines are offered in the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/f-pace/2017/2017-jaguar-f-pace-first-drive-review-practical-sports-car/">2018 Jaguar F-Pace,</a> a 2.0-liter turbodiesel I-4 making 180 hp and 318 lb-ft of torque, a 2.0-liter gas turbo-four with 247 hp and 269 lb-ft, and a 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 rated at 340 hp or 380 hp and 332 lb-ft. An eight-speed automatic transmission is the only gearbox available on all F-Pace variants. EPA fuel economy estimates haven’t been announced for the 2018 model, but the diesel variant should retain the 2017 car’s 26/33 mpg city/highway while the V-6-powered models will likely keep the 2017 car’s 18/23 mpg. Expect the gas 2.0-liter turbo-four to fit in between the diesel and the V-6 in terms of fuel economy.</p>

<p>Cargo space is 33.5 cubic feet and can be expanded to 63.5 cubic feet with the standard 40/20/40 split-folding rear seats folded. The diesel and V-6-powered F-Pace can tow up to 5,290 pounds when properly equipped; expect the 2.0-liter gas turbo-four to have less towing capacity.</p>

<p>Standard and optional features include a panoramic sunroof, adaptive LED headlights, alloy wheels up to 22 inches in diameter, a Meridian premium audio system, leather upholstery, a head-up display, Jaguar’s InControl Touch multimedia interface with standard eight-inch touchscreen in the base version or a 10.2-inch unit in the Pro variant, a 12.3-inch digital display replacing traditional gauges, the Adaptive Dynamics drive model selector, and Jaguar Land Rover’s All Surface Progress Control, which aids when driving the F-Pace off-road.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Jaguar F-Pace. Available active safety and driver assistance systems include lane keeping assist with driver condition monitoring, adaptive cruise control with queue assist, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, and blind-spot warning.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/f-pace/2017/2017-jaguar-f-pace-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we said that the Jaguar F-Pace offers excellent driving dynamics and offers strong acceleration when equipped with the optional supercharged V-6 engine. Larger alloy wheels, however, produce more road noise and makes the ride worse than. Opting for smaller alloy wheels improves the F-Pace’s ride and minimizes the road impacts from uneven surfaces. Although there is a decent amount of cargo space inside, fit and finish is subpar, with cheap materials throughout the interior.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Jaguar F-Pace was first previewed by the sexy C-X17 concept that debuted at the 2013 Frankfurt auto show.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/xe/2018/">2018 Jaguar XE</a> gets an upgraded 2.0-liter gas turbo-four from <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/">Jaguar</a> <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/">Land Rover</a>’s Ingenium engine family. Forward traffic detection and forward vehicle guidance have also been added to the available suite of active safety features. A 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster display is also now available. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/xe/2018/">Jaguar XE</a> S gets more power with its supercharged 3.0-liter V-6 now rated at 380 hp.</p>

<p>A <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/jaguar-launches-car-payment-system-fueling-stations/">new Shell app</a> allows owners to pay for fuel via the car’s touchscreen and a power-operated trunk is now offered.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Jaguar XE is a compact premium sports sedan that slots below the midsize XF and is the British automaker’s answer to the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/3-series/2018/">BMW 3 Series</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a4/2018/">Audi A4</a>. Rear-wheel drive is standard and all-wheel drive is optional on the diesel-powered and V-6-powered variants.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Three engines are available in the 2018 XE, a new 2.0-liter gas turbo-four making 247 hp and 269 lb-ft of torque, a 2.0-liter turbodiesel I-4 rated at 180 hp and 318 lb-ft, and a 3.0-liter supercharged 3.0-liter V-6 with 340 hp or 380 hp and 332 lb-ft of torque. An eight-speed automatic transmission is the only gearbox available on all models.</p>

<p>Cargo space stands at 15.9 cubic feet regardless of the variant and can be expanded with the 40/20/40 split-folding rear seats that’s available on all but the base XE. Compared to the 2017 model year, fuel economy numbers shouldn’t change much with the diesel, which is the most efficient at 32/42 mpg city/highway for rear-drive models and 30/40 mpg with all-wheel drive. The more powerful variants with the supercharged 3.0-liter V-6 should retain the same 21/30 mpg rating for rear-drive variants and 20/29 mpg with all-wheel drive. However, the gas 2.0-liter turbo-four could see an improvement from the 2017 model’s 21/30 mpg rating.</p>

<p>Standard and available features include Jaguar Land Rover’s InControl infotainment system with a standard eight-inch touchscreen or a larger 10.2-inch unit, navigation, a Meridian premium audio system, a rearview camera, head-up display, heated and ventilated front seats, leather upholstery, adaptive HID headlights, a moonroof, keyless entry/start, alloy wheels up to 20 inches in diameter, and heated rear seats.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Jaguar XE. A suite of active safety and driver assistance features is available and includes automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, blind-spot warning, lane keeping assist, driver condition monitoring, and adaptive cruise control with queue assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/xe/2017/2017-jaguar-xe-25t-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we said that the XE offers smooth power delivery, and features a great ride and handling balance. Noise levels inside the XE’s cabin is minimal but the fit and finish is not up to par with the class due to some cheap materials used in some areas include the paddle shifters. The seat bottom are also lacking in thigh support, especially taller drivers with long legs. As for the infotainment system, Jaguar Land Rover’s InControl interface is finicky and suffers from glitches that cause it to freeze (at least, in our test car). The touchscreen is also slow to respond, especially when inputting commands for navigation. Rear seat space is also cramped due to the car’s swoopy roofline.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Jaguar XE features an aluminum-intensive architecture that helps keep its weight down.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The F-Type gained a new base 2.0-liter turbocharged engine for the coupe’s mid-cycle refresh and a limited-edition 400 Sport model featuring a 400-hp supercharged V-6 engine. The refresh adds new front fascia with redesigned headlights, new paint and wheel options, new lightweight slimline seats, ventilated seats are now available, and two new interior color options include noble chrome and Sienna Tan. New driver assist safety features have also added to the F-Type lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The F-Type is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/">Jaguar</a>’s only two-door car and convertible, and also the sportiest and quickest vehicle in the British automaker’s lineup. The F-Type starts below the flagship XJ but can be optioned to be the most expensive vehicle in Jaguar’s lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 F-Type is available with three engines, two of those with multiple power outputs.</p>

<p><strong>Model: F-Type, F-Type Premium</strong><br>
Engine: 296-hp, 295-lb-ft 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4<br>
Transmission: eight-speed automatic</br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: F-Type, F-Type Premium</strong><br>
Engine: 340-hp, 332-lb-ft 3.0-liter supercharged V-6<br>
Transmission: six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 20/28 mpg city/highway (automatic); 16/24 mpg (manual)</br></br></br></p>

<p><strong>Model: F-Type R-Dynamic, F-Type R-Dynamic AWD</strong><br>
Engine: 380-hp, 339-lb-ft 3.0-liter supercharged V-6<br>
Transmission: six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 19/27 mpg (automatic); 15/24 mpg (manual); 18/26 mpg (all-wheel drive)</br></br></br></p>

Transmission: eight-speed automatic<br>

<p>The Jaguar InControl Touch Pro infotainment system is now standard and features a faster processor. New for the infotainment system is a GoPro connectivity feature dubbed ReRun, an app that can record track data including speed, lateral acceleration, gear selection, and throttle and brake position. The data can then be overlaid with GoPro footage and downloaded on a smartphone. For added look and bite, you can opt the SVR model with the available Carbon Ceramic Brake package that will likely return for 2018 and includes yellow brake calipers and 20-inch Maelstrom five twin-spoke forged alloy wheels. The Extended Leather package adds a leather upper dash trim and leather sports sun visor with mirror while the Exterior Carbon Fiber package adds carbon fiber hood louvers, mirror caps, front splitter, and side vents.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>Jaguar improved the safety on the 2018 F-Type by offering Autonomous Emergency Braking, Lane Departure Warning, Lane Keep Assist, Traffic Sign Recognition, and Driver Condition Monitor that can sense driver fatigue. Also new is Adaptive Speed Limiter, the feature uses Traffic Sign Recognition to determine if the speed limit has changed and automatically speeds up or slows down the F-Type until the vehicle reaches the new speed limit. Safety features from 2017 should carry over and include blind-spot monitoring, Forward Collision Warning, and parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In <em><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mclaren/570/2016/2016-motor-trend-best-drivers-car/">Motor Trend’s 2016 Best Driver’s Car</a></em> competition, we felt the 2017 F-Type SVR was the most capable F-Type ever with the new all-wheel-drive system and improved chassis: “A really satisfying car to drive on corner entry; power doesn’t seem to change the car’s balance a lot. It’s like I’m carving the friction circle.”</p>

<p>The Jag impressed us by still feeling like a rear-wheel drive car: “Its steering remains fluid, linear, and marvelously uncorrupted by torque inputs into the front wheels.” However, the eight-speed automatic lagged behind the rest: “The biggest letdown is the eight-speed automatic, which in both auto and manual modes always feels a beat behind the rest of the car. Feels unsophisticated compared with the other automatics here.”</p>

<p>In the end, the F-Type finished in ninth place out of 12 cars driven on the track and on public roads.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/f-type/2016/2016-jaguar-f-type-r-coupe-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/f-type/2016/">2016 Jaguar F-Type</a> R, the coupe’s new all-wheel-drive system improved performance by allowing the Jag to perform better in acceleration runs and in our figure-8 handling course. “While I do miss the ability to do monstrous, adolescent burnouts at the drop of a foot, the 2016 F-Type R Coupe is more fun to drive on a winding road than the car it replaces. That’s what confidence—and traction—does for you.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Jaguar’s 3.0-liter supercharged V-6’s horsepower output ranges from 340 hp to 400 hp but the torque output only ranges from 332 lb-ft of torque to 339 lb-ft.</p>

The 2018 XF’s available active safety feature suite now includes forward traffic detection and forward vehicle guidance.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/xf/2018/">Jaguar XF</a> is a midsize luxury sedan slotting above the compact XE and the full-size XJ. Rear-wheel drive is standard and all-wheel drive is optional.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Three engines are available in the 2018 XF including a 2.0-liter gas turbo-four with 247 hp/269 lb-ft of torque, a 2.0-liter turbodiesel I-4 with 180 hp/318 lb-ft or a 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 rated at 340 hp or 380 hp and 332 lb-ft. An eight-speed automatic is the sole transmission offered across the entire XF lineup.</p>

<p>The XF’s spacious trunk can be expanded via the available 40/20/40 split-folding rear seats in the Premium and higher trims. EPA fuel economy ratings for the 2018 XF should change much compared to the 2017 model, which was rated at 31/42 mpg city/highway for the rear-drive diesel models and 30/40 mpg with all-wheel drive. The supercharged V-6 should retain its 20/29 mpg rating for rear-drive version and the 20/28 mpg with all-wheel drive. Expect the 2.0-liter turbo-four’s EPA mileage to fall in between</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Jaguar XF hasn’t been crash tested by the NHTSA and IIHS. Active safety and driver assistance features include adaptive cruise control with queue assist, automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, blind-spot warning, and lane keeping assist with driver condition monitoring.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/xf/2017/2017-jaguar-xf-awd-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we said that regardless of the variant you choose, the XF is fun to drive, offering excellent handling thanks to its great chassis and well-tuned steering. The aluminum structure also helps keep the XF’s ride comfortable and minimize tire noise. However, the diesel engine can get noisy and the stiff suspension doesn’t fare well on rough pavement. We also noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/xf/2016/2016-jaguar-xf-first-drive-review/">2016 First Drive</a> that the infotainment system, which is displayed on an available 10.2-inch touchscreen, is quicker than before. <p>The Renegade is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/">Jeep</a>’s smallest and least expensive crossover, positioned below the larger Compass, Cherokee, Wrangler JK, the new Wrangler JL, and the Grand Cherokee.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Renegade Sport</strong>: The base Sport model comes standard with the 1.4-liter turbo-four engine, 16-inch steel wheels, a 5.0-inch touchscreen with the Uconnect 3 infotainment system and Bluetooth calling, a 3.5-inch instrument panel driver’s display, a rearview camera, push-button ignition, and remote keyless entry.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Renegade Latitude</strong>: The Latitude trims makes the 2.4-liter I-4 engine available, and adds 17-inch aluminum wheels, a 7.0-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Andriod Auto, SiriusXM satellite radio, dual-zone climate control, roof rails, fog lights, automatic headlights, and an upgraded steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Renegade Altitude</strong>: Moving up into the Altitude trim will add 18-inch gloss black aluminum wheels, High Glass Black interior and exterior accents, black cloth seats with black stitching, and body-colored exterior mirrors with turn signals.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Renegade Limited</strong>: The Limited comes standard with the 2.4-liter I-4 engine, 18-inch aluminum wheels, heated front seats, leather-trimmed seating, leather-wrapped and heated steering wheel, a quick entry system, remote vehicle start, silver metallic roof rails, and a 7.0-inch instrument panel driver’s display.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Renegade Trailhawk</strong>: The Trailhawk adds off-road features including 17-inch off-road wheels and all-season/off-road tires, Active Drive Low four-wheel drive system (20:1 crawl ratio) with Selec-Terrain traction management system, a 0.8-inch off-road suspension lift, hill descent control, red tow hooks, off-road fascia, skid plates, and a black accent roof.</p>

<p>The 2018 Renegade’s standard engine is a 1.4-liter turbo-four that produces 160 hp and 184 lb-ft of torque and delivers an EPA-rated 21/34 mpg city/highway with front-wheel drive and 24/31 mpg with all-wheel drive. The optional 2.4-liter I-4 pumps out 180 hp and 175 lb-ft and is rated at 22/30 mpg with front-wheel drive and 21/29 mpg with all-wheel drive. The 1.4-liter turbo-four can only be paired with a six-speed manual and the 2.4-liter is backed by a nine-speed automatic. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/renegade/2018/">2018 Jeep Renegade</a> Sport 4×4 (nine-speed automatic) hit 60 mph in 9.0 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 123 feet.</p>

<p>The 2017 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/renegade/2018/">Jeep Renegade</a> received a four-star overall safety rating out of five stars from the NHTSA. In IIHS testing, the 2017 Renegade received the second highest rating of Acceptable in the driver side small overlap front test, and Good in the other crash tests. In the front crash prevention evaluation, the second highest score of Advanced was issued because the crossover reduced the speed of a 12-mph collision by 10 mph and reduced the speed of a 25-mph collision by 5 mph thanks to the optional automatic emergency braking feature found in the Advanced Technology group that also consists of forward collision warning, lane departure warning, lane keep assist, rear parking sensors, and automatic high beams. The Safety and Security group includes blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, a security alarm, rain-sensitive wipers, HID headlights, and a tonneau cover. A rearview camera is standard.</p>

<p>The 2018 Renegade offers 18.5 cubic feet of cargo space behind the rear seats and 50.8 cubic feet with the rear seats folded down. When equipped with all-wheel drive, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/hr-v/2018/">Honda HR-V</a> has 23.2 cubic feet and 55.9 cubic feet, respectively. Front seat passengers have 41.2 inches of legroom and rear seat passengers have 35.1 inches.</p>

<p>The Renegade’s standard tech includes the Uconnect 3 infotainment system displayed on a 5.0-inch center touchscreen with Bluetooth, a USB outlet (another is included for rear-seat passengers on most trims), and an auxiliary port. The upgraded Uconnect 4 system is displayed on a larger 7.0-inch touchscreen and adds SiriusXM satellite radio and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. The optional Uconnect 4C system is displayed on an 8.4-inch touchscreen and includes a navigation system with SiriusXM Travel Link, Traffic Plus, and Guardian (remotely lock/unlock doors, turn on/off the ignition, honk the horn, etc.). The standard six-speaker audio system can be upgraded to a nine-speaker Beats audio system. The instrument panel driver’s display can be upgraded to a 7.0-inch display from the standard 3.5-inch one.</p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/jeep-renegade-2016-motor-trend-suv-of-the-year-contender/">2016 <em>Motor Trend</em> SUV of the year testing</a>, the Renegade Latitude and Trailhawk failed to make our finalist cut. We liked the Renegade’s value and interior packaging and roominess but did not care for the lack of power, sub-par transmissions, and poor off-road performance. We concluded by saying that “buyers who are able to overlook engines that feel slightly overtaxed and less than ideal transmissions will find themselves piloting a stylish cute-ute with an exceptionally spacious and well-packaged interior.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/xv-crosstrek/2015/the-big-test-2015-2016-subcompact-crossovers/">2015/2016 Big Test</a> of subcompact crossovers, the Renegade came in third place out of six. “Objectively, the Jeep is a weak performer, yet it still garnered two first-place votes, thanks to an engaging personality and a stylish, commodious cabin. But its temperamental transmission and recent stop-sale over ’software issues‘ are reasons for concern.”</p>

<p>“It’s hard not to be charmed by this little Renegade, and if FCA spent half as much time working on the nine-speed to make it smoother and more efficient as it did on the Jeep’s Easter eggs, you’d be looking at the winner,” we concluded.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/grand-cherokee/2018/">2018 Jeep Grand Cherokee</a> Laredo</strong>: The base Laredo model comes standard with 17-inch alloy wheels, automatic headlights, fog lights, power and heated side view mirrors, the a 7.0-inch center display and two USB ports, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a 7.0-inch instrument panel driver’s display, a six-speaker audio system, LED map lights, manually adjustable front seats, a fold-flat front passenger seat, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and a rearview camera with rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/grand-cherokee/2018/">Jeep Grand Cherokee</a> Limited</strong>: Moving up to the Limited adds 18-inch painted wheels, a power liftgate, a remote start system, roof rails, a memory system (for the driver’s seat, side view mirrors, radio station, and the power tilt/telescoping steering wheel if equipped), SiriusXM satellite radio, two additional USB ports, an auto-dimming rearview mirror, leather-trimmed seats, heated front and second-row seats, eight-way power front seats, a heated steering wheel, and a 115-volt power outlet.</p>

The Overland keeps the same 8.4-inch touchscreen and Alpine audio system as the Trailhawk model.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Jeep Grand Cherokee Summit</strong>: The very luxurious Summit builds off the Overland and adds fully polished 20-inch wheels, a 19-speaker Harman Kardon audio system, performance all-season tires (versus regular all-season or all-terrain), perforated Natura Plus leather-trimmed seating, an adaptive cruise control system, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, forward collision warning with automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning with lane keep assist, and a self-parking system.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Jeep Grand Cherokee SRT</strong>: The higher-performance Grand Cherokee SRT packs the powerful 6.4-liter V-8, and sports 20-inch Satin Carbon alloy wheels, a flat-bottom steering wheel, a Bilstein Active Damping system, Brembo high-performance, launch control, all-wheel drive with a traction management system, wider tires, HID headlights with LED fog lights, leather and perforated suede SRT seats, and Performance Pages (a feature that records the vehicle’s performance). <p><strong>2018 Jeep Grand Cherokee Trackhawk</strong>: The high-performance Trackhawk is powered by the 707-hp supercharged 6.2-liter V-8. <p>The Sterling edition is only available on the Limited trim and adds Platinum Chrome exterior accents, 20-inch painted Heritage wheels, unique Heritage seats with stitching, an 8.4-inch infotainment display with navigation, a nine-speaker Alpine audio system, and a power sunroof. <p>The Grand Cherokee’s base 295-hp, 260-lb-ft of torque 3.6-liter V-6 that delivers an EPA-rated 19/26 mpg city/highway with rear-wheel drive and 18/25 mpg with four-wheel drive. A 360-hp, 390 lb-ft 5.7-liter V-8 is only available with four-wheel drive and is rated at 14/22 mpg. The powerful 6.4-liter V-8 found on the all-wheel-drive SRT produces 475 hp and 470 lb-ft and is rated at 13/19 mpg. The new Grand Cherokee Trackhawk is powered by a 707-hp, 645-lb-ft of torque 6.2-liter supercharged V-8 mated to a beefed-up eight-speed automatic that routes power to an all-wheel-drive system and delivers 11/17 mpg. An eight-speed automatic backs all powertrains. The 240-hp, 420-lb-ft 3.0-liter turbodiesel V-6 engine is currently not rated by the EPA due to an ongoing emissions investigation.</p>

<p>In IIHS testing, the 2018 Grand Cherokee received the second-lowest score of Marginal for the driver-side small overlap front test and the highest score of Good for the other crash tests. The lowest score of Basic was issued for the front crash prevention test for properly warning the driver of a possible collision, but the automatic emergency braking feature was not tested. The automatic emergency braking feature is found in the Active Safety Group and is standard on Summit, SRT, and Trackhawk trims. The Active Safety group also includes lane departure warning, blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert, adaptive cruise control, a rain-sensing windshield, and a self-parking system. The 2017 Jeep Grand Cherokee received the NHTSA’s highest five-star overall safety rating with four-wheel drive and a four-star overall rating with rear-wheel drive. The optional SOS call and Assist buttons provide emergency or roadside assistance.</p>

<p>The Grand Cherokee offers 36.3 cubic feet of cargo space behind the rear seats and 68.3 with the rear seats folded down. Front seat passengers have up to 40.3 inches of legroom and rear seat passenger receive 38.6 inches.</p>

<p>The base Laredo trim comes standard with a 7.0-inch center touchscreen with a six-speaker audio system and two USB ports. The upgraded system is displayed on an 8.4-inch center touchscreen and features navigation (including SiriusXM Traffic and Travel Link) with SiriusXM satellite radio, Apple CarPlay, and Android Auto. Two upgraded audio systems include a nine-speaker Alpine system and a 19-speaker, 825-watt Harman Kardon system. A 7.0-inch instrument panel driver’s display is standard on all trims and two additional USB ports are standard on the Limited trim and up.  An optional Blu-ray rear entertainment system consists of two seatback mounted screens and audio/video ports for other devices. SiriusXM Guardian can remotely control many features of the Jeep from an app such as starting the engine.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/grand-cherokee/2017/2017-jeep-grand-cherokee-trailhawk-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2017 Jeep Grand Cherokee Trailhawk, we felt the standard V-6 offered plenty of power and the air suspension rides well on pavement. Off-road, “the Grand Cherokee Trailhawk just motored on up steep hills and frame-twisting ruts like they weren’t even there. Although many off-roaders turn their noses up at air suspensions because of a perceived lack of reliability, the Grand Cherokee Trailhawk’s didn’t exhibit any bad behavior; it rode incredibly well off-road and never bottomed out on more extreme obstacles, which is an issue exhibited by many air suspension–equipped off-roaders.”</p>

<p>“…The Grand Cherokee Trailhawk offers up some serious off-road potential and on-road comfort at a killer price,” we concluded.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/grand-cherokee/2018/2018-jeep-grand-cherokee-trackhawk-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2018 Jeep Grand Cherokee Trackhawk, we were very impressed with its acceleration at the track: “The Trackhawk hit 60 mph in 3.3 seconds in our testing, beating Jeep’s claimed time of 3.5 seconds. The quickest we’ve ever hit 60 mph in Hellcat testing is 3.7 seconds, for both the Challenger and the Charger …  For SUVs, the quickest to 60 mph we tested before the Trackhawk were <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-x/2018/">Tesla Model X</a> (3.2 seconds), the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/bentayga/2018/">Bentley Bentayga</a> (3.5 seconds), the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/x6/2018/">BMW X6</a> M (3.7 seconds) and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>-AMG GLE 63 S Coupe 4Matic (3.9).”</p>

<p>“In the quarter-mile test, ” we continued, “the Trackhawk runs 11.7 seconds at 116.2 mph. Did you ever think we’d see the day when a production SUV runs the quarter in the 11s? That’s just crazy! Or should I say ludicrous, as the Model X when in Ludicrous mode also runs an 11.7-second quarter mile.”</p>

<p>The Trackhawk also put down a respectable braking distance and a quick figure-eight time. We concluded by saying, “I’m sure we can all agree that there’s no need for a vehicle like this. But boy, are we all happy Jeep gave it the green light. I got no problem with crazy, as long as it’s the good kind of crazy. You know, the kind that makes a supercar saturated car scribe giggle like a toddler.”</p>

<p>The Wrangler JK gets three new special-edition models for the 2018 model year: the Golden Eagle, Freedom Edition and the Altitude. <em>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/wrangler/2018/">2018 Jeep Wrangler</a> JK is the previous-generation model that will be sold alongside <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/wrangler/2018/">the all-new</a> <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/wrangler/2018/">2018 Wrangler</a>.</em></p>

<p>The older Wrangler JK comes standard with four-wheel drive and is available in two-door guise or a four-door called the Unlimited.</p>

<p><strong>Wrangler Sport: </strong>The base Sport trim comes with 16-inch steel wheels, Dana front and rear axles, cloth upholstery, and an eight-speaker audio system.</p>

<p><strong>Wrangler Sport S: </strong>Moving up to the Sport S trim gets you 17-inch alloy wheels, air conditioning, and a leather-wrapped steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>Wrangler Willys Wheeler:</strong> The Willys Wheeler comes with 17-inch gloss black wheels, 32-inch BF Goodrich all-terrain tires, a 3.73 ratio limited-slip differential, gloss black grille and bumper accents, voice command, Bluetooth, a USB port, and suspension tuned for off-road use.</p>

<p><strong>Wrangler Freedom Edition: </strong>One of the special edition models on the Wrangler JK, the Freedom Edition gets Oscar Mike fender badges and seat embroidery, 17-inch alloy wheels and grille in low gloss Granite Crystal finish, body-colored fender flairs, heavy duty rock rails, black taillight guards and fuel filler door, steel front and rear bumpers, silver accents on the interior, and Iron Gray grab handles, door pools and vent rings on the dash.</p>

<p><strong>Wrangler Sahara: </strong>One of the more comfort-oriented trims, the Sahara adds 18-inch alloy wheels, side steps, embroidered cloth upholstery, automatic headlights, and LED fog lights.</p>

<p><strong>Wrangler Altitude: </strong>Base on the Sahara trim, the Wrangler Altitude body-colored headlight accents, front and rear bumpers, a black <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/">Jeep</a> badge, heated front seats, 18-inch gloss black alloy wheels, Liquid Titanium air vent surrounds and door and instrument panel grab handles, and black taillight guards and fuel filler door.</p>

<p><strong>Wrangler Rubicon: </strong>The Rubicon is the most off-road capable model and comes with 17-inch alloy wheels with BF Goodrich all-terrain tires, locking front and rear axles, LED headlights, LED fog lights, and an upgraded four-wheel drive system with a 4:1 low range ratio.</p>

<p><strong>Wrangler Rubicon Recon: </strong>Building on the Rubicon trim, the Rubicon Recon gets heated front seats, leather upholstery, red seat belts, winch-capable steel front and rear bumpers, Dana 44 front axle and cast differential covers, a vented hood, automatic climate, control, remote start, and the Connectivity group, which adds voice command, a tire pressure monitor, and Bluetooth</p>

<p><strong>Wrangler Golden Eagle: </strong>One of a number of special edition models available, the Wrangler Golden Eagle comes with a tan-colored soft top, Golden center and side hood decals, body-colored grille and fender flares, bronze tow hooks, Golden Eagle logos on the front seats, and 17-inch alloy wheels with bronze accents.</p>

<p>Key features include a choice between soft and hardtop roofs, a locking limited-slip differential, keyless entry, a nine-speaker Alpine audio system, and navigation with a 6.5-inch touchscreen.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/wrangler/2018/">Jeep Wrangler</a> JK is powered by a 3.6-liter V-6 rated at 285 hp and 260 lb-ft of torque, and it can be paired to either a six-speed manual or a five-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings for the two-door model is 17/21 mpg city/highway regardless of the transmission choice. Opt for four-door Unlimited model and fuel economy ratings drop to 16/20 mpg with the manual or 16/21 mpg with the automatic.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/wrangler-jk/2018/">2018 Jeep Wrangler JK</a> received a three-star rating on the front crash and rollover rating for the Unlimited and a three-star rollover rating for the two-door model (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 Wrangler JK but the 2017 model received a Good score driver’s side front small overlap and moderate front overlap test, Marginal on the side impact, and Poor on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). Two-door models scored Good only on the moderate front overlap test, Poor on the side impact test, Marginal on the driver’s side front small overlap test and Poor on the headlights test. There are no active safety features available on the 2018 Wrangler JK.</p>

<p>The two-door Wrangler JK has 12.8 cubic feet of cargo space behind the rear seats and 56.5 cubic feet behind the front seats. You can also remove the rear seats on the two-door model. Unlimited models have 31.5 cubic feet behind the rear seats and 70.6 cubic feet behind the front seats. When properly equipped, the two-door Wrangler JK can tow up to 2,000 pounds of payload while the four-door Unlimited is rated at 3,500 pounds.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/wrangler-unlimited/2016/2016-jeep-wrangler-unlimited-rubicon-first-test-review/">2016 First Test,</a> we were impressed with the Wrangler JK’s off-road capabilty where it tackled the trails in Moab, Utah with minimal issue. The electronic nannies, while helpful, weren’t really needed anymore because the Wrangler JK has so much capability built in to it that it can crawl over nearly anything. We also put the Wrangler JK in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/land-cruiser/2016/jeep-wrangler-mercedes-benz-g550-toyota-land-cruiser-comparison/">2016 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> G550 and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/land-cruiser/2018/">Toyota Land Cruiser</a> where it placed second due to its sluggish five-speed automatic transmission and lack of power.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/wrangler-jk/2018/">Jeep Wrangler JK</a> was the first Wrangler to use the Pentastar V-6 engine.</p>

<p>With its major redesign last year, the 2018 Compass receives minimal changes. The Limited trim can now be ordered with front-wheel drive.</p>

<p>In Jeep’s six-vehicle lineup, the Compass slots above the smaller Renegade and below the more expensive Wrangler JK, Cherokee, Wrangler JL, and Grand Cherokee.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Compass Sport</strong>: The entry-level trim comes equipped with 16-inch steel wheel painted in low gloss black, the Uconnect 3 infotainment system with a 5.0-inch touchscreen and Bluetooth, a 3.5-inch instrument panel driver’s display, six-way manual front seats, a rearview camera, remote keyless entry, power adjustable and heated side view mirrors, and push-start ignition.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Compass Latitude</strong>: Moving up to the Latitude trims will get you 17-inch silver aluminum wheels, black roof rails, premium cloth and vinyl seats, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, rear seat A/C vents, keyless entry, and automatic headlights.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Compass Limited</strong>: Adding more tech and luxury, the Limited trim comes standard with 18-inch polished aluminum wheels, Uconnect 4 with an 8.4-inch touchscreen and SiriusXM satellite radio, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a 7.0-inch instrument panel driver’s display, leather-trimmed seats with perforated inserts, heated eight-way power adjustable front seats, dual-zone climate control, a 115-volt power outlet, two-tone black roof, and bright roof rails.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Compass Trailhawk</strong>: The rugged Trailhawk packs 17-inch polished aluminum wheels with all-terrain tires, Active Drive Low four-wheel drive system with 20:1 crawl ratio, Selec-Terrain traction control system, off-road suspension, hill descent control, skid plates, black hood decal, and Ruby Red tow hooks.</p>

<p>Available on the Latitude trim, the Popular Equipment group adds lots of features including an eight-way power adjustable driver’s seat, an auto-dimming rearview mirror, remote start ignition, dual-zone climate control, Uconnect 4 with a 7.0-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, SiriusXM satellite radio, a 7.0-inch instrument panel driver’s display, and a 115-volt power outlet.</p>

<p>Powering all Compass models is a 180-hp, 175-lb-ft of torque 2.4-liter I-4 engine that delivers an EPA-rated 23/32 mpg city/highway with the standard six-speed manual transmission and front-wheel drive and 22/31 with all-wheel drive. When backed by the six-speed automatic (only available in front-wheel drive) the Compass is rated at 23/31 mpg. The nine-speed automatic can only be paired with all-wheel drive and delivers 22/30 mpg. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the all-wheel-drive Compass Limited hit 60 mph in a slow 10.5 seconds and hit the quarter-mile in 17.8 seconds at 76.1 mph.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/compass/2018/">2018 Jeep Compass</a> received a four-star overall safety rating out of five stars from the NHTSA. The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/compass/2018/">Jeep Compass</a> is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick for receiving the highest rating of Good in all crash tests and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention test by avoiding both a 12- and 25-mph frontal collision thanks to the automatic emergency braking feature found in the Advanced Safety and Lighting group. That feature group also consists of forward collision warning, lane departure warning and lane keep assist, auto-dimming rearview mirror, automatic high beams, and HID headlights. The Safety and Security group includes blind-spot monitoring, rear-cross traffic alert, rear parking sensors, and rain-sensitive wipers.</p>

<p>The 2018 Jeep Compass offers 27.2 cubic feet of cargo space behind the rear seats and 59.8 cubic feet with the rear seats folded down. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/rogue/2018/">Nissan Rogue</a> Sport has between 19.9 and 22.9 cubic feet behind the rear seats and between 53.3 and 61.1 cubic feet with the rear seats down. Legroom for the Compass is 41.8 inches for the front seats and 38.3 for the rear seats.</p>

<p>The Compass comes standard with the Uconnect 3 infotainment system displayed on a 5.0-inch touchscreen with Bluetooth and media hub that consists of two USB ports and an auxiliary port. The Uconnect 4 system can be displayed on either a 7.0-inch or 8.4-inch touchscreen and adds Apple CarPlay and Android Auto (SiriusXM satellite radio is optional on the 7.0-inch display and standard on the 8.4-inch display). The Uconnect 4C system (8.4-inch touchscreen) features a navigation system and adds SiriusXM Traffic Plus, Travel Link, and Guardian (remote start/stop, honk the horn, turn off the lights, and lock/unlock doors). The standard six-speaker audio system can be upgraded to a nine-speaker Beats audio system.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/crosstrek/2018/no-mans-land/">three-way comparison</a> that included the Compass Trailhawk, Rogue Sport AWD, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/crosstrek/2018/">Subaru Crosstrek</a>, the Compass finished in second place. The Compass’ acceleration was the slowest (9.4 seconds to 60 mph) and fuel economy was also the lowest of the three. The engine revs slowly and is loud and the nine-speed automatic transmission shifts slow but it smoother than in other earlier Jeep models. On the road, “The steering wheel loads up nicely through corners, and the off-road-oriented tires start to squeal far before the Jeep is ever at risk of losing grip. The Compass Trailhawk’s ride is also particularly noteworthy—it eats up harsh pavement and potholes without transmitting any of the impacts into the cabin.”</p>

<p>We didn’t care for the interior’s cheap components and seats that lacked lateral support. Off-road capability was very impressive: “Even in its default Auto mode, the Compass stomps through the off-road obstacles. Placed in Snow or Sand mode, the Jeep exhibits seemingly endless traction.”</p>

<p>“If all-wheel-drive capability is your priority, the Trailhawk might seem to be the best option. However, our winner [the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/">Subaru</a> Crosstrek] proved to be just as capable off the beaten path while even better to drive on pavement,” we concluded.</p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/jeep-compass-2018-suv-of-the-year-contender/">2018 Motor Trend SUV of the Year testing</a>, the Compass Trailhawk and Limited 4×4 did not make the finalist cut due to the lack of power and the slow-shifting transmission. However, we did like the crossover’s new styling, value, and off-road capability.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>The all-new <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/wrangler/2018/">2018 Jeep Wrangler</a> features an optional turbocharged engine, a redesigned interior, and the latest version of FCA’s UConnect infotainment system. <em>Now</em> c<em>alled the Wrangler JK, <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/wrangler-jk/2018/">the last-generation Wrangler will be sold alongside the new one</a>.</em></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/wrangler/2018/">Jeep Wrangler</a> is a four-wheel drive off-road-oriented SUV that’s available in a two-door layout or a four-door called the Wrangler Unlimited. Four trim levels are available on the new 2018 Wrangler.</p>

<p><strong>Wrangler Sport: </strong>The base Wrangler Sport comes with fog lights, 17-inch steel wheels, keyless start, cloth upholstery, an eight-speaker audio system, a USB port, and a rearview camera.</p>

<p><strong>Wrangler Sport S: </strong>Moving up to the Sport S adds power windows and door locks, 17-inch aluminum wheels, single-zone air conditioning, and keyless entry.</p>

<p><strong>Wrangler Sahara: </strong>Available only on the four-door Wrangler Unlimited, the Sahara trim comes standard with a 115-volt outlet in the center console, 18-inch alloy wheels, automatic headlights, dual-zone climate control, LED interior ambient lighting, FCA’s UConnect infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, and an additional USB port for the second row.</p>

<p><strong>Wrangler Rubicon: </strong>The most off-road capable Wrangler, the Rubicon adds Dana 44 solid front and rear heavy duty axles, electronically locking front and rear differentials, a more capable four-wheel-drive system with a 4:1 low gear ratio, two-piece fender flares, and 17-inch allow wheels shod with all-terrain tires.</p>

<p>Notable options include an Alpine premium audio system, FCA’s UConnect interface with a 7.0-inch or 8.4-inch touchscreen, navigation, heated front seats, a heated steering wheel, LED headlights, a 7.0-inch multi-information display, rear parking sensors, leather upholstery, and Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration.</p>

<p>One of the key differences between the two- and four-door Wrangler models is that the two-door seats four, but the four-door — also known as the Wrangler Unlimited — seats five. At 96.8 inches, the two-door Wrangler’s wheelbase is 21.6 inches shorter than the Unlimited’s. The breakover angle on the two-door is about 5 degrees better than the Unlimited, but the four-door’s departure angle is slightly superior at 36.1 degrees versus the two-door’s 35.9 degrees (with the 245/75R17s on the Sport trim).</p>

<p>In terms of exterior dimensions, the two-door Wrangler is significantly shorter in length at 166.8 inches versus the Unlimited, which checks in at 188.4 inches. Both the two- and four-door models are 73.8 inches wide and 73.6 inches tall.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/">Jeep</a> Wrangler is powered by a 3.6-liter V-6 with 285 hp and 260 lb-ft of torque; a six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic transmission are available. A 2.0-liter turbo-four with 270 hp and 295 lb-ft is optional and paired exclusively with the eight-speed automatic. A 3.0-liter turbodiesel V-6 with 260 hp and 442 lb-ft will follow in the near future and come paired exclusively with the eight-speed automatic.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the 3.6-liter V-6-equipped four-door Unlimited models are 17/23 mpg city/highway with the manual and 18/23 mpg with the automatic. If you’re looking for the ratings on the EPA’s site, search for what’s currently called “New Wrangler Unlimited.” Ratings for the 2.0-liter turbo-four-powered models and the new two-door Wrangler haven’t been released yet.</p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Jeep Wrangler yet. Blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert is available on the Sport S, Sahara and Rubicon trims as part of the Jeep Active Safety group.</p>

<p>The four-door 2018 Wrangler Unlimited has 31.7 cubic feet behind the second row and can be expanded to 72.4 cubic feet. Four-door models can tow up to 3,500 pounds when properly equipped.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/wrangler/2018/2018-jeep-wrangler-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive review</a>, we were impressed that the new Wrangler featured more on-road ride comfort without sacrificing its vaunted off-road capability. The 3.6-liter V-6, however, feels lacking on the larger four-door Wrangler Unlimited. When equipped with the optional turbo-four, the Wrangler remains plenty capable off-road. The eight-speed automatic transmission continues to be a gem with its quick and smooth shifts, and well-calibrated computer that knows what gear to be in at all times.</p>

<p>The 2018 Jeep Wrangler is the first Wrangler to utilize the new 2.0-liter turbo-four in FCA’s range.</p>

<p>Jeep changes the Cherokee’s trim lineup by adding a new Latitude Plus and Latitude with Tech Connect trims and removing the former base Sport trim and Sport Altitude trim, making the Latitude the new base trim. The High Altitude trim has also been removed from the lineup. The Trailhawk and Limited trims receive more standard features. The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/cherokee/2019/2019-jeep-cherokee-first-drive-review/">2019-model-year Cherokee</a> gets an extensive refresh with a newly available turbo-four engine.</p>

<p>The Cherokee slots in the middle of Jeep SUV and crossover lineup, positioned above the less expensive Renegade, Compass, and Wrangler JK and below the more expensive new Wrangler JL, and the flagship Grand Cherokee.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Cherokee Latitude</strong>: The base Latitude trim equips the 2.4-liter I-4 and comes standard with 17-inch aluminum wheels, a 5.0-inch center touchscreen with Uconnect 3 infotainment system with Bluetooth, a media port hub (12-volt, auxiliary, SD card, and USB ports), a 3.5-inch instrument panel driver’s display, a five-mode traction control system (4×4 only), automatic HID headlights, fog lights, a rearview camera, a six-way manual driver’s seat, and roof rails.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Cherokee Latitude with Tech Connect</strong>: The Latitude with Tech Content adds an 8.4-inch touchscreen with Uconnect 3C and navigation, 4G connectivity, an Alpine premium audio system, 18-inch aluminum wheels, and Gloss Black exterior accents. This trim also adds Alexa with a free Echo Dot and a three-month trial to Audible and Amazon Music.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Cherokee Latitude Plus</strong>: Building off the Latitude’s features, the Latitude Plus trim makes the 3.2-liter V-6 available and adds an 8.4-inch touchscreen with Uconnect 3C and Uconnect Access, SiriusXM satellite radio, quick entry with push-start ignition, leather and cloth seating, an eight-way power driver’s seat, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and a fold-flat front passenger seat.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Cherokee Limited</strong>: Moving up to the Limited trim, the Cherokee receives a larger 7.0-inch instrument panel driver’s display, 18-inch aluminum wheels, leather-trimmed seats, heated front seats and steering wheel, a power liftgate, remote vehicle start, rear parking sensors, and blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Cherokee Trailhawk</strong>: Enhancing off-road capability, the rugged Trailhawk adds 17-inch polished and painted off-road aluminum wheels with all-terrain tires, the Active Drive Lock 4×4 system with Selec-Terrain drive modes including Rock mode, upgraded off-road suspension, a 1.0-inch suspension lift, skid plates, accent-colored tow hooks, a unique off-road fascia, and exclusive Trailhawk seats with Nappa leather-trimmed bolsters and Ruby Red accent stitching.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Cherokee Overland</strong>: Adding to the Cherokee Limited’s features, the top Overland trim comes standard with an 8.4-inch touchscreen with Uconnect 3C with navigation, 18-inch polished aluminum wheels, body-color fascia and cladding, heated and ventilated Nappa leather-trimmed front seats, a premium leather-wrapped instrument panel, a leather-wrapped steering wheel with wood trim, eight-way power passenger’s seat, and a nine-speaker Alpine premium audio system. The 3.2-liter V-6 becomes standard on the Overland with four-wheel drive.</p>

<p>If you plan to do some serious off-roading in your Cherokee, opt for the Heavy Duty Protection package that consists of skip plates for the fuel tank, front suspension, transmission, and underbody (also includes a full-size spare tire).</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/cherokee/2018/">2018 Jeep Cherokee</a>’s standard engine is a 2.4-liter I-4 that produces 184-hp and 171 lb-ft of torque and is backed by a nine-speed automatic transmission routing power to the front wheels or to an all-wheel drive system. With two-wheel drive, the engine delivers an EPA-rated 21/30 mpg city/highway, 21/28 mpg with the Active Drive I all-wheel-drive system, 21/27 mpg with the Active Drive II four-wheel-drive system, and 19/25 mpg in the four-wheel-drive-equipped Trailhawk. Also backed by a nine-speed automatic, the 271-hp, 239-lb-ft 3.2-liter V-6 delivers 21/29 mpg with front-wheel drive, 20/27 mpg with the Active Drive I system, 18/26 mpg with the Active Drive II system, and 18/24 in the Trailhawk. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the Cherokee Latitude with Active Drive II hit 60 mph in 6.8 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 122 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/cherokee/2018/">Jeep Cherokee</a> received a four-star overall safety rating out of five stars from the NHTSA. In IIHS testing, the 2018 Cherokee was issued the second-lowest rating of Marginal for the driver-side small overlap front crash test and the highest rating of Good in four other crash tests. The Cherokee received the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention test by avoiding a 12 mph collision and reducing the speed of a 25 mph collision by 12 mph. The SafetyTec group (available on Latitude Plus) includes the following driver assist safety features: blind-spot monitoring, rear-cross traffic alert, and rear parking sensors. The Technology group (available on the Limited, Overland, and Trailhawk trims) consists of forward collision warning with automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning, rain-sensing windshield wipers, automatic high beams, adaptive cruise control with stop and go, and a self-parking system.</p>

<p>The Cherokee can hold between 26.4 and 29.1 cubic feet of cargo behind the rear seats (depending on the position of the slidable rear seats) and 54.9 cubic feet with the rear seats folded down (58.9 cubic feet with the optional fold-flat front passenger seat). The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/escape/2018/">Ford Escape</a> tops that with 34.0 and 68.0 cubic feet, respectively. The front seats offer 41.1 inches of legroom and 40.3 inches for the rear seats.</p>

<p>The 2018 Cherokee’s standard infotainment system consists of a 5.0-inch touchscreen with Uconnect 3 with Bluetooth, and a media hub (12-volt outlet, auxiliary, SD card, and USB ports). The upgraded system features an 8.4-inch screen with the Uconnect 3C system, SiriusXM satellite radio, an additional USB port, and can be optioned with a navigation system (also includes SiriusXM Traffic and Travel) and 4G connectivity. The standard instrument panel driver’s display is 3.5 inches but can upgraded to a 7.0-inch display. A nine-speaker Alpine premium audio system is optional (standard on Overland) and replaced the standard six-speaker system. The Technology group consists of a suite of driver assist safety features and a self-parking system.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/cherokee/2016/2016-jeep-cherokee-v-6-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2016 Cherokee Latitude with Active Drive II (V-6), the Jeep handled its heavyweight well and feels quick around town. At the track, acceleration was on par with some turbo-four rivals and braking was strong. The nine-speed automatic has improved but still delivers some rough shifts. Handling dynamics are similar to a true SUV—top heavy and tippy—and not fun like some competitors. The liftover height for the cargo area and access to the rear seats is high but rear seat space is good. The interior is nicely detailed but the “build quality isn’t quite as detailed, and we noticed several small squeaks and rattles on rougher pavement.”</p>

<p>“Whether it’s the unmistakable styling or the unstoppable attitude, there’s just something endearing about the Jeep Cherokee that makes you want to love it,” we wrote. “If we’re being rational, we might say the poor small front overlap crash test result might outweigh the overachieving (but low for the segment) fuel economy (Real MPG scored it at 21.8/28.1/24.2 mpg city/highway/combined compared to the EPA’s 19/26/22), but car purchases are often emotional choices, and this Jeep just gets us. When everything else is a car on stilts, a crossover that actually drives like an SUV is special to the right kind of person.”</p>

<p>However, in a more mainstream-consumer-focused <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-5/2016/small-crossover-comparison-big-test/">2016/2017 Big Test of nine small crossovers</a>, the Jeep Cherokee came in last place: “Were the criteria for Big Test less consumer-oriented and more enthusiast-oriented, odds are this Jeep would be much higher on this list.”</p>

<p>“As much as we all liked our V-6-powered Jeep Cherokee Latitude tester’s styling and off-road ability, we relegated it to ninth place because of poor crash test scores, high cost of ownership, and low fuel economy.”</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/soul/2018/">2018 Kia Soul</a> gets the UVO3 interface and automatic climate control as standard on all trims. Active safety features such as automatic emergency braking and adaptive cruise control are now available on the Plus trim with the optional Primo package.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/soul/2018/">Kia Soul</a> is a tall compact wagon that comes exclusively in front-drive configuration. In addition to the gas-powered models, the Soul is also available as an EV model with an EPA-estimated range of 93 miles on a single charge.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Soul offers three engines (in addition to the electric model) including a base 1.6-liter I-4 with 130 hp and 118 lb-ft of torque, a 2.0-liter I-4 rated at 161 hp and 150 lb-ft, and a turbocharged 1.6-liter I-4 with 201 hp and 195 lb-ft. A six-speed manual is standard on the base 1.6-liter and a six-speed automatic is optional. The 2.0-liter I-4 comes exclusive with a six-speed automatic while the 1.6-liter turbo-four is paired to a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic. EPA fuel economy ratings for the base model are 24/30 mpg city/highway with the manual or 25/30 mpg with the automatic. The 2.0-liter is rated at 25/30 and the turbocharged 1.6-liter I-4 is rated at 26/31 mpg, making it the most fuel efficient Soul despite also being the most powerful. Thanks to its boxy shape, the 2018 Soul has 24.2 cubic feet of space behind the 60/40 split-folding rear seats and it can be expanded to 61.3 cubic feet. However, when it’s equipped with the removable underfloor tray, it drops to 18.8 cubic feet and 49.5 cubic feet, respectively.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base 2018 Soul include 16-inch alloy wheels, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/">Kia</a>’s UVO3 interface, a six-speaker audio system, cloth upholstery, 60/40 split-folding rear seats, a USB port, and Bluetooth. Higher trim levels can be had with a rearview camera, HID headlights, LED fog lights, heated and ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, a heated steering wheel, a 4.3-inch multi-information display, navigation, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, leather upholstery, power-adjustable front seats, additional USB ports, keyless entry/start, and alloy wheels up to 18 inches in diameter.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Soul a five-star overall safety score (out of a possible five stars). Although the IIHS hasn’t crash tested the 2018 Soul, a 2017 model received a Good score on all crash worthiness tests (Good is the highest possible score). When equipped with the Primo package, the mid-grade Soul Plus gets adaptive cruise control, automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning, and forward collision warning. Blind spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert are bundled separately and are available on the Plus and Exclaim trims.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think<br/></strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/soul/2014/2014-kia-soul-first-test/">2014 First Test</a>, we said that the Soul offers excellent interior space thanks to its boxy shape. Additionally, the cabin stays quiet on the highway and the ride is comfortable. However, the 2.0-liter I-4’s power is merely adequate, making it feel like it’s struggling going uphill.</p>

<p>The turbocharged Soul Exclaim gives the Soul the power it needs and uses a dual-clutch transmission, which we found quick to shift in a 2017 <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/soul/2017/2017-kia-soul-turbo-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a>. Put the car into Sport mode and it keeps the car in the meat of its power band, so you’ve always got power on tap for accelerating and merging. The Soul Exclaim’s wider tires, however, do cause the cabin to get noisy on poor surfaces and the steering isn’t very communicative especially in Normal mode.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>On the Plus and Exclaim trims, the Soul can be had with speaker lights that change colors.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/optima/2018/">Kia Optima</a> Hybrid and Optima Hybrid Plug-In are carryover models for 2018 and did not receive any significant changes.</p>

<p>The Optima Hybrid and Plug-In are the only hybrid sedans offered by <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/">Kia</a>. The two four-doors are positioned above the more affordable Niro hybrid and Niro plug-in hybrid wagons.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Optima Hybrid Premium</strong>: When compared to the traditional Optima, the Hybrid models come with a unique grille, front and rear bumper valences, and side sills. Standard features include 16-inch wheels, active grille shutters, Smart Trunk (opens automatically by standing behind it with the key fob), a drive mode selector, a 7.0-inch center touchscreen with SiriusXM satellite radio and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, Bluetooth, USB and auxiliary ports, a 4.3-inch instrument panel driver’s display, automatic headlights, dual-zone automatic climate control, 8-way manually adjustable driver’s seat (six-way for passenger), and a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Optima Hybrid EX</strong>: The top Hybrid EX trim adds 17-inch alloy wheels, an 8.0-inch center touchscreen with a navigation system with SiriusXM Traffic and HD radio, a 10-speaker Harman Kardon QuantumLogic sound system, two USB ports, quick-entry with push-start ignition, rear A/C vents, leather seating, 12-way power driver’s seat, heated front seats, and a heated steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Optima Plug-In Hybrid EX</strong>: The Plug-In model comes in one well-equipped trim and adds a slightly more powerful hybrid powertrain and a charging station charge port. The Plug-In EX trim has the same standard features as the Hybrid EX model but adds exclusive blue exterior accents and badging, the Active Eco system (a system to help the vehicle achieve optimum fuel economy), and an electronic parking brake with auto hold.</p>

<p>Both EX trims offer a Technology package that consists of steering-responsive LED headlights, high beam assist, a panoramic sunroof, ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, rear side window sunshades, LED interior lighting, a 10-way power adjustable passenger’s seat, and a suite of driver assist safety features.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/optima/2018/">2018 Kia Optima</a> Hybrid utilizes a hybrid powertrain consisting of a 154-hp, 140 lb-ft of torque 2.0-liter I-4 engine and an electric motor for a combined output of 192 hp and 271 lb-ft (202 hp and 276 lb-ft for the Plug-In model). A six-speed automatic sends power to the front wheels for both models. The Optima Hybrid delivers an EPA-rated 39/46 mpg and the Plug-In is rated at 38/43 mpg when operating like a hybrid but can also go up to 29 miles on all-electric power (103 mpg-e).</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/optima-hybrid/2018/">2018 Kia Optima Hybrid</a> received the highest five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (the Plug-In was not tested). The 2018 Kia Optima (non-hybrid) is considered a 2018 Top Safety Pick from the IIHS for receiving the highest rating of Good in all crash tests and in the headlights evaluation, and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention test by avoiding 12- and 25-mph frontal collisions thanks to the automatic emergency braking system found in the Technology package. The Technology package also adds adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, lane departure warning, high beam assist, blind-spot monitoring, lane change assist, rear cross-traffic alert, and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/optima-hybrid/2018/">Kia Optima Hybrid</a> offers up to 13.4 cubic feet of cargo space in the trunk while the Plug-In model offers 9.9 cubic feet thanks to the larger battery pack. The non-hybrid Optima holds up to 15.9 cubic feet of cargo space. All Optima models have 45.5 inches of legroom for the front seats and 35.6 inches for the rear seats.</p>

<p>The 2018 Optima comes well-equipped with a standard 7.0-inch center touchscreen with SiriusXM satellite radio and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, Bluetooth, and a 4.3-inch instrument panel driver’s display. The center touchscreen can be updated to an 8.0-inch display with a navigation system, SiriusXM Traffic, and HD radio. The standard six-speaker audio system can be upgraded to a 10-speaker Harman Kardon premium sound system. The standard UVO eServices app can among other things help you find your vehicle in a parking lot, look up vehicle information and points of interest, and call for roadside assistance.</p>

<p>We have yet to test a Kia Optima Hybrid or Plug-In but we did test the similar <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata/2016/">2016 Hyundai Sonata</a> Hybrid in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata-hybrid/2016/2016-hyundai-sonata-hybrid-first-test/">First Test review</a> and concluded by saying, “At $35,550, the 2016 Sonata Hybrid isn’t cheap, but when you consider an array of features usually found on pricier cars, the price starts making sense. Except for minor fit and finish issues and non-linear brakes, the Sonata Hybrid is a solid proposition, offering value, fuel efficiency, a smooth powertrain, and a well-appointed interior. In fact, the hybrid delivers similar levels of performance as its gas-only siblings but with the bonus of stellar fuel economy.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata-plug-in/2016/2016-hyundai-sonata-plug-hybrid-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the Optima Plug-In’s sibling, the similar <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata/2018/">Hyundai Sonata</a> Plug-In, we said, “The Sonata PHEV offers a great blend of fuel efficiency, power, generous EV-only range, and user-friendly technology.”</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/stinger/2018/">2018 Kia Stinger</a> is an all-new model for the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/">Kia</a> brand and is its first sports sedan.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/stinger/2018/">Kia Stinger</a> is a midsize sports four-door that features a fastback roofline and a large hatch. Rear-wheel drive comes standard and all-wheel drive is optional.</p>

<p><script type="text/javascript">!function(e,n,t){var o,c=e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];e.getElementById(t)||(o=e.createElement(n),o.id=t,o.src="//connect.facebook.net/en_US/sdk.js#xfbml=1&version=v2.2",c.parentNode.insertBefore(o,c))}(document,"script","facebook-jssdk");</script></p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The Stinger is offered with two engines including a 2.0-liter turbo-four rated at 255 hp and 260 lb-ft of torque, and a 3.3-liter twin-turbo V-6 with 365 hp and 376 lb-ft. Both engines are paired exclusively to an eight-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p>Available features include LED headlights, Kia’s UVO infotainment system, leather upholstery, a head-up display, a Harman/Kardon premium audio system, blind spot warning, and a multi-information display between the gauges. Rear-drive models come standard with a mechanical limited-slip differential, while all-wheel-drive-equipped cars have torque vectoring control instead. The Stinger is also the first Kia to feature an adaptive suspension system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Kia Stinger. Available active safety features include adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, lane keeping assist, rear cross-traffic alert, and driver attention assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>We have yet to drive the production-spec 2018 Kia Stinger but we expect it to be a car that should drift easily in rear-drive guise, as we noted on our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/kia-stinger-gt-first-look/">First Look</a>. The rear-drive 3.3-liter twin-turbo V-6-equipped Stinger GT should be the most potent and driver-focused variant of the Korean brand’s first sports sedan.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Kia Stinger’s exterior design was inspired by the GT Concept that first debuted at the 2011 Frankfurt auto show.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/sedona/2018/">2018 Kia Sedona</a> is unchanged except for the some exterior color updates. Silky Silver replaces Bright Silver and Celestial Blue replaces Midnight Sapphire. Beachwood Pearl has been discontinued.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/sedona/2018/">Kia Sedona</a> is a front-drive minivan with seating for up to eight passengers and is available in five trim levels.</p>

<p><strong>Sedona L</strong>: The base Sedona L comes with 17-inch alloy wheels, cloth upholstery, a sliding second row, a 5.0-inch touchscreen, a four-speaker audio system, Bluetooth connectivity, a USB port, keyless entry, and a rearview camera.</p>

<p><strong>Sedona LX</strong>: Moving up to the LX trim adds power-folding side mirrors, power sliding doors, eight passenger seating, eight-way power adjustable front seats, a 3.5-inch multi-information display, and six-speaker audio system.</p>

<p><strong>Sedona EX</strong>: Mid-level EX models adds 18-inch alloy wheels, fog lights, silver roof rails, leather upholstery, heated front seats, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, tri-zone climate control, a larger 7.0-inch touchscreen, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, additional USB ports, keyless start, and front and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>Sedona SX</strong>: The second highest trim adds LED taillights, a power-operated passenger seat, ventilated front seats, an Infinity premium audio system, a drive mode selector, heated second row seats, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, and blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert.</p>

<p><strong>Sedona SXL: </strong>As the most luxurious variant of the Sedona, the SXL trim adds HID headlights, 19-inch alloy wheels, a mesh grille, a heated steering wheel, and a 360-degree view camera system. Nappa leather upholstery, dual sunroofs, and second-row captain’s chairs are optional only on the SXL.</p>

<p>The 2018 Sedona is powered exclusively by a 3.3-liter V-6 with 276 hp and 248 lb-ft of torque paired to a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 18/24 mpg city/highway for the L, LX and EX trims. The SX trim is the most efficient at 18/25 mpg while the range-topping SXL grade is the least efficient at 17/22 mpg.</p>

<p>In NHTSA testing, the 2018 Sedona received a five-star overall rating (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to fully test the 2018 Sedona but the 2017 model received a Good score on five crashworthiness tests, and in the headlights test, the 2017 model received a Poor rating (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Sedona received a Superior rating after it avoided 12- and 25-mph collisions (Superior is the highest rating for the front crash prevention test). As a result, the Sedona received the 2017 Top Safety Pick award from the IIHS.</p>

<p>Active safety and driver assistance features are available on the LX trim and higher and it includes lane departure warning, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, adaptive cruise control, blind spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/cadenza/2018/">2018 Kia Cadenza</a> has 33.9 cubic feet of cargo space behind the third row, 78.4 cubic feet behind the second row, and 142 cubic feet behind the front seats. When properly equipped, the 2018 Sedona can tow up to 3,500 pounds.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/sedona/2015/2015-kia-sedona-sxl-first-test/">2015 First Test</a>, we said it offers a comfortable ride and respectable handling for its size. The second row, especially with the optional captain’s chairs, offer high levels of comfort. However, the third row is on the tight side, particularly with the sunroof that eats into passenger head room. There’s also a lack of folding second row seat stowage, which means the Sedona isn’t as practical as rivals such as the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/pacifica/2018/">Chrysler Pacifica</a>.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/town-&amp;-country/2015/the-big-test-2014-2015-minivans/">2015 comparison tes</a>t that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/sienna/2018/">Toyota Sienna</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/odyssey/2018/">Honda Odyssey</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> Quest, and the recently discontinued <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/">Chrysler</a> Town &amp; Country, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/">Kia</a> Sedona won because of its combination of style, comfort, and respectable driving dynamics. Its interior was also the best of the bunch with high quality materials all around, Nappa leather upholstery, and a comfortable second row.</p>

<p>The optional second-row captain’s chairs on the 2018 Sedona were inspired by long haul first class seats on airplanes.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/sorento/2018/">2018 Kia Sorento</a>’s base L trim receives a rearview camera and auto on/off headlights, and the LX 2.4 model now offers a Cool &amp; Connected package. All-wheel-drive variants of the LX 2.4 grade now come standard with third-row seating. EX 2.0 Turbo models get the hands-free <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/smart/">smart</a> power liftgate, power-folding side mirrors, a 7.0-inch multi-information display, an auto-dimming rearview mirror, and auto up/down passenger windows as standard. The EX V-6 adds automatic emergency braking and a new Advanced Touring package option in addition to the same new standard features found on the EX 2.0 Turbo. Rain-sensing wipers and an auto-dimming rearview mirror now come standard on the SX trim.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting above the compact Sportage, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/sorento/2018/">Kia Sorento</a> is a midsize crossover that’s available in front- or all-wheel-drive configurations and five- or seven-seat layouts.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Sorento offers three engines including a base 2.4-liter I-4 with 185 hp and 178 lb-ft of torque, a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 240 hp and 260 lb-ft that’s available only on the EX trim, and a 3.3-liter V-6 with 290 hp and 252 lb-ft. All three engines are paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. Towing capacity is 2,000 pounds for the base 2.4-liter, 3,500 pounds for the 2.0-liter turbo-four, and 5,000 pounds for the V-6. Cargo space behind the third row is 11.3 cubic feet, 38.8 cubic feet behind the second row, and 73.5 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings are 21/28 mpg city/highway for the base 2.4-liter in front-drive guise and 21/25 mpg with all-wheel drive. The 2.0-liter turbo-four is slightly less efficient at 20/27 mpg with front-wheel drive and 19/25 mpg with all-wheel drive. Models with the V-6 are the least efficient at 18/25 mpg in front-drive configuration and 17/23 mpg in all-wheel-drive guise.</p>

<p>The base L trim comes with 17-inch alloy wheels, a six-speaker audio system, Bluetooth connectivity, cloth upholstery, a USB port, a rearview camera, and 40/20/40 spit-folding second row seats. Higher trim levels can be had with a larger 7.0- or 8.0-inch touchscreen, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/">Kia</a>’s UVO multimedia interface, navigation, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay, an Infinity premium audio system, additional USB ports, a surround view camera system, HID headlights, leather or Nappa leather upholstery, keyless entry/start, heated and ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, dual-zone climate control, a heated steering wheel, and a panoramic sunroof.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Sorento a five-star overall safety rating (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS evaluations, 2018 Sorento received a Good score on all but the new headlights test where it received an Acceptable score (Good is the highest possible score). Thanks to its strong performance on the front crash prevention test where it avoided a 12- and 25-mph collision, the 2018 Sorento receive a Superior rating (Superior is the highest score in the front crash prevention test). As a result, the crossover was awarded the Top Safety Pick+ rating</p>

<p>On all but the base L trim, a full suite of active driver assistance and safety features is available or standard equipment. The tech includes forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, adaptive cruise control, and lane departure warning. Blind spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert are only available on certain trim levels.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/sorento/2016/2016-kia-sorento-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we noted that the 2.0-liter turbo-four suffers from slow throttle response but features plenty of torque for passing; however, it was barely quicker than the base 2.4-liter in our acceleration tests. The larger V-6 engine offers significantly better acceleration but its driving dynamics remain similar to four-cylinder-equipped models, meaning it’s easy to maneuver thanks to its tight turning radius. Interior noise levels are kept in check with minimal road and wind noise entering the cabin. Ride comfort, on the other hand, is excellent thanks to a revised suspension while handling veers more towards relaxed than sporty Material quality, especially in the SX Limited trim, is excellent, and the infotainment system is user-friendly. With the third row in place, cargo space does take a hit and it’s best suited for children on long trips.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Sorento’s optional 2.0-liter turbo-four is also used in the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/optima/2018/">Kia Optima</a> and Sportage, and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata/2018/">Hyundai Sonata</a> and Santa Fe Sport.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The biggest news for the 2018 Niro is that the Touring model now comes standard with HID headlights, Autonomous Emergency Braking, a Forward Collision Warning system, a Lane Keep Assist system, adaptive cruise control, and a wireless phone charger. The new Touring Graphite Edition includes Platinum Graphite paint, Glossy Black 18-inch wheels, Glossy Black roof rails, metallic colored grille, 10-way power driver’s seat with adjustable lumbar, and an 8.0-inch display screen with navigation and a Harmon Kardon premium audio system. The Lane Keep Assist system is now included in the Advanced Technology package and an auto-dimming rearview mirror is now standard on the EX model.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The Niro hybrid is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/">Kia</a>’s hybrid-only crossover-like front-drive hatchback that carries a base price that’s about the same as that of the Optima sedan and Sportage crossover. In Kia’s two-car hybrid lineup, the Niro slots below the Optima Hybrid. The <strong>Niro Plug-In Hybrid</strong> debuts for the 2018 model year, and will slot below the Optima Plug-In Hybrid in price.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/niro/2018/">2018 Kia Niro</a> is powered by a hybrid powertrain consisting of a 104-hp, 109-lb-ft of torque 1.6-liter I-4 engine paired to a 43-hp, 125-lb-ft of torque electric motor that has a combined power output of 139 hp and 195 lb-ft of torque. A six-speed dual-clutch automatic routes power to the front wheels.
