The base <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/niro/2018/">Kia Niro</a> FE delivers an impressive EPA-rated 52/49 mpg city/highway but mid-level Niros are rated at 51/46 mpg. The range-topping Touring model has the lowest fuel economy rating at 46/40 mpg. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the Kia Niro hit 60 mph in 8.7 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 134 feet.</p>

<p>The Niro FE comes standard with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, 16-inch wheels, automatic headlights, rear spoiler, matte black front grille, a 4.2-inch instrument cluster display, woven and knit cloth seats, six-way adjustable driver’s seat, dual-zone automatic climate control, and Drive Mode Select (Active Eco and Sport modes). At the top end of the Niro range is the Touring model, which comes loaded with 18-inch alloy wheels, power-folding heated side-view mirrors, Gloss Black front grille, power moonroof, satin chrome inside door handles, leather upholstery, 10-way power adjustable driver’s seat, heated and ventilated front seats, leather-wrapped and heated steering wheel, rear A/C vents, an 8.0-inch touchscreen with navigation, an eight-speaker Harman Kardon premium audio system, rear USB charger, and a wireless phone charger.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Kia Niro is available with a suite of driver assist safety features: Autonomous Emergency Braking with Pedestrian Detection, Forward Collision Warning, Lane Keep Assist, and adaptive cruise control are standard on the Touring model and optional on the LX and EX models (not available on the FE model). Blind-spot monitoring with Lane Change Assist and rear cross traffic alert are standard on the EX and Touring models (not available on the FE or LX models). A rearview camera is standard;  front and rear parking sensors are standard on the Touring model.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/niro/2017/2017-kia-niro-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2017 Kia Niro, we praised it for its non-hybrid looks, smooth shifting six-speed dual-clutch, and flat-folding rear seats. We also appreciated the seamless shift between EV mode and hybrid mode and felt the Niro had good regenerative braking. Interior space is good for a small crossover-like hatch and we appreciated all the available driver assist safety features. Negatives include too much wind noise. “Kia has a solid strategy, but time will tell whether the Niro wins a piece of the hybrid market.”</p>

<p>When we drove a Kia Niro again for a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/niro/2017/2017-kia-niro-hybrid-first-test-review/">First Test review</a>, we liked the quick acceleration for the segment and the good fuel economy, but the Prius does offer better fuel economy. We liked the smooth transition from EV to gas power and the hybrid’s Sport mode. Braking performance at the track was not that good and there was too much tire noise, but the ride was comfortable and interior space was good for passengers. We concluded by saying, “The Niro hybrid isn’t a standout performer, but there is value in its pricing, and there’s lots of room for your Uber or Lyft passengers. When you’re ready to appreciate the Niro’s longer driving range and quiet city operation, Kia finally has something to offer buyers who don’t want the segment’s most popular entry: the Prius.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Kia Niro shares the same powertrain and platform as the smaller <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/ioniq/2018/">Hyundai Ioniq</a> that delivers an impressive 57/59 mpg city/highway (Blue model), topping the Niro FE model that manages 52/49 mpg.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/">Kia</a> expands the Forte sedan’s features-list by adding cruise control as standard on the base LX model and including UVO3 with Android Auto and Apple CarPlay on the Popular package. The S model receives a new 16-inch alloy wheel design, the Technology package now includes a moonroof and the Premium package has been discontinued. Kia also expands the Forte’s safety features by adding rear cross-traffic alert and blind-spot monitoring with Lane Change Assist as standard on the top EX model. The Forte5 hatchback will likely receive similar updates.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>Kia’s compact Forte sedan is positioned above the subcompact Rio but below the large and more expensive Optima, Cadenza, Stinger, and K900 sedans. The Forte has a similar starting price as the Soul, Kia’s crossover-like hatchback.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>Powering the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/forte/2018/">2018 Kia Forte</a> LX and S sedans is a 147-hp, 132 lb-ft of torque 2.0-liter I-4 engine that delivers 25/34 mpg city/highway when backed by a standard six-speed manual transmission and 29/37 mpg with a six-speed automatic. Found in the range-topping EX sedan is a direct-injection 2.0-liter I-4 that produces 164 hp and 151 lb-ft of torque and is rated at 25/33 mpg with the six-speed automatic (not available with the manual transmission).</p>

<p>The Forte5 hatchback uses the 164-hp 2.0-liter I-4 paired to the six-speed automatic in the base LX and EX trims and comes rated at 25/34 mpg. The top SX model packs a 1.6-liter turbocharged I-4 that pumps out 201 hp and 195 lb-ft of torque and is rated at 25/30 mpg with the seven-speed dual-clutch transmission and 23/29 mpg with the six-speed manual. The Forte and Forte5 are only available in front wheel drive.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/forte/2018/">Kia Forte</a> is available with 17-inch alloy wheels, LED daytime running lights, HID headlights that turn in the direction the car is traveling, LED taillights, power-folding and heated side view mirrors, a power moonroof, a 4.2-inch instrument cluster display, 10-way power adjustable heated and ventilated leather front seats, a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, dual-zone automatic climate control, and a 7.0-inch center display with the UVO3 infotainment system and navigation and Android Auto and Apple CarPlay. The Forte5 is also available with all the above features as well as 18-inch alloy wheels, perimeter approach lighting, puddle lamps, gloss black side view mirrors, dual chrome exhaust finishers, Sport front and rear fascia with red accents, metal pedals, two-way power driver’s lumbar support, and soft-touch front upper door panels.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Forte received a five-star overall rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The Forte5 hatchback received five stars for the side crash test and four stars for the rollover evaluation (an overall rating has not been issued). The 2017 Forte sedan is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick+ – the IIHS’ highest award – because the sedan received the highest score of Good in all five crash test evaluations and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention test by avoiding a frontal  collision in 12- and 25 mph tests thanks to the available Autonomous Emergency Braking system found in the Technology or Premium packages (depending on the model). Those packages also include the remaining driver assist safety features: Forward Collision Warning system, a lane departure warning system, lane keep assist system, HID headlights, blind-spot monitoring, Lane Change Assist and rear cross traffic alert.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/kia-forte-2017-car-of-the-year-contender/">2017 <em>Motor Trend</em> Car of the Year testing</a>, the refreshed 2017 Kia Forte sedan did not make it as a finalist. We liked the refreshed exterior styling and loads of value but found that the acceleration and fuel economy lagged behind some competitors. The interior is not much to look at and the ride is too firm: “The Forte is a solid, well-behaved, value-priced commodity car, but it’s nothing special. Playing catch-up doesn’t get you into the finalist circle.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Thanks to direct injection (versus port injection), the 2.0-liter I-4 in the EX model produces an extra 17 hp and 19 lb-ft of torque.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/optima/2018/">2018 Kia Optima</a> receives a 7.0-inch touchscreen, blind spot warning, and rear cross-traffic alert as standard equipment on all models. Laminated front windows, a 10-way power driver’s seat, and auto up/down front windows are now standard on the LX 1.6T and the LX 2.4 with the Convenience package. A new S trim has also been added, slotting just above the LX 2.4.</p>

<p>The SX Turbo model gets LED fog lights, a panoramic sunroof, heated and ventilated front seats, a 10-way power front passenger seat, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/">Kia</a>’s UVO3 infotainment system as standard. Kia has also discontinued the SX Limited trim and turned it into an optional package for the SX trim of the Optima.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/optima/2018/">Kia Optima</a> is a front-drive midsize sedan slotting above the compact Forte and below the larger, full-size Cadenza. In addition to gas-powered variants, the Optima is also available as a hybrid and plug-in hybrid.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Three gas engines are available in the 2018 Optima including a 2.4-liter I-4 with 185 hp and 178 lb-ft of torque, a 1.6-liter turbo-four with 178 hp and 195 lb-ft, and a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 245 hp and 260 lb-ft. A six-speed automatic transmission is paired to the base 2.4-liter I-4 and 2.0-liter turbo-four, while a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic is exclusive to the 1.6-liter turbo-four. EPA fuel economy ratings are 24/34 mpg city/highway for the base 2.4-liter in LX and EX grade, 25/36 mpg for the 2.4-liter in FE trim, 28/37 mpg for the LX 1.6T and 22/31 mpg for the SX Turbo. Trunk space in the 2018 Optima is 15.9 cubic feet and can be expanded via the 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In addition to the gas engines, the <strong>Optima is also available as a hybrid</strong> that combines a 2.0-liter I-4, an electric motor, a lithium-ion battery, and a six-speed automatic. The standard Optima Hybrid is has a combined output of 192 hp and 271 lb-ft and the Optima Plug-In is rated at 202 hp and 276 lb-ft. EPA fuel economy ratings are 39/46 mpg for the standard hybrid. The Optima Plug-In is rated at 40 mpg combined and can travel up to 29 miles in EV mode thanks to a larger battery. Total range with a full tank and a fully charged battery is 610 miles according to the EPA. Opting for the hybrid powertrain does cut trunk space down to 13.4 cubic feet but retains the 60/40 split-folding rear seats. The Optima Plug-In loses more cargo space and the 60/40-split-folding rear seats due to the larger battery, cutting trunk space to 9.8 cubic feet.</p>

<p>Base models come with 16-inch alloy wheels, Kia’s UVO3 infotainment system, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, a 3.5-inch multi-information display, cloth upholstery, Bluetooth connectivity, a rearview camera, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, a USB port, blind spot warning, and rear cross-traffic alert. Higher trim levels can be had with leather or Nappa leather upholstery, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, a Harman/Kardon premium audio system, a panoramic sunroof, adaptive LED headlights, alloy wheels up to 18 inches in diameter, a surround view camera system, heated and ventilated front seats, a heated steering wheel, heated rear seats, keyless entry/start, a <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/smart/">smart</a> trunk with a hands-free opening, and additional USB ports for fast charging.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Optima received a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 model but the 2017 Optima received a Good score on all crash tests and the headlights tests (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Optima received a Superior rating after in avoided a 12- and 25-mph collision (Superior is the highest rating in the front crash prevention test). As a result, the Optima received the 2017 Top Safety Pick+ award.</p>

<p>On the EX and SX trims, a suite of driver assistance and active safety features that includes automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, adaptive cruise control, and lane departure warning are available.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/optima/2016/2016-kia-optima-lx-1-6t-first-test-review/">2016 First Test of the Optima LX 1.6T</a>, we noted that the tiny little turbocharged engine didn’t give up much when it comes to acceleration thanks to a quick-shifting dual-clutch automatic. At highway speeds, however, you do need to plan your passes as the small turbo engine can feel slightly lethargic. Interior space, on the other hand, is generous with plenty of room for front and rear seat passengers. Material quality on lower trim levels is also not on par with higher grade models, especially on the base LX trim.</p>

<p>The more powerful 2.0-liter turbo-four in the SX trim didn’t have much of an advantage in terms of acceleration due to prodigious amounts of turbo lag, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/optima/2016/2016-kia-optima-sxl-2-0t-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>. Comfort levels and ride quality, on the other hand, are respectable even with the standard 18-inch alloy wheels on the SX trim.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Optima’s optional 2.0-liter turbo-four is also found in a number of vehicles including the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/sorento/2018/">Kia Sorento</a> and Sportage, as well as the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/sonata/2018/">Hyundai Sonata</a> and Santa Fe Sport.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/cadenza/2018/">2018 Kia Cadenza</a> gets LED interior lighting and a panoramic sunroof as part of the Luxury package.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/cadenza/2018/">Kia Cadenza</a> is a large front-drive sedan slotting above the midsize Optima and alongside the sporty Stinger in price. Above the Stinger and Cadenza is the large, luxury-minded K900.</p>

<p><strong>Cadenza Premium: </strong>The base Cadenza Premium comes well equipped with 18-inch alloy wheels, projector-beam headlights, a 3.5-inch instrument cluster display, leather upholstery, power-adjustable front seats, heated front seats, dual-zone climate control, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, an eight-speaker audio system, Bluetooth, keyless entry and start, a rearview camera, and the Smart Trunk feature (stand behind the trunk for a few seconds with the key fob in your pocket and the trunk opens). Opting for the Luxury package gets you the 12-speaker Harman Kardon audio system, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, a panoramic sunroof, and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>Cadenza Technology: </strong>Moving up to the Technology trim gets you a larger 7.0-inch instrument cluster display, 19-inch alloy wheels, LED headlights, rain-sensing wipers, a power-operated steering column adjuster, ventilated front seats, a heated steering wheel, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, a 12-speaker Harman Kardon audio system, wireless phone charging, rear parking sensors, and an auto-dimming rearview mirror.</p>

<p><strong>Cadenza Limited: </strong>Range-topping Limited models built on the Technology grade with more standard features like a 360-degree view camera system, a head-up display, the Smart Trunk feature, heated outboard rear seats, Nappa leather upholstery, and a power rear sunshade.</p>

<p>The 2018 Cadenza is powered by a 3.3-liter V-6 with 290 hp and 252 lb-ft of torque, and uses an eight-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 20/28 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p>The NHTSA hasn’t crash tested the 2018 Cadenza. In IIHS evaluations, the 2018 Cadenza received a Good score on all crash-worthiness tests (Good is the highest possible score). However, it only receives the Top Safety Pick rating because it only got an Acceptable rating on the headlights test.</p>

<p>In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the 2018 Cadenza received a Superior score after it avoided collisions in 12- and a 25-mph tests (Superior is the highest rating on the front crash prevention evaluation). Adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, high beam assist, lane keeping assist, lane change assist, blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert comes standard on the Technology and Limited trims. The base Premium trim is available with lane change assist, blind-spot monitoring, and rear cross-traffic alert when you opt for the Luxury package.</p>

<p>The 2018 Cadenza has a 16-cubic-foot trunk but it can’t be expanded because the rear seats only have ski pass through (they don’t split and fold).</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/cadenza/2017/2017-kia-cadenza-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we were impressed with the Cadenza’s ride comfort. However, the car’s handling isn’t as sporty as competitors like the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/maxima/2018/">Nissan Maxima</a> and has a bit more body roll. We also noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/cadenza/2017/2017-kia-cadenza-first-drive-review/">2017 First Drive</a> that the eight-speed automatic is smooth and nearly unnoticeable while the interior stays well-insulated even at highway speeds.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/sportage/2018/">2018 Kia Sportage</a> get an updated Popular package with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay, and automatic climate control. There’s also a new Technology package for the LX trim that adds automatic emergency braking, blind-spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, and lane departure warning. EX models get blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert as standard while the EX Technology package for all-wheel-drive models get heated rear seats. SX variants get an electronic parking brake.</p>

<p>The 2018 Sportage is a compact crossover that slots below the larger Sorento and above the smaller Soul. Front-wheel drive comes standard while all-wheel drive is optional. It’s available in three trim levels.</p>

<p><strong>Sportage LX: </strong>The base LX grade comes standard with 17-inch alloy wheels, cloth upholstery, a five-inch touchscreen, a 3.5-inch instrument cluster display, a six-speaker audio system, Bluetooth, keyless entry, a rearview camera, and a USB port.</p>

<p><strong>Sportage EX: </strong>Moving up to the EX grade adds a 7.0-inch touchscreen, 18-inch alloy wheels, fog lights, leather upholstery, a power-operated driver’s seat, heated front seats, dual-zone climate control, a second USB port, and keyless start.</p>

<p><strong>Sportage SX Turbo: </strong>Range-topping SX Turbo models add navigation, HID headlights, 19-inch alloy wheels, the Smart power tailgate (with the key fob in your pocket, the tailgate will lift after a few seconds standing behind the car), ventilated front seats, an eight-speaker Harman Kardon audio system, a sport-tuned suspension, a flat-bottom steering wheel with paddle shifters, LED fog lights, and a heated steering wheel.</p>

<p>The 2018 Sportage LX and EX come with a 2.4-liter I-4 with 181 hp and 175 lb-ft of torque. A 2.0-liter turbo-four with 240 hp (237 hp with all-wheel drive) and 260 lb-ft is standard on the range-topping SX trim. Both engines come exclusively with a six-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy varies based on the trim level, front-drive LX models are rated at 23/30 mpg city/highway and the EX grade is rated at 22/29 mpg. Opting for all-wheel drive drops those ratings down to 21/25 mpg. The least efficient model is the more powerful SX grade, which is rated at 21/26 mpg for front-drive models and 20/23 mpg with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p>The 2018 Sportage received a five-star overall rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 Sportage received a Good score on all crash-worthiness tests (Good is the highest possible score). However, the crossover received an Acceptable score on the headlights test, which meant it only qualified for a Top Safety Pick rating.</p>

<p>In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the 2018 Sportage received a Superior rating after it avoided collisions in 12- and a 25-mph tests (Superior is the highest score for the front crash prevention test). Active driver assistance features like automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, and lane departure warning are standard on the SX trim. Blind-spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, and lane change alert is standard on the EX and SX trims, and part of LX Technology package, which also include lane departure warning.</p>

<p>The 2018 Sportage has 30.7 cubic feet of cargo space behind the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats and it can be expanded to 60.1 cubic feet.</p>

<p>When properly equipped, the 2018 Sportage can tow up to 1,650 pounds of payload without a trailer and up to 2,000 pounds with one.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=2263520&amp;action=edit">2017 First Test</a>, we were not impressed with the Sportage’s poor fuel economy, which was due in part to its curb weight of nearly 4,000 pounds. This means the additional grunt of the 2.0-liter turbo-four didn’t help straight-line performance as much as we’d hoped. The six-speed automatic, on the other hand, was smooth and the car features a good ride and handling balance that’s comfortable without sacrificing agility. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-5/2016/small-crossover-comparison-big-test/">2016 crossover comparison test of nine vehicles</a>, the Sportage placed seventh because of its lackluster fuel economy, tight rear seats, and inconsistent material quality inside the cabin.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The all-new <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/rio/2018/">2018 Kia Rio</a> features a more conservative exterior and a new interior that features a tablet-style touchscreen on higher trim levels.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting below the compact Forte, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/rio/2018/">Kia Rio</a> is a front-drive subcompact car <strong>available in sedan and hatchback body styles</strong>.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>A 1.6-liter I-4 with 130 hp and 119 lb-ft of torque is the only engine available in the 2018 Rio and it can be paired to either a standard six-speed manual or a six-speed automatic transmission. The manual, however, is only available on the base LX trim. EPA fuel economy ratings are 29/37 mpg city/highway for the manual and 28/37 mpg with the automatic.</p>

<p>There’s 13.7 cubic feet of trunk space in the Rio sedan, and 60/40 split-folding rear seats is available on the S or EX grades. Should you need more cargo space, hatchback offers 17.4 cubic feet of cargo space behind the second row and 32.8 cubic feet behind the front seats. Additionally, all variants of the Rio hatchback come standard with 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>The base 2018 Rio LX trim comes with 15-inch steel wheels, cloth upholstery, six-way adjustable driver’s seat, a four-speaker audio system, a 5.0-inch screen and a USB port. Move up to the S trim and that adds a rearview camera, Bluetooth connectivity, additional USB ports, cruise control, keyless entry, and a six-speaker audio system. On the range-topping EX trim, the Rio adds on 15-inch alloy wheels, a 3.5-inch multi-information display, automatic emergency braking, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/">Kia</a>’s UVO3 infotainment system, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, and a 7.0-inch touchscreen. The only option available is the Red Accent Leather package, which is only available on the EX trim.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Automatic emergency braking and forward collision warning is standard on the EX trim.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Alongside the Forte, the Rio is produced in Kia’s new manufacturing facility in Mexico.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/">Land Rover</a> updates the Range Rover with new LED headlights, new 24-way power and massaging front seats, air cabin ionization, Touch Pro Duo infotainment system, and Gesture Sunblind advanced gesture control. The range-topping 557-hp SVAutobiography Dynamic joins the lineup for 2018.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>Land Rover’s flagship SUV is positioned above the rest of the SUV lineup, including the Range Rover Sport, Velar, Evoque, Discovery, and entry-level Discovery Sport. The Range Rover is offered with multiple engines and two wheelbase sizes.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Range Rover Land Rover comes standard with a 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 that produces 340 hp and 332 lb-ft of torque and delivers an EPA-rated 17/23 mpg city/highway. A 380 hp version of the same engine is available in the HSE model. The optional 3.0-liter turbodiesel V-6 pumps out 254 hp and a healthy 443 lb-ft of torque and comes rated at 22/28 mpg. Available in the Supercharged and Autobiography models is the 518-hp, 461-lb-ft 5.0-liter supercharged V-8 that delivers 14/19 mpg (all 2017 fuel economy figures). The new 557-hp, 516-lb-ft version of the same supercharged V-8 comes equipped in the top SVAutobiography Dynamic model. All engines are backed by an eight-speed automatic and models come with four-wheel drive as standard. The available long-wheelbase model comes standard with the 518-hp V-8. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 340-hp Range Rover hit 60 mph in 6.3 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 126 feet.</p>

<p>The Range Rover P400e plug-in model will join the lineup in 2019 with up to 31 miles of all-electric driving range.</p>

<p>The Range Rover comes well equipped with many standard features including 19-inch alloy wheels, Terrain Response off-road driving mode, LED headlights with signature DRL, grained leather seats, 16-way heated front seats, three-zone climate control, Touch Pro Duo infotainment system with rotary control with navigation, a Meridian sound system, power-operated gesture tailgate, electrically adjustable steering wheel, and interior ambient lighting. The range-topping SV Autobiography Dynamic model adds 21-inch wheels with a Dark Grey finish, SVAutobiography suspension tuning, quilted and perforated semi-aniline leather seats, 24-way heated and cooled massaging front seats, executive class power recline heated and cooled rear seats, perforated leather headlining, illuminated door sills with SVAutobiography script, SVAutobiography pedals, Pro Services with a Wi-Fi hotspot, and a head-up display. The Touch Pro Duo infotainment system is made up of two 10.0-inch touchscreens, the upper screen is capable of swipe and pinch-to-zoom and can be angled to counter glare. Opening the Gesture Sunblinds only takes a rearward swipe in front of the rear-view mirror.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Range Rover comes standard with a few driver assist safety features including lane departure warning, automatic emergency braking, front and rear parking sensors, a rearview camera, and adaptive cruise control with speed limit warning. The optional Drive pack adds blind-spot monitoring, Driver Condition Monitor (drowsy driver alert) and Traffic Sign Recognition. The Drive Pro pack adds high-speed emergency braking, blind spot assist, lane keep assist, and adaptive cruise control with automatic stop/go. The Park pack includes a 360-degree camera system, Reverse Traffic Monitor, and Clear Exit Monitor, a feature that alerts rear exiting passengers if a vehicle is approaching and warns them with a flashing light on the door. Park Pro Pack adds Park Assist, a self-parking system that aids in parallel and perpendicular parking.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/range-rover/2017/2017-land-rover-range-rover-svautobiography-dynamic-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2017 Range Rover SVAutobiography, we loved the effortless acceleration and said: “What that single data point doesn’t tell you, however, is how effortlessly quick the SVAutobiography Dynamic feels on the road compared with a regular full-size Range Rover. The secret sauce is not so much the 40 hp power boost, but the 41 lb-ft increase in torque to 502 lb-ft, all of which swells nicely right in the midrange of the powerband.”</p>

<p>The ride is comfortable, even with 22-inch wheels shod in low-profile tires. “The Range Rover SVAutobiography Dynamic’s interior, awash with beautifully wrought diamond quilted leather and highlighted with sparkling metalwork, is a wonderfully serene place from which to watch the world go by. The dash and door panels feature a black veneer, and the rotary shifter features a thin red band. Red anodized paddles peek out from behind the leather-clad steering wheel, unless you’ve ordered a tan interior.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/escalade/2015/the-big-test-large-luxury-suvs/">six-way full-size premium SUV comparison</a>, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/range-rover/2018/">Land Rover Range Rover</a> HSE placed fourth. In the comparison, we said: “Gorgeous truck, Gerry McGovern be praised. But the suspect build quality and pricey everything else leaves us cold.” Even so, we enjoyed the comfortable ride, luxurious features, and fuel efficiency (compared to competitors).</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>In the upcoming 2019 P400e plug-in model, the Range Rover can operate in all-electric mode when off-roading, even when traversing in the transmission’s low range.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/range-rover/2018/">2018 Land Rover Range Rover</a> Evoque gets a new turbocharged four-cylinder engine from <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/">Jaguar</a> <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/">Land Rover</a>’s Ingenium family. Base SE models now come standard with auto-dimming rearview mirrors and 4G LTE connectivity has been added. Land Rover has also discontinued the slow-selling coupe variant of the Evoque. A new Landmark Edition has also been added with unique exterior and interior styling cues.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/range-rover/2018/">Land Rover Range Rover</a> Evoque is the smallest crossover in Land Rover’s lineup, slotting below the larger Range Rover Velar. It comes standard with four-wheel drive and is available as a four-door crossover or a two-door convertible. Six trim levels are available in the four-door and the convertible is only available in SE Dynamic and HSE Dynamic.</p>

<p><strong>Range Rover Evoque SE: </strong>The base SE trim comes standard with a leather-wrapped steering wheel, push-button start, 12-way power adjustable front seats, dual-zone climate control, front and rear parking sensors, Bluetooth, navigation, 18-inch alloy wheels, leather upholstery, and an 8.0-inch touchscreen.</p>

<p><strong>Range Rover Evoque SE Premium:</strong> Moving up to the SE Premium gets you HID headlights, keyless entry, and a rearview camera.</p>

<p><strong>Range Rover Evoque Landmark Edition: </strong>This new special edition model comes with unique 19-inch alloy wheels, gray contrast roof, a hands-free tailgate, a panoramic glass roof, an upgraded eight-speaker audio system, Graphite Atlas exterior design cues including the logo, and perforated leather upholstery.</p>

<p><strong>Range Rover Evoque HSE: </strong>The HSE grade adds a 10-speaker Meridian premium audio system, a 10.0-inch touchscreen, fog lights, heated side mirrors with memory, memory function for the front seats, heated front and rear seats, blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert, an upgraded navigation interface, 19-inch alloy wheels, a hands-free power tailgate and Windsor leather upholstery.</p>

<p><strong>Range Rover Evoque HSE Dynamic: </strong>The HSE Dynamic trim adds black hood louvers, square exhaust tips, and a perforated leather steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>Range Rover Evoque Autobiography: </strong>On the range-topping Autobiography trim, you get adaptive HID headlights, a full Windsor leather interior, the All Terrain Progress Control system, Satin brushed aluminum interior, illuminated kick plates, 20-inch alloy wheels, and a 16-speaker Meridian premium audio system.</p>

<p>Key options include alloy wheels up to 20 inches in diameter, full LED headlights, a 360 degree camera system, a head-up display, parallel and perpendicular parking assist, a heated steering wheel, ventilated front seats with massaging function, and contrasting roof colors in grey or black.</p>

<p>The 2018 Range Rover Evoque is powered by a 2.0-liter turbo-four rated at 237 hp and 251 lb-ft of torque. A high output variant with 286 hp and 295 lb-ft is available in the four-door but only on the HSE Dynamic and Autobiography trims. The only transmission available on the 2018 Evoque is a nine-speed automatic sourced from ZF. Regardless of the body style and engine output EPA fuel economy ratings are 21/29 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p>Active safety tech is available as part of the Driver Assistance package on the HSE trim and higher and it includes lane keeping assist, automatic emergency braking, a driver condition monitor, lane departure warning, and traffic sign recognition. Adaptive cruise control is only available on the HSE Dynamic and Autobiography trims as part of the Driver Assistance Plus package.</p>

<p>Behind the second row, the 2018 Range Rover Evoque has 20.3 cubic feet of cargo space and that can be expanded to 51 cubic feet. The convertible has a small 8.9-cubic-foot trunk that can be expanded via the split-folding rear seats. When properly equipped, the Evoque has a maximum towing capacity of 3,968 pounds of payload regardless of body style.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/nx200t/2015/the-big-test-2015-luxury-compact-crossovers/">2015 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/nx/2018/">Lexus NX</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkc/2018/">Lincoln MKC</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/x3/2018/">BMW X3</a>, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/xc60/2018/">Volvo XC60</a>, the Range Rover Evoque placed third thanks to its stylish, well-built interior. With the 20-inch alloy wheels, however, the ride suffers and gets harsh. On-road handling, on the other hand, is sporty and tossable.</p>

<p>Like the four-door Evoque, the convertible is capable when the trail ends. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/range-rover-evoque/2017/2017-land-rover-range-rover-evoque-convertible-first-drive-review/">2017 First Drive</a>, we were impressed with the Evoque convertible’s capability in the snow and in the dirt, meaning it can easily work as a four-seasons vehicle.</p>

<p>We noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/range-rover-evoque/2017/2017-range-rover-evoque-convertible-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a> of the convertible that the nine-speed automatic makes it hard to modulate the throttle because it can be a little too eager. With the 20-inch alloy wheels, there’s excessive road and tire noise. Visibility is surprisingly good for a convertible with the top up. Trunk, however, is small and doesn’t hold much. The multimedia system needs work and the touchscreen is mounted low on the center stack.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/range-rover-evoque/2018/">2018 Land Rover Range Rover Evoque</a>’s new turbocharged four-cylinder engine is shared with a number of vehicles including the newly released Jaguar E-Pace crossover.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/range-rover/2018/">Land Rover Range Rover</a> Velar is an all-new model from the automaker and is underpinned by the aluminum-intensive D7a platform from the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/xe/2018/">Jaguar XE</a> and XF sedans and the F-Pace SUV.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The Range Rover Velar is positioned ahead of the entry-level Evoque but behind the Range Rover Sport and flagship Range Rover model in price. Additionally, the Velar has the same starting price as the new <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/discovery/2018/">Land Rover Discovery</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The four-door Velar will come with a choice of three engines, a 177-hp, 317-lb-ft of torque 2.0-liter turbodiesel I-4, a 380-hp, 332-lb-ft 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 (shared with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/">Jaguar</a> F-Pace), and a 247-hp, 269-lb-ft 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4. An eight-speed automatic transmission routes power to an all-wheel-drive system. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/">Land Rover</a> claims that the V-6 equipped Velar will hit 60 mph in 5.6 seconds.</p>

<p>The Velar First Edition (only to be sold during the first model year) is the most expensive Velar and comes standard with most of the options and features available on the Velar. The exterior sports a black contract roof with power sliding panoramic roof, LED headlights with Signature daytime running lights, 22-inch split-nine-spoke wheels with Diamond Turned finish, a First Edition badging, and auto-dimming, power-fold, heated doors mirrors with approach lights. The interior includes perforated Windsor leather, carbon fiber with copper wire door finishers, leather-wrapped heated steering wheel, 20-way adjustable heated and cooled front seats with massage, 1300-watt Meridian Signature Sound System with 23 speakers, a 12.3-inch high-definition driver display in the instrument panel, a head-up display, illuminated door sills, configurable ambient lighting, and Land Rover Touch Pro Duo (two 10-inch high-definition touchscreens).</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The base Velar comes standard with Autonomous Emergency Braking, Lane Departure Warning, Trailer Stability Assist, Roll Stability Control, Cornering Brake Control, Low Traction Launch, and six airbags. To get the most safety out of your Range Rover Velar, opt for the Drive Pro package that consists of adaptive cruise control with Queue Assist and Intelligent Emergency Braking, Lane Keep Assist, Traffic Sign Recognition, Adaptive Speed Limiter, Driver Condition Monitor, and Blind Spot Assist.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 4x4i menu offers slope information, steering wheel angle, driveline torque distribution, suspension articulation, and Wade Sensing data.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>A 10.0-inch touchscreen is now standard on all 2018 Discovery models and comes with <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/">Jaguar</a> <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/">Land Rover</a>’s InControl Pro infotainment system. Automatic emergency braking is standard on all models, and both gas and diesel engine options are now available on all trims.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/discovery/2018/">2018 Land Rover Discovery</a> is a large luxury SUV that’s capable off-road and can seat up to seven passengers with its optional two-seat third row. Three trims are offered.</p>

<p><strong>Discovery SE: </strong>The base SE trim comes with a fixed panoramic glass roof, automatic headlights, 19-inch alloy wheels, a 10-speaker audio system, 12-way adjustable front seats, rear parking sensors, leather upholstery, navigation, a 10.0-inch touchscreen, ambient lighting, dual-zone climate control, a rearview camera, keyless start and a gesture-operated tailgate.</p>

<p><strong>Discovery HSE: </strong>Moving up to the HSE trim adds 20-inch alloy wheels, a panoramic sunroof, full LED headlights, fog lights, keyless entry, a 10-speaker Meridian premium audio system, and front parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>Discovery HSE Luxury: </strong>The HSE Luxury trim adds a two-speed transfer case, air suspension, 16-way power front seats with driver’s side memory, Windsor leather upholstery, tri-zone climate control, configurable ambient lighting, a power-folding third row, and a 14-speaker Meridian premium audio system.</p>

<p>Notable options include heated and ventilated front seats, heated second row seats, four-zone climate control, a heated steering wheel, a 360-degree view camera system, Land Rover’s All Terrain Progress Control system, heated third row seats, massaging front seats, and an active locking rear differential.</p>

<p>The 2018 Discovery is powered by either a gas 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 with 340 hp and 332 lb-ft of torque or a 3.0-liter turbodiesel V-6 with 254 hp and 443 lb-ft for the SE, HSE, and HSE Luxury models. SVX models come powered by a supercharged 5.0-liter V-8 rated at 518 hp and 461 lb-ft. All variants come exclusively with an eight-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings haven’t been released for the 2018 Discovery but the 2017 model was rated at 16/21 mpg city/highway for the gas engine and 21/26 mpg for the diesel.</p>

<p>Automatic emergency braking comes standard on all 2018 Discovery SUVs. Driver condition monitor, adaptive cruise control, and traffic sign recognition are available on all models as part of the Drive and Drive Pro packages. Blind-spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, and lane keeping assist are added to the Drive and Drive Pro packages on the HSE and HSE Luxury trims.</p>

<p>Seven-seat variants of the 2018 Discovery have 9.1 cubic feet of cargo space behind the third row and that can be expanded to 40.2 cubic feet behind the second row and 85 cubic feet behind the front seats. Five-seat models have 43.5 cubic feet behind the second row and 88.3 cubic feet behind the front seats. When properly equipped, the gas-powered Discovery can tow up to 8,201 pounds of payload while the diesel is rated at 7,716 pounds.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/discovery/2017/2017-land-rover-discovery-review/">2017 review</a>, we said that the Discovery offers excellent off-road performance despite moving to a unibody platform. On pavement, the Discovery drives smaller than it looks thanks to its good steering and independent suspension. Due to its size, the Discovery’s handling isn’t as confidence inspiring and the SUV can feel sloppy.</p>

<p>Inside, we noted that the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/discovery/2017/2017-land-rover-discovery-first-drive-review/">Discovery’s</a> third row is usable for adults and that the second row can slide forward and back, giving it better flexibility. We did note, however, that the diesel engine is lacking and needs more grunt to improve its passing power. When it comes to smoothness, on the other hand, the diesel engine is more linear and doesn’t lurch from a stop like the gas engine does. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/discovery/2017/2017-land-rover-discovery-first-test-civilized-beast/">2017 First Test review</a>, we said that the interior is well-appointed, feels premium, and has plenty of storage spaces.</p>

<p>The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/land-rover-discovery-svx-serious-off-roader/">Land Rover Discovery SVX</a> is a nearly-production-ready concept that’s powered by a supercharged 5.0-liter V-8 with more than 500 horsepower.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/discovery/2018/">2018 Land Rover Discovery</a> Sport gets a new 2.0-liter turbo-four from <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/">Jaguar</a> <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/">Land Rover</a>’s Ingenium engine family. Two new exterior colors, Byron Blue and Namib Orange, replace Loire Blue and Phoenix Orange. Four-way lumbar support is now standard on the Discovery Sport.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/discovery/2018/">Land Rover Discovery</a> Sport is a compact luxury crossover that slots below the larger Discovery and comes with standard all-wheel drive. Three trim levels are offered on the 2018 Discovery Sport.</p>

<p><strong>Discovery SE: </strong>The base Discovery Sport SE comes standard with the Terrain Response system, partial leather seats, 18-inch alloy wheels, a 10-speaker audio system, a rearview camera, rear parking sensors, three USB ports, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, and Bluetooth.</p>

<p><strong>Discovery HSE: </strong>Jumping to the HSE trim adds keyless entry/start, front parking sensors, a fixed panoramic glass roof, a gesture-operated power tailgate, leather upholstery, 10-way power front seats, fog lights, and HID headlights.</p>

<p><strong>Discovery HSE Luxury: </strong>The range-topping HSE Luxury adds configurable mood lighting, 19-inch alloy wheels, navigation, a 10-speaker Meridian premium audio system, and Windsor leather upholstery.</p>

<p>Notable options include heated and ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, a 360-degree view camera system, a two-seat third row, a head-up display, and a WiFi hotspot.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/discovery-sport/2018/">2018 Land Rover Discovery Sport</a> is powered by a 2.0-liter turbo-four rated at 237 hp and 251 lb-ft of torque. A higher-output variant with 286 hp and 295 lb-ft is available on the HSE and HSE Luxury trims. A nine-speed automatic transmission is the only gearbox available. EPA fuel economy estimates haven’t been released yet but it should be slightly better than the 2017 model’s 20/25 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Discovery Sport. On the HSE and HSE Luxury trims, active safety tech is optional and includes lane keeping assist, driver condition alert, automatic emergency braking, and traffic sign recognition. Adaptive cruise control is available exclusively on the range-topping HSE Luxury trim.</p>

<p>Behind the second row, there’s 34.6 cubic feet of cargo space that can be expanded to 62.7 cubic feet. The optional third row eats up the cargo space behind the second row and leaves barely any room for your gear. When properly equipped, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/discovery-sport/2018/">Land Rover Discovery Sport</a> can tow up to 4,409 pounds of payload.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2015-land-rover-discovery-sport-first-test-review/">2015 First Test</a>, we noted that the Discovery Sport felt strained on the road and that the nine-speed automatic feels jerky and has inconsistent shift quality. Handling is acceptable with the crossover’s quick and accurate steering but it does have a stiff ride. Interior quality, however, is lacking and there’s  excessive noise entering the cabin at high speeds. Off the pavement, the Discovery Sport performs reasonably well, provided you pick the right mode before you venture off the beaten path.</p>

<p>The 2018 Land Rover Discovery Sport is available in front-wheel drive configuration in other world markets.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/rx/2018/">2018 Lexus RX</a> gets an updated Lexus Enform telematics system on all models.  Blind-spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert can now be had as standalone options on the RX 350 and RX 450h. Navigation, heated and ventilated front seats, and a moonroof are available as standalone options on the RX 450h. A new Premium package option on the RX 450h adds power-folding side mirrors with memory, wood interior trim, leather upholstery, driver’s seat memory, and a rear center armrest with a storage bin.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/rx/2018/">Lexus RX</a> is a midsize five-seat crossover that slots above the compact NX and the larger, more capable GX. Front-wheel drive is standard and all-wheel drive is optional. An all-wheel-drive hybrid variant called the RX 450h is also offered at a premium above the RX 350.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Lexus RX comes with two powertrain options including the <strong>RX 350</strong>‘s 3.5-liter V-6 with 295 hp and 267 lb-ft of torque paired to an eight-speed automatic transmission or the <strong>RX 450h</strong>‘s hybrid system that combines the V-6 with three electric motors, a nickel metal hydride battery, and a CVT for a total output of 308 hp.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings are 20/27 mpg city/highway for the front-drive RX 350 and 19/26 mpg with all-wheel drive. Even though it comes standard with all-wheel drive, the RX 450h is the most efficient at 31/28 mpg.</p>

<p>The 2018 RX 350 has 18.4 cubic feet behind the split-folding rear seats and it can be expanded to 56.3 cubic feet. Due to the additional hybrid powertrain components, the RX 450h has slightly less cargo space at 18 cubic feet behind the second row and 55.9 cubic feet behind the front seats. When properly equipped, the 2018 Lexus RX can tow up to 3,500 pounds of payload.</p>

<p>Standard features include 18-inch alloy wheels, LED headlights, keyless entry/start, leatherette upholstery, 40/20/40 split-folding rear seats, 10-way power adjustable front seats, dual-zone climate control, an 8.0-inch screen, a rearview camera, a power lift gate, and Bluetooth connectivity.  Options include navigation, a larger 12.3-inch screen, a Mark Levinson premium audio system, a panoramic sunroof, touch-free power liftgate, triple-beam LED headlights, 20-inch alloy wheels, heated and ventilated front seats, a heated steering wheels, semi-aniline leather upholstery, and a rear seat entertainment system with two 11.6-inch screens.</p>

<p>The F Sport package adds 20-inch alloy wheels, an active sound generator, an adaptive variable suspension system, a Sport+ mode, black side mirror covers, a black headliner, an F Sport steering wheel, F Sport gauges, heated and ventilated F Sport seats, a more aggressive front fascia, paddle shifters and an F Sport-specific suspension setup.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave all variants of the 2018 Lexus RX a five-star safety rating except for the front-drive RX 350, which received four stars (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test a 2018 RX but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crash tests and Average on the new headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the RX received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph and a 25-mph collision (Superior is the highest possible rating in the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p>All variants of the 2018 RX come standard with the Lexus Safety System+ suite which bundles together automatic high beams, lane departure warning with steering assist, lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, and pedestrian detection. Blind-spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert are available as standalone options.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkx/2016/2016-lexus-rx-mercedes-benz-glc-lincoln-mkx-comparison/">2016 comparison test</a>, the Lexus RX placed third due to the F Sport model’s tendency to get jarring over rough road surfaces, outdated graphics on its multimedia system, and overly complicated infotainment controls. Additionally, the stiffer suspension in the RX 350 F Sport didn’t translate to better handling; the crossover exhibited too much body roll and didn’t feel planted. We did note in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/rx350/2016/2016-lexus-rx-350-f-sport-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a> review that the RX’s luxurious interior has comfortable seats up front and in the back. The front seats, in particular, offer excellent comfort levels. However, the interior isn’t as well-insulated as one would expect of a Lexus vehicle.</p>

<p>The more powerful RX 450h, with its 308-hp hybrid system, offers better off-the-line acceleration thanks to its electric motors but with superior fuel economy compared to the gas-only RX 350, as we observed in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2016-lexus-rx-first-drive-review/">2016 First Drive</a> review.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Lexus RX’s base 3.5-liter V-6 is shared with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/sienna/2018/">Toyota Sienna</a> and Highlander.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p> </p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/is/2018/">2018 Lexus IS</a> gets a 5-hp bump on V-6-powered models and the IS 350 F Sport now comes standard with a limited-slip differential. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/">Lexus</a> also renamed the IS 200t the IS 300 RWD.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/is/2018/">Lexus IS</a> is a compact premium sports sedan available in rear- or all-wheel drive configuration. With the discontinuation of the CT 2ooh hatchback, the IS is now the entry-level model in the Lexus lineup, slotting below the larger GS and ES sedans.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">The 2018 Lexus IS is available with two engines, a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 241 hp and 258 lb-ft of torque in the IS 300 RWD or a 3.5-liter V-6 with 260 hp and 236 lb-ft in the IS 300 AWD or 311 hp and 277 lb-ft in the IS 350. Rear-drive models come exclusively with an eight-speed automatic transmission while all-wheel drive models are equipped with a six-speed automatic. EPA fuel economy ratings are 22/32 mpg city/highway for the IS 300 RWD, 19/28 mpg for the IS 350, and 19/26 mpg for the IS 300 AWD and IS 350 AWD. Trunk space is on the small side at 10.8 cubic feet but it can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">Standard features include 17- or 18-inch alloy wheels (IS 300 and IS350 respectively), a moonroof, leatherette upholstery, Bluetooth connectivity, a 7.0-inch screen, keyless entry/start, a 10-speaker audio system, a rearview camera, and LED headlights. Options include navigation with a 10.3-inch screen, a Mark Levinson premium audio system, leather upholstery, adaptive headlights, parking sensors, heated/ventilated front seats, memory for the front seats, and a heated steering wheel. F Sport models come with unique 18-inch alloy wheels, F Sport suspension, F Sport seats, an LFA-inspired gauge cluster, and aluminum pedals. The IS 350 F Sport gets more go fast goods such as a limited-slip differential and an adaptive F Sport suspension with a Sport+ mode.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">The 2018 Lexus IS received a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test a 2018 model but the 2017 IS received a Good score on side impact, roof strength, and moderate front overlap crashes, and an Average on the small front overlap and headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Lexus IS received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph and 25-mph collision (Superior is the highest possible score in the front overlap crash test).</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">Standard on all 2018 Lexus IS models is the Lexus Safety System+ suite of active driver assistance and safety features that bundles together forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, pedestrian detection, adaptive cruise control, automatic high beams, and lane departure warning with steering assist. Blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert is available as part of a package.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/giulia/2017/alfa-romeo-giulia-bmw-330i-audi-a4-mercedes-benz-c300-cadillac-ats-jaguar-xe-lexus-is-200t-volvo-s60-comparison/" style="font-family: Georgia, serif">2017 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/xe/2018/">Jaguar XE</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/3-series/2018/">BMW 3 Series</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a4/2018/">Audi A4</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/c-class/2018/">Mercedes-Benz C-Class</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/giulia/2018/">Alfa Romeo Giulia</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/s60/2018/">Volvo S60</a>, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/ats/2018/">Cadillac ATS</a>, the Lexus IS placed fourth thanks to its sporty handling, comfortable ride, excellent build quality, and comfortable seats. However, its infotainment system proved infuriating for some to use and the car’s rear seats were cramped. We also noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/is/2017/2017-lexus-is200t-first-test-review/" style="font-family: Georgia, serif">2017 First Test</a> that the car’s weight hindered it, making it slower than most of its competitors.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Lexus IS’ base 2.0-liter turbo-four was first used in the NX crossover.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 12pt;font-family: Georgia, serif"><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/3-series/"></a><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/">BMW</a> 3 Series<br/></span><span style="font-size: 12pt;font-family: Georgia, serif"><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/c-class/"></a><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> C-Class<br/></span><span style="font-size: 12pt;font-family: Georgia, serif"><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a4/">Audi A4</a></span><span style="font-size: 12pt;font-family: Georgia, serif"><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/q50/"><br/></a></span><span style="font-size: 12pt;font-family: Georgia, serif"><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/ats/">Cadillac ATS</a></span></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/ls/2018/">2018 Lexus LS</a> is all-new and now rides on the new GA-L platform that first appeared on the LC coupe. In addition to the gas-powered variant, there’s also a hybrid model.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The flagship of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/">Lexus</a> lineup, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/ls/2018/">Lexus LS</a> is a full-size sedan available with a gas or hybrid powertrain. As with the previous generations, the new model comes standard with rear-wheel drive but all-wheel drive will likely be added as an option on the <strong>gas-powered LS 500</strong>. The <strong>hybrid model is called LS 500h</strong>.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Compared to the outgoing model, the 2018 Lexus LS is much larger. The 2018 model is longer than the long-wheelbase version of the outgoing car. The previous model’s V-8 engine has also been replaced by a 3.5-liter twin-turbo V-6 rated at 415 hp and 442 lb-ft of torque. A 10-speed automatic transmission replaces the old eight-speed unit. The hybrid model returns but is now makes use of a 3.5-liter V-6 coupled to an electric motor, a lithium-ion battery, a CVT and a four-speed automatic. Total output stands at 354 hp.</p>

<p>The F Sport trim receives 20-inch alloy wheels, larger brakes measuring 15.7 inches up front and 14.1 inches in the back and summer performance tires for the rear-drive LS 500 F Sport. An optional Handling package adds variable gear ratio steering, active rear steering, an active stabilizer, and a sport-tuned air suspension. F Sport variants also receive a revised spindle grille, rocker panels, trunk moldings, F Sport exclusive front seats, a unique F Sport steering wheel, an LFA-inspired gauge cluster, aluminum pedals, and Ultrasuede upholstery. The LS 500 and LS 500h can both be had in F Sport trim.</p>

<p>Expect the 2018 LS to feature a slew of new tech including an updated multimedia system with a large screen with touchpad controls, heated, ventilated and massaging seats for front and rear passengers, rear-wheel steering, tri-beam LED headlights, and an intuitive pedestrian detection system than can steer the car out of pedestrians’ way.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, pedestrian detection, lane departure warning with steering assist, and intelligent high beams should come standard in the 2018 LS as part of the Lexus Safety System+ suite of active safety and driver assistance features. Expect other features such as blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert and lane keeping assist to also be available.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>We haven’t driven the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/ls/2018/2018-lexus-ls-first-look-building-a-bolder-flagship/">2018 Lexus LS</a> yet but we expect it to be a more luxurious car than its predecessor. The hybrid variant should be more fuel efficient as it has ditched the 5.0-liter V-8 in favor of a 3.5-liter V-6 as its gas engine. Both the LS 500 and <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/lc-500h/2018/2018-lexus-ls-500h-first-look-review/">LS 500h</a> should be better to drive and ride much better thanks to the new platform.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The LS 500h’s new hybrid powertrain first appeared in the LC 500h coupe</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/es/2018/">2018 Lexus ES</a> gets available bi-LED headlights and all variants receive an updated <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/">Lexus</a> Enform interface. A new Premier package is now available on the ES 350.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting below the larger, rear-drive GS, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/es/2018/">Lexus ES</a> is a front-drive entry-level midsize luxury sedan. Unlike the smaller, rear-drive IS, the ES is more oriented toward comfort instead of sportiness, and is also available as a four-cylinder hybrid. Lexus ES models include the <strong>ES 300h</strong> hybrid and <strong>ES 350</strong> V-6.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Lexus ES offers two powertrain options including a 3.5-liter V-6 with 268 hp and 248 lb-ft of torque paired to a six-speed automatic transmission in the ES 350. Go for the ES 300h and the car has a 200-hp hybrid system that couples a 2.5-liter I-4 to an electric motor and a CVT in the ES 300h. EPA fuel economy ratings are 21/30 mpg city/highway for the ES 350 and 40/39 mpg for the ES 300h. Trunk space is generous in the ES 350 at 15.2 cubic feet; however, the ES 300h only has 12.1 cubic feet due to hybrid system components eating up a bit of the trunk. Neither model has split-folding rear seats, making the ES less practical than some of its competitors.</p>

<p>Standard features include keyless entry/start, Bluetooth connectivity, 10-way power adjustable front seats, leatherette upholstery, a rearview camera, LED headlights, 17-inch alloy wheels and dual-zone climate control. Options include 18-inch alloy wheels (ES 350 only), navigation, an 8.0-inch screen, a Mark Levinson premium audio system, heated and ventilated front seats, a panoramic sunroof, a power-operated trunk, leather upholstery, and ambient lighting.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Lexus ES received a five-star overall safety rating (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test a 2018 ES but a 2017 model received a Good score on all crash tests and Average on the new headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the ES received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph and 25-mpg collision (Superior is the highest score possible on the front crash prevention test). As a result, the Lexus ES got the Top Safety Pick+ award from the IIHS.</p>

<p>The Lexus Safety System+ safety suite comes standard and combines forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, pedestrian detection, high beam assist, adaptive cruise control, and sway warning. Blind spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert are optional as part of a package.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>Even though it’s the less powerful variant, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/es300h/2018/">Lexus ES 300h</a> offers plenty of power on tap while giving you excellent fuel economy for its size. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/es300h/2017/2017-lexus-es-300h-hybrid-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we were impressed with the car’s spacious interior, especially the rear seats, which offer plenty of room for three across thanks to a nearly nonexistent drivetrain hump. However, like most hybrids, the brakes aren’t linear and will take time to get used to. The suspension, on the other hand, offer a comfortable ride until you get to rough surfaces where it can become bouncy.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/buick/lacrosse/2012/2012-buick-lacrosse-hyundai-azera-2013-lexus-es-350-comparison/">2012 comparison test</a> that also included the last-generation <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/buick/lacrosse/2018/">Buick LaCrosse</a> and the recently discontinued <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/azera/2018/">Hyundai Azera</a>, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/es350/2018/">Lexus ES 350</a> ended up in third place due to its lack of sound deadening in the interior, dull driving manners, unsupportive seats and surprisingly rough ride for a Lexus.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Lexus ES was the second vehicle to join the Lexus lineup, debuting alongside the full-size LS sedan back in 1989.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/lc/2018/">2018 Lexus LC</a> is a new grand touring coupe that serves as the flagship of the Japanese automaker’s lineup and is the first vehicle to use the GA-L platform.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/lc/2018/">Lexus LC</a> is a rear-drive luxury coupe slotting above the smaller RC coupe, with prices starting just below $100,000. A hybrid variant is also available but all-wheel drive isn’t offered on any variant.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/">Lexus</a> LC comes in two variants, the <strong>LC 500</strong>, which is powered by a 5.0-liter V-8 with 471 hp and 398 lb-ft of torque paired to a 10-speed automatic transmission, and the <strong>LC 500h</strong>, which features a hybrid system that combines a 3.5-liter V-6, an electric motor, a nickel metal hydride battery, a CVT and a four-speed automatic for a total output of 354 hp. EPA fuel economy ratings are 16/26 mpg city/highway for the LC 500 and 26/35 mpg for the LC 500h. There’s 0nly 5.4 cubic feet of cargo space in the LC 500 and 4.7 cubic feet in the LC 500h.</p>

<p>Standard features include 20-inch alloy wheels, LED headlights, leather upholstery, 10-way power front seats, an 8.0-inch multi-information display, keyless entry/start, a 12-speaker audio system, navigation with a 10.3-inch screen, and a rearview camera. Options include heated and ventilated front seats, semi-aniline leather upholstery, 21-inch alloy wheels, a limited-slip differential, a head-up display, a carbon fiber roof, active rear wheel steering, a variable gear ratio steering system, active rear spoiler, carbon fiber scuff plates, a heated steering wheel and a Mark Levinson premium audio system.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/lc/2018/2018-lexus-lc500-lc500h-first-test-review/">2018 First Test review</a>, we said that the LC 500 offers good acceleration but its curb weight of over 4,000 pounds and fuel economy-tuned transmission hinders its straight line performance. Although the LC does handle well, it’s more of a grand tourer than a sports car. On the road, the LC offers a comfortable ride even with the massive 20- or 21-inch alloy wheels, making it an excellent long distance cruiser. The interior is exquisitely crafted with high-quality materials and supremely comfortable seats, further hinting at its grand tourer leanings. Rear seat space, however, is tight in the LC 500 and even more so in the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/lc-500/2018/2018-lexus-lc-500-lc-500h-first-drive-review/">LC 500h</a> due to the extra components of the hybrid powertrain. Lexus’ infotainment system lags behind its competitors and is distracting to use due to its touchpad controls.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Lexus LC. Lexus Safety System+ is standard on the 2018 Lexus LC. That standard package of tech includes adaptive cruise control, automatic high beams, lane keeping assist with steering assist, lane departure warning, pedestrian detection, automatic emergency braking and forward collision warning.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Lexus LC shares its platform and hybrid system with the upcoming LS sedan.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/rc/2018/">2018 Lexus RC</a> gets a new 10.3-inch screen when equipped with navigation, an updated <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/">Lexus</a> Enform telematics system, and a 5 hp bump for V-6-powered models. Lexus Safety System+ is now standard on all variants of the RC.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/rc/2018/">Lexus RC</a> is a compact luxury sports coupe that slots below the larger, more luxurious LC coupe. Rear-wheel drive is standard and all-wheel drive is optional. A high-performance variant called the RC F is also offered and comes exclusively in rear-drive configuration.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Three engines choices are available in the 2018 Lexus RC including a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 241 hp and 258 lb-ft of torque in the <strong>RC 300 RWD</strong>, a 3.5-liter V-6 with 260 hp and 236 lb-ft in the <strong>RC 300 AWD</strong>, 311 hp and 277 lb-ft in the <strong>RC 350</strong>, or a 5.0-liter V-8 with 467 hp and 389  lb-ft in the <strong>RC F</strong>. An eight-speed automatic transmission is standard on rear-drive variants of the RC coupe while all-wheel drive models get a six-speed unit. EPA fuel economy ratings are 22/32 mpg city/highway for the RC 300 RWD, 19/26 mpg for the RC 300 AWD and RC 350 AWD, 19/28 mpg for the rear-drive RC 350, and 16/25 mpg for the RC F. Trunk space in the RC coupe is small at 10.4 cubic feet and it’s even less in the RC F at 10.1 cubic feet; however, it can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>Standard features include leatherette upholstery, keyless entry/start, 18-inch alloy wheels, Bluetooth connectivity, a 10-speaker audio system, a rearview camera, a 7.0-inch screen, and power adjustable front seats. Options include a Mark Levinson premium audio system, navigation with a 10.3-inch screen, leather upholstery, heated/ventilated front seats, a heated steering wheel, driver’s seat memory, and 19-inch alloy wheels. F Sport models get unique features like sport seats, an F Sport steering wheel, adaptive variable suspension, and an LFA-inspired gauge cluster. The RC F can be had with performance goodies like a torque vectoring rear differential as part of the Performance package, which also adds a carbon fiber roof and rear spoiler.</p>

<p><strong>Safety<br/></strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Lexus RC. A 2017 model, however, earned a Good score on all crash worthiness tests and an Average score on the headlights test from the IIHS (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Lexus RC got an Advanced rating after it avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the impact of a 25-mph one by 8 mph (Superior is the highest score on the front crash prevention test.</p>

<p>Lexus Safety System+ is standard on all 2018 RC coupes and it bundles together automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, lane departure warning with steering assist, and adaptive cruise control. Blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert is available as part of an optional package.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/rc-f/2015/2015-lexus-rc-f-first-test/">2015 First Test</a>, we noted that the RC F offers strong acceleration; however, since the car’s platform is built out of parts from three different cars, which means it is surprisingly heavy. Despite its heft, the RC F offers good handling and understeer was easy to correct. Drifting the RC F was also easy thanks to the torque vectoring rear differential. The less powerful RC 350 is just as playful in the corners but because it’s so heavy, it felt underpowered despite having over 300 hp. The car’s brakes aren’t meant for track duty, and will easily overheat if pushed hard. The RC F lost a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/rc-f/2015/2015-bmw-m4-vs-2015-lexus-rc-f-comparison/">2014 comparison test</a> against the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/m4/2018/">BMW M4</a> because it was deemed too soft for track use and as a whole, the M4 performance better. However, the Lexus sounds great and is much easier to drive at its limit thanks to its stability.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Lexus RC’s platform is a combinations of bits and pieces taken from the current generation IS and GS sedans, and the previous generation IS Convertible.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/gx/2018/">2018 Lexus GX</a> gets two-tone Black and Sepia leatherette upholstery as standard on the bench seat with the Premium package and standard semi-aniline leather upholstery on the Luxury trim. Second-row captain’s chairs now come standard with the available Sport Design package on the range-topping Luxury grade.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/gx/2018/">Lexus GX</a> is a midsize three-row SUV with seating for up to seven passengers with the standard bench seats or six with the optional second-row captain’s chairs. The GX slots below the flagship LX and two-row RX midsize crossover in <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/">Lexus</a>’ lineup. Four-wheel drive comes standard on all Lexus GX variants.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Lexus GX’s only engine is a 4.6-liter V-8 with 301 hp and 329 lb-ft of torque, that is paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are low at 15/18 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p>Despite its size, the 2018 Lexus GX isn’t very roomy with 11.6 cubic feet behind the third row, 46.7 cubic feet behind the second row, and 64.7 cubic feet behind the front seats, making it less practical than other SUVs of similar size. When properly equipped, the GX can tow up to 6,500 pounds of payload.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base GX 460 include a rearview camera, LED low-beam headlights, 18-inch alloy wheels, leatherette upholstery, 10-way power front seats, 40/20/40 split-folding second-row bench, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, a nine-speaker audio system, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, keyless entry/start, the Kinetic Dynamic Suspension system, and a Torsen limited-slip differential with an electronic locking feature.</p>

<p>Options include navigation, blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert, LED fog lights, heated and ventilated front seats, heated second-row seats, parking sensors, second-row captain’s chairs, tri-zone climate control, adaptive variable suspension, front and right side view cameras, a rear entertainment system, and a Mark Levinson premium audio system. The Sport Design package, which is available on the Premium and Luxury trims, adds a a unique front bumper and front grille lower garnish, a rear bumper spoiler, a chrome-tipped exhaust, Scarlet Red taillight graphics, side mirrors with chrome accents, and gunmetal 18-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Lexus GX. However, the IIHS did give the SUV a Basic rating for the front crash prevention test thanks to its forward collision warning tech but hasn’t tested the GX’s crash avoidance tech (Superior is the highest rating for the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p>The Driver Support package, which is available exclusively on the range-topping Luxury trim as an order-only option, adds features including lane departure warning, adaptive cruise control, automatic high beams, driver attention alert, pedestrian detection, and the Pre-Collision System, which combines forward collision warning and automatic emergency braking.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/gx460/2017/2017-lexus-gx-460-first-test-review/">2017 First Test review</a>, we said that the Lexus GX is an excellent off-road vehicle and can easily tackle rough terrain. That doesn’t come at the cost of on-road comfort because it rides well for a truck-based SUV. The GX’s cabin stays quiet while on the road, and build quality is typical Lexus, which means high-grade materials throughout the interior. As for the infotainment system, it’s easy to use since it doesn’t have the mouse-like controls or the touchpad found in newer Lexus models; however, it is dated and doesn’t come with Apple CarPlay or Android Auto support. Handling is sloppy due to excessive body roll when taking turns. Also, the six-speed automatic transmission sometimes upshifts too early.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Lexus GX is closely related to the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/4runner/2018/">Toyota 4Runner</a> and the global-market <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/land-cruiser/2018/">Toyota Land Cruiser</a> Prado.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>
