<p>The refreshed <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/nx/2018/">2018 Lexus NX</a> gets a slightly revised exterior, standard active safety features, and a new name for the turbocharged model, which now carries the NX 300 moniker instead of NX 200t. A larger 10.3-inch is now available along with the updated navigation option, and a new exterior color called Caviar has also been added.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/nx/2018/">Lexus NX</a> is a compact luxury crossover that slots below the larger midsize RX and above the upcoming UX subcompact crossover. In addition to the gas-only variant, the NX is also available as a hybrid that comes standard with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/">Lexus</a> NX comes with two powertrain options, a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 235 hp and 258 lb-ft of torque in the <strong>NX 300</strong> that comes paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission or a hybrid system in the <strong>NX 300h</strong> that couples a 2.5-liter I-4 to three electric motors, a nickel metal hydride battery and a CVT. Combined output in the NX 300h is 194 hp.</p>

<p>There are no EPA fuel economy ratings for the 2018 Lexus NX but the 2017 model was rated at 22/28 mpg city/high for front-drive models and non-F Sport all-wheel drive variants or 22/27 for F Sport models with all-wheel drive. The NX 300h is the most fuel efficient model and is rated at 33/30 mpg.</p>

<p>Cargo space in the NX 300 is 17.7 cubic feet with the 60/40 split-folding rear seats in place or 54.6 cubic feet with them down. The extra hybrid powertrain components in the NX 300h cuts into cargo capacity slightly, dropping the space to 16.8 cubic feet with the rear seats in place and 53.7 cubic feet with them folded. When properly equipped, the NX 300 can tow up to 2,000 pounds of payload while the NX 300h can tow up to 1,500 pounds.</p>

<p>Standard features include LED headlights, an 8.0-inch screen, the Lexus Safety System+ active safety suite, 17-inch alloy wheels, a rearview camera, power-folding side mirrors, Bluetooth connectivity, and a 4.2-inch multi-information display. Options include a Mark Levinson premium audio system, 18-inch alloy wheels, heated and ventilated front seats, a power liftgate, navigation with a 10.3-inch screen, and a power-adjustable steering column. The F Sport package adds some sporty flair to the 2018 NX 300 and adds features like a unique front fascia, an Active Sound Control system, sport seats, an F Sport steering wheel, and an LFA-inspired gauge cluster.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Lexus NX received a five-star overall rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). Although the IIHS has yet to test the 2018 NX, it has crash tested the 2017 model, which received a Good score on all crash worthiness tests and Average on the new headlight test (Good is the possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the NX avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the severity of a 25-mph impact by 9 mph, enabling it to receive an Advanced rating (Superior is the highest possible score in the front crash prevention test). As a result, the NX received the Top Safety Pick+ award from the IIHS.</p>

<p>Lexus Safety System+ is standard on the 2018 NX and it bundles together adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, pedestrian detection, lane departure warning, and automatic high beams. Blind-spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert are available as part of an optional package.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>We’ve yet to review the refreshed 2018 NX but in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/nx300h/2015/2015-lexus-nx-200t-300h-first-drive/">2015 First Drive review</a>, we said that the NX features a comfortable ride thanks to its unique suspension setup despite its short wheelbase. The crossover’s steering is lively and holds the road well, giving it confident handling. Both variants of the NX, however, are a bit heavy, so regardless of the engine choice, neither will be a rocket in a straight line compared to the competition, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/nx300h/2015/2015-lexus-nx-200t-f-sport-300h-first-test/">2015 First Test</a>.</p>

<p>The NX won a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/nx200t/2015/the-big-test-2015-luxury-compact-crossovers/">2015 comparison test</a> that included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/x3/2018/">BMW X3</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/range-rover/2018/">Land Rover Range Rover</a> Evoque, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkc/2018/">Lincoln MKC</a>, and the previous generation <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/xc60/2018/">Volvo XC60</a>. Thanks to its lowest as-tested price, confident handling, well-crafted interior, and low ownership costs. However, the NX did get dinged for its lack of headroom and poor visibility.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Lexus NX was the first Lexus vehicle to feature the brand’s 2.0-liter turbo-four when it first arrived for the 2015 model year.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/gs/2018/">2018 Lexus GS</a> gets an updated adaptive cruise control system and the GS 200t has been renamed to the GS 300.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/gs/2018/">Lexus GS</a> is the brand’s midsize luxury sport sedan, slotting below the larger LS and above the compact IS. Rear-wheel drive comes standard and all-wheel drive is available only on the GS 350.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">Four powertrain choices are available in the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/">Lexus</a> GS.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 11pt;line-height: 115%;font-family: Georgia, serif">Model: <strong>GS 300 RWD</strong></span><span style="font-size: 11pt;line-height: 115%;font-family: Georgia, serif"><br>
Engine and Transmission: 2.0-liter turbo-four – eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 241 hp/258 lb-ft of torque<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 22/32 mpg city/highway (GS 300); 21/30 mpg (GS 300 F Sport)</br></br></br></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 11pt;line-height: 115%;font-family: Georgia, serif">Model: <strong>GS 350 RWD; GS 350 AWD</strong></span><span style="font-size: 11pt;line-height: 115%;font-family: Georgia, serif"><br>
Engine and Transmission: 3.5-liter V-6 – eight-speed automatic ((rear-wheel drive) or six-speed automatic (all-wheel drive)<br>
Power: 311 hp/280 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 20/28 mpg (GS 350 RWD); 19/28 mpg (GS 350 F Sport); 19/26 mpg (GS 350 AWD)</br></br></br></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 11pt;line-height: 115%;font-family: Georgia, serif">Model: <strong>GS 450h</strong></span><span style="font-size: 11pt;line-height: 115%;font-family: Georgia, serif"><br>
Engine and Transmission: 3.5-liter V-6 + electric – CVT<br>
Power: 338 hp combined<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 29/34 mpg</br></br></br></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size: 11pt;line-height: 115%;font-family: Georgia, serif">Model: <strong>GS F</strong></span><span style="font-size: 11pt;line-height: 115%;font-family: Georgia, serif"><br>
Engine and Transmission: 5.0-liter V-8 – eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 467 hp/289 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 16/24 mpg<br/></br></br></br></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">Cargo space in the GS 300 and GS 350 is 18.4 cubic feet but it can’t be expanded since the car doesn’t come with split-folding rear seats. The GS 450H has less cargo space at 15.9 cubic feet due to the extra powertrain components. The GS F has the least cargo space at 14 cubic feet.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">Standard features include keyless entry/start, dual-zone climate control, a moonroof, 10-way power front seats with memory, a drive mode selector, LED headlights, Bluetooth connectivity, a 8.0-inch screen, a 12-speaker audio system, and a rearview camera. Options include heated and ventilated front seats, leather upholstery, navigation with a 12.3-inch screen, a heated steering wheel, parking sensors, a Mark Levinson premium sound system, a power-operated trunk, a head-up display, triple-beam LED headlights and 19-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">The F Sport variant comes with unique styling cues such as a different grille, an F Sport leather-wrapped steering wheel, aluminum trim, dark graphite 19-inch alloy wheels, high performance brakes (rear-drive models only), F Sport adaptive variable suspension, 16-way adjustable F Sport front seats, a Sport S+ mode, LFA-inspired digital gauge cluster, and optional orange brake calipers. The GS 350 F Sport can be had with other go-fast features such as the Lexus Dynamic Handling System that bundles together variable gear ratio steering and rear-wheel steering, and a Torsen limited-slip differential.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">The NHTSA hasn’t crash tested the 2018 Lexus GS. In IIHS testing, it earned a Good rating on the roof strength, moderate front overlap impact, and side impact tests (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Lexus GS only received a Basic rating to indicate that it has forward collision warning since the rest of its front crash avoidance tech hasn’t been tested yet (Superior is the highest score in the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">Standard on all Lexus GS models is the Lexus Safety System+, which bundles together adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning with steering assist, and automatic high beams. Blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert is available as a separate option or as part of a package.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal">In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/gs/2017/2017-lexus-gs-350-f-sport-first-test-review/" style="font-family: Georgia, serif">2017 First Test review</a>, we said that the GS 350 F Sport offers linear acceleration thanks to its smooth V-6 engine; however, its competitors are more powerful and are quicker in a straight line. The F Sport variant’s stiffer suspension, offers excellent handling but it comes at the cost of ride comfort. Interior space is average for the class and the infotainment system’s mouse-like controls are finicky to use. The less powerful 2.0-liter turbo-four offers respectable mid-range punch and doesn’t feel underpowered, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/gs-200t/2016/2016-lexus-gs-200t-first-drive-review/" style="font-family: Georgia, serif">2016 First Drive review</a>. However, it does suffer from turbo lag and takes some time before it finally gives you power. Even with the smaller engine, the GS is fun to drive thanks to well-controlled body motions and confident handling.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">The performance-oriented GS F placed second in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/cts-v/2016/comparison-audi-s6-4-0t-quattro-vs-cadillac-cts-v-sport-vs-lexus-gs-f/" style="font-family: Georgia, serif">2016 comparison test</a> that also include the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/s6/2018/">Audi S6</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/cts/2018/">Cadillac CTS</a> VSport thanks to its well-appointed interior and engaging driving dynamics. However, the overly harsh ride and dulled responses on all but the most aggressive kept it from winning along with its complicated multimedia interface.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Lexus GS was the automaker’s third vehicle launched after the LS and ES.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: Georgia, serif"><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/e-class/">Mercedes-Benz E-Class</a></span><span style="font-family: Georgia, serif"><br><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/5-series/">BMW 5 Series</a><br><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a6/">Audi A6</a><br><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/genesis/g80/">Genesis G80</a><br><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/s90/">Volvo S90</a></br></br></br></br></span></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/lx/2018/">2018 Lexus LX</a> gets an updated <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/">Lexus</a> Enform telematics system and a new exterior color, Eminent White Pearl, which replaces Starfire Pearl.</p>

<p><strong> Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/lx/2018/">Lexus LX</a> is the most expensive SUV in Lexus’ lineup, slotting above the smaller GX. It comes standard with four-wheel drive and seats up to eight passengers.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Lexus LX is available as a a single model, the LX 570, and is powered exclusively by a 5.7-liter V-8 with 383 hp and 403 lb-ft of torque that comes paired exclusively to an eight-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings for the 2018 LX isn’t very good at 13/18 mpg city/highway, making it one of the least efficient vehicles in its class.</p>

<p>With all seats in place, the 2018 LX has 9.1 cubic feet of cargo space, which is extremely small for such a large car. That can be expanded to 24.8 cubic feet with the third row folded and 44.7 cubic feet behind the front seats, both of which are still smaller than many SUVs its size. When properly equipped, the 2018 LX can tow up to 7,000 pounds of payload.</p>

<p>Standard features include LED headlights, 20-inch alloy wheels, parking sensors, Crawl Control with Turn Assist, the Multi-Terrain Select System, an adjustable suspension system, leather upholstery, power front seats, power-operated split-folding second and third row seats, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, a 360-degree camera system, keyless entry/start, a 12.3-inch screen, navigation, a nine-speaker audio system, four-zone climate control, and a power tailgate.</p>

<p>The Luxury package adds semi-aniline leather upholstery with contrast stitching and heated and ventilated front and second row seats. Standalone options include 21-inch alloy wheels, a wireless mobile device charging pad, a head-up display, a Mark Levinson premium audio system, a cool box, and a rear entertainment system with two 11.6-inch screens and two headphones.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Lexus LX a five-star rollover rating and a four-star front crash rating (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has not crash tested the 2018 Lexus LX.</p>

<p>Standard on all 2018 LX models is the Lexus Safety System+ suite that bundles together adaptive cruise control, automatic high beams, lane departure warning, pedestrian detection, forward collision warning, and automatic emergency braking. Blind-spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert also comes standard on the 2018 LX.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/lx570/2016/2016-lexus-lx-570-first-test-review/">2016 First Test review</a>, we said that the LX 570 is a capable off-road vehicle thanks to its adjustable suspension; however, it doesn’t have the same capability as its sister vehicle, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/land-cruiser/2018/">Toyota Land Cruiser</a>, because it lacks the necessary departure angles. On pavement, Comfort mode does cause a significant amount of body roll while Sport mode does enable the transmission to more frequently. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/lx570/2018/">Lexus LX 570</a> is distinguished from the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> Land Cruiser thanks to its array of luxury and comfort features, as well as different exterior styling including an enormous grille.</p>

<p><strong> Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Lexus LX is closely related to Toyota Land Cruiser and is built in the same factory in Aichi, Japan.</p>

<p><strong> Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkx/2018/">2018 Lincoln MKX</a> gets the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/">Lincoln</a> Way app with Lincoln Connect as standard across all models. Black Label variants now come standard with the Climate package. For the 2019 model year, the MKX becomes <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2019-lincoln-nautilus-first-look-review-mkx-replacement-gets-new-name/">the Nautilus</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Trim Levels (Interior and Exterior Options)</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkx/2018/">Lincoln MKX</a> is a midsize five-passenger luxury crossover that slots below the three-row MKT and smaller MKC. Front-wheel drive is standard and all-wheel drive is optional.</p>

<p><strong>MKX Premiere:</strong> The base Premiere trim comes standard with HID headlights, rear parking sensors, remote start, keyless entry and start, two USB ports, a 10-speaker audio system, the Sync 3 infotainment system with an 8.0-inch touchscreen, heated 10-way power adjustable front seats, a rearview camera, and 18-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>MKX Select: </strong>Moving up to the Select trim adds a hands-free power liftgate, dual-zone climate control, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and leather upholstery.</p>

<p><strong>MKX Reserve: </strong>The Reserve trim adds navigation, a panoramic glass roof, wood interior trim, ventilated front seats, and 20-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>MKX Black Label: </strong>Black Label models come with exclusive interior treatments such as embroided Venetian leather upholstery, and add a Revel Ultima premium audio system with 19 speakers.</p>

<p>Options include adaptive LED headlights, a 360-degree camera system, front parking sensors, active parking assistant, heated outboard rear seats, 21-inch alloy wheels, adaptive suspension, and 22-way power adjustable front seats with massage function. Navigation and ventilated front seats, which are standard on higher trims, are available on lower trims as part of packages.</p>

<p><strong>Performance and Fuel Economy</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 MKX comes standard with a 3.7-liter V-6 rated at 303 hp and 278 lb-ft of torque. A 2.7-liter twin-turbo V-6 with 335 hp and 380 lb-ft is optional. Both engines are paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the base 3.7-liter V-6 is 17/24 mpg city/highway in front-drive guise and 16/23 mpg with all-wheel drive. Surprisingly, the more powerful 2.7-liter twin-turbo V-6 is the most efficient at 18/25 mpg for front-drive models and 17/25 mpg for all-wheel-drive-equipped models.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 MKX received a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing the 2018 MKX received a Good score on all crash tests except the headlights test where it received a Marginal rating (Good is the highest possible score). In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the 2018 MKC received a Superior rating after it avoided 12- and a 25-mph collisions (Superior is the highest rating for the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p>Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert are optional on the Select trim and standard on the Reserve trim. Lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, adaptive steering, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, and automatic emergency braking is available as part of the Driver Assistance package.</p>

<p><strong>Utility</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Lincoln MKX has 27.2 cubic feet of cargo space behind the rear seats and can be expanded to 68.8 cubic feet behind the front seats. When properly equipped the 2018 MKX can tow 3,500 pounds.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkx/2016/2016-lincoln-mkx-awd-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we were impressed with the MKX’s ride and handling balance thanks to its supple ride and excellent body control. The optional twin-turbo V-6 offers plenty of power on tap, giving it plenty of straight-line performance. Lincoln’s multimedia interface, however, isn’t quick to respond.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkx/2016/2016-lexus-rx-mercedes-benz-glc-lincoln-mkx-comparison/">2016 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/glc-class/2018/">Mercedes-Benz GLC-Class</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/rx/2018/">Lexus RX</a>, the Lincoln MKX placed second. Despite having a well-built interior, there’s some cheap plastics in certain places and hollow-sounding buttons on the center stack.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Lincoln MKX, along with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/edge/2018/">Ford Edge</a>, was one of the first vehicles to utilize <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a>’s 2.7-liter twin-turbo V-6.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkc/2018/">2018 Lincoln MKC</a> gets a number of new exterior colors including Blue Diamond Metallic, Iced Mocha Metallic, and Rhapsody Blue. All models now come standard with 4G LTE connectivity and four-way lumbar support for the driver. The MKC gets <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkc/2019/2019-lincoln-mkc-first-look-review/">a minor update</a> for the 2019 model year.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkc/2018/">Lincoln MKC</a> is a compact luxury crossover that slots below the MKX (the MKX is called the Nautilus starting in the 2019 model year). Front-wheel drive comes standard and all-wheel drive is optional.</p>

<p><strong>MKC Premiere: </strong>Standard equipment on the base Premiere trim include keyless entry and start, dual-zone climate control, remote start, the Sync 3 multimedia system with an 8.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth, two USB ports, a nine-speaker audio system, heated power adjustable front seats with 12-way and six-way adjustments for the driver and passenger respectively, rear parking sensors, HID headlights, a power liftgate, 18-inch alloy wheels, and a rearview camera.</p>

<p><strong>MKC Select: </strong>Moving up to the Select trim adds leather upholstery, ambient lighting, configurable daytime running lights, and 12-way power adjustable passenger seats.</p>

<p><strong>MKC Reserve: </strong>The range-topping Reserve grade adds a navigation, ventilated front seats, and a hands-free power liftgate.</p>

<p>Options include a heated steering wheel, heated rear outboard seats, a THX-certified audio system, active parking assist, adaptive suspension and 19- or 20-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p>The 2018 MKC comes standard with a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 245 hp and 275 lb-ft of torque. A 2.3-liter turbo-four with 285 hp and 305 lb-ft is optional. Both engines are paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the standard 2.0-liter turbo-four is 21/28 mpg city/highway for front-drive models and 19/25 mpg with all-wheel drive. Move up to the 2.3-liter turbo-four and fuel economy drops to 18/25 mpg.</p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 MKC a four-star overall safety rating (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 MKC received a Good rating and the side impact and moderate front overlap test (Good is the highest possible score). The car also received a Basic rating on the IIHS’ front crash prevention test for having an available forward collision warning system.</p>

<p>Blind-spot monitoring comes standard on the Reserve trim. The Technology package, which is also available on the Reserve grade, adds forward collision warning, adaptive cruise control, automatic emergency braking, and lane keeping assist.</p>

<p><strong>Utility</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/">Lincoln</a> MKC has 25.2 cubic feet of cargo space with the standard split-folding rear seats in place and it can be expanded to 53.1 cubic feet. When properly equipped, the 2018 MKC can tow up to 3,000 pounds.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkc/2015/2015-lincoln-mkc-20-23-ecoboost-first-test/">2015 First Test</a>, we said that with the optional 2.3-liter turbo-four, the MKC offers potent acceleration, giving it good straight-line performance. However, the six-speed automatic sometimes feels lazy with its responses. Cabin materials are a mixed bag: the buttons feel cheap, but most of the interior features high-quality plastics, wood, and metal.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/nx200t/2015/the-big-test-2015-luxury-compact-crossovers/">2015 comparison test</a> that also included the previous-generation <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/x3/2018/">BMW X3</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/nx/2018/">Lexus NX</a>, Range Rover Evoque, and the previous-generation <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/xc60/2018/">Volvo XC60</a>, the Lincoln MKC placed fourth. The Lincoln’s unpredictable throttle response hurt its overall drivability and its handling felt clumsy. On the positive side, minimal road noise enters the cabin and the ride is comfortable thanks to the available adjustable dampers.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Everything. The <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/navigator/2018/">2018 Lincoln Navigator</a> gets its first major makeover in a decade. Thanks to a new chassis and aluminum body panels, the Navigator loses about 200 pounds over the previous model. In addition to the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/refreshing-revolting-2018-lincoln-navigator/">Continental-influenced exterior styling</a>, updates include a revised drivetrain, more infotainment options, and quieter interior as well as more luxurious interior appointments.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The full-size three-row 2018 <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/navigator/2018/">Lincoln Navigator</a> is the premium brand’s flagship model and sits above the compact MKC and midsize two-row MKX and three-row MKT crossovers as well as the full-size Continental and midsize MKZ sedans.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/navigator/2018/2018-lincoln-navigator-first-look-review/">Power for the 2018 Lincoln Navigator</a> comes from a second-generation twin-turbo 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6 making an estimated 450 hp and 500 lb-ft of torque. The engine also features a new stop/start system. A 10-speed automatic backs the engine and sends power to the all-wheel-drive system with an electronically locking rear differential.</p>

<p>Luxury appointments include front heated and ventilated 30-way power seats with massage function and memory settings, French-stitched leather seats in all three rows, second-row climate control and tilting second- and third-row seats.</p>

<p><a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/">Lincoln</a> isolated the Navigator’s interior from the outside world by adding laminated windows, a noise-canceling system, redesigned climate ducts, and new tires. Infotainment features include a 20-speaker Revel Ultima audio system, and Android Auto and Apple CarPlay. The Navigator also features second-row audio controls. An available rear entertainment system features a pair of 10.0-inch screens on the back of the front headrests as well as SD, HDMI, and quick-charging 2.5-amp USB ports (there are six USB ports overall). The system also supports wireless streaming to each screen via Android phones.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Notable safety driver assistance features include a head-up display, Trailer Backup Assist, a 360-degree camera system, and adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact:</strong></p>

<p>The key fob in the driver’s possession will adjust up to 80 vehicle settings upon start up.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkt/2018/">2018 Lincoln MKT</a> gets three new exterior colors: Blue Diamond Metallic, Iced Mocha Metallic, and Ivory Pearl Metallic.</p>

<p><strong>Trim Levels (Interior and Exterior Options)</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkt/2018/">Lincoln MKT</a> is a midsize three-row crossover slotting above the two-row Nautilus (formerly MKX) and below the flagship three-row Navigator. Front-wheel drive is standard and all-wheel drive is optional. A seven-seat configuration is standard and a six-seat variant is optional.</p>

<p><strong>MKT Premiere: </strong>The base Premiere trim comes standard with a fixed glass roof, adaptive HID headlights, keyless entry and start, remote start, rear parking sensors, a power liftgate, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, ambient lighting, a 10-speaker audio system, the Sync 3 infotainment system, leather upholstery for the first and second rows, 12-way power adjustable front seats, heated and ventilated front seats, 19-inch alloy wheels, and a rearview camera.</p>

<p><strong>MKT Reserve:</strong> Moving up to the Reserve trim gets you an adaptive suspension, three-zone climate control, a heated steering wheel, navigation, and a power-folding third row.</p>

<p>Available options include active parking assist, heated and ventilated second-r0w bucket seats, 20-inch alloy wheels, a power-opening panoramic sunroof, a refrigerator-like chilled compartment in the second row, and a rear-seat entertainment system with two screens mounted in the back of the front seat headrests.</p>

<p><strong>Performance and Fuel Economy</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/">Lincoln</a> MKT comes standard with a 3.7-liter V-6 with 303 hp and 279 lb-ft of torque. Reserve models come standard with all-wheel drive and a 3.5-liter twin-turbo V-6 rated at 365 hp and 350 lb-ft. Both engines come paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings are 16/24 mpg city/highway for the front-drive MKT with the standard 3.7-liter V6 while opting for all-wheel drive drop those numbers to 16/23 mpg. The optional 3.5-liter twin-turbo V-6 drops is the least efficient at 15/21 mpg.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA has only rated the 2018 MKT on the rollover test where it got a four-star rating (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the crossover received a Good score on all but the headlights test where it received a Marginal rating and the front small overlap test where it hasn’t been tested (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the 2018 MKT got a Basic rating for having an available forward collision warning system (Superior is the highest rating for the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p>Blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert comes standard on the Reserve trim. Lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, and automatic emergency braking are available only on the Reserve grade.</p>

<p><strong>Utility</strong></p>

<p>With all seats in place the 2018 MKT has 17.9 cubic feet of cargo space. Fold the third row and that expands to 39.6 cubic feet. That can be expanded further with the second- and third rows down, giving the crossover 75.9 cubic feet of cargo capacity.</p>

<p>Front-drive 2018 MKTs with the standard 3.7-liter V-6 can tow up to 2,000 pounds when properly equipped. The more powerful twin-turbo V-6 increases towing capacity to 4,500 pounds.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkt/2010/2010-lincoln-mkt-ecoboost-test/">2010 First Test</a>, we said that the third row is cramped. With the optional 3.5-liter twin-turbo V-6, the MKT’s acceleration is quick for a such a large vehicle. However, the crossover has a spongy brake pedal that has a delayed response.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkt/2010/2010-lincoln-mkt-ecoboost-test/">2018 Lincoln MKT</a> is closely related to the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/flex/2018/">Ford Flex</a> and shares the same engine options.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors<br/></strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/continental/2018/">2018 Lincoln Continental</a> gets standard 4G LTE. Black Label models now come with the Climate package and a moonroof. The exterior colors Blue Diamond, Ivory Pearl Metallic and Iced Mocha Metallic replace Midnight Sapphire, Jade Metallic, Diamond Black and Palladium Gold.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/continental/2018/">Lincoln Continental</a> is a large luxury sedan that slots above the midsize MKZ and is available in front- or all-wheel-drive configurations. In addition to the three trims described below, the Continental is available in a Black Label variant that features two-tone upholstery in vibrant colors, embroidery on the headrests, complimentary maintenance for four years or 50,000 miles, and more.</p>

<p><strong>Continental Premiere: </strong>The base Premiere trim comes standard with adaptive steering, adaptive suspension, 18-inch alloy wheels, rear parking sensors, keyless entry/start, remote start, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, dual-zone climate control, a 10-inch audio system, the Sync 3 multimedia system with an 8.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth, heated 10-way power adjustable front seats with driver’s side memory, leatherette upholstery, and HID headlights.</p>

<p><strong>Continental Select: </strong>Move up to the Select grade and you get 19-inch alloy wheels, front parking sensors, ambient lighting, and leather upholstery.</p>

<p><strong>Continental Reserve: </strong>The range-topping Reserve trim comes with tri-zone climate control, navigation, a 13-speaker Revel audio system, 24-way power front seats, a power-operated trunk and ventilated front seats.</p>

<p>Options include full LED headlights, heated and ventilated rear seats, 30-way multi-contour front seats with massage function, 20-inch alloy wheels, a 19-speaker Revel Ultima audio system, a heated steering wheel, an automatic parking system, and a head-up display. Features such as navigation, heated and ventilated 24-way adjustable front seats, and the power-operated trunk are available as part of packages or as standalone options on lower trims.</p>

<p>The 2018 Continental comes with three six-cylinder engine choices that are all paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. A 3.7-liter V-6 with 305 hp and 280 lb-ft of torque comes standard on the Premiere and Select trim. The range-topping Reserve trim comes standard with a 2.7-liter twin-turbo V-6 good for 335 hp and 380 lb-ft. This engine is also available as an option on the mid-grade Select. The most powerful engine, a 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 with 400 hp and 400 lb-ft, is only available on the Reserve and Black Label grades and comes standard with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the base 3.7-liter V-6 are 17/26 mpg city/highway for front-drive models and 16/24 mpg with all-wheel drive. Move up to the more powerful 2.7-liter twin-turbo V-6 and fuel efficiency goes up to 18/27 mpg for front-drive variants and 17/25 mpg on cars with all-wheel drive. The 400-hp 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 is rated at 16/24 mpg.</p>

<p>The 2018 Continental received a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing the 2018 Continental received a Good rating in all crashworthiness tests and in the new headlight test (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the 2018 Continental received a Superior rating after it avoided collisions in 12- and 25-mph tests (Superior is the highest rating in the front crash prevention test). As a result of its excellent crash test and front crash prevention scores, the Continental received the 2018 Top Safety Pick+ award from the IIHS.</p>

<p>Forward collision warning comes standard on all but the base Premiere trim. Blind-spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert are optional on the Select grade and standard on the Reserve and Black Label variants. The Technology package, which is available on all but the entry-level Premiere trim, adds lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, pedestrian detection, automatic emergency braking, and automatic high beams.</p>

<p>The 2018 Continental has a 16.7-cubic-foot trunk but it can’t be expanded since the car doesn’t come with split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/continental/2017/2017-lincoln-continental-30t-awd-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we noted that the Continental, when equipped with the 400-hp 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6, offers strong acceleration and handles well for a heavy sedan with most of its weight hanging over the front wheels. However, the six-speed automatic is hesitant to downshift. On the road, the Continental is quiet and the cabin is well-insulated. Ride comfort is excellent for the most part, but sometimes the suspension struggles to soak up sharp bumps, especially when equipped with the 19- and 20-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p>The Continental recently participated in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/genesis/g90/2018/bmw-740e-vs-lexus-ls-500-vs-genesis-g90-33t-vs-lincoln-continental-30/">2017 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/ls/2018/">Lexus LS</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/7-series/2018/">BMW 7 Series</a>, and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/genesis/g90/2018/">Genesis G90</a>. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/">Lincoln</a> placed fourth because it needed more refinement. Throttle tip-in is too aggressive and its cabin suffers from squeaks and rattles. Passenger space, however, is spacious for both front and rear passengers and, overall, editors were impressed by the Lincoln’s potential.</p>

<p>The 2018 Lincoln Continental was one of the first vehicles to utilize the 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 that’s exclusive to Lincoln vehicles.</p>

<p>The <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkz/2018/">2018 Lincoln MKZ</a> gets 4G LTE as standard on all models and the Reserve trim now comes standard with the Revel audio system. A power-operated trunk is now part of the Select Plus package. The new Magnetic package adds cosmetic changes such as a painted grille, aluminum pedals, and 19-inch alloy wheels. Three new exterior colors — Blue Diamond, Ivory Pearl Metallic and Iced Mocha Metallic — are now available.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkz/2018/">Lincoln MKZ</a> is a midsize premium sedan slotting below the larger, more luxurious Continental. Front-wheel drive comes standard and all-wheel drive is optional on gas-only models. A hybrid variant is also available. In addition to the three trims described below, an exclusive Black Label variant based on the Reserve trim comes with unique interior color schemes including two-tone leather upholstery with embroidery.</p>

<p><strong>MKZ Premiere: </strong>The base Premiere trim comes standard with HID headlights, rear parking sensors, a 10.1-inch reconfigurable gauge cluster, dual-zone climate control, leatherette upholstery, keyless entry and start, remote start, two USB ports, the Sync 3 multimedia system with an 8.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth, a 14-speaker Revel premium audio system, a rearview camera, heated 10-way power adjustable front seats, adaptive suspension, and 18-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>MKZ Select: </strong>Moving up to the Select grade adds leather upholstery, ambient lighting, wood interior accents, a power-adjustable steering column, and two additional USB ports.</p>

<p><strong>MKZ Reserve: </strong>Opt for the range-topping Reserve trim and you’ll get navigation, perforated leather upholstery, ventilated front seats, and 19-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p>Optional extras include heated rear seats, multi-contour front seats with massage function, a 20-speaker Revel audio system, a sport-tuned suspension, a heated steering wheel, automatic high beams, and full LED headlights.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/">Lincoln</a> MKZ comes standard with a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 245 hp and 275 lb-ft of torque. A 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 is optional and makes 350 hp in front-drive models or 400 hp with all-wheel drive and 400 lb-ft. Both engines are paired only to a six-speed automatic transmission. The MKZ Hybrid comes with a 2.0-liter I-4 coupled to an electric motor and a CVT for a combined system output of 188 hp.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the base 2.0-liter turbo-four are 21/31 mpg city/highway for front-drive models and 20/28 mpg with all-wheel drive. The more powerful 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 is EPA-rated at 18/27 mpg for front-drive models and 17/26 mpg with all-wheel drive. Hybrid variants are the most efficient, at 41/38 mpg.</p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 MKZ a five-star overall safety rating (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 MKZ received a Good rating on all crash worthiness tests except the headlights test where it received a Marginal rating (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the 2018 MKZ received a Superior score after it avoided collisions in 12- and 25-mph tests (Superior is the highest rating for the front crash prevention test). Active driver assistance features including lane keeping assist, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, automatic emergency braking and adaptive cruise control are optional on the Select and Reserve trims. Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert come standard on the Reserve grade and is optional on the Select model.</p>

<p>The 2018 MKZ has a 15.4-cubic-foot trunk that can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats. Hybrid models have a smaller 11.1-cubic-foot trunk.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkz/2017/2017-lincoln-mkz-3-0t-awd-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we noted that the optional 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 offers strong acceleration but stomping on the accelerator from a stop can easily overwhelm the car’s tires. The six-speed automatic transmission, on the other hand, reacts slower than units found in the MKZ’s rivals. Despite the stiff suspension, active dampers, and torque vectoring, the MKZ is more of a cruiser and doesn’t handle as well as expected. The car is right at home on the open highway, where it remains comfortable and quiet.</p>

<p>Although the MKZ Hybrid isn’t as powerful as its gas-only siblings, we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/lincoln/mkz-hybrid/2017/2017-lincoln-mkz-hybrid-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a> that the car doesn’t feel underpowered. However, it rides stiffly and the steering isn’t precise. We also noted that the our test vehicle had a number of creaks.</p>

<p>The 2018 MKZ rides on the same platform as the <a href="https://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fusion/2018/">Ford Fusion</a> and features the same hybrid system.</p>

<p> </p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/levante/2018/">2018 Maserati Levante</a> gets an updated electric power steering system, and additional active safety features including traffic sign recognition, active blind-spot monitoring, and highway assist.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/levante/2018/">Maserati Levante</a> is a midsize crossover that comes standard with all-wheel drive. It is the first crossover in <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/">Maserati</a>’s lineup and is closely related to the Ghibli and Quattroporte sedans.</p>

<p><strong>Levante GranLusso: </strong>The luxury-oriented Levante GranLusso features touches like a protection plate in a metallic finish, open-pore wood trim, a wood-finished steering wheel, comfort-oriented seats with 12-way adjustability, and two interior choices full Italian Leather or the available silk upholstery by luxury clothing maker Ermengildo Zegna.</p>

<p><strong>Levante GranSport: </strong>On the other side of the spectrum is the Levante GranSport, which features front sport seats, Piano Black interior trim, black roof rails, a sport steering wheel, brushed chrome paddle shifters, and power adjustable aluminum pedals.</p>

<p>Standard features include leather upholstery, 19-inch alloy wheels, an 8.4-inch touchscreen with a rearview camera, Bluetooth connectivity, and heated front seats. Notable options include alloy wheels up to 21 inches in diameter, a surround view camera system, heated rear seats, a heated steering wheel, four-zone climate control, a panoramic sunroof, navigation, HID headlights, air suspension, ventilated front seats, and a Bowers &amp; Wilkins premium audio system.</p>

<p>The 2018 Maserati Levante is powered by a 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 rated at 345 hp and 369 lb-ft of torque in the base Levante Q4 and 424 hp and 428 lb-ft in the Levante S Q4. An eight-speed automatic transmission is the only gearbox available. EPA fuel economy ratings are 14/20 mpg city/highway for the Levante Q4 and 14/19 mpg for the Levante S Q4.</p>

<p>Active safety features are available as part of a package and it includes highway assist, lane keeping assist, blind spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert, traffic sign recognition, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking and adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p>When properly equipped, the 2018 Levante can tow 5,900 pounds of payload. Cargo space is slightly behind most midsize luxury crossovers at 19.4 cubic feet with the split-folding rear seats in place and 57.3 cubic feet with them folded.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/levante/2017/2017-maserati-levante-sq4-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we said that the more powerful Levante S Q4 offers strong acceleration, making it quicker than many of its key competitors. The crossover pairs straight-line speed with excellent handling and a ride that’s comfortable and well-controlled. However, its start/stop system is too aggressive and will activate even if you’ve only stopped for a quick second. The exhaust note in Sport mode also became annoying as it opened up the baffles completely even at half throttle. Passenger space for passengers is generous thanks to the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/levante/2017/2017-maserati-levante-q4-first-test-review/">Levante</a>‘s long wheelbase but it comes at cost of cargo capacity. Interior materials quality, on the other hand, could use improvement because there are trim pieces and buttons that were clearly taken out of the Fiat-<a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/">Chrysler</a> parts bin.</p>

<p> </p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/quattroporte/2018/">2018 Maserati Quattroporte</a> gets a more powerful twin-turbo V-6 engine, an updated electric power steering system, and additional active safety features. Adaptive LED headlights are now available on the 2018 Quattroporte.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/quattroporte/2018/">Maserati Quattroporte</a> is a full-size luxury sedan slotting above the midsize Ghibli. It comes standard in rear- or all-wheel drive configurations; however, the latter is only available on the S grade.</p>

<p><strong>Quattroporte GranLusso:</strong> The more luxury-oriented variant of the Quattroporte features unique interior trims such as wood inlays, unique alloy wheel designs, and wood-trimmed steering wheel. In addition to leather upholstery, the GranLusso is offered with silk upholstery by luxury clothing maker Ermenegildo Zegna that come with personalized labels stitched into the sun visors.</p>

<p><strong>Quattroporte GranSport: </strong>Geared more towards a sportier look, the Quattroporte GranSport features front sport seats, a sport steering wheel, paddle shifters, and an optional Interior Carbon package that adds carbon fiber paddle shifters and door guards.</p>

<p>Notable standard features include 19-inch alloy wheels, leather upholstery, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/">Maserati</a>’s new infotainment system with an 8.4-inch touchscreen, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, a rearview camera, and 12-way power adjustable front seats. Options include a Bowers &amp; Wilkins premium audio system, LED headlights, leather with silk inserts by Zegna, the Skyhook suspension system, and a surround view camera system.</p>

<p>The 2018 Maserati Quattroporte comes standard with a 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 rated at 424 hp and 428 lb-ft of torque on the S and S Q4 models. A 3.8-liter twin-turbo V-8 with 523 hp and 524 lb-ft is only available on the range-topping Quattroporte GTS. Both engines come paired exclusively to an eight-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 16/23 mpg city/highway for the Quattroporte S and S Q4, and 15/22 mpg for the Quattroporte GTS.</p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Maserati Quattroporte. Active safety features are available as part of an optional package and include blind-spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, traffic sign recognition, and highway assist.</p>

<p>Trunk space is generous at 18 cubic feet that can be expanded via the standard split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/quattroporte/2014/2014-maserati-quattroporte-s-q4-first-drive/">2014 First Drive</a>, we said that the V-6-powered Quattroporte offers plenty of power thanks to its prodigious low-end torque. The cabin is well-insulated and stays quiet with minimal wind and road noise. One of the biggest highlights is the Quattroporte’s awesome engine note, which gives it plenty of character but can get tiring after a while if you’re accustomed to the quieter experience provided by the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/s-class/2018/">Mercedes-Benz S-Class</a>. Also, interior quality could be better, as some trim pieces and buttons are too appear to be taken directly from the Fiat <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/">Chrysler</a> Group parts bin.</p>

<p>The more powerful Quattroporte GTS has a more linear power delivery with very little turbo lag, as we observed in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/quattroporte/2014/2014-maserati-quattroporte-v-8-drive/">2014 First Drive</a>. For its size, the Quattroporte handles well thanks to its excellent chassis and steering system. The eight-speed automatic shifts quickly and has a full manual mode that gives you full control of shifting duties.</p>

<p>The 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 in the Quattroporte was designed with input from <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ferrari/">Ferrari</a>.</p>

<p> </p>

<p>The refreshed <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/ghibli/2018/">2018 Maserati Ghibli</a> gets an updated exterior, additional active safety features, and more power on the S and S Q4 variants. Two new sub-models have been added: the luxury-oriented GranLusso and the sporty GranSport. A new electric power steering system has been added to the 2018 Ghibli, as well.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/ghibli/2018/">Maserati Ghibli</a> is a luxury midsize sedan that slots below the large full-size Quattroporte. Rear-wheel drive is standard on all models while all-wheel drive is available only on the Ghibli S Q4.</p>

<p><strong>Ghibli GranLusso: </strong>As the more luxury-oriented sub-trim, the Ghibli GranLusso features chrome bumper inserts, body-colored side skirts, a front spoiler, wood trim and comfort seats with 12-way adjustability. In addition to the standard leather upholstery, you can also opt for silk upholstery by Ermenegildo Zegna in a two-tone scheme.</p>

<p><strong>Ghibli GranSport:</strong> The sport-oriented Ghibli GranSport comes with from sport seats, a more aggressive front bumper, a sport steering wheel, paddle shifters, and sport pedals. You can also opt for a unique grille featuring a Trident badge with blue inserts.</p>

<p>Standard features include leather upholstery, 19-inch alloy wheels, an updated infotainment system with an 8.4-inch touchscreen, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, and a rearview camera. Options include full LED headlights, a surround view camera system, a Bowers &amp; Wilkins premium audio system, navigation,  Wi-Fi connectivity, paddle shifters, alloy wheels up to 21 inches in diameter, adaptive dampers, a power-operated trunk and paddle shifters.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/">Maserati</a> Ghibli is powered by a 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 that comes in two flavors, 345 hp and 369 lb-ft of torque in the base model or 424 hp and 428 lb-ft in the S and S Q4 variants. An eight-speed automatic transmission is the only gearbox available. EPA fuel economy ratings are 17/24 mpg city/highway for the base Ghibli and 16/24 mpg for the Ghibli S and S Q4.</p>

<p>The 2017 Ghibli received a Good score in all crashworthiness tests except the front small overlap impact (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Ghibli received a Basic rating since it comes with a forward collision warning system (Superior is the highest rating available). Its front crash prevention features haven’t been crash tested yet. Active safety features are available as optional extras include blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert, lane keeping assist, highway assist, traffic sign recognition, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, and adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p>Trunk space is 17.6 cubic feet and can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/ghibli/2014/2014-maserati-ghibli-first-drive/">2014 First Drive</a>, we said that despite the well-built interior, which includes high-quality leather, many parts are clearly from the Fiat <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/">Chrysler</a> parts bin especially the buttons and trim. On the road, the Ghibli offers an engaging driving experience thanks to its nimble handling and strong acceleration. The more powerful Ghibli S accelerates quickly thanks to its twin-turbo V-6 and the quick-shifting eight-speed automatic transmission, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/maserati/ghibli/2014/2014-maserati-ghibli-s-q4-first-test/">2014 First Test</a>. However, because of its stiff suspension it doesn’t ride as smoothly as other midsize luxury sedans, and it can get noisy due to its exhaust note.</p>

<p>The Maserati Ghibli shares its underpinnings with the recently launched Levante crossover.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-9/2018/">2018 Mazda CX-9</a> gets automatic emergency braking and G-Vectoring Control as standard on all trims. When entering a turn, G-Vectoring Control reduces torque slightly to shift the car’s weight to the front tires to improve steering response and increase cornering force. Once the steering wheel unwinds, full power comes on, transferring weight to the rear tires and adding stability. Heated second row seats are now available on upper trim levels and the full suite of active safety tech is now available as an optional package in lower trims. Soul Red Crystal, an exterior color that debuted on the second-generation CX-5, replaces Soul Red Metallic in the 2018 CX-9.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting above the compact CX-5, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-9/2018/">Mazda CX-9</a> is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/">Mazda</a>’s large three-row crossover that seats up to seven passengers. Front-wheel drive is standard and all-wheel drive is optional on all but the range-topping Signature trim, which has standard all-wheel drive.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The only engine available is a 2.5-liter turbo-four with 310 lb-ft of torque and 250 hp on premium fuel or 227 hp on regular gas. The engine is paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 22/28 mpg city/highway for front-drive models and 20/26 mpg with all-wheel drive. Despite its size, the CX-9 isn’t the roomiest three-row crossover with 14.4 cubic feet behind the third row, 38.2 cubic feet behind the second row, and 71.2 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>The base Sport trim comes with LED headlights, 18-inch alloy wheels, tri-zone climate control, keyless start, cloth upholstery, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, the MazdaConnect infotainment system, Bluetooth connectivity and tw0 USB ports. Move up to the Touring trim and you’ll get a power driver’s seat, a power liftgate, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, heated front seats, keyless entry, a power front passenger seat, and leather upholstery. The Touring Premium package adds LED fog lights, navigation, a 12-speaker Bose premium audio system, parking sensors, and a sunroof.</p>

<p>Grand Touring models feature the same equipment as the Touring trim with the Touring Premium package and adds 20-inch alloy wheels, aluminum interior trim, a head-up display, adaptive headlights, heated second-row seats, a heated steering wheel, and roof rails. The range-topping Signature trim adds all-wheel drive, Auburn Nappa leather upholstery, rosewood interior trim by Japanese guitar maker Fujigen, LED interior lights, and LED grille lighting.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA hasn’t crash-tested the 2018 Mazda CX-9. Although the IIHS hasn’t evaluated the 2018 CX-9, the 2017 model received a Good score on all crash worthiness tests and an Average rating on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the CX-9 received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph and a 25-mph collision (Superior is the highest possible score on the front crash prevention test). As a result, the Mazda CX-9 received the 2017 Top Safety Pick+ award from the IIHS.</p>

<p>All 2018 Mazda CX-9s get a standard low-speed automatic emergency braking system that works up to 19 mph. Optional on lower trims and standard on the upper grades is an automatic emergency braking system that works at highway speeds. Other available active safety features include forward collision warning, lane keep assist, lane departure warning, Distance Recognition Support and blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-9/2016/2017-gmc-acadia-2016-mazda-cx-9-2017-toyota-highlander-comparison/">2016 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/highlander/2018/">Toyota Highlander</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/acadia/2018/">GMC Acadia</a>, the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-9/2016/2016-mazda-cx-9-touring-fwd-first-test-review/">Mazda CX-9 </a>won thanks to its engaging driving dynamics and premium-feeling interior. However, the crossover did have its quirks including steering that can get too heavy for a family-oriented vehicle, a stiff suspension that gets upset on poor road surfaces, and an overly aggressive automatic emergency braking system. The CX-9 Signature’s interior is a highlight because it feels expensive and can nearly rival interiors found in luxury cars, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-9/2016/2016-mazda-cx-9-signature-awd-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>. Third row access is easy thanks to a single latch that moves the second row seats out of the way, and there’s respectable amounts of room for adults back there for short trips.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The CX-9 is currently the only vehicle in Mazda’s lineup that uses the brand’s turbocharged 2.5-liter I-4.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-3/2018/">2018 Mazda CX-3</a> gets low-speed automatic emergency braking and the G-Vectoring Control system as standard on all trims. New options include a full color head-up display, power driver’s seat with memory settings, and a heated steering wheel. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/">Mazda</a> also tweaked the steering and chassis to improve the CX-3’s ride comfort, handling, and quietness. A new exterior color, Machine Grey Metallic, has also been added, replacing Meteor Grey Mica.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Serving as the brand’s entry-level crossover, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-3/2018/">Mazda CX-3</a> slots below the larger CX-5. Front-wheel drive is standard on all trims and all-wheel drive is optional.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>All 2018 CX-3s are powered by a 2.0-liter I-4 with 146 hp and 146 lb-ft of torque paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 29/34 mpg city/highway for front-drive models and 27/32 mpg with all-wheel drive. However, opting for all-wheel drive gets you a smaller 11.9-gallon tank instead of the larger 12.7-gallon one found in front-drive CX-3s.</p>

<p>Cargo space is on the small side at 12.4 cubic feet behind the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats and 44.5 cubic feet behind the front seats. The available cargo space gets cut down to 10.1 cubic feet and 42.3 cubic feet respectively with the optional Bose premium audio system, which comes standard on the range-topping Grand Touring trim.</p>

<p>Standard equipment on the base CX-3 Sport trim includes cloth upholstery, two USB ports, a rearview camera, the MazdaConnect infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, low-speed automatic emergency braking and 16-inch alloy wheels. Move up to the mid-level CX-3 Touring trim and it adds 18-inch alloy wheels, leatherette upholstery with suede inserts, keyless entry/start, blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, heated front seats, automatic climate control, and auto on/off headlights. Opt for the Touring Preferred Equipment package and that adds a Bose premium audio system, a sunroof, satellite radio and a cargo cover. The range-topping CX-3 Grand Touring trim adds leather upholstery with suede inserts, adaptive LED headlights, LED fog lights, navigation, a head-up display, a Bose premium audio system, and paddle shifters as standard. Power-adjustable front seats and a heated steering wheel are available as part of the Grand Touring Preferred Equipment package, which also comes with active safety and driver assistance features.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 CX-3 a five-star overall safety score (out of a possible five stars). Although the IIHS has yet to test the 2018 model, a 2017 model received a Good score on all crash worthiness tests and an Average rating on the new headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). The CX-3 also received a Superior rating on the front crash prevention test after it avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the impact of a 25-mph one by 23 mph (Superior is the highest possible rating for the front crash prevention test). As a result, the IIHS awarded the CX-3 a Top Safety Pick+ rating.</p>

<p>Low-speed automatic emergency braking comes standard on all trims on the 2018 CX-3. On the Grand Touring trim, the Grand Touring Preferred Equipment package adds automatic emergency braking for high speeds, adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, and high beam assist. Blind spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert come standard on the Grand Touring trim and are optional on the mid-level Touring grade as part of the Touring Preferred Equipment package.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>Thanks to its light curb weight, the Mazda CX-3 is easy to drive and we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-3/2016/2016-mazda-cx-3-first-drive/">2016 First Drive</a> that even though it’s not very powerful, it can easily accelerate to highway speeds without much drama. However, the six-speed automatic does tend to upshift to the highest gear to save fuel. The interior is well appointed, especially in the two-tone black and cream leather/suede combo with red contrast stitching, giving it a more upscale feel.  Handling is one of CX-3’s strengths, offering great steering feel and a buttoned-down chassis that makes it right at home on windy roads, as we observed in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-3/2016/2016-mazda-cx-3-grand-touring-awd-first-test-review/">2016 First Test review</a>.</p>

<p>The CX-3 placed second in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/xv-crosstrek/2015/the-big-test-2015-2016-subcompact-crossovers/">2015 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/trax/2018/">Chevrolet Trax</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/hr-v/2018/">Honda HR-V</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/renegade/2018/">Jeep Renegade</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> Juke, and the previous-generation <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/crosstrek/2018/">Subaru Crosstrek</a>. Although the attractive Mazda excels in driving dynamics and fuel efficiency, the CX-3’s lack of interior space held it back. Rear seat space is cramped and there’s not much cargo capacity, especially compared to the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a> HR-V and the comparison test winner, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/">Subaru</a> Crosstrek.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Even though it’s nearly the same size as the Mazda3, the Mazda CX-3 rides on a smaller platform that also underpins the global market Mazda2 subcompact and its sibling, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/yaris/2018/">Toyota Yaris</a> iA.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>All 2018 Mazda3 models now come standard with forward collision warning and automatic emergency braking, and all Touring trims are now powered by the 2.5-liter I-4.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Mazda3 is a front-drive compact car slotting below the midsize Mazda6. Sedan and four-door hatchback body styles are available.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two engines are available in the 2018 Mazda3 including a 2.0-liter I-4 with 155 hp and 150 lb-ft of torque in the base Sport trim or a 2.5-liter I-4 with 184 hp and 185 lb-ft in the Touring and Grand Touring grades. Both engines can be paired to a six-speed manual or a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings for the 2.0-liter-equipped sedan are 28/38 mpg city/highway with the automatic or 28/37 mpg with the manual. The hatchback with the base engine is rated at 28/37 mpg with the automatic and 27/37 mpg with the manual. Opt for the larger 2.5-liter I-4 and the Mazda3 sedan’s fuel economy is rated 27/36 mpg with the automatic and 25/34 mpg with the manual. The more practical hatchback is slightly less efficient with the 2.5-liter I-4 at 26/35 mpg with the automatic and 25/33 mpg with the manual. Trunk space in the sedan is 12.4 cubic feet while the hatchback has 20.2 cubic feet with the rear seats up and 47.1 cubic feet with them down.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base Sport trim include 16-inch alloy wheels, a rearview camera, the MazdaConnect infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, a six-speaker audio system, cloth upholstery, and 60/40 split-folding rear seats. The Touring trim adds 18-inch all0y wheels, dual-zone climate control, heated front seats, leatherette upholstery, keyless entry/start, and blind spot warning. Opt for the range-topping Grand Touring trim and you also get LED headlights and fog lights, a Bose premium audio system, leather upholstery, and a flip up head-up display. Navigation can be had as an accessory in the Sport and Touring trims or as part of the Premium Equipment package on the Grand Touring grade.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Mazda3 a five-star overall score (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 Mazda3 received a Good score on all crash tests and an Average score on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). It also earned a Superior rating on the front crash prevention evaluation after it avoided a 12- and 25-mph collision (Superior is the highest possible rating). Overall, the IIHS gave the 2018 Mazda3 the Top Safety Pick+ award.</p>

<p>Automatic emergency braking and forward collision warning are standard on all 2018 Mazda3 models. Additional driver assistance features such as blind spot warning, adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, and high beam assist are available as part of package in the Grand Touring trim.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a Big Test comparison of 2016 and 2017 compact sedans, a 2016 Mazda3i Grand Touring (with the 2.0-liter engine) placed <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2016/2016-2017-big-test-compact-sedans/">fourth out of seven competitors</a>.</p>

<p>“For evidence of just how quickly this segment is moving along,” we wrote, “just look to the Mazda3, which came in Fourth Place, the winner in the 2014 Big Test. It feels less special now and offers middling performances in almost all of our seven criteria.”</p>

<p>Despite how the compact has aged in the face of newer competitors, in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/mazda3/2017/2017-mazda3-2-5-grand-touring-first-test-review/">2017 First Test of a 2.5-liter model</a>, we said that the Mazda3’s chassis continues to be its defining feature, giving it its sporty driving dynamics. The 184-hp 2.5-liter I-4 provides plenty of power on tap even for climbing up hills and steep grades. The six-speed automatic is responsive and holds gears in manual mode, making it more enthusiast-friendly. However, interior space is on the small side especially when you compare it to newer compact cars such as the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2018/">Honda Civic</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/">Mazda</a> MX-5 Miata is now available with a Dark Cherry soft top. Sport models now come with a 7.0-inch touchscreen as standard and Club trims now come with heated seats. Heated Recaro seats are now available on the soft-top’s Club trim as part of the BBS/Brembo package. Nappa leather is now available on the Grand Touring trim and can be had in the Auburn color found in the RF Launch Edition, and the Signature trim of the CX-9. The soft top also received some suspension and steering updates for improved ride and handling.</p>

<p>The 2018 Miata gets three new exterior colors that include Soul Red Crystal Metallic, Eternal Blue Mica, and Snowflake White Pearl.</p>

<p>The 2018 Mazda MX-5 Miata is a rear-drive two-seat convertible that’s offered with a soft top and as a power retractable hardtop model called the Miata RF. Soft-top models are available in three grades while the RF hardtop is only available on the top two trims. RF models can raise and stow the power retractable roof in about 12 seconds. The manual roof on the soft top, on the other hand, can be raised or lowered in about 2-3 seconds thanks to its simple latch system.</p>

<p><strong>MX-5 Miata Sport: </strong>The base Sport grade (only available with the soft top) gets a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth, cloth upholstery, full LED headlights, fog lights, keyless entry and start, 16-inch alloy wheels, and a USB port.</p>

<p><strong>MX-5 Miata Club: </strong>Club models come with heated seats, LED fog lights, blind-spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, a nine-speaker Bose audio system, 17-inch alloy wheels, and a second USB port. Models equipped with the standard manual transmission also have a sportier suspension tune, a shock tower brace, and a limited-slip differential as standard. The Club is the base model on the RF and adds a 4.6-inch instrument cluster display as standard.</p>

<p><strong>MX-5 Grand Touring: </strong>Essentially a more loaded comfort-oriented trim, the Grand Touring grade adds navigation, leather upholstery, automatic high beams, lane departure warning, and automatic climate control.</p>

<p>Optional extras on the Miata include Nappa leather upholstery (exclusively on the Grand Touring trim) and the BBS/Brembo package, which adds Brembo front brakes, lightweight 17-inch BBS alloy wheels, a front lip spoiler, black side sills, leather upholstery and a rear spoiler. An upgraded BBS/Brembo package is also available on the soft top with heated Recaro seats. You can only opt for the BBS/Brembo package on the Club trim.</p>

<p>The 2018 Mazda MX-5 Miata is powered by a 2.0-liter I-4 with 155 hp and 148 lb-ft of torque, and offers a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 26/33 mpg city/highway with the manual and 26/35 mpg with the automatic.</p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Miata. Blind-spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert come standard on the Club and Grand Touring grades. Lane departure warning is only available on the Grand Touring trim.</p>

<p>The 2018 Miata has a small trunk that measures 4.6 cubic feet on the soft top and 4.5 cubic feet on the RF hardtop.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/miata/2016/2016-mazda-mx-5-vs-2015-subaru-brz-comparison/">2015 comparison test</a> against the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/brz/2018/">Subaru BRZ</a>, the Miata won because of its superior performance on the road and on a closed circuit. Its light and responsive character makes it a joy to drive on your favorite winding roads and its suspension tuning is well-balanced, so it doesn’t beat you up on rough roads. As with its predecessors, the 2018 Miata has a surprising amount of body roll, especially for such a lightweight sports car. Interior space is also at a premium.</p>

<p>The heavier, more stylish Miata RF is just as fun to drive as its lighter soft top sibling. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/miata/2017/2017-mazda-mx-5-miata-rf-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we noted that the added roll stiffness doesn’t have as much abrupt body roll, making it easier to control when you’re tossing the car around. On the road, the RF has a quieter interior with the roof up even at high speeds. However, with the roof down, there is more noise due to excessive wind buffeting.</p>

<p>The 2018 Mazda MX-5 shares its platform with the Fiat 124 Spider.</p>

<p>In addition to an exterior design refresh, the 2018 Mazda6 gets an updated powertrain lineup that includes a 2.5-liter turbo-four option and an updated multimedia system. A new Signature trim is now the range-topping model.</p>

<p>The 2018 Mazda6 is a front-drive midsize sedan that slots above the Mazda3 and is available in four trims.</p>

<p><strong>Mazda6 Sport: </strong>The base Sport trim gets you a 17-inch alloy wheels, Bluetooth, the MazdaConnect infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, cloth upholstery, a rearview camera, a USB port, keyless entry/start, blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert.</p>

<p><strong>Mazda6 Touring: </strong>Moving up to the Touring grade gets you features like dual-zone climate control, 19-inch alloy wheels, heated front seats, a power-operated driver’s seat,  leatherette upholstery, navigation and a low-speed automatic emergency braking system. LED headlights, a sunroof, and a Bose audio system are available in packages.</p>

<p><strong>Mazda6 Grand Touring: </strong>As the second highest trim, the Grand Touring grade gets you adaptive full LED headlights, LED grille accent lighting, a sunroof, leather upholstery, LED fog lights, paddle shifters, a power-operated front passenger’s seat, heated rear seats, and an 11-speaker Bose audio system.</p>

<p><strong>Mazda6 Signature: </strong>The new range-topping model, the Signature, gets you unique features such as brown Nappa leather, real wood and aluminum trim, a 7.0-inch instrument cluster display, an 8.0-inch touchscreen for the MazdaConnect infotainment system, ventilated front seats, and a windshield-projected head-up display.</p>

<p>The 2018 Mazda6 comes standard with a naturally aspirated 2.5-liter I-4 paired to a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission. Power figures should be the same as in the CX-5, which is 187 hp and 186 lb-ft of torque. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/">Mazda</a>’s new 2.5-liter turbo-four with 250 hp (227 hp on regular fuel) and 310 lb-ft is optional and is only available with the six-speed automatic. EPA fuel economy ratings are 26/35 mpg city/highway with the automatic, 24/33 mpg with the manual, and 23/31 mpg with the turbo-four.</p>

<p>The 2018 Mazda6 received a five-star overall rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS hasn’t tested the 2018 model yet but the 2017 Mazda6 received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests and an Average rating on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the 2017 Mazda6 received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the speed of a 25-mph impact by 24 mph (Superior is the highest rating for the front crash prevention test). With its solid crash and front crash prevention scores, the 2017 Mazda6 received the Top Safety Pick+ rating from the IIHS.</p>

<p>Available active safety features include adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, automatic high beams, and lane keeping assist. Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert are available on all trims.</p>

<p>The 2018 Mazda6 has a 14.8-cubic-foot trunk that can be expanded via the 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/mazda6/2016/2016-mazda6-gt-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we said that the Mazda6 is fun to drive and offers great steering feel. However, it does suffer from excessive road noise with the optional 19-inch alloy wheels. The infotainment system works fine, but we wish the system offered Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. The naturally aspirated 2.5-liter I-4 offers acceptable power and, helpfully, the six-speed automatic transmission is not stingy with downshifts.</p>

<p>The 2018 Mazda6 is the second model to use the automaker’s 2.5-liter turbo-four after the three-row CX-9.</p>
