<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-5/2018/">2018 Mazda CX-5</a> gets cylinder deactivation for improved fuel economy. Base Sport models get more standard features including a leather-wrapped steering wheel, a leather-wrapped shift knob, and blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert. Touring models get a full suite of active safety features as standard.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-5/2018/">Mazda CX-5</a> is a compact crossover that slots below the larger three-row CX-9 and the subcompact CX-3. Front-wheel drive comes standard and all-wheel drive is optional on all trim levels.</p>

<p><strong>Sport</strong>: On the base Sport trim, standard features include LED headlights, 17-inch alloy wheels, cloth upholstery, the MazdaConnect infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, a rearview camera, and Bluetooth connectivity.</p>

<p><strong>Touring</strong>: The mid-grade Touring model adds leatherette upholstery, keyless entry, heated front seats, dual-zone climate control, four USB ports (instead of the standard two), and 19-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Grand Touring:</strong> Range-topping Grand Touring models come standard with leather upholstery, memory function for the driver’s seat, a power-operated passenger seat, adaptive LED headlights, LED taillights and fog lights, navigation, a Bose premium audio system, a power liftgate and a moonroof.</p>

<p>Options include a heated steering wheel, a head-up display and heated rear seats on the Grand Touring model, which are part of the Grand Touring Premium package. The Touring Preferred package adds navigation, a power liftgate, a sunroof, and the Bose premium audio system to the Touring trim.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/">Mazda</a> CX-5 is powered by a 2.5-liter I-4 with 187 hp and 186 lb-ft of torque paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings aren’t out for the 2018 CX-5 but it shouldn’t differ much from the 2017 model, which is rated at 25/31 mpg city/highway in front-drive models and 24/30 mpg with all-wheel drive. A diesel-powered is expected to arrive at some point during the next couple years.</p>

<p>In NHTSA testing, the 2018 CX-5 received a four-star overall safety rating (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 CX-5 but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except the passenger side small overlap impact where it hasn’t been crash tested and the headlights test where it received an Acceptable score (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the CX-5 received a Superior rating after it avoided 12- and a 25-mph collisions (Superior is the highest possible rating in the front crash prevention test). As a result, the Mazda CX-5 received the 2018 Top Safety Pick+ award from the IIHS</p>

<p>Standard on all CX-5s is a low-speed automatic emergency braking system, blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert. Touring and Grand Touring trims come standard with the full suite of active safety features, which includes adaptive cruise control, high-speed automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning, and lane keeping assist. Sport models, on the other hand, are available with the full active safety suite via the Sport i-ActivSense package.</p>

<p>With the standard 40/20/40 split-folding rear seats in place, the 2018 Mazda CX-5 has 30.9 cubic feet of cargo space and that can be expanded to 59.6 cubic feet. When properly equipped, the CX-5 can tow up to 2,000 pounds of payload.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-5/2017/2017-mazda-cx-5-grand-touring-awd-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we noted that due to its additional curb weight, the new CX-5 is slower than its predecessor and it the non-defeatable stability control made it a handful during handling tests. We enjoyed the CX-5’s crisp steering, quick throttle response, and quieter cabin thanks to additional sound deadening. Its handling chops continued to impress where it felt right at home on winding roads and didn’t exhibit much body roll.</p>

<p>The 2017 CX-5 lost a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/cr-v/2017/2017-honda-cr-v-vs-2017-mazda-cx-5-comparison-review/">comparison test</a> to the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/cr-v/2017/">2017 Honda CR-V</a> because of the latter’s superior fuel economy, lower cost of ownership, more spacious interior, and is nearly on par with the Mazda in terms of driving dynamics. Although the CX-5 features an interior that’s more luxurious thanks to the extensive use of higher quality materials. However, the CX-5’s seats don’t have much support and feel flat.</p>

<p>The 2018 Mazda CX-5 was the first Mazda vehicle to feature the automaker’s new deconstructed grille design.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The RedArt Edition (SLC300) is new for 2018 and consists of Selenite Grey Metallic paint, chrome hood fins, red brake calipers, 18-inch wheels, exterior red trim, two-tone Black/Silver Pearl leather with red accents, aluminum with dark carbon grain interior trim, heated seats with Airscarf, and exclusive floor mats, steering wheel, and shift lever. The Performance Studio RedArt (AMG SLC43) includes designo Selenite Grey Magno paint, two-tone Black/Silver Pearl Nappa leather with red piping, two-tone Silver Pearl/Black Nappa leather seating, red exterior trim, and RedArt embroidery in the interior. The SLC-Class also receives mirror logo lamps and blind-spot assist (SLC43) as standard and an available Sport steering wheel wrapped in leather and Dinamica.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The SLC is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>’ smallest and most affordable roadster, positioned below the SL-Class and AMG GT roadsters. If you’re considering cabriolets, the C-Class Cabriolet is a softtop with more passenger and cargo space, but with a price that’s a few thousand dollars more than the SLC. Before the roadster was renamed the SLC as part of a 2017 refresh, the car was known for years as the SLK.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>Two models make up the SLC-Class including the entry-level <strong>SLC300,</strong> which is powered by a 241-hp, 273-lb-ft 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 that’s EPA-rated at 25/32 mpg city/highway. The higher-performance <strong>AMG SLC43</strong> produces 362 hp and 384 lb-ft of torque from its 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 and delivers 20/29 mpg. A nine-speed automatic backs both engines, and all models send power to the rear wheels. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 SLC43 hit 60 mph in a quick 4.5 seconds. Opening and closing the hard top can be done at speeds up to 25 mph.</p>

<p>Standard features on the SLC300 include a rearview camera, integrated roll bar, Dynamic Select drive modes, electric trunk partition, a sport exhaust system, active LED headlights, 18-inch wheels, ambient lighting, a 7.0-inch display, power Sport seats, and aluminum interior trim with a carbon fiber finish. Available features include Magic Sky Control, Nappa/Dinamica Sport steering wheel, 18-inch AMG multispoke wheels, Designo Nappa leather upholstery, heated seats, Comand system with navigation and Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, and an in-car WiFi-hotspot. The SLC43 comes standard with many of the above options as well as AMG Ride Control Sport Suspension, an AMG limited-slip differential, AMG Night package, IWC Ingenieur dashboard analog clock, AMG carbon fiber interior trim, AMG illuminated door sills, and red brake calipers.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/slc-class/2018/">2018 Mercedes-Benz SLC-Class</a> comes standard with Active Brake Assist (automatic emergency braking), Attention Assist (drowsy driver warning), dual roll bars, Neck-Pro head restraints (helps reduce rear-impact neck injuries), and a rearview camera. Most driver assist safety features can be found in the available Premium Package 3 (expect for Blind Spot Assist) and include Lane Keeping Assist, Distance Pilot Distronic (adaptive cruise control), Parking Assist, and Pre-Safe, a feature that flashed hazard lights, tightens the seat belt, and closes the windows if the system detects an impending collision.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The SLC utilizes exhaust sound flaps based on the engine speed that stay closed most of the time when in Eco and Comfort modes, and open earlier when in Sport mode.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/cls-class/2018/">2018 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class</a> now comes standard with a rearview camera. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a> also discontinued the CLS400, leaving only the CLS550 and CLS63 S.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/cls-class/2018/">Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class</a> is a coupe-like luxury sedan that slots above the smaller CLA-Class and is available in rear- or all-wheel-drive configurations. Two models are available, the CLS550 (CLS550 4Matic is the all-wheel-drive variant) and AMG CLS63 S.</p>

<p><strong>CLS550 and CLS550 4Matic</strong>: Standard on the CLS550 and CLS550 4Matic are an adaptive air suspension, 14-way power front seats with memory, leather upholstery, ambient lighting with multiple color choices,  dual-zone climate control, heated front seats, Mercedes’ COMAND infotainment system with an 8.0-inch screen, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, a Harman Kardon premium audio system, navigation, Bluetooth, 18-inch alloy wheels, a sunroof, and LED headlights.</p>

<p><strong>AMG CLS63 S: </strong>In addition to the added power, the CLS63 S comes standard adaptive headlights, 19-inch alloy wheels, a rear spoiler, an AMG-tuned adaptive air suspension, an AMG sport exhaust, a limited-slip rear differential, and semi-aniline leather upholstery.</p>

<p>Notable options include ventilated front seats, a Bang &amp; Olufsen premium audio system, an active multicontour driver’s seat, keyless entry/start, carbon ceramic brakes, and a heated steering wheel.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> CLS-Class comes standard with a 4.7-liter twin-turbo V-8 rated at 402 hp and 443 lb-ft of torque in the CLS550 and it’s paired to a nine-speed automatic transmission. The high-performance AMG CLS63 S comes with a 5.5-liter twin-turbo V-8 rated at 577 hp and 590 lb-ft, and it’s paired to a seven-speed automatic. EPA fuel economy ratings for the 2018 CLS550 is 18/26 mpg city/highway for rear-drive models and 17/25 mpg with all-wheel drive. AMG CLS63 S variants are the least efficient at 16/22 mpg.</p>

<p>All 2018 CLS four-doors get forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, and attention assist. Pedestrian detection, adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assist, adaptive high beams, blind-spot monitoring, and rear cross-traffic alert are part of the optional Driver Assistance and Lane Tracking packages.</p>

<p>The 2018 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class has a 15.3-cubic-foot trunk and it can be expanded via the optional 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/cls-class/2015/2015-mercedes-benz-cls-class-first-drive/">2015 First Drive</a>, we said that the CLS550 offers prodigious power and the nine-speed automatic transmission shifts smoothly. The standard air suspension also allows the CLS550 to handle well without causing the ride to get too harsh especially in  Sport mode. Even if you choose the AMG CLS63 S, the car rides surprisingly well, meaning it’s possible to drive it daily.</p>

<p>The first-generation Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class helped popularize the trend of coupe-like rooflines in sedans across the industry.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>After a refresh for the 2017 model year, the only update for 2018 is a new 19-inch wheel design.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The three-row GLS-Class may be the largest SUV in <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>’ lineup but it’s not the most expensive; the flagship G-Glass starts at almost double the GLS’ starting price. The GLS is positioned above the rest of the SUV lineup that includes the GLA-Class, GLC-Class, and the GLE-Class.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The base <strong>GLS450</strong> comes equipped with a 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 that produces 362 hp and 369 lb-ft of torque and comes with an EPA-rating of 17/22 mpg city/highway. The next step up is the <strong>GLS550</strong> that is powered by a 4.7-liter twin-turbo V-8 that churns out 449 hp and 516 lb-ft of torque and delivers 14/19 mpg. The range-topping <strong>AMG GLS63</strong> packs a 577-hp, 561 lb-ft of torque twin-turbo 5.5-liter V-8 that comes rated at 13/18 mpg. 4Matic all-wheel drive is standard across the board and a nine-speed automatic backs the non-AMG models while a seven-speed automatic backs the AMG GLS63. With the third and second rows folded down, the GLS offers an impressive 93.8 cubic feet of cargo space.</p>

<p>Standard features in the GLS450 include Airmatic air suspension, Dynamic Select drive modes, power-folding third-row, remote start, power folding mirrors with <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> logo projector, 19-inch wheels, Nappa leather steering wheel, LED interior lighting, heated front seats, power moonroof, and a power liftgate. Available features include the Active Curve system (active stabilizer bars), an enhanced off-road driving program (adjustable off-road modes), 21-inch AMG wheels, interior aluminum trim, heated and cooled front cupholders, cabin-air purification system, heated second row seats, Nappa leather upholstery, 8.0-inch display with Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, a rear seat entertained system, and a Bang &amp; Olufsen BeoSound premium sound system. The AMG GLS63 comes with many of the above features as standard but adds AMG Sport Suspension with adaptive damping plus, an AMG high-performance braking system, an AMG Sport exhaust, and available 22-inch AMG multispoke wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The GLS-Class comes standard with Active Brake Assist (collision warning and automatic braking), Attention Assist (drowsy driver warning), Trailer Stability Assist, Crosswind Assist, Pre-Safe (accident preparation system), and a rearview camera. Opt for the Driver Assistance package and your GLS will get Lane Keeping Assist, Speed Limit Assist, Pre-Safe Plus, adaptive cruise control with Steering Pilot, Active Blind Spot Assist, and Active Brake Assist with Cross-Traffic function (automatic braking for cross traffic and pedestrians). The AMG GLS63 comes standard with all the above features.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>During <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/mercedes-benz-gls-class-2017-suv-of-the-year-contender/">2017 SUV of the Year testing</a>, we sampled the GLS450 and GLS550 and enjoyed the large SUV’s handling prowess as it felt half its size on the track and we felt the transmission programming was spot-on. The new Comand infotainment system is good, but although “its bones are still good—it delivers a great ride and performance and one of the best third rows in the entire segment—it’s clear this is a vehicle nearing the end of its life cycle.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/gl-class/2015/2015-mercedes-benz-gl450-4matic-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 2015 Mercedes-Benz GL450 (when the model was refreshed for 2017, the name changed from GL to GLS), we liked the efficiency and power of the new twin-turbo V-6 that is more fuel efficient than the outgoing twin-turbo V-8 and provides similar performance. Handling was great for a large SUV but we found the interior a little boring.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Although very capable on the road, the GLS-Class offers 12.5 inches of ground clearance with the air suspension raised all the way up and 23.6 inches of fording depth.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a> gave the 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 a power bump to 385 hp. The AMG Performance Studio package is now available on the GLE43, and Natural Grain Brown Ash, Anthracite Poplar Wood trim, and Anthracite Poplar Wood trim are now available at no cost on the GLE63 and GLE63 S models.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>In <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a>’s coupe-like SUV lineup, the GLE-Class Coupe is positioned above the only other such model, the GLC-Class Coupe. When considering all SUVs, the GLE-Class Coupe slots below the GLS-Class and G-Class in price, but above the GLA-Class, GLC-Class, and the traditional GLE-Class.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The GLE-Class Coupe lineup consists of two AMG models including the <strong>AMG GLE43 Coupe</strong> and the <strong>AMG GLE63 S Coupe</strong>. A 385-hp, 384-lb-ft of torque 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 backed by a nine-speed automatic comes equipped in the GLE43 and has an EPA rating of 17/22 mpg city/highway. The GLE63 S uses the same engine found in the AMG GLS63, a 5.5-liter twin-turbo V-8 that churns out a potent 577 hp and 561 lb-ft of torque and delivers 14/18 mpg. The GLE63 S utilizes a seven-speed automatic but both models come with 4Matic all-wheel drive standard. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the GLE43 and GLE63 S hit 60 mph in 5.2 seconds and 3.9 seconds respectively.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/gle-class/2018/">2018 Mercedes-Benz GLE-Class</a> Coupe comes well-equipped with standard features that include AMG-enhanced Direct-Steer system, AMG Airmatic Sport suspension, adaptive damping, Active Curve System with active roll stabilization (GLE 63 S), Wi-Fi hotspot, AMG Sport front seats, Nappa leather AMG Sport steering wheel, panorama roof, Active LED headlights, and adaptive high beams. Available features include AMG Dynamic Performance Exhaust (GLE63 S), 22-inch AMG wheels, the AMG Night package, interior aluminum trim, Exclusive Nappa leather upholstery (standard on GLE63 S), multi-contour front seats with massage feature, a rear seat entertainment system, and a Bang &amp; Olufsen BeoSound premium audio system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The GLE-Class, the SUV on which the GLE Coupe is based, is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick+ from the IIHS (the highest designation) because the crossover received the highest score of Good in all five crash evaluations and the highest score of Superior for front crash prevention. The crossover was able to completely avoid a 12 mph and 25 mph frontal collision thanks to the optional Active Braking Assist with Cross-Traffic Function (same as in the GLE Coupe) that is found in the Premium 3 package. However, the standard Active Braking Assist did not properly warn the driver of a possible collision and the IIHS did not test this system’s automatic braking feature.</p>

<p>Other standard safety features include Attention Assist (sleepy driver warning), Active LED headlights, blind spot warning, lane keep assist, Pre-Safe (pre-collision preparation), crosswind assist, and trailer stability assist. All of the available driver assist safety features are found in the Premium 3 package and include Distance Pilot Distronic with Steering Pilot (adaptive cruise control with lane centering), Active Brake Assist with Cross Traffic function, Active Blind Spot Assist, Active Lane Keeping Assist, speed limit assist, Pre-Safe Plus (Pre-Safe with after collision braking), Parking Pilot, and a surround view camera system.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/x6/2015/x6-m-range-rover-sport-svr-gle63-s-coupe-cayenne-turbo-s/">four-way comparison</a> among large premium and quick SUVs, The AMG GLE63 S Coupe came in last behind the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/cayenne/2018/">Porsche Cayenne</a> Turbo S, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/range-rover/2018/">Land Rover Range Rover</a> Sport SVR, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/x6/2018/">BMW X6</a> M. We didn’t like the brakes, transmission, and weight of the AMG and said, “Combine the noticeable heft of the GLE63 with the slowest-shifting transmission and least enjoyable brakes, and you wind up with a machine that feels massive.” “The transmission shifts quickly, but then there’s a delay and a lag after the shift.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/gle-class-coupe/2016/2016-mercedes-benz-gle-coupe-first-test-review/">First Drive</a> of the two GLE-Class Coupe models, we said, “Both SUVs handle like sports cars during straight-line cruising at speeds over 100 mph. They feel heavy but very stable. The ride is quiet and the only noise you hear is from the exhaust, which will likely turn more heads than anything else about the AMG models.” Overall we liked how the coupe-like crossovers drove and said, “The GLE Coupe is comfortable, quiet, and powerful, whether you have the turbocharged V-6 or that wonderful V-8 under the hood.” “The fact that they are not actually coupes doesn’t really matter. Those few who understand what the GLE Coupe offers will be quite content to roll down the road in comfort while going really fast.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The GLE Coupe offers 60.7 cubic feet of cargo space, a significant drop from the non-coupe’s 80.3 cubic feet.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>-Benz gave the GLA-Class a mild makeover that includes redesigned front and rear bumpers, a redesigned instrument cluster, new wheels, a new Canyon Beige paint color, and Black Ash matte wood trim replaced Burl Walnut. An 8-inch high-resolution display and a rearview camera are now standard and a limited Ice Edition is now available.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The GLA-Class is Mercedes-Benz’s smallest and least expensive SUV that slots behind the GLC-Class, the GLE-Class, the GLS-Class, and the G-Class in the automaker’s SUV lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Mercedes-Benz GLA250 (front-wheel drive) and GLA250 4Matic (all-wheel drive) are powered by a 208-hp, 258-lb-ft of torque 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 mated to a seven-speed automatic. The high-performance AMG GLA45 uses a 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 that produces an impressive 375 hp and 350 lb-ft of torque. This hand-built engine is mated to AMG’s seven-speed dual-clutch automatic that sends power to an AMG all-wheel-drive system. Neither Mercedes-Benz nor the EPA has yet to release fuel economy figures as of this writing. Mercedes-Benz claims the 0-60 mph time drops from 7.2 and 7.1 seconds with the front- and all-wheel-drive GLA250 models to 4.3 seconds for the AMG GLA45. In Motor Trend testing, however, we clocked an all-wheel-drive GLA250 hitting 60 in 6.9 seconds.</p>

<p>Mercedes-Benz no longer holds back with standard features such as a power liftgate, remote start with the mbrace apps, 18-inch wheels (19-inch for GLA45), 8-inch infotainment display screen, mbrace services with mbrace Connect, pre-wiring for Garmin Map Pilot, and Dynamic Select driving modes. Generous optional features consist of Android Auto, panorama roof, a 12-speaker harman/kardon sound system, 12-color ambient lighting, and an available Night package. The available Dynamic Plus Package features a front limited slip differential, AMG Ride Control Sport suspension, a Race mode, and a 167-mph top speed.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The GLA-Class now comes standard with Active Brake Assist as standard. This feature will warn the driver of a possible impact and apply the appropriate braking force if necessary. If the driver does not react or reacts too late the system can autonomously apply the brakes to prevent or reduce the impact of a collision. Another new standard feature is the automaker’s Attention Assist, a system that can detect signs of drowsiness and warn the driver. Other standard features include Hill-Start Assist, automatic brake drying, a brake hold feature, and eight airbags. The optional Active Lane Keeping Assist will nudge you back into your lane while Distance Pilot Distronic automatically maintains a selected distance to the vehicle in front during stop and go driving.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/gla-class/2015/2015-mercedes-benz-gla-class-first-drive/">First Drive review</a> of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/gla-class/2015/">2015 Mercedes-Benz GLA-Class</a>, we liked the driving dynamics of the GLA250 and the power and sound from the GLA45: “The new GLA could be a real problem for a handful of premium compact utes. Those who choose the GLA likely won’t care what makes an SUV real or not. The GLA’s prestigious badge and … low price of entry will be reason enough, especially for the younger buyers.” In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/gla-class/2015/2015-mercedes-benz-gla250-gla45-amg-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 2015 GLA250 and GLA45 we enjoyed the fun-driving GLA250, forgave some of its cheap interior pieces, and loved how exciting the GLA45 is to drive and said, “The GLA45 AMG is a riot on wheels; it’s fast as stink and begs the driver to wring the four-banger out for all it’s worth. Without a doubt, the GLA45 is most at home being throttled mercilessly on winding back-country two-tracks.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/gla-class/2018/2018-mercedes-benz-gla-first-look-review/">2018 Mercedes-Benz GLA-Class</a> features an optional off-road comfort suspension package that raises the ride height by 1.2 inches.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> expands the E-Class lineup with the addition new advanced safety features, new engines, as well as new wagon, coupe, and cabriolet models.  A more powerful AMG E63 S will be available in sedan and wagon body styles.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>In price, the E-Class is positioned above the entry-level CLA-Class and smaller C-Class but below the more expensive CLS and flagship S-Class. The E-Class is available in several body styles powered by an assortment of turbocharged engines.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The base E300 (rear-wheel-drive) and E300 4Matic (all-wheel-drive) are powered by a 241-hp, 273-lb-ft of torque 2.0-liter turbo I-4 engine. A 329-hp, 354-lb-ft 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 powers the E400/E400 4Matic Cabriolet, the E400 4Matic Wagon, and E400/E400 4Matic Coupe. The AMG E43 Sedan (4Matic) uses a more powerful version of the 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 that is tuned to deliver 396 hp and 384 lb-ft. The AMG-handcrafted 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 produces a whopping 603 hp and 627 lb-ft of torque and comes equipped in the new <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>-AMG E63 S Sedan and Wagon (both with 4Matic all-wheel drive). All engines are paired to a nine-speed automatic transmission; the AMG E63 models use a beefier AMG Speedshift nine-speed unit.</p>

<p>The 2018 E-Class Coupe and Cabriolet come standard an impressive 12.3-inch high-resolution display with navigation, ambient lighting with 64 colors to choose from, Dynamic Select driving modes, panorama roof on the coupe, and power-adjustable front seats with lumbar adjustability and memory. Available features include a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster (in addition to the 12.3-inch Comand screen), Air Body Control air suspension, head-up display, wireless charging, and multi-contour seats with four different massage functions. The sleek and powerful AMG E63 S Wagon includes many high-performance features like the AMG Dynamic Select drive modes, AMG suspension with full-support multi-chamber air suspension with three different damping modes, an electronically controlled rear limited-slip differential, a specially tuned all-wheel-drive system, dynamic engine mounts, and an available AMG Ceramic Composite braking system for maximum stopping power. The E63 S Sedan comes with the above features but also adds a new AMG Track Pace app for iPhone users that supplements the Racetimer feature. Owners can use the app to analyze vehicle data and improve their track time, share the results with other drivers via Facebook, Vimeo, or YouTube, and can connect to GoPro cameras.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The E-Class offers some of the most advanced active safety features currently on the market. The Pre-Safe Impulse Side feature rapidly inflates the front driver or passenger seat’s side bolster, moving the passenger 2.75 inches away from the impact zone once the system detects a side collision. When the standard Pre-Safe Sound detects an accident, the system will emit a short interference signal if a collision is detected, triggering a protective reflex in the ear helping to reduce hearing loss. Distance Pilot Distronic can follow a vehicle at a pre-selected distance up to 130 mph while Steering Pilot helps the driver stay in the middle of the lane with slight steering wheel adjustments. Evasive Steering Assist will assist the driver in an evasive maneuver by adding calculated steering torque and the Cross-Traffic feature of the Active Brake Assist system can detect cross-traffic and automatically brake if necessary. Active Lane Change Assist will automatically change lanes for the driver if clear. The standard Car-to-X Communication (car-to-car) feature can communicate with other Mercedes-Benz vehicles equipped with the same feature and help the driver avoid upcoming road hazards they cannot see yet like traffic accidents.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/e-class/2018/2018-mercedes-amg-e63-s-4matic-first-drive-review/">First Test review</a>, we loved the 603-hp, all-wheel-drive AMG E63 S and said it drives “monstrously.” “For the past year, I’ve been running around Los Angeles in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/">Dodge</a> Hellcat: 707 horsepower, 650 lb-ft of torque, 4,530 pounds, and an eight-speed automatic transmission. The E63 feels as if it could snap the Hellcat in half.”</p>

<p>However, this big and fast sedan is not a track car as the E63 tends to understeer on tight corners. The AMG prefers to conquer straight roads. “Time will tell, but until then, rest comfortably in the knowledge that the new E63 does nothing to tarnish the legend of both the mighty sedans that came before or AMG itself. Long live the Hammer.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/s90/2017/volvo-s90-t6-cadillac-ct6-20t-mercedes-benz-e300-luxury-sedan-comparison/">2.0-liter turbo-four luxury sedan comparison</a>, the 2017 E300 Sport came in ahead of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/ct6/2017/">2017 Cadillac CT6</a> but behind the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/s90/2018/">Volvo S90</a> T6 AWD Inscription. “Although the Mercedes E300 makes a good case for itself behind the wheel, its tight backseat package and inconsistent self-driving suite combined with its test-highest $70,025 sticker price relegate it to second place.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/e-class/2017/2017-mercedes-benz-e400-4matic-wagon-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2017 Mercedes-Benz E400 4Matic Wagon, we felt the E400 was a superb wagon until you switch modes, “Speaking of modes, switching between the Eco, Comfort, Sport and Sport+ settings available for the powertrain, suspension and steering reveals the E400 4Matic’s sole weakness: Inexplicably clumsy calibration of the steering weighting and transmission shift feel. Still, overall we still enjoyed the Mercedes-Benz wagon and said, “In so many ways it’s a worthy successor to the legendary W123 and W124 wagons; durable, high-quality, deeply capable cars that were the stealth-wealth icons of the 70s and 80s. And although a few gigabytes perhaps separate it from sublime greatness – the steering and the transmission niggles are easy software fixes – it is still the world’s best wagon.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The AMG S63 S Wagon’s handcrafted 4.0-liter twin-turbo produces an impressive 627 lb-ft of torque from 2,500-4,500 rpm and a peak power rating of 603 hp, providing a Mercedes-Benz claimed 0-60 mph time of 3.4 seconds.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Two new special edition CLAs include the <strong>Ice Edition</strong> (400 units) in Cirrus White or Polar White paint with Matte White foil strips, AMG Line exterior body panels, the Night package, LED High-Performance headlights, Premium package, a panorama roof, and 18-inch AMG wheels with black accents. There’s also the <strong>AMG Studio</strong> package, which comes in Night Black or Cosmos Black with contrast AMG stripes in Matte Graphite Gray, yellow exterior accents, 19-inch Black AMG wheels with yellow trim and performance seats.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> markets the CLA-Class lineup as a coupe due to its coupe-like styling, but this entry-level vehicle has four doors and slots below the rest of the automaker’s sedan lineup that includes the C-Class, E-Class, CLS-Class, and S-Class sedans. The CLA is the most affordable vehicle in the Mercedes’ portfolio and was refreshed for the 2017 model year.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The CLA-Class consists of three models including the CLA250, CLA250 4Matic, and the range-topping AMG CLA45 (standard with 4Matic all-wheel drive) that comes powered by a very potent 2.0-liter turbo-four that generates 375 hp and 350 lb-ft of torque and still manages to deliver a respectable 23/30 mpg city/highway. The entry-level CLA250 and CLA250 4Matic both also pack a 2.0-liter turbo-four but tuned to produce a more efficient 208 hp and 258 lb-ft of torque and come with an EPA rating of 24/37 mpg and 24/32 mpg for the 4Matic. Both engines are backed by a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic.</p>

<p>The CLA-Class’ standard equipment includes a rearview camera, Active Brake Assist, 8.0-inch center display, adaptive braking technology, Dynamic Select driving modes, dual-zone climate control and 17-inch wheels. Available equipment includes Parking Pilot (self-parking system), a panorama roof, LED headlights and taillights (standard on AMG), a Harman Kardon premium audio system, smartphone integrations with Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, 12-color ambient lighting, heated front seats, and the AMG Aerodynamics package (standard on the AMG). The AMG Dynamic Plus package is exclusive to the CLA45 and consists of a front limited-slip differential, AMG Ride Control with adaptive damping, Race mode, and a 167-mph track top speed.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The CLA-Class has not been crash tested but the IIHS gave the sedan the second highest rating of Advanced for front crash prevention because the standard Collision Prevention Plus automatic braking feature was able to reduce a 12 mph collision by 7 mph and a 25 mph collision by 22 mph. However, with the Driver Assist package that includes Distronic Plus adaptive cruise control and Lane Keep Assist, the highest rating of Superior was issued because the system was able to completely avoid a 12 mph and 25 mph collision and properly warned the driver. Attention Assist, a drowsy driver alert, is standard.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>After one year with our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/cla-class/2015/2015-mercedes-benz-cla250-4matic-review-verdict/">long-term 2015 Mercedes-Benz CLA250 4Matic</a>, we appreciated the size of the sedan for the city — not too big to park and not too small to feel vulnerable. The Mercedes drove well but we didn’t care for the transmission that defaults into Eco mode. However, the accurate and nicely weighted steering made the CLA fun to drive. The very small back seats are an issue as they do not fit adults very well, but the Comand infotainment system is impressive. “Dynamically, we hope Mercedes can recalibrate the unappealing transmission shift settings. And because that entry price has surged a bit, sprinkling some of the top technology into this lower-tier model might not be such a stretch.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2014-mercedes-benz-cla-250-first-test/">2014 CLA First Test</a> review, we felt the sedan had great value with loads of standard equipment and good interior quality but the back seats are very small. The standard sport suspension can be stiff over harsh roads but provided fun driving dynamics. The engine provides quick acceleration and plenty of torque and the sedan’s design is bold. “With the CLA250, engineers have put together a vehicle that melds technology, style, fuel frugalness, and sportiness seamlessly, and a build quality that new brand buyers — both young and old — will devour.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The CLA250’s 258 lb-ft of torque happens very early at just 1,200 rpm, and lasts until 4,000 rpm.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Minor updates include two new exterior colors – Designo Orange Metallic and Designo Ocean Blue Metallic – and the new Designo Manufaktur Red and Black Edition on the G550 and the AMG Performance Studio package on the AMG G63.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The G-Class is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a>’s flagship SUV, positioned above the GLA-Class, GLC-Class, GLE-Class, and GLS-Class in price (although the GLS is bigger). This body-on-frame SUV has one of the highest starting prices in the automaker’s entire lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>Powering the G550 base model is a 416-hp, 450-lb-ft of torque twin-turbo V-8 that delivers an EPA-rated 13/14 mpg city/highway. The same engine powers the lifted G550 4×4<sup>2 </sup>model, but that version delivers 11/11 mpg. The AMG G63 is powered by 5.5-liter V-8 that churns out 563 hp and 561 lb-ft of torque and is rated at 12/14 mpg. The range-topping AMG G65 packs a big 6.0-liter twin-turbo V-12 that produces a whopping 621 hp and 738 lb-ft of torque and delivers 11/13 mpg. All models come standard with permanent four-wheel drive (with a two-speed transfer case and three locking differentials) and a seven-speed automatic transmission. The G550 4×4<sup>2 </sup>has an incredible 17.2 inches of ground clearance.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>-Benz G-Glass comes standard with a dual side-exit exhaust system, 19-inch AMG wheels, stainless-steel brush guard, LED daytime running lights, Nappa leather upholstery, 10-way power heated and ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, interior ambient lighting, Comand multimedia system with central controller and Apple CarPlay/Android Auto. Available features for the G-Class lineup include an AMG Sport exhaust system, an AMG high-performance braking system, 21-inch AMG wheels, Nappa/Dinamica AMG Performance steering wheel, Designo wood trim, a Dinamica Interior Package, an AMG Night package, and a rear seat entertainment system. The G550 4×4<sup>2 </sup>comes standard with 22-inch wheels, wide wheel arches, two-tone paint, portal axles with red suspension springs, stainless steel undercarriage skid plates, AMG carbon fiber trim, and seats and doors panels in Dinamica microfiber with diamond stitching.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The G-Class lineup comes standard with adaptive cruise control, blind-spot warning, Parking Assist Parktronic (front and rear parking sensors), rearview camera, trailer stability assist, and an illuminated entry system. The G-Class does not have any additional driver assist safety features available.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/land-cruiser/2016/jeep-wrangler-mercedes-benz-g550-toyota-land-cruiser-comparison/">three-way comparison</a> among highly capable and expensive off-road SUVs, the AMG G65 came in third: “Although the Mercedes G550 handled everything, we agreed that its poor observed fuel economy, propensity to scrape expensive mechanical bits off-road, and white-knuckle handling characteristics both on the road and in the snow should put this endearing European in third.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2016-mercedes-benz-g550-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the refreshed G550, we liked the power from the 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 and the decent ride quality, but the on-road driving dynamics are poor. We enjoyed the G-Glass’ luxury and said, “Part of the G-Wagen’s mountain-crushing weight is all the sound-deadening material they’ve crammed into it over the years. Thanks to that it’s actually pretty comfortable and quiet inside despite the big tires, truck frame, and barn-inspired aerodynamic profile. The leather is absurdly rich for the vehicle, the seats are comfortable and supportive.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The G550 4×4<sup>2 </sup> weighs in at a whopping 6,825 pounds.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>C300 and C300 4Matic models receive a new nine-speed transmission and 18-inch five-spoke split wheels are standard on the coupe and cabriolet models. The sedan models now have a power moonroof standard and the C350e gets standard LED headlights. A rearview camera is now standard on coupe models, as is wood trim on the cabriolet models. The coupe and cabriolet models now offer Designo Selenite Grey Magno paint and the AMG Performance Studio package. All AMG models now have the AMG Track App feature.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>In <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a>’s sedan lineup, the C-Class is positioned above the entry-level CLA-Class and below the larger and more expensive E-Class and S-Class sedans. The C-Class coupe is the most affordable slotting below the E-Class, CLS-Class, S-Class, and the AMG GT coupes. The E-Class and S-Class cabriolets slot above the smallest of the cabriolets, the C-Class cabriolet.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/c-class/2018/">2018 Mercedes-Benz C-Class</a> lineup offers three turbocharged engines – 2.0-, 3.0-, and 4.0-liter – backed by either a nine-speed automatic or a seven-speed automatic for the AMG 63 and 63 S models. The C350e plug-in utilizes a hybrid powertrain paired to a seven-speed automatic. All models come standard with rear-wheel-drive or with the available 4Matic all-wheel-drive system. (2017 data when noted, we will update with 2018 figures when available)</p>

<p><strong>Model: C300, C300 4Matic Sedan</strong></p>

<p>Engine and Transmission: Turbocharged 2.0-liter I-4; nine-speed automatic</p>

<p>Power: 241 hp/273 lb-ft of torque</p>

<p>EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 24/33 mpg city/highway, 23/32 mpg (4Matic)</p>

<p><strong>Model: C300 Coupe, C300 4Matic Coupe</strong></p>

<p>Engine and Transmission: Turbocharged 2.0-liter I-4; nine-speed automatic</p>

<p>Power: 241 hp/273 lb-ft of torque</p>

<p>EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 22/30 mpg city/highway (for both rear-wheel-drive and 4Matic)</p>

<p><strong>Model: C300 Cabriolet, C300 4Matic Cabriolet</strong></p>

<p>Engine and Transmission: Turbocharged 2.0-liter I-4; nine-speed automatic</p>

<p>Power: 241 hp/273 lb-ft of torque</p>

<p>EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 22/29 mpg city/highway (for both rear-wheel-drive and 4Matic)</p>

<p><strong>Model: C350e</strong></p>

<p>Hybrid Powertrain and Transmission: Turbocharged 2.0-liter I-4 + electric motor; seven-speed automatic</p>

<p>Power: 275 hp (combined)/443 lb-ft of torque (combined)</p>

<p>EPA-Rated Fuel Economy (2017 model): 51 mpg-e; 28/32 mpg; EV range: 9 miles</p>

<p><strong>Model: AMG C43 Sedan, AMG C43 Coupe, AMG C43 Cabriolet</strong></p>

<p>Engine and Transmission: Twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6; nine-speed automatic</p>

<p>Power: 362 hp/384 lb-ft of torque</p>

<p>EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 20/27 mpg city/highway (Sedan and Coupe), 19/26 mpg (Cabriolet)</p>

<p><strong>Model: AMG C63 Sedan, AMG C63 Coupe, AMG C63 Cabriolet</strong></p>

<p>Engine and Transmission: Twin-turbocharged 4.0-liter V-8; seven-speed automatic</p>

<p>Power: 469 hp/479 lb-ft of torque</p>

<p>EPA-Rated Fuel Economy (2017 model): 18/25 mpg city/highway (Sedan), 17/23 mpg (Coupe), 17/22 (Cabriolet)</p>

<p><strong>Model: AMG C63 S Sedan, AMG C63 S Coupe, AMG C63 S Cabriolet</strong></p>

<p>Engine and Transmission: Twin-turbocharged 4.0-liter V-8; seven-speed automatic</p>

<p>Power: 503 hp/516 lb-ft of torque</p>

<p>EPA-Rated Fuel Economy (2017 model): 18/24 mpg city/highway (Sedan), 17/23 mpg (Coupe), 17/22 (Cabriolet)</p>

<p>The base 2018 C300 comes standard with Dynamic Select drive modes, a selective damping suspension system, 17-inch split-spoke wheels, natural grain brown ash wood trim, a central controller with a 7.0-inch high-mounted color display, and 5 years of <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>-Benz mbrace Connect. The coupe model adds a panorama roof, Sport seats, LED headlights and taillights, 18-inch wheels, and a sport-tuned suspension as standard. The cabriolet comes standard with the above-mentioned features but adds Airscarf (neck-level heating), a removable wind blocker, blind-spot assist, power-folding soft top, and heated front seats.</p>

<p>Available features on the non-AMG models include Sport suspension, a Sport brake system, Airmatic suspension, an AMG Line interior with Sport front seats, 19-inch AMG wheels, multicolor LED ambient lighting, Air Balance cabin fragrance system, Nappa leather upholstery, Comand navigation with an 8.4-inch display screen and Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, Burmester surround sound audio system, and an in-car WiFi hotspot.</p>

<p>The range-topping AMG 63 S comes standard with an AMG electronic limited-slip differential, dynamic engine mounts, AMG Ride Control Sport suspension, an AMG high-performance braking system, AMG Nappa leather performance steering wheel, AMG menu with Racetimer, and a Race Start launch control feature. Available features include an AMG Performance exhaust, an AMG exterior carbon fiber package, 19-inch forged cross-spoke wheels, red seat belts, AMG Performance front seats, AMG carbon fiber interior trim, and Nappa leather upholstery.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/c-class/2018/">Mercedes-Benz C-Class</a> their highest five-star rating and the IIHS considered the C-Class as a 2017 Top Safety Pick. The Top Safety designation was given because the C-Class scored the highest rating of Good in all five crash evaluations and received the highest rating of Superior for front crash prevention by avoiding a 12 and 25 mph frontal collision thanks to the available Pre-Safe with Pedestrian Recognition driver assist safety feature. The C-Class missed out on a Top Safety Pick+ rating because the IIHS rated its headlights as Poor.</p>

<p>Collision Prevention Assist warns the driver of a collision and applies the brakes automatically at speeds up to 65 mph if necessary then actives Pre-Safe. If Pre-Safe detects a rollover or collision, the system will tighten the front seat belts, adjusts the front passenger seat, and closes all the windows and the moonroof. Pre-Safe Brake with Pedestrian Detection can detect an impending collision with a large object or pedestrian and can apply up to 100 percent of braking power up to 35 mph. That feature comes in the Premium Driver Assistance package that also includes blind spot assist, adaptive cruise control with Steering Assist, brake assist with cross-traffic assist, Pre-Safe Plus, Active Lane Keeping assist, speed limit assist, satellite radio, and hands-free keyless access.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>During <em><a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/mercedes-benz-c300-coupe-4matic-2017-car-of-the-year-contender/">Motor Trend Car of the Year testing</a></em>, the 2017 C300 4Matic coupe handled great on our test track, with good braking and acceleration, but we felt the ride was terrible over rough road surfaces. The interior is appealing and quality is good but the bad packaging leaves an extremely small rear seat. We also didn’t like the styling of the coupe, preferring the sedan’s styling instead. “Although the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/c-class/">Mercedes-Benz C-Class</a> sedan may have edged ahead of its <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/3-series/">BMW 3 Series</a> rival, its coupe brother makes a less compelling case compared with the better-looking and more dynamic <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/4-series/">BMW 4 Series</a>.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/giulia/2017/alfa-romeo-giulia-bmw-330i-audi-a4-mercedes-benz-c300-cadillac-ats-jaguar-xe-lexus-is-200t-volvo-s60-comparison/">Big Test of premium sedans</a>, the 2017 Mercedes-Benz C300 came in third place out of eight. The C300 handled very well but delivered a stiff ride, but braking and acceleration were impressive. The Mercedes’ interior was the best in the competition, luxurious, comfortable and quiet but crash safety scores were mid-pack. At the end of the comparison we said, “An excellent all-around performer, the Mercedes-Benz C300 is by far the most luxurious car here while still offering serious performance credentials. If its options packages were more value-oriented and the Sport edition carried a more luxurious ride, it might’ve managed the silver instead of bronze.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/giulia/2017/alfa-romeo-giulia-quadrifoglio-bmw-m3-mercedes-amg-c63-cadillac-ats-v-comparison/">four-way super premium sedan comparison</a>, the 2017 Mercedes-AMG C63 S came in last place. The best part of the sedan was the powerful and great-sounding 503-hp twin-turbo V-8, but other than that, the AMG fell short in the competition, “The AMG is impressive in the corners, beating everything but the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/">Cadillac</a> in our handling tests. Unfortunately, the experience doesn’t back up the numbers—the C63 feels like an unwilling participant in the sport-sedan game. Its steering turns rubbery as the g-forces rise, and its brake pedal becomes less responsive when the carbon-ceramic front (and steel rear) brakes heat up.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>During <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the rear-drive Mercedes-AMG C63 S (503 hp) hit 60 mph in 4.0 seconds, only 0.2 seconds faster than the all-wheel drive 362-hp AMG C43.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>The only significant change on the 2018 GLE-Class is an increase of horsepower on the 3.0-liter twin-turbo engine found in the GLE43, from 362 hp to the current model’s 385 hp. Also, with the GLE43 in the lineup, the GLE400 model is gone.</p>

<p>The GLE-Class is positioned above the GLA-Class, GLC-Class, but below the GLS-Class. The GLE-Class is also offered in coupe-like SUV form—that model is positioned above the GLC-Class Coupe in size and price.</p>

<p><strong>2018 GLE350 (and GLE350 4Matic)</strong>: The GLE-Class’ base trim comes equipped with Dynamic Select drive modes, the Active Curve system, 19-inch wheels, aluminum roof rails, all-wheel drive (4Matic model), Nappa leather-wrapped steering wheel, interior LED lighting, Eucalyptus wood trim, Active Brake Assist (automatic emergency braking), Attention Assist, Pre-Safe, rearview camera, 10-way power driver’s seat, heated front seats, dual-zone automatic climate control, power sunroof, power liftgate, MB-Tex upholstery, an 8.0-inch display screen with a central controller, and dual USB audio ports.</p>

<p><strong>2018 GLE550e 4Matic</strong>: Slotting above the GLE350 is the GLE550e that comes standard with a plug-in hybrid powertrain, a four-mode hybrid drive mode selector, a radar-based regenerative braking system, topstitched dashboard trim, side-mirror logo projectors, blind-spot assist, lane keep assist, leather upholstery, a 115-volt power outlet, Comand infotainment system with navigation and a touchpad controller, a Harman/Kardon audio system, dual USB audio ports with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and an in-dash DVD/CD player.</p>

<p><strong>2018 AMG GLE43</strong>: The entry-level AMG model is the GLE43, which comes equipped with an AMG-enhanced engine, AMG Performance-focused 4Matic all-wheel-drive system, AMG Dynamic Select drive modes, AMG Sport Airmatic suspension with adaptive damping, aluminum paddle shifters, an AMG Sport exhaust system, AMG body styling, Gloss Black exterior accents, 20-inch AMG five-spoke wheels, a Sport steering wheels, AMG instrument cluster, dual-chrome exhaust tips, and aluminum interior trim.</p>

<p><strong>2018 AMG GLE63</strong>: The next step up is the AMG GLE63 that features a hand-crafted AMG engine, an AMG high-performance braking system, 20-inch AMG 10-spoke wheels, AMG Nappa leather-wrapped performance steering wheel, dual chrome AMG exhaust tips, multi-color interior ambient lighting, active LED headlights, Parking Pilot self-parking system, a surround-view camera system, heated and cooled front cup holders, Exclusive Nappa leather upholstery, and a 10-way power passenger’s seat.</p>

<p><strong>2018 AMG GLE63 S</strong>: The range-topping trim adds a more powerful AMG engine, 21-inch AMG cross-spoke silver wheels, AMG Nappa/Dinamica performance steering wheel, and 14-way power AMG Sport front seats with heated and ventilated controls.</p>

<p>Notable features for the non-AMG models include wood/leather steering wheel, Natural Grain Brown Ash wood trim, designo black Dinamica headliner, Distance Pilot Distronic and Steering Pilot (adaptive cruise control with lane centering), cabin-air purification system, multicontour front seats with massaging feature, and designo Expresso Brown exclusive Nappa leather. AMG models are available with AMG Dynamic Performance exhaust, AMG carbon fiber and black piano lacquer interior trim, and the AMG Night package.</p>

<p>The GLE-Class utilizes one of the few non-turbo engines left in <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>’ portfolio, a 3.5-liter V-6 found in the base GLE350 (rear-wheel drive) and GLE350 4Matic that produces 302 hp and 273 lb-ft of torque. The <strong>GLE350</strong> comes with an EPA rating of 18/23 mpg city/highway with rear-wheel drive and 18/22 mpg with all-wheel drive. The <strong>GLE550e 4Matic plug-in</strong> is powered by a 3.0-liter twin-turbo engine and an electric motor for a combined output of 436 hp and 479 lb-ft and delivers 20/23 mpg, 43 mpge with help from the plug-in hybrid system, and can run on all-electric power for up to 8 miles. The <strong>AMG GLE43</strong> sports a twin-turbo V-6 that now produces 385 hp and 384 lb-ft of torque and is rated at 17/23 mpg. The <strong>AMG GLE63</strong> and range-topping <strong>GLE63 S</strong> pack a 5.5-liter twin-turbo V-8 that produces 550 hp, 516 lb-ft in GLE63 form with 577 hp and 561 lb-ft if you go for the S model. The engine delivers 14/18 mpg in both power outputs. With the exception of the rear-drive GLE350 base model, all models come standard with 4Matic all-wheel drive. The GLE AMG43 is the only GLE model to utilize the nine-speed automatic, the remaining models use a seven-speed automatic.</p>

<p>The GLE-Class is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick+ from the IIHS (the highest designation) because the crossover received the highest rating of Good in all five conducted crash evaluations and the highest score of Superior for front crash prevention. The GLE completely avoided 12- and 25-mph frontal collisions thanks to the optional Active Braking Assist with Cross-Traffic Function that is found in the available Premium 3 package. Unfortunately, the standard Active Braking Assist system did not properly warn the driver of a possible collision and the IIHS did not test this system’s emergency automatic braking feature. Additional driver assist safety features found in the Premium 3 package include Active Blind Spot Assist, Active Lane Keep Assist, Active LED headlights, Adaptive Highbeam Assist, Parking Pilot (self-parking system), Distance Pilot Distronic with Steering Pilot (adaptive cruise control with lane centering), a surround view camera system, speed limit assist, and Pre-Safe Plus (applies brakes after accident). Standard features include Active Brake Assist, Attention Assist (drowsy driver alert), trailer stability assist, crosswind assist, blind-spot monitoring, lane keep warning, rearview camera, and Pre-Safe (pre-collision preparation).</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> GLE350 (also 4Matic) and GLE550e offer 38.2 cubic feet of cargo space with the seats up and 80.3 cubic feet with the seats folded down. That’s a decent amount of cargo room but slightly less than the three-row <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/xc90/2018/">Volvo XC90</a>’s 85.7 cubic feet of total cargo room. Front seat legroom measures in at 40.3 inches and 38.4 inches for the rear seats.</p>

<p>The GLE-Class comes standard with an 8.0-inch center display with an infotainment system controlled by a rotary central controller, Bluetooth, dual USB audio ports, remote start with cabin preconditioning, and a household-type 115-volt power outlet for electronics. Available technology features include the Comand infotainment system with a touchpad rotary controller, navigation, a rear seat entertainment system featuring two LCD monitors, a 14-speaker 900-watt Bang &amp; Olufsen BeoSound premium sound system, a 4G LTE WiFi hotspot, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and adaptive cruise control that can come to a complete stop, with lane centering. The various mbrace packages offer services including turn-by-turn route guidance through mbrace Concierge and SOS/Emergency Call through mbrace Secure.</p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/mercedes-benz-gle-class-2016-motor-trend-suv-of-the-year-finalist/">2016 Motor Trend SUV of the Year testing</a>, the GLE-Class was a finalist. We liked the many engine choices, off-road capability, and on-road behavior, but felt the new “Coupe” model was impractical and had strange styling. We liked the power from the turbocharged V-6 and V-8 engines but wished the new nine-speed automatic was used in all models. Hurting the GLE is its somewhat boring interior: “Same old but slightly more refined Benz interior, particularly the center stack. Time to try something new, guys.”</p>

<p>At the end of our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/gle-class/2016/2016-mercedes-benz-gle-class-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2016 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/gle-class/2018/">Mercedes-Benz GLE-Class</a> lineup, we said that “the GLE, no matter what flavor of powertrain a person selects, is the complete package. It still has the utility to carry all the gear for a hockey team, but it does so with more luxury than before. It can get the groceries, deliver the kids to school, and still be ready for a road trip. That’s the real power to this SUV, it does everything buyers in this segment will want.”</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The GLC-Class Coupe lineup receives two new and quick variants, the AMG GLC63 and the GLC63 S coupes. Both new GLC Coupe variants are powered by a twin-turbo V-8.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The GLC-Class Coupe is the smallest and most affordable of the coupe-like SUVs, slotting below the GLE-Class Coupe. In <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>’ entire SUV lineup, the GLC Coupe is positioned above the GLA-Class and GLC-Class but below the GLE-Class, GLE-Class Coupe, GLS-Class, and G-Class.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The base model <strong>GLC300 4Matic Coupe</strong> is powered by a 241-hp, 273-lb-ft of torque 2.0-liter I-4 that comes with an EPA rating of 22/27 mpg city/highway. The <strong>AMG GLC43 Coupe</strong> packs a 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 that produces 362 hp and 384 lb-ft of torque and delivers 18/24 mpg. The <strong>AMG GLC63</strong> and <strong>GLC63 S</strong> are both powered by the same 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 but in different power outputs — 469 hp and 479 lb-ft for the GLC63 and 503 hp and 516 lb-ft for the S model. All models come standard with a nine-speed automatic transmission and 4Matic all-wheel drive. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> claims that the GLC63 S can hit 60 mph in 3.7 seconds, which is very quick for an SUV.</p>

<p>The 2018 Mercedes-Benz GLC300 comes standard with Dynamic Select drive modes, selective damping system, torque vectoring braking, 19-inch wheels, natural grain Brown Ash wood trim, 14-way power driver’s seat, power liftgate, 7.0-inch display with central controller, and dual-zone climate control. THE AMG GLC43 Coupe comes standard with upgraded front axle with a wider track, AMG Sport air suspension, AMG Performance braking system, AMG Sport exhaust system, AMG body styling, 20-inch wheels, red seat belts, AMG menu with Racetimer, heated front sport seats, an illuminated entry system, and stitched MB-Tex upper dash and door trim. The AMG GLC63 and GLC63  come standard with a Panamericana grille, a three-stage AMG Ride Control Sport suspension, an AMG Performance exhaust system, and a mechanical rear limited-slip differential for the GLC63 Coupe and an electronic limited-slip differential for the GLC63 S Coupe model. Some available features include ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, an Air Balance package, ambient lighting, a head-up display, and an 8.4-inch Comand infotainment system with a touchpad and central controller.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The IIHS issued the highest rating of Good for the moderate overlap front and side crash evaluations for the 2017 GLC-Class, the SUV on which the GLC Coupe is based. Standard driver assist safety features include Collision Prevention Assist Plus, Attention Assist (drowsy driver alert), crosswind assist, a rearview camera, Pre-Safe (collision preparation), and trailer stability assist. The remaining driver assist features are located in the Premium Driver Assistance package that includes blind spot warning, Distronic Plus with Steering Assist (adaptive cruise control with lane centering), Brake Assist Plus with Cross-Traffic Assist, Pre-Safe with Pedestrian Recognition, Pre-Safe Plus (post-accident braking), Active Blind Spot Assist, Active Lane Keeping Assist, and Speed Limit Assist. Parktronic with Active Parking Assist (self-parking system) and a surround view camera system are available in the Advanced Parking Assist package.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/glc-class-coupe/2017/2017-mercedes-benz-glc300-coupe-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/glc-class/2017/">2017 Mercedes-Benz GLC-Class</a> Coupe, we said, “Mercedes-Benz says the GLC Coupe is “the sports car among the midsize SUVs,” which suggests the marketing folks haven’t driven either the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/macan/2018/">Porsche Macan</a> or the new <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/">Jaguar</a> F-Pace. The GLC300 Coupe is a smidge more nimble, a touch more buttoned-down, than the regular GLC300, but it is no sports car. The chassis doesn’t disappoint, but it doesn’t excite, either. It’s just quietly competent. The GLC300 Coupe steers better and rides better than <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/">BMW</a>’s X4.”  “Push hard, though, and it’s the front end that cries uncle first, the nose running wide until you get off the gas. Dynamically, it’s pretty one-dimensional.”</p>

<p>“AMG’s bigger wheels and tires, different front and rear bumper fascias, and a discreet spoiler across the lip of the rear hatch give the GLC43 Coupe a more muscular street presence than the regular version,” we said in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/glc-class/2017/2017-mercedes-amg-glc43-coupe-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2017 Mercedes-Benz GLC43 Coupe. We enjoyed the quick acceleration, smooth nine-speed, and the exhaust’s crackles. The ride didn’t feel anymore harsher than the regular GLC Coupe and the larger tires gave more grip, but the steering doesn’t have much feel. “A little quicker in a straight line and a little sharper in the twisties, the Mercedes-AMG GLC43 Coupe doesn’t merely look the part; it is unquestionably a more sporty drive than the GLC Coupe. Which is arguably the whole … er … point.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The new GLC63 and GLC63 S use the same AMG Speedshift nine-speed transmission that debuted in the Mercedes-AMG E63 S.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> gave its flagship lineup a refresh that includes redesigned front and rear fascia, updated headlights and taillights, a new three-spoke steering wheel, and the latest generation of the automaker’s COMAND infotainment system. Two new models, the S450 and S450 4Matic, join the lineup and are powered by a 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6. A revised 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 with two different power outputs is also new, as are a host of advanced driver assist safety features, and three new upholstery choices: Silk Beige/Deep-Sea Blue, Magma Grey/Espresso Brown, and Mahogany/Silk Beige.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The S-Class is the automaker’s flagship lineup and consists of the largest and most expensive models produced by <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>-Benz. Positioned above the E-Class and CLS-Class four-door models, the lineup consists of the traditional S-Class models, the high-performance AMG models, and the long-wheelbase, uber luxurious Mercedes-Maybach models.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/s-class/2018/">2018 Mercedes-Benz S-Class</a> lineup currently comes with a choice of four engine options paired to seven- or nine-speed automatic transmissions; rear- and all-wheel-drive (4Matic) is available. Currently, the only available body style is the sedan, but expect coupe and cabriolet models to return to the lineup.</p>

<p>Model: <strong>S450 and S450 4Matic </strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 – nine-speed automatic<br>
Power: 362 hp/369 lb-ft of torque</br></br></p>

<p>Model: <strong>S560 and Mercedes-Maybach S560 4Matic</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 – nine-speed automatic<br>
Power: 463 hp/516 lb-ft of torque</br></br></p>

<p>Model: <strong>AMG S63 (4Matic)</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 – nine-speed automatic<br>
Power: 603 hp/664 lb-ft of torque</br></br></p>

<p>Model: <strong>AMG S65 (rear-wheel drive)</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 6.0-liter twin-turbo V-12 – seven-speed automatic<br>
Power: 621 hp/738 lb-ft of torque</br></br></p>

<p>The new optional Energizing Comfort feature links the climate control system, fragrance system, heater, ventilation, and massage seat functions, console heating, ambient lighting, and music to create six different comfort programs. Each program runs for 10 minutes and displays visuals on the headunit with colorful graphics, backed by suitable music.</p>

<p>Another newly available comfort feature is the Curve function, which allows the car’s body to lean toward the inside of the turn by up to 2.65 degrees, reducing centrifugal forces felt by passengers. Standard for the S-Class are the two impressive-looking high-resolution display screens that each measure 12.3 inches diagonally and share a single glass cover. Available options include interior ambient lighting with 64 colors, Qi wireless smartphone charging, a Burmester High-End 3D Surround Sound 1520-watt audio system, and mbrace Concierge service that can make restaurant reservations and gather information for sporting events. The AMG models can be optioned with high-performance features like the powerful AMG Ceramic Composite Braking system and the AMG Track Pace App that records vehicle data and lap times when on a race track and displays the information on the COMAND display and the dual cockpit displays.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>Mercedes-Benz loaded the 2018 S-Class with the latest in active safety and driver assistance technology. Available features include adaptive cruise control, Active Steering Assist, Active Emergency Stop Assist, Active Lane Change Assist, Active Speed Limit Assist, and a Route-based Speed Adaptation system that can reduce speed based on map data (if a curve is coming up). Additional features include Active Brake Assist with Cross-Traffic function, Evasive Steering Assist, Active Blind Spot Assist, Active Lane Keeping Assist, Car-to-X communication and Pre-Safe Plus. The new Pre-Safe Impulse Side inflates the seat bolster when an impact is detected to move the passenger up to 2.75 inches away from the crash zone and Pre-Safe Sound will omit an interference signal in an effort to prevent hearing loss.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In an <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/mercedes-amg-s65-bentley-continental-gt-battle-head-2-head/">episode of the <em>Head 2 Head</em></a> series, the 2017 Mercedes-AMG S65 Cabriolet goes up against the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bentley/continental-gt/2017/">2017 Bentley Continental GT</a> Speed Convertible Black Edition. Determining the winner ultimately came down to the vehicle with the modern platform. “Driving the two cars back-to-back, that decade of difference and development is quite apparent. With that said, it isn’t one or two small differences, it’s only clear when you add them all up. When you do, it’s clear that the winner of this <em>Head 2 Head </em>needs to be the Mercedes-AMG S65 Cabriolet.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/slc-class/2017/2017-mercedes-benz-s-class-cabriolet-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2017 Mercedes-Benz S550 Cabriolet and Mercedes-AMG S63 Cabriolet, we loved the very luxurious interior of the S550 and said, “From behind the wheel, the ambiance remains über premium. My pearlescent white land yacht featured a maritime-inspired interior of deep-sea blue and porcelain, a fitting combination for the venue and one that felt as sumptuous as it looked, with extensive application of Nappa leather on the seats, doors, and dash.”</p>

<p>Once behind the wheel of the S63, the cabriolet proved to be a high-performance champ, “With standard 4Matic all-wheel drive that is split 33/67 front/rear and AMG’s proven seven-speed automatic, the S63 Cab deftly manages all 577 horses and 664 lb-ft, making not only sub-4.0-second 0-60 blasts seem routinely nonchalant but also Vmax runs to 200 mph seem wholly realistic.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Race Start function (launch control) is now available on the S63 and is activated by being in Sport or Sport+ mode and pressing hard on the brake pedal with the left foot while fully depressing the throttle with the right foot at the same time. As soon as the brake pedal is released, the S63 rockets forward with optimal traction, in a manufacturer-claimed 0-60 time of 3.4 seconds.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The high-performance AMG GLC63 joins the lineup, packing a twin-turbo V-8 and all-wheel drive. The Storage package and entrance lamps are now standard and the AMG Sport Exhaust, AMG Performance exhaust, rear chrome trim, and the AMG Track Pace App are now available on the AMG models.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The compact GLC-Class is positioned above the entry GLA-Class and below the GLE-Class, GLS-Class, and G-Class. The GLC-Class Coupe has a higher starting price than the traditional model.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> <strong>GLC300</strong> (rear-wheel drive base model) and the GLC300 4Matic (all-wheel drive) are powered by a 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 that produces 241 hp and 273 lb-ft of torque and comes with an EPA rating of 22/28 mpg city/highway and 21/28 mpg (4Matic). A 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 that produces 362 hp and 384 lb-ft of torque is found in the <strong>AMG GLC43</strong> and is rated at 18/24 mpg. The new <strong>AMG GLC63</strong> packs a 469-hp, 479 lb-ft of torque 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 that <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a> claims will send the SUV to 60 mph in 3.9 seconds. All models come standard with a nine-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p>The 2018 GLC300’s standard equipment includes Dynamic Select drive modes, selective damping suspension system, 18-inch wheels, natural grain Brown Ash wood trim, 14-way power driver’s seats, power liftgate, dual-zone climate control, a 7.0-inch display with a central controller, and an illuminated entry system. The AMG GLC43 models add a wider front track, AMG Sport Air Suspension, three-stage electronic stability control, AMG Performance Braking system, AMG Sport exhaust system, AMG instrumentation, and AMG menu with Racetimer. Available features for the lineup include adaptive air suspension, a sport brake system (larger and with M-B lettering), 20-inch wheels, AMG body styling, panorama roof, heated steering wheel, cabin fragrance and air purification system, Designo Nappa leather upholstery, heated and ventilated front seats, a touchpad controller, the Comand infotainment system with a 8.4-inch screen, a head-up display, Burmester Surround Sound audio system, Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, and a WiFi-hotspot. The range-topping GLC63 comes standard with a mechanical limited-slip differential, a Panamericana grille, three-stage AMG Ride Control sport suspension, and an AMG Performance exhaust system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/glc-class/2017/">2017 Mercedes-Benz GLC-Class</a> was issued the highest rating of Good for the moderate overlap front and side crash evaluations. In front crash prevention testing, the standard Collision Prevention Assist Plus driver assist feature did not properly warn the driver of a possible collision and the automatic braking feature was not tested. The optional Pre-Safe with Pedestrian Recognition properly warned the driver of a possible collision but the automatic braking was also not tested. The previously mentioned Collision Prevention Assist Plus, Attention Assist (drowsy driver alert), crosswind assist, a rearview camera, Pre-Safe (collision preparation), and trailer stability assist are standard . The Premium Driver Assistance package includes the remaining driver assist features: blind-spot warning, Distronic Plus with Steering Assist (adaptive cruise control with lane centering), Brake Assist Plus with Cross-Traffic Assist, Pre-Safe with Pedestrian Recognition, Pre-Safe Plus (post-accident braking), Active Blind Spot Assist, Active Lane Keeping Assist, and Speed Limit Assist. Parktronic with Active Parking Assist (self-parking system) and a surround view camera system are available in the Advanced Parking Assist package.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>The Mercedes-Benz GLC300 4Matic won our coveted title of <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/mercedes-benz-glc-class-2017-suv-of-the-year/">2017 Motor Trend SUV of the Year</a>: “The GLC isn’t the sexiest choice for SUV of the Year, but it’s without hesitation the smartest. The design is solid, the interior is first-class, the engineering is as good as small SUVs get, and the value proposition is strong. We have no crash data yet, but the E-Class chassis that the GLC is based upon underpins one of the safest cars on the road. And despite surprising all of us with its power output, displacing just 2.0 liters means that the engine is also scarily efficient.”</p>

<p>“The GLC is just solid, it aces all six of our criteria without skipping a beat.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/glc-class/2017/2017-mercedes-amg-glc43-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 AMG GLC43, we were impressed with the <em>Motor Trend</em> tested 0-60 mph time of 4.7 seconds and the 13.4-second quarter mile. The GLC43 did well in braking and on the skidpad. We enjoyed the driving dynamics of the SUV, “We loved the GLC300’s chassis, and the GLC43’s power hasn’t ruined it. AMG’s done a fantastic job of integrating the more powerful engine into this car, and it doesn’t just put up better numbers. The GLC43 remains highly composed in corners and puts its power down well. The body rolls a little as you first turn the wheel, but rather than floppy, it feels controlled and calculated.” The ride is firmer but not bad and handling is better. However, we wish the GLC had a snow, rain, and off-road driving modes.</p>

<p>The starting price is high and only gets worse with options, putting the small SUV in the pricing territory of larger SUVs. “Still, if you’re the type who wants your luxury SUV to haul ass, the 2017 Mercedes-AMG GLC43 delivers. Best of all, it does it without giving up any of the qualities that made the GLC-Class our SUV of the Year.”</p>

<p>Learn why a <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/">Jaguar</a> F-Pace beat an AMG GLC43 in a snowy three-way comparison test <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/f-pace/2017/jaguar-f-pace-s-mercedes-amg-glc43-porsche-macan-gts-comparison/"><strong>here</strong></a>.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Panamericana grille, standard on the AMG GLC63, was once exclusive to the AMG GT coupe and roadster lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong> Minor updates for the new model year include a standard rearview camera and mirror logo lamps, and available silver or red seatbelts.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong> The SL-Class slots in the middle of <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>’ roadster lineup, after the SLC-Class but before the AMG GT roadster. The SL-Class is one of the most expensive lineups offered by the automaker, with starting prices of the V-12 AMG model surpassing $200,000.</p>
