<p><strong>Overview </strong> The SL-Class lineup consists of four models starting with the entry-level SL450 that comes powered by a 362-hp, 369-lb-ft 3.0-liter twin-turbo V-6 that delivers 20/28 mpg city/highway (2017). The top non-AMG model is the SL500 that comes equipped with a 4.7-liter twin-turbo V-8 that makes 449 hp and 516 lb-ft of torque and is rated at 17/25 mpg (2017). A 577-hp, 664 lb-ft of torque 5.5-liter twin-turbo V-8 powers the AMG SL63 and is rated at 16/25 mpg (2017). The range-topping SL65 packs the automaker’s 6.0-liter twin-turbo V-12 that produces an impressive 621 hp and a whopping 738 lb-ft of torque and delivers 13/22 mpg. The non-AMG models are backed by a nine-speed automatic while the AMG models utilize AMG’s seven-speed dual-clutch transmission. Like a roadster should be, all models are rear-wheel drive. The base SL450 comes standard with Dynamic Select drive modes, ambient lighting, LED Intelligent Light System (adaptive headlights), smartphone integration with Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, Parking Assist, a retractable hard top with a panorama view, and a Harman/Kardon surround sound audio system. AMG standard features add an AMG Sport Exhaust System, AMG high-performance compound braking system, 19-inch staggered width alloy wheels, carbon fiber engine cover, Nappa leather upholstery, heated and ventilated seats, and a Dinamica headliner in the SL63, and a Nappa leather headliner in the SL65. Optional features for the non-AMG models include Magic Sky Control (panoramic transparency feature), the Active Body Control with Curve function suspension system, Piano Lacquer wood trim, exclusive Designo Nappa leather upholstery, and active multicontour seats with massage. Available features on the AMG models consist of an AMG Carbon Ceramic braking system, AMG exterior carbon-fiber package, 19/20-inch AMG forged wheels, an AMG Nappa/Dinamica performance steering wheel, and a Bang &amp; Olufsen BeoSound premium sound system (standard on SL65).</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong> The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/sl-class/2018/">2018 Mercedes-Benz SL-Class</a> lineup comes standard with Attention Assist (sleepy driver alert), pop-up roll bars, Collision Prevention Assist Plus and Active Brake Assist, a collision warning and automatic braking system, and Pre-Safe (closes windows and tightens seatbelt before an accident). To get the most of the driver-assist safety system, opt for the Driver Assistance package that includes Distance Pilot Distronic with Steering Pilot (adaptive cruise control with lane centering), blind-spot assist, active lane keeping, Pre-Safe plus (keeps brakes  applied after rear-end collision), cross-traffic assist, Active Brake Assist with forward cross-traffic warning, and Pre-Safe brake (emergency braking when using Distronic).</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong> In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/sl-class/2017/2017-mercedes-benz-sl-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the refreshed 2017 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/sl-class/2018/">Mercedes-Benz SL-Class</a>, we liked the handling and acceleration of the roadster, but we weren’t crazy about the design and said: “Its collection of discordant visual treatments that are all clamoring too hard for attention. It’s like a pencil sketch that’s been drawn and erased too many times, every time with a firmer hand.” We also said: “The SL really does handle incredibly well. At the limit, it’s a car of big doses of both brain and brawn, a heavily muscled mechanical athlete that’s thinking much faster than you to keep the car on the road and away from those idyllic trees smearing past.” Surprisingly, we enjoined the SL450 the most and said: “We like the lighter feel and nimbler responses of the V-6-powered SL-Class, and despite it being the least powerful of the bunch, still found it to be faster than anyone would need it to be.” In a three-way <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/sl-class/2013/audi-r8-spyder-mercedes-benz-sl63-porsche-911-s-cabriolet/">super convertible comparison</a>, the 2013 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> SL63 (prerefresh but same model) came in second place, “Now, true, the SL63 is very ugly, the steering isn’t wonderful, and the price is nosebleed high, but what an engine!” We also said: “There are very few cars on the market that pull as hard at 150 mph as they do at 50 mph, and even fewer are convertibles. The power and response of this motor are simply incredible.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong> With the Active Body Control equipped, the SL can lower itself automatically by 0.51 inch, and at the press of a button, the SL can raise itself 1.97 inches if traveling on rough roads.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>AMG adds new variants to the GT lineup: the GT Roadster, GT C Coupe, GT C Roadster, and the quickest variant, the GT R coupe. The GT and GT S models received a facelift.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The GT is the flagship and only model that <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a>’s in-house performance division, AMG, produces, though the brand modifies many other <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a> vehicles. The base AMG GT has the highest starting price of all the automaker’s drop-top models and the second highest starting price of all the automaker’s coupes, after the S-Class Coupe. The AMG GT was bred for high-performance.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>All 2018 AMG GT models come equipped with a 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 in different power outputs depending on the model. The base GT coupe and GT Roadster produce 469 hp and 465 lb-ft of torque, the GT S coupe delivers 515 hp and 494 lb-ft of torque, The GT C Roadster and coupe both churn out 550 hp and 502 lb-ft of torque, and lastly, the GT R coupe produces an impressive 577 hp and 516 lb-ft of torque. All engines are mated to AMG’s seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission that routes power to the rear wheels.</p>

<p>The 2018 AMG GT Roadster and coupe come standard with Airpanel active air management (automatic grille shutters), AMG Dynamic Select driving modes, AMG sport suspension, a limited slip rear differential, AMG Performance seats, AMG Panamericana grille reminiscent of a classic Mercedes, and a weight-optimized fabric soft top (roadster). On the other end of the spectrum is the GT R that comes standard with forged aluminum wheels (19-inch front and 20-inch rear) wrapped in Michelin Pilot Sport Cup 2 tires, adjustable nine-setting AMG traction control system, extensive use of carbon fiber, active rear-wheel steering, electronic limited-slip differential, manually adjustable AMG coil-over suspension, active aerodynamics, and the AMG Dynamic Plus package that includes Dynamic Engine and Transmission Mounts, increased front-wheel negative camber, and increased peak horsepower from 6,000-6,500 rpm.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 AMG GT’s standard features include eight airbags, Adaptive Highbeam Assist, a rearview camera, blind-spot monitoring, Lane Keeping Assist, and the Attention Assist system that alerts the driver if the system detects drowsiness. Collision Prevention Assist Plus alerts the driver of a possible collision, applies the ideal amount of braking, and can autonomously apply the brakes at speeds up to 65 mph. Adaptive braking technology consists of Predictive Brake Priming (sets the pads closer to the discs for a more immediate braking response), Automatic Brake Drying (periodically applies the brakes just enough to remove water from the discs), and Hill-Start Assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/amg-gt/2018/2018-mercedes-amg-gt-r-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2018 Mercedes-AMG GT R, we were very impressed with the AMG’s driving dynamics, “This combination of agility and stability is the first thing you notice when hot-lapping the GT R. Compared with the GT S, the front end feels much more alert, responsive, and communicative into a corner. Stability under braking is stunning.” The overall performance of the coupe has significantly increased, “Acceleration, steering, braking, chassis balance: In every way the AMG GT R is noticeably more precise, more responsive, more athletic on the track than the GT S.” However, when compared to its direct competitor, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/911/2018/">Porsche 911</a>, it feels a lot bigger, the driver does not get the same amount of feedback found in the 911, and the dual-clutch transmission is great but not as intuitive as the 911’s PDK transmission. However, “the GT R turned a 7-minute, 10.9-second-lap in the Green Hell, a comfortably quicker time than any 911 has managed.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/amg-gt/2018/2018-mercedes-amg-gt-roadster-first-ride-review/">First Ride review</a> of the new 2018 Mercedes-AMG GT C Roadster, we said, “In short, the dark gray GT C we only got to experience from the wrong seat is emotional, loud, quick, and sexy. It will be available for individuals with a high net worth to purchase by fall 2017. What a little monster.”</p>

<p>In Motor Trend’s <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/amg-gt/2016/2015-motor-trend-best-drivers-car/">2016 Best Driver’s Car testing</a>, the 2015 Mercedes-AMG GT S won the coveted prize out of 10 sports cars. “By the end of the program, it grew obvious that the AMG GT S was greater than the sum of its parts. Part Palm Springs weekend getaway car, part mountain road menace, and part track star, and wholly incomparable.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The available AMG Track Pace feature is an app that owners can use on their smartphone. The app links to the GT and records a host of data in real-time, such as speed, gear, time, position, acceleration, and steering angle.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Mini Clubman gets a rearview camera and rear parking sensors as standard. Apple CarPlay is now included as part of the Technology package. A feature called the Attentive Assistant now comes standard and will recognize if the driver needs to take a break.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Mini Countryman is a small four-door hatchback/wagon available in front- or all-wheel drive configurations. The car is unique from other hatchbacks and wagons in that it features barn-style doors out back instead of a traditional hatch.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>There are two engines available in the 2018 Clubman including a base 1.5-liter turbo-three rated at 134 hp and 162 lb-ft of torque or a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 189 hp and 207 lb-ft in the Clubman S, or 228 hp and 258 lb-ft in the high-performance JCW model. A six-speed manual is standard on all models while a six-speed automatic is optional on the base front-drive Clubman. Base models with all-wheel drive, the Clubman S and JCW feature an eight-speed automatic option instead of the six-speed unit. There’s 17.5 cubic feet behind the split-folding rear seats and 47.9 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings are 24/34 mpg city/highway for the manual-equipped base Clubman and 24/32 mpg with the automatic. Opt for all-wheel drive and those numbers drop to 22/32 mpg with the manual and 23/31 mpg with the automatic. The Clubman S is slightly less efficient at 22/31 mpg with the manual and 23/32 mpg for the automatic. Add all-wheel drive and those numbers drop down to 21/30 mpg and 22/31 mpg for the manual and automatic respectively. The Clubman JCW, which comes standard with all-wheel drive, is rated at 21/31 mpg with the manual or 23/31 mpg with the automatic.</p>

<p>Standard features include 16-inch alloy wheels, leatherette upholstery, keyless start, a 6.5-inch screen, a rearview camera, rear park assist, Bluetooth connectivity, 60/40 split-folding rear seats and adjustable mood lighting. Options include leather upholstery, LED headlights, alloy wheels up to 19 inches in diameter, a head-up display, automatic parking assist, Apple CarPlay integration, an 8.8-inch touchscreen, navigation, a Harman Kardon premium audio system, wireless phone charging, adaptive dampers, 40/20/40 split-folding rear seats, driver’s seat memory, and keyless entry. As with all Mini models, the Clubman is available with an extensive list of customization options that includes racing stripes, chrome side mirror caps, two-tone interior upholstery, and unique roof decals.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash-tested the 2018 Mini Clubman. Models equipped with the Fully Loaded package can be equipped with the Active Driving Assistant, which bundles together adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, and automatic high beam assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mini/clubman/2016/2016-mini-clubman-first-drive-review/">2016 First Drive</a>, we noted that the Mini Clubman S provided plenty of power on tap and that the eight-speed automatic shifted smartly and was always in the right gear. The manual transmission, on the other hand, worked well with the base 1.5-liter turbo-three and has gates that are easy to find, a smooth shifter, and good clutch action. In terms of handling, the Clubman is precise and its steering is not overly heavy. However, the start/stop system is abrupt because it restarts in a rough manner. The car’s interior is a major step up compared to its predecessor, as it now feels more upscale and is well-insulated.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Mini Clubman’s base engine, which is shared with the Hardtop, Convertible and Countryman, is related to the unit found in the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/i8/2018/">BMW i8</a> sports car.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Mini Hardtop now comes with a rearview camera and rear parking sensors as standard.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Available in two- or four-door body styles, the 2018 Mini Hardtop is a front-drive subcompact hatchback that currently serves as the entry-level model for the Mini brand.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two engines are available in the 2018 Mini Hardtop a 1.5-liter turbo-three with 134 hp and 162 lb-ft of torque and a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 189 hp and 207 lb-ft in the S or 228 hp and 236 lb-ft in the JCW. Both engines can be paired to either a six-speed manual or a six-speed automatic transmission. Cargo space is limited in the two-door at 8.7 cubic feet with the rear seats up and 34 cubic feet with them down. The four-door Hardtop is slightly more practical with 13.1 cubic feet behind the second row and 40.7 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the base two-door Hardtop in the Cooper trim are 28/38 mpg city/highway with the manual or 27/35 mpg with the automatic. The more powerful Cooper S and JCW models have the same fuel economy ratings at 23/32 mpg for the manual and 25/32 mpg with the automatic. Opt for the more practical four-door variant and you’ll be seeing 28/37 mpg with the manual or 27/35 mpg with the automatic, both equipped with the base three-cylinder. The more powerful S trim retains the same ratings as its two-door sibling.</p>

<p>Standard features include leatherette upholstery, a 6.5-inch screen, a rearview camera, rear parking sensors, Bluetooth connectivity, 15-inch alloy wheels, and keyless start. Options include navigation, an 8.8-inch screen, a Harman Kardon premium audio system, alloy wheels up to 18 inches in diameter, LED headlights, a head-up display, automatic parking assist, keyless entry, and adjustable dampers. You can also customize the Mini Hardtop extensively with upgrades such as two-tone exterior treatments, Union jack decals, and racing stripes.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Mini Hardtop a four-star overall safety score for the tw0-door model (out of a possible five stars) but it has yet to rate the four-door variant. In IIHS testing, the Hardtop received a Good score on all crash tests and Marginal on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). On the front crash prevention test, the car received an Advanced rating after it avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the impact in a 25-mph test by 7 mph (Superior is the highest rating for the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2015-mini-hardtop-4-door-cooper-s-first-test-review/">2015 First Test</a> of a four-door Hardtop Cooper S, we said that the shifter is awkward, making it a chore to use the shifter on manual-equipped cars. The 2.0-liter turbo-four offers plenty of power on tap, making it easy to pass at higher speeds. However, the stop/start system is clunky and makes the car feel like its going to stall. Cabin noise is minimal thanks to plenty of sound insulation, making it a great cruiser. The high-performance JCW Hardtop proved plenty fun to drive, especially with the standard six-speed manual.  However, the car’s starting price is quite high and it can get even more expensive with just a few options, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2015-mini-john-cooper-works-hardtop-first-drive-review/">2015 First Drive</a>.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/gti/2015/comparison-four-fun-sporty-runabouts-under-30000/">2014 comparison test</a> that also included the previous-generation <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/golf/2018/">Volkswagen Golf</a> GTI, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/wrx/2018/">Subaru WRX</a>, and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2018/">Honda Civic</a> Si, the Mini Hardtop Cooper S placed fourth due to is imprecise gearbox and busy ride. At the track, it wasn’t as confidence inspiring as it rivals because of its tendency to bounce around too much.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Mini Hardtop’s base turbocharged three-cylinder engine is closely related to the unit found in the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/i8/2018/">BMW i8</a> hybrid sports car.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018<br/></strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Mini Countryman gets a rearview camera and rear parking sensors as standard. Apple CarPlay is now included in the Technology package and the Attentiveness Assistance, which monitors driver fatigue, will come standard on all trims.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Mini Countryman compact crossover is available in front- or all-wheel drive configurations. Along with the Clubman, the Countryman is one of the largest Mini models to date. A plug-in hybrid variant called the Countryman S E All4 is also offered in addition to the traditional gas-powered models.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Three powertrain options are available in the 2018 Countryman, a 1.5-liter turbo-three with 134 hp and 162 lb-ft of torque, a 2.0-liter turbo-four rated at 189 hp and 207 lb-ft in the Countryman S or 228 hp and 258 lb-ft in the Countryman JCW, and a plug-in hybrid system that pairs the base 1.5-liter turbo I-3 with an electric motor for a total output of 221 hp and 284 lb-ft. All gas models except for the front-drive Countryman S and the Countryman S E All4 come standard with a six-speed manual. A six-speed automatic is optional on the front-drive base model and standard on the Countryman S E All4 plug-in hybrid. An eight-speed automatic comes standard on the front-drive Countryman S and optional on the all-wheel-drive-equipped base Countryman, Countryman S, and JCW. Cargo space in the 2018 Countryman is 17.6 cubic feet with the split-folding rear seats up and 47.6 cubic feet with them down. The Countryman S E All4 has slightly less cargo space at 17.2 cubic feet behind the second row and 47.4 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the base 2018 Countryman are 24/34 mpg city/highway with the manual or 24/32 mpg with the automatic. With all-wheel drive, those numbers drop to 22/32 mpg with the manual and 23/30 mpg with the automatic. The front-drive Countryman S is rated at 23/32 mpg with its standard automatic transmission while the all-wheel-drive Countryman S All4 is slightly less efficient at 21/31 mpg with the manual and 22/31 mpg with the automatic. The performance-minded Countryman JCW is the least efficient model at 21/29 mpg with the manual and 22/30 mpg with the automatic. The plug-in Countryman S E All4 can travel up to 12 miles in EV mode and up to 270 miles with a full charge and a full tank according to the EPA, with 27 mpg combined.</p>

<p>Standard features include 17-inch alloy wheels, leatherette upholstery, keyless entry/start, a panoramic sunroof, a 6.5-inch screen, a rearview camera, rear parking sensors, Bluetooth connectivity, and split-folding rear seats. Options include leather upholstery, alloy wheels up to 19 inches in diameter, a Harman Kardon premium audio system, a head-up display, an 8.8-inch touchscreen, navigation, Apple CarPlay integration, LED headlights, adaptive damping, automatic parking assist, wireless phone charging and a power tailgate. As with all Mini models, there’s an extensive list of available accessories that will allow you to customize the car accordingly from Union Jack side mirror covers to racing stripes and side stripes.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA hasn’t crash-tested the 2018 Countryman. In IIHS testing, the Countryman received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests and a Marginal rating on the new headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). The crossover also received an Advanced rating on the front crash prevention test after it reduced the impact of a 12- and 25-mph crash by 7 mph (Superior is the highest possible score in front crash prevention). Models with the Fully Loaded package can be equipped with the Active Driving Assistant, which bundles forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, and high beam assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mini/countryman/2017/2017-mini-countryman-first-drive/">2017 First Drive review</a>, we said that the Countryman drives like a tall hot hatch but it no longer crashes over bumps, making it feel more refined than its predecessor. Material quality in the cabin is also much improved, giving it a more upscale feel and there’s now generous space for rear seat passengers thanks to the longer wheelbase. Despite the more upscale vibe, the Mini Countryman’s quirky character hasn’t been lost. On the road, the Countryman handles well but suffers from more body roll than the Clubman. Even so, its ride remains smooth thanks to its longer wheelbase, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mini/countryman/2017/2017-mini-countryman-s-all4-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>. The latest version of <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/">BMW</a>’s iDrive system is also much easier to use and now has a touchscreen controls in addition to the knob and button combo.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact<br/></strong></p>

<p>The Countryman S E All4’s plug-in hybrid powertrain features a battery mounted below the rear seats instead of under the trunk to minimize the amount of space it takes from the cargo area.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Mini Convertible gets a rearview camera and rear parking sensors as standard equipment. Base models no longer come with a compact spare tire.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Mini Convertible is a front-drive soft-top convertible with seating for up to four passengers, and is closely based on the Hardtop model.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two engines are available in the 2018 Mini Convertible including a 1.5-liter turbo I-4 with 134 hp and 162 lb-ft of torque or a 2.0-liter turbo I-4 rated at 189 hp and 207 lb-ft in the S trim or 228 hp and 236 lb-ft in the JCW.  A six-speed manual transmission is standard on all models and a six-speed automatic is optional. EPA fuel economy ratings are 28/37 mpg city/highway for the base car with the manual or 27/35 mpg with the automatic. The more powerful S trim is rated with 23/32 mpg with the manual or 25/32 mpg with the automatic. JCW models are rated at 22/31 mpg with the manual or 25/33 mpg with the automatic. Cargo space is small at 7.6 cubic feet with the top up and 5.7 cubic feet with the top down. Split-folding rear seats come standard for additional cargo space.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base model include 15-inch alloy wheels, leatherette upholstery, keyless start, rear parking sensors, a rearview camera, a 6.5-inch screen, Bluetooth connectivity, and interior mood lighting. Options include alloy wheels up to 18 inches in diameter, LED headlights, leather upholstery, a Harman Kardon premium audio system, a head-up display, navigation, an 8.8-inch screen, keyless entry, adjustable dampers, and automatic parking system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Mini Convertible. However, the Mini Hardtop, the car on which the convertible is based, was awarded the IIHS’ Top Safety Pick award after it received a Good score on all crash tests and a Marginal on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). It also received an Advanced rating on the front crash prevention test when it avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the severity of a 25-mph one by 7 mph (Superior is the highest possible rating).</p>

<p>On cars with the Fully Loaded package, you can opt for the Active Driving Assistant option that bundles forward collision warning, and automatic emergency braking, automatic high beams.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mini/cooper/2016/2016-mini-convertible-cooper-s-first-drive-review/">2016 First Drive</a>, we noted that with the roof in place, the cabin stays quiet and that wind buffeting is well-controlled when it’s down. However, the roof doesn’t stow into the trunk, impeding on rear visibility when the top is down. Steering is twitchy like the Hardtop and torque steer is present when accelerating hard. Handling, on the other hand, is excellent with the car possessing excellent body control and generous grip. The infotainment controller, however, is finicky to use and is positioned too low and too far back.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Unlike most convertibles, the Mini Convertible’s roof can be retracted all the way down or just halfway, and function like a sunroof.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mitsubishi/">Mitsubishi</a> latest generation of its continuously variable transmission (CVT8) now backs a 2.4-liter engine, a revised front grille, and a new rear fascia design. LED daytime running lights and fog lights are standard on the SE and SEL and those models also receive Apple CarPlay/Android Auto as available. Inside, Mitsubishi updated the center console, shift lever, and now comes standard with a 7.0-inch touchscreen display. A new Touring package with driver assist safety features is now available.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The Outlander Sport is Mitsubishi’s entry-level crossover, positioned below the Eclipse Cross and three-row Outlander crossovers.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Outlander Sport comes standard with a 2.0-liter I-4 that produces 148 hp and 145 lb-ft of torque. When backed by the CVT and with front-wheel drive, the crossover delivers an EPA-rated 24/30 mpg city/highway and 23/29 mpg with all-wheel drive (AWD). The base five-speed manual is only available with front-wheel drive and comes with a rating of 23/29. The 168-hp, 167 lb-ft 2.4-liter I-4 can only be paired to the CVT and is rated at 23/28 with front-wheel drive and 22/27 with AWD. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2015 Outlander Sport 2.4 hit 60 mph in 8.6 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a very respectable 115 feet.</p>

<p>Standard features for the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mitsubishi/outlander/2018/">Mitsubishi Outlander</a> Sport include rear LED combination taillights, heated side-view mirrors, 18-inch wheels, a color LCD driver’s display, six-way manually adjustable driver’s seat, automatic climate control, leather wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, soft touch upper instrument panel and door trim, FUSE Hands-free link with USB port, and a 7.0-inch center touchscreen. Available features include paddle shifters, HID headlights, power-folding side view mirrors, panoramic glass roof with adjustable LED mood lighting, a drive selector (2WD, 4WD Auto, 4WD Lock), leather seating surfaces, eight-way power adjustable heated seats, aluminum pedals, navigation, and a 710-watt Rockford-Fosgate premium audio system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave both the FWD and AWD models of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mitsubishi/outlander/2018/">2018 Mitsubishi Outlander</a> Sport four out of five stars for the crossover’s overall score. In IIHS testing, the crossover received the second highest score of Acceptable for the small overlap front test and the highest rating of Good for the remaining crash tests (moderate overlap front, side, roof strength, and head restraints and seats). Standard safety features include hill start assist, active stability control, a rearview camera, and seven airbags. Forward Collision Mitigation, lane departure warning, and automatic high beam driver assist safety features are located in the new Touring package.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/mitsubishi-outlander-sport-24-gt-awc-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the Outlander Sport 2.4 GT, we said, “Other than the increase in power, the Outlander Sport GT is much the same as the Outlander Sport ES. It has modern exterior lighting and aggressive EVO-like face, and while the black interior initially feels upscale, it’s saddled with some hard plastics throughout. The seats are fairly comfortable but could use a lumbar adjustment. Although the upgraded audio system enriches the sound, particularly with lower frequencies due to the Rockford Fosgate subwoofer. … After all, the compact crossover has only had minor revisions since it went on sale for the 2011 model year.”</p>

<p>We did not like the slow acceleration of the standard 2.0-liter engine in our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2015-mitsubishi-outlander-sport-20l-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 2015 Outlander Sport 2.0 FWD. Even so, we appreciated the value of the crossover and said, “Despite the lackluster drivetrain, the $23,645 (including $850 destination) 2015 Outlander Sport offers lots of standard and available features.” We concluded our review by saying, “…the 2015 Outlander Sport combines an aggressive face with a tidy exterior that makes parking in urban areas a breeze. Inside, our tester’s black interior felt upscale, and the seats were mostly comfortable on the 9.5-hour drive, though a lumbar adjustment for the front seats would be welcome. The interior isn’t a bad place to be, and the available electronics are appreciated.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Outlander Sport is Mitsubishi’s best-selling model.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mitsubishi/">Mitsubishi</a> adds more standard feature to the Mirage lineup including a 7.0-inch touchscreen with Bluetooth phone/audio streaming, a rearview camera, and steering wheels audio and Bluetooth controls. The USB port has been relocated to the center console and the G4 sedan model now has a standard truck pass through. The Mirage received a mid-cycle refresh for the 2017 model year.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The <strong>Mirage</strong> <strong>hatchback</strong> and <strong>Mirage G4 sedan</strong> is Mitsubishi’s most affordable and smallest model in the automaker’s lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The subcompact Mirage hatchback and Mirage G4 sedan are powered by a 1.2-liter I-3 engine that produces 78 hp and 74 lb-ft of torque that delivers an EPA-rated 33/41 mpg city/highway with the five-speed manual transmission (33/40 mpg for the G4) and 37/43 with the CVT (35/41 mpg for the G4). In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the pre-refresh <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mitsubishi/mirage/2014/">2014 Mitsubishi Mirage</a> (with a 74-hp version of the same engine) hit 60 mph in a slow 12 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a decent 127 feet.</p>

<p>The base Mirage ES model comes equipped with the previously mentioned 7.0-inch touchscreen with Bluetooth phone/audio streaming, a rearview camera, and steering wheels audio and Bluetooth controls. The ES also includes a rear spoiler, an Eco indicator light (on CVT models), and a USB port. The range-topping GT model comes equipped with 15-inch two-tone alloy wheels, HID headlights, heated front seats, and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Other available features include a Rockford Fosgate premium audio system, an LED interior illumination package, and a Quick Value package that adds front and rear mudguards, scuff plates, black leather shift knob, cargo mat, cargo net, and an exhaust finisher.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mitsubishi/mirage/2018/">Mitsubishi Mirage</a> a four-star rating for the hatchback’s overall score (the G4 has yet to be tested by the NHTSA). In IIHS testing, the Mirage received the highest score of Good in all but one evaluation, scoring the second-lowest rating of Marginal in the small overlap front test. The G4 sedan model received the same ratings with the exception of the side crash test, scoring the second-highest rating of Acceptable. The Mitsubishi Mirage was not tested for front crash prevention because the Mirage does not offer any active driver assist safety features. The Mirage comes standard with seven airbags, stability control, and is available with front and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mitsubishi/mirage/2014/2014-mitsubishi-mirage-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the pre-refresh 2014 Mitsubishi Mirage, we did not like much about the car. The hatchback has lousy handling, a bumpy ride, very slow acceleration, has a lot of interior noise and vibration, and interior quality is very cheap as well. The best part of the car if the very low starting price and the good fuel economy, “Is that fuel economy, plus the Mirage’s slight pricing advantage, enough to justify the car over its better-driving competition? Not for me, but I can see how some cash-strapped car shoppers without any enthusiast leanings might see otherwise. Whether it beats rolling in an older, used vehicle is debatable, but the 10-year, 100,000-mile powertrain warranty makes it an attractive used car alternative.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Mirage and Mirage G4 come with a fully transferable 5-year/60,000 mile limited warranty and a 10-year/100,000 miles powertrain warranty.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mitsubishi/">Mitsubishi</a> updates the looks of the Outlander with new front and rear bumper designs, LED running lights, a new center console, and shift lever. A 7.0-inch touchscreen display with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto is now standard in addition to new silver interior stitching. The SEL trim receives blind spot warning with rear cross traffic alert and a power tailgate standard. The top GT model now comes equipped with a multi-view camera system and a heated steering wheel standard. Lastly, the new Touring package is available on the SEL and GT trims.</p>

<p><strong><a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2018-mitsubishi-outlander-phev-starts-at-35535/">A new plug-in hybrid model</a></strong> also debuts as part of the 2018 Outlander lineup, with a starting price in the mid-$30,000 range.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The Outlander is Mitsubishi’s three-row crossover, positioned above the entry-level Outlander Sport and the new Eclipse Cross crossover.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>With the exception of the range-topping GT model, the standard engine is a 2.4-liter I-4 engine that produces 166 hp and 162 lb-ft of torque and delivers an EPA-rated 25/30 mpg city/highway with front-wheel drive and 24/29 mpg with all-wheel drive (AWD). The GT trim utilizes a 224-hp, 215 lb-ft 3.0-liter V-6 that is only available in AWD and is rated at 20/27 mpg. The 2.4-liter is backed by a CVT while the V-6 is paired to a six-speed automatic. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the Outlander 2.4 SEL (AWD) hit 60 mph in 9.2 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a respectable 119 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 Outlander comes standard with a 7.0-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, LED daytime running lights, heated side view mirrors, 18-inch wheels, seven-passenger seating, dual-zone climate control, and a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift lever. Many available features are bundled together in the SEL Touring package that includes a multi-view camera system, adaptive cruise control, Forward Collision Mitigation, lane departure warning, automatic high beams, LED headlights and fog lights, heated steering wheel, a 710-watt Rockford-Fosgate sound system, blind-spot warning with lane change assist and rear cross-traffic alert, power glass moonroof, and a power remote liftgate.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mitsubishi/outlander/2018/">2018 Mitsubishi Outlander</a> received the highest five-star rating for the AWD model and four stars for the FWD version from the NHTSA for the crossover’s overall score. The Outlander is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick+ (the highest designation) from the IIHS for receiving the highest rating of Good in all crash tests and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention evaluation. The Superior rating was issued because the Outlander was able to avoid 12 mph and 25 mph frontal collisions thanks to the Forward Collision Mitigation System found in the previously mentioned Touring package that adds all available driver assist safety features.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>After one year with our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mitsubishi/outlander/2016/2016-mitsubishi-outlander-sel-awd-review-verdict/">long-term 2016 Mitsubishi Outlander SEL</a>, we enjoyed the fact that the crossover gave us no issues, and was cheap to maintain. We did wish for more power from the equipped 2.4-liter I-4, as it would struggle with more than two people in the crossover, but the fuel economy was good. We liked the driver assist safety features but felt they were a little too sensitive and not as refined as other competitive systems. The interior was conservative and simple, the front seats were comfortable, but the third-row seats are very small, not made for adults. The 63.3 cubic feet of cargo space was great for fitting many things, but the power liftgate was slow to open and close. At the end of our long-term verdict, we said, “Our Outlander had a good amount of content for its $33,095 sticker price. But again, not all of those features work as well as those offered by the competition. I think the Outlander makes a more compelling case as a stripped-down base model. A front-wheel-drive 2017 Outlander ES is a great value at its $24,390 starting price because it offers more room than a <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/cr-v/2018/">Honda CR-V</a> and has a standard third row for less money.”</p>

<p>During our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mitsubishi/outlander/2016/2016-mitsubishi-outlander-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the refreshed 2016 Outlander, we felt the crossover was quieter than the previous model year but still not as quiet as we would have liked. The interior was an improvement, especially the more comfortable front seats and the easier-to-fold-down rear seats. Equipped with the I-4, the crossover felt more nimble than the V-6 but needed more power. “The well-equipped SEL front-drive model starts at $25,845, and the V-6 AWD is still a value at $31,845. Will all the improvements, plus the value, add up to more interest from U.S. buyers? They’d be wise to consider the new crossover for its value.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2.4-liter I-4 has a towing capacity of 1,500 pounds, while the V-6 more than doubles that at 3,500 pounds.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/titan/2018/">2018 Nissan Titan</a> gets a new Midnight Edition model that comes with dark inserts on the grille, dark headlights, black fog light surrounds, black exterior badges, black side mirror covers, 20-inch black-finished alloy wheels, and black Midnight Edition badges. Only the SV and SL crew cab models can be had as a Midnight Edition variant.</p>

<p><strong>Trim Levels (Interior and Exterior Options)</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/titan/2018/">Nissan Titan</a> is a full-size truck that slots above the midsize Frontier and is available in three cab styles and in rear- or four-wheel drive. Five trims are available including a luxury-oriented Platinum Reserve and off-road-oriented Pro-4X. Above the Titan is the Titan XD, which offers an eight-cylinder diesel engine.</p>

<p><strong>Titan S: </strong>The base S trim comes with 18-inch alloy wheels, cloth upholstery, a 5.0-inch screen, a USB port, keyless entry and start, Bluetooth, and a rearview camera.</p>

<p><strong>Titan SV: </strong>Moving up to the SV trim adds chrome door handles, satellite radio, and a front overhead console.</p>

<p><strong>Titan Pro-4X: </strong>Off-road-minded Titan Pro-4X models come with a leather-wrapped steering wheel, all-terrain tires, LED low-beam headlights, fog lights, a spray-on bedliner, Bilstein shocks, additional skid plates, leather upholstery, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, an eight-way adjustable power driver’s seat, and navigation.</p>

<p><strong>Titan SL: </strong>Stepping up to the SL trim gets you 20-inch alloy wheels, a 12-speaker Rockford Fosgate audio system, heated front seats, a power tilt and telescoping steering wheel, a power adjustable front passenger seat, chrome side mirror covers, and fixed aluminum running boards.</p>

<p><strong>Titan Platinum Reserve: </strong>As the luxury-oriented trim, the Titan Platinum Reserve gets features like ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a>’s Around View Monitor surround-view camera system, and open-pore wood interior trim.</p>

<p>Features such as navigation, the 7.0-inch touchscreen, the Rockford Fosgate audio system, and heated and ventilated front seats are available on lower trims as part of packages. However, only the Platinum Reserve can be had with the rear-seat entertainment system.</p>

<p>All Titans come with a five-year/100,000-mile basic warranty.</p>

<p><strong>Performance and Fuel Economy</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Nissan Titan is powered by a 5.6-liter V-8 with 390 hp and 394 lb-ft of torque that’s paired to a seven-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 15/21 mpg city/highway for rear- and four-wheel drive models. Pro-4X models are less efficient at 15/20 mpg.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Titan crew cab received a four-star overall rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). King Cab and Single Cab models were only tested in the rollover test by the NHTSA, where they received four stars.</p>

<p>In IIHS testing, the 2018 Titan received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except the passenger side front small overlap test where it hasn’t been tested and the headlights test where it got a Marginal rating (Good is the highest possible score). The IIHS hasn’t given the 2018 Titan a rating on the front crash prevention test. Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert are available on the Titan SV and higher trims.</p>

<p><strong>Utility</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Titan can haul a maximum payload of 1,950 pounds. When properly equipped, it can tow up to 9,740 pounds. As with all full-size trucks, the towing and payload capacities depend on the cab style and drivetrain configuration.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>During our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/nissan-titan-2017-truck-of-the-year-contender/">2017 Truck of the Year evaluations</a>, we liked the Titan’s ride quality and accurate steering. However, the more you loaded the truck up and the higher up in altitude you went, the more it suffered, which meant it struggled up the Davis Dam tow climb.  Interior comfort also lags behind its rivals and the multimedia could be improved.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 5.6-liter V-8 in the 2018 Titan is also used on the Armada full-size SUV and the Titan XD.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/murano/2018/">2018 Nissan Murano</a> receives new standard features including an 8.0-inch touchscreen with <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> Connect Navigation, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and satellite radio. Also standard on all trims is automatic emergency braking and forward collision warning driver assist systems. The new SV Premium package consists of a surround-view camera system, a driver alert system (sleepy driver alert), adaptive cruise control, a panoramic moonroof, an 11-speaker Bose premium audio system, heated front seats, heated outside mirrors, and 18-inch Gun Metal alloy wheels. The Murano also received a revised center console design, a Midnight Edition package for the SL trim, and a new SL Moonroof package. Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross traffic alert are now standard on the SV trim (one above the base trim).</p>

<p>In Nissan’s SUV and crossover lineup, the Murano is positioned above the Juke, the new Kicks, the Rogue Sport, and the Rogue, but below the larger and more expensive Pathfinder and full-size Armada.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Murano S</strong>: The base trim comes well-equipped with an 8.0-inch touchscreen with NissanConnect Navigation, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and satellite radio. Also standard is emergency automatic braking, forward collision warning, LED daytime running lights, LED taillights, automatic headlights, a 7.0-inch driver’s instrument cluster display, a rearview camera, dual-zone automatic climate control, as well as front and rear USB ports.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Murano SV</strong>: The SV trim adds a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, remote engine start with climate control, a 10-way power adjustable driver’s seat, four-way power passenger’s seat, fog lights, black roof rails, auto-dimming rearview mirror, blind-spot monitoring, and rear-cross traffic alert.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Murano SL</strong>: Building off the SV’s features, the SL adds heated leather seats (front and rear), a surround view camera system, a Bose premium audio system, a motion-activated liftgate, interior ambient lighting, silver roof rails, adaptive cruise control, and a heated steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Murano Platinum</strong>: The top Platinum trim adds 20-inch alloy wheels, LED headlights, heated and cooled front seats, NissanConnect Services, a power panoramic moonroof, power tilt/telescoping steering wheel, and power return rear seatbacks.</p>

<p>A Wi-Fi hotspot, wireless smartphone charger, and a frameless auto-dimming rearview mirror with Universal Remote are also available.</p>

<p>The 2018 Murano is powered by a 3.5-liter V-6 that produces 260 hp and 240 lb-ft and is backed by a CVT that routes power to the front wheels or to the optional all-wheel-drive system. The Murano delivers an EPA-rated 21/28 mpg city/highway in both front- and all-wheel drive systems. The 2015 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/murano/2018/">Nissan Murano</a> Platinum FWD (with the same engine as the 2018 model) hit 60 mph on 7.0 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 120 feet in <em>Motor Trend</em> testing.</p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2017 Nissan Murano its highest five-star overall rating for the AWD model and a four-star overall rating for the FWD model. The 2018 Murano received the highest rating of Good for five crash tests the IIHS conducted and the highest rating of Superior for front crash prevention because the crossover avoided a 12 mph frontal collision and reduced speed in a 25 mph collision by 11 mph thanks to the standard emergency automatic braking and forward collision warning systems. Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross traffic alert are standard on the SV trim and the SL trim gets adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p>The Murano’s cargo space with the rear seats up measures in at 32.1 cubic feet, and 67.0 cubic feet with the seats down. That is less than the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/edge/2018/">Ford Edge</a>’s 39.2 and 73.4 cubic feet, respectively, but the Murano offers a flatter load floor. The Murano’s front seats offer 40.5 inches of legroom and 38.7 inches for the rear seats. The Edge offers more with 42.6 inches for the front and 40.6 for the rear. However, in a comparison that included a Murano, Edge, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/santa-fe/2018/">Hyundai Santa Fe</a> Sport, we noted that the Murano had more legroom than the other cars: “The specs allege the Nissan to have the least rear legroom here … but our collective perspective says otherwise. Potential customers’ best course of action is checking everything in person.”</p>

<p>The Murano‘s 8.0-inch touchscreen with NissanConnect Navigation and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto is standard on all trims. satellite radio, Bluetooth, and two USB ports are also standard. A 7.0-inch driver’s instrument cluster display is standard but the optional Bose premium audio system is not. The optional NissanConnect Services powered by SiriusXM includes automatic collision notification, emergency call service, and stolen vehicle locator. With the remote services app, owners can start/stop the engine, lock/unlock the doors, flash the lights, honk the horn, and set curfew and speed alerts.</p>

<p>After one year with our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/murano/2015/2015-nissan-murano-sl-awd-review-verdict/">long-term 2015 Nissan Murano SL</a>, we concluded by saying, “The Murano passes my personal test, as well—and does so with a luxurious, quiet, comfortable interior. The exterior styling is bold, polarizing, and conversation-starting. It drives well and is reliable. And although it never hooked me emotionally, I would have no qualms about recommending one to friends and family. Except in orange.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/murano/2015/2015-ford-edge-nissan-murano-hyundai-santa-fe-sport-comparison/">three-way crossover comparison</a> with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> Edge and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/santa-fe-sport/2018/">Hyundai Santa Fe Sport</a>, the Murano came in first place. We said, “Vehicles able to smartly mix work and play are always welcome in our schedule book. The Nissan will contentedly float along on the freeway, and then, as it’s done since model year 2003, surprise with a one-two punch of a normal-feeling continuously variable automatic and astonishingly engaging handling.”</p>

<p>But visibility is not that good: “The Murano’s visibility was indeed sacrificed to the style deities when it came to the thick A- and kookily-drawn C- and D-pillars.” However, we preferred the quiet, luxurious, and stylish cabin of the Murano over the other two crossovers. “The navigation system was one of the best I have ever worked with, thanks to the large, responsive touchscreen and crisp graphics. The seats were very comfortable.”</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/armada/2018/">2018 Nissan Armada</a> gets a rearview mirror with an LCD camera as standard (if rear visibility is blocked by cargo or passengers, a digital screen fills the rearview mirror’s display to show what’s behind the vehicle).</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting above the three-row Pathfinder, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/armada/2018/">Nissan Armada</a> is the brand’s flagship SUV and is closely related to the global-market Patrol and the outgoing <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/qx80/2018/">Infiniti QX80</a>. Rear-wheel drive is standard and four-wheel drive is optional. The Armada can seat up to eight passengers in its standard configuration or seven with the optional second-row captain’s chairs.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>All 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> Armadas are powered by a 5.6-liter V-8 with 390 hp and 394 lb-ft of torque paired to a seven-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 14/19 mpg city/highway for rear-drive models and 13/18 mpg with four-wheel drive. When properly equipped, the Armada can tow up to 8,500 pounds. The Armada has 16.5 cubic feet of cargo space behind the third row, 49.9 cubic feet behind the second row, and 95.4 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base SV trim include the NissanConnect infotainment system with an 8.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, keyless entry/start, dual-zone climate control, remote start, Bluetooth connectivity, a rearview camera, eight-way power adjustable heated front seats with driver memory, cloth upholstery, 60/40 split-folding second and third rows, a 13-speaker Bose premium audio system, USB ports, LED low-beam headlights, parking sensors, and 18-inch alloy wheels. Higher trim levels add leather upholstery, heated second-row seats, ventilated front seats, 20-inch alloy wheels, a heated steering wheel, second-row captain’s chairs, a power liftgate, an entertainment system, and Nissan’s Around View Monitor multi-camera visibility system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Nissan Armada hasn’t been crash tested by the NHTSA and IIHS. Active safety features such as adaptive cruise control, automatic emergency braking, blind-spot warning, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, rear automatic emergency braking, and Moving Object Detection are available on the SL trim as part of the Technology package and standard on the range-topping Platinum grade.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think<br/></strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/armada/2017/2017-nissan-armada-platinum-first-test-review/">2017 First Test review</a>, we said that the V-8 provides prodigious power and doesn’t feel tasked with hauling the Armada around even with the optional four-wheel-drive system. The seven-speed automatic has good logic and quick shifts, and at higher speeds, keeps revs under 2,000 rpm. Even with the optional 20-inch alloy wheels, the Armada rides well but its handling is sloppy due to excessive body roll and numb steering. The interior is nearly similar to the one found in the more expensive <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/infiniti/">Infiniti</a> QX80, meaning it’s built well with high quality materials all around. However, the third row seats are cramped.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Automatic emergency braking, a rearview camera, and 5.0-inch center display with Bluetooth streaming audio and Siri Eyes-Free is now standard on all models (except NISMO models). The SV model receives dual zone automatic climate control and 16-inch aluminum alloy wheels. Adaptive cruise control is now standard on the SR 1.8L and SL models. The SL Premium Tech package equipment is now standard on the SL and includes a moonroof, a Bose premium audio system, and NissanConnect Services.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The compact Sentra sedan slots above the enter-level Versa sedan but below the larger and more expensive Altima and Maxima. The Sentra starts significantly less than <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a>’s smallest crossovers, the Juke and Rogue Sport.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/sentra/2018/">2018 Nissan Sentra</a> comes equipped with a standard 1.8-liter I-4 engine that produces 124 hp and 125 lb-ft of torque and has an EPA-rating of 29/37 mpg city/highway with the CVT and 27/35 with the six-speed manual transmission. Both Sentra SR Turbo and NISMO variants use a 188-hp 1.6-liter turbocharged I-4 with 177 lb-ft of torque that delivers 27/33 mpg (25/30 mpg for the NISMO) with the CVT and 26/32 mpg (25/31 mpg for the NISMO) with the six-speed manual transmission. All powertrains send power to the front wheels of the compact sedan. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/sentra/2018/">Nissan Sentra</a> NISMO equipped with the six-speed manual hit 60 mph in 7.3 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a respectable 112 feet. The 2016 Nissan Sentra SL with the CVT hit 60 mph in 10.0 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 128 feet.</p>

<p>The Sentra’s base S model comes standard with a 5.0-inch center display with Bluetooth streaming audio and Siri Eyes Free, three drive modes (Eco, Sport, Normal), automatic headlights, a USB port, and cruise control.</p>

<p>The luxurious SL model comes equipped leather-appointed seats, heated front seats, dual-zone automatic climate control, auto-dimming rearview mirror, six-way power driver’s seat, a 5.8-inch touchscreen with NissanConnect with Navigation, a 5.0-inch driver’s display, leather-wrapped steering wheel, LED headlights with accents, fog lights, and 17-inch aluminum wheels, power moonroof, Bose audio system, adaptive cruise control, and Forward Emergency Braking.</p>

<p>The bolder NISMO Sentra is equipped with NISMO-tuned suspension and steering, NISMO sport front seats, NISMO Alcantara and leather-wrapped steering wheel, NISMO leather-wrapped shift knob, NISMO tachometer, 18-inch NISMO wheels, a NISMO aerodynamic body kit, and NISMO black outside mirrors.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA issued the 2017 Nissan Sentra a four-star overall crash safety rating out of possible five stars. However, the Nissan Sentra is considered a 2017 IIHS Top Safety Pick for receiving the highest rating of Good in all five crash tests (though the Sentra has yet to be rated in the new passenger side small overlap test) and for receiving the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention evaluation by properly warning the driver of a possible collision, avoiding a collision in a 12-mph test, and for reducing the speed of a 25-mph collision by 10 mph thanks to the now-standard automatic emergency braking driver assist safety feature. Other available driver assist features include blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert and adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/sentra/2017/2017-nissan-sentra-nismo-first-test-review/">2017 First Test review</a> of the 2017 Nissan Sentra NISMO, we concluded, “Our test vehicle with the six-speed manual checked in at $27,370, putting it in the same price range as the Civic hatchback, Jetta GLI, and Mazda3 2.5, but from the 2017 Nissan Sentra NISMO’s stiff ride and suspension to its lackluster handling and laggy powertrain, it feels incomplete. Additionally, the interior’s age is amplified by an infotainment system that’s well behind the units found in competitors such as the Civic and in more mainstream compacts such as the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/cruze/">Chevrolet Cruze</a>. The 2017 Sentra NISMO could use more power and should handle better, but as it stands, we’re not sure the car is worthy of a NISMO badge considering its performance didn’t improve much over its predecessors from 10 years ago.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2016/2016-2017-big-test-compact-sedans/">seven-way compact sedan Big Test comparison</a>, the 2016 Nissan Sentra SL came in last place, we said, “The seventh-place finisher, the 2016 Nissan Sentra SL, suffered with the least powerful and least efficient engine, dreadful steering and seating, the highest forecasted cost of ownership, and the worst published IIHS crash scores despite being loaded with the most features.”</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> adds Automatic Emergency Braking and adaptive cruise control as standard for the new model year. Additionally, the top 3.5 SL model receives adaptive cruise control and NissanConnect with navigation and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. The base 2.5 and 3.5 SR models have been removed from the lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>Nissan’s midsize sedan is positioned above the Versa models and the compact Sentra but below the larger and more expensive Maxima. If considering a crossover, the Altima starts slightly more than the compact Rogue Sport but less than the traditional Rogue.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/altima/2018/">2018 Nissan Altima</a>’s base engine is a 179-hp, 177-lb-ft of torque 2.5-liter I-4 that delivers an impressive, EPA-rated 27/38 mpg city/highway (or 26/37 as a 2.5 SR model). The available 3.5-liter V-6 produces 270 hp and 251 lb-ft of torque and comes with a fuel economy rating of 22/32 mpg. Both engines are backed by a CVT that routes power to the front wheels. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 Altima 2.5 SV hit 60 mph in 7.8 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 121 feet.</p>

<p>The base 2.5 S model comes standard with 16-inch wheels, a 5.0-inch center display, Siri Eyes Free, Bluetooth phone and streaming audio, a 4.0-inch driver display, and a USB port. The top 3.5 SL model features 18-inch wheels, NissanConnect with navigation and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a 7.0-inch center touchscreen, leather appointed seats, eight-way power heated front driver’s seat, heated steering wheel, power moonroof, rear air conditioning vents, remote engine start, and front and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/altima/2018/">Nissan Altima</a> received the highest five-star rating from the NHTSA for the sedan’s overall rating and the 2017 model is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick+ from the IIHS for receiving the highest rating of Good in all crash five tests and for the highest rating of Superior for front crash prevention for properly warning the driver of a possible collision, avoiding a 12 mph collision, and reducing the impact of a 25 mph collision by 10 mph. This is thanks to the now standard and previously mentioned Automatic Emergency Braking and Intelligent Forward Collision Warning systems. Rear cross-traffic alert and blind-spot warning are standard and the 2.5 SV model and above and the adaptive cruise control feature is standard on the 3.5 SL model.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/altima/2016/2016-nissan-altima-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the refreshed 2016 Nissan Altima, we liked the new SR sports model and the improved fuel efficiency of the 2.5-liter engine but felt the paddle shifters were gimmicky and denied many shifts. We enjoyed the new sound deadening and said, “Back-to-back runs in mainstream 2015 and 2016 models reveal that the new car sounds a full price class quieter than its predecessor. We’re talking near deep-space quiet to match the NASA zero-gravity seats.” The Altima also drove better, “Grip and body-motion control on the SR seem a noticeable step ahead of most of its ‘sport’ competitors. Lean hard enough into a turn to find the understeer limit then lift, and the nose tucks in exactly as a proper performance car’s nose should.”</p>

<p>We concluded by saying, “To these eyes the 2016 Altima looks better (I’d deem it the best Energetic Flow design because the budget didn’t allow for overstyling the body sides and C-pillars), it handles better, and it feels more refined. It even delivers better efficiency.”</p>

<p>“Were <em>Motor Trend</em> to ever organize a WGMSDR (World’s Greatest Midsize Sedan Drag Race), the 2017 Altima would be fighting for the lead. We clocked a 0–60 time on our moderately equipped tester of just 7.8 seconds, which may not sound all that great before you remember this is the base engine,” we said during a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/altima/2017/2017-nissan-altima-25-sv-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 Nissan Altima 2.5 SV. That feat is hard to accomplish while also having great fuel economy, “Although your mileage may vary depending on how often you take advantage of the Altima’s relative quickness, [the car’s EPA ratings] put it near the top of the class.” The CVT has been tuned to respond faster and not drone as much as previous models did.</p>

<p>We wished the 7.0-inch center screen was larger and placed higher in the dashboard. Even so, “the 2017 Nissan Altima gets most of the basics right. The car is as spacious as you’d expect, and it’s quicker than other midsizers from <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/">Hyundai</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a>, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> [this review was written before the 2018 Camry, which hits 60 mph just slightly quicker, arrived]. The updated front styling isn’t for everyone (I’m not a fan), but if the low-mounted 7.0-inch touchscreen doesn’t bother you and CVTs don’t scare you, add the 2017 Altima to your list.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The good fuel economy can be partly attributed to the Altima’s impressive drag coefficient of 0.26, better than the Leaf’s 0.28.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/rogue/2018/">2018 Nissan Rogue</a> Sport carries over unchanged save for a new Technology package for the SV trim, which replaces the Premium package. Features originally found on the SL’s Platinum package have been integrated to the Premium package.</p>

<p><strong>Trim Levels (Interior and Exterior Options)</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/rogue/2018/">Nissan Rogue</a> Sport is a subcompact crossover that slots below the larger Rogue and above the upcoming Kicks. It’s available in three trims with front-wheel drive as standard and all-wheel drive as an option.</p>

<p><strong>Rogue Sport S: </strong>The base S trim comes standard with 16-inch steel wheels with covers, a four-speaker audio system, a 5.0-inch screen, Bluetooth, a USB port, a rearview camera, cloth upholstery, and keyless entry.</p>

<p><strong>Rogue Sport SV: </strong>Move up to the SV trim and that adds 17-inch alloy wheels, automatic headlights, a six-speaker audio system, dual-zone climate control, keyless start, an eight-way power adjustable driver’s seat, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a>’s Divide-N-Hide cargo divider system.</p>

<p><strong>Rogue Sport SL: </strong>Range-topping SL grades get leather upholstery, 19-inch alloy wheels, remote start, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, heated front seats, Siri Eyes Free, Nissan’s Around View Monitor surround-view multi-camera system, a heated steering wheel, and fog lights.</p>

<p>Features like the heated front seats, navigation, remote, start, the Around View Monitor, the 7.0-inch touchscreen, and the heated steering wheel are available as part of optional packages in the SV grade. The SL trim is available with the Premium package, which adds LED headlights, a moonroof and a full suite of active driver assistance features.</p>

<p><strong>Performance and Fuel Economy</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Rogue Sport is powered exclusively by a 2.0-liter I-4 rated at 141 hp and 147 lb-ft of torque paired exclusively to a CVT. EPA fuel economy ratings are 25/32 mpg city/highway for front-drive models and 24/30 mpg with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the 2018 Rogue Sport received a Basic rating for having an available forward collision warning system (Superior is the highest rating for the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p>Active driver assistance features are available only on the SV and SL grades. Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert are available on both SV and SL trims but lane departure warning, adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, automatic emergency braking, and high beam assist are only available on the SL model as part of the Premium package.</p>

<p><strong>Utility</strong></p>

<p>With the split-folding rear seats in place, the 2018 Rogue Sport has 22.9 cubic feet of cargo space (20 cubic feet on the SV and 19.9 cubic feet on the SL). Fold the rear seats down and cargo space expands to 61.1 cubic feet in the S trim or 53.3 cubic feet on the SV and SL grades.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/rogue-sport/2017/2017-nissan-rogue-sport-first-drive-review/">2017 First Drive</a>, we said that thanks to its size, the Rogue Sport is easy to maneuver and rides comfortably. The multimedia system, however, lacks Android Auto and Apple CarPlay. Sportiness isn’t what the Rogue Sport excels at because although its got secure handling, the steering is numb and uncommunicative.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/crosstrek/2018/no-mans-land/">2017 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/compass/2018/">Jeep Compass</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/crosstrek/2018/">Subaru Crosstrek</a>, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/rogue-sport/2018/">Nissan Rogue Sport</a> placed third because of its dated infotainment system, tight back seats, and slow acceleration. Ride quality, on the other hand, is smooth as the suspension does a good job of absorbing bumps. Off the pavement, our all-wheel-drive Rogue Sport tester easily got stuck in the sand and its lack of power kept it from freeing itself.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>In other markets, the 2018 Rogue Sport is known as the Qashqai.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>A <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2018-nissan-370z-heritage-edition/">new 2018 Nissan 370Z Heritage Edition</a> celebrates nearly 50 years on the market. The new Heritage Edition, which is available on the base model, features a Chicane Yellow or Magnetic Black exterior paint. Yellow cars feature black mirror caps and exterior graphics, while black cars feature silver exterior graphics. Both cars have yellow interior trim.</p>

<p>Although it’s now in its 10th model year, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> updated all 370Z models with revised headlights and taillights, smoked chrome door handles, rear fascia, and a new EXEDY clutch for manual-equipped cars.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The rear-drive two-seat <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/370z/2018/">2018 Nissan 370Z</a> coupe and roadster are the automaker’s entry-level sports cars that slot below the four-seat all-wheel-drive <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/gt-r/2018/">2018 Nissan GT-R</a> supercar.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>Power for all 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/370z/2018/">Nissan 370Z</a> models come from a naturally aspirated 3.7-liter V-6 mated to a six-speed manual with Downshift Rev Matching or a seven-speed automatic transmission. Most models make 332 hp at 7,000 rpm and 270 lb-ft of torque at 5,200 rpm, while the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/gt250r/2015/2015-nissan-370z-nismo-first-look/">370Z NISMO coupe</a> makes 350 hp at 7,400 rpm and 276 lb-ft at 5,200 rpm. Base and Touring models feature an open rear differential, while Sport, Sport Tech, NISMO, and NISMO Tech models feature a viscous limited-slip differential (VLSD).</p>

<p>Inside, the base audio system features and AM/FM/CD with four speaker, while a 240-watt, eight-speaker Bose audio system is available. Tech models feature a hard-drive navigation system with 7.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth phone and audio streaming, USB input, and DVD player.</p>

<p>Eight-way manual driver’s and four-way passenger manual cloth are standard, while eight-way (four-way power, four-way manual, and adjustable lumbar) driver’s and four-way power passenger leather and synthetic suede seats are optional.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p><a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/370z/2011/2011-nissan-370z-touring-test/">In testing, a 2011 Nissan 370Z Touring</a> reached 60 mph in 4.9 seconds and finished the quarter-mile in 13.4 seconds at 105.4 mph. A set of massive Akebono brakes stopped the Z in 102 feet while a set of 19-inch Rays Engineering forged alloy wheels wrapped in Bridgestone Potenza RE050A rubber helped our tester pull 1.01 g lateral average on the skidpad.</p>

<p>Despite its additional power, <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/370z/2015/2015-nissan-370z-nismo-first-test/">our 2015 Nissan 370Z Nismo tester</a> was slightly slower than our 2011 tester (4.9 seconds, 13.5 seconds at 105.4 mph), and took longer to stop (114 feet). We concluded: “Although our time behind the wheel of the 2015 Nissan 370Z NISMO was enjoyable, there were some definite shortcomings. For the $46K price tag, we would have liked more creature comforts, such as power seats and more upscale materials. But as it sits, the new 370Z NISMO is a track car for the streets… In the end, the 2015 Nissan 370Z is one of those cars that is fun to drive but hard to justify buying.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Nissan 370Z was one of the first cars with a rev-matching manual transmission.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><iframe allow="autoplay; encrypted-media" allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/vo7MoX_Fuds?feature=oembed" width="660"></iframe></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> Pathfinders gets automatic emergency braking standard on all trim levels and gets a new rear door alert system that reminds you to check the rear seats if something was left behind. SL models can now be had with the Midnight Edition package, which adds 20-inch black alloy wheels, black side mirror covers, and a black roof spoiler.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/pathfinder/2018/">2018 Nissan Pathfinder</a> is a three-row crossover slotting above the compact Rogue and two-row Murano but below the larger, full-size Armada. Unlike some previous generations of the Pathfinder, the current-generation model comes standard with front-wheel drive and all-wheel drive is an option. When it was first introduced for the 2013 model year, the current Pathfinder was also available as a hybrid; however, that model was short-lived as it was discontinued after only being in the market for a single model year.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/pathfinder/2018/">Nissan Pathfinder</a> is powered by a 3.5-liter V-6 with 284 hp and 259 lb-ft of torque that’s paired exclusively to a CVT. EPA fuel economy ratings stand at 20/27 mpg city/highway for front-drive models and 19/26 mpg with all-wheel drive. Cargo space is 16 cubic feet with all seats in place, 42.4 to 47.8 cubic feet behind the second row depending on the position of the sliding second row, and 79.8 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>Standard features include an 8.0-inch touchscreen, a multi-information display, a rearview camera, tri-zone climate control, keyless entry/start, 18-inch alloy wheels, and Bluetooth connectivity. Higher trims get alloy wheels up to 20 inches in diameter, parking sensors, remote start, heated and ventilated front seats, leather upholstery, Nissan’s Around View Monitor, a heated steering wheel, a power liftgate, a Bose premium audio system, LED headlights, and a panoramic sunroof.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The IIHS and NHTSA haven’t tested the 2018 Pathfinder but the 2017 model received a five-star overall score from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2017 model received the Top Safety Pick award after it earned a Good score on all crash tests (Good is the highest possible score). It missed the highest rating, Top Safety Pick+, due to the headlight rating of Marginal (instead of Acceptable or Good). On the front crash prevention test, a 2017 Pathfinder received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the impact of 25-mph crash by 14 mph. Automatic emergency braking and forward collision warning are now standard on all 2018 Pathfinders while other active safety tech like blind spot spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, Moving Object Detection, and adaptive cruise control are available only on higher trim levels.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>Although the additional power didn’t make the Pathfinder quicker, we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/pathfinder/2017/2017-nissan-pathfinder-sv-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a> that the crossover didn’t feel underpowered. The crossover is easier to drive in urban areas because its car-based underpinnings make it easier to maneuver. Inside, the Pathfinder has plenty of space in all three rows and can easily accommodate adult passengers. However, the material quality in the lower S and SV trims are subpar due to excessive amounts of hard plastics and a hard dash. The Pathfinder’s 7.0 inches of ground clearance also means it isn’t as capable off-road as its predecessor.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The current generation Nissan Pathfinder switched rides on a unibody platform shared with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/altima/2018/">Nissan Altima</a>, Maxima, and Murano.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>
