<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/versa/2018/">2018 Nissan Versa</a> gets a new exterior color called Deep Blue Pearl. The SL trim has been discontinued, making the SV the new range-topping model.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/versa/2018/">Nissan Versa</a> is a front-drive subcompact sedan that slots below the larger Sentra and is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a>’s entry-level vehicle. A hatchback variant called the Versa Note is also available.</p>

<p><strong>Versa S</strong>: The base Versa S comes with 15-inch steel wheels with covers, cloth upholstery, Bluetooth connectivity, and a four-speaker stereo system.</p>

<p><strong>Versa S Plus</strong>: Building on the base S trim, the S Plus adds cruise control, chrome exterior door handles, a rear spoiler and air deflectors.</p>

<p><strong>Versa SV</strong>: On the range-topping SV trim, additional standard features include an upgraded instrument cluster, 60/40 split-folding rear seats, a USB port, and keyless entry.</p>

<p>Notable options include the SV Special Edition package, which adds fog lights, 15-inch alloy wheels, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, fog lights, a 5.0-inch screen for the infotainment system, a Special Edition badge, and a rearview camera.</p>

<p>The 2018 Nissan Versa is powered by a 1.6-liter I-4 rated at 109 hp and 107 lb-ft of torque. It can be paired to either a five-speed manual transmission or a CVT. EPA fuel economy ratings are 27/36 mpg city/highway for the manual or 31/39 mpg with the CVT.</p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Versa a four-star rating on the front crash and rollover tests (out of a possible five stars). The 2018 Versa hasn’t been crash tested by the IIHS but the 2017 model received a Good score on the three categories it has been tested in, side impact, roof strength and head restraints and seats (Good is the highest possible score). There are no active safety and driver assistance features on the 2018 Nissan Versa.</p>

<p>For a subcompact sedan, the 2018 Nissan Versa has a massive trunk at 14.9 cubic feet and on the SV trim, it can be expanded with the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/versa/2012/2012-nissan-versa-sedan-first-drive/">2012 First Drive</a>, we said that the despite its small exterior footprint, the Nissan Versa has a spacious cabin for front- and rear-seat passengers. Ride comfort is good for a small car but it’s slow to accelerate. Interior materials quality is cheap with extensive amounts of hard plastics throughout the interior. We also noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/versa/2012/2012-nissan-versa-sl-test/">2012 First Test</a> that on the highway, the Versa doesn’t feel comfortable and the steering feels overboosted and doesn’t firm up enough. Also, the powertrain doesn’t respond to the driver’s inputs very well.</p>

<p>In global markets, the Nissan Versa is also known as the Latio, Sunny, and Almera.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/titan/2018/">2018 Nissan Titan</a> XD gets a new Midnight Edition model that comes with black grille inserts, dark headlights, black fog light surrounds, black side mirror covers, black door handles, 20-inch black alloy wheels, black badges, and black Midnight Edition badges. This particular model is only available on the crew cab SV and SL trims with the optional diesel engine.</p>

<p><strong>Trim Levels (Interior and Exterior Options)</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/titan/2018/">Nissan Titan</a> XD is a heavy duty truck that slots above the standard, full-size Titan. The truck is available in three cab styles and in rear- or four-wheel drive configurations. There are five trims available including an off-road-minded Pro-4X trim and a luxury-oriented grade called the Platinum Reserve.</p>

<p><strong>Titan XD S: </strong>The base S trim gets cloth upholstery, a 5.0-inch screen, a four-speaker audio system, a USB port, Bluetooth, a rearview camera, keyless entry and start, and 17-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Titan XD SV: </strong>Moving up to the SV trim adds front tow hooks, a six-speaker audio system, Siri Eyes Free, and a front overhead console.</p>

<p><strong>Titan XD Pro-4X:</strong> The off-road-oriented Titan XD Pro-4X adds 18-inch alloy wheels, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, Bilstein shocks, a spray-in bedliner, skid plates, a receiver hitch, leather upholstery, eight-way power adjustable driver’s seat,  LED headlights, fog lights, chrome door handles, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, heated front seats, dual-zone climate control, and navigation.</p>

<p><strong>Titan XD SL: </strong>SL models are more premium-oriented and comes with 20-inch alloy wheels, fixed running boards, a 12-speaker Rockford Fosgate audio system, a power-adjustable steering column, remote start, as well as front and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>Titan XD Platinum Reserve: </strong>Sitting at the top of the Titan XD range is the Platinum Reserve model that adds <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a>’s Around View Monitor surround-view multi-camera system, heated rear seats, ventilated front seats, and open-pore wood trim.</p>

<p>The Platinum Reserve is the only model available with the rear entertainment system option.</p>

<p>The Titan XD comes standard with a five-year/100,000-mile basic warranty.</p>

<p><strong>Performance and Fuel Economy</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/titan-xd/2018/">2018 Nissan Titan XD</a> comes standard with a 5.6-liter V-8 rated at 390 hp and 394 lb-ft of torque paired to a seven-speed automatic transmission. A 5.0-liter turbodiesel V-8 with 310 hp and 555 lb-ft is optional and comes paired to a six-speed automatic. Heavy duty trucks including the Titan XD, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-250/2018/">Ford F-250</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/2500/2018/">Ram 2500</a>, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a> Silverado 2500 aren’t rated by the EPA.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/titan-xd/2018/">Nissan Titan XD</a> hasn’t been crash tested by the NHTSA and IIHS. Blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert is available on the SV and higher grades. No other active driver assistance features are offered.</p>

<p><strong>Utility</strong></p>

<p>When properly equipped, the single cab variant can tow up to 12,760 pounds depending on the engine, cab style and the drivetrain. Maximum payload capacity on the 2018 Titan XD is 2,710 pounds depending on the cab style, engine, and drivetrain configuration.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/titan-xd/2016/2016-nissan-titan-xd-v-8-platinum-reserve-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we said that the Titan XD didn’t perform as well as expected on the incline test at Davis Dam due to its weight and powertrain calibration, which caused it to hold gears at redline and not shift to the next one. During standard acceleration tests, the Titan XD with the 5.6-liter V-8 is noticeably slower than the standard Titan due to its weight. Seat comfort was also not the Titan XD’s forte because the front seats lack support and the rear seats felt like slabs. Its infotainment system looked dated and the resolution is grainy. Ride quality, on the other hand, is good but its interior gets very noisy and the steering wheel transmits an excessive amount of vibration to the driver’s hands.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The optional diesel engine on the 2018 Titan XD is build by Cummins in Columbus, Indiana.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/gt-r/2018/">2018 Nissan GT-R</a> gets a new base trim level called the Pure, slotting below the Premium grade.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/gt-r/2018/">Nissan GT-R</a> is the automaker’s flagship supercar and it comes standard with all-wheel drive. Four trims are available in the 2018 GT-R.</p>

<p><strong>GT-R Pure:</strong> Standard features on the base Pure trim includes 20-inch Rays forged alloy wheels, a rear spoiler, a six-speaker audio system, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, Apple CarPlay integration, Bluetooth, a rearview camera, keyless entry/start, dual-zone climate control, leather and synthetic suede upholstery, full LED headlights and heated front seats.</p>

<p><strong>GT-R Premium: </strong>The Premium trim adds an 11-speaker Bose audio system with active noise cancellation, an active sound enhancer, and a titanium exhaust system.</p>

<p><strong>GT-R Track Edition: </strong>Slotting between the GT-R Premium and the GT-R NISMO, the Track Edition gets additional adhesive bonding for improved body rigidity, a NISMO-tuned suspension that’s lighter and stiffer, 20-inch NISMO forged alloy wheels, NISMO-specific tires, Recaro front bucket seats and a carbon fiber rear spoiler.</p>

<p><strong>GT-R NISMO: </strong>In addition to the added power, the GT-R NISMO gets the same body and suspension modifications as the Track Edition but adds a NISMO-specific aero kit, a different carbon fiber rear spoiler, and an Alcantara-trimmed steering wheel.</p>

<p>Notable options include all-season tires and a Premium Interior package with hand-stitched semi-aniline leather upholstery.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> GT-R is powered by a 3.8-liter twin-turbo V-6 paired to a six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. On the Pure, Premium and Track Edition, it’s rated at 565 hp and 467 lb-ft of torque while the NISMO is rated at 600 hp and 481 lb-ft. EPA fuel economy estimates are 16/22 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 GT-R. There are no active safety features available on the 2018 GT-R.</p>

<p>Trunk space in the 2018 GT-R is 8.8 cubic feet and can be expanded via the standard split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/gt-r/2017/2017-nissan-gt-r-first-drive-review/">2017 First Drive</a>, we said that the GT-R’s power delivery is immediate and more linear than older versions. The improved steering also requires less corrections when driven hard, making the GT-R easier to drive fast. However, the dual-clutch transmission isn’t very quick to respond to downshifts with some lag occurring before it actually switches cogs. Seat comfort has improved without sacrificing their ability to hold you in place during enthusiastic driving. The updated multimedia system is easier to use but it’s slow to respond to your inputs whether it’s using the controller knob or the touchscreen. Interior noise has also been lessened thanks to additional sound insulation.</p>

<p>The GT-R placed second in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/nsx/2017/2017-acura-nsx-vs-nissan-gt-r/">2016 comparison test</a> against the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/nsx/2018/">Acura NSX</a> because of its excessive understeer during enthusiastic driving and the transmission, which sometimes responded quickly but other times reacted too slowly.</p>

<p>The 2018 GT-R’s available titanium exhaust system first appeared for the 2015 model year on the GT-R NISMO.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>For the 2018 model year, the Rogue crossover adds ProPilot Assist as an available option and NissanConnectSM featuring Apple CarPlay and Android Auto as standard. A motion-activated liftgate is now standard on the SV model and adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, lane departure assist, and automatic emergency braking with pedestrian detection are now standard on the SL model. The Midnight Edition package has been revised with a new black front and rear fascia accents, black rear license plate finisher, black V-motion grille, and black emblems. Scarlet Ember and Midnight are new exterior colors.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The compact Rogue is positioned above the smaller Juke and Rogue Sport but below the larger and more expensive Murano, Pathfinder, and Armada. The Rogue hybrid is currently <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a>’s only hybrid vehicle.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/rogue/2018/">2018 Nissan Rogue</a> is powered by a 170-hp 2.5-liter I-4 with 175-lb-ft of torque. The engine gets an EPA-rated fuel economy of 26/33 mpg city/highway with front-wheel drive and 25/32 mpg with all-wheel drive. The <strong>Rogue Hybrid</strong> utilizes a 141-hp, 144-lb-ft 2.0-liter I-4 engine paired to a 40-hp, 118-lb-ft electric motor and delivers 33/35 mpg with front-wheel drive and 31/34 with all-wheel drive. All engines are back by a CVT.</p>

<p>Above the base Rogue S is the Rogue SV, which comes standard with 17-inch alloy wheels, dual-zone automatic climate control, privacy glass, push-button ignition, eight-way power driver’s seat with power lumbar support, roof rails, automatic headlights, heated front seats, remote engine start, and a motion-activated liftgate. The SL model receives leather front seats, a Bose audio system, NissanConnect with navigation, a 7.0-inch touchscreen display, a surround-view camera system, 18-inch wheels, heated steering wheel, and automatic high beams. The Rogue Hybrid adds a standard automatic engine start/stop and an energy flow guide. The Platinum Reserve Interior package includes premium tan leather-appointed seats with special quilted leather inserts. A panoramic moonroof and LED headlights are part of the Premium package.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2017 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/rogue/2018/">Nissan Rogue</a> received a four-star overall safety rating out of five stars from the NHTSA. However, the crossover is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick from the IIHS for receiving the highest rating of Good in five crash tests, the second-highest rating of Acceptable for the headlights evaluation, and the highest rating of Superior for front crash prevention by properly warning the driver of a possible collision, avoiding a 12 mph collision, and reducing the speed of a 25 mpg collision by 23 mph thanks to the automatic emergency braking system with pedestrian detection that’s standard on the SL model. Other driver assist safety features include the standard blind-spot monitoring and rear-cross traffic alert systems, as well as lane departure warning, lane keep assist, and adaptive cruise control. The new ProPilot Assist driver assist feature is located in the SL Platinum package and provides assisted steering, braking, and accelerating during highway driving.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/rogue/2017/2017-nissan-rogue-hybrid-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 Nissan Rogue Hybrid, we liked how the premium for the hybrid was only about $1,000 and costs less than the RAV4 hybrid. However, we did not care for the hybrid’s sluggish acceleration and somewhat rough transition from electric to hybrid power. Additionally, the Real MPG and EPA fuel economy figures are lower than those of the RAV4 Hybrid, but higher than the traditional Rogue. The brakes have an unnatural feel and the steering is very slow. The front seats are comfortable but rear visibility is not good (as with most modern crossovers).</p>

<p>“In a way, the front- and all-wheel-drive Nissan Rogue Hybrid is a value,” we wrote in the review. “The hybrid is offered at about $1,000 more than the same trim in nonhybrid form, an impressively low premium. Even so, it’s tough to recommend the Nissan because its prime competition is quicker, more efficient in our testing, drives better, and has more cargo space. If you aren’t completely set on the Nissan brand, test-drive the RAV4 Hybrid before committing to one over the other.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-5/2016/small-crossover-comparison-big-test/">Big Test nine-way compact crossover comparison</a>, the 2016 Nissan Rogue SL came in eighth place, we said, “The Nissan Rogue SL was another crossover that we all really enjoyed, but its fuel economy figures and driving dynamics were ultimately unimpressive compared to our top six.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Magnetic Black, Gun Metallic, and Pearl White exterior colors are offered in the Midnight Edition package offered on the Rogue SV model.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/versa/2018/">2018 Nissan Versa</a> Note lineup gets cut down to three trim levels with the discontinuation  of the SL grade, making the SR the new range-topping model.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/versa/2018/">Nissan Versa</a> Note is a subcompact hatchback that slots below the compact Sentra. It is closely related to the Versa sedan but features more flexibility and more cargo space.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/versa-note/2018/">2018 Nissan Versa Note</a> is powered by a 1.6-liter I-4 rated at 109 hp and 107 lb-ft of torque. The engine is paired exclusively to a CVT (a manual is available on the Versa sedan). EPA fuel economy ratings are excellent at 31/39 mpg city/highway, making it one of the more efficient subcompact cars available. Cargo capacity is 18.8 cubic feet with the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats up and 38.3 cubic feet with them folded. In addition to the folding rear seats, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/versa-note/2018/">Nissan Versa Note</a> features storage underneath the cargo floor, which also doubles as a divider.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base S trim include 15-inch steel wheels with covers, cloth upholstery, a four-speaker audio system, Bluetooth connectivity, and four-way manual adjustable seats. The SV trim adds a 5.0-inch screen, 15-inch alloy wheels, cruise control, keyless entry, a rearview camera, and six-way adjustable front seats. On the range-topping SR trim, it gets 16-inch alloy wheels, faux suede upholstery, fog lights, keyless entry/start, side sills, a roof-mounted spoiler, turn signals integrated into side mirrors, and the Easy-Fill tire alert system. The SV Special Edition package adds features from the SR trim to the SV grade like fog lights, keyless entry/start, and the Easy-Fill tire alert system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> Versa Note a three-star front crash and a four-star rollover rating (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS hasn’t crash-tested the 2018 Versa Note. There are no active safety features available on the 2018 Versa Note in any trim level.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/versa-note/2014/2014-nissan-versa-note-sv-with-sl-tech-package-first-test/">2014 First Test</a>, we said that the front and rear seats are spacious and there’s no center tunnel cutting into the passenger foot well in the back. However, material quality is poor because the interior is composed mostly of hard plastics. The 1.6-liter I-4 doesn’t have much power and is sluggish off the line, meaning you need t0 plan your highway passes. Handling is also a weak point due to the car’s numb steering, uninspiring chassis and low-rolling resistance tires that easily lose grip and howl the moment you take a corner.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>In Japan, the Nissan Versa Note, which is called the Note, is offered in an e-Power hybrid model that’s powered solely by an electric motor backed by a gas engine that acts as a generator.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/nv200/2018/">2018 Nissan NV200</a> gets a new 5.0-inch touchscreen, a USB port, and a rearview camera as standard.</p>

<p><strong>Trim Levels (Interior and Exterior Options)</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/nv200/2018/">Nissan NV200</a> is a compact commercial vehicle slotting below the larger <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> NV1500. It’s available in S and SV grades. In addition to the cargo van, there’s also a taxi variant available.</p>

<p><strong>NV200 S: </strong>The base S trim gets you 15-inch steel wheels with covers, Bluetooth, a 5.0-inch touchscreen, a rearview camera, cloth upholstery, a USB port, and a two-speaker audio system.</p>

<p><strong>NV200 SV: </strong>Moving up to the SV trim adds keyless entry, six floor-mounted D-rings in the cargo area, cruise control, a chrome grille, body-colored bumpers, and two 12-volt outlets.</p>

<p><strong>Performance and Fuel Economy</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Nissan NV200 is powered by a 2.0-liter I-4 with 131 hp and 139 lb-ft of torque that’s paired to a CVT. EPA fuel economy ratings are 24/26 mpg city/highway. Taxi variants are less efficient at 23/26 mpg.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Nissan NV200 hasn’t been crash tested by the NHTSA and IIHS. There are no available active driver assistance features on the 2018 NV200.</p>

<p><strong>Utility</strong></p>

<p>There’s 122.7 cubic feet of cargo space in the 2018 NV200 and the van can haul up to 1,480 pounds of payload depending on the trim level. The 2018 NV200 isn’t rated for towing.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/nv200/2013/2013-nissan-nv200-sv-long-term-verdict/">2013 Long Term Verdict</a>, we said that the NV200’s 2.0-liter I-4 and CVT was laggy and the transmission is loud until you get to cruising speeds, where it settles down. Stability was good at city speeds but it can get unstable at higher speeds. The sliding doors and rear barn doors make it easy to load and the engine didn’t feel tasked even when packed to the brim.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>A rearview camera is now standard on all models, and the base S receives updated standard equipment including air conditioning, cruise control, Bluetooth, and a 5.0-inch color center display with Siri Eyes Free. A new Midnight Edition consists of a gloss-black grille, 18-inch gloss-black aluminum wheels, semi-gloss black step rails, body-color front and rear bumpers, back outside rear view mirrors and door handles, black badging, and available Midnight Edition floor mats.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The Frontier is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a>’s smallest truck, positioned below the full-size Titian truck. The Frontier is also the most affordable truck on the market.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/frontier/2018/">2018 Nissan Frontier</a>’s standard engine is a 2.5-liter I-4 engine that produces 152 hp and 171 lb-ft of torque and delivers an EPA rated 19/23 mpg city/highway when backed by the five-speed manual and 17/22 mpg with the five-speed automatic. The 2.5-liter I-4 is only available with rear-wheel drive.</p>

<p>The optional 4.0-liter V-6 engine produces 261 hp and 281 lb-ft of torque and is rated at 16/22 mpg with the six-speed manual transmission (16/21 mpg with four-wheel drive) and 16/23 mpg with the five-speed automatic (15/21 mpg with four-wheel drive). The Frontier is available in king cab and crew cab configurations with standard and long beds. The Frontier’s maximum towing capacity is 6,690 pounds when properly equipped. In <em>Motor Tren</em>d testing, the 2015 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/frontier/2018/">Nissan Frontier</a> Pro-4X hit 60 mph in 7.8 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a long 139 feet.</p>

<p>The Frontier is available with heated and power adjustable leather-appointed front seats, a Rockford Fosgate audio system, dual-zone automatic climate control, a 5.8-inch touchscreen with NissanConnect with navigation, a shift-on-the-fly electronically controlled four-wheel-drive system (2WD/4HI/4LO modes), and an electronic locking rear differential. The PRO-4X model includes off-road-tuned Bilstein high-pressure performance gas shocks, skid plates (oil pan, fuel tank, and transfer case), and a limited-slip rear differential.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>In IIHS testing, the 2017 Nissan Frontier scored the second lowest rating of Marginal for the small overlap front crash test and the second-highest rating of Acceptable for the head restraints and seats evaluation. The highest score of Good was issued for the moderate overlap front, roof strength, and side collision crash test. Front crash prevention was not tested because the Frontier does not offer a collision warning system or emergency automatic braking feature. The NHTSA issued the truck a four-star overall rating out of a possible five stars for the crew cab model; the king cab model has only been tested for the rollover evaluation, where the truck received three stars out of five.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>After <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/frontier/2012/2012-nissan-frontier-4x4-pro4x-verdict/">one year with our long-term 2012 Nissan Frontier</a> Pro-4X 4×4, we said, “Though the aging interior and trusty V-6 engine seemed to be a common complaint when the <em>Motor Trend</em> staff borrowed the truck, the Frontier is enduring and fun to drive with carlike steering, an easy-to-shift six-speed gearbox, the PRO-4X suspension package that rides well on- and off-road, and the ‘just-my-size’ feel for the weekend projecteer or the on-the-fly adventure seeker.”</p>

<p>“We worked our tester to its capacities on a regular basis,” we wrote, “and the truck shined through it all. Though it doesn’t have the power or luxury of a full-size truck, the Frontier can haul, tow, and play just as hard.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>If you are looking to haul a lot of cargo, opt for the base, rear-drive S V-6 model that provides the maximum payload capacity of 1,460 pounds with the five-speed automatic (1,450 with the six-speed manual).</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Maxima gains Apple CarPlay and Android Auto smartphone compatibility as standard equipment and the Maxima SR Midnight Edition returns for the new model year.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The Maxima is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a>’s flagship sedan that slots above the smaller and less expensive Altima, Sentra, and Versa sedans.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/maxima/2018/">2018 Nissan Maxima</a> sedan is powered by a 300-hp, 261-lb-ft of torque 3.5-liter V-6 engine backed by a CVT that routes power to the front wheels and delivers 21/30 mpg city/highway. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, 2016 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/maxima/2018/">Nissan Maxima</a> Platinum hit 60 mph in 5.7 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 122 feet.</p>

<p>The base Maxima S comes standard with 18-inch aluminum wheels, a Drive Mode selector, fog lights, an 8.0-inch center display screen with navigation and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a 7.0-inch instrument cluster digital display, two USB ports, LED daytime running lights, dual mufflers with chrome tips, dual-zone automatic climate control, eight-way power driver’s seat, and a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob.</p>

<p>The range-topping Platinum model includes LED headlights, panoramic moonroof, a surround-view multi-camera system, power tilt/telescoping steering wheel, adjustable interior ambient lighting, rear window power sunshade, climate-controlled front seats (heated and ventilated), heated steering wheel, Premium Ascot leather-appointed seats with diamond-quilted leather inserts, Mahogany wood-tone faceted interior trim, an 11-speaker Bose Centerpoint 2 premium audio system, and active noise cancellation.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The Nissan Maxima received top honors from both crash-test-rating institutions in 2017: the NHTSA gave it a five-star overall rating and the IIHS made it a 2017 IIHS Top Safety Pick+. The Maxima received the TSP+ designation for receiving the highest rating of Good in all six crash test evaluations (including the new small overlap front passenger side test), for receiving the second-highest rating of Acceptable for the headlights evaluation, and for receiving the highest rating of Superior for front crash prevention for avoiding a collision in a 12-mph test, and for reducing the impact of a 25-mph collision by 11 mph thanks to the standard Intelligent Forward Collision Warning and Automatic Emergency Braking features. The SL trim adds blind-spot monitoring with rear cross-traffic alert and adaptive cruise control. The Platinum trim receives Moving Object Detection, an Intelligent Driver Alertness system, as well as front and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/maxima/2016/2016-nissan-maxima-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2016 Nissan Maxima, we liked the improved and retuned CVT and the quick acceleration. However, the Maxima’s back seats and trunk space aren’t as large as in some rivals. “Buyers who want more than the average midsize sedan can offer but know how quickly the MSRP adds up on German luxury sport sedans should definitely add the 2016 Nissan Maxima to their shopping list. As long as expectations are kept in check in terms of interior and cargo space, the Maxima is one of the better semi-premium midsize sedans around.”</p>

<p>After <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/maxima/2016/2016-nissan-maxima-sr-review-verdict/">one year with our long-term 2016 Nissan Maxima SR</a>, we liked the sedan’s performance, handling, and interior comfort, we said, “After nearly 30,000 miles, we decided the 2016 Nissan Maxima SR was a nice place to spend time. Although it may not compete against traditional sport sedans, it offers a dose of sport with a roomy interior for everyday use or a road-trip-with-room for two couples or a family with two teenaged children.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>In Sport mode, engine throttle response increases, the CVT shifts more aggressively under braking and holds simulated gears longer, the steering weight increases, and the Active Sound Enhancement feature increases in volume.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Entering its second generation, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> Leaf has been completely redesigned for the new model year, featuring a more powerful electric motor, a longer driving range, and more technology.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The Leaf is Nissan’s only EV and is positioned above the Versa sedan and Versa Note, the Sentra, and the Altima when comparing starting price.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Nissan Leaf’s electric powertrain consists of a 40 kWh battery pack that powers an electric motor that produces 147 hp and 236 lb-ft of torque and has a Nissan-claimed driving range of 150 miles. A one-speed transmission routes power to the front wheels. The hatchback’s battery pack can be fully recharged in just 40 minutes using a DC Fast Charging station or eight hours using a Level 2 charger (240-volt). If you are short on time, a one-hour charge on a Level 2 charger will give you 22 miles of range and half an hour on a DC Fast Charger will give you 88 miles of range. Expect a more powerful battery pack and electric motor for the next model year.</p>

<p>The base Leaf S comes standard with a 7.0-inch driver’s display screen, automatic temperature control, the Nissan Connect EV App, and the new e-Pedal, a one-pedal regenerative braking driving system. The mid-grade SV model gets 17-inch wheels, a Quick Charge Port, and a Nissan navigation system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. The range-topping SL features leather-appointed seats, Bose Energy Efficient Series premium audio system, a portable charge cable, and LED headlights with LED daytime running lights. The All Weather package includes heated outside mirrors, rear heating/cooling ducts, and heated front seats and steering wheel. Nissan’s new ProPilot Assist system is now available in the 2018 Leaf, see the Safety section for more information.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The S model comes standard with Automatic Emergency Braking with Pedestrian Detection, the SV adds Intelligent Cruise Control, and the SL adds Intelligent Around View Monitor camera system and blind spot warning. The remaining driver assist safety features include high-beam assist, rear cross traffic alert, Intelligent Lane Intervention, and ProPilot Assist. ProPilot Assist uses an adaptive cruise control system that atomically accelerates and brakes for the driver and will maintain the speed of the vehicle ahead, even to a complete stop, and will automatically accelerate once the vehicle ahead does. The system also uses a lane keeping system that helps the driver keep the Leaf in its lane.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/leaf/2018/2018-nissan-leaf-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2018 Nissan Leaf, we preferred the new design of the Leaf and the extra power and range from the electric powertrain. The ProPilot Assist system worked very well, “Yet what elevates it to the same conversation as AutoPilot is how accurately it also threads down the center of the road.”</p>

<p>The e-Pedal driving feature worked very well: “If that stop is on a hill, the Leaf’s motor will just hold it motionless (after pausing, you can lift your feet from both pedals; no need to hold the brake). The new Leaf could quickly become the most popular car in San Francisco.” However, we were not impressed with the 150-mile driving range due to the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/bolt-ev/2018/">Chevrolet Bolt EV</a>’s 238-mile range and the base <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-3/2018/">Tesla Model 3</a>’s 225-mile range. We said, “Maybe anticipating criticism, the Leaf will offer an even-better-chemistry 60-kW-hr pack next year (SL trim), likely extending its leash to about 225 miles (a two-tier strategy akin to the Model 3’s estimated 50 and 75 kW-hrs). Thus, the Bolt’s singular battery size will be bookended by its competitors, with the Nissan’s upgraded pack matching it and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/">Tesla</a>’s smaller pack offering Bolt-competitive range due to better sedan aerodynamics.” At the end of our drive, we were excited with the news of an <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/nissan-prepares-leaf-nismo-concept/">upcoming Leaf NISMO</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The more powerful battery pack in the new Leaf is the exact same size as the previous one thanks to a 67-percent increase in battery energy density versus the 2010 Leaf.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/nv/2018/">2018 Nissan NV</a> is unchanged for the 2018 model year.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/nv/2018/">Nissan NV</a> is a range of commercial vans that includes the NV1500, NV2500HD, NV3500 Passenger, and the NV3500HD.  In addition to the standard roof, the NV2500HD and NV3500HD are also available in high roof models.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two engines are available in the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> NV including a 4.0-liter V-6 with 261 hp and 281 lb-ft of torque coupled to a five-speed automatic transmission. The more powerful engine is a 5.6-liter V-8 with 375 hp and 387 lb-ft paired to a seven-speed automatic. The V-6 engine is standard on the NV1500 and NV2500HD but not available on the largest variant, the NV3500HD. As for the V-8 engine, it’s optional on the NV2500HD and standard on the NV3500HD.</p>

<p>Standard roof variants have 234.1 cubic feet of interior space and high roof models have 323.1 cubic feet of interior space. The 2018 NV can haul up to 3,860 pounds of payload and when equipped with a tow hitch receiver, it can tow up to 9,400 pounds. Passenger variants can accommodate up to 12 passengers and the seating configuration can be modified in 324 different ways.</p>

<p>The base S trim comes with 17-inch steel wheels, cloth upholstery, manually adjustable seats, and a two-speaker radio. Options include a rearview camera, cruise control, the NissanConnect infotainment system with a 5.8-inch touchscreen, navigation, Bluetooth connectivity, keyless entry, and a USB port. Passenger variants can be had with heated front seats, a power driver’s seat, and leather upholstery.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/four-things-learned-moving-2017-nissan-nv-3500-high-roof-sl-v8/">a review</a> of a 2017 Nissan NV3500HD van in SL trim, we remarked at how much improved the updated 375-hp version of the 5.6-liter V-8 felt compared to the outgoing 317-hp engine, and liked how smooth the seven-speed automatic performed. We said the step-in height to the cargo area was a bit high, though, and noted that the NV’s one wheelbase size should work for many buyers (but there’s no longer-wheelbase option).</p>

<p>As for the van’s ride, we noted in our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2012-nissan-nv-2500hd-long-term-verdict/">2012 Long Term Verdict</a> that when the NV2500HD is empty, it gets bouncy and only smooths out when it’s loaded. There’s also minimal sound insulation in cargo variants of the NV, making its interior extremely loud.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Nissan NV family shares its underpinnings with the first generation <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/titan/2018/">Nissan Titan</a> pickup and Armada SUV.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/718-boxster/2018/">2018 Porsche 718 Boxster</a> gets new cosmetic options including a high gloss black rear spoiler, new contrast stitching colors, new two-tone upholstery and colored seat belt options. A new cabin filter has also been added.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Formerly the entry-level model of <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/">Porsche</a>’s sports car lineup, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/718-boxster/2018/">Porsche 718 Boxster</a> is a mid-engine, rear-drive, two-seat convertible that’s closely related to the 718 Cayman. With the Cayman now taking the place of the Boxster as the 718 line’s base model, the Boxster is now more expensive.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two engines are available in the 2018 718 Boxster including a 2.0-liter turbo flat-four with 300 hp and 280 lb-ft of torque in the base model, or a 2.5-liter turbo flat-four with 350 hp and 309 lb-ft in the S model. Both engines can be paired to either a standard six-speed manual or an optional seven-speed twin-clutch automatic gearbox. EPA fuel economy ratings are 21/28 mpg city/highway for the manual and 22/29 mpg with the automatic when equipped with the base engine. The more powerful 2.5-liter is rated at 20/26 mpg with the manual and 21/28 mpg with the automatic. Because the 718 Boxster is a mid-engine sports car, it has cargo areas up front and in the back. The trunk can has a 4.4-cubic foot capacity and the front trunk, or “frunk,” is slightly larger at 5.3 cubic feet.</p>

<p>Standard features include 18-inch alloy wheels, partial leather upholstery, the PCM interface, a rearview camera, parking sensors, Bluetooth connectivity, and HID headlights. Options include alloy wheels up to 20 inches in diameter, leather upholstery, adaptive sport seats, heated and ventilated front seats, navigation, a premium audio system from Bose or Burmester, Porsche’s torque vectoring system, carbon ceramic brakes, a sport exhaust system, active suspension, a larger fuel tank, a heated multi-function steering wheel, LED headlights and dual-zone climate control. Like other Porsche models, the 2018 718 Boxster can be extensively customized with unique exterior colors, two-tone interior upholstery, contrast stitching, metal and wood trim, and seat belts of different colors.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Some safety features include lane change assist and adaptive cruise control with Porsche Active Safe, which bundles automatic emergency braking and forward collision warning.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/718-boxster/2017/2017-porsche-718-boxster-first-drive-review/">2017 First Drive</a>, we said that both new turbo engines offer excellent levels of power and both transmission are easy to operate. However, the six-speed manual’s active rev-matching function turns on in Sport and Sport+ mode and can’t be turned off. The 718′ Boxster’s handling remains excellent thanks to its light but direct steering and excellent chassis that makes it feel like an extension of the driver.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Like all Porsche models, the 718 Boxster can be ordered and picked up in Germany via Porsche’s European delivery program, which enables an owner to custom order the car and pick up the car in either Leipzig or Zuffenhausen. Additionally, U.S. customers can also pick up their Boxsters at the Porsche Experience center in Atlanta, Georgia.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/panamera/2018/">2018 Porsche Panamera</a> gets a new wagon body style called the Sport Turismo and a new range-topping variant known as the Panamera Turbo S E-Hybrid.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/panamera/2018/">Porsche Panamera</a> is available in hatchback or wagon body styles and in either rear- or all-wheel drive configurations. In addition to the standard gas-powered models’ there are two hybrid variants available, the Panamera 4 E-Hybrid and the Panamera Turbo S E-Hybrid. There’s also a long-wheelbase variant for the Panamera hatchback, which adds extra leg room and cargo capacity.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Panamera offers five powertrain options that are paired exclusively to a new eight-speed twin-clutch automatic transmission.</p>

<p>Model: <strong>Panamera, Panamera 4, Panamera 4 Sport Turismo, Panamera 4 Executive</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 3.0-liter turbo V-6 – eight-speed twin-clutch automatic<br>
Power: 330 hp/331 lb-ft of torque<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy:<br>
Panamera: 21/28 mpg city/highway<br>
Panamera 4: 21/27 mpg<br>
Panamera 4 Sport Turismo: Not Yet Rated<br>
Panamera 4 Executive: 21/27 mpg</br></br></br></br></br></br></br></p>

<p>Model: <strong>Panamera 4S, Panamera 4S Sport Turismo, Panamera 4S Executive</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 2.9-liter twin-turbo V-6 – eight-speed twin-clutch automatic<br>
Power: 440 hp/405 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy:<br>
Panamera 4S: 21/28 mpg<br>
Panamera 4S Sport Turismo: Not Yet Rated<br>
Panamera 4S Executive: 21/28 mpg</br></br></br></br></br></br></p>

<p>Model: <strong>Panamera 4 E-Hybrid, Panamera 4 E-Hybrid Sport Turismo, Panamera 4 E-Hybrid Executive</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 2.9-liter twin-turbo V-6 + electric motor – eight-speed twin-clutch automatic<br>
Power: 462 hp/516 lb-ft combined<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: Not Yet Rated</br></br></br></p>

<p>Model: <strong>Panamera Turbo, Panamera Turbo Sport Turismo, Panamera Turbo Executive</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 – eight-speed twin-clutch automatic<br>
Power: 550 hp/567 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy:<br>
Panamera Turbo 18/25 mpg<br>
Panamera Turbo Sport Turismo: Not Yet Rated<br>
Panamera Turbo Executive: 18/25 mpg</br></br></br></br></br></br></p>

<p>Model: <strong>Panamera Turbo S E-Hybrid, Panamera Turbo S E-Hybrid Executive</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 + electric motor – eight-speed twin-clutch automatic<br>
Power: 680 hp/ 626 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: Not Yet Rated</br></br></br></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/">Porsche</a> Panamera has 17.6 cubic feet of cargo space behind the split-folding rear seats and 47.3 cubic feet behind the front seats. Plug-in hybrid models have slightly less, at 14.3 cubic feet with the second row in place and 44 cubic feet with them down. The Panamera Executive has the most cargo space at 17.6 cubic feet wit the rear seats up and 52.6 cubic feet with them down; however, opting for the hybrid variants drops capacity down to 14.3 cubic feet and 49 cubic feet, respectively. The newest addition, the Panamera Sport Turismo offers 18.3 cubic feet with the second row in place and 49 cubic feet with them down. Hybrid variants also take a hit in cargo capacity to 16 cubic feet with the rear seats in place and 45 cubic feet with them down.</p>

<p>Standard equipment includes 19-inch alloy wheels, the PCM interface with navigation and a 12.3-inch touchscreen, a 10-speaker audio system, LED headlights, Bluetooth connectivity, Apple CarPlay integration, keyless drive, two-zone climate control, a rearview camera and heated front seats. Options include heated rear seats, ventilated and massaging front and rear seats, alloy wheels up to 21 inches in diameter, adaptive sport seats, soft close doors, premium audio systems from Bose or Burmester, a rear entertainment system, a 360-degree view camera system, rear-wheel steering, adaptive air suspension with active suspension management, carbon ceramic brakes, and a sport exhaust system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Porsche Panamera; however, it is available with active safety features such as lane change assist, lane keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, traffic jam assist, turn assist, night vision assist, and Porsche Active Safe, which combines forward collision warning and automatic emergency braking.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/panamera/2017/2017-porsche-panamera-first-drive-review/">2017 First Drive</a>, we noted that the Panamera 4S’ new twin-turbo V-6 engine and the Panamera Turbo’s new 4.0-liter twin-turbo V-8 are smooth and at home driving at high speeds. Put the Panamera in Sport+ mode and you get a more buttoned-down ride, excellent throttle response, and crisp handling accompanied by quick shifts from the twin-clutch automatic and crackling noises from the car’s exhaust. Even in Comfort mode, the Panamera stays planted at high speeds and never feels sloppy. The Panamera E-Hybrid, on the other hand, is a stealth hybrid, featuring only small hints at its electrified nature such as the acid green accents and brake calipers. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/panamera/2018/2018-porsche-panamera-hybrid-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive,</a> we noted that the same crisp driving dynamics remains on the electrified Panamera. However, since it has a dual-clutch transmission, there’s shunting at low speeds especially when the car is slowing down.</p>

<p>The more practical Panamera Sport Turismo retains the same strong acceleration as its hatchback siblings but with more practicality and seating for up to five. However, the center rear seat is best reserved for smaller passengers since it’s quite tight, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/panamera/2018/2018-porsche-panamera-sport-turismo-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive</a>. Despite the additional weight of the Panamera Turbo S E-Hybrid, its acceleration is explosive and feels right at home on the track despite it being such a large car. Out on the road, we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/panamera/2018/2018-porsche-panamera-turbo-s-e-hybrid-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive</a> that the Panamera Turbo S E-Hybrid is also an excellent cruiser and can travel in electric mode for a short time.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Porsche Panamera Sport Turismo first appeared as a concept back in 2012.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 911 gets three new variants including the GTS trims (for the Carrera, Cabriolet, and Targa models), plus the high performance GT2 RS and GT3 models.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/911/2018/">2018 Porsche 911</a> is the German automaker’s iconic rear-engine sports car that’s available in rear- or all-wheel drive configurations. In addition to the coupe, the 911 is also available as a convertible and as targa, which is essentially a power retractable roof section that stows away.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 911’s six engine choices are paired to a six- or seven-speed manual transmission or a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic.</p>

<p>Model: <strong>911 Carrera, 911 Carrera 4, 911 Carrera Cabriolet, 911 Carrera 4 Cabriolet, 911 Targa 4</strong><br>

<p>Standard features on the base 911 Carrera include 19-inch alloy wheels, the PCM interface with navigation and a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, Apple CarPlay integration, an eight-speaker audio system, a rearview camera, rear parking sensors, a 4.6-inch multi-information display, two-zone climate control, front sports seats, partial leather upholstery, and HID headlights. Options include premium audio systems from Bose or Burmester, leather upholstery, adaptive seats, LED headlights, a sport exhaust system, a GT sport steering wheel, alloy wheels up to 20 inches in diameter, heated and ventilated front seats, a front axle lift system, carbon-ceramic brakes, power steering plus, and an adaptive sport suspension. Cargo capacity is 5.1 cubic feet in the front trunk (sometimes known as a frunk) and 9.1 cubic feet behind the front seats when the rear seats are folded down.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>When equipped with the seven-speed dual-clutch automatic, the 911 can be had with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/">Porsche</a> Active Safe system that combines forward collision warning and automatic emergency braking. Lane change assist is a standalone option on the 911 lineup.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/corvette/2017/2017-chevrolet-corvette-grand-sport-vs-2017-porsche-911-carrera-s/">2016 comparison test</a> against the Corvette Grand Sport, the 911 Carrera S lost by a narrow margin mainly because it didn’t offer the same level of excitement as the Corvette until you go into its sportiest setting and drive it hard. However, in terms of refinement the 911 was superior thanks to its well-built cabin and more compliant ride. Even heavier variants of the 911 remain highly capable as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/911/2017/2017-porsche-911-targa-4s-first-test-review/">2017 911 Targa 4S First Test</a>. The car combines exceptional performance and handling with daily usability thanks to its excellent ride comfort even in poorly maintained surfaces. The 3.0-liter twin-turbo flat-six provides prodigious power for passing and accelerating on the highway. However, like all 911 models, its price can skyrocket with options.</p>

<p>The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/911/2018/2018-porsche-911-gts-review/">911 Carrera GTS</a> offers even more performance while retaining its daily usability. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/911/2017/2017-porsche-911-carrera-gts-first-drive/">2017 First Drive</a>, we said that all-wheel-drive-equipped models offer prodigious levels of grip more stability. The manual transmission, while slick and easy to use, can’t be rushed or you risk accidentally shifting to the wrong gear.</p>

<p>On the higher end of the 911 spectrum, the 911 Turbo S proves that you can have a seriously potent supercar that won’t beat you up on the daily grind thanks to the adjustable dampers, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/911/2017/2017-porsche-911-turbo-s-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>. Even the less powerful 911 Turbo (compared to the 911 Turbo S) offers explosive power and unflappable handling even with less body rigidity in convertible form. However, in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/911/2017/2017-porsche-911-turbo-cabriolet-first-test-ultimate-socal-car/">2017 First Test</a>, we noted that there’s way too many buttons for nearly every feature and function.</p>

<p>Those seeking the most track-focused 911 should look to the 911 GT3 and with a new six-speed manual option or a seven-speed dual-clutch transmission. We noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/911/2018/2018-porsche-911-gt3-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive</a> that the dual-clutch transmission is an excellent companion that responds quickly with snappy shifts in automatic and manual modes.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/macan/2018/">2018 Porsche Macan</a> gets a new cabin air filter and an updated instrument cluster display that shows cabin air circulation.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting below the midsize Cayenne, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/macan/2018/">Porsche Macan</a> is the brand’s entry-level compact luxury crossover and comes standard with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two engines are available in the 2018 Macan including a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 252 hp and 273 lb-ft of torque in the base model or a 3.6-liter twin-turbo V-6 in the S, GTS, and Turbo variants. The twin-turbo V-6 is rated at 340 hp and 339 lb-ft in the Macan S, 360 hp and 369 lb-ft in the Macan GTS, and 400 hp and 406 lb-ft in the Macan Turbo. With the optional Performance package, the Macan Turbo’s output rises to 440 hp and 442 lb-ft, and adds bigger brake pads, active suspension, the Sport Chrono package, and a Sport+ mode. The only transmission available on all Macan models is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/">Porsche</a>’s seven-speed twin-clutch automatic transmission.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings are 20/25 mpg city/highway for the base Macan and 17/23 mpg for all models equipped with the 3.6-liter twin-turbo V-6. There’s 17.7 cubic feet of cargo space behind the second row and it can be expanded to 53 cubic feet with them down. All variants of the Macan can tow up to 4,409 pounds of payload when properly equipped.</p>

<p>Standard features include 18-inch alloy wheels, the PCM multimedia interface, parking sensors, a rearview camera, Bluetooth connectivity, a 7.0-inch multi-information display, a power tailgate, HID headlights, power front seats, 40/20/40 split-folding rear seats, and tri-zone climate control. Options include navigation, alloy wheels up to 21 inches in diameter, leather upholstery, adaptive sport seats, heated and ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, a heated steering wheel, a premium audio system from Bose or Burmester, a rear entertainment system, active air suspension, Porsche’s torque vectoring system, a sport exhaust system, and carbon ceramic brakes on more powerful variants.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Porsche Macan. Lane change assist can be had as a standalone option or bundled with lane keep assist. Adaptive cruise control comes bundled together with Porsche Active Safe system, which combines forward collision warning and automatic emergency braking.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/macan/2015/2015-porsche-macan-s-turbo-first-test/">2015 First Test</a>, we said that the Macan drives as a Porsche should, offering strong acceleration and sure-footed handling when the road starts turning. Steering feel, however, could be improved with more feedback. When the pavement ends, the Macan is surprisingly capable; however, it’s no rock crawler and should be limited to light trails and not extreme rock crawling. Pricing — especially when equipped with desirable options — is a bit above some of its rivals.</p>

<p>The mid-level Macan GTS splits the difference between the Macan S and Turbo but also provides an even more driver-centric experience just like every GTS model. In terms of handling, the Macan GTS is superior to the other models in the lineup including the more powerful Macan Turbo thanks to its superior suspension setup. On the road, we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/macan/2017/2017-porsche-macan-gts-first-test/">2017 First Test</a> that the Macan GTS drives just like one would expect out of a Porsche, offering confident handling and quick acceleration with its twin-turbo V-6.</p>

<p>However, some issues caused the Macan GTS to place third in <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/f-pace/2017/jaguar-f-pace-s-mercedes-amg-glc43-porsche-macan-gts-comparison/">a recent comparison test</a> to the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>-AMG GLC43 and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jaguar/">Jaguar</a> F-Pace S, which was the winner. Its cabin, for instance is cramped and the seats give up too much comfort in the name of sporty driving, and it felt out of its element on the highway. Surprisingly the Macan GTS’ twin-clutch automatic isn’t as polished as it is on other Porsche vehicles, shifting harshly and sometimes interrupting power delivery. The twin-turbo V-6 also suffers from turbo lag and runs out of power the closer you get to its redline.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The base 2.0-liter turbo-four in the Porsche Macan is shared with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/audi/a4/2018/">Audi A4</a>, A5, A6, Q5, and Q7.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/cayenne/2018/">2018 Porsche Cayenne</a> gets a new cabin air filter and an updated instrument cluster that shows air circulation. A new Cayenne debuts <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/cayenne/2019/2019-porsche-cayenne-first-look-review/">for the 2019 model year</a> with an evolutionary exterior design and new powertrain options shared with the second-generation Panamera.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting above the smaller Macan, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/cayenne/2018/">Porsche Cayenne</a> is the brand’s midsize crossover that comes standard with all-wheel drive and is available in gas or plug-in hybrid variants.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/">Porsche</a> Cayenne is available with five different engine options that are all paired to an eight-speed automatic transmission. All variants of the Cayenne have a towing capacity of 7,716 pounds when properly equipped.</p>

<p>Model: <strong>Cayenne, Cayenne Platinum Edition</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 3.6-liter V-6 – eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 300 hp/295 lb-ft of torque<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy:<br>
Cayenne: 18/24 mpg city/highway<br>
Cayenne Platinum Edition: 17/23 mpg</br></br></br></br></br></p>

<p>Model: <strong>Cayenne S</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 3.6-liter twin-turbo V-6 – eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 420 hp/406 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 17/23 mpg</br></br></br></p>

<p>Model: <strong>Cayenne GTS</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 3.6-liter twin-turbo V-6 – eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 440 hp/442 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 16/23 mpg</br></br></br></p>

<p>Model: <strong>Cayenne Turbo, Cayenne Turbo S</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 4.8-liter twin-turbo V-8 – eight-speed automatic<br>
Power:<br>
Cayenne Turbo: 520 hp/553 lb-ft<br>
Cayenne Turbo S: 570 hp/590 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 14/21 mpg</br></br></br></br></br></p>

<p>Model: <strong>Cayenne S E-Hybrid, Cayenne S E-Hybrid Platinum Edition</strong><br>
Engine and Transmission: 3.0-liter supercharged V-6 + electric motor – eight-speed automatic<br>
Power: 416 hp/435 lb-ft<br>
EPA-Rated Fuel Economy: 22 mpg combined, 14 miles in EV mode</br></br></br></p>

<p>Behind the split-folding rear seats, the 2018 Cayenne has 23.6 cubic feet of cargo space and it can be expanded to 62.8 cubic feet, which is on the small side for a crossover its size. The Cayenne S E-Hybrid has slightly less capacity at 20.5 cubic feet behind the second row and 59.7 cubic feet behind the front seats due to the hybrid system’s extra components.</p>

<p>Standard features include 18-inch alloy wheels, HID headlights, eight-way power adjustable front seats, 40/20/40 split-folding rear seats, a power lift gate, Bluetooth connectivity, and the PCM multimedia system with navigation. Options include LED headlights, all0y wheels up to 21 inches in diameter, parking sensors, a rearview or 360-degree view camera system, a panoramic sunroof, soft close doors, heated and ventilated front and rear seats, a rear entertainment system, premium audio systems from Bose or Burmester, adaptive sport seats, an active air suspension system, Porsche’s torque vectoring system, dynamic chassis control, carbon ceramic brakes, power steering plus, and a sport exhaust system.</p>

<p>Like all Porsche models, the Cayenne can be customized with a full range of upholsteries and unique exterior colors. This includes two-tone interior schemes with unique contrast stitching, colored seatbelts, and interior trim ranging from wood and metal to carbon fiber.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Cayenne hasn’t been crash tested by the NHTSA and IIHS. Lane keep assist and lane change assist are bundled together as a single option. Adaptive cruise control is bundled together with Porsche Active Safe (PAS), a system that combines automatic emergency braking and forward collision warning. Lane departure warning is a standalone option.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/cayenne/2015/2015-porsche-cayenne-s-turbo-first-drive/">2015 First Drive</a>, we noted that the Cayenne S has a smooth engine with plenty of power on tap; however, those looking for the best straight line performance should immediately look to the Turbo models with their twin-turbo V-8s, both of which offer prodigious power that’s enough to push you back into your seat when you hit the gas. To go with its excellent on-road manners, the Cayenne is also right at home doing some off-road driving where it easily goes crawls over rocks and hills. However, the Cayenne is no rock crawler. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/x6/2015/x6-m-range-rover-sport-svr-gle63-s-coupe-cayenne-turbo-s/">2015 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>-AMG GLE63 Coupe, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/land-rover/range-rover/2018/">Land Rover Range Rover</a> Sport SVR, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/x6/2018/">BMW X6</a> M, the Porsche Cayenne Turbo S placed third due to excessive amounts of turbo lag, a clinical driving experience, and the fact that it felt dated compared to its rival.</p>

<p>The Cayenne S E-Hybrid proved that it’s still capable when the road starts to turn with its excellent handling despite the additional weight added by the hybrid powertrain’s extra components. However, as with most hybrids, the Cayenne S E-Hybrid’s steering is lackluster and not very communicative. The plug-in hybrid powertrain offers plenty of power and is right at home at high speeds, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/cayenne/2015/2015-porsche-cayenne-s-e-hybrid-first-drive/">2015 First Drive</a>. Interior quality is typical Porsche with soft touch, high-grade materials throughout the cabin.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Alongside the Panamera, the Cayenne is one of two Porsche models that’s available with a plug-in hybrid variant.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/718-cayman/2018/">2018 Porsche 718 Cayman</a> adds customization options that includes a gloss black rear spoiler, contrasting colored stitching and seat belts. There’s also a new cabin air filter.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary<br/></strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/718-cayman/2018/">Porsche 718 Cayman</a> is a mid-engine, rear-drive, two-seat coupe that’s less expensive than the rear-engined 911, and is a sister vehicle to the 718 Boxster.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 718 Cayman is powered by one of two turbocharged flat-four engines including a 2.0-liter with 300 hp and 280 lb-ft of torque in the base model or a 2.5-liter with 350 hp and 309 lb-ft in the Cayman S. Both engines can be paired to a standard six-speed manual or an optional seven-speed twin-clutch automatic transmission.</p>

<p>The EPA hasn’t given the 2018 718 Cayman its fuel economy ratings but its sister vehicle, the 718 Boxster is rated at 21/28 mpg city/highway with manual and 22/29 mpg with the automatic when powered by the base engine. Opting for the more powerful 2.5-liter unit drops those numbers down to 20/26 mpg with the manual and 21/28 mpg with the automatic. Since the 718 Cayman is a mid-engine vehicle, it has 5.3 cubic feet of cargo space in its frunk and 9.7 cubic feet in the rear hatch.</p>

<p>Standard features include partial leather upholstery, 18-inch alloy wheels, a rearview camera, the PCM interface, Bluetooth connectivity, parking sensors, and HID headlights. Options include navigation, adaptive sport seats, premium audio system from Bose or Burmester, alloy wheels up to 20 inches in diameter, leather upholstery, an active suspension system, carbon ceramic brakes, a torque vectoring system, a sport exhaust, a larger fuel tank, heated and ventilated front seats, a heated multi-function steering wheel, LED headlights and dual-zone climate control. Additionally, you can also customize the 718 Cayman with different interior treatments such as two-tone color schemes, contrasting seat belts and stitching, and metal or wood trim.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/">Porsche</a> 718 Cayman, which is available with lane change assist, adaptive cruise control and Porsche Active Safe, which bundles together forward collision and automatic emergency braking.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/porsche/718-cayman/2017/2017-porsche-718-cayman-first-drive-review/">2017 First Drive</a>, we said that with the smaller yet more powerful engine, the 718 Cayman drives as a Porsche should. The base 2.0-liter turbocharged engine features linear power delivery and doesn’t suffer from much turbo lag. However, its engine note isn’t as pleasing as the six-cylinder unit it replaced. The larger 2.5-liter flat-four has a wider power band and offers even more effortless acceleration. Handling, on the other hand, is excellent thanks to the improved steering system taken out of the 911 Turbo, improved chassis, and wider tires.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Before it received the 718 name, the Cayman was more expensive than the Boxster.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/promaster/2018/">2018 Ram ProMaster</a> gets the UConnect infotainment system with a 5.0-inch touchscreen and a rearview camera now comes standard. Bluetooth and steering wheel audio controls are now standard on all ProMaster models.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/promaster/2018/">Ram ProMaster</a> is a large commercial van that slots above the smaller ProMaster City. There are no trim levels available but the van can be had in either low or high roof variants and with three wheelbase lengths.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/">Ram</a> ProMaster Cargo Van:</strong> The ProMaster cargo van comes standard<strong> </strong>four-way manual seats, a UConnect infotainment system with a 5.0-inch touchscreen, a USB port, Bluetooth connectivity, keyless entry, 16-inch steel wheels, and a rearview camera.</p>

<p>Notable options include remote start, parking sensors, navigation, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, 16-inch aluminum wheels, side windows, and power adjustable side mirrors.</p>

<p>The 2018 Ram ProMaster comes with two engine choices, a 3.6-liter V-6 with 280 hp and 260 lb-ft of torque or a 3.0-liter turbodiesel I-4 rated at 174 hp and 295 lb-ft. A six-speed automatic is the only transmission available with the 3.6-liter V-6 while the diesel comes with a six-speed automated manual.</p>

<p>The smaller ProMaster 1500 short-wheelbase model has 259 cubic feet of cargo volume. Moving up to the medium-wheelbase model increases cargo volume to 304 cubic feet for low-roof variants and 353 cubic feet for high-roof variants. On the larger ProMaster 2500, the high-roof medium-wheelbase model has 353 cubic feet of cargo volume and the long-wheelbase model comes in at 420 cubic feet. The largest model, the 3500 cargo and window vans have 420 cubic feet of cargo volume because they’re available exclusively with the long wheelbase. Should you need more space, the extended high-roof ProMaster 3500 cargo van has 463 cubic feet of cargo volume.</p>

<p>When it comes to hauling payload, the 1500 can carry up to 3,990 pounds provided you choose the gas-powered short-wheelbase ProMaster cargo van with the low roof. The most capable ProMaster 2500 is the medium-wheelbase low-roof model, which can haul 4,740 pounds of payload. For the ProMaster 3500, the V-6-powered model is the most capable with a max payload of 5,2oo pounds.</p>

<p>When properly equipped with a trailer, all variants of the 2018 Ram ProMaster can tow up to 5,100 pounds of payload.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/promaster/2014/2014-ram-promaster-first-drive/">2014 First Drive review</a>, we said that with the 3.6-liter V-6, the ProMaster accelerated easily and didn’t get excessively noisy. Ride comfort was good when the van was empty but improved when it had a payload. We also liked the ProMaster’s low load height, making it easy to put cargo into the van. The driving position, however, is awkward and lacks adjustments, making it hard to get comfortable. Its touchscreen is also small and can be distracting to use when driving.</p>

<p>The Ram ProMaster is called the Fiat Ducato in Europe.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/">Ram</a> updates its 1500 model with a new range-topping and luxurious Limited Tungsten edition, a Sport appearance upgrade, available leather interior on the Rebel model, and an 8.4-inch multimedia interface that features 4G LTE, HD Radio, Android Auto, Apple CarPlay, pinch and zoom functions, and improved resolution. Also new is Sirius Guardian with SOS Call, Roadside Assistance, Remote Services, Send and Go, and Vehicle Finder. A standard rearview camera, an LED bed light switch now located in the bed, and a Fleet Telematics Module for vehicle tracking are additional new features.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The 1500 is Ram’s entry-level pickup truck, positioned below the larger and more expensive 2500 and 3500 series trucks.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/1500/2018/">Ram 1500</a>’s base engine is a 3.6-liter V-6 that produces 305 hp and 269 lb-ft and delivers an EPA-rated 17/25 mpg city/highway with rear-wheel drive and 16/23 mpg when equipped with four-wheel drive. The torquey and efficient 3.0-liter turbodiesel V-6 pumps out 240 hp and a healthy 420 lb-ft of torque and is rated at 20/27 mpg with rear-wheel drive and 19/27 mpg with four-wheel drive. The top 5.7-liter Hemi V-8 churns out 395 hp and 410 lb-ft of torque and comes rated at 15/22 mpg with rear-wheel drive and 15/21 mpg with four-wheel drive (13/19 mpg with the six-speed automatic). Besides the sole six-speed automatic, all engines come standard with an eight-speed automatic. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/1500/2018/">2018 Ram 1500</a> is available in a regular cab with an 8-foot or 6-foot-4-inch bed, a quad cab with a 6-foot-4-inch bed, or a crew cab with a 5-foot-7-inch bed or a 6-foot-4-inch bed. The Ram 1500 can tow up to 10,620 pounds when properly equipped.</p>

<p>Standard features for the base Tradesman include a spray-in bed liner, 17-inch wheels, a full-size spare, a 3.5-inch instrument cluster driver’s display, vinyl upholstery, a rear backlight, a Class IV trailer hitch, a USB port, and Radio 3.0 user interface. At the top of the range, the Limited crew cab includes active-level four-corner air suspension, an LED bed lighting system, chrome bodyside moldings, dual rear exhaust, fog lights, chrome grille with large R-A-M logo, halogen projector headlights with LED running lights, heated and power-folding side view mirrors, 20-inch aluminum wheels, dual-zone automatic climate control, a 7.0-inch instrument cluster driver’s display, power-adjustable pedals, heated and ventilated 10-way power (six-way for passenger) premium leather front seats, heated and leather-wrapped steering wheel, power sliding rear window, Uconnect 4C with an 8.4-inch center display and navigation, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and a Premium II 10-speaker audio system.</p>

<p>For the ultimate in luxury, opt for the Limited Tungsten package that includes a Frost/Indigo leather interior, body-color door handles, a sport performance hood, Platinum Chrome bodyside moldings and badges, body-color R-A-M tailgate lettering, black bezel Sport projector headlights, Sport LED taillights, Platinum Chrome R-A-M logo grille, and 20-inch Satin Carbon painted aluminum wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>All 2018 Ram 1500 models (crew, quad, regular, 2WD, 4WD) received a four-star overall NHTSA rating (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the Ram 1500 received the second lowest score for the small overlap front and roof strength crash teat evaluations but received the highest score of Good in the moderate overlap front and head restraints and seats evaluations. The front crash prevention evaluation was not conducted because the Ram 1500 does not offer a collision warning or emergency automatic braking system. Safety features include the standard rearview camera system and available front and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/1500/2014/comparison-2015-ford-f-150-vs-ram-1500-chevrolet-silverado/">three-way pickup truck comparison conducted late in 2014</a>, the Ram 1500 EcoDiesel topped the (last-generation) <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-150/2018/">Ford F-150</a> 4×4 and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevrolet</a> Silverado Z71, we said, “Forget ‘jack-of-all-trades.’ This truck masters every one of them.” “With the Ram 1500 EcoDiesel, you get a truck that’s quick when you want it to be, efficient most all of the time, always comfortable loaded or unloaded, luxurious, and always ready to work. It’s amazing how capable this truck is — the more time I spend with it, the more I’m reminded why it’s our first-ever back-to-back truck of the year winner.”</p>

<p>The 2014 Ram 1500 (same model) won the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2014-ram-1500-is-motor-trend-2014-truck-of-the-year/">2014 <em>Motor Trend</em> Truck of the Year</a> award, “We’ve been awarding Truck of the Year since 1979 and have never given the award to the same truck two years in a row. The Ram 1500 makes history as the first back-to-back Truck of the Year winner because it offers all the things truck buyers want in a rig: choice, value, great design, and more than enough power and torque. And with the EcoDiesel, you can add efficiency and guts to that list. Ram has made a game-changing decision by bringing diesel to the full-size market. It’s a bold move truck lovers have been begging for, which is why the Ram 1500 is our 2014 Truck of the Year.”</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>A new range-topping, luxurious Limited Tungsten edition and a new Sport appearance package have been added to the lineup on the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/2500/2018/">2018 Ram 2500</a>. The Uconnect 8.4 infotainment system now includes 4G LTE, HD Radio, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay, pinch and zoom functions, and improved resolution. An exterior LED bed light switch is now located in the bed and a rearview camera is now standard on all models. A Fleet Telematics Module (vehicle tracking) and Sirius Guardian with SOS Assist, Remote Services, Send and Go, and Vehicle Finder are now available.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The 2500 Heavy Duty slots right in the middle of <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/">Ram</a>’s truck lineup, above the 1500 but below the more expensive and powerful 3500 HD model.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The base 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/2500/2018/">Ram 2500</a> is powered by a 5.7-liter V-8 that produces 383 hp and 400 lb-ft of torque. The available 6.4-liter V-8 cranks out 410 hp and 429 lb-ft of torque. Both engines are backed by a six-speed automatic. The range-topping 6.7-liter Cummins turbodiesel I-6 engine is rated at 350 hp and 660 lb-ft of torque with the six-speed manual transmission but gets an increase with the six-speed automatic transmission to 370 hp and 800 lb-ft of torque. All models are available with rear- or four-wheel drive. The 2500 HD is available in a few configurations that include a regular cab with a long bed, Crew Cab with a short or long bed, and the Mega Cab with a short bed.</p>

<p>The 2018 Ram 2500 comes standard with a Class V hitch receiver, four- and seven-pin trailer harness, automatic headlights, a 3.5-inch driver’s cluster display, vinyl upholstery and floor covering, an auto-dimming rearview camera, 3.0 radio system, 17-inch wheels, and a full-size spare tire.
