The mid-level Laramie model adds chrome bumpers, fog lights, a chrome surround grille with chrome inserts, chrome projector headlights with LED taillights, heated and power-folding chrome side view mirrors with puddle lights, body-color wheel flares, dual-zone automatic climate control, a 7.0-inch driver’s display cluster display, leather-trimmed seats, heated and ventilated 10-way driver’s seat (six-way for front passenger), heated and leather-wrapped steering wheel, Uconnect 4C with an 8.4-inch display with a 2.5-amp USB charging port, a Premium II audio system, and 18-inch polished aluminum wheels. The Limited model adds Premium Natura leather, premium full-length floor console, and heated second-row seats. For the ultimate in Ram luxury, opt for the Limited Tungsten package that consists of a suede headliner, power-folding Platinum mirrors, a Limited tailgate applique, bodyside moldings, body color R-A-M tailgate lettering, a unique Ram grille, and 20-inch aluminum wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Ram 2500 received a four-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars) for rear- and four-wheel-drive models. Standard features include an electronic trailer brake controller (except on base Tradesman model), backup camera, and a tire-pressure monitoring system. Front/rear parking sensors and a cargo-view camera are optional.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/ram-2500-3500-hd-2017-truck-of-the-year-contender/">2017 Motor Trend Truck of the Year Testing</a>, the Ram 2500 and 3500 lost to the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> Super Duty. We loved the power from the Cummins turbodiesel but felt the 3500 had a terrible ride and drivetrain lash, “I felt bumps and other vibrations like no other truck here on parts of the drive loop that I didn’t feel anything in any other truck.” The off-road package equipped 2500 actually had a much better ride. We felt the Ford Super Duty beat the Ram Heavy Duty model in just about every category except looks, “The heavy-duty Rams’ biggest problem, however, is that everything it can do, both Ford Super Duties can do better. Towing, hauling, phone connectivity, mirror coverage, interior features and fabrics—you name it, the burly Ford has the Ram beat. Except for one thing: looks.” “Even if the bull’s-nostrils grille isn’t your thing, you have to admire the big Ram’s Kardashianesque hips.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/2500/2017/chevrolet-colorado-zr2-vs-ford-f-150-raptor-vs-ram-2500-power-wagon/">three-wayoff-road truck comparison</a>, the Ram 2500 Power Wagon topped the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/colorado/2018/">Chevrolet Colorado</a> ZR2 and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/f-150/2018/">Ford F-150</a> Raptor. We concluded, “During the worst of [our long off-road journey], when the Colorado was skipping over bumps and the Raptor was sliding sideways, the Ram tracked straight and true. The Power Wagon’s Bilstein monotube shocks aren’t as fancy as the Raptor’s Fox shocks or ZR2’s Multimatic dampers, but you can’t tell from behind the wheel. The ride is slightly stiffer, mostly because of its size and higher payload capacity, but it’s never punishing. The Power Wagon always grips no matter what stands in its path. Focus on your line. The Ram has everything else handled. It’s the right truck for the terrain we encountered on the entirety of the Trans-Labrador Highway.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The special off-road gear for the Power Wagon includes front and rear locking differentials, a 4.10 axle ratio, tow hooks, fuel tank and transfer case skid plates, <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/how-to-use-the-2017-ram-2500-power-wagon-electric-winch/">a front electronic winch</a>, electronic disconnecting front anti-roll bar, Ram Articulink front suspension, and 17-inch polished aluminum wheels shod in 285/70RD OWL all-terrain tires.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/3500/2018/">2018 Ram 3500</a> gains a standard rearview camera, an exterior switch in the bed for the LED bed lights, a Fleet Telematics Module (vehicle tracking), a Sport appearance upgrade, and the luxurious Limited Tungsten edition. The 3500 lineup also receives Sirius Guardian that includes SOS Assist, Remote Services, Send and Go, and Vehicle Finder. Additionally, the Uconnect system with the 8.4-inch display includes 4G LTE, HD Radio, Android Auto, Apple CarPlay, pinch and zoom functions and improved resolution.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/3500/2018/">Ram 3500</a> Heavy Duty is the automaker’s most powerful and expensive pickup truck. The 3500 slots above the 2500 and 1500 models.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/">Ram</a> 3500 packs a 383-hp, 400-lb-ft of torque 5.7-liter V-8 or the available 6.4-liter V-8 that produces 410 hp (370 hp with the Mega Cab) and 429 lb-ft of torque, both engines are backed by a six-speed automatic transmission. For the most hauling and towing power, opt for the 6.7-liter Cummins turbodiesel I-6 that produces 350 hp and 660 lb-ft of torque with the six-speed manual transmission, 370 hp and 800 lb-ft with the lighter duty six-speed automatic, and 385 hp and a whopping 930 lb-ft of torque with the heavy duty six-speed automatic transmission. All powertrains are available with four-wheel drive and with dual-rear wheels (DRW). The regular cab can be had only the long bed, the Crew Cab can be equipped with the short or long bed, and the Mega Cab can only be paired with the short bed. The 3500 HD can also be ordered as a chassis cab (bed removed) for commercial use starting with a 60-inch cab-to-axle length. A diesel-powered 2016 Ram 3500 HD Limited hit 60 mph in 8.6 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 134 feet during <em>Motor Trend</em> testing.</p>

<p>For those needing to tow and haul heavy loads, opt for the Dual Rear Wheels package (it also includes clearance lamps for the cab, box, and fenders) and the fifth-wheel/gooseneck towing prep package that includes an in-bed seven-pin harness connector and mounting points for the fifth wheel or gooseneck hitches. The DOT-certified Roadside Safety Kit includes a DOT fire extinguisher, three reflecting triangles, two red vinyl flags, and spare fuses. The off-road-ready Power Wagon includes front and rear locking differentials, a 4.10 axle ratio, tow hooks, skid plates, a front electric winch, an electronic disconnecting front sway bar, Ram Articulink front suspension, and 17-inch wheels wrapped in 285/70RD OWL all-terrain tires. The new Sport Appearance package includes monotone paint, body-colored door handles, black and body-colored exterior mirrors, blacked-out headlights and taillights, body-colored painted front and rear bumpers, body-colored grille with R-A-M logo, body-colored wheel flares, and 20-inch aluminum wheels with OWL (outside white lettering) tires.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The Ram 3500 HD is available with a cargo-view camera as well as front and rear parking sensors. Standard safety features include an electronic trailer brake controller, rearview camera, and a tire pressure monitoring system.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2014-ram-3500-hd-laramie-longhorn-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 Ram 3500 HD Cummins turbodiesel, we felt the best part of the truck was the insane torque and how easy the truck is to drive, however, we did not like the rough ride and felt the brakes could be stronger and the steering more responsive.</p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/ram-2500-3500-hd-2017-truck-of-the-year-contender/">2017 Truck of the Year testing</a>, the Ram did not win but we loved the 3500 HD’s exterior design and serious power but felt the truck had a horrible ride and was outperformed by the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a> Super Duty series in all categories. “The heavy-duty Rams’ biggest problem, however, is that everything it can do, both Ford Super Duties can do better. Towing, hauling, phone connectivity, mirror coverage, interior features and fabrics—you name it, the burly Ford has the Ram beat. Except for one thing: looks.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Cummins 6.7-liter turbodiesel inline-six engine is the only six-cylinder in the segment and uses a whopping 12 quarts of engine oil and 23.8 quarts of coolant. For comparison, the gas-powered 6.4-liter V-8 uses 7.0 quarts of oil and 16.6 quarts of coolant.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Uconnect 3 radio with a 5.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, and a rearview camera are now standard features for the new model year. Sliding and back door window grates are now available in Cargo Vans without partition.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The ProMaster City is one of two commercial vans offered by <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/">Ram</a>, slotting below the larger and more expensive <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/promaster/2018/">Ram ProMaster</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>Powering the front-drive 2018 ProMaster City is a 178-hp, 174 lb-ft of torque 2.4-liter I-4 engine backed by a nine-speed automatic. EPA-rated fuel economy comes in at 21/28 mpg city/highway. In the cargo van configuration, the ProMaster City can tow up to 2,000 pounds and the passenger wagon model can tow up to 1,914 pounds. Payload capacity for the cargo van is 1,886 pounds and 1,760 pounds for the passenger wagon. The van offers up to 131.7 cubic feet of cargo capacity in the cargo van model and 101.7 cubic feet for the passenger wagon. The cargo van can accommodate two passengers and the wagon offers seating for five.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/promaster/2018/">2018 Ram ProMaster</a> City comes standard with the previously mentioned Uconnect 3 radio with a 5.0-inch touchscreen and Bluetooth connectivity. Available features include sliding side doors with fixed or vented glass, roof rack with cross bars, heated front seats with vinyl upholstery, a Mopar Web Wi-Fi hotspot and a six-speaker audio system. There is also an available Cargo Partition package and a Trailer Tow group that consists of a Class III hitch receiver and four- and seven-pin harness.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>Safety features for the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/promaster-city/2018/">2018 Ram ProMaster City</a> include the standard front, knee, side, and curtain airbags; a rearview camera; and a tire pressure monitoring system. rear parking sensors and a DOT-certified roadside safety kit are available.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/promaster-city/2015/2015-ram-promaster-city-first-drive/">First Drive review</a> of the 2015 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/promaster-city/2018/">Ram ProMaster City</a>, we liked the quick off the line acceleration thanks to the short first gear and the smooth shifting nine-speed automatic. The engine provides plenty of power, even with cargo, but at idle the van does vibrate a lot. The City provides good fuel economy for the segment and a good ride when loaded thanks to its fully independent suspension and plenty of storage cubbies. The van also handles well around town but has a strange driving position (flat steering wheel and far away pedals).</p>

<p>“It gets the stamp of approval of this former delivery driver. It’s easy to load and unload, it’s the right size for most small businesses, it gets good fuel economy, it fits nicely through small alleys and tight parking lots, and it’s even a bit of fun to drive. If you’re going to drive a van all day, you can do much worse than this one, and you’d be hard-pressed to do better.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Ram ProMaster City van is built in Bursa, Turkey at the joint venture TOFAS plant and is then upfitted into its final form at the FCA US Transformation Center in Baltimore, MD.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p>The Smart Fortwo coupe and convertible are now all-electric vehicles; the gasoline engine is no longer available.</p>

<p>The Fortwo Electric Drive is a small two-seat urban electric vehicle and the only model offered by Smart in North America.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Smart Fortwo Pure</strong>: The base Pure trim comes equipped with 15-inch steel wheels, dashboard-mounted power and charge meter gauges, LED daytime running lights, a rearview camera, a 3.5-inch instrument cluster display, black fabric upholstery, an audio system with Bluetooth audio streaming and calling, automatic climate control, a flat-folding passenger seat, a tailgate storage compartment, hill-start assist, and rear fog lights. The Fortwo cabrio’s top can open or close in 12 seconds and comes in four different colors.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Smart Fortwo Passion</strong>: Moving up to the Passion trim adds your choice of seven interior colors (versus just black), four different grille color options (versus just black), two two-tone upholstery color combinations, powered and heated side view mirrors, 15-inch alloy wheels, center console with pullout storage, a retractable cargo cover, and three cupholders (versus one).</p>

<p><strong>2018 Smart Fortwo Prime</strong>: The top Prime trim adds steering-responsive fog lights, heated seats, black leather upholstery with white stitching, a panoramic sunroof, LED taillights, ambient lighting, a rain-sensing windshield, automatic headlights, and upgraded LED daytime running lights.</p>

<p>Optional features include a smartphone cradle, a JBL audio system, a heated steering wheel, and an armrest. The Sport package includes 16-inch black alloy wheels, a leather-wrapped sport steering wheel, and brushed stainless steel pedals. For additional tech, opt for the Smart Media System, which includes a 7.0-inch touchscreen with navigation and live traffic, ECO driving statistics, rear parking sensors, and Android Auto connectivity.</p>

<p>The rear-drive Smart Fortwo Electric Drive is powered by a rear-mounted 80-hp, 118-lb-ft of torque electric motor backed by a one-speed transmission. The 17.6 kWh battery pack powers the motor for up to an EPA-rated 58 miles (108 combined mpg-e) for the coupe and 57 miles (102 mpg-e) for the cabrio. Smart claims that the battery pack can be fully charged in 3 hours using a 240-volt (level 2) charger and up to 16.5 hours using a standard 120-volt (level 1) charger.</p>

<p>The 2017 Smart Fortwo coupe (gasoline) received a four-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA. In IIHS testing, the 2017 Fortwo (gasoline) received the highest rating of Good in the moderate overlap front and side crash tests (the three additional crash tests were not conducted). Smart does not offer automatic emergency braking and the car received the lowest rating of Basic for the front crash prevention evaluation by warning the driver of a possible collision. Standard safety feature include hill-start and crosswind assist. Automatic headlights and steering-responsive fog lights are optional.</p>

<p>The two-seat 2018 Smart Fortwo can hold up to 8.7-8.9 cubic feet of cargo (the passenger seat can fold flat if additional room is needed). The Fiat 500, which seats four, offers 9.5 cubic feet with the rear seats up.</p>

<p>The Fortwo comes standard with an audio system with Bluetooth streaming audio and calling and the instrument cluster features a 3.5-inch display. The Fortwo also offers a multimedia system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen with navigation, live traffic, and Android Auto connectivity. The base audio system can be upgraded to a JBL audio system or to a higher-performance 240-watt, eight-speaker JBL audio system that can only be ordered with the 7.0-inch infotainment screen.</p>

<p>During <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/smart-fortwo-electric-drive-2018-car-of-the-year-contender/">2018 Motor Trend Car of the Year</a> testing, we liked the 2018 Fortwo Electric Drive for its fun handling dynamics and small size for the city, but felt the car was uncompetitive as a result of its very short driving range (57-58 miles) and its lack of comfort. “The car gets very upset on rough surfaces,” we said. “Imperfections that are minor bumps to other cars feel very threatening when encountered in the Smart.”</p>

<p>“Value is simply not there,” we said. “It’s priced high at $24,550-$29,230, especially relative to the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> Leaf.” We concluded by saying, “There’s simply no reason to own one in the U.S.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/smart/fortwo/2017/2017-smart-fortwo-electric-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2017 Smart Fortwo Electric Drive, we weren’t sure who would buy the Smart Electric Drive when the larger <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/chevrolet-bolt-ev-2017-car-of-the-year/">Bolt EV</a> and its much longer range is available for not much more. “And unless you’re one of the few people in the U.S. who absolutely, positively needs an electric vehicle no more than 106.1 inches long, chances are you’re going to want the electric car that takes you a lot farther for the money, and is roomier and more fun to drive,” we said. “In other words, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/">Chevy</a> Bolt.” However, the electric Smart wasn’t all that bad: “It’s smoother, quicker, and quieter than its internal combustion engine powered siblings, thanks to the [electric motor] that delivers 118 lb-ft of torque the moment you squeeze the accelerator pedal.”</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>After a full redesign for the 2017 model year, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/impreza/2018/">2018 Subaru Impreza</a> gets automatic headlight activation, which turns on the headlights when the windshield wipers are activated.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/impreza/2018/">Subaru Impreza</a> is an all-wheel drive compact car that slots below the midsize Legacy. Sedan and hatchback body styles are available.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/">Subaru</a> Impreza is powered by a 2.0-liter flat-four rated at 152 hp and 145 lb-ft of torque. A five-speed manual transmission is standard on the base and Sport models, and a CVT is optional (Premium and Limited trims come only with the CVT). Trunk space on the sedan is 12.3 cubic and can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats. The hatchback offers more space at 20.8 cubic feet behind the split-folding rear seats and 55.3 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings vary depending on the model. With the manual, the sedan is rated at 24/32 mpg city/highway while the hatchback is rated at 24/31 mpg. Opt for the CVT and that jumps to 28/38 mpg for the sedan and 28/37 mpg for the hatchback. The Sport trim is the least efficient, with manual-equipped models rated at 22/31 mpg for the sedan and 23/30 mpg for the hatchback. CVT-equipped Sport models are rated at 27/36 mpg for the sedan and 27/35 mpg for the hatchback.</p>

<p>The base Impreza comes standard with 16-inch steel wheels, cloth upholstery, Bluetooth connectivity, Subaru’s Starlink infotainment system with a 6.5-inch touchscreen, a USB port, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, and a rearview camera. Higher trims can be had with automatic climate control, navigation, a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, a Harman Kardon premium audio system, keyless entry/start, leather upholstery, fog lights, adaptive full LED headlights, alloy wheels ranging from 16 to 18 inches in diameter and heated front seats. The Impreza Sport features a sport-tuned suspension and Active Torque Vectoring.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Impreza received a five-star rating on the side impact and rollover test from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS hasn’t crash tested a 2018 Impreza yet but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests and the new headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front collision prevention test, the Impreza received a Superior rating after it avoided collisions in 12- and 25-mph tests (Superior is the highest possible rating in the front collision prevention test). As a result, the IIHS awarded the Impreza the 2017 Top Safety Pick+ award.</p>

<p>Subaru’s EyeSight suite is available on all but the base trim of the 2018 Impreza. It bundles adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, as well as lane departure and sway warning. Blind spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert are bundled together with EyeSight and automatic high beams or fog lights that turn into corners.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/impreza/2017/2017-subaru-impreza-first-drive-review/">2017 First Drive</a>, we said that the Impreza feels solid thanks to its new platform and improved steering, which makes it feel more responsive. The interior has high-quality materials with plenty of soft touch bits. Subaru’s newest infotainment system is easy to use and easily integrates with your smartphone via Apple CarPlay or Android Auto. There’s also minimal exterior noise entering the cabin while passenger and cargo space is generous all around. However, we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/impreza/2017/2017-subaru-impreza-sedan-hatchback-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, that the 2.0-liter flat-four is underpowered. Throttle tip-in is touchy and can get jerky when accelerating from a stop. Ride comfort, on the other hand, is smooth even on poor surfaces except in the Sport trim with its 18-inch alloy wheels and sport-tuned suspension, which can get rough and unsettled. Handling is respectable on all models but the Sport trim doesn’t really make any noticeable improvements over the base, Premium, and Limited models.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/wrx/2018/">2018 Subaru WRX</a> receives a revised front fascia, an upgraded suspension, a new Performance package, a larger multi-information display, updated EyeSight safety suite, and available Recaro seats. The higher-performance WRX STI comes standard with new 19-inch wheels, Brembo brakes, and a revised all-wheel-drive system.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/wrx/2018/">Subaru WRX</a> is a sports sedan that’s well-regarded for its rally heritage and all-wheel-drive performance capabilities.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 WRX is powered by a 2.0-liter turbo-four with 268 hp and 258 lb-ft of torque; the quicker WRX STI model gets a 2.5-liter turbo-four with 305 hp and 290 lb-ft. A six-speed manual is standard on the WRX and a CVT is optional. The WRX STI comes exclusively with a six-speed manual gearbox. EPA fuel economy ratings for the 2018 WRX stand at 21/27 mpg city/highway for the manual or 18/24 mpg with the CVT. The more powerful WRX STI has yet to be rated but the 2017 model returned 17/23 mpg. Trunk space stands at 12 cubic feet and it can be expanded with the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>Standard features include a new 5.9-inch instrument cluster display, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/">Subaru</a>’s Starlink infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, 17-inch alloy wheels, Bluetooth connectivity, cloth upholstery, front sport seats, and a rearview camera. Options include navigation, a Harman Kardon audio system, adaptive LED headlights, dual-zone climate control, power-operated front sport seats, leather upholstery, a sunroof, fog lights, and 18-inch alloy wheels. The new Performance package for the WRX adds Recaro seats, Jurid brake pads, red brake calipers and deletes the sunroof.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Subaru WRX hasn’t been crash tested but the 2017 model received a Top Safety Pick rating from the IIHS, earning a Good score on all but the headlights test where it received a Marginal rating (Good is the highest possible score). In the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the WRX received a Superior rating when it avoided a 12- and 25-mph collision. Subaru’s EyeSight safety suite features adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, lane keeping assist and sway warning, and lane departure warning. However, the technology is only available on the range-topping Limited trim.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/wrx/2015/2015-subaru-wrx-first-test/">2015 First Test</a>, we said that despite being slower than previous-generation model, the current WRX offers better road holding capabilities, giving it superior handling. The active torque vectoring control system keeps body roll and understeer in check. However, with the more rigid chassis, the car rides rougher and stiffer than before. The more powerful WRX STI lost a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/golf/2015/2015-subaru-wrx-sti-vs-2015-volkswagen-golf-r/">2015 comparison test</a> against the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/golf/2018/">Volkswagen Golf</a> R because of its rough ride that made it too bouncy. Turbo lag is also prominent in the WRX STI and it lacks the refinement of the Golf R despite having similar performance capabilities.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The WRX’s 2.0-liter turbo-four first appeared in the Forester XT.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The refreshed <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/outback/2018/">2018 Subaru Outback</a> gets a revised exterior design, a retuned suspension for a smoother ride, an updated multimedia system, and available adaptive full LED headlights.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/outback/2018/">Subaru Outback</a> is a midsize crossover-like wagon that slots above the slightly smaller Forester and comes standard with all-wheel drive on all trim levels.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/">Subaru</a> Outback can be had with a 2.5-liter flat-four that produces 175 hp and 174 lb-ft of torque, or a 3.6-liter flat-six with 256 hp and 247 lb-ft. A CVT is the only transmission available on all trims. EPA fuel economy ratings are 25/32 mpg city/highway for the four-cylinder and 20/27 mpg with the six-cylinder.</p>

<p>Cargo space is generous at 35.5 cubic feet with the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats in place and 73.3 cubic feet with them folded. When properly equipped, the 2018 Outback can tow up to 2,700 pounds regardless of the engine choice.</p>

<p>Standard equipment on the base Outback include 17-inch alloy wheels, cloth upholstery, Bluetooth connectivity, Subaru’s Starlink multimedia system with a 6.5-inch touchscreen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a four-speaker audio system, and a rearview camera. Higher trims can be optioned with navigation, a Harman Kardon premium audio system, a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, dual-zone climate control, up to four USB ports, heated front and rear seats, keyless entry/start, leather upholstery, a heated steering wheel, power-adjustable front seats, a moonroof, and adaptive full LED headlights.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Subaru Outback a five-star side impact rating and a four-star rollover score (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 Outback received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests and Acceptable on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the 2018 Outback received a Superior rating after it avoided collisions in 12- and 25-mph tests (Superior is the highest possible score in the front crash prevention test). As a result, the 2018 Subaru Outback received the IIHS’ 2017 Top Safety Pick+ award.</p>

<p>Subaru’s EyeSight safety suite is available on the Premium trim and higher. The safety features included are forward collision warning, automatic front and rear emergency braking, adaptive cruise control, lane departure and sway warning, and lane keeping assist. Automatic high beams as well as blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert and lane change assist also come bundled with the EyeSight suite.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>When powered by the base 2.5-liter flat-four, the Outback isn’t very quick, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/outback/2015/2015-subaru-outback-25i-limited-first-test/">2015 First Test</a> and throttle tip in is touchy just like in its sibling, the Legacy midsize sedan. For a tall wagon-based crossover, the Outback offers respectable handling thanks to its standard all-wheel-drive system. The interior has high-quality materials and Subaru’s Starlink intotainment system is easy to use. The larger 3.6-liter flat-six offers better acceleration, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/outback/2015/2015-subaru-outback-36r-first-test/">2015 First Test</a>, but it comes at the cost of fuel economy.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Outback was one of the first crossover wagons on the market when it debuted in the 1990s as a variant of the Legacy wagon.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The new Black Edition package for the 2.5i joins the lineup and Active Torque Vectoring is now standard on the 2.0XT Touring model. Touring models now feature EyeSight Driver Assist Technology as standard, and High Beam Assist and Reverse Auto Braking is added to the EyeSight suite of driver assist features.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting above the smaller Crosstrek and below the larger but similarly priced Outback, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/forester/2018/">2018 Subaru Forester</a> is the brand’s compact offering and one of its best-selling models. Like other <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/">Subaru</a> models except for the BRZ coupe, the Forester comes standard with all-wheel drive. For now, it’s also the only crossover sold by Subaru that’s available with a turbocharged engine.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Engine choices in the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/forester/2018/">Subaru Forester</a> crossover include a 170-hp, 174-lb-ft of torque 2.5-liter flat-four as standard and paired to either a six-speed manual (22/28 mpg city/highway) or a CVT (26/32 mpg). The 250-hp, 258-lb-ft 2.0-liter turbo-four, which is essentially a less powerful version of the unit found the WRX sports sedan, is the optional powertrain paired exclusively to a CVT and delivers an EPA-rated 23/27 mpg. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 Subaru Forester 2.0XT hit 60 mph in a quick 6.8 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in an impressive 115 feet.</p>

<p>The Forester 2.5i Premium is one step above the base 2.5i and comes standard with a panoramic power moonroof, 17-inch alloy wheels, X-Mode off-road mode (CVT only), automatic climate controls, 10-way power driver’s seat, rear roof spoiler, raised roof rails, reclining rear seats, a 4.3-inch color driver’s display, and a 7.0-inch Starlink Multimedia Plus infotainment system. The top 2.0XT Touring model comes equipped with leather-trimmed upholstery, 18-inch wheels, LED steering responsive headlights, dual chrome exhaust outlets, a sport-design front fascia, heated front seats, one-touch folding rear setbacks, leather-wrapped heated steering wheel, paddle shifters, dual-zone automatic climate control, power liftgate, navigation with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, and a Harman Kardon audio system. The new Black Edition package includes 18-inch black aluminum wheels, a Sport grille, fog lights, black rear badging, black painted side view mirrors, seat bolsters, and a shifter handle with leather boot and Gloss Black trim.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Subaru Forester earned the NHTSA’s highest overall safety rating of five stars and is considered an IIHS 2017 Top Safety Pick+ (the highest honor). The Top Safety Pick+ designation was earned because the Forester received the highest rating of Good in five out of the six crash tests, the highest rating of Superior for front crash avoidance, and the second-highest rating of Acceptable for the headlights evaluation. The Forester received the second-lowest rating of Marginal for the new passenger-side small overlap front crash test. The Superior rating was achieved because the Forester properly warned the driver of a possible collision, avoided a collision in 12-  and 25-mph frontal tests thanks to the optional EyeSight suite of driver assist safety features that includes adaptive cruise control, an emergency automatic braking system, lane departure and sway warning, and lane keep assist. High beam assist, blind-spot monitoring, reverse automatic braking, and rear-cross traffic alert are also available. A rearview camera is standard on all models.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/forester/2017/2017-subaru-forester-20xt-touring-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 Subaru Forester 2.0XT, we were very impressed with the crossover’s acceleration, which was the best in the segment. Although we did not like the aggressive initial throttle response and somewhat stiff suspension, the Forester handled well. We liked the improved cabin insulation, updated technology, and the new Saddle Brown leather interior that feels and looks good. We weren’t fans of the old-looking dual-screen layout  or the display screen resolution. However, we loved the large and spacious cabin for passengers and cargo and the great outward visibility. We concluded our review by saying: “Although the Forester won our 2014 SUV of the Year award, its competition has advanced just as far, and in terms of design and technology, even more quickly. Just think of rivals that offer Apple CarPlay, a head-up display, and larger touchscreens with crisp graphics. Luckily the faithful Forester remains quick and all-around functional, qualities many of its rivals still haven’t mastered.”</p>

<p>In a nine-way compact <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-5/2016/small-crossover-comparison-big-test/">crossover Big Test comparison</a>, the 2016 Subaru Forester 2.5i finished fourth. “Just ahead of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> goes our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2014-suv-of-the-year-subaru-forester/">2014 SUV of the Year</a> champ, the Subaru Forester,” we wrote. “Age hasn’t been kind the Forester, and although it still has impressive fuel economy and safety scores that you can hang your hat on, an interior that leaves us wanting, loud cabin, and jumpy throttle response do in the Subbie.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Forester 2.0XT’s 2.0-liter turbo-four engine produces 250 hp at 5,600 rpm, the WRX 2.0-liter turbo-four engine does 268 at that same rpm. However, both engines make 258 lb-ft of torque from 2,000 rpm, but the WRX holds that power until 5,200 rpm versus the Forester’s 4,800 rpm.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The refreshed <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/legacy/2018/">2018 Subaru Legacy</a> gets a mild exterior design revision and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto  as standard. Higher trim levels are now available with adaptive LED headlights and a larger eight-inch touchscreen for the updated Starlink infotainment system.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/legacy/2018/">Subaru Legacy</a> is a midsize sedan slotting above the compact Impreza. In its class, the Legacy is the only midsize sedan that comes standard with all-wheel drive. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/fusion/2018/">Ford Fusion</a> also offers all-wheel drive, but only on a higher-cost engine option.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two engine options are available in the 2018 Legacy including a 175-hp 2.5-liter flat-four or a 256-hp 3.6-liter flat-six. Both engines are paired exclusively to a CVT. EPA fuel economy ratings for the 2018 Legacy have yet to be announced but shouldn’t deviate much from the 2017 model, which is rated at 25/34 mpg city/highway with the 2.5-liter and 20/28 mpg with the 3.6-liter. Trunk space is generous at 15 cubic feet and it can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>Standard features include a rearview camera, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/">Subaru</a>’s Starlink infotainment system with a 6.5-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, and cloth upholstery. Options include power front seats with driver memory, leather upholstery, heated front seats, a Harman Kardon audio system, navigation, a new and larger eight-inch touchscreen for the Starlink infotainment system, adaptive LED headlights, and alloy wheels up to 18 inches in diameter.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Subaru Legacy hasn’t been crash tested yet, but the 2017 model received high scores including a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS evaluations, the car received a Good score on all crash tests and the new headlight safety test, and a Superior rating on the front crash prevention test after it avoided a 12-mph and 25-mph collision (Good is the highest possible score). Subaru’s EyeSight suite of active safety and driver assistance features is available and includes automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning, lane keeping assist, forward collision warning, blind spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert and lane change assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Thi</strong><strong>nk</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/legacy/2015/2015-subaru-legacy-25i-limited-first-test/">2015 First Test</a>, we said that the CVT  operates quietly and doesn’t sound like one. However, since the Legacy doesn’t have a torque converter, its CVT is abrupt and jerky from a standstill even with the lightest throttle application.  The base 2.5-liter flat-four doesn’t offer much power but due to the car’s standard all-wheel-drive system, it offers decent handling and good grip levels. Inside, the material choices are good and even the fake wood trim feels high quality.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Subaru Legacy is closely related to the Outback crossover.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/crosstrek/2018/">Subaru Crosstrek</a> has been redesigned for the 2018 model year. Built on a new platform, the crossover features an updated engine, a standard six-speed manual, Stablex dampers, active torque vectoring, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, as well as available reverse automatic braking and Steering Responsive headlights.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The Crosstrek is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/">Subaru</a>’s smallest crossover. Based on the Impreza hatchback, the Crosstrek has a lower starting price than the Forester and Outback.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/crosstrek/2018/">2018 Subaru Crosstrek</a> crossover packs the Impreza’s 2.0-liter I-4 with 152 hp and 145 lb-ft of torque, mated to a CVT that sends power to Subaru’s Symmetrical all-wheel-drive system. That’s a small bump in power from the outgoing 2.0-liter I-4, which produced 148 hp. A six-speed manual is the standard transmission. The Crosstrek returns 27/33 mpg city/highway when equipped with the CVT and 23/29 with the six-speed manual. The Crosstrek sports 8.7 inches of ground clearance that give the vehicle a more crossover-like stance.</p>

<p>The Crosstrek 2.0i base model includes a 6.5-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, multi-function driver’s display, 17-inch wheels, and integrated roof rails. Opt for the Premium model and your Crosstrek will come standard with LED daytime running lights and headlights, 18-inch alloy wheels, Steering Responsive headlights, leather upholstery with orange contrast stitching, a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shifter, 6-way power driver’s seat, and an 8.0-inch display screen.  Available features include blue footwell lighting, Harman Kardon audio system, map and dome LED lighting, remote start, an STI rear spoiler and 18-inch STI alloy wheels. Available accessories include a multitude of different Thule branded roof carriers, crossbar set, and bike hitch carrier.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Subaru Crosstrek has yet to be crash tested by the IIHS and NHTSA. However, its platform mate, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/impreza/2017/">2017 Subaru Impreza</a> has, and the hatchback model was given the highest five-star rating from the NHTSA and the highest honor of 2017 Top Safety Pick+ from the IIHS.</p>

<p>Subaru offers two packages that include EyeSight driver assist technologies for the 2018 Crosstrek. The EyeSight system includes adaptive cruise control, pre-collision braking, lane departure warning with sway warning and lane keep assist. One package also includes high beam assist, reverse automatic braking, and a moonroof. The other package includes all the features from the previous package and adds Starlink 8.0-inch multimedia with navigation and an eight-speaker Harman Kardon audio system.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think </strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/crosstrek/2018/2018-subaru-crosstrek-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2018 Subaru Crosstrek, we were impressed with its off-road capability and improved rigidity, “With 8.7 inches of ground clearance (and 18/29 degrees of approach/departure angle), the Crosstrek’s intelligent all-wheel-drive system and off-road calibrated ABS put fears of ever getting stuck in anything less than rock-crawling situations to rest.”</p>

<p>However we were not impressed with the power from the updated powertrain that still provides slow acceleration. “The Crosstrek “wants” to have 200 horsepower. The last time we tested a 2015 Crosstrek (with 148 hp vs the current 152 hp), it sauntered to 60 mph in 10.3 seconds—or 1 to 3 seconds behind its main competitors.”</p>

<p>Even so, the interior did impress us: “The new interior rivals class leaders in terms of layout, quality, and materials choices.” At the end of our review we said that “for those who want the off-road capability and upscale features of either a Forester ($23,710–$37,005) or an Outback ($26,810–$39,605) but in a smaller package at a more manageable price, the Crosstrek follows where the Legacy Outback wagon or Outback Sport once blazed the trail before it grew to become a bona fide SUV in 2015.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The new Crosstrek may look similar to the outgoing one, but according to Subaru, the 2018 model is 90 percent new.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/brz/2018/">2018 Subaru BRZ</a> gets a new tS variant that comes with Brembo brakes, an adjustable rear wing, Bilstein shocks, 18-inch alloy wheels in black, and a more aggressive suspension setup for sharper handling.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/brz/2018/">Subaru BRZ</a> is a rear-drive sports coupe and the only vehicle in <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/">Subaru</a>’s U.S. lineup to not come with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Subaru BRZ is powered by a 2.0-liter flat-four with 205 hp and 156 lb-ft of torque when equipped with the standard six-speed manual transmission. With the optional six-speed automatic transmission, the engine is rated at 200 hp and 151 lb-ft. EPA fuel economy ratings are 21/29 mpg city/highway with the manual and 24/33 mpg with the automatic. Trunk space is small at 6.9 cubic feet, but it can be expanded with the single-piece folding rear seats.</p>

<p>Standard features include a leather-wrapped steering wheel, 17-inch alloy wheels, Bluetooth connectivity, Subaru’s Starlink multimedia interface with a 6.2-inch touchscreen, a rearview camera, LED headlights, keyless entry, cloth upholstery, and a USB port. The Limited trim adds dual-zone climate control, keyless start, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, heated front seats, Alcantara/leather upholstery, and fog lights. Navigation is available via a mobile phone-based app. Optional only on the Limited trim, the Performance package sharpens the BRZ’s handling by adding wider tires, Brembo brakes on all four corners, Sachs dampers, and black 17-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 BRZ received a four-star rating on the front crash test and five stars on the rollover test from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 BRZ but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except for the front small overlap test where it got an Acceptable rating (Good is the highest possible score).  The IIHS has yet to test the BRZ’s headlights. Active safety features aren’t available on the 2018 BRZ.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/brz/2017/2017-subaru-brz-first-drive-review/">2017 First Drive</a> review, offers even better handling than the pre-refresh BRZ thanks to its improved suspension and a new Track mode that keeps the electronic nannies from interfering too much. Driving enjoyment remains the focus in the Subaru BRZ, which makes it easy to drift on a track. The 2.0-liter flat-four, however, still needs to be revved because there’s still not much mid-range grunt.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Subaru BRZ’s 2.0-liter flat-four is the only Subaru-made engine to feature <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a>’s D-4S direct- and port injection system.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/">Tesla</a> is not your average automaker in many ways, including how the company avoids the traditional model year designations and model year updates. Instead, Tesla prefers rolling out over-the-air updates and adding and dropping powertrain variants throughout the vehicle’s lifecycle. In recent months, Tesla has dropped the base 60 kWh powertrain and the 90 kWh powertrain, replaced by the now base 75 kWh powertrain and the range-topping 100 kWh powertrain, respectively.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The Model S is one of the most popular EVs in the world and is Tesla’s flagship vehicle, positioned above the new Model 3 sedan. The Model S has a slightly lower starting price than the Model X crossover but has a longer range and quicker acceleration. During the third quarter of 2017, the 100 kWh models got <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-cuts-the-price-of-its-most-powerful-models/">price cuts</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The base <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-s/2018/">Tesla Model S</a> 75D utilizes a 75 kWh battery pack that powers the front and rear mounted electric motors (all-wheel drive) that together produce 518 hp and have an EPA-rated driving range of 259 miles (listed ratings are for 2017 model year). The mid-level 100D is powered by a 100 kWh battery pack that also consists of front and rear mounted electric motors and has a long range of 335 miles (2017), currently the longest of any electric car. The top P100D utilizes the same battery pack to power more powerful front and rear-mounted electric motors that produce a whopping 680 hp and 791 lb-ft of torque and come rated with a 315-mile driving range (2017). All powertrains use a one-speed transmission.</p>

<p>As for charging times, using a 75 kWh home wall charger will take about three hours of charging time for 100 miles of driving range. A 100 kWh home wall charger will take approximately two hours for 100 miles, but a Tesla Supercharger will only take 15 minutes of charge time for 100 miles of driving range. For 300 miles of driving range (only possible on the 100 kWh), a Tesla Supercharger only takes about an hour of charging time, but the 75 kWh home charger will take about nine hours.</p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-s/2017/2017-tesla-model-s-p100d-first-test-review/"><em>Motor Trend</em> testing</a>, the Model S P100D hit 60 mph in a record-braking 2.3 seconds, quicker than any other production car we have tested.</p>

<p>The Tesla Model S comes standard with a 17.0-inch captive touchscreen with navigation, a Wi-Fi hotspot, heated power-folding side view mirrors, two USB ports for smartphone connectivity and charging, 12-way power and heated front seats, lighted door handles, LED interior ambient lighting, and LED fog lights. If you order the $5,000 Premium Upgrade package, your Model S will also come with a HEPA air filtration system (includes bioweapon defense mode), an 11-speaker custom audio system, satellite radio, heated rear seats, a heated steering wheel, wiper blade defrosters, and washer nozzle heaters. The Enhanced Autopilot (semi-autonomous self-driving system) will set you back $5,000 but adds three more cameras and 12 ultrasonic sonar sensors. The Full Self-Driving Capability (not full but semi-autonomous) package is an additional $3,000 and doubles the number of cameras to eight. The two small rear-facing seats will set you back $4,000.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-s/2017/">2017 Tesla Model S</a> received the second highest score of Acceptable for the IIHS’ small overlap front crash test and the highest rating of Good from the remaining four crash evaluations (moderate overlap front, side, roof strength, and head restraints and seats). The Model S’ automatic emergency braking system avoided a collision in the 12- and 25 mph crash tests. In NHTSA testing, the Tesla was only tested for the rollover evaluation and received the highest five-star rating. Safety features include collision avoidance and automatic emergency braking and dynamic LED rotating headlights.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/bolt-ev/2017/2017-chevrolet-bolt-ev-vs-2016-tesla-model-s-60/">comparison review</a> between the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/bolt-ev/2018/">Chevrolet Bolt EV</a> and the Tesla Model S 60, we liked the fact that the Tesla can receive over-the-air updates and the quick acceleration provided by the powerful electric motor. We also enjoyed the big premium sedan feel and the quietness of the electric powertrain. The Model S is more of a cruiser, providing a comfortable ride and decent cornering ability. The interior of the Tesla is well-packaged and the 17.0-inch display screen is one of the best in the industry. The rear seats lack some headroom and the floor is a little high. We concluded by saying, “Ultimately the Bolt and Model S 60 quite close in performance and function. The Model S remains a technical tour de force three years after its release, with Tesla appearing to have no intention of letting its flagship car wither on the vine. If semi-self-driving technology and a proven quick-charging capability with worldwide infrastructure for long-distance travel is what you’re after, there’s really no choice but the Tesla.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-s/2015/2015-tesla-model-s-p90d-ludicrous-upgrade-first-test-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2015 Tesla Model S P90D, we said, “Aside from the horsepower bonus, the P90D remains the Model S we know and love; the ride is luxury-car compliant despite the big wheel and tire package, and steering is still sharp for a vehicle that’ll never be described as ‘light’.” We concluded by saying, “The P90D can run 10.9-second quarter miles right out of the Tesla showroom, and it offers up hypercar acceleration for around $130,000. The takeaway here shouldn’t solely be that the Model S P90D is currently the quickest four-door on the market. Rather, the focus should be that it does it without burning a single ounce of gasoline.”</p>

<p>Don’t miss our World’s Greatest Drag Race 7, an amazing competition in which a Model S competed:</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>In <em>Motor Trend’s</em> instrumented testing, the Tesla Model S P100D hit 30 mph in 0.9 seconds and 100 mph in 6.0 seconds. Those are extremely quick acceleration rates for any production car.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Currently, like the Model S, the Model X has three variants, the 75D, 100D, and the range-topping P100D. The 75 and 90 variants are no longer offered. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/">Tesla</a> recently <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-lowers-starting-price-model-x/">lowered the starting price</a> of the Model X.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The Model X is currently the electric automaker’s only crossover, with the compact Model Y crossover on the way. The Model X has a higher starting price than the Model S sedan and has a lower driving range.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 75D is currently the Model X’s base model and comes with an EPA-rated driving range of 238 miles (all range figures refer to 2017 EPA ratings) thanks to a 75 kWh battery pack that powers front and rear-mounted electric motors (all-wheel drive) that produce a combined total of 518 hp. The 100D’s 100 kWh battery pack powers more powerful front and rear-mounted electric motors and comes with a driving range of 295 miles. The P100D variant utilizes the same battery pack as the 100D but power is increased to 680 hp and 791 lb-ft of torque and the driving range slightly decrease to 289 miles (2017). All Teslas use a one-speed transmission. To give you an idea of charging time, charging time for 150 miles of driving range using a 75 kWh home wall charger will take about five hours and about three hours using a 100 kWh home wall charger. A Tesla Supercharger will only take half an hour for 150 miles of driving range. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the now discontinued Model X P90D hit 60 mph in a very quick 3.2 seconds and braked from 60 mph in an impressive 106 feet.</p>

<p>The Model X comes standard with air suspension with a 17.0-inch capacitive touchscreen with media connectivity, 14-way power adjustable and heated front seats, hand-wrapped microfiber and synthetic leather interior surfaces, GPS memory (for automatic ride height adjustment), a very large panoramic windshield, Falcon Wing doors, power liftgate, interior ambient lighting, heated front seats, a towing package, LED fog lights, LED taillights, power-folding and heated side view mirrors, and navigation with traffic information. A five-seat configuration is standard but a six- and seven-seat configurations are available. Opt for the Premium Upgrades package and your Model X will also come with a HEPA filtration system, a self-presenting front door, a custom audio system, satellite radio, heated seats for all passengers, a heated steering wheel, wiper blade defrosters, and heated washer nozzles. The Enhanced Autopilot and Full Self-Driving Capability system (actually semi-autonomous) are additional available features.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the Model X the institution’s highest overall rating of five stars and received five stars in all categories (frontal crash, side crash, and rollover). The Model X comes standard with collision avoidance and automatic emergency braking systems and rotating LED headlights. The Autopilot, Enhanced Autopilot, and Full Self-Driving Capability semi-autonomous driving systems can be considered safety features because they help drivers avoid accidents. The IIHS has yet to evaluate the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-x/2018/">Tesla Model X</a>.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-x/2016/2016-tesla-model-x-75d-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2016 Model X 75D, we said, “Bottom line: If you long for the daily sense of wonderment that can come from driving a futuristic pod that essentially does everything slightly differently from “normal” vehicles and if your SUV needs pretty much start and end with a high seating position and enough hood to distinguish you from the hordes of minivan drivers, then rest assured that a Model X 75D (or perhaps even a 60D) will absolutely deliver 90 percent of the everyday adventure you’d get from the top-performing Ludicrous models at a price that starts out $42,500 cheaper than a P90D with Ludicrous Speed upgrade. Just understand that with any Model X, you won’t be carrying big things, and you may occasionally be required to leave apology notes on the windshields of parked cars your doors have attacked.”</p>

<p>“In fact, say what you like about Tesla’s gimmicks, but the Model X, like its sedan sibling, is such a well-done piece of machinery that it makes you look at all other cars as if they’ve come straight out of the past. It’d be a better SUV without the falcon doors, the monopost seats, and the windshield, but as it sits now, the Model X is one hell of a people hauler. And at 3.2 seconds to 60, its ability to haul tail is anything but a gimmick,” we concluded in our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-x/2016/2016-tesla-model-x-p90d-ludicrous-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-x/2016/">2016 Tesla Model X</a> P90D.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Model X 100D weighs in at a hefty 5,421 pounds, has an even weight distribution of 50/50, and its air suspension provides up to 8.3 inches of ground clearance.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Everything. The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-3/2018/">Tesla Model 3</a> represents the automaker’s first effort to build an affordable sedan for the mainstream consumer.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/">Tesla</a> Model 3 slots below the full-size <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-s/2017/">Model S sedan</a> and three-row <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-x/">Model X crossover</a>. Where the Model S sedan features a rear hatch with available rear jump seats for up to seven passengers, the Model 3 is a traditional five-seat sedan.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Although Tesla hasn’t divulged full specs about the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-3/2018/tesla-model-3-first-look-review/">new Model 3 sedan</a>, the automaker has made a few claims about its more affordable model. Pricing for the Model 3 is said to start at $35,000 before government incentives. In contrast, the base rear-drive <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-s/2018/">Tesla Model S</a> 60 starts around $70,000.</p>

<p>Tesla says the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-model-3-behind-the-scenes/">Model 3 sedan</a> will have a 215-mile range and accelerate to 60 mph in less than 6 seconds. The five-seat sedan is also said to have been designed to earn a five-star safety rating. Other features include autopilot hardware and the ability to use the company’s supercharger network designed for the Model S.</p>

<p>Inside, the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-3/2017/tesla-model-3-second-ride-review/">Model 3 features a simplified interior</a> compared to the Model S and Model X vehicles. In production-ready models, expect a large center-mounted horizontal screen replacing both the driver information display and the vertical infotainment screen used in automaker’s current models.</p>

<p>Despite its fastback profile, the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-model-3-photos-analysis/">Tesla Model 3 is a traditional sedan</a> about the size of a <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/3-series/2018/">BMW 3 Series</a>/4 Series Gran Coupe, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/c-class/2018/">Mercedes-Benz C-Class</a>. Unlike the Model S’ aluminum-intensive body, the Model 3 is constructed of a steel unit-body with aluminum panels.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Tesla anticipates a five-star crash test rating, and we expect the automaker to offer lots of active safety tech in conjunction with the automaker’s autopilot hardware.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>Initial impressions from our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/tesla/model-3/2018/tesla-model-3-first-ride-review/">Tesla Model 3 First Ride review</a>: “Our Model 3, which was a fairly well-equipped dual-motor version with air suspension and what we think could be a 70 kWh battery pack, shot effortlessly forward when our Tesla minder flattened the accelerator. Despite the fact that our car was loaded down with five people, acceleration was quick, smooth, and quiet. Typical Tesla. While the Model 3 won’t throw you back in your seat like a Model S P90D will, it’s not going to leave drivers wanting for more oomph. Think of the difference in acceleration compared to a Model S like a <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/">BMW</a> 328i versus an M3; both are quick, but one feels a bit more so. Handling from the passenger seat felt solid, too. With the center of gravity kept low by the floor-mounted battery pack, there was little if any body roll detectable during our mini-slalom course, but count on Motor Trend for a full, instrumented track test once we can get our hands on a production-spec model.”</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/tacoma/2018/">2018 Toyota Tacoma</a> gets the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> Safety Sense-P safety suite as standard. The five-speed manual option has been discontinued on the SR and SR5 trim. TRD Sport, TRD Off-Road, and Limited trims are now available with the Cement exterior color. TRD Pro models get the Cavalry Blue exterior color, which replaces Cement. Midnight Black replaces Black in all trims. All trims except for the TRD Pro get a revised grille.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/tacoma/2018/">Toyota Tacoma</a> is a midsize truck that slots below the larger, full-size Tundra and is available in rear- or four-wheel drive configurations. Two bed lengths and three cab variants are available.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Toyota Tacoma comes standard with a 2.7-liter I-4 with 159 hp and 180 lb-ft of torque, and is paired to a six-speed automatic transmission. There’s also an optional 3.5-liter V-6 with 278 hp and 268 lb-ft that can be had with a six-speed manual or a six-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p>EPA ratings for the base four-cylinder are 19/23 mpg city/highway for rear-drive models and 19/22 mpg with four-wheel drive. Opting for the V-6 doesn’t come at the cost of fuel economy with the automatic-equipped rear-drive Tacoma rated at 19/24 mpg and the four-wheel drive version coming in at 18/23 mpg. The least efficient Tacoma is the TRD Pro, which is rated at 18/21 mpg with the manual and 17/20 mpg with the automatic.</p>

<p>Four-cylinder variants can tow up to 3,500 pounds of payload when properly equipped. With the available V-6 Tow Prep package, the V-6-powered Tacoma can tow up to 6,800 pounds in the rear-drive Access Cab configuration with the standard bed or 6,500 pounds with four-wheel drive. Double cab models with the V-6 can tow up to 6,700 pounds in rear-drive guise and 6,400 pounds with four-wheel drive. Opting for the long bed drops the rear-drive double cab’s towing capacity down to 6,600 pounds.</p>

<p>Standard features include 16-inch steel wheels, cloth upholstery, Toyota’s Entune multimedia system with a 6.1-inch touchscreen, a USB port, Bluetooth connectivity, and a rearview camera. Options include a larger 7.0-inch touchscreen, a JBL premium audio system, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, keyless entry/start, a wireless phone charger, dual-zone climate control, leather upholstery, a moonroof, alloy wheels up to 18 inches in diameter, heated front seats, power-adjustable front seats, and parking sensors.</p>

<p>The Tacoma TRD Pro is distinguished with its standard Fox shocks, Rigid Industries LED fog lights, a unique grille with a heritage-inspired Toyota badge, a TRD Pro skid plate, a TRD exhaust, a hood scoop, and TRD Pro 16-inch alloy wheels wrapped in all-terrain tires.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Tacoma a four-star overall safety rating (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 Tacoma but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except for the passenger side front small overlap impact where it hasn’t been tested yet and the headlights test where it received a Poor rating (Good is the highest possible score). The IIHS hasn’t crash-tested the 2018 Tacoma’s front crash prevention features.</p>

<p>Now standard on all Tacomas for the 2018 model year is Toyota Safety Sense-P, which bundles together forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, automatic emergency braking, adaptive cruise control, automatic high beams, and lane departure warning. Blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert is available only on the TRD Sport and higher trims.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/tacoma/2016/2016-toyota-tacoma-first-drive-review/">2016 First Drive</a> review, we said that the more rigid chassis and body makes the Tacoma feel more solid and refined on the road, giving it a quieter cabin. However, the brakes are overly sensitive. Steering has poor on-center feel and makes it feel like you’re driving a larger truck, and the six-speed automatic has a tendency to hunt for gears. Interior quality, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/tacoma/2016/2016-toyota-tacoma-v-6-first-test-review/">2016 First Test,</a> is good, but the rear seats were tight.</p>

<p>The off-road-oriented Tacoma TRD Pro was right at home outside of the pavement. It handled rough terrain with ease and wasn’t hard to control. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/tacoma/2017/2017-toyota-tacoma-trd-pro-off-road-review/">2017 First Drive</a>, we also noted that the 3.5-liter V-6 needs more revs than the old 4.0-liter V-6 it replaces.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p> </p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/yaris/2018/">2018 Toyota Yaris</a> iA is unchanged.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/yaris/2018/">Toyota Yaris</a> iA is a front-drive subcompact sedan that slots below the larger Corolla.</p>

<p>Like other former Scion models, the 2018 Yaris iA comes only in a single trim with standard features that include keyless entry/start, 16-inch alloy wheels, a rearview camera, a six-speaker audio system, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, two USB ports, Bluetooth, and cloth upholstery.</p>

<p>Available accessories include an armrest, a rear spoiler, a tablet holder, and navigation.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/yaris-ia/2018/">2018 Toyota Yaris iA</a> is powered by a 1.5-liter I-4 rated at 106 hp and 103 lb-ft of torque paired to either a six-speed manual or automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 30/39 mpg city/highway with the manual and 32/40 mpg with the automatic.</p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Yaris iA a five-star overall rating (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing, the Yaris iA received a Good score on all but the passenger side front overlap impact where it hasn’t been evaluated (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the 2018 Yaris iA avoided a 12-mph impact, allowing it to get an Advanced rating (Superior is the highest rating on the front crash prevention test). A low-speed automatic emergency braking system comes standard on the 2018 Yaris iA.</p>

<p>Trunk space is 13.4 cubic feet and can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/scion/ia/2016/2016-scion-ia-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we noted that the Yaris iA has a quiet engine but its throttle response is on the lazy side. On cars with a manual, the clutch is light and the take-up is easy to find. Since it’s essentially a Mazda2 (a car we no longer get in the U.S. as a <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/">Mazda</a>), the Yaris iA is surprisingly nimble thanks to its light weight. However, you will need a few downshifts when the car is loaded with more people. Although the interior is mostly hard plastic, touch points are well-finished and the controls are laid out logically. The cabin, however, does lack many storage cubbies because of the lack of a center console storage area.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/yaris-ia/2018/">Toyota Yaris iA</a> is essentially a Mazda2 sedan underneath and it’s built in Mazda’s factory in Mexico.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/avalon/2018/">2018 Toyota Avalon</a> Hybrid is unchanged.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/avalon/2018/">Toyota Avalon</a> Hybrid is the hybrid variant of the full-size Avalon sedan and it comes exclusively in a front-drive configuration. A non-hybrid six-cylinder Avalon model is also available.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> Avalon’s powertrain consists of a 2.5-liter I-4 coupled to an electric motor, a nickel metal hydride battery and a CVT. Total system output is 200 hp. EPA fuel economy ratings are 40/39 mpg city/highway, making the 2018 Avalon Hybrid one of the most fuel efficient large sedans available. Trunk space, however, drops to 14 cubic feet from 16 cubic feet in the gas-only Avalon due to the extra components of the hybrid system.</p>

<p>The base Avalon Hybrid <strong>XLE Plus</strong> trim comes with keyless entry/start, 17-inch alloy wheels, heated front seats, leather upholstery, a rearview camera, dual-zone climate control, Toyota’s Entune multimedia system, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, and eight-way power front seats. Move up to the Avalon Hybrid <strong>XLE Premium</strong> trim and you’ll get navigation, driver’s seat memory, a wireless phone charger, blind-spot warning, and rear cross-traffic alert. The range-topping Avalon Hybrid <strong>Limited</strong> trim adds heated rear seats, ventilated front seats, a JBL premium audio system, HID headlights, 17-inch chrome look alloy wheels, interior ambient lighting, and tri-zone climate control.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Avalon Hybrid a five-star overall safety score (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test a 2018 Avalon Hybrid but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crash worthiness tests and an Average rating on the new headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). On the front crash prevention test, the Avalon received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph and a 25-mph collision (Superior is the highest possible score). As a result, the Avalon Hybrid received the Top Safety Pick+ rating from the IIHS.</p>

<p>Toyota Safety Sense-P, which bundles together adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, pedestrian detection, lane departure warning with steering assist, and automatic high beams come standard on all 2018 Avalon Hybrid models. Blind-spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert are standard only on the XLE Premium and Limited grades.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>Although we haven’t tested a 2018 Avalon Hybrid, <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2014-toyota-avalon-limited-hybrid-first-test/">we did review a 2014 model</a> and said that it offers plenty of power on tap and has a CVT that’s willing to leave the car in the middle of its power band. For a large sedan, the Avalon Hybrid is also not as floaty as past Avalons thanks to its stable ride. Inside, the cabin is well-insulated and the infotainment system features two large knobs and a responsive touchscreen. However, the excessive amount of chrome in the cabin can cause too much glare in the sun.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The hybrid system in the 2018 Avalon Hybrid is also found on the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/es/2018/">Lexus ES</a> 300h, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/nx/2018/">Lexus NX</a> 300h, and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/rav4/2018/">Toyota RAV4</a> Hybrid.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>In addition to a new front fascia, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/yaris/2018/">2018 Toyota Yaris</a> receives an upgraded infotainment system and a new instrument cluster in the L and LE trims with a multi-information display. Blue Eclipse replaces Blue Streak Metallic and Crushed Ice with a black roof is replaced by Blue Streak with a black roof as the second two-tone exterior color.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting below the compact Corolla, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/yaris/2018/">Toyota Yaris</a> is the Japanese brand’s entry-level vehicle available in two- or four-door hatchback variants. A sedan based on the global market Mazda2 called the Yaris iA is also available.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>All Yaris hatchbacks are powered by a 1.5-liter I-4 with 106 hp and 103 lb-ft of torque, paired to a five-speed manual or a four-speed automatic transmission. The EPA hasn’t released fuel economy ratings for the 2018 model but the 2017 Yaris was rated at 30/36 mpg city/highway with the manual or 30/35 mpg with the automatic. There’s 15.3 cubic feet of cargo space behind the split-folding rear seats in the two-door variant or 15.6 cubic feet in the four-door model.</p>

<p>Standard features include Bluetooth connectivity, a 6.1-inch touchscreen, a USB port, Siri Eyes Free, cloth upholstery, and a multi-information display. The SE trim gets a larger 7.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, and 16-inch alloy wheels as additional standard features.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Toyota Yaris hasn’t been crash tested but the 2017 model received a four-star overall rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The car was also tested by the IIHS and it received a Good score on all but the small overlap front crash where it got a Marginal rating (Good is the highest possible score). The IIHS gave the 2017 Yaris a Basic score for front crash prevention. Standard on the 2018 Yaris the TSS-C active safety feature suite that includes forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning, and automatic high beams.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/yaris/2015/2015-toyota-yaris-first-drive/">2015 First Drive</a>, we said that Yaris has a good bit of body roll and it gets worse the harder you push the car. Keeping up your speeds in the Yaris is easy since it doesn’t weigh much; however, the tall gearing means acceleration is slow and lacks torque, making it a challenge to get it up a hill. Steering, on the other hand, is responsive and makes the car feel nimble.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Toyota Yaris is one of two affordable subcompact cars that features automatic emergency braking, the other being the Yaris iA sedan.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/toyota-c-hr-9-unique-features-paris-motor-show/">2018 Toyota C-HR</a> is the newest entry among subcompact crossovers, America’s fastest-growing segment. Compared to some other subcompacts, the C-HR puts an emphasis on style instead of practicality with its controversial exterior design.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting below the compact RAV4, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/c-hr/2018/">2018 Toyota C-HR</a> will be the newest and smallest crossover entry when it arrives next year.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Not much is known regarding what engine will power the North American-spec 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/c-hr/2018/">Toyota C-HR</a> but it’s likely a 2.0-liter I-4 paired only to a CVT. It’s also likely that a new turbocharged engine could make its debut in the North American C-HR. A new version of the Entune infotainment system should find its way into the Toyota C-HR.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>As with all Toyota models except the 86 sports coupe, the 2018 C-HR could get the TSS-P suite of active safety features as standard. It includes forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, and adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>We expect the 2018 Toyota C-HR to be a more interesting drive than most Toyota vehicles available since it’s underpinned by Toyota’s new TNGA platform. The car’s polarizing styling should also cause a lot of heads to turn since it stands out from the crowd more than most cars today.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>In the European market, the 2018 Toyota C-HR is offered with the same hybrid powertrain found in the fourth generation <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/prius/2018/">Toyota Prius</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The redesigned <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/camry/2018/">2018 Toyota Camry</a> rides on Toyota’s new TNGA platform that underpins the Prius and C-HR.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>Slotting above the Corolla and below the Avalon, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/camry/2018/">Toyota Camry</a> is the latest generation of the most popular sedan in the U.S., and one of the best-selling nameplates today. A hybrid variant joins the four- and six-cylinder gas variants.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>
