<p>The 2018 Toyota Camry features three updated powertrains including a base 2.5-liter I-4, a 3.5-liter V-6 with Toyota’s direct- and port-injection system, and a hybrid that now features the revised 2.5-liter I-4 and a lithium-ion battery in all but the base trim level. The base 2.5-liter I-4 and the optional 3.5-liter V-6 come paired exclusively with an eight-speed automatic while the hybrid is only available with a CVT.</p>

<p>Available features include an updated version of Toyota’s Entune multimedia interface with an eight-inch touchscreen, a 10-inch head-up display, a seven-inch LCD cluster in between the gauges, a panoramic sunroof, a JBL premium audio system, leather upholstery, alloy wheels ranging from 16- to 19 inches, a 360-degree view camera system, navigation, and Bluetooth.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Toyota’s TSS-P suite of active safety features comes standard in the 2018 Camry and includes high beam assist, lane departure warning with steering assist, adaptive cruise control, and the Pre-Collision system, which bundles forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking and pedestrian detection. Other available safety features include blind spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a drive of a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/camry/2018/2018-toyota-camry-prototype-drive-review/">2018 Camry prototype</a>, we said that the redesigned Camry feels better planted on the road thanks to its new underpinnings and suspension, solid brake pedal feel, and improved handling. The car’s steering feel is also much improved, making it feel livelier than ever.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Toyota Camry will be the third vehicle to utilize the new TNGA platform.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/sienna/2018/">2018 Toyota Sienna</a> gets the TSS-P active safety suite of technologies, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, additional USB ports, an optional 360-degree view camera system, and an updated rear-seat entertainment system. A revised front fascia freshens the 2018 Sienna’s styling.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/sienna/2018/">Toyota Sienna</a> offers seating for up to eight passengers and is the only minivan available in front- <em>and</em> all-wheel-drive configurations.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>All 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> Siennas are powered by a 3.5-liter V-6 with 296 hp and 263 lb-ft of torque, an engine that comes exclusively with an eight-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings haven’t been released for the 2018 Sienna but the 2017 model was rated at 19/27 mpg city/highway for front-drive models or 18/24 mpg with all-wheel drive. Cargo space stands at 29.1 cubic feet behind the third row, 87.1 cubic feet behind the second row, and 150 cubic feet behind the front seats. Front-drive models are rated to tow up to 3,500 pounds but all-wheel drive variants aren’t rated for towing.</p>

<p>Standard features include 17-inch alloy wheels, a multi-information display, tri-zone climate control, cloth upholstery, and keyless entry. Options include navigation, a power liftgate, a rear-seat entertainment system, Toyota’s Enture 3.0 multimedia system with navigation and an app suite, leather upholstery, HID headlights, a JBL premium audio system, keyless entry/start, a heated steering wheel, a 360-degree view camera system, and heated front seats.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Toyota Sienna hasn’t been crash tested but the 2017 model received a five-star overall score from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS evaluations, the previous model received a Good score on all tests except for the small overlap front crash test where it received an Average rating (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the car received an Advanced rating after it reduced a 12-mph impact by 9 mph and a 25-mph crash by 7 mph. The TSS-P suite comes standard with automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning with steering assist, automatic high beams, and pedestrian detection.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/town-&amp;-country/2015/the-big-test-2014-2015-minivans/">2015 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/">Nissan</a> Quest, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/sedona/2018/">Kia Sedona</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/odyssey/2018/">Honda Odyssey</a>, and the outgoing <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/">Chrysler</a> Town &amp; Country (now replaced by the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chrysler/pacifica/2018/">Chrysler Pacifica</a>), the Toyota Sienna placed third thanks to its quick acceleration and easy-to-remove center seat in the second row. However, its cabin was filled with hard plastics and the SE trim’s sport-tuned suspension hurts the minivan’s overall ride quality, which got bouncy over rough pavement.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>A version of the 3.5-liter V-6 that powers the Sienna is also used in the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/rx/2018/">Lexus RX</a> 350 and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/highlander/2018/">Toyota Highlander</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/mirai/2018/">2018 Toyota Mirai</a> gets two additional USB ports and a larger wireless phone charging pad. In late 2017, the Mirai received an updated navigation system, a Wi-Fi hotspot, and Destination Assist Connect. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> also discontinued the hydrogen station finder phone app.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/mirai/2018/">Toyota Mirai</a> is a hydrogen fuel cell sedan that’s currently available only in California and is expected to go on sale in five northeastern states sometime in the 2018 calendar year. It’s available only as a single loaded model.</p>

<p>Standard features include Toyota’s Entune multimedia system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, Bluetooth, a JBL audio system, dual-zone climate control, leatherette upholstery, a heated steering wheel, heated front and rear seats, keyless entry and start, 17-inch alloy wheels, full LED headlights, front and rear parking sensors, and rain-sensing wipers.</p>

<p>The 2018 Toyota Mirai features a hydrogen fuel cell stack powering an electric motor with 151 hp and 247 lb-ft of torque coupled to a single-speed automatic transmission, and a nickel-metal hydride battery. It has two high pressure carbon fiber-reinforced hydrogen tanks with a total volume of 122.4 liters. The 2018 Mirai’s EPA-rated driving range is 312 miles.</p>

<p>The 2018 Mirai hasn’t been crash-tested by the NHTSA and IIHS. Standard active driver assistance features include adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, blind-spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, and the Pre-Collision System, which bundles together automatic emergency braking and forward collision warning.</p>

<p>Trunk space is small in the 2018 Mirai at 12.8 cubic feet, though that’s still one cubic foot larger than the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/clarity/2018/">Honda Clarity</a> Fuel Cell.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/mirai/2016/2016-toyota-mirai-first-drive/">2016 First Drive</a> review, we said that the Mirai’s user interface works well even with all the touch-sensitive buttons. On the road, the Mirai doesn’t snap off the line like some electric vehicles do but it does drive smoothly once you get going. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/bolt-ev/2017/hyundai-ioniq-hybrid-vs-toyota-prius-chevrolet-volt-vs-prius-prime-bolt-ev-vs-ioniq-ev-vs-honda-clarity-vs-mirai/">2017 comparison test</a> against the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a> Clarity, we noted that the Mirai is quieter and more comfortable. Even so, the Clarity won that comparison thanks to its five-seat capacity, superior range, and better driving dynamics, in comparison to the Mirai.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/mirai/2016/2016-toyota-mirai-review-long-term-verdict/">2016 long-term verdict</a> review after six months with the car, we said that the Mirai’s driving range was somewhat disappointing because we only managed 279 miles per tank most of the time and rarely broke past the 300-mile mark. We also found that the lack of hydrogen fuel stations made it inconvenient to fuel up and not all stations functioned smoothly. Its low beltline meant visibility out of the car was excellent, and we appreciated its comfortable ride and high-quality interior. The Mirai’s vague handling proved to be a weak point, however, and the car felt heavy through corners.</p>

<p>The Toyota Mirai’s name in Japanese translates to future in English.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/4runner/2018/">2018 Toyota 4Runner</a> gets two new option packages including the Wilderness package, which adds roof rack crossbars, all-weather floor liners and a cargo tray.  The TRD Enhancement package comes with 17-inch matte gray alloy wheels and a TRD front skid plate. The Wilderness package is available on the SR5, SR5 Premium, TRD Off-Road and TRD Off-Road Premium trim while the TRD Enhancement package is only available on the latter two grades. Three new exterior colors—Super White, Midnight Black, and Calvary Blue—are exclusive to the 4Runner TRD Pro,.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/4runner/2018/">Toyota 4Runner</a> is one of the last truck-based SUVs left in the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> lineup, slotting below the larger Sequoia. Rear-wheel drive comes standard and four-wheel drive is optional. Some trim levels including the TRD Off-Road and TRD Pro comes standard with four-wheel drive. Depending on the model, the 4Runner can be equipped with a third-row, increasing seating capacity from five to seven.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Toyota 4Runner is powered by a 4.0-liter V-6 with 270 hp and 278 lb-ft of torque, paired to a five-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 17/21 mpg city/highway for rear-drive models and 17/20 with four-wheel drive.</p>

<p>Cargo space stands at 9.0 cubic feet behind the optional third row, 47.2 cubic feet behind the split-folding second row seats, and 89.7 cubic feet behind the front seats. The optional sliding deck cuts cargo space down to 46.3 cubic feet behind the second row and 88.8 cubic feet behind the front seats. When properly equipped, the 2018 4Runner can tow up to 5,000 pounds of payload.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base SR5 trim include 17-inch alloy wheels, Toyota’s Entune infotainment system with a 6.1-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, a rearview camera, keyless entry, 40/20/40 split-folding rear seats, a power liftgate, a multi-information display, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, cloth upholstery, and an eight-way power adjustable driver’s seat. The SR5 Premium adds leatherette upholstery, heated front seats, navigation, and a power-operated passenger seat. The Limited trim features more creature comforts like dual-zone climate control, leather upholstery, ventilated front seats, driver’s seat memory, 20-inch chrome alloy wheels, and a JBL premium audio system.</p>

<p>The TRD models come with features that improve off-road performance such as a locking rear differential, the Multi-Terrain Select System, Crawl Control, skid plates, off-road tires, a TRD-tuned suspension with Bilstein shocks, and Toyota’s Kinetic Dynamic Suspension system. The Limited trim also comes with a unique suspension setup that features a locking center-mounted limited-slip differential, the X-REAS Sport Enhancement Suspension, and full-time four-wheel drive with Active Traction Control.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Toyota 4Runner received a four-star overall safety score from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The 2018 model has yet to be tested by the IIHS but the 2017 4Runner received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except the front small overlap crash where it received a Marginal rating, and the headlights test where it got a Poor rating (Good is the highest possible score). No active safety features are available on the 2018 Toyota 4Runner.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/4runner/2017/2017-toyota-4runner-trd-pro-first-test-review/">a 2017 First Test review</a>, we were impressed with 4Runner’s off-road capability. Despite all of its credentials when the road ends, the 4Runner’s ride is comfortable on pavement, even in TRD Pro guise with knobby all-terrain tires. Handling, however, is sloppy due to the slow steering, and there’s plenty of dive when performing panic stops. The utilitarian cabin is dated with its ancient infotainment system and tiny touchscreen that’s clunky to use.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Toyota 4Runner is closely related to the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/gx/2018/">Lexus GX</a> and the global-market Land Cruiser Prado.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The refreshed <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/sequoia/2018/">2018 Toyota Sequoia</a> receives a new headlight design, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> Safety Sense-P suite of active safety features, and a new TRD Sport trim that comes with a new front grille, metallic black mirror caps, 20-inch alloy wheels, darkened rear taillight housing, TRD Sport shift knob, TRD Sport floor mats, TRD Sport sill protectors, Bilstein shocks, and TRD front and rear anti-roll bars. Three new colors, Midnight Black Metallic, Shoreline Blue Pearl, and Toasted Walnut Pearl, have been added.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/sequoia/2018/">Toyota Sequoia</a> is a full-size body-on-frame SUV that slots above the midsize, car-based Highlander. Rear-wheel drive is standard and four-wheel drive is optional.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Sequoia’s only engine is a 5.7-liter V-8 with 381 hp and 401 lb-ft of torque, and it’s paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. The EPA has yet to rate the 2018 Sequoia’s fuel economy but the 2017 model was rated at 13/17 mpg city/highway for rear- and four-wheel-drive variants.</p>

<p>When properly equipped, the 2018 Sequoia can tow up to 7,400 pounds of payload for rear-drive models or 7,200 pounds for four-wheel-drive models. There’s 18.9 cubic feet of cargo space behind the third row and it can be expanded to 66.6 cubic feet behind the second row and 120.1 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>Standard and available features include Toyota’s Entune multimedia interface, Bluetooth connectivity, a 4.2-inch multi-information display between the gauges, LED headlights, leather upholstery, and second row captain’s chairs.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Toyota Sequoia. Toyota’s Safety Sense-P suite of active safety and driver assistance features comes standard and includes automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, lane departure alert, and automatic high beams.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/sequoia/2017/2017-toyota-sequoia-4x4-platinum-first-test-size-matters/">2017 First Test of the pre-refresh model</a>, we said that the Sequoia’s standard V-8 engine offers plenty of power for hauling the massive SUV; however, its handling takes a hit because of its size and weight. As for comfort, the Sequoia offers large seats that are great for long road trips and it’s coupled with a smooth ride. The infotainment system, however, is old and isn’t up to par with newer units</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Toyota Sequoia is closely related to the Tundra full-size truck.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/prius/2018/">2018 Toyota Prius</a> gets a large 11.6-inch touchscreen option on the Four and Four Touring trims.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/prius/2018/">Toyota Prius</a> is a hybrid hatchback that slots above the smaller Prius C. A Touring model with a different suspension calibration is also available in the Three and Four grades, and is distinguished by the standard 17-inch alloy wheels and a higher-efficiency Eco model is also offered based on the Two trim. A plug-in variant called the Prius Prime is also available.</p>

<p><strong>Prius One:</strong> The base One grade comes with a rearview camera, full LED headlights, 15-inch alloy wheels, keyless entry and start, a customizable 4.2-inch instrument cluster display, cloth upholstery, and a 6.1-inch touchscreen.</p>

<p><strong>Prius Two:</strong> Moving up to the Two or Two Eco gets you a rear window wiper and a spare tire.</p>

<p><strong>Prius Three:</strong> Three variants get more features including navigation, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, the Entune app suite, padded upper door trims, and a wireless charging pad. Three Touring models also get 17-inch alloy wheels and leatherette upholstery as standard.</p>

<p><strong>Prius Four:</strong> The range-topping Four grade gets a large 11.6-inch touchscreen, heated front seats, and leatherette upper door trims and armrests. Four Touring models get the same 17-inch alloy wheels as the Three Touring.</p>

<p>Available options include a head-up display, automatic parking assist, and a JBL audio system.</p>

<p>Powering the 2018 Prius is a 1.8-liter I-4 paired to an electric motor, a CVT, and either a nickel-metal hydride battery in the base model or lithium-ion battery on higher grades. Total system output is 121 hp. EPA fuel economy ratings are 54/50 mpg city/highway for all but Prius Two Eco, which is even more efficient at 58/53 mpg.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> Prius received a five-star overall rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS testing it received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests except for the passenger side small front overlap impact, where it hasn’t been tested (Good is the highest possible score). On the new headlights test, the 2018 Prius received an Acceptable rating; as a result, it qualified for the IIHS’ Top Safety Pick rating.</p>

<p>On the IIHS’ front crash prevention test, the 2018 Prius received a Superior rating after it avoided collisions in 12- and 25-mph tests (Superior is the highest rating on the front crash prevention test). All 2018 Prius cars include Toyota Safety Sense-P (TSS-P), which bundles together adaptive cruise control, automatic high beams, lane departure warning with steering assist, pedestrian detection, forward collision warning, and automatic emergency braking. Blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert are standard on the Four and Four Touring models, and optional on the, Two, Two Eco, Three and Three Touring.</p>

<p>The 2018 Toyota Prius has 27.4 cubic feet of cargo space that can be expanded via the standard split-folding rear seats. The Two, Three, and Three Touring models have slightly less cargo capacity at 24.6 cubic feet.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/prius/2016/2016-toyota-prius-four-touring-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we said that the Prius handles surprisingly well and the steering is precise for a hybrid, but acceleration is sluggish. We noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/volt/2016/2016-chevrolet-volt-toyota-prius-best-way-to-use-gallon-of-gas/">2016 comparison test</a> against the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/volt/2018/">Chevrolet Volt</a> that the Prius’ interior gets noisy at higher speeds. Brake pedal feel can be unpredictable as a result of the car not having smooth transitions from regenerative to mechanical braking. In a 2017 comparison test against the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/ioniq/2018/">Hyundai Ioniq</a> Hybrid, the Toyota Prius won because it offered a smoother driving experience, superior fuel economy, and slightly better interior quality to justify its slightly higher price.</p>

<p>The hybrid system on the 2018 Prius is available on the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/c-hr/2018/">Toyota C-HR</a> outside of North America.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/highlander/2018/">2018 Toyota Highlander</a> is unchanged after a refresh in the 2017 model year.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/highlander/2018/">Toyota Highlander</a> is a three-row midsize crossover with seating for up to eight passengers. The crossover slotts above the compact RAV4 and below the full-size Sequoia. Front-wheel drive comes standard and all-wheel drive is optional. A hybrid variant is available and it comes with all-wheel drive standard. Another affordable <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a>-branded three-row vehicle is the Sienna minivan, which is also available with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Toyota Highlander offers three engine choices including a 2.7-liter I-4 185 hp and 184 lb-ft of torque, a 3.5-liter V-6 with 295 hp and 263 lb-ft, and a hybrid powertrain that combines the 3.5-liter V-6 with three electric motors, a CVT and a nickel metal hydride battery for a total output of 306 hp. A six-speed automatic is the only transmission available with the base four-cylinder engine and the V-6 comes exclusively with an eight-speed automatic.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings are 20/24 mpg city/highway for the front-drive four-cylinder model and 20/27 mpg for V-6 models with front-wheel drive. All-wheel drive models are rated at 20/27 mpg for the LE Plus, 19/26 mpg for the LE, and 20/26 mpg in the XLE, SE, Limited, and Limited Platinum trims. The most efficient Highlander is the Highlander Hybrid at 30/28 mpg for the LE Plus trim and 29/27 mpg for the XLE, Limited and Limited Platinum trims.</p>

<p>Cargo space is 13.8 cubic feet behind the third row, 42.3 cubic feet behind the second row and up to 83.7 cubic feet behind the front seats on the LE and LE Plus models. The XLE, SE and Limited trims have slightly less maximum cargo space at 83.2 cubic feet and adding the panoramic sunroof drops capacity even more to 82.6 cubic feet. When properly equipped, the four-cylinder Highlander can tow up to 1,500 pounds while the V-6-powered ones can tow 5,000 pounds. The Highlander Hybrid can only tow up to 3,500 pounds when properly equipped.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base Highlander <strong>LE</strong> trim includes 18-inch alloy wheels, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, cloth upholstery, 50/40 split-folding second- and third-row seats, keyless entry, five USB ports, Toyota’s Entune infotainment system with a 6.1-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity and a rearview camera. The Highlander <strong>LE Plus</strong> grade adds a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, tri-zone climate control, power adjustable front seats, and a leather-wrapped steering wheel. Jump up to the Highlander <strong>XLE</strong> trim and you get navigation, leather upholstery, heated front seats, a sunroof and keyless start. The Highlander <strong>SE</strong> trim features similar equipment as the XLE but adds sporty design cues like black leather upholstery with contrast stitching, a unique suspension tune and 19-inch alloy wheels finished in black.</p>

<p>Move up to Highlander <strong>Limited</strong> trim and it adds perforated leather upholstery, ventilated front seats, second-row captain’s chairs, a JBL premium audio system, 19-inch chrome-look alloy wheels, and LED accent strips on the headlights. The range-topping Highlander <strong>Limited Platinum</strong> gets a panoramic sunroof, dark chrome look 19-inch alloy wheels, a 360-degree view camera system, a heated steering wheel, and heated second-row seats. Second-row captain’s chairs are also available on the XLE trim while the rear-seat entertainment system is available on all but the LE and LE Plus models.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Highlander received a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS hasn’t tested the 2018 Highlander but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests and Acceptable on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Highlander received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the impact of a 25-mph impact by 24 mph (Superior is the highest possible rating on the front crash prevention test). As a result, the Toyota Highlander received the IIHS’ Top Safety Pick+ rating.</p>

<p>Standard on all 2018 Highlanders is Toyota Safety Sense-P, which bundles together forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning with steering assist, automatic high beams, and adaptive cruise control. Blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert is available only on the XLE, SE, Limited and Limited Platinum trims.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/highlander/2017/2017-toyota-highlander-se-awd-first-test/">2017 First Test</a>, we said that the SE trim’s sportier suspension tuning produces a harsher ride than in other variants with minimal improvements to handling. Throttle response wasn’t as responsive, as the eight-speed automatic always wanted to upshift to the highest gear and had a tendency to shuffle between gears even while cruising. Off pavement, the Highlander performed well and was able to handle dirt without getting bogged down too much.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-9/2016/2017-gmc-acadia-2016-mazda-cx-9-2017-toyota-highlander-comparison/">2016 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/gmc/acadia/2018/">GMC Acadia</a> and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-9/2018/">Mazda CX-9</a>, the Highlander placed second thanks to its powerful V-6 engine and roomy second row. The third row, however, isn’t comfortable for adults on a long drive, and some cheap materials scattered throughout the cabin kept it from getting the win.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>Two of the Toyota Highlander’s powertrain choices are shared with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/rx/2018/">Lexus RX</a> crossover.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/camry/2018/">2018 Toyota Camry</a> Hybrid is all-new and features a new exterior design, an updated infotainment system, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a>’s super efficient hybrid system. The car also rides on the new TNGA platform that underpins the Prius and the C-HR, which features a new fully independent suspension design with control arm rear suspension at the rear.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/camry/2018/">Toyota Camry</a> Hybrid is the hybrid variant of the Camry midsize sedan and it comes exclusively in a front-drive configuration. In terms of size, the Camry Hybrid slots above the more compact Prius hatchback and the Prius Prime plug-in hybrid but below the larger Avalon sedan.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/camry-hybrid/2018/">2018 Toyota Camry Hybrid</a> is powered by a new direct- and port-injected 2.5-liter I-4 that’s coupled to an electric motor, a lithium-ion or nickel metal hydride battery, and a CVT. Combined power output is 208 hp. EPA fuel economy ratings are 51/53 mpg city/highway in the base LE trim, which comes equipped with the lithium-ion battery, and 44/47 mpg on the SE and XLE grades, both of which use the nickel metal hydride battery.</p>

<p>Thanks to the TNGA platform, the Camry Hybrid’s batteries are now positioned under the rear seats, which means it now has the same 15.1-cubic-foot trunk as the gas-only variants and it can be expanded 60/40 split-folding rear seats. The gas-only Camry’s base L trim has the least cargo space at 14.1 cubic feet and doesn’t come with split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>The base Camry Hybrid <strong>LE</strong> trim comes with LED headlights, 16-inch steel wheels, dual-zone climate control, Toyota’s Entune infotainment system, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, a six-speaker audio system, a USB port, a rearview camera, cloth upholstery, 60/40 split-folding rear seats,  keyless entry/start, heated front seats, dual-zone climate control and a 4.2-inch multi-information display. Move up to the Camry Hybrid <strong>SE</strong> trim and you get 18-inch alloy wheels, leatherette upholstery, a rear spoiler and a Sport mode for the drive mode selector. The range-topping Camry Hybrid <strong>XLE</strong> trim gets a 7.0-inch multi-information display, leather upholstery, adjustable rear headrests, a 10-inch head-up display, two extra USB ports, and a chrome-tipped exhaust. Options include a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, a JBL premium audio system, a wireless phone charger, a 360-degree view camera system, and adaptive headlights.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Like its gas-only sibling, the entire 2018 Camry Hybrid lineup comes standard with Toyota Safety Sense-P, which bundles together forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, pedestrian detection, lane departure warning with steering assist, automatic high beams, and adaptive cruise control. Blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert comes standard on the XLE grade or as part of an optional package in the LE and SE trim. The XLE trim also gets rear automatic emergency braking as standard equipment.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/camry/2018/2018-toyota-camry-first-drive-review/">2018 First Drive review</a>, we said that the new Camry’s handling is much improved offers composed handling and a comfortable ride thanks to the new chassis. Steering, however, is light and doesn’t have much feel. The cabin is well-insulated thanks to generous amounts of sound deadening. Visibility is excellent thanks to the wide windows and low belt line. Toyota’s updated infotainment system is user-friendly but doesn’t come with support for Android Auto or Apple CarPlay.</p>

<p>Although the car doesn’t have as much power as the available V-6 engine, the Camry Hybrid still offers plenty of power, especially in Sport mode when the electric motor adds extra power. The CVT does a convincing job imitating gears in Sport mode with its quick upshifts; however, when you downshift, it doesn’t cause the car to decelerate much.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Camry Hybrid is the first to utilize the electrified version of Toyota’s Dynamic Force 2.5-liter I-4, which has a thermal efficiency of 41 percent in hybrid applications.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018<br/></strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/rav4/2018/">2018 Toyota RAV4</a> Hybrid gets a new exterior color, Ruby Flare Pearl, and optional heated front seats on the XLE trim.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/rav4/2018/">Toyota RAV4</a> Hybrid slots below the larger three-row Highlander Hybrid and comes standard with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/rav4-hybrid/2018/">2018 Toyota RAV4 Hybrid</a>’s powertrain system combines a 2.5-liter I-4, three electric motors, a nickel metal hydride battery, and a CVT. Combined output is 194 hp, making it more powerful than the gas-only RAV4, which has 176 hp and 172 lb-ft of torque. EPA fuel economy ratings for all variants are 34/30 mpg city/highway, making the RAV4 Hybrid one of the most efficient compact crossovers available. Despite the added hybrid powertrain components, cargo space is still generous at 35.6 cubic feet behind the split-folding second row and 70.6 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>Standard features on the hybrid model’s base XLE trim include 17-inch alloy wheels, a sunroof, dual-zone climate control, a rearview camera, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a>’s Entune infotainment system, a 6.1-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, cloth upholstery, and keyless entry/start. The SE trim adds LED headlights, 18-inch alloy wheels, leatherette upholstery, a power driver’s seat, and heated front seats. On the range-topping Limited trim, additional standard features include parking sensors, a height-adjustable power liftgate, a larger 7.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, and driver’s seat memory. A 360-degree camera system and a JBL premium audio system are optional on the SE and Limited trims. The higher end multimedia systems are available as part of optional packages on the XLE and SE grades.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 RAV4 Hybrid a five-star overall safety score (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test a 2018 RAV4 Hybrid but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crash worthiness tests and Average on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the RAV4 Hybrid received a Superior rating after it avoided 12-mph and 25-mph collisions (Superior is the highest possible score in the front crash prevention test). As a result, the IIHS gave the RAV4 Hybrid the 2017 Top Safety Pick+ award.</p>

<p>Standard on all 2018 RAV4 Hybrids is Toyota Safety-Sense-P, which bundles together automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, lane departure warning with steering assist, and automatic high beams. Blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert is standard on the SE and Limited trims and part of an optional package for the base XLE grade.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/rav4/2016/2016-toyota-rav4-hybrid-first-drive-review/">2016 First Drive</a> review, we noted that the RAV4 Hybrid features a vastly improved interior with higher quality materials and surprisingly punchy acceleration. The hybrid system also has a seamless interplay between the gas engine and electric motors, making it more refined on the road. We also said in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/rav4-hybrid/2016/2016-toyota-rav4-hybrid-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a> that despite the additional components of the hybrid powertrain, the cargo area remains spacious and family friendly, making the RAV4 Hybrid an excellent choice for hauling gear and people. The RAV4 Hybrid’s brakes are a standout since they transition smoothly from regenerative to mechanical braking.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/corolla/2018/">2018 Toyota Corolla</a> iM carries over unchanged.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/corolla/2018/">Toyota Corolla</a> iM is a compact front-drive four-door hatchback that slots above the subcompact Yaris.</p>

<p>Available as a single well-equipped trim, the 2018 Corolla iM comes standard with 17-inch alloy wheels, a chrome exhaust tip, LED daytime running lights, automatic headlights, dual-zone climate control, keyless entry, a rearview camera, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, a six-speaker Pioneer audio system, a USB port, Bluetooth, and a leather-wrapped steering wheel.</p>

<p>Navigation is available as an option. There are a number of accessories available in the 2018 Corolla iM that includes a roof spoiler and TRD goods such as a performance air filter.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/corolla-im/2018/">2018 Toyota Corolla iM</a> is powered by a 1.8-liter I-4 rated at 137 hp and 126 lb-ft of torque. A six-speed manual gearbox comes standard and a CVT is optional. EPA fuel economy estimates are 27/35 mpg city/highway with the manual and 28/36 mpg with the CVT.</p>

<p>The 2018 Corolla iM hasn’t been crash tested by the NHTSA. In IIHS testing, the 2018 Corolla iM has only been evaluated for side and moderate overlap front impact tests where it received a Good score (Good is the highest possible rating).</p>

<p>The hatchback’s front crash prevention features haven’t been tested yet but the IIHS gave the 2018 Corolla iM a Basic rating for front crash prevention for its standard forward collision warning system (Superior is the highest rating for front crash prevention). <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> Safety Sense-C comes standard on the 2018 Corolla iM and it bundles together automatic high beams, lane departure warning and the Pre-Collision System, which bundles together forward collision warning and automatic emergency braking.</p>

<p>There’s 20.8 cubic feet of cargo space and can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2016-scion-im-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we noted that the Corolla iM isn’t very quick, especially with a CVT. Even in Sport mode, which improves throttle response, the throttle response is better but the car is no quicker. The Corolla iM’s four-wheel independent suspension gives it a comfortable ride, making it a good car for commuting. Passenger space is generous up front and in the rear. The Corolla iM has a dated multimedia system and isn’t available with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto.</p>

<p>In other global markets, the Corolla iM is also called the Toyota Auris.</p>

<p> </p>

<p>The refreshed <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/prius/2018/">2018 Toyota Prius</a> C gets <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> Safety Sense-C, a rearview camera, black roof rails and black body cladding with silver accents as standard.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/prius/2018/">Toyota Prius</a> C is a subcompact hybrid hatchback that slots below the standard Prius hatchback and comes in four trims.</p>

<p><strong>Prius C One:</strong> The base One trim comes with 15-inch alloy wheels, black roof rails and body cladding, LED headlights, a rearview camera, cloth upholstery, a 3.5-inch instrument cluster display, keyless entry, four-way adjustable front seats, a 6.1-inch touchscreen, a four-speaker audio system, a USB port, and automatic climate control.</p>

<p><strong>Prius C Two:</strong> Moving up to the Two trim adds cruise control, six-way adjustable driver’s seat, and a six-speaker audio system.</p>

<p><strong>Prius C Three:</strong> Building on the Prius C Two, the Three grade adds navigation and keyless entry and star as standard.</p>

<p><strong>Prius C Four:</strong> The range-topping Four model gets leatherette upholstery, heated front seats, leatherette-wrapped steering wheel, fog lights, heated side mirrors, and a moonroof.</p>

<p>The moonroof is available on the Three trim as an option and the Four grade can be had with 16-inch alloy wheels.</p>

<p>The 2018 Prius C is powered by a hybrid system that couples a 1.5-liter I-4 with an electric motor, a CVT and a nickel metal-hydride battery. Total system output is 99 hp and the car is EPA-rated at 48/43 mpg city/highway.</p>

<p>The 2018 Toyota Prius C received a four-star overall rating (out of a possible four stars). In IIHS testing, the 2018 Prius C got a Good score on all but the driver’s side front small overlap test where it got an Acceptable rating (Good is the highest possible score). The 2018 Prius C hasn’t been crash tested for the passenger side front small overlap crash.</p>

<p>Toyota Safety Sense-C comes standard on the 2018 Prius C, which features lane departure warning and the Pre-Collision System that bundles together automatic emergency braking and forward collision warning.</p>

<p>The 2018 Prius C has 17.1 cubic feet of cargo space that can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/prius-c/2014/2014-toyota-prius-c-first-test/">2014 First Test</a>, we said that the Prius C’s acceleration is extremely sluggish and noted that the cabin is small. The car’s turning radius does increase when you opt for the optional 16-inch alloy wheels but the standard 15-inch units hurt its handling. Ride comfort also takes a hit with the 16-inch wheels.</p>

<p>Like the fourth-generation Prius, the smaller Prius C’s battery is placed under the rear seats to keep it from decreasing the car’s overall cargo capacity.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/avalon/2018/">2018 Toyota Avalon</a> is unchanged.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/avalon/2018/">Toyota Avalon</a> is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a>’s flagship front-drive full-size sedan slotting above the midsize Camry. In addition to the gas-only model, the Avalon is also available as a hybrid.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Toyota Avalon is available with two powertrain choices, a 3.5-liter V-6 with 268 hp and 248 lb-ft of torque paired to a six-speed automatic transmission or a hybrid system that couples a 2.5-liter I-4 to an electric motor, a CVT, and a nickel metal hydride battery for a total output of 200 hp. EPA fuel economy ratings for the 2018 are 21/30 mpg city/highway for the V-6 and 40/39 mpg for the hybrid. Trunk space in the gas-only Avalon is generous at 16 cubic feet, but the Avalon Hybrid only has 14 cubic feet due to extra powertrain components taking up space. Neither variant of the Avalon has split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base Avalon XLE trim include 17-inch alloy wheels, dual-zone climate control, Bluetooth connectivity, a multi-information display in between the gauges, keyless entry/start, a rearview camera, and Toyota’s Entune infotainment system with a 7.0-inch touchscreen. Higher trims can be had with navigation, a JBL premium audio system, perforated leather upholstery, heated and ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, a wireless phone charger, three-zone climate control, HID headlights, 18-inch alloy wheels, and a moonroof.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Toyota Avalon received a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 Avalon but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests and Acceptable on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Avalon received a Superior score after it avoided a 12-mph and 25-mph collision (Superior is the highest possible score for the front crash prevention test). As a result, the Toyota Avalon received the Top Safety Pick+ rating from the IIHS.</p>

<p>Toyota Safety Sense-P comes standard on all Avalon models. The safety tech package includes adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning with steering assist, automatic high beams, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, and automatic emergency braking. Blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert is available on all trims except the XLE and XLE Plus.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/taurus/2013/the-big-test-2013-2014-full-size-sedans/">2013 comparison test</a>, the Toyota Avalon placed third out of five cars thanks to its generous interior space, especially in the rear seats. However, interior material quality wasn’t as impressive and its ride wasn’t as composed and had a tendency to crash over bumps. The cabin also gets noisy over rough surfaces.</p>

<p>The hybrid variant offers strong acceleration and with the smaller 17-inch alloy wheels, features a ride that’s more buttoned down and composed, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2014-toyota-avalon-limited-hybrid-first-test/">2014 First Test.</a></p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Toyota Avalon features the same powertrain choices as the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/es/2018/">Lexus ES</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The refreshed <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/tundra/2018/">2018 Toyota Tundra</a> receives a slightly revised front fascia with a new grille and a new TRD Sport trim that comes with a hood scoop, 20-inch alloy wheels, a mesh grille, a TRD shift knob, TRD Sport floor mats, Bilstein shocks, and TRD front and rear anti-roll bars. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a>’s Safety Sense-P suite of active safety features now comes standard on all 2018 Tundra models.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/tundra/2018/">Toyota Tundra</a> is a full-size truck that slots above the midsize Tacoma and is available in three cab styles, two bed lengths, and in either rear- or four-wheel-drive configurations.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two engines are available in the 2018 Tundra including a 4.6-liter V-8 rated at 310 hp and 327 lb-ft of torque, and a 5.7-liter V-8 with 381 hp and 401 lb-ft. A six-speed automatic transmission is the only gearbox available. The EPA hasn’t released fuel economy ratings for the 2018 Tundra, but the 2017 model was rated at 15/19 mpg city/highway for rear-drive trucks with the base 4.6-liter V-8 or 14/18 mpg with four-wheel drive. The more powerful 5.7-liter unit was rated at 13/18 mpg for rear-drive models and 13/17 mpg with four-wheel drive equipped.</p>

<p>Depending on the cab style, bed length, engine and drivetrain, the 2018 Tundra can haul between 1,440 to 2,080 pounds of payload. When properly equipped, the truck has a towing capacity of 6,400 to 10,500 pounds depending on body style, drivetrain, engine and bed length.</p>

<p>Standard and available features include LED taillights, Bluetooth connectivity, Toyota’s Entune infotainment system, leather upholstery, alloy wheels up to 20 inches in diameter, a rearview camera, and a multi-information display in between the gauges.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Toyota Tundra. The outgoing 2017 Tundra received a four-star overall safety score from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). In IIHS evaluations, the extended cab variant received a Good score on all crash tests except the front small overlap test where in received a Marginal rating (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>Standard on all models is the Toyota Safety Sense-P suite of active safety features, which includes forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, automatic emergency braking, lane departure alert, adaptive cruise control, and automatic high beams.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/tundra/2015/2015-ram-1500-rebel-4x4-hemi-vs-2015-toyota-tundra-trd-pro-comparison/">2015 comparison test</a> against the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ram/1500/2018/">Ram 1500</a> Rebel, the Toyota Tundra TRD Pro won because it offered a comfortable ride and superior off-road capability all in one package. However, in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/tundra/2014/2014-toyota-tundra-1794-edition-crewmax-4x4-first-test/">2014 First Test</a>, we noted that the Tundra’s interior lacks insulation with plenty of exterior noise entering the cabin. Front seat comfort is also lacking as the seats are hard, flat, and lacking lateral support. Rear seat accommodations, on the other hand, proved generous and the available 5.7-liter V-8 has plenty of power on tap.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The base 4.6-liter V-8 in the 2018 Tundra is also used in the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/gx/2018/">Lexus GX</a> 460.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/86/2018/">2018 Toyota 86</a> gets a second trim level with more standard equipment—the new trim is similar to the 860 Edition from last year except for the stripes and the Supernova exterior color.</p>

<p>Formerly the Scion FR-S, the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/86/2018/">Toyota 86</a> is a rear-drive sports coupe that <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> co-developed with <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/">Subaru</a>.</p>

<p>The base trim comes with a leather-wrapped steering wheel, six-way driver’s seats, a four-way adjustable front seats, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, a rearview camera, cloth upholstery with suede-like inserts, keyless entry, a USB port, 17-inch alloy wheels, full LED headlights and an eight-speaker Pioneer audio system.</p>

<p>Higher-trim models get goodies like heated front seats, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, a rear spoiler, keyless start, fog lights and dual-zone climate control. Navigation is optional. A host of TRD accessories are also available for the 2018 86 including an exhaust system, cold air intake, air filter, lowering springs, 18-inch alloy wheels with staggered tires, and short shifter kit.</p>

<p>The 2018 86 is powered by a 2.0-liter flat-four rated at 205 hp and 156 lb-ft of torque with the standard six-speed manual transmission or 200 hp and 151 lb-ft with the optional six-speed automatic. EPA fuel economy ratings for the 2018 86 are 21/28 mpg city/highway with the manual or 24/32 mpg with the automatic.</p>

<p> </p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Toyota 86 a four-star frontal crash and five-star rollover rating (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 86 but the 2017 model received a Good score on all but the driver’s side front small overlap impact where it received an Acceptable rating and the passenger side small overlap where it hasn’t been tested yet (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>The 2018 86 has 6.9 cubic feet of trunk space and can be expanded via the standard folding rear seats.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/86/2017/2017-toyota-86-860-edition-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a>, we were impressed with the 86’s exceptional handling prowess thanks to its impeccably tuned chassis and precise steering. The standard six-speed manual transmission is easy to operate with its short, precise throws and a clutch with an engagement point that’s easy to find. However, there’s not much torque under 4,000 rpm, meaning you have to rev it high to get any power out of the engine.</p>

<p>Inside, there are hard plastics everywhere and the infotainment system is dated and slow to respond. Although it technically seats four, the small rear seats in the Toyota 86 are best used as an extension of the small trunk. Comfort is also a weak point because the 86’s stiff chassis means the car has a harsh ride over rough pavement.</p>

<p>The Toyota 86’s engine is a Subaru-designed flat-four equipped with Toyota’s D-4S direct- and port injection system.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/rav4/2018/">2018 Toyota RAV4</a> gets a new special-edition model called the RAV4 Adventure, which comes with the Tow Prep package, a higher ride height, 18-inch alloy wheels, lower body guards, black headlight bezels and fog light surrounds, a 120V power outlet in the cargo area, all-weather floor mats, special interior trim panels, and a leather-wrapped shift knob.</p>

<p>Additional new features for the 2018 RAV4 include a heated steering wheel, and optional heated and power operated front seats on lower-trim models with cloth upholstery.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/rav4/2018/">Toyota RAV4</a> is a compact crossover that slots below the larger, three-row Highlander and the above the new subcompact C-HR. Front-wheel drive is standard and all-wheel drive is optional. In addition to the gas-only model, the RAV4 is also available as a hybrid with all-wheel drive as standard.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>A 2.5-liter I-4 rated at 176 hp and 172 lb-ft of torque is the base engine in the 2018 RAV4 and it’s paired exclusively to a six-speed automatic transmission. The RAV4 Hybrid takes the 2.5-liter I-4 and pairs it to three electric motors for a total output of 194 hp and swaps the six-speed automatic in favor of a CVT. EPA fuel economy ratings for the 2018 RAV4 haven’t been released but the 2017 model was rated at 23/30 mpg city/highway for the front-drive LE and XLE, or 23/29 for the SE and Limited grades. Opting for all-wheel drive drops those numbers down to 22/28 mpg. The RAV4 Hybrid is the most fuel efficient at 34/30 mpg despite having the most power and all-wheel drive.</p>

<p>When properly equipped, the 2018 RAV4 can tow up to 1,500 pounds while the RAV4 Hybrid can haul 1,750 pounds. Cargo space is massive inside the RAV4 with 38.4 cubic feet behind the split-folding rear seats and 73.4 cubic feet behind the front seats. The RAV4 Hybrid has 2.8 cubic feet less cargo space across the board due to the additional powertrain components, checking in at 35.6 cubic feet behind the rear seats and 70.6 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>Standard and available features include Bluetooth connectivity, a rearview camera, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a>’s Entune infotainment system with a 6.1- or 7.0-inch touchscreen, a sunroof, 60/40 split-folding rear seats, a programmable power tailgate, LED headlights, 18-inch alloy wheels, a 360-degree view camera system, a 4.2-inch multi-information display in between the gauges, and leatherette upholstery. Unique to the SE trim is a sport-tuned suspension that slightly improves the RAV4’s handling.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 RAV4 but the outgoing 2017 model earned high marks. It received a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars) and the Top Safety Pick+ award from the IIHS after it scored Good on all crash tests, Superior on the front crash prevention test for avoiding a 12- and 25-mph collision, and an Acceptable in the new headlight safety test (Good is the highest possible score).</p>

<p>Starting from the 2017 model year, the Toyota RAV4 comes standard with Toyota Safety Sense-P, a suite of active safety and driver assistance features that include automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, adaptive cruise control, lane departure alert, and automatic high beams.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-5/2016/small-crossover-comparison-big-test/">2016 comparison test</a> that included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/tucson/2018/">Hyundai Tucson</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/cr-v/2018/">Honda CR-V</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-5/2018/">Mazda CX-5</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/forester/2018/">Subaru Forester</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/escape/2018/">Ford Escape</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/rogue/2018/">Nissan Rogue</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/sportage/2018/">Kia Sportage</a>, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/cherokee/2018/">Jeep Cherokee</a>, the Toyota RAV4 placed fifth. The crossover was praised for its spacious interior but the fit and finish lags behind its competitors due to the excessive amounts of low-quality materials. Handling also proved to be another RAV4 weak spot and we found the steering to be numb.</p>

<p>The RAV4 Hybrid, on the other hand, is a better package, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/rav4-hybrid/2016/2016-toyota-rav4-hybrid-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>, thanks to its smooth powertrain and well-calibrated brakes that smoothly transition between regenerative and mechanical braking. However, since it isn’t a plug-in hybrid, the RAV4 Hybrid doesn’t have much EV mode range and can only travel around 0.5 miles on electricity.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The SE is the only RAV4 trim level that can be had with a cool two-tone exterior color scheme.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/corolla/2018/">2018 Toyota Corolla</a> adds a leather-wrapped steering wheel for the SE and XLE trims. All models get an illuminated sunvisors for the driver and front passenger. The Corolla iM hatchback models carry over unchanged for the 2018 model year.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/corolla/2018/">Toyota Corolla</a> is a front-drive compact car that slots below the midsize Camry and above the subcompact Yaris. In addition to the sedan, the 2018 Corolla is also available as a hatchback called the <strong>Corolla iM</strong> (formerly the Scion iM), which comes as a single well-equipped package.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> Corolla is powered by a 1.8-liter I-4 with 132 hp and 128 lb-ft of torque. The engine is paired to a six-speed manual transmission or a CVT. In the Corolla Eco, that engine makes 140 hp and 126 lb-ft but it only comes with the CVT. The Corolla iM uses the same engine as the Corolla Eco sedan but rated slightly lower at 137 hp and 126 lb-ft. In the Corolla iM hatch, the engine can be paired to a six-speed manual or a CVT.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings are 27/35 mpg city/highway for manual-equipped Corolla sedans and the Corolla iM hatchback, and 28/36 mpg with the CVT. The Corolla Eco is the most efficient at 29/38 mpg with the 16-inch alloy wheels or 30/40 mpg with the 15-inch steel wheels. The Corolla sedan has a 13-cubic-foot trunk that can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats. For additional practicality, the Corolla iM features 20.8 cubic feet behind the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>Standard features on the 2018 Corolla sedan include 60/40 split-folding rear seats, a USB port, a rearview, Bluetooth connectivity, Toyota’s Entune infotainment system with a 6.1-inch touchscreen, LED headlights, 15-inch steel wheels, and cloth upholstery. Higher trims can be had with alloy wheels up to 17 inches in diameter, a moonroof, multi-beam LED headlights, leatherette upholstery, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, keyless entry/start, heated front seats, and navigation with a 7.0-inch touchscreen.</p>

<p>The Corolla iM hatchback comes standard with 17-inch alloy wheels, a rearview camera, dual-zone climate control, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, 60/40 split-folding rear seats, a 7.0-inch touchscreen, a six-speaker Pioneer audio system, Bluetooth connectivity, and a USB port. Navigation is optional along with a number of visual accessories.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Corolla sedan a five-star overall safety rating (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test a 2018 model but the 2017 Corolla received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests and Acceptable on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Corolla received a Superior rating after it avoided a 12-mph and a 25-mph collision (Superior is the highest possible score in the front crash prevention test). As a result, the Toyota Corolla sedan received the Top Safety Pick+ award from the IIHS. The Corolla iM hasn’t been crash tested by the NHTSA and IIHS.</p>

<p>Every 2018 Corolla sedan comes with standardToyota Safety Sense-P, which bundles together adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning with steering assist and automatic high beams. The Corolla iM comes with Toyota Safety Sense-C, which only comes with forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning, and automatic high beams.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/corolla/2017/2017-toyota-corolla-first-drive-review/">2017 First Drive</a> review, we said that during panic stops, the brakes don’t inspire much confidence and that its acceleration is sluggish. Interior space, on the other hand, is generous with plenty of rear-seat space and we appreciated that the car comes standard with advanced safety features.</p>

<p>The Corolla iM hatchback offers a more comfortable ride thanks to its independent rear suspension. However, we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2016-scion-im-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a> that it’s also slow because it still uses the same engine from the Corolla sedan. Cabin insulation is surprisingly good, with minimal noise entering the cabin. Like the Corolla sedan, the Corolla iM has a roomy cabin with plenty of space for all passengers and the hatch makes it even more practical.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Toyota Corolla’s 1.8-liter I-4 was originally introduced in the 10th generation model when it debuted for the 2008 model year.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/land-cruiser/2018/">2018 Toyota Land Cruiser</a> gets a standalone rear-seat entertainment system option.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/land-cruiser/2018/">Toyota Land Cruiser</a> is the range-topping four-wheel-drive SUV from <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> that slots above the full-size Sequoia. The Land Cruiser comes as a single fully loaded package with only one option, and the nameplate traces back to Toyota’s start in the U.S. decades ago.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Toyota Land Cruiser is powered by a 5.7-liter V-8 with 381 hp and 401 lb-ft of torque that’s paired to an eight-speed automatic transmission. EPA fuel economy ratings are 13/18 mpg city/highway. When properly equipped, the 2018 Land Cruiser can tow up to 8,100 pounds. Cargo space is respectable for a three-row SUV with 16.1 cubic feet behind the third row, 43 cubic feet behind the second row, and 81.7 cubic feet behind the front seats.</p>

<p>Standard features on the 2018 Land Cruiser include Toyota’s Kinetic Dynamic Suspension, Crawl Control, the Multi-Terrain Select System, full LED headlights, 18-inch alloy wheels, four-zone climate control, a wireless phone charger, heated and ventilated power adjustable front seats, heated second-row seats that split 40/20/40, 50/50 split-folding third row, leather upholstery, keyless entry/start, a JBL premium audio system, Toyota’s Entune infotainment system with navigation and a 9.0-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, a rearview camera, and front- and side-mounted cameras. The rear-seat entertainment system is the only option available.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Toyota Safety Sense-P is standard on all 2018 Land Cruisers. The package includes automatic high beams, adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, and automatic emergency braking. Blind-spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert also come standard on the 2018 Land Cruiser.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/land-cruiser/2016/jeep-wrangler-mercedes-benz-g550-toyota-land-cruiser-comparison/">2016 comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/g-class/2018/">Mercedes-Benz G-Class</a> and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/jeep/wrangler/2018/">Jeep Wrangler</a> Unlimited, the Toyota Land Cruiser won thanks to its impressive off-road capability and comfortable ride on the road. The SUV’s interior is also quiet and well-insulated; however, the brakes are touchy and the transmission is tuned for fuel economy. The interior, compared to the pre-facelift car, now has better quality materials and the 5.7-liter V-8 never feels like its struggling, as we noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/land-cruiser/2016/2016-toyota-land-cruiser-first-test-review/">2016 First Test</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Land Cruiser was one of the first Toyotas to receive Toyota Safety Sense-P as standard equipment.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/highlander/2018/">2018 Toyota Highlander</a> Hybrid is unchanged.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/highlander/2018/">Toyota Highlander</a> is currently the only mainstream hybrid three-row crossover available and it comes standard with all-wheel drive. There’s seating for up to eight passengers in the LE and XLE grades; however, the Limited only seats seven because it features second row captain’s chairs instead of a bench setup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>On the 2018 Highlander Hybrid, a 3.5-liter V-6 is coupled to three electric motors, a nickel metal hydride battery, and a CVT. Total system output is 306 hp, making the Highlander Hybrid one of the most powerful mainstream three-row midsize crossovers available. EPA fuel economy ratings are 30/28 mpg city/highway for the LE trim and 29/27 mpg for the XLE and Limited grades. Despite the additional components of the hybrid powertrain, the Highlander Hybrid still offers plenty of cargo space at 13.8 cubic feet behind the third row, 42.3 cubic feet behind the second row, and 83.7 cubic feet behind the front seats. When properly equipped, the Highlander Hybrid can tow up to 3,500 pounds.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base Highlander Hybrid <strong>LE</strong> trim include 18-inch alloy wheels, a rearview camera, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a>’s Entune infotainment system, a 6.1-inch touchscreen, a 4.2-inch multi-information display, cloth upholstery, keyless entry/start, five USB ports, and Bluetooth connectivity. The Highlander Hybrid <strong>XLE</strong> trim adds a height adjustable power liftgate, a sunroof, tri-zone climate control, an 8.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, leather upholstery, heated front seats, and an auto-dimming rearview mirror.</p>

<p>The range-topping Highlander Hybrid <strong>Limited</strong> trim comes with 19-inch alloy wheels, a JBL premium audio system, heated and ventilated front seats, blue LED interior ambient lighting, and a tonneau cover for the cargo area. Optional on the Limited trim is the <strong>Platinum</strong> package that adds a heated steering wheel, heated second-row captain’s chairs, and a 360-degree view camera system.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/highlander-hybrid/2018/">2018 Toyota Highlander Hybrid</a> received a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test a 2018 Highlander Hybrid but the 2017 model received a Good score on all crash worthiness tests and Average on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the 2017 model received a Superior rating after in avoided a 12-mph collision and reduced the speed of a 25-mph impact by 24 mph (Superior is the highest rating for the front crash prevention test). As a result, the IIHS awarded the Highlander Hybrid the Top Safety Pick+ award.</p>

<p>Toyota Safety Sense-P comes standard on all Highlander Hybrid models and it bundles together adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, pedestrian detection, lane departure warning with steering assist, and automatic high beams. Blind-spot warning and rear cross-traffic alert are standard on the XLE and Limited trims and unavailable on the base LE grade.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>We’ve yet to review a 2018 Highlander Hybrid but on our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/highlander/2014/2014-toyota-highlander-35-fwd-hybrid-awd-first-test/">First Test of the pre-refresh model</a>, we noted that the hybrid variant was slower than the gas-only Highlander in a straight line. We also found it hard to keep the Highlander Hybrid in EV mode without causing the gas engine to kick in. Lower trims feature lower-quality plastics throughout the cabin, but higher grade models have better quality materials, making it feel more premium. The third row is best used for short trips as it’s not very comfortable for adults.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/highlander-hybrid/2018/">Toyota Highlander Hybrid</a>’s hybrid system is shared with the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/lexus/rx/2018/">Lexus RX</a> 450h.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The Prius Prime does not receive any significant changes for the new model year.</p>

<p>The four-passenger Prius Prime is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a>’s only plug-in vehicle and the most expensive model in the Prius family that also includes the Prius C, Prius liftback, and Prius V wagon.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Prius Prime Plus</strong>: The Prime comes standard with 15-inch alloy wheels, quad-LED projector headlights, LED daytime running lights, LED taillights, charge port with illumination and charge indicator light, a 7.0-inch center display with Entune Premium Audio with navigation and SiriusXM satellite radio, a 4.2-inch instrument panel driver’s display, remote climate control, a six-way manually adjustable driver’s seat (four-way for passenger), heated front seats, quick entry with push-start ignition, and the Toyota Safety Sense P package of driver assist safety features.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Prius Prime Premium</strong>: Moving up to the Premium adds automatic headlights, a charging cable lock, a large 11.6-inch center display (same Entune system), SoftTex-trimmed (synthetic leather) seats, eight-way power driver’s seat, and a wireless charging pad.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Prius Prime Advanced</strong>: Building off the Premium trim, the top Advanced trim adds LED fog lights and accents lights, rain-sensing windshield wipers, Entune Premium JBL Audio with Prime Apps and a 10-speaker JBL GreenEdge audio system, a heated steering wheel, an auto-dimming rearview mirror, Safety Connect remote vehicle assistance, a color head-up display, a self-parking system, front and rear parking sensor with automatic reverse braking, and blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/prius/2018/">2018 Toyota Prius</a> Prime’s hybrid powertrain consists of a 95-hp, 105-lb-ft of torque 1.8-liter I-4 engine paired to two electric motors for a total system output of 121 hp. A CVT routes power to the front wheels. The Prius Prime delivers an EPA-rated (2017 figures) 55/53 mpg city/highway when in hybrid mode and can travel up to 25 miles on all-electric power (133 mpg-e combined). The Prime has a long driving range of 640 miles based on 45-percent highway and 55-percent city driving. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/prius/2018/">Toyota Prius</a> Prime hit 60 mpg in a slow 10.0 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in 125 feet.</p>

<p>The NHTSA did not evaluate the Prime model, but the regular 2018 Prius liftback received the highest overall rating of five stars. The 2018 Prius Prime is considered a 2018 Top Safety Pick from the IIHS for receiving the highest rating of Good in all conducted crash tests, the second-highest rating of Acceptable for the headlights evaluation, and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention test by avoiding 12- and 25-mph frontal collisions thanks to the automatic emergency braking feature with pedestrian detection found in the standard Toyota Safety Sense P package of driver assist safety features. Safety Sense P also includes lane departure alert with steering assist, automatic high beams, and adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/prius-prime/2018/">2018 Toyota Prius Prime</a> offers up to 19.8 cubic feet of cargo space under its hatch, almost doubling the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/volt/2018/">Chevrolet Volt</a>’s 10.6 cubic feet. The regular Prius liftback holds between 24.6 and 27.4 cubic feet of cargo. Front and rear legroom is 43.2 inches and 33.4 inches, respectively, the same as the traditional Prius.</p>

<p>Standard tech found in the Prime Plus includes Entune Premium Audio with navigation displayed on a 7.0-inch center screen, SiriusXM satellite radio, and Siri Eyes Free. In the Premium trim, the screen is upgraded to 11.6 inches and a wireless phone charging pad is added. The top Entune Premium JBL Audio system found in the Advanced trim adds Prime Apps (on top of the App Suite) and a 10-speaker JBL GreenEdge audio system. The Advanced trim also adds a color head-up display, a self-parking system, front and rear parking sensors, and blind-spot monitoring with rear-cross traffic alert on top of the standard Safety Sense P package. With the standard remote climate control system, passengers can check and adjust the Prime’s temperature and with Prime Apps, passengers can find their vehicle, find a charging station, see the battery’s charge status, and much more. Safety Connect offers emergency assistance, stolen vehicle locator, roadside assistance, and automatic collision notification.</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/prius-prime/2017/2017-toyota-prius-prime-first-drive-review/">First Drive</a> review of the 2017 Prius Prime, we like the longer all-electric driving range versus the outgoing Prius plug-in. The Prime provides decent handling dynamics, quick initial acceleration, and a better ride than the standard Prius. The rear seats only fit two passengers but offer plenty of space. Due to the larger battery, there is less cargo room, a hump of about one inch in the cargo floor, and an uneven load floor with the seatbacks down. We were impressed with the optional 11.6-inch center display, the carbon-fiber reinforced rear hatch, and Toyota’s standard Safety Sense P package.</p>

<p>We concluded by saying, “Toyota seems to have the ingredients for a good argument here. The Prime finally has (just) enough battery for most folks’ needs and provides a proper EV experience—with it all backed up by the world’s most popular hybrid mode.”</p>

<p>In a comparison <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/bolt-ev/2017/hyundai-ioniq-hybrid-vs-toyota-prius-chevrolet-volt-vs-prius-prime-bolt-ev-vs-ioniq-ev-vs-honda-clarity-vs-mirai/">between the Prius Prime and Chevrolet Volt</a>, we liked that if you floor the Prime in EV mode, the engine will not turn on until you hit 84 mph. The larger battery pack adds weight to the rear and that can be felt when cornering and can make the Prius heave over road undulations. “So despite the Prius Prime’s peculiarities (the recorded piano accompaniment to ingress and egress sounds like the sappy soundtrack to a daytime soap opera), its usability, packaging, acceptable EV range, and much better hybrid-mode mileage give it the edge,” we concluded.</p>

<p><strong>New for 2018 </strong></p>

<p>Everything. Although the standard-wheelbase <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/u-s-spec-2018-volkswagen-tiguan-revealed-at-detroit/">2018 Volkswagen Tiguan</a> will be available in most markets, the U.S.-spec model will only be available in the long-wheelbase version. That wheelbase stretch allows for a sliding second-row bench (split 40:20:40) as well as optional third-row seating.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/tiguan/2018/">2018 Volkswagen Tiguan</a> is the automaker’s entry-level crossover and slots below the three-row <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/atlas/2018/">Volkswagen Atlas</a> family crossover and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/touareg/2018/">Volkswagen Touareg</a> luxury crossover.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>Power for the 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/tiguan/2018/">Volkswagen Tiguan</a> comes from the automaker’s turbocharged 2.0-liter TSI I-4 making 184 hp and 221 lb-ft of torque. An eight-speed automatic routes power to the available 4Motion all-wheel-drive system with four driving modes for various terrain.</p>

<p>The brand’s current styling has found its way to the exterior and interior. Standard and optional features include LED exterior lighting and a fully digital and reconfigurable display.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/">Volkswagen</a> Tiguan (and new Atlas) have a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2018-volkswagen-atlas-tiguan-get-longer-bumper-to-bumper-warranties/">transferable 6-year/72,000-mile bumper-to-bumper warranty</a>. That’s double the warranties from <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a>, or <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a>, and still more than the 5-year/60,000-mile warranty of <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/">Hyundai</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/">Kia</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Standard safety features include rearview camera and Automatic post-Collision Braking System, while the list of available active safety and driver assist tech includes adaptive cruise control, Forward Collision Warning and Autonomous Emergency Braking (Front Assist) with Pedestrian Monitoring; Blind Spot Monitor with Rear Traffic Alert; and a lane departure assist system that can steer the car back in its lane.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>
