<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/jetta/2018/">2018 Volkswagen Jetta</a> gets a new Wolfsburg variant that comes with 16-inch alloy wheels, heated front seats, leatherette upholstery, GLI bumpers, a leather shift knob and hand brake, black side mirror covers, and a Wolfsburg badge in the B-pillar. The S, SEL, and GLI gets new alloy wheel designs and the S, SE, and SEL gets a new chrome grille. SEL models now come with a rear spoiler and the Fender premium audio system. The Sport grade adds 17-inch alloy wheels, a rear spoiler, black side mirror covers, a black headliner, black interior trim, a sunroof, and blind-spot warning.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/jetta/2018/">Volkswagen Jetta</a> is a front-drive compact sedan that slots below the midsize Passat and serves as the brand’s entry-level sedan. A performance variant called the Jetta GLI is also available for those seeking a spicier compact sedan.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Three turbocharged four-cylinder engines are available in the 2018 Jetta. The base S and SE trims comes with a 1.4-liter unit with 150 hp and 184 lb-ft of torque that can be paired to a five-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission. On the Sport and SEL trims, the Jetta gets a 1.8-liter with 170 hp and 184 lb-ft that’s coupled exclusively to a six-speed automatic. At the top of the range is the Jetta GLI, which comes with a 2.0-liter unit with 210 hp and 207 lb-ft paired to either a six-speed manual or six-speed dual-clutch automatic. There’s 15.7 cubic feet of cargo space in the trunk and it can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>The base S trim comes with 15-inch steel wheels, Bluetooth connectivity, 60/40 split-folding rear seats, LED daytime running lights, a 5.0-inch touchscreen, a rearview camera, a USB port, and cloth upholstery. The SE trim adds keyless entry/start, leatherette upholstery, blind spot warning, heated front seats, leatherette upholstery, 16-inch alloy wheels, and a sunroof. Moving up to the Sport trim adds fog lights, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration, a 6.3-inch touchscreen, navigation, 17-inch alloy wheels, and a rear spoiler. The SEL trim builds on the Sport trim and adds dual-zone climate control, a power driver’s seat, a Fender premium audio system, adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, and automatic emergency braking. The Jetta GLI comes with similar features as the SEL trim but it doesn’t have any driver assistance features other than blind-spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, and parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Jetta received a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test a 2018 Jetta but a 2017 model received a Good score on all crash tests and Acceptable in the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the 2018 Jetta received an Advanced rating after it reduced the impact of a 12-mph collision by 9 mph, but didn’t reduce speed at all in a 25-mph test (Superior is the highest rating for front crash prevention).</p>

<p>On higher trims, the 2018 Jetta comes with forward collision warning, adaptive cruise control, automatic emergency braking, blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, and parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=2222036&amp;action=edit">recent compact car comparison test</a> that also included the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2018/">Honda Civic</a>, Mazda3, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/elantra/2018/">Hyundai Elantra</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/cruze/2018/">Chevrolet Cruze</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/corolla/2018/">Toyota Corolla</a>, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/sentra/2018/">Nissan Sentra</a>, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/">Volkswagen</a> Jetta placed fifth in part because its interior didn’t feel as solid as other Volkswagen models.</p>

<p>We noted in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/jetta/2016/2016-volkswagen-jetta-14t-first-test-review/">2016 First Test </a>that the new base 1.4-liter turbo-four in the Jetta offers plenty of torque for strong acceleration; however, there’s plenty of road noise entering the cabin and the ride isn’t very comfortable at low speeds. Handling, on the other hand, is respectable, as the Jetta stays composed on turns and the steering is responsive.</p>

<p>As we wrote in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/jetta/2015/2015-volkswagen-jetta-first-drive/">2015 First Drive</a>, the optional 170-hp 1.8-liter turbo-four offers plenty of power on tap and the six-speed automatic shifts smartly. Despite its age, the Jetta’s infotainment system is easy to use and there’s plenty of space for front and rear passengers in the cabin.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Jetta is the first vehicle in the U.S. to use Volkswagen’s new 1.4-liter turbo-four.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/passat/2018/">2018 Volkswagen Passat</a> gets a new GT trim for V-6-equipped cars that comes with a sport suspension, R-Line bumpers and grille, 19-inch alloy wheels, dual exhausts with unique tuning, and red brake calipers. A new 2.0-liter turbo-four replaces the old 1.8-liter turbo-four as the new base engine.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/passat/2018/">Volkswagen Passat</a> is a front-drive midsize sedan that slots above the compact Jetta and below the upcoming, near-luxury Arteon.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two engines are available in the 2018 Passat including a 2.0-liter turbo-four that is estimated to have 174 hp and 184 lb-ft of torque or a 3.6-liter V-6 with 280 hp and 258 lb-ft of torque. A six-speed automatic transmission is standard on the base 2.0-liter turbo-four while the V-6 comes with a six-speed dual-clutch automatic. EPA fuel economy ratings are 25/36 mpg city/highway for the four-cylinder and 20/28 mpg with the V-6. Trunk space is 15.9 cubic feet and can be expanded via the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base <strong>S</strong> trim include automatic headlights, 16-inch alloy wheels, Bluetooth connectivity, a USB port, a rearview camera, dual-zone climate control, a 5.0-inch touchscreen, and cloth upholstery. The <strong>R-Line</strong> trim adds unique bumpers, 19-inch alloy wheels, blind-spot warning, heated front seats, power driver’s seats, blind-spot warning, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, and leatherette upholstery. On the <strong>SE</strong> trim, it gets 17-inch alloy wheels, sunroof, a 6.3-inch touchscreen, and keyless entry/start. The Technology package for the SE trim adds navigation, adaptive cruise control and park assist while the Lighting package adds LED headlights and taillights. <strong>SEL Premium</strong> models get LED headlights, power-folding side mirrors, 18-inch alloy wheels, a Fender premium audio system, leather upholstery, navigation and heated rear seats.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/">Volkswagen</a> Passat received a five-star overall safety rating from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). Although the IIHS has yet to test the 2018 model, the 2017 Passat received a Good score on all crash tests and Poor on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the 2017 Passat received an Advanced rating after it avoided a 12-mph collision but didn’t reduce the speed at all in a 25 mph test (Superior is the highest rating for front crash prevention). As a result, it was able to get the Top Safety Pick rating from the IIHS.</p>

<p>Standard on all 2018 Passats is forward collision warning and automatic emergency braking. Higher trim levels can be had with blind-spot warning, lane keep assist, rear cross-traffic alert, adaptive cruise control, and parking assist.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>We’ve yet to review the 2018 Passat with the new 2.0-liter base engine but in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/passat/2016/2016-volkswagen-passat-review/">2016 First Test</a>, we noted that the Passat’s interior is spacious and has user-friendly center stack controls. Handling is respectable for its size but it falls slightly short of sportier entries such as the Mazda6. On the road, there’s minimal road and wind noise, making the Passat’s cabin a nice place to be. As for the exterior styling, even after 2016-model-year updates, its exterior design is still on the conservative side in its segment.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The current-generation Volkswagen Passat was the first vehicle to roll out of Volkswagen’s Chattanooga, Tennessee assembly plant.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p><a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/u-s-spec-2018-volkswagen-golf-revealed-ahead-of-new-york/">The Volkswagen Golf gets a mid-cycle update for the 2018 model year</a>. The most notable changes include the discontinuation of the two-door model as well as the availability of the new Discover Media navigation infotainment system with 8.0-inch touchscreen. Other updates include revised exterior styling front and rear. All-wheel drive is now available on the base Golf SportWagen S model.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The compact <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/golf/2018/">Volkswagen Golf</a> hatchback and Golf SportWagen slot next to the Jetta sedan below the midsize CC and Passat sedans in the automaker’s lineup. The Golf is offered in several variants including hatchback, SportWagen, and raised Alltrack (crossover-like wagon) body styles as well as the GTI and Golf R hot hatches, and the electric e-Golf.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The base engine in the Golf lineup is the automaker’s turbocharged 1.8-liter I-4 that makes 170 hp and 199 lb-ft of torque. The turbo-four is mated to a five-speed manual or six-speed automatic in the hatchback or a six-speed manual or six-speed dual-clutch automatic in the Golf SportWagen or <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/golf-alltrack/">Golf Alltrack</a> model. Front-drive is standard on the hatchback and SportWagen, while all-wheel-drive is optional on the SportWagen and standard on the Alltrack.</p>

<p>The sporty <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/">Volkswagen</a> Golf GTI is powered by a turbocharged 2.0-liter I-4 making 220 hp and 258 lb-ft and is mated to a six-speed manual or six-speed dual-clutch transmission. The former Performance package is now standard and includes VAQ differential and larger brake pads. A DCC adaptive suspension is only offered on the Autobahn trim.</p>

<p>At the top of the Golf food chain is the Golf R with a 292-hp version of the turbocharged 2.0-liter, which is mated to either a six-speed manual or seven-speed dual-clutch transmission that sends power to all four wheels. The DCC adjustable suspension and navigation are optioned together.</p>

<p>Android Auto and Apple CarPlay are available on even the base model. Other standard features include automatic headlights, rain-sensing wipers, and a 6.5-inch touchscreen. Optional equipment includes keyless entry/start, 8.0-inch touchscreen, navigation, LED headlights, and more.</p>

<p>Before the Golf was refreshed, the model was the 2015 Motor Trend Car of the Year. We appreciated the Golf’s many engine options and various body styles, as well as how each one drove. Learn more about why it won <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2015-volkswagen-golf-is-the-motor-trend-car-of-the-year/">right here</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The Golf SE comes with blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, and front assist with pedestrian detection, while the SEL adds adaptive cruise control. Lane keeping assist, automatic high beams, parking sensors, and park assist are part of a package.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact: </strong></p>

<p>The top-spec Golf R features Volkswagen’s reconfigurable Digital Cockpit with a 12.3-inch multi-function display.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Everything. The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/volkswagen-crossblue-concept-first-look/">2018 Volkswagen Atlas</a> is an all-new model for the 2018 model year. Though the SUV shares its MQB chassis and drivetrains with other <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/">Volkswagen</a> Group products, this is the brand’s first three-row crossover offered in the U.S.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/atlas/2018/">Volkswagen Atlas</a> is the German automaker’s all-new three-row midsize crossover that, in size, slots above the two-row midsize Touareg and compact Tiguan SUVs as well as the Golf Alltrack and Golf SportWagen in the automaker’s people and cargo carrying lineup. The Atlas competes in a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/styling-size-2018-volkswagen-atlas-vs-midsize-suv-competition/">crowded segment that includes</a> the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/explorer/2018/">Ford Explorer</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/chevrolet/traverse/2018/">Chevrolet Traverse</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/pilot/2018/">Honda Pilot</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/nissan/pathfinder/2018/">Nissan Pathfinder</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/highlander/2018/">Toyota Highlander</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mazda/cx-9/2018/">Mazda CX-9</a>, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/dodge/durango/2018/">Dodge Durango</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Atlas comes standard with a turbocharged 2.0-liter I-4 rated at 235 hp and 258 lb-ft of torque, while a 3.6-liter VR6 rated at 276 hp and 266 lb-ft is optional. Both engines use an eight-speed automatic transmission. Front-drive is standard with both engines, and the automaker’s 4Motion all-wheel-drive system is optional with the 3.6-liter engine. EPA-rated fuel economy hasn’t been revealed for the turbo 2.0-liter, but the 3.6-liter is EPA-rated 18/25 mpg city/highway for the front-drive model and 17/23 mpg with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p>With 153.7 cubic-feet of interior volume, the <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/atlas/2018/2018-volkswagen-atlas-first-look-three-row-cuv-debuts-massive-interior/">Atlas has impressive interior dimensions</a> for the segment. Other interior features include the automaker’s latest touchscreen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay Android Auto, and MirrorLink connectivity. A digital instrument panel and Fender audio system are also available.</p>

<p>If you’re looking for a sportier look, Volkswagen will offer a ritzy <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2018-volkswagen-atlas-gets-r-line-exterior-package/">R-Line trim package</a> with unique details.</p>

<p><strong>May</strong><strong> 2017 Update: </strong>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/atlas/2018/">2018 Volkswagen Atlas</a> (and redesigned 2018 Tiguan) will have a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2018-volkswagen-atlas-tiguan-get-longer-bumper-to-bumper-warranties/">transferable 6-year/72,000-mile bumper-to-bumper warranty</a>. Competitors such as <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/ford/">Ford</a>, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/">Honda</a>, and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/toyota/">Toyota</a> offer 3-year/36,000-mile warranties, while <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/hyundai/">Hyundai</a> and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/kia/">Kia</a> offer 5-year/60,000-mile basic warranties.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>Active safety and driver assistance tech includes adaptive cruise control, blind-spot monitoring, forward collision prevention, lane keeping assist, post-collision braking, and a parking assistant. Other safety features include standard LED headlights and available LED taillights.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>We haven’t yet driven a production 2018 Volkswagen Atlas, but we did have the opportunity to <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2018-volkswagen-b-suv-first-drive-big-hitter/">drive a pre-production mule before the Atlas name was announced</a>. About that prototype, we said it felt “big and substantial.”</p>

<p>“A broad, flat hood stretches way out ahead,” we wrote, “announcing to all (especially the owner) that this ain’t no minivan derivative. You can’t see the ground right in front of the vehicle, but a 360-degree around-view camera system helps when maneuvering in tight quarters. In highway mode, the VR6 accelerated the B up to gravel-road speeds with reasonable authority—at least with two people aboard.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>LED headlights, Bluetooth, Apple CarPlay, and Android Auto are all standard.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/golf/2018/">2018 Volkswagen Golf</a> GTI has been refreshed with an updated exterior design, a new multimedia system with a larger touchscreen, and more power on the base trim. The high-performance Golf R also gets new standard features including <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/">Volkswagen</a>’s Digital Cockpit and an optional seven-speed dual-clutch automatic replacing the six-speed unit.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/golf/2018/">Volkswagen Golf</a> GTI is the performance-focused variant of the Golf hatchback and slots above the less potent standard model. In addition to the front-drive <strong>GTI</strong>, the <strong>Golf R</strong> model has more power and comes standard with all-wheel drive.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Golf GTI’s 2.0-liter turbo-four is rated at 220 hp and 258 lb-ft of torque, and can be paired to a standard six-speed manual transmission or an optional six-speed dual-clutch automatic. A 2.0-liter turbo-four also powers the 2018 Golf R but is rated at 292 hp and 280 lb-ft. Transmission choices for the Golf R include a standard six-speed manual or a new-to-the-model seven-speed dual-clutch automatic.</p>

<p>The EPA hasn’t rated the 2018 Golf GTI for fuel economy yet but the 2017 model was rated at 24/34 mpg city/highway with the manual and 24/32 mpg with the automatic. The more powerful Golf R is rated at 21/29 mpg with the manual and 22/29 mpg with the automatic. Thanks to their hatchback body style, the 2018 Golf GTI and Golf R can double as small family cars with 22.8 cubic feet of cargo space behind the standard 60/40 split-folding rear seats and that can be expanded to a generous 52.7 cubic feet with the second row folded.</p>

<p>Standard features on the base S trim include LED taillights, a 6.5-inch touchscreen, automatic high beams, auto engine stop/start (with the automatic only), 18-inch alloy wheels, plaid cloth upholstery, LED fog lights, as well as Android Auto and Apple CarPlay integration. The SE trim adds a larger 8.0-inch touchscreen, an electronically controlled limited-slip differential, full LED headlights and keyless entry/start. Additional standard features on the Autobahn trim include navigation, Dynamic Chassis Control, 12-way power driver’s seat, a panoramic sunroof, adaptive cruise control, and a Fender premium audio system.</p>

<p>The Golf R comes standard with features like Volkswagen’s Digital Cockpit, full LED headlights, 18-inch alloy wheels, keyless entry/start, heated front seats, a 12-way power driver’s seat, and leather upholstery. Move up to the DCC with Navigation trim and the Golf R gets 19-inch alloy wheels, adaptive cruise control, a Fender premium audio system, navigation, blind-spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, lane keeping assist, high beam assist, Dynamic Chassis Control, and automatic parking assist.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA gave the 2018 Golf GTI and Golf R a five-star overall safety rating (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test the 2018 Golf GTI but a 2017 model received a Good score on all crashworthiness tests and a Poor score on the headlights test (Good is the highest possible score). In the front crash prevention test, the Golf GTI only received an Advanced rating after it reduced the impact speed of a 12-mph collision by 10 mph and a 25-mph impact by 1 mph (Superior is the highest possible score for the front crash prevention test).</p>

<p>On the SE trim and higher, the Golf GTI comes standard with automatic emergency braking, forward collision warning, pedestrian detection, blind-spot warning, and rear cross-traffic alert. Adaptive cruise control is only available on the range-topping Autobahn trim where it comes standard. The Driver Assistance package on the Autobahn trim adds lane keeping assist, automatic park assist, and high beam assist. The Golf R is also available with the same active safety features as the GTI but they’re exclusive to models equipped with Dynamic Chassis Control and navigation where they come standard.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>Although we haven’t tested the 2018 Golf GTI, we have reviewed the pre-refresh model. In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/gti/2015/comparison-four-fun-sporty-runabouts-under-30000/">2014 comparison test</a> that also included the Mini Hardtop Cooper S, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/subaru/wrx/2018/">Subaru WRX</a>, and the previous generation <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/civic/2018/">Honda Civic</a> Si, the Volkswagen Golf GTI won thanks to its blend of daily drivability and performance. At the track, the Golf GTI proved to be an excellent companion thanks to its sporty chassis and a stability control system that wasn’t very intrusive. Despite its excellent handling, the Golf GTI doesn’t have a rough ride and is surprisingly comfortable as a daily driver. Overall, the car feels more expensive than it actually is.</p>

<p>The more powerful Golf R won a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/golf/2015/2015-subaru-wrx-sti-vs-2015-volkswagen-golf-r/">2015 comparison test</a> against the WRX STI because that pre-refresh model takes the GTI formula up a notch but doesn’t come at the cost of daily drivability. At the track, however, the Golf R understeers too much when pushed to its limit. Out on public roads, the Golf R shined because it felt composed and stable thanks to its solid chassis.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The original Volkswagen Golf GTI arguably invented the hot hatch segment when it first debuted in the mid-1970s; however, the U.S. market didn’t get the Golf GTI until the second-generation model arrived in the 1980s.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>A new 2.0-liter turbo-four replaces the old 1.8-liter unit as the new base engine in the 2018 Beetle. The base S trim gets a new Style &amp; Comfort package that adds automatic headlights, rain-sensing wipers and keyless entry. There’s also a new Coast special edition model that features a unique Deep Sea Teal exterior color, Heritage alloy wheels, blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, and plaid seats. The SE trim gets additional standard features including automatic climate control and a sunroof.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/beetle/2018/">2018 Volkswagen Beetle</a> is a front-drive compact car available in two body styles, a two-door coupe with a hatch or a convertible with a power-operated soft top.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>Two 2.0-liter turbo-fours are offered in the 2018 Beetle. On the S, SE, SEL, Coast, and Dune models, it’s rated at 174 hp and 184 lb-ft of torque and comes exclusively with a six-speed automatic transmission. The R-Line model has more power at 210 hp and 207 lb-ft, and comes exclusively with a six-speed dual-clutch automatic.</p>

<p>EPA fuel economy ratings for the base 2.0-liter turbo-four are 26/34 mpg city/highway for the coupe and 26/33 mpg for the convertible. The more powerful R-Line is the least efficient Beetle at 23/29 mpg. Behind the 50/50 split-folding rear seats there’s 15.4 cubic feet of cargo space that can be expanded to 29.9 cubic feet. The convertible has less cargo capacity at 7.1 cubic feet.</p>

<p>The base Beetle S trim receives a five-inch touchscreen, 16-inch alloy wheels, a USB port, Bluetooth connectivity, a rearview camera, automatic headlights, a rear spoiler, cloth upholstery, and 50/50-split folding rear seats. Jump up to the SE trim and you get 17-inch alloy wheels, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, a 6.3-inch touchscreen, keyless entry/start, heated front seats, a secondary glove box, and leatherette upholstery. The SEL trim adds a panoramic sunroof, navigation, parking sensors, 18-inch alloy wheels, a Fender premium audio system, dual-zone climate control, blind-spot warning, and rear cross-traffic alert.</p>

<p>Beetle <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/beetle/2017/2017-volkswagen-beetle-dune-convertible-first-test-review/">Dune</a> variants get unique bumpers, a raised suspension with a wider track, unique 18-inch alloy wheels, two-tone leatherette upholstery, front sport seats, and LED taillights. R-Line models get HID headlights, sportier front and rear bumpers, a sport suspension, 20-inch alloy wheels, and leather upholstery on top of the standard features found on the SEL grade. Lower trims can get a lighting package that adds LED taillights, LED daytime running lights, and HID headlights.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Beetle coupe received a four-star rating in the front crash and rollover tests from the NHTSA (out of a possible five stars). The IIHS has yet to test a 2018 Beetle but a 2017 model received a Good rating on all but the small overlap crash where it got a Marginal score (Good is the highest possible score). On higher trims, the Beetle can be had with rear cross-traffic alert and blind-spot warning.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/beetle/2017/2017-volkswagen-beetle-dune-convertible-first-test-review/">2017 First Test</a> of the Beetle Dune, we noted that it rides stiffer than expected and doesn’t stay as composed as other Beetles over poor surfaces. On the road, the Beetle Dune isn’t very sporty due to its vague steering. There’s also plenty of road noise on the convertible variant regardless of whether you have the roof up or down. Design inside and out gives the Dune more character, and its multimedia controls are easy to use.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 Beetle is one of the first cars to utilize the newest version of <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volkswagen/">Volkswagen</a>’s 2.0-liter turbo-four.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The T8 plug-in hybrid eAWD model is now available, and the base T5 trim can now be had with all-wheel drive (AWD). Starting with the 2018 model year, <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/">Volvo</a> adds 4.5 inches to the wheelbase on all models, and the T5 AWD and T6 AWD models now come standard with a panoramic moonroof, blind-spot warning with rear-cross traffic alert, Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, and retractable sideview mirrors. The Inscription model adds a tailored dashboard and upper door panels, power-operated sun curtains for the rear and rear side windows, and optional 20-inch eight-spoke silver alloy wheels.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The S90 is Volvo’s flagship sedan positioned ablvd the S60 sedan. With the exception of the V90, the S90 has the highest starting price of the brand’s entire lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The base T5 model comes standard with a 250-hp, 258-ft-lb 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 engine that delivers an EPA-rated 24/34 mpg city/highway with front-wheel drive and 23/32 mpg with AWD. The T6 comes standard with AWD and sports a 2.0-liter turbocharged and supercharged I-4 that cracks out 316 hp and 295 ft-lb of torque and comes rated at 22/31 mpg. The range-topping T8 plug-in hybrid model (AWD) packs the above engine paired to an electric motor for a total system output of 400 hp and 472 lb-ft of torque and delivers 26/33 mpg and can drive up to 21 miles on all-electric energy. In<em> Motor Trend </em>testing, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/s90/2017/">2017 Volvo S90</a> T6 hit 60 mph in a quick 5.6 seconds.</p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/s90/2018/">Volvo S90</a> comes standard with a leather-wrapped steering wheel and gear shift knob, leather upholstery, 10-way power front driver’s seat, a 9.0-inch center display, an 8.0-inch digital driver’s display, a panoramic moonroof, 18-inch wheels, and LED headlights with Thor’s Hammer daytime running lights. For additional features, opt for the Convenience package to receive heated washer nozzles, a 360-degree view camera system, Park Assist Pilot, and a power-operated trunk lid. The Luxury package will add a Nubuck headliner, ventilated and heated rear seats, front massaging seats, and a deluxe rear sear center armrest.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The Volvo S90 is considered an IIHS 2017 Top Safety Pick because the sedan received the highest rating of Good in all five crash tests and the highest rating of Superior for front crash prevention for properly warning a driver of a possible collision and avoiding both a 12 mph and 25 mph frontal collision thanks to the standard City Safety automatic emergency braking system. The 2018 S90 also comes standard with many driver assist safety features including rear parking sensors, Pilot Assist (semi-autonomous drive system) with adaptive cruise control, lane keep assist, blind-spot warning with rear-cross traffic alert, road sign information, front emergency braking, after collision automatic braking, driver alert control (drowdy driver assist), and a rear collision alert system.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/s90/2017/2017-volvo-s90-t5-first-test-review-e300-530i-alternative/">First Drive review</a> of the 2017 Volvo S90 T5, we said the car isn’t sporty and has a fussy infotainment system, but “if you’ve ever ventured beyond a <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes-Benz</a> or <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/bmw/">BMW</a> dealership for a midsize luxury car, the Volvo S90 should interest you. The car is different yet still premium, and it is a value compared to top-tier luxury brands as a base model or loaded car. Despite its faults, the S90 is worth consideration whether you don’t mind the lack of a three-pointed star or blue-and-white badge on the hood or if that’s the very reason Volvo is on your list at all.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/s90/2017/volvo-s90-t6-cadillac-ct6-20t-mercedes-benz-e300-luxury-sedan-comparison/">three-way, turbocharged 2.0-liter premium sedan comparison</a>, the Volvo S90 T6 was the winner, topping both the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/ct6/2018/">Cadillac CT6</a> 2.0T and the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/mercedes-benz/">Mercedes</a>-Benz E300 Sport. We said, “The price further elevates the Volvo’s standing in this comparison, as this nearly loaded S90 undercuts the Mercedes and <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/cadillac/">Cadillac</a> by three to four grand. For its few faults, the Volvo S90 is the Goldilocks of the three: It’s not the outright sportiest, nor is it the roomiest, but its properly luxurious, the best to drive, and the best at driving itself. The Volvo S90, quite simply, is 2.0-liter luxury done right.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Volvo S90 utilizes a multi-link rear suspension with a transverse leaf-spring, a very uncommon type of suspension set-up, especially for premium sedans.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Minor updates for the new model year include an available power adjustable passenger seat for the base V60 (the feature is already standard on other trims), as well as heated front seats and a heated steering wheel.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The V60 is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/">Volvo</a>’s entry-level wagon that shares the same platform as the S60 sedan and slots below the larger and more expensive V90 wagon. Expect a redesigned V60 wagon in the next couple years.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/v60/2018/">2018 Volvo V60</a> T5 base model is powered by a 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 that produces 250 hp and 258 lb-ft of torque and comes with an EPA rating of 25/36 mpg city/highway with front-wheel drive and 22/33 mpg with all-wheel drive (AWD). The <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/v60-cross-country/2017/2017-volvo-v60-cross-country-t5-awd-first-drive-review/"><strong>Cross Country model</strong></a> (a raised model with 7.9 inches of ground clearance) comes standard with AWD and exclusively uses that T5 engine to deliver 22/30 mpg.</p>

<p>If you stick with the more traditional non-Cross-Country model, upgrading to the T6 will result in AWD and the more powerful 2.0-liter supercharged and turbocharged I-4 that churns out 302 hp and 295 lb-ft of torque and comes rated at 22/32 mpg. The high-performance <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/v60/2017/2017-volvo-v60-polestar-first-test-review/">Polestar model</a> packs the same engine but tuned to produce 362 hp and 347 lb-ft of torque and with 20/27 mpg ratings. In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 V60 Polestar hit 60 mph in a quick 4.8 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in an impressive 105 feet.</p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/v60/2018/">Volvo V60</a> comes standard with HID headlights with LED daytime running lights, leather upholstery, eight-way power adjustable driver’s seat, leather-wrapped steering wheel, illuminated gearshift knob, interior aluminum trim, glass moonroof, an R-design grille, 18-inch diamond-cut wheels, and Sensus Connect. For additional luxury opt for the Navigation/Audio package that includes Sensus Navigation and a Harman Kardon premium audio system or the Sport package that consists of a sport-tuned chassis, power steering personalization, paddle shifters, and 19-inch black alloy wheels. The V60 Polestar comes standard with Polestar exterior and interior trim and badging, six-piston Brembo brakes, Ohlins shock absorbers, 20-inch Polestar exclusive wheels with performance summer tires, carbon fiber rear view mirror covers, and a carbon fiber front splitter.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The Volvo V60 is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick+, the IIHS’ highest designation, for receiving the highest score of Good in all five crash tests and the highest rating of Superior for front crash prevention for properly warning the driver of a possible collision, avoiding a 12 mph collision, and reducing the speed of a 25 mph collision by 16 mph thanks to the optional Collision Warning with Full Auto Brake and Pedestrian Detection found in the Technology package. When equipped with the standard City Safety feature, the wagon received the rating of Advanced for avoiding a 12 mph collision and reducing the speed of a 25 mph collision by 2 mph, but did not warn the driver. Additional safety features found in the Technology package are adaptive cruise control, active high beams, lane keep assist, Driver Alert Control (sleepy driver alert), Distance Alert, and road sign information. Blind Spot Information System, rear cross-traffic alert, and a rear view camera with rear parking sensors are found in the Vision package. Active bending lights are standard.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/v60/2017/2017-volvo-v60-polestar-first-test-review/">First Test review</a> of the 2017 Volvo V60 Polestar, we liked the wagon’s immediate and quick acceleration and the snarly engine note. Handling prowess has improved over the outgoing inline-six engine model and the new eight-speed transmission is eager to downshift but the wagon still likes to understeer as it did before. The ride is good considering the stiffer suspension and the seats are very comfortable but the infotainment system is outdated. “That said, it doesn’t get more special than the Volvo V60 Polestar, especially in our tester’s eye-catching Rebel Blue Metallic paint. And with the next-generation V60 just around the corner, we’re hopeful Volvo will continue to supply us with our fix of fast and fun wagons.”</p>

<p>After <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/v60/2015/2015-volvo-v60-t5-drive-e-long-term-verdict-review/">one year with our long-term 2015 V60 T5</a>, we had few complaints that included an annoying auto start/stop feature and hard sport seats and said, “Although I may not be Volvo’s quintessential customer—I have no kids or pets—the Volvo V60 T5 Drive-E quickly became one of my favorite vehicles I’ve had the pleasure of driving in the past few years. The combination of performance, styling, comfort, and safety make this sweet wagon one I would consider purchasing with my own money if I had the $45,625 to spare. We’re sad to see it go, and look forward to the next chance to drive such a fun sporty wagon.”</p>

<p>Many of Volvo’s competitors have dropped out of the wagon segment, and that gives the V60 an advantage. In sedan form, the S60 felt dated and placed last in <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/giulia/2017/alfa-romeo-giulia-bmw-330i-audi-a4-mercedes-benz-c300-cadillac-ats-jaguar-xe-lexus-is-200t-volvo-s60-comparison/#399-lease-deal-special-front-end-in-motion">a 2017 large test of compact luxury sport sedans</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The Polestar model utilizes MacPherson strut suspension front and rear, versus the standard V60’s more traditional multi-link set-up.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>The V90 Cross Country is now available in the base T5 trim along with a Plus package. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/">Volvo</a> also added a new Denim Blue exterior color and a Maroon Brown interior color.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The V90 is Volvo’s flagship wagon that is also available in the raised all-wheel drive Cross Country model. Positioned above the smaller V60 wagon, the V90 has a higher starting price than the S90 and XC90.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>A 250-hp, 258-lb-ft of torque 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 powers the base T5 model, including the front-wheel drive regular wagon (EPA-rated 24/34 mpg city/highway) and the Cross Country version (23/31 mpg). The T6 models are powered by a 2.0-liter supercharged and turbocharged I-4 that produces 316 hp and 295 lb-ft of torque and delivers 22/31 mpg in the regular V90 wagon (standard AWD for the T6) and 22/29 mpg in the Cross country. Volvo claims that the V90 T5 can hit 60 mph in 6.7 seconds while the T6 can do it in 5.8 seconds.</p>

<p>The V90 comes standard with many features including an R-design grille, 19-inch Matte Black diamond cut wheels, a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, a panoramic moonroof, LED headlights and fog lights, Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, interior ambient lighting, 10-way power driver’s seat, front sport seats, a Charcoal headliner, an R-Design leather steering wheel and gearshift knob, illuminated door sills, a drive mode selector, a 9.0-inch center display with Sensus Connect and Sensus navigation, and a sport-tuned suspension. For additional features, opt for the Convenience package and receive a 360-degree surround view camera system, Park Assist Pilot (self-parking system), grocery bag holder, Homelink, rear view mirror compass, and heated washer nozzles. The Heated Seats/Heated Steering Wheel package includes exactly that. The Luxury package consists of power-adjustable front seats (including side bolsters and cushion extension), fully color-coordinated door sills and bumpers, massaging front seats, perforated Nappa leather, power cargo cover, four-zone climate control with glove box cooling, heated rear seats, rear side sun curtains, and tailored dashboard and upper door panels.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/v90/2018/">Volvo V90</a> has yet to be crash tested but the IIHS did evaluate the S90 (the sedan on which the V90 is based) and the sedan is considered a 2017 Top Safety Pick for receiving the highest rating of Good in all five crash tests and the highest rating of Superior for the front crash prevention evaluation thanks to the standard City Safety system that is also standard in the V90. The City Safety crash mitigation system properly warned the driver of a possible collision and avoided a collision in 12 and 25 mph tests. The V90 comes standard with many driver assist safety features including Blind Spot Information System with Cross Traffic Alert, lane keep assist, Pilot Assist semi-autonomous drive system with adaptive cruise control, road sign information, rear parking sensors, emergency brake assist, and Collision Mitigation Support, a feature that will steer the vehicle away from an oncoming collision.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/v90/2017/2017-volvo-v90-cross-country-t6-awd-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/v90/2017/">2017 Volvo V90</a> Cross Country, we liked how the optional air suspension soaked up rough road conditions and the four drive modes. We also enjoyed how the Pilot Assist semi-autonomous system works and the Sensus infotainment system.</p>

<p>We loved the interior of the Volvo V90 wagon in our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/v90/2018/2018-volvo-v90-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> and said, “The interior is spectacular, an unmistakably Swedish take on luxury without the smorgasbord of clichés. With the rear seats upright, the V90 will swallow 19.8 cubic feet of stuff; with the seats folded flat, capacity balloons to 53.9 cubic feet.”</p>

<p>“There’s plenty of precision and grip through the turns,” we said, “so it can be hustled along a winding two-lane deceptively quickly. But this big Volvo is not trying to be a sports car; its transient responses are deliberate, measured. The V90 is a roomy, comfortable, practical, enjoyable wagon. It’s Volvo doing what Volvo has long done best, just more stylishly and luxuriously so.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>When compared to the V90 wagon, Volvo made over 200 tweaks to the Cross Country’s chassis in order to properly handle off-road excursions.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Now riding on the modular SPA platform, the redesigned <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/xc60/2018/">2018 Volvo XC60</a> gains a new suspension setup, new engines, an available plug-in hybrid variant, and a new exterior design featuring <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/">Volvo</a>’s signature T-shaped LED accents.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/xc60/2018/">Volvo XC60</a> is a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/xc60/2018/2018-volvo-xc60-first-look-review/">compact luxury crossover</a> that slots below the larger XC90 and can seat up to five passengers. Front-wheel drive will likely be standard on the base XC60 T5 while all-wheel drive should be available on all variants.</p>

<p><strong>Overview</strong></p>

<p>The 2018 XC60 will be offered in three powertrain options including a 2.0-liter turbo-four in the T5, a 2.0-liter super- and turbocharged I-4 in the T6, and a 400-hp plug-in hybrid that couples the T6’s engine to an electric motor. Expect the base 2.0-liter turbo-four to be rated around 250 hp and 258 lb-ft of torque, with the super- and turbocharged 2.0-liter I-4 checking in at 316 hp and 295 lb-ft. An eight-speed automatic transmission should be the only gearbox available across the entire lineup. Volvo also says that the lighter and smaller XC60 plug-in hybrid should be able to travel more miles in EV mode compared to the heavier XC90.</p>

<p>Available features include a large digital multi-information display replacing traditional gauges, leather upholstery, a Bowers &amp; Wilkins premium audio system, LED headlights, Volvo’s Sensus infotainment system with a portrait-style 9-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth connectivity, navigation, and a panoramic sunroof.</p>

<p><strong>Safety</strong></p>

<p>The NHTSA and IIHS haven’t crash tested the 2018 Volvo XC60. A full suite of active safety and driver assistance features will be available, including adaptive cruise control, pedestrian and cyclist detection, large animal detection, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, lane keeping assist, lane departure warning, and Pilot Assist, Volvo’s semi-autonomous driving assistance system that takes control of steering, braking and lane changing at speeds of up to 80 mph on roads that are well-marked. New safety features include Oncoming Lane Mitigation, which is designed to prevent head-on collisions.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>Although we haven’t driven the 2018 XC60 yet, we have high hopes, considering the XC90 was <a href="//www.motortrend.com/news/2016-volvo-xc90-is-the-motor-trend-suv-of-the-year/">our 2016 <em>Motor Trend</em> SUV of the Year</a>.</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>The T-shaped LED accents in the 2018 XC60’s headlights are inspired by Thor’s hammer.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors</strong></p>

<p>The XC90 gains more standard features for the 2018 model year including the Pilot Assist semi-autonomous drive system with adaptive cruise control, blind-spot warning with rear cross-traffic alert, auto-dimming interior and exterior mirrors, retractable side view mirrors, as well as Apple CarPlay and Android Auto smartphone integration. <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/">Volvo</a> added heated front seats and a heated steering wheel as individual options, and new wheel designs include a 21-inch V-Spoke Black diamond cut design. Maple Brown, Denim Blue, and Pine Grey are new exterior colors and Maroon Brown is a new interior color.</p>

<p>The XC90 is Volvo’s largest crossover, positioned above the compact XC40 and XC60 crossovers.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/xc90/2018/">2018 Volvo XC90</a> Momentum</strong>: The XC90’s base trim includes a suite of driver assist safety features, an 8.0-inch instrument cluster display, a 9.0-inch center display touchscreen with navigation, auto-dimming interior and exterior mirrors, leather-wrapped steering wheel and gearshift knob, four-zone climate control, 10-way power front seats with power lumbar and memory, power-folding rear headrests, leather upholstery, interior aluminum accents, USB hub with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, silver roof rails, LED headlights with Thor’s Hammer daytime running lights, panoramic moonroof, 18-inch alloy wheels, power liftgate, and drive mode settings.</p>

<p><strong>2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/xc90/2018/">Volvo XC90</a> R-Design</strong>: Opt for the R-Design and Volvo adds automatic bending LED lights with active high beam, color-coordinated illuminated door handles with puddle lights, a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, higher-level interior illumination, front seat power cushion extender, R-Design three-spoke steering wheel, R-Design perforated gearshift knob, R-Design pedals, sport seat padding, Charcoal Nubuck and Nappa leather in a Charcoal-colored interior, metal mesh aluminum interior accents, R-Design grille, 20-inch five-spoke diamond-cut alloy wheels, and paddle shifters.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Volvo XC90 Inscription</strong>: The Inscription model adds heated front and perforated Nappa leather front seats, linear walnut wood interior accents, rear-side window sunblinds, power-adjustable seat bolsters, aluminum roof rails, Inscription grille, Inscription color-coordinated door sills and bumpers, 20-inch 10-spoke diamond-cut alloy wheels and all-wheel drive.</p>

<p><strong>2018 Volvo XC90 Excellence</strong>: The range-topping Excellence adds a Homelink remote garage door opener, Park Assist self-parking system, front and rear parking sensors, a Bowers &amp; Wilkins premium sound system with subwoofer, crystal gearshift knob by Orrefors, heated steering wheel, a Nubuck headliner, ventilated front and rear seats with massaging function, a tailored instrument panel, a head-up display, beverage cooler, chrome door molding with Excellence logo, 21-inch eight-spoke diamond-cut alloy wheels, four-corner air suspension, Four-C active chassis, and a plug-in hybrid powertrain (rear axle-mounted electric motor).</p>

<p>Additional options include a rear media system with dual 7.0-inch display screens and DVD player, a trailer hitch, and various roof carriers and roof storage boxes.</p>

<p>Powering the base 2018 Volvo XC90 T5 is a 250-hp, 258-lb-ft of torque 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 that delivers an EPA-rated 22/29 mpg city/highway with front-wheel drive and 22/28 mpg with all-wheel drive. The T6 model is powered by a 316-hp, 295-lb-ft of torque 2.0-liter supercharged and turbocharged I-4 engine and comes with standard AWD, delivering20/27 mpg. The range-topping T8 plug-in model uses the 316-hp turbo-four engine paired to an electric motor for a total system output of 400 hp and 472 lb-ft, and is rated at 26/30 mpg when in hybrid mode. The XC90 T8 can travel up to 19 miles on all-electric power. All engines route power through an eight-speed automatic transmission.</p>

<p>In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the 2017 XC90 T8 hit 60 mph in a quick 5.0 seconds and stopped from 60 mph in a respectable 115 feet.</p>

<p>The 2018 Volvo XC90 received the highest overall rating of five stars from the NHTSA, and the 2017 model is considered an IIHS 2017 Top Safety Pick for receiving the highest rating of Good in all five crash tests and the highest rating of Superior for front crash prevention for properly warning the driver of a possible collision and for avoiding collisions in 12- and 25-mph tests thanks to the standard City Safety emergency automatic braking safety feature. Additional standard safety features include lane keeping assist, Collision Mitigation (steers out of oncoming traffic), road sign information, front and rear parking sensors, Park Assist self-parking system, and the previously mentioned blind-spot warning system with rear cross traffic alert and Pilot Assist semi-autonomous drive with adaptive cruise control.</p>

<p>The XC90 offers 15.8 cubic feet of cargo space behind the third row, equaling that of the popular three-row <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/acura/mdx/2018/">Acura MDX</a>. However, the Volvo’s total cargo capacity of 85.7 cubic feet is just shy of the MDX’s total capacity. Front- and second-row legroom is 40.9 and 37 inches respectively. The third-row is tighter, offering 31.9 inches of legroom.</p>

<p>The 2018 XC90 comes standard with lots of technology including the 9.0-inch portrait style center touchscreen with navigation, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto connectivity, and an 8.0-inch instrument cluster display featuring a large central gauge, navigation directions, telephone calls, road signs, and more. The standard Volvo On Call app gives you access to your dashboard, can remote start your engine, calls emergency services in case of an accident, and can contact an operator for GPS and roadside assistance. Also standard is the Pilot Assist semi-autonomous drive system that assists the driver in traffic by automatically maintaining a set distance to the vehicle in front and keeping the XC90 in the center of the lane. The upgraded digital instrument cluster display is a large 12.3 inches and features two large gauges and plenty of information for the driver. The available audio system is a 19-speaker, 1400-Watt Bowers &amp; Wilkins premium audio system featuring Kevlar speaker cone technology and stainless steel mesh speaker grilles.</p>

<p>In our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/xc90/2016/2016-volvo-xc90-first-drive/">First Drive review</a> of the 2016 Volvo XC90, aside from vague steering feel and strange braking feel on the XC90 T8 hybrid, we liked the crossover and said: “This new 2016 Volvo XC90 really is a worthy successor to the name. Like the original, it advances the brand’s design markedly, it introduces all-new technology to the industry, it drives and performs well, and it comes at just the right time for the brand. It’s not wildly charismatic like some sporty crossovers and SUVs but rather like an old friend that’s always there for you, even before you know you need them.”</p>

<p>In our <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/xc90/2016/2016-volvo-xc90-t6-inscription-first-test/">First Test review</a> of the 2016 Volvo XC90, we liked the interior and exterior styling of the crossover, the high quality and luxurious interior, and the long list of safety features. The twin-charged engine provides brisk acceleration and the optional air suspension is very comfortable and offers six modes. “The 2016 Volvo XC90 T6 Inscription performs as well as its direct competitors, earns better fuel economy, and still comes to the table at or below their prices (base and loaded).”</p>

<p>The Volvo XC90 was the 2016 Motor Trend SUV of the Year.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>New for 2018</strong></p>

<p>Minor changes for the new model year include the addition of optional heated front seats and steering wheel and an available power front seat. Expect a redesigned S60 for the 2019 or 2020 model year.</p>

<p><strong>Vehicle Summary </strong></p>

<p>The S60 is <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/">Volvo</a>’s entry-level vehicle, the smallest and most affordable sedan in the automaker’s lineup.</p>

<p><strong>Overview </strong></p>

<p>The <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/s60/2018/">2018 Volvo S60</a> sedan comes standard with a 240-hp, 258-lb-ft of torque 2.0-liter turbocharged I-4 engine (T5) that routes power to the front wheels (EPA-rated 25/36 mpg city/highway) or to an all-wheel drive (AWD) system (22/33 mpg). The <strong>raised Cross Country model</strong> utilizes the same engine with AWD as standard and delivers 22/30 mpg. The available 2.0-liter supercharged and turbocharged I-4 power plant (T6) produces 302 hp and 295 lb-ft of torque and is only paired to an AWD system delivering 22/32 mpg. The <strong>range-topping Polestar model</strong> is only available with AWD and is rated at 20/27 mpg. In Motor Trend testing, the 2017 S60 T6 AWD (Platinum) hit 60 mph in a quick 5.2 seconds and broke from 60 mph in an impressive 111 feet.</p>

<p>The base 2018 <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/s60/2018/">Volvo S60</a> T5 Dynamic comes standard with LED daytime running lights, leather upholstery, leather wrapped steering wheel, interior ambient lighting, eight-way power driver’s seat, milled aluminum interior trim, remote engine start, 18-inch Tucan Diamond Cut wheels, and a powered glass moonroof. Available features include an R-Design steering wheel and gearshift knob, sport pedals, a 12-speaker Harman Kardon premium audio system, powered front passenger seat, digital instrument cluster, Sensus Connect with navigation, 19-inch Ixion alloy wheels, and a sport-tuned chassis. The rang-topping, high-performance S60 Polestar comes standard with exclusive 20-inch Polestar wheels with performance summer tires, Brembo six-piston front brakes, Polestar Ohlins shocks, a Polestar carbon fiber front splitter, Polestar carbon fiber rearview mirror covers, Polestar rear spoiler, Polestar sport leather upholstery, heated front and rear seats, and a Polestar grille and badging.</p>

<p><strong>Safety </strong></p>

<p>The 2018 S60 received a five-star overall rating from the NHTSA (the highest possible rating). The IIHS considers the S60 to be a 2017 Top Safety Pick+, the highest designation, because the Volvo received the highest rating of Good in all five crash tests and the highest rating of Superior for front crash prevention. In testing, the S60 managed to properly warn the driver of a possible collision, avoided a 12-mph collision, and reduced the impact of a 25-mph impact by 14 mph thanks to the optional Collision Warning with Full Auto Brake and Pedestrian Detection driver assist safety feature found in the Technology Package. The standard City Safety automatic braking system was issued the second highest rating of Advanced because the system was only able to reduce the impact of a 25-mph impact by 2 mph but still avoided the 12-mph collision. Active bending HID lights are also standard. Other driver assist safety features are found in the Technology package and include adaptive cruise control, active high beams, Driver Alert Control (drowsy driver alert), lane keep assist, road sign information, and distance alert (front collision alert). The Vision package adds blind spot assist, rear cross-traffic alert, and rear parking sensors.</p>

<p><strong>What We Think</strong></p>

<p>In an <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/alfa-romeo/giulia/2017/alfa-romeo-giulia-bmw-330i-audi-a4-mercedes-benz-c300-cadillac-ats-jaguar-xe-lexus-is-200t-volvo-s60-comparison/">eight-way Big Test comparison</a> of premium sedans, the Volvo S60 T6 came in last place. We commended the sedan on its high safety scores and comfortable seats but felt the S60 has become very outdated and said, “Far and away the oldest car in the test, it was outclassed at nearly every turn. Thoughtful updates have kept it on life support, but a new engine is no substitute for the comprehensive updates needed to make the S60 truly competitive, and the all-new car can’t come soon enough.” “Stylish and safe, the Volvo can’t escape its long-past sell-by date. It’s an old car in a hyper-competitive class, and it just can’t keep up anymore.”</p>

<p>In a <a href="//www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/s60/2017/2017-volvo-s60-v60-polestar-first-drive-review/">First Drive review</a> of the 2017 Volvo S60 and V60 Polestar, we said, “The updated Polestars are better than the cars they replace. That much is certain. However, please remember that they aren’t aimed squarely at the top dogs from the Big German Three.” “Compared to the S4, 340i M Sport, and C43 (previously known as the C450 AMG Sport), the S60 and V60 Polestars are quite compelling. The biggest demerit against the Swedes would be the frankly outdated navigation and entertainment system.”</p>

<p><strong>Cool Fact</strong></p>

<p>In <em>Motor Trend</em> testing, the <a href="http://www.motortrend.com/cars/volvo/v60/2017/">2017 Volvo V60</a> Polestar wagon hit 60 mph in 4.9 seconds.</p>

<p><strong>Key Competitors:</strong></p>
